Black Coffee never resorts to stale melodrama or cheap laughs, sticking true to a low key straight romance between characters that aren't locked into stereotype.

It is the style, stupid- the dialogue, the gloominess, the shadows, the doomed destiny that prevails over everything. This is right in line with these noir ideals, but tells the story with bravura and a technical prowess not available in the 1940s.
Not about the horrific murder and lacks erotic appeal. Hartnett cries a lot. De Palma kills the golden goose.
... there are some mysteries no one can solve. Including, apparently, the one that involves bringing The Black Dahlia satisfyingly to the screen.
Film noir set in Los Angeles in 1947 is way too long, poorly acted, and covered with a haze of cigarette smoke.
I can't say anything really stood out in a positive way.
It meticulously resembles a 60 year-old Hollywood artifact, but with a contemporary cynicism.
The film gets worse the longer it goes on, as Brian De Palma slowly loses confidence in his story and starts trying to compensate for it by engaging in overwrought melodramatics.
Such a shame that The Black Dahlia collapses into a gruesome pile of steaming camp in the last half hour.
The picture is a kind of fattened goose that's been stuffed with goose-liver p√¢t√©. It's overrich and fundamentally unsatisfying.
The real case of the Black Dahlia was never solved, and watching this film we understand why: the story is just way too complicated.

Despite genius-level contributions from cinematographer Vilmos Zsigmond and art director Dante Ferretti, the handsome film is almost abusively murky, trafficking in difficult-to-follow plot manipulations, arbitrary twists and mumbled dialogue.
'Character? Forget it. I'm playing me,' said Johansson. 'I'm the Burgess Meredith of T & A.'
Most Brian De Palma movies, as abhorrent as they are, have an ironic sense of purity. 'The Black Dahlia' is a jumbled mess.
Such a baroque, incoherent mess it fails to please as a period piece or a murder mystery.
With skeletons flying out of the closet at every turn, this overplotted mess unfolds more like a dumb, daytime soap opera than a well-crafted crime thriller.
In The Black Dahlia, narrative strands tangle and wither, and minor characters clutter the plot.
Words cannot possibly do justice to what a total monstrosity this film is.
It slides from pulp classic to guilty pleasure to cautionary example to full-bore train wreck.
De Palma has made a bizarre, baffling and at times flat-out bad movie. But at least it's rarely boring.
Forget it, Bucky, the film seems to say. It's De Palma-town.
This is a lean and mean variation on a familiar theme, tense throughout, with some terrific performances.
Engaging, gripping and tightly constructed thriller with a sharp script, effective action sequences and strong performances from all three leads.

... a feminist reworking of 'Most Dangerous Game' and 'Deliverance,' with the friends soon stripped down and armed, like a tribe of Amazonian huntresses ... has the visceral appeal of early Kathryn Bigelow.
This isn't quite the distaff Deliverance promised, but it's a credible indie thriller with characters worth caring about.

The kind of endeavor that can run on spirit alone, if you let it, and although it won't ever become a staple of the genre, it does well by it, providing a far more enjoyable getaway than the ladies on the screen experience.
"Black Rock" is as dingy and dirty as the genre thrillers it appears to want to one-up. All it does, though, is bring everyone down.
Slender, but committed: even Kate Bosworth, as the girls' team leader, forswears her usual lipgloss.
It feels amateurish, as though it was made up as they went along. The violence - because that's what most of the action consists of - feels phony.
Efficient thriller that's practically a feature-length evocation of Thomas Hobbes' notion of life in nature: "nasty, brutish and short."
This indie, female-centric riff on "Deliverance" is spare, smartly written and shot through with moments of twig-snapping tension.
Genre pieces can be straightforward but shouldn't confuse shallowness with efficiency.
A formulaic dirge, further let down by a lack of the shocks, scares and interesting characterisations.
Black Rock makes subtle changes that distinguish it as a marginally more thoughtful stalking killer movie, but horror fans will find its twists and turns too familiar to leave a lasting impression.
Maybe it's a parody?
despite the occasional mismatch between the human drama and more genre-bound concerns, for the most part Black Rock is a tense, atmospheric and engaging affair, with an existential edge.
'Black Rock' is never dull, but it's hardly the attention-grabbing calling card its creator presumably intended.
Black Rock is well-acted, and contains a couple of memorable scenes, but for the most part this is a blah buddy dramedy that transforms into a blah chase thriller.
It works because Aselton and Bell turn in wildly physical, primal performances. You do not want to mess with these women. "Black Rock" is ferocious stuff.
A nice, taut thriller, full of tension and atmosphere. A well-paced survival tale, it mostly knows when to speed up and slow down.
The concept is there, but a movie like this needs a much more polished execution that "Black Rock" gets.
Enter this in any student horror film festival, and Black Sheep wins hooves down.
The lush hills of New Zealand provide an ironic backdrop for this witty little horror show about a farm where genetically altered sheep have been turned into devilish zombies.
The human characters in Black Sheep are nothing more than tired stereotypes... But the sheep are fabulous!
A one-joke skit that trots in a straight line, and your enjoyment of it will depend entirely on how many times you need to see gonzo sheep rip out human entrails.
This lurid lunacy from New Zealand is a horror-humor cross-breed of animal lore and giddy gore.
Maybe it's not exactly what Romero had in mind, but for pure insanity, Black Sheep does its job and it does it well.
If you have the bad taste for this sort of thing, it's rarely done better, even by Peter Jackson.
[A] refreshingly fun and over-the-top take on the sickeningly overdone zombie genre.
Wool growers of the undead!
Takes a ludicrous concept and plays it as totally straight-up horror, which makes it even funnier than it might have been if it were presented as a joke in the first place.
...Black Sheep never rises above sensation and splatter, or goes beyond the one thing it does best: It bites.
Jonathan King's film is an intentionally moronic mash-up of horror clich√©s bound to delight all fans of grade-Z entertainment.

A really solid horror comedy: beautifully shot, decently acted, fast moving and creative with the disembowelments. And it manages the weird feat of making a flock of sheep bounding across a meadow seem vaguely menacing.

Slickly made but not deeply felt, and while [director] King shows signs that he may one day make a film as rich as Peter Jackson at his peak, next time he should try to get the audience to care equally about the eaters and the eaten.
A giddily subversive addition to the age-old cinema tradition of the horror comedy.
It's about time that New Zealanders got their share of some ribbing.
Killer sheep. Really, is there much more that needs to be said?
If there was a list of movies about killer mutated sheep, this would undoubtedly be the best of the bunch.
The most gruesomely satisfying spectacle for hard-core environmentalists would be that of a group of foreign investors in the evil enterprise being gobbled up by a flock of rampaging sheep.
The film is fabulous, perfectly capturing the sense of silly horror while bloodying the meadows of NZ with gore.
Another stupid Disney live-action piece of inane cliches and situations.
Undeniably silly and somewhat dated, Blackbeard‚Äôs Ghost remains harmless, modestly entertaining family fare.
The plot is completely confused, and kids, who are much better at these things than adults, will enjoy its twists and turns. Ustinov is fine as the rum swilling, yo-ho-hoing Blackbeard.
Ustinov e Jones fazem uma tima dupla cmica em um filme que, de forma inocente (at mesmo bobinha), conquista pela despretenso.
Middling Disney a la Dean Jones and Peter Ustinov; OK family fare.
A yo-ho-wholesome retread of Disney favorites.
[Peter Ustinov 's] very funny in the role of Blackbeard.
Fraser is full of charm and good-natured innocence, and he and Silverstone spark well together.
Blast From the Past is no message movie, but it has a few good points to make, and does so with a gentle, observant wit.
Blast From the Past serves up the kind of frothy fun that recalls the spirit of the classic screwball comedy -- and that, my friends, is a good thing.
The 40-minute setup is deliciously nutty, with eccentric turns from Walken and Spacek. But the longer Adam remains above ground, the more plodding and predictable the scenario becomes.
Once it's in the second act, the groans catch up to the laughs and ultimately that race is a photo finish.
Fraser and Silverstone also have a sweet, unforced romantic rapport, but it's not enough to overcome the thudding weight of the premise.
Unfortunately Mr. Fraser comes off as a forlorn, outsize Pee Wee Herman.
While this comedy strives for teen-age appeal above ground, it's mostly the fallout shelter notion that makes for the laughs.
Pleasantville seemed to say that such squeaky clean living is unnatural and unsustainable. Blast probably aims lower than its counterpart, but it came closer to its mark.

Garish and not funny enough, Wilson's shapeless satire plods on, squandering its nice premise and its appealing actors. Miraculously, Fraser has a force field around him and manages to radiate energy in this comic black hole.
Blast From the Past saves its best for first.
Quite a stylish, sophisticated and sweetly satirical comedy

Thanks to a clever script, tight direction, a first-rate cast and the dynamite combination of Brendan Fraser and Alicia Silverstone, Blast from the Past blows away the recent crop of romantic comedies.
Frothy fun.
It's pleasant enough, with Fraser's goofy charm particularly winning.
Blast from the Past is actually better executed than it was written.
...entertains without pretensions.
Blast from the Past is a sweet-natured comedy that is worth seeing.
Although the material is lightweight, it is a cute, amusing film.
The movie takes a few small belly-flops now and then but is quite enjoyable.
... bogged down by its deliberate pace, reliance on Catholic symbolism, and its one-dimensional characters.
Bless Me, Ultima creates a wholly original coming of age story by blending mysticism with conventional Catholicism.
Meticulous recreation of a time and place, but this poetic novel becomes all-too-prosaic on the screen.
An offbeat slice of Americana will intrigue thoughtful moviegoers.
Although Bless Me, Ultima can feel a bit overstuffed, it's an honest and naturalistic kids' story about growing up Mexican-American.
A deeply satisfying feat of storytelling, "Bless Me, Ultima" makes a difficult task look easy.
The film's interest in social themes remains background fodder within a far more generic good-versus-evil narrative.
a profound story told in a deceptively simple way. Deceptive, but curiously suitable for a film about identity, belief, and the nature both good and evil in all their guises.
Theater firebrand and big-screen presence Miriam Colon portrays Ultima with a minimum of fuss and a gorgeous supply of elder authority.
Its very existence in a godforsaken marketplace is a minor miracle.
A thoughtful, sentimental fable.

Nearly as sacred as the Good Book itself in some circles, Rudolfo Anaya's Bless Me, Ultima has survived the leap to the bigscreen with much of its magic intact, thanks to a respectful if somewhat wooden adaptation by writer-director Carl Franklin.
Here's a coming-of-age movie that feels both generic and personal.
[Director Carl] Franklin is sensitive to the way boys interact, bump chests, bicker, and bond-just as he is to how adults justify their hypocrisy and excuse their failures.
It wants to be something grand, but its ambition far exceeds its reach.
Based on the novel of the same name by Rudolfo Anaya, "Bless Me, Ultima" is a magical compilation of family, life, death, religion and the meaning of it all.
The film won't disappoint fans of the book, although they may regret some of the adaptation's necessary condensation and/or elimination of narrative themes and events.

The material calls out for a more expressive cinematographic treatment. Had the film been less antiseptic and more bold in its visuals and the emotional depths of its performances, it could have been a classic; instead, it's a rather ordinary indie.
A mostly gentle and tastefully photographed depiction of a young boy's coming of age in rural 1940s New Mexico.
"Bless Me, Ultima" is a beautifully photographed film, but it has a lot of problems...sketchy character development, but the bigger issue is the film's disjointed flow.
An anger-inducing social commentary and likeable lead can't save the awkwardness and tedium of this little musical number.

Instead of using music to help digest its potentially interesting mix of humour and contemporaneously resonant commentary, Blinded By The Light goes the more saccharine sing-along route that feels emptier and trite.
A jubilant story that's told with grounded honesty.
It'll remind you of the importance of chasing dreams and loving yourself as well as others.
Chadha misses the worrying rise in those years of the Nazi National Front, and the musical moments often seem a bit pedestrian. [Full Review in Spanish]
Nevertheless, the message that Blinded by the Light conveys is highly positive, even more so in the insecure and dark times we are living today. [Full Review in Spanish]
Blinded by the Light is the exuberant movie that Yesterday should have been.
Unabashedly cheesy and a charming coming-of-age tale featuring a breakthrough performance by its lead, Blinded by the Light sticks to convention, while at the same time, being entirely authentic.
However familiar they may be, it's in these clashes, when everyone stops fixating on Springsteen, that the film feels most visceral and authentic.
Blinded by the Light at its very best, captures the experience of being a fan, the pure exhilaration of it, and the sense of your vision opening out to vistas beyond your horizon.
"Light" has too many characters and too many subplots to sustain its throughline momentum, making for an intermittently entertaining but ultimately tedious experience.
[Kalra] is as authentic and earnest a movie teen as ever populated a John Hughes movie, and he makes us feel the yearning he channels in every Springsteen song.
Perhaps if Yesterday had not preceded the release of Blinded by the Light, my expectations wouldn't have been so high, but this film truly disappoints.
The direction by Gurinder Chadha finds a perfect balance between optimism and sensibility.
Overall, I think that Blinded by the Light is going to hit home for so many of us, even being set in the late '80s, and it truly shows the power of music and how it can uplift us.
As in "Bend it Like Beckham," Chadha's gift for kinetic storytelling reflects the turbulent emotion of the young protagonists.
(Gurinder) Chadha's film is almost impossible to dislike.
The best film of 2019, "Blinded by the Light" knows exactly what it's like, internally and externally, to discover Springsteen; how the music makes one feel. It's brilliant.
Blinded by the Light is an incredibly raw and powerful picture with an inspiring story, outstanding performances, and deeply emotional moments.
Kalra is terrific in his role as the introverted, misunderstood son who blossoms under his newfound voice in the form of Springsteen's lyrics.
A startlingly immediate re-creation of the January 1972 Derry massacre.
Greengrass gives the film a brawling, bruising intimacy that makes the graphic finale hard to watch.
it's certainly worth riding the rough whirlwind digital camera for insights that U2 can only hint at.
It's an extraordinary adrenaline-pumping immersion into historical events, and goes along way to explain the bitterness that has resounded from that day.
You're not merely watching history, you're engulfed by it.
Leaves you dazed and shaken, as if you, too, had been caught in the swirl of events that led to unspeakable sadness and a lot more bloodshed.
[An] outstanding dramatization of real-life emergencies, with a nerve-jangling, documentary-type immediacy.
What's most striking about Greengrass' film is just how real it all feels.
A great achievement: tense and passionate, a film that one feels not just emotionally but also physically.
An astonishing re-creation of the Londonderry massacre of January 1972.
what remains is as clear an explanation as any of how a tinderbox sometimes erupts into conflagration with nothing so much as a strike.

Watching the day's events of Bloody Sunday unfold in edgy, as-it's-happening documentary style, the stomach knots up, the heart sinks and the grief surfaces long before any bullets fly into the backs of fleeing, unarmed Catholic slum dwellers.
Few films have captured the chaos of an urban conflagration with such fury, and audience members will leave feeling as shaken as Nesbitt's Cooper looks when the bullets stop flying.
Both an admirable reconstruction of terrible events, and a fitting memorial to the dead of that day, and of the thousands thereafter.
A dreadful day in Irish history is given passionate, if somewhat flawed, treatment.
The film could have been one of the year's finest, if only it was more accessible.
...the makers keep it tight and interesting from beginning to end and keep the gut-clenching suspense going right through to the finale that sums up the repercussions of "Bloody Sunday."
Assumes familiarity with the background of the 'troubles' and proceeds viscerally to portray the British as murderers of Irish demonstrators in 1972.
Captures the horrors of a civil rights march taking a wrong turn in the Northern Ireland city of Londonderry on Sunday, January 30, 1972.
a gut-wrenching account of that day and all days where humans bring tragedy upon their own race

The dialogue is meaningful and realistic. The first-rate cinematography and an explosive soundtrack make an indelible impression. This sad and very personal movie will generate lots of discussions. Marriage counselors and divorce lawyers should get a...
Pulls no punches in terms of its heavy subject matter and boasts wonderful performances from stars Ryan Gosling and Michelle Williams
Though difficult and never exactly enjoyable, Cianfrance's compelling and superbly acted film is still a rewarding and thought-provoking experience.
It's at its root a hard-to-resist character study. That's because the character being studied is you and me and everyone else who has ever fallen in, and out of, love
Blue Valentine does the impossible, and captures the uncapturable: to watch this film is to watch two people fall in, and eventually out of, love. Few films have ever done it so well.
As adult relationship dramas go [...] you've not seen something as rich, nuanced and true as Blue Valentine in a very long while.

It's an anguished, acutely observed and at times deeply affecting story about falling in love - and out of love - that channels the keening, ugly desperation and emotional heft of the great John Cassavetes.
It's very sad but it's so beautiful.
Blue Valentine is a tough and tender drama that doesn't pull any punches, and it's a thrill to see two of the best actors of their generation going toe-to-toe.
It could easily have devolved into sweaty, pretentious melodrama or ersatz John Cassavetes if Cianfrance and his actors didn't maintain perfect control over the material.

Michelle Williams and Ryan Gosling give tender, nuanced performances in the most authentic portrayal of romance we've seen in a long time - its hopeful, giddy beginning and its stagnant, fracturing end.
Featuring two remarkable performances

Every once in a while a film arrives that is so honest, so expertly crafted and so sincere that the powerful emotional response it elicits is profound. Blue Valentine is one of those rare films. See it with somebody you are breaking up with.
Highly recommended, except if you choose it as your next date movie.
Michelle Williams and Ryan Gosling take the plunge, reeling beneath their characters' troubled lives.
A reminder that well-measured and expertly acted pain can be as thrilling to watch as 3-D spectacle.
[Director] Cianfrance is not interested in the Hollywood fairytale, he want to show that love can scar.
Gosling and Williams are some of the finest young actors...and Blue Valentine is the perfect showcase for their skills.
There is something raw and naked that translates from the actors to the audience, even mediated by the movie screen.
Watching it requires as much courage as curiosity. That it was just as hard to see the second time around says something about it. I'm just not sure what.
Call me sacrilegious, but I don't think The Blues Brothers is all that great.
A demolition symphony that works with the cold efficiency of a Moog synthesizer gone sadistic.
I have never been quite sure why this $30 million comedy made by John Landis in 1980 became such a cult.
Goes on way too long, but still a fun movie that immortalizes John Belushi
The film retains a huge nostalgic kick, thanks in large part to Aykroyd and Belushi's easy rapport, a smattering of daft, shaggy humour and some truly iconic musical sequences.
Bloated, overlong, too many car crashes, too little humor. A big disappointment.
The story is thin, but there's a consistently wonderful over-the-top mentality.
There is no more material sustaining The Blues Brothers"than one would find in a silent comedy short running 10 or 20 minutes.
There's no indication that Landis knows what the words "pace" or "mood" mean. He operates on one track.
There's not one ineffective cameo in a movie with many because there's no sense of stunt casting or camera hogging.
A classic for all time!
It's the kind of film that sweeps you up in its fun, enthusiasm, and energy but after repeated viewings you slowly start picking out its various flaws.
Just about the only Saturday Night Live skit that makes a successful transition into a feature-length comedy.
The humor is predicated on underplaying in overscaled situations, which is sporadically funny in a Keaton-esque way but soon sputters out through sheer, uninspired repetition.
The Blues Brothers truly captures a moment in time and celebrates one of the greatest musical genres in history.
Formless, chaotic and lazy, and quite brilliant because of it.
Given all the chaos, director and, with Aykroyd, cowriter, John Landis manages to keep things reasonably controlled and in a straight line.
Big, loud, often obnoxious, but surprisingly sweet-tempered.
The Blues Brothers is, by any objective standard, a messy wreck... That this is so does not in anyway change that it is an absolutely wonderful movie.
A cult musical comedy film with a still-growing reputation.
... "Body Double" finds Brian De Palma at the zenith of his cinematic virtuosity.
Uneven, but underrated De Palma effort.
...ugly, unedifying exploitation cinema.

A spectacularly sleazy send-up that finds the puckish, thin-skinned director confronting his critics and doubling down on everything that upstanding, respectable people hate about Brian De Palma films.
It's an expertly crafted B-movie, a brisk and twisty mixture of the slick and sleazy, the glossy and grungy.
It's not so much like a Hitchcock thriller as it is a Mel Brooks comedy.
It's a mystery, a romance, a horror flick, and a straight-faced parody all rolled into one unique little movie.
Body Double, while not his finest, is the best candidate as Brian De Palma's signature film.
A gripping murder mystery in which director Brian De Palma offers sly tributes to Alfred Hitchcock.
Ultimately, Body Double feels like a film that seems more interested in pleasing itself than pleasing the audience.
'Body Double' remains as a palpable testimony of the immense influence that Alfred Hitchcock's cinema had on the generations that knew how to see in him the same as Truffaut. [Full Review in Spanish]
...De Palma's expectedly grandiose directorial choices go a long way towards keeping things interesting...
Sneaky, bloody but clever reworking of Vertigo
Emblematizes De Palma's refusal to take Hollywood seriously.

Body Double is an exhilarating exercise in pure filmmaking, a thriller in the Hitchcock tradition in which there's no particular point except that the hero is flawed, weak, and in terrible danger -- and we identify with him completely.
No one can rip off Hitchcock quite like De Palma
Another sexed-up Hitchcockian thriller from Brian De Palma. Plays much better today than it did in 1984.
enough to portend the downfall of civilization... a guilty pleasure
Is Body Double Brian De Palma's most underrated film or merely a guilty pleasure on my part? Naturally, I make the case for the former.
Kinda stupid, really.
Body of War is a powerful and effective documentary because it keeps its focus very tight and makes its story vivid in personal terms.
Body of War is neither the most cinematic nor the most elegantly crafted of recent Iraq war documentaries, but that doesn't stop it from being one of the most deeply affecting.

Equal parts sadness and inspiration, fury and compassion, the film is sure to divide audiences along ideological lines. But there's no denying the reality of Tomas Young's experiences. A man who has paid so much is more than entitled to his opinions.
Half an excellent and touching profile of a young veteran, but unfortunately, half a strident anti-war propaganda film.
A chance to witness the struggles of a remarkable young man. Young may be paralyzed in the body, but his mind is fiercely alive.
A searing documentary that reveals the courageous antiwar heroism of a Iraq war veteran who is paralyzed from the waist down.
...more than just another run-of-the-mill political documentary.
A tough, affecting documentary about an American soldier in the Iraq war.
Body of War makes no bones about its activism. Then again, like the others, it's the willingness to contextualize events and apply reason to them that makes it and others so valuable.
Anti-war messages don't get any more powerful than this.
"Body of War" is so simple-minded and ham-handed in its case against the war that it ends up diluting its own argument.
Almost by definition, documentaries about Iraq are gut-wrenching reminders of the unaccomplished mission. Body of War transcends even that tough standard.
Architecturally sound, emotionally ravaging.
The lack of ego and relatively little self-pity [wheelchair-bound Tomas] Young has is astounding.
The doc gets up-close and personal. It shows one injured vet's reality after war.
A powerful argument against impetuous decisions, be they to join the military or to attack a country.
Lazy, shallow and repetitive, Phil Donahue's Body of War is one of the most incompetent documentaries to emerge from the Iraq war.
Drenched in emotion and suffused with good intentions, Body of War is impossible not to like, but difficult to admire.
It is not merely an antiwar document, but a complex profile in courage of a paraplegic and patriot.
[Tomas Young] deserves better treatment from the government than he's gotten as a returning veteran, and a better movie than this simpleminded indictment of every senator who voted 'yea.'
Ferrara keeps the human element at the forefront of the story
As sheer moviemaking, it is skilled and knowing, and deserves the highest praise you can give a horror film: It works.
Instead of really being scary, the film made me think of something that has troubled me since: don't movie characters watch movies?
Won't ever challenge Siegel's or Kaufman's versions, but it's a pretty worthwhile adaptation for fans of Jack Finney's source material.
One of the creepiest and most overlooked horror movies made in the past decade, featuring a strong, scary turn by Meg Tilly.
Okay remake. Might have been better is screenwriter Stuart Gordon had directed.
A very effective horror remake that's driven by character rather than cheap shocks.
One almost never says that a SECOND remake is worth a dang, but this is that very rare exception to prove the rule.
The original was far better.
A misfire on a classic remake.
Offers a few stunning moments of paranoia-laced terror.
A teen horror film with grown-up violence.
An entertaining and dread filled horror science fiction film...
Though the look is upgraded and the tone more sinister than in previous iterations, there aren't enough new twists to warrant yet another interpretation.
Director Ali Abbasi juggles multiple tones and storylines thanks to the strength of this central relationship.

A grown-up fairytale and a love story with that traditional mix of light and darkness. Eva Melander is emotionally devastating; Eero Milonoff's performance is unsettling and ambiguous. Brilliant and frustrating, every reveal raising so many questions.
Some people will think this is the worst movie of the year. Others will love it. Both groups won't be able to stop talking about it.
It... gnaws at the brain for its subliminal messages about how we treat the people in our midst who don't fit whatever definition of "normal" we're carrying around with us.
Border spins an old-fashioned tale about good and evil, but it does so in surprising ways that allow breathing room for all manner of very timely concerns.
It's a wonderfully weird often surprising movie that is utterly Scandinavian to its bones, but also surprisingly Hollywood in its narrative commitment to the procedural genre.

Instead, it betrays a lack of faith in the familiarity of the Other, something that might have given lasting resonance to what is otherwise an initially intriguing but finally self-consciously distinctive curio.
Wins over your heart as a 21st-century tonal poem that embraces the hybridity and plurality that radicalism seeks to thwart.
An indie full of smart allegories on immigration politics, with a little bit of lo-fi fashionable horror sprinkled in.
Abbasi delivers formidable jolts because his deliberate pacing and low-key approach make the revelations all the more stunning.
Border doesn't all fit together -- it even tries too hard to fall into place at points -- but its ambition matches its heart.
In 'Border' remain, as indelible marks, its passionate reflections on identity in many aspects. [Full Review in Spanish]
Border is less invested in glib symbolism or political commentary than in the specific, felt experience of being adrift between social boundaries and categories.
He mines John Ajvide Lindqvist's (Let the Right One In) short story of outsider love and Nordic folklore for ideas of radicalization, empowerment, gender fluidity and feminine rage.
While the film does take some twists and turns - some fairly contrived - it mostly drills down and explores her emotional conundrum without drawing symbolic conclusions about the world we live in.
...one of the most singular and genre-defying films to come along the pike in a great while... An absolute cracker.

a film of stylistic virtuosity saddled with a humdrum scenario, yet graced with a few subversive surprises.

A richly detailed, unforgettable slice of menace.

In its own modest, genial terms, the picture succeeds.

... a rare romantic comedy that gets both the romance and the comedy right.
The first contemporary romantic comedy I've seen in years that feels as if it's made by a real human being for other real human beings.
It's all fun and games, basically, but a pleasing diversion for those who can wade through the thick London accents.
The best movie revolving around a dance hall since 'Shall We Dance.'
While you sense the writer lurking behind these twists and oddball moments, the film is not without its shaggy charm.
Wonderfully written.

Nicely structured, but is ultimately predictable.
Only sporadically entertaining.
The screenplay is a shade smarter than that of the average romantic comedy, and there are plenty of funny lines and scenes.
While Born Romantic won't win any prizes for originality, it's still a charming diversion.
In spite of its artlessness, you'll leave smiling and smooching your significant other.
The actors are good enough to make it all work.
Except for Jimmy ... these are not very interesting folks and, at first, it's hard to keep them all straight or even care.
This lightweight British import is harmless but unenlightening, a scruple that seems to have taken its lead from an episode of HBO's "Taxi Cab Confessions."
Boy could have been a twee mush of cuteness and bathos but it's not, in large part because of the outstanding cast of unself-conscious Maori kids.
Funny and touching at times, but a little bit of Dad goes a long way.
Writer-director Taika Waititi may be the founder of his own school of humor: call it "cruel-reality" comedy..it entertains and touches with sly assurance and deep feeling.
It's a disarmingly lovely, big-hearted film, and hilarious in places.

Boy contains very little 'quirk for quirk's sake' -- and that's no mean feat for a film that's replete with 'nudge-nudge-wink-wink' 80s nostalgia, music video recreations, and a key character who may or may not be a superhero.
Rolleston's winning presence doubtless has much to do with the fact that Boy is a record-breaking hit in its home country, but there's some salt mixed in with the film's sugar.
Writer-director and co-star Taika Waititi ("Eagle vs Shark") never builds much momentum for his largely uneventful if sometimes inventive story.
One might predict that Boy, loosely based on the 1980s New Zealand childhood of Taika Waititi, would be funny and offbeat, but the surprise is how refreshingly original, charming and emotional it is.
It's a lovely oddity, and one that will probably hit home for preteen audiences all over the world.
Somehow manages both to drag on and feel too short at the same time.
New Zealand coming-of-age story has moments of beauty and warmth, but is ultimately too twee by half.
A simple story of coming of age and the bitter failings of hero worship that succeeds thanks to the impressive skills of its young star.
This is a good-natured, goofy and often charming little coming-of-age comedy that is bright, light and fun.
"Boy" is a delightful discovery, a charming little film about fathers, sons, New Zealand and Michael Jackson.
An alternately zany, sentimental, and remarkably insightful look at the quirks of a child's mind.
Beautifully realised and touching on serious issues, this moving film is propelled by big laughs and an even bigger heart.
Joy juxtaposed with humiliation, silliness with sadness, fantasy with reality, and none of it formulaic. The editing feels fresh, as does the film.
Boy is a charmer, a funny and affecting coming-of-age story rendered with heart, and with nuttiness.
"Boy" finds hope, and love, in the oddest corners.
It feels like a while since I smiled this wide and felt this good watching any film, kiwi or otherwise.
For a film about the hardened soldiers who oversaw the most notorious detainment center of the Iraq War, Boys Of Abu Ghraib is remarkably squeamish about tackling its subject matter head-on.
A halfhearted attempt at truly getting inside these men's and women's heads to make sense of their actions, which is ostensibly the purpose of dramatizing such a recent and shameful ordeal.
The film hardly scratches Abu Ghraib's surface.

It's a shame the picture ends on its knees when it had to the potential to create a certain viewpoint that could invite an understanding of the Abu Ghraib prison environment and the stress placed on all involved parties.

What made these soldiers participate in such deplorable activities? Boys of Abu Ghraib attempts to answer that question. The explanations it comes up with may not be definitive, but they certainly make for a powerful, hard-hitting drama.
Its tendency to water down the realities of Abu Ghraib trivializes its subject instead of providing depth or context.
Writer-director-star Luke Moran's drama about Abu Ghraib is an ambitious if not particularly revealing debut.

Moran's writing and directing debut is an admirably ambitious examination of the one-baby-step-at-a-time process that leads a fundamentally decent person to shut down his moral compass do things that are, by any objective standard, reprehensible.

"Boys of Abu Ghraib" has a few, brief insights into how boredom, anger, and frustration helped fuel the rage that led to torture but the film couches it all in the filmmaking of TV-movie melodrama, draining it of all potential power or social context.
Boys of Abu Ghraib is a credible depiction of the tedium, frustration and humiliation of wartime service.
What begins as a probing look at this culture feels in the end like pro-surf gang propaganda.
It aspires to but falls short of Dogtown's inspired, edgy mix of sports history, pop culture, social commentary, and revealing interviews.

Despite the undeniable sorrow you see expressed by all, your foot may start to tap and you may find yourself wishing you were on some beach yourself.
A piece of PR propaganda.
...there's an undeniable energy to this subjective, self-serving film which at times says more than it means to about this male-dominated culture.
In-depth intimate portrait of how a tough Aussie environment within a larrikin culture of rebels with or without a cause has produced spectacular professional surfers.
Maddeningly shallow.
A messy, cheeky, inelegant but unusual and interesting memoir.
Bra Boys is nevertheless intriguing for its insider's perspective of an outsider culture steeped in tradition, male-bonding rituals, and intense localism.
Russell Crowe narrates this engrossing Australian documentary, which chronicles the development of the notorious Sydney surfing crew.
Lengthy coverage of a murder trial involving Jai and Koby supplies the odd moment of meaningful reflection, but the overall impression is that of an unconvincing PR exercise.
An odd and suspect mix of documentary and public relations.
It is a sobering piece of raw filmmaking.
An often fascinating but awkward mix.
You know going in that this is going to be a fairly one-sided portrait. But it's also fairly thorough with its archival footage, historical and sociological perspective.
The film is narrated by Russell Crowe, whose star power is probably the only reason it's being released here.
Bra Boys is a carefully manicured PR video for the infamous Bra Boys surfer community.
This crude, rowdy movie is unexpectedly touching in its embrace of surfing as an escape from the stigma of poverty and broken homes.
Sorely in need of an outsider's impartial slant.
Go in with low expectations and you might be pleasantly surprised, but this isn't another Pixar bulls-eye.
By the climax, at which all right-thinking viewers will have dissolved in a puddle of warm appreciation, the new Pixar film has earned two cheers and a big bear hug.
Tepid Story Undercuts Brave's Dynamic Visuals

The promising first act turns turns into a laborious chase scene. Though beautifully animated and well-scored with authentic Scottish music, we expect that a Pixar tale would be more, um, arrow-dynamic.
A gleefully entertaining adventure movie... and what it lacks in cunning it makes up for in sincerity and crisply defined but still archetypal central characters.
The film's real strength is in the central relationship, which pays off in a way that's far more delicate and complex than most animated films would dare
"Brave" is easy to like but hard to love, a feel-good fable with the latest bells and whistles.
Brave proves a worthy addition to the Pixar canon that families and film fans should find enchanting.
A charming and vibrant new member of the Disney/Pixar stable. And the heroine's flaming red hair is at last something that makes the fuss over 3D worthwhile.
Still better than 90% of the family entertainment out there. But there's a whole lot of craftsmanship but not so much magic in Brave.
A perfectly fine effort that lacks the Pixar touch of distinction.
With its amusing, endearing characters - particularly Merida's cute little brothers - Brave is clever, exciting and moving at times.
"Brave" will provide you and your family a good time, with laughs and a few surprises. If that seems like faint praise, it's only because Pixar is capable of so much more.
I really hope that people will give this imaginative little fairy tale a chance, and I can't wait to show it to my 6-year-old daughter.
It still entertains and there's enough animated detail here to stay invested in the screen antics, but it's far from the sorely needed fairy tale reimagining the opening promises.
Though it falls short of the studio's best in many respects, Brave is ravishing to look at. Merida's carrot corona is alone worth the price of admission.
In the end it feels that destiny has passed by not just our heroine, but her vehicle too.
A sweet story, beautifully animated, and one that -- coming on the heels of "Cars 2" -- suggests the magic is back at Pixar.
This latest outing just goes to show that even an off-day at Pixar HQ can result in a well-told tale more than worthy of your time and attention.
Cockamamie folklore from a land too distant for Hollywood digimators to strain themselves over authenticity.
engrossing military drama that contains a wealth of insight into the intertwined tragedies of power, politics, war, and human nature.
A superb war movie with an unsettling moral.
Breaker Morant is a top-notch film about an injustice in the annals of military history.

contains one of cinema's most undernoticed and passionate speeches

Memorable Aussie epic with Edward Woodward particularly good.

Bold, uncompromising and completely compelling filmmaking.

Based on a true story but playing like a close cousin to Stanley Kubrick's 1957 masterpiece Paths of Glory.

Documenting a particularly heinous miscarriage of justice from the country's military history, Beresford's title helped established a legacy of commemorative reenactments from his native country and showcases a trio of excellent performances.
Brick is almost fiendish in its insistence on finding modern-day parallels to classic pulp-fiction figures.

Brick is kinda brilliant and kinda demented, and you love it for the former far more than you hold the latter against it.

Wisely conscious of its own inherent absurdity in combining afterschool intrigue with a hard-boiled atmosphere.
This year's Donnie Darko? Brick is in a class of its own, showing neither a hint of pretension nor convolution.
If imitation is the sincerest form of flattery, does that apply when an idea is taken, massacred, and awkwardly plopped in a high school setting?
While this plot is heartbreaking and high school movie generic, the execution is lively and deft.
The conventions of films noirs ... shrivel in the bright California sun. There's no reason 'Brick' should do this, of course -- which is to say, there's really no reason for 'Brick.'
The movie's ambience, most apparent in its slangy hardboiled banter, is unprecedented and invigorating.
Like the best noirs, Brick is a triumph of attitude, and there's no arguing that its brand of deadpan cool is precisely unique.
A smart, original neo-noir that works as an ingenious mindgame as well as a slick Hollywood calling card.
Forget the media-saturated affectations that surrounded Brokeback Mountain and Crash. The real vicious truth is the state of the American teenager.
Rian Johnson's flashy cinematic stunt grafts the hard-boiled argot of Dashiell Hammett onto an upscale Southern California high school.
After discovering his girlfriend has been murdered, a high school geek attempts to unravel the mystery in what may be the best teen movie you've ever seen.
Everyone is smart and everyone assumes that everyone else is smart. That includes Johnson and his high regard for his audience.
Johnson isn't the first director to subvert suburbia, but he's probably the first to have done such a fine job of it on his first outing.
If Brick isn't totally successful, it does make Johnson a director to watch.
Never really offers an adequate justification for its central genre-transplant conceit.
Leanly scripted, directed for maximum tension, fast-moving and filled with a surprising amount of droll humor.
Here's a tough, twisty, relentlessly paced little indie in which a college frat hazing looks pretty much like a gang initiation.
Punchily played and cannily directed, this may be a touch contrived and overpopulated with minor characters, but it's still highly entertaining.
The film's self-conscious brand of imitation Tarantino was already stale over a decade ago. It's no better now.
Like its characters, Brotherhood is not a perfect film, but it's a highly effective, jolting and dark ride that plays especially well with an audience.
Ingeniously constructed and propulsively paced.
...a passable thriller [that is] disappointingly uninvolving for the duration of its refreshingly brief running time.
Viewers get paddled into submission in this strident frat-house thriller.
Lean and satisfying.
Most are curious about the seedy undertones of fraternity life and the reality behind the hazing clichs. Brotherhood opens up the story, it just doesn't waste time telling it.
College-fraternity stunts go past the point of no return, which is also the point where we cease to be convinced or care.
Brotherhood has its faults -- the plot unravels a fair bit -- but the Tarantino homage is reasonable and the nightmarish atmosphere well maintained, with bizarre black-comic jolts.
Brotherhood moves fast, but it can't outrun its superficiality.
Despite a running time of less than 70 minutes (- the credits), still outstays its welcome.
Doesn't make much of an impression past a few visceral flashes of conflict, with the majority of the film a frustrating sit that seems to drag on far longer than its 70-minute-long running time.
The gathering implausibility is dispelled by a nice ending twist.
You are more likely to be scoffing than biting your nails at this theatrical little effort.

We can't say enough great things about this terrific debut and how well it plays even on repeat viewings when you know where things are going.
Just a variant on the old chestnut about a fraternity initiation gone terribly wrong...but told so tautly that you're swept up in it nevertheless.

I was so angry at everybody involved in the making of this film. It's just astonishing.

A series of musty gross-out gags ranging in sophistication from sperm bank hijinks to sloppy man-on-man kissing, Bob Odenkirk's cringemaker-with-a-heart is a ragged Xerox of Dumb And Dumber that seems incredibly creaky after the summer of Superbad.
The trick to a comedy like this is to make an audience care about these goofballs, but we're just like everyone else the brothers come into contact with. We simply wish they would go away.
Early on you realize these dorks aren't going to get any funnier, and it's a sinking feeling. Oh, no! Oh, no! Oh, noooo!
Occasionally, a film comes around that is so bad it's hilarious. This is not that film. This film just plain sucks.
The film is another example of how talented TV performers often lose their way in movies.
It's hard to hate a movie that tries so valiantly to resurrect the career of Lee Majors. But even that noble task ultimately fails.
Odd-couple comedy that tries much too hard and, in other ways, not hard enough.
Wanna see a raunchy, hilarious adult comedy? Then by all means go to "Superbad," the not-so-surprise hit about being a teen-ager that's definitely for grownups.
This miscarriage of a movie feels more like a overly long SNL skit that never knows when to end.
A strong argument for birth control and 2007's worst comedy to date.
It won't work for everyone, but it will work for some people. I was one of those people. You might not be. What else can I tell you?
Odenkirk keeps the absurdity both contained and free-flowing.
A syrupy fable about love and family? What happened?

What feels like a three-hour descent into boredom is only a 90-minute test of might -- pitting you against unlikable characters, horribly written dialogue, and direction that's as painful as a root canal.
A dismal gross-out comedy.
It's one lame idea stretched into a string of even worse variations on the idea.
If you're looking for Schindler's List here, please stay home.
The film is only sporadically funny, and it's frequently in poor taste, but it's got energy to spare, and Gyllenhaal's performance gives it a soul.
A farcical, romantic fairy tale told with respect, warmth and humor.
The ultimate cinematic bafflement, one that will leave the most jaded Hollywood observer with a Freddie Prinze Jr.-like look of bug-eyed, slack-jawed shock.
Another smart-alecky road comedy with something to offend half the population.
Certainly the meanest-spirited film ever associated with the Disney hallmark.
While this critic generally likes it when comedies trample on p.c. pieties, Bubble Boy crosses way over the line.
Desperately unfunny.
Try to imagine something Peter and Bobby Farrelly might make if they had no talent whatsoever, and you'll have some idea what to expect.
Someone like Tom Green or Carrot Top probably could have done a better job of reacting to Jimmy's issues and done it without a darn bubble in their way.
Bubble Boy is a strange, bizarre, twisted romantic comedy.
Has a goofy and over-the-top way of making its point, but as long as you're not stuck on it fitting a particular mould, it's a fun - and meaningful - ride.
Hayes shows a deft touch with both cartoony slapstick and character-based comedy and manages to create moments of real poignancy in between.
Exploits and offends.
You may be surprised at how closely it resembles Pee-wee's Big Adventure in spirit.
Has a heart that swells as big as Jimmy's plastic prison.
Hardly original and rarely laugh-out-loud funny... What keeps the film bobbing along is Gyllenhaal's goofy innocence and energetic eagerness.
An empty-headed, chaotic, utterly tasteless atrocity...bubble- brained and obnoxious.
After enduring only a few minutes of this shrill debacle, you'll feel more trapped in the theater than Jimmy is by his bubble.
With an elegant simplicity that befits the man at the center of it all, it's a multi-layered, metaphor-rich film with beautiful, hard-to-ignore lessons.

Perhaps Brannaman's art is too subtle and instinctive to be captured on camera, but it's a shame Meehl doesn't do a better job of capturing exactly what makes him, by all accounts, a miraculously successful trainer.
one of those rare films that not only satisfies but effects change in the viewer -- provoking a humble desire to live a more dignified life.
As a manual for handling animals - and people, for that matter - Brannaman's common-sense teachings broaden his story's appeal.
The guy's a star: the magic charisma that works on horses, no matter how disturbed, shines out of him in person, too.
A touching, if occasionally overwrought look at the inspiration behind Robert Redford's Horse Whisperer.
Stirring low-key and no-nonsense documentary on renown horse trainer Buck Brannaman.

Transcendent, emotional, moving, informative and ethereal, this surprisingly tough-minded look at a man and his life's work is a wonderful excursion that says just as much about the viewer as it does about the figure at the center of it all.
Beautifully photographed..."Buck" shows life at its most simple level.
Much of the movie - too much of it - is just Buck in the corral, riding, working with ropes and flags, conditioning a horse to behave.
The man's mythology precedes him, and it's the movie's failing that we don't understand how or whether he uses that mythology because he knows it's good business.
Documentaries have a wonderful way of making us care about people and things way outside our own experience, and "Buck" is a prime example.
Buck offers a good-natured amble through one man's compelling life path.
Astonishing and moving.

Some years ago, Robert Redford made an excellent movie called The Horse Whisperer, based on Nicholas Evans' novel. It turns out that a horseman named Buck Brannaman helped inspire Evans to create the character that Redford played; he even...
Despite these odds, Brannaman grew into a preternaturally gentle adult who channels hard-earned patience and compassion into his work.
Breaking the cycle of abuse, Buck's deep-rooted respect for these dignified animals is truly inspiring.
No, a young Scarlett Johansson doesn't make an appearance in Buck, as she did in The Horse Whisperer. But Buck, the man and the movie, are that rare thing, the real deal.
It is perhaps a measure of the success of a documentary to be able to interest you in a subject that you'd not normally gravitate toward.
Ultimately a plea for compassion and kindness for both horses and humans...
The Bull Durham cast was assembled with obvious care.
Rather than a vapid national epic, it is a warm, droll, deftly cracked romantic comedy.
Classic performances, witty and insightful script, this is about so much more than baseball and will no doubt prove to be a quiet classic.

Writer-director Ron Shelton tells a wonderful story of how a veteran ballplayer and up-and-comer collide in the world of the minor leagues, and how they are loved by a baseball groupie who's also a philosopher and poet.
Bull Durham puts Shelton in the Hollywood big leagues, and he's hit his very first pitch over the scoreboard in centerfield.
As much laughs as there's salt in ballpark popcorn!
The acting in Bull Durham cannot be faulted and should be remembered at Oscar time. Sarandon has one of the juiciest female roles in years and she makes you think no one could play it better.
Costner is a natural as the dyed-in-the-wool ballplayer. His best lines are when he's philosophizing, like on being an All-American male who hates anything by Susan Sontag.
Tim Robbins acts circles around Kevin Costner.
Might have been the greatest baseball movie ever made if not for the sluggish centerpiece performance by Kevin Costner.
A witty, sexy baseball comedy with a knowing world-weary outlook.
Screwball Annie and hardball Crash aren't playing the same game, which is Shelton's conceit as well as a possible screen-writing miscalculation.
Bull Durham, the new baseball movie starring Kevin Costner and Susan Sarandon, eases up on you, lazy as a cloud, and carries you off in a mood of exquisite delight.
Costner's prime, long gone now.
Writer/director Ron Shelton lobs juicy lines to players Kevin Costner, Susan Sarandon and Tim Robbins, and they all hit home.
[Crash's] remit? To teach talented but undisciplined pitcher Ebby (Tim Robbins) about hurling a ball. And a little about life.
Bull Durham is a treasure of a movie because it knows so much about baseball and so little about love.
...the best sports movie ever.
Writer/Director Ron Shelton clearly knows what he's doing here.

Shelton, nominated for a best-original-screenplay Oscar, nails the details of minor-league ball visually as well, from the players' superstitious pregame rituals to the dead, painted-green grass on the field.
What the filmmakers captured over the course of that year is remarkable: a story of pride in the face of hopelessness, bonding in the face of troubles, exhilaration in the face of certain death
Vividly captures a year in the life of eastside Detroit's Engine Company 50.
Who needs the fake fires and explosions of the"Terminator" series when you can see the real thing in this doc?
The endless scenes of burning buildings and macho posturing merely provide an action-driven context for the filmmakers to deal with more personal topics like loneliness and resiliency.

Burn captures the danger (and, yes, excitement) of putting out blazes, as well as the futility of dousing flames in a city rife with arson-and the struggles to maintain adequate funding in a wrecked economy that hits the public sector hardest.
The film makes you thankful for members of this macho breed, who relish risking their lives to save others.

Burn is not just a celebration of these wonderful, involving fighters of fires and so much more that threatens survival. It is also a tribute to the decent working class and firefighters everywhere who impact so many lives.
If Black America is an internal colony, then Detroit is its epicenter. Hence, the more than coincidental ties between this powerful documentary and Pontecorvo's masterpiece.

... the dynamic on-the-fly scenes of danger and chummy stationhouse camaraderie are slowly peeled away to reveal a fascinating and multigenerational portrait of loss, resiliency, frustration and regret.

Directors Tom Putnam and Brenna Sanchez structure Burn in a brilliant way, allowing viewers not just access to life behind the fire hose but to make personal connections with these men who act against the human instinct to run away from the flames.
An emotional character study of a group of heroic, yet very human, individuals.

As powerful as Burn's images can be, the Detroit firefighters tell their own stories about what's important to them, their neighborhood connections, their family legacies, their pride in their fellows and in their community.
These stories are moving, but what really distinguishes the film is the sense of an entire city giving in to self-immolation.
An action-packed look at the men who do their best to keep Detroit from going up in flames.
Burn, from directors Tom Putnam and Brenna Sanchez, is a straight-up documentary about a year in the life of the Detroit Fire Department. And what a year.
Burn does some eulogising for a great nation that may never achieve that greatness again, but it also celebrates the spirit of community that built it up.
Burn lets us inside a world we wouldn't otherwise see -- it's far too dangerous for most of us. But these admirable men wouldn't have it any other way.

Burning will bore the hell out of you for a long time, but never enough to lose interest or tap out, before catching you in an anaconda vice; what was once boring becomes an unforgettable work of genius deserving to be repeatedly examined
This is a gripping nightmare.
It's chilling and brilliant.
Combining the unruffled quotidian spell of Hou Hsiao Hsien's dramas with the pertinent observation of Jia Zhangke's contemporary themes, this film burns slowly ...
Lee Chang-dong's potent drama sparks unconventional mysteries
With Burning, Lee extraordinarily obliterates the bifurcation between life and representation, the thing in itself and the metaphor.

Acclaimed Korean director Lee Chang-dong has fleshed out the minimalist narrative of Murakami's story and created an extended ending, turning "Burning" from mere rumination into a dramatic suspense thriller...
It's haunting stuff, as fascinating as it is difficult to shake.

Is it a love triangle, a murder mystery or a comment on the human condition? Whatever you call this stunning, slow-build thriller from South Korean director Lee Chang-dong, it sizzles with a cumulative power that will knock the wind out of you.
Burning is an intriguing dramatic mystery that rarely bequeaths answers, usurping the male gaze and dichotomy between the well-meaning creep and madman.

Lee Chang-dong's Burning moves at a pace all its own, telling a tale of mystery and obsession with no easy answers. Hypnotic, haunting, and featuring an incredible performance from Steven Yuen, Burning is one of the year's best movies.
The result is a strict realistic and prosaic narrative's disquieting tale, but whose inner nature is allowed to infect the abyss of the fantastic. [Full review in Spanish]
This aptly titled beauty never offers easy answers, but a sparkling young trio, as mesmerizing as any that Hollywood might assemble, keeps you looking for them anyway.
The director, aside from telling a fascinating story on its own merit, articulates an eloquent portrait of South Korea. [Full Review in Spanish]

A twisted love triangle at the core of this Korean thriller...becomes something far more unsettling thanks to a bracing midway plot jolt and a powerful atmosphere of doom and dread created by the director Lee Chang-dong.
Lee Chang-dong delivers what may be cinema's most elliptical serial killer drama...
A stunted writer gets wrapped up in a mysterious romantic triangle in Lee Chang-dong's yawningly meticulous Korean mumblecore Gatsby riff.
The three actors bring a vitality and intensity to their roles, making the film a gripping character study.
Since the film never force-feeds the audience, its conclusions are all the more alarming and inevitable.
Burning is an immersive game of ambiguities, uncertainty and absences, where we doubt everything, including what Lee Chang-dong projects on the screen. [Full Review in Spanish]

Even though Burying the Ex shambles through the motions like an actual zombie, it inherently has a good spirit and is trying so desperately to entertain. And that's more than can say about a lot of other horror films...
The freedom of the director's best work is missing.
The cast is game but ultimately BURYING THE EX doesn't work as either a comedy or a horror flick.
The scariest thing about Burying the Ex is that there are screenwriters and producers who believe there's an audience for this sub-Entourage swill.
Pays its respect to the genre and is ideal for a drive-in experience where the popcorn butter flows like blood.
Jonathan Hall's garish cinematography makes the whole movie look like a psychedelic mortuary. The screenplay, by Alan Trezza, is deadly, no pun intended.
A strained sexist rom-com.
"Burying the Ex" may not be a breakthrough along the lines of "Gremlins," but it is a cheerily macabre lark and a welcome fresh entry to Dante's oeuvre.
Even masters have their off days ... and Dante's new picture, "Burying The Ex," seems to have been made over the course of quite a few of them.
It alternates awkwardly between shrill, borderline misogynistic sex farce and desperately gory, pun-rife creature feature.
Despite a game trio of leads, Joe Dante's zombie rom-com disappoints with its outmoded sexism and indifferent visuals.
Dante has always been at least as much of a comedian as a monster fan, and the film has plenty of gruesome dark humor about embalming fluid and rigor mortis.

What we get here is not a reinvention, it's the wholesale reanimation of something that had been buried for a long while. Like the shambling zombie corpse it is, initially we're glad to see it come back to life, but pretty soon it starts to decompose.
It's a lot of fun, and Dante's heart is palpably in it.
I refuse to believe Burying The Ex is a Joe Dante production, as it's far too lifeless and drab. Sorry. I just don't buy it.

Joe Dante has gifted the world great cinematic treats, such as creature feature Gremlins, sci-fi comedy adventure Innerspace, and the love letter to the cinema, Matinee. Alas, Burying the Ex will not be thought of with such reverence in the future.
a plainly executed geek show with nothing for horror geeks to get excited about.
Populated by stock types, the story is backed by little in the way of characterisation, and missing is a necessary campiness to complement the aesthetic.
A zombie breakup movie whose best joke might be its all-the-description-you-need title.
A Joe Dante movie I didn't like?!? Oh, well. It was bound to happen at least once.
The never-naughty Calendar Girls is as easy to take as it is because director Nigel Cole avoids the hard sell.
An amusing film.
Don't race to see it unless a female Full Monty is just what you've been waiting for.
Calendar Girls is the kind of film which makes you appreciate the humor divide between the Hollywood machine and the UK.
Calendar Girls is a prime example of why Americans appreciate British humor. And in this case, we have the added perk of a tale that once again proves that real life is often funnier than fiction.
Amiable enough as a frothy entertainment, with darker overtones rendered with emotional effectiveness.
Helen Mirren stars in yet another professionally acted and staged wry-crisp comedy about British modesty that gets its laughs, but seems increasingly out of date.
Unabashedly celebrates the luminescent beauty of the older woman.
Mirren and company charm their way through this year's feel-good British entry.
The movie -- like the calendar -- moves along smoothly.
The humor lacks bite, and the drama is forced.
There's a terrific comedy buried somewhere here about moral hypocrisy and community panic, but it never fully emerges.
While the picture (which is based on a true story) has its charms, it just gets flimsier as it goes on.
'Calendar Girls' offers laughs, maybe a tear or two and lots of heart.
Dishes just enough laugh-out-loud jokes and female-empowerment moments to divert our attention from its threadbare script.
Um filme imensamente simptico que, alm de divertir, ainda se transforma em um verdadeiro manifesto de glorificao da sensualidade feminina.
Tampoco hay que ponerse demasiado exigente; (...) la pelcula tiene su gracia y cumple con casi todo lo que promete.
Helen Mirren gives a funny, saucy and surprisingly tender performance as Chris Harper.
A paper-thin comic distraction.
Gentlemen - you whose significant other may hold the weekend movie choice card - keep a stiff upper lip. You'll get through Calendar Girls just fine.
The moments are there. They sneak up on you.
Anyone seeing this happily contagious film will just have to have a copy.
There's not been a more infectious jazz performance screen treat since 1959's classic Jazz on a Summer's Day.
A must-see for avid fans and a welcome primer for nascent hip-shakers everywhere.
If the list of names in paragraph three means something to you, then Calle 54 is absolutely worth the price of admission. If you recognized no one but Tito Puente, Calle 54 probably isn't for you.
A loving Buena Vista Social Club -style hymn to the rhythm and life of salsa.
You come away with more appreciation of how inclusive Latin jazz, with its roots in Africa, really is.
There is much to be said for a music film that seems to be playing directly to us, the viewers.
Calle 54 is an engaging sampler of Latin jazz and its permutations.
The film will greatly appeal to current fans of the musical genre and should win over more than a few converts.
Calls attention to deserving musicians, but in an oddly cautious style that would fit comfortably onto a PBS fund drive.
Clearly a labor of love, Fernando Trueba's docu is a great chronicle of Latiz jazz, its history, performers, and enduring appeal.
If you're not a fan now, these 105 celebratory minutes could go a long way toward your conversion.
The knowledge of the musicians' connection to one another makes it the most touching interlude in an overlong but nevertheless entertaining film.
You can find half a dozen things to complain about and yet enjoy every minute of the film completely.
Although it isn't the human-interest story that Buena Vista Social Club was, Fernando Trueba's Calle 54 is the next best thing to that milestone musical documentary.
It is easy to imagine Calle 54 having a long shelf life on home video after its run in theaters. It can be played over and over again with increasing satisfaction.
Descriptions of great art are, of course, ultimately irrelevant, and Trueba knew we'd have to experience his passion for ourselves. He's offering a dazzling invitation -- take him up on it.
For much of its 105 minutes, it simply sizzles with sophisticated passion.
Even casual listeners will have a hard time not enjoying the often complex sounding and clearly infectious music.

A rare and invigorating spotlight on the back to basics collective spirit among salt of the earth workingclass enthusiasts of any game played among them, simply for the love of sports beyond money and fame. And just the way it was always meant to be.
[Director] Lundgren has a light touch and a weakness for wistful indie lullabies; it is the former that gives this classic coming-of-age film its distinctive ring.
When you don't care about the character who gives a movie its name, you've got terminal problems.
Lundgren's screenplay beautifully juggles the story's alternately comic and poignant elements and renders all three main characters with surprising depth.
Aside from Zahn, thesping is uneven.
A grand-slam comic drama that's heartwarming, funny, inspirational and, above all, triumphant.

Most baseball movies are about dreams; Calvin Marshall is a sentimental comedy about self-delusion, and the young actor Alex Frost can't find a way to make sense of Calvin, or to make him sympathetic.
A baseball movie suffused with authentic patter and love for the game equal to that harbored by its titular character.
Director Gary Lundgren's Calvin Marshall eventually falls flat in its heavy-handed efforts to score an emotional homerun.

Good-natured but not overly sentimental, Calvin Marshall makes its formula work with thoroughly realized characters and unforced comic moments about the irrepressible charms of the obliviously self-deluded.
This Hollywood film has passed the test of time and is still a good watch, especially, during an election year.
Reveals the hollow center of a campaign manipulated by media mercenaries and political Machiavellis who value victory over integrity and substantive moral issues.
Much like Network, this satire on an American institution continues to gain relevance instead of lose it.
One of the few good, truly funny American political comedies ever made.
Ritchie and Redford's follow-up to Downhill Racer is one of the more intelligent films to have been made about political machinations in America.

The first and arguably the sharpest expose of the new media-determined American political process, The Candidate offers producer-star Redford one of his strongest dramatic roles; Michael Ritchei's 1972 cautionary tale became prophetic in its message
Good early intro to the political machinery behind the candidates, where the emphasis is clearly only focused on winning
Redford's superior acting talents, which not-often-enough are tapped by the scripts he decides to do, are nearly all on display herein in a virtuoso peformance.
Redford fancies himself so superior to the electoral process that he ends up with a completely fatuous characterization of a politician.
Neither the authentic political atmosphere nor canny performances by Redford, Boyle and Porter go far to cut through the basic glibness of the film.
Much of it has a pleasing air of accuracy. But Redford's inability to suggest any irony about himself finally sinks it -- it's the only sanctimonious satire you'll ever see.
With Redford giving one of his best comedic performances, helped by a Oscar winning script, The Candidate is witty and charming, while looking good and proving quite memorable.
Robert Redford's engaging performance here breathes fresh life into the all-power-corrupts theme, and the sharply observed situations won an Oscar for scriptwriter Jeremy Larner.
[The Candidate] is the best film about American electioneering politics since The President's Analyst.
The result is a fascinating film that sometimes feels like a documentary. Despite minor glitches, this is a prophetic glimpse of politics in the age of TV.
If this candidate doesn't prove to be a winner, I'll demand a recount.

It is full of political insights, of ironic humor. It shows an understanding of words that mean nothing. What the script lacks is definition of people as people. It stacks its deck. McKay is too charming, too nice, his rival too much a villain.
[Michael] Ritchie's technical skill as a director is impressive.
I'm not sure there's a lot more to say about heroin addiction, but if there is, Candy doesn't say it.
... although there are some very striking moments in Neil Armfield's debut, there are simply not enough to keep us absorbed the way a movie should.
Even as they spiral inevitably downward from ecstasy to hell -- she turns tricks, he steals -- they somehow still look really attractive, which is a ridiculous thing.
... for a druggie movie, "Candy" is surprisingly dynamic and involving ...
The question is whether "Candy" is intended to be an honest and unflinching look at the junkie life, or merely trying to top "Trainspotting" and its ilk.
a rough movie to watch, but the acting performances make it worth it.
Think of this warts-and-all misadventure as the cinematic equivalent of a 'Just Say No' public service announcement.
... a flawed but engrossing parable on love and sacrifice.
Candy is pretty much the standard, downbeat, drug-addicts-in-love tale we've seen repeatedly over the years.
Harrowing and strongly moving, this junkie drama beautifully explores the emotional core of its characters. It helps, of course, that the cast is this good.
If the characters' trajectory feels pre-ordained, the actors force us to sit up and pay attention with renewed focus.
There is nothing harder to do well on screen than a picaresque drama about drug addiction... Despite good performances and excellent cinematography, this is a struggle that the filmmaker loses.
This may be a good film to take the kiddies to if you want to scare them. Sort of like those car crash films in driver's ed. But it's generally not worth it.
Rehab comes not a moment too soon.
Doesn't deviate much from the downward-spiral norm, but benefits hugely from an atypically loose performance by Heath Ledger.
It's one thing for a movie to show us the perils of addiction. It's another for it to give us two people who can't seem to find any joy in it.
Undeniably affecting.
There have been other movies about heroin addicts, but none more harrowing than Candy.
[T]here's a lot of cinematic pleasure to be had in Heath Ledger's thoroughly un-self-conscious performance...
Beautifully shot and wonderfully directed, Candy is a gut-wrenching, sobering, and passionate look at relationships, addiction, and one woman's journey down the rabbit hole.
How bad is this infamous 1980 musical mega-dud? So bad that it stars not, one, not two, but three people who can't sing, dance or act.
Points for not calling it "The Village People Movie" -- but not many.
An absolute train wreck of a movie, but viewed as a sort of fevered dream, some hilariously campy moments!
The unevenness of the acting comes as a kind of blessing, though, since the rest of the movie is so thoroughly homogenized.
It's tough to believe any movie that opens with Steve Guttenberg dancing on rollerskates could actually get worse from there, but it does -- and in such spectacular fashion!
The Village People, along with ex-Olympic decathlon champion Bruce Jenner, have a long way to go in the acting stakes.
Please DO stop the music! A '70s disco holdover.

Pretty poor, but the enjoyable level of kitsch places it above the other musical turkeys of the era, all of which are far more painful to endure (Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band, Xanadu, The Apple).
Paul Greengrass isn't much of a jingoist. He doesn't leave room for fist-pumping revenge-applause.
When it comes to an authentically hand-held grit, and a feeling of being in the doomed cockpit, Greengrass has few peers.
The film ... tells a story of courage but not in broad, idealistic strokes.
"Captain Phillips" is intensity to the max and one of the best movie watching experiences this year.
...slam-bang action...Greengrass keeps the tension mounting throughout the entire film. Despite the runtime, the story does not lag.
A ruthless, ripped-from-the-headlines seafaring thriller with a vintage turn from Tom Hanks.
An edge-of-your-seat cat-and-mouse game for much of its running time.

This antagonistic yet somehow respectuful relationship between the two skippers gives Captain Phillips its twist: we knew to expect a white-knuckle cinematic experience from this director, but not such a uniquely challenging relationship drama too.
It's the work of Tom Hanks that makes this film unforgettable.
...lets its central character's vulnerability live and breathe.
True stories this remarkable are rare, and movies about them that work this well are even rarer.
Another highlight in Tom Hanks' Americana gallery, the story of a seemingly regular guy who turns out to be something more than a regular guy, thus giving hope to regular guys everywhere.
It's a brilliantly accomplished hostage drama -- claustrophobic and breathlessly paced -- and Greengrass' commanding piloting of a Hollywood juggernaut can blind you to the film's faults.
It seems strange to say that an actor as awarded and acclaimed as Tom Hanks is still capable of surprising us. But he does in 'Captain Phillips,' which is one of the best films of the year.
Great movies nearly always involve a director's galvanizing vision and an actor's willingness to let character drive performance. Captain Phillips is a great movie.
Even though we know the end of the story, this film generates so much nerve-shredding suspense that we feel like we need to be debriefed afterwards.
It goes from exciting to exhausting mighty quickly and the final act.
What makes Captain Phillips so gripping, apart from its visceral sense of danger, is that it daringly gives us both points of view.
The action flows thick and fast, but so much of what drives the film happens beneath the surface.

The movie plays as verite' as scripted cinema can... It's a shame of sorts that such a celebrity as Tom Hanks plays the title role, sticking out among mostly unknown faces, reminding us that what often appears real isn't documentary.
Captivity the movie has been thoroughly eclipsed by Captivity the marketing.

If critics offended by the rise of the horror-movie sub-genre they've derisively tagged 'torture porn' ever needed a prime suspect to haul before any moral court, the first 20 minutes of this brutal kidnapping thriller from Roland Joffe would work.

Joffe and his screenwriter Larry Cohen deserve a little credit for pointing up the psychological horrors where they can, but Captivity is still a grubby, exploitative film with an extremely guessable twist and universally dull performances.
Captivity is the kind of film that gives torture porn a bad name. It's disturbing in the most unpleasant ways possible outside of Abu Ghraib or battlefield snuff films.

There's something about Captivity that'll keep you watching; it could be your morbid curiosity, perhaps it's a sick bloodlust, or maybe, just maybe, it's because Elisha Cuthbert is clad in a low-cut dress at all times. My money's on all three.
It's a Saw rip-off with less smarts. (Take a moment, please, to allow that sentence to sink in.)
...so ineptly conceived and staged it could be the first torture-porn comedy
Destined to be better remembered for its grisly billboard imagery than for its relatively tame torture-porn tropes.
Courtney Solomon tried to polish the turd by adding some torture scenes, but all he did was make the turd turdier.
It feels desperate from beginning to end, and is only offensive in that it presumes to be better than we think...
Torture junkies should remember it's only four months to Saw IV -- so you can afford to avoid Captivity.
Some inventive individual moments aside, Captivity is off-puttingly derivative and clumsily written.
What a loathsome, reckless and sickening glimpse into madness this is.
