As a horror/thriller trying to add another dimension to what has gone before in countless low budget American incarnations, Captivity feels like a cop out given its promising beginnings.
Polished and atmospheric, but utterly vacuous.
Even in the fetid swamp of the torture porn genre, it stands out as a particularly awful movie.
With the exception of ramming my head into a brick wall, then backing up and repeating the exercise, I can't think of anything I'd rather not be doing on a Friday afternoon.

The current plight of Paris Hilton makes you suspect that the heiress' jail sentence is an elaborate marketing ploy for Captivity. If only the once great director Roland Joffe and writer Larry Cohen behind Captivity could show such imagination.

Without even calling into question the morals of a film which seems to exist only to depict the suffering of multiple women through hideous tortures, the film is still an empty mess, offering only a minor afterthought of an explanation to who is doing the
Captivity is an abomination, and perhaps a new low in the torture-porn genre: a film I liked even less than Hostel.
Aside from the interminable music videos, set to a constant, very loud Top-40 soundtrack, much of the film is so surrealistic and weird that you may think certain scenes are meant to be of daydreams.
Jennifer Connelly is very easy to look at. Career Opportunities isn't.
Paper-thin premise entertains thanks to a game Whaley and a luminous Connelly.
Tolerable only for Jennifer Connelly.
Scenes like the one in which Jimmy's father eats fried chicken dipped in peanut butter should appeal to kids of all ages.
Mediocre teen pic, with a memorable Connelly performance
[The film] has plenty of absorbing characters, smart, snappy dialog and delightful stretches of comic foolery.
Let's be honest, the only reasons to watch this movie are Jennifer Connelly in a skintight tank top rollerskating and riding an electric pony.
If we didn't know from other, better Hughes movies what the themes and emotional registers were supposed to be, it's hard to say that this would be able to supply them itself.
Career Opportunities plays like a hodgepodge of Hughes' greatest hits.
The movie is very good, both as a first-order viewing experience and as a contemporary gloss on Brian De Palma's classic 1976 adaptation of Stephen King's novel.
Peirce is gifted, but she lacks the ability of directors like DePalma to transform schlock into something deeply personal.
By the time Carrie's famous blood-splattering climax strangely twists and turns toward a final curtain, there even might be room for a sequel. But I doubt it.
Peirce's imagery is pungent: the mark of Carrie's bloody palm print on the eggshell blue of her gym teacher's skirt; a slow-motion whirling sateen dervish of a student and her gown in flames.
The Pictionary version of Carrie: instantly recognizable, but lacking in flourish.
I was expecting passive mediocrity. Instead, I got something actively bad.
There is no 'good' reason to revisit the story, except for the most important one: It's a really damn fine story.
There is nothing especially timely, revealing, or surprising in this remake.
Not just the best horror in ages but a remarkably astute teen drama.
An engaging and worthwhile new take on De Palma's blood-soaked classic.
Effective teen horror with bags of character - think Mean Girls with buckets of blood, only maybe not quite as much of a masterpiece as that would suggest.
It's perfectly watchable, but I've been more scared at a vicarage tea party.
For the most part, this is a solid adaptation of [Stephen] King's work that honors the source material.

By the time the pig's blood has splattered (three times) and Carrie has wreaked her awkward destruction (sprinklers set off before the fire?) you'll be convinced that the new Carrie is average at best.
Carrie travels a predictable, distressingly straight line...hitting all the expected notes along the way diligently, but with little inspiration.

Playing it safe to appeal to a generation that hasn't been exposed to this tale of telekinetic woe, the new Carrie is much like the old Carrie, only now the mayhem is more hard drive-based than wonderfully, inventively practical.
Man, what a disappointment.
Neither bold enough to strike its own path nor powerful enough to match the first film
The DePalma is about Sue and Kris, the Peirce is about Carrie herself--and therein lies all the difference.
...almost a textbook case study in the pitfalls of remakes.
Casual Sex?, the movie, is exactly like the real thing -- kinda empty, kinda unfulfilling, and you feel just awful afterward.

Definitely a lightweight movie, without any heavy ambitions, but for the most part a likable one; with script and direction by women, it's considerably less arch and dehumanized than the usual sex comedy.
Aside from these confessional flourishes and the very infrequent bright remark (''It was the early 80's, and sex was still a good way to meet new people''), the film is as ordinary as it can be.
After a variety of sketchy farcical/romantic complications, the movie settles for a rather sentimental epilogue, but it remains surprisingly engaging.

This is hardly a film that is going to change anyone's life, but while profundity is not its aim,Casual Sex? has a ring of emotional truth, as it cleverly pokes fun at the crisis-altered. sexual mores of the 1980s.
Casual Sex? is a casual mess. It's casual in that it is shallow, uninvolving, superficial and leaves no lasting impression, and a mess in that it's ... a mess.
If the script is dubious, the direction matches it. The cast is less directed than exploited.
Only the "Vin Man," a beast from the East named Vinny and played as a macho send-up by comic Andrew Dice Clay, lightens up the proceedings.
With the late 1980s sensibility, their sex conversations are peppered with the girls' finding their own identities in relationships with men outside the sex act. Is it mature? Yes. Is it funny? No.
A third-generation Tarantino rip-off distinguished only by its equal-opportunity nudity.

Director John Stockwell uses split screens, a blaxploitation soundtrack, and hammy, Get Smart sound effects to put some old-school spring in Cat Run's step. It makes for an odd combination with the film's ecstatic, viscera-laden violence.
Bullets, babes, perverts, Euro travel, secret documents, hitmen, car bombs, and testicular torture. Oh my.

A brazenly efficient and articulate female assassin nearly worthy of a Tarantino or Coen Brothers movie sticks out from amidst the schlocky criminal muck of Cat Run, a self-consciously sleazy comic crime saga composed of facetious elements.
Made for today it just is more chaotic, has more nudity, and had more violence including some slightly nauseating scenes of torture. Otherwise the film is funny and fun, a fast, entertaining ride.
An incoherent hybrid of buddy movie, "Girls Gone Wild" episode and James Bond spoof that employs cheap cinematic tricks like multiple split screens for no apparent purpose.
An extended trailer masquerading as a feature film

Words like "smug," "derivative," and "shallow" could all be fairly applied to the film, but as a piece of late-night exploitation, it delivers the violence and nudity with the regularity of an IV drip, and some familiar faces in the cast help class it up.
Though John Stockwell's action comedy is shamelessly derivative, his enthusiastic cast propels it much further than it should go.
A loud, ugly and terrible movie that doesn't skillfully juggle its various elements; it throws them violently at your face and calls it edge.

It's easy to feel sucked into some kind of time warp back to the heyday of late-'90s post-Tarantino crime thrillers, cut-rate knockoffs filled with casually cartoonish violence, quippy patter, overtly flash filmmaking and incongruous pop tunes.
The nicest thing to be said about Cat Run might be that it doesn't know what kind of movie it wants to become.
If you can't dazzle 'em with brilliance, baffle 'em with genre baloney -- and enough shoplifted visual trickery to fill Quentin Tarantino's kitchen sink.
This movie is fiercely uneven, feeling like two different movies got drunk and had a sloppy love child that now no one wants.
Run, don't walk, to Cat Run.
A well-made and aggravating (in a good way) character study.
...another Hollywood celebration of someone else's courage...
Slovo refuses to turn either Vos or Chamusso into an easily identifiable 'good guy' or 'bad guy,' and Robbins and Luke follow the same lead, creating credible, well-rounded characters...
Manages to feel dated despite the extreme relevance of the message that one man's freedom fighter is another man's terrorist...
"Catch a Fire" is an excellent real-life story with a social conscience.
"Catch a Fire" is an incendiary movie about an individual's desperate decision to battle a corrupt government system after being mentally and psychically abused.
Thanks to a terrifically shaded performance by Robbins, Vos comes across as a complex character with clearly ambivalent feelings about his task and his place in the apartheid system.
Having first burst on the scene in his groundbreaking title role in Antwone Fisher, Luke delivers here a top-notch performance that is nuanced and layered, with just the right emotional punch.
As out-of-Africa dramas go these days, Catch a Fire is downright old-fashioned, a liberal political thriller about a noble black man who stands up to a white imperial monster.
Director Phillip Noyce has crafted a powerful portrait of a people, their love of their land and their struggle to be free.
Although Catch a Fire was clearly done for the right reasons, the movie dissipates its own tensions.
Had it been released twenty years ago, it would have had a better chance of catching on with audiences.
It's a bit too neatly constructed, but Noyce's skills are sharp as ever.
Derek Luke's amazing performance elevates the movie beyond any misstep.
Luke has grown as an actor to have the same kind of screen presence as Matt Damon. If he keeps putting in performances like this, we'll upgrade him to Leonardo DiCaprio status.
Timely in theme, Catch a Fire resonates because it is about an issue from a time not so long ago -- apartheid ended in 1991 -- with which we can still identify.
A sizzling performance by Derek Luke ignites this story about Patrick Chamusso, a South African oil refinery worker who became caught up in the fight against apartheid.
The danger with films like Catch a Fire is that it wields the past purposefully as propaganda without tipping off the audience.
Movies like Catch a Fire are perhaps the most banal sort to write about.
Ultimately, [director Phillip Noyce] does a pretty good job of telling us the cost of freedom; he just can't quite put us inside the skin of the people who had to pay it.
A terrific cast does not necessarily make for a good pic.
One of film's greatest dissapointments.
If you cherish the idea of Joe Pesci, John Turturro (wearing a cowboy hat), Dean Stockwell, and Dennis Hopper in the same room, you won't be able to resist Backtrack.

Foster's scenes where she is utterly surprised by Hopper's lack of knowledge of the world, are so inviting without being condescending, eerily reminiscent of how she responded to De Niro in Taxi Driver.
The violence is cyclical, no one learns anything, and any points gained for absurdism are lost by landing too many punches square on the nose.

A picture that blends its irreverence with a satirical undercurrent that enriches the narrative, making for a film that is irrepressibly entertaining - and yet is complete with a rather pointed socio-political message.
It's a highly enjoyable experience to watch these cats' fur really fly.
There may be some fiendishly clever satire at work here, but the violence is so protracted and unpleasant, and the end result so lacking in laughs, that I soon gave up trying to find it.
Ultimately overstretched, but kudos to Oh and Heche for giving this often wickedly funny tale their all.
Drawing its energy from revenge and its jagged humor from a black well of contempt for the wealthy, the movie fashions a world in which the only likable characters are the crazy and the doomed.
Played with committed ferocity by the excellent Oh and Heche, this riotous state-of-the-nation satire may lack subtlety, but it has the courage of its socko convictions and certainly packs a punch.
Catfight is not the story of two gals who hate each other and then realize, over appletinis, how much they have in common. Tukel takes that tired clich and blows it to smithereens.
As a joke, Catfight is a punch line with a really shaky setup.
This film positions Ashley and Veronica as symbols of America, angry and resentful to the point of absurdity. The film is red-raw in its antagonism to modern culture.
Onur Tukel's proudly ragged, black-and-black comedies lean gleefully toward interpersonal savageries, and the compelling fisticuffs of the presciently Trumpian Catfight ... is no exception
As troubling as it is punchily entertaining.

Catfight will turn off many from the outset (there were many walkouts during the screening I attended) but its strange combination of brutal physical comedy and pitch black satire make it an oddity worth fighting over.
Frequently hilarious, delivering bellylaughs to go with broken faces, keeping the bizarre endeavor wonderfully entertaining.
Our expectations are forced into conjuring hope for a wild, frenzied ride. Onur Tukel doesn't disappoint with this broad satire of American politics and wealth disparity.
Veronica is the trophy wife of a reptilian businessman. Ashley is a struggling artist who paints pictures of decapitated sperm. Both are vile.
The absurdist use of fisticuffs in Onur Tukel's extremely independent Catfight is unnerving, strangely hilarious -- and, whether you accept it or not, meaningful.
This crude, bluntly effective movie is supposed to be a satirical exaggeration, but the anxiety it depicts feels very real right now.
Catfight is a satire that contains a biting wit that hits from the minute the movie begins.

Made well before the official presidency of Donald Trump, Catfight feels, in many ways, like one of the most finely tuned responses to the new political climate we've seen yet. But Catfight isn't so much reactionary as it is prescient.
And you thought MySpace was scary.
If you begin with the premise that all films, docs and dramas, are constructs of one sort or another and it's the how and why that's important, you'll have fun pulling this apart.
The film begs lots of questions about how, and when, it became clear any of this was worth documenting, but it certainly was.
I say this with a heavy sigh: this is, by far, one of the most intriguing movies of the year.
Catfish certainly feels real enough to leave you with a stunned feeling at its finale and a nagging suspicion that the world is an even stranger place than you imagined.
Catfish demands to be seen, if only for the excellent arguments you'll have about it on the drive home.
an emotional roller-coaster ride that you won't be able to shake for days afterwards
The final narrative movement ... lets the early part of the film rest as the weaker premise that it is.
The first thing to know about Catfish is that the trailers and ads are [misleading]... . The second thing to know is that Catfish is better than the movie described in the ads.

Facebook must be blushing this week about the release of two films focused on the darker side of all those glowing computer screens. Between The Social Network and Catfish, some of Facebook's 500 million members may think twice about logging on.
At the end of this exquisitely poignant film, it's clear we humans are going to need a refreshed emotional skill set if we're to make sense of the real relationships we forge in our virtual worlds.
Worth seeing.
Impressively directed and superbly edited, this is an utterly riveting documentary that is by turns suspenseful, hilarious, disturbing and moving.

Catfish will leave you with plenty of nagging questions, but whatever the truth behind the story, this is an extraordinary, provocative film and one that grips like a vice right up to the troubling and moving finale.
Your mom told you to be wary of strangers, right? Good advice. And that's all I'm gonna say.
It may or may not be one of the year's best documentaries, but it's certainly one of the most unforgettable ...
The core story might be legitimate, but too much of the film is so blatantly staged that it is impossible to imagine this is a genuine record of life unfolding.
I applaud the makers of Catfish for the way in which they've made and marketed their movie. They're selling it as something different... and that's a big reason why I liked it.
Even as a work of fiction, Catfish would remain provocative and true.
Catfish is heartbreaking, funny and not necessarily what you'd expect.
This powerful film in the New Directors/New Films Series about a girl's alienation is also an attempt to grapple with the horrors of Argentina's recent history.
Cautiva makes us question the things we take for granted.
A finely wrought coming-of-age drama that crackles with political tension...
Sporadically artful yet stupefyingly dull -- there are some segments that are so beautiful and monotonous that they very nearly hypnotise us...into a coma.
Another mediocre Argentinean film to ride into town on a wave of inexplicable critical approval.
This intriguing debut by Argentinean writer-director Gaston Biraben sets up a lot of tough choices before finally taking the easy way out.

The debut feature of Gastn Biraben, Cautiva is most potent in its first hour, as it bears witness to the disorientation and distrust experienced by a young girl whose life is suddenly turned upside down.
The Argentine thriller Cautiva features a solid performance by 23-year-old Barbara Lombardo that goes a long way in making up for the telenovela script.

Neither Biraben's script nor his direction leave room for doubt as to how he feels about the nightmarish past, but he's smart enough to know that even justified outrage sometimes has to be tempered with the complexities of human intentions and realities.
If Biraben had devoted more energy to the human contours of his story, its metaphorical implications would have sorted themselves out.
At every step, Cautiva is a noble, thoughtful effort. Too bad it's so often a dull one.
Part detective story, part coming of political age saga, and all teenage identity crisis.

An almost Kafkaesque story of the daughter of two "disappeared" parents in Argentina discovering her true identity. Similar to "The Official Story" but with a key difference. The daughter is a teenager rather than a 5 year old and hence more vulnerable to
A rare beauty.
Though the concept is an amusing way to educate, it isn't the most effective at diversion.
As director of the film, Frank Lloyd deserves the most enthusiastic praise.
The unholy joy of war
This is a kind of a film which is rare, and good, and true -- and one which you will not be ashamed to shed a tear over.
A loose collection of unfortunate events strung together to make a feature film sadly lacking a coherent theme.
A creaky tearjerker filled with shrill messages about patriotism and anti-war feelings...
Almost certain to be near the top of the list for 1933.
It is a film that everyone should see.
Despite the old fashioned, mawkish tone, I found the story to have a cumulative effect on me.
Worse films have won the Best Picture Oscar... there is a real argument to be made, though, that it is the most defective movie to win that award.
If nothing else, this reveals something about the lingering power of World War I on the national and international psyches during the era.

Critics at the time loved this rather sanctimonious jaunt through history. Seen from the vantage point of post-Second World War egalitarianism, however, it all appears quaint and riddled with accepted class differences.
It's all very stiff-upper-lip stuff, but 70 years after it was made, it still remains a very rousing, moving experience.
For solid acting, inventive cinematography, superb costuming and historic value, this is a great study.
This is the first big film out of the Fox studio since Sheehan's return there and this is a big picture from and on every angle.
A gloriously, heart-rendingly beautiful, stirring picture of a generation in British family life.
I can only glean that Cavalcade's obscurity is owed largely to the fact that it's just not that great a movie.

When one forgets the pace, the flow, and the really dignified and lovely quality of the picture - which is easier said than done - one can hear some very cheap theatrical observations from that choleric old empire-builder, Mr. Coward.

The first soap opera to win the Best Picture Oscar, Cavalcade, based on Noel Coward's long-running play tells the 30-year saga of a upper-class British family that loses both sons, the older in the Titanic tragedy, the younger in WWI.
A rushed, chaotic and almost incoherent recap of the backstory behind the Lower East Side's iconic (and now defunct) punk music club.
Some of the worst impersonations seen on film this year.
I fail to grasp the point of making this movie.
CBGB is like a cheap cover band - sure, you'll get some entertainment, but the experience is missing that original spark of life.
"CBGB" ain't no party, it ain't no disco, it ain't no foolin' around.
Warm gloss of nostalgia over the rise of the punk music scene in gritty 1970's downtown New York. The spirit of musical and visual energy outweighs fanciful superficiality.
As the film moves from one musical performance to another, the result increasingly feels like a series of celebrity impersonations set to a best-of-punk compilation album.
Yet another film from Miller, starring Rickman, with an engaging protagonist and an interesting backdrop or pitch, but little sense of psychological depth.
With nonexistent character depth, abysmal storytelling, and an aesthetic gimmick that hurts the film far more than it helps, all CBGB only benefits from a killer soundtrack.
If you really want to remember those times? Get out "Horses." Or "Talking Heads: 77." Or "Blank Generation." Preferably on vinyl, with all the pops and scratches. And play them. Loud.
Mythologizing by way of whip-pans and slapstick spit-takes, CBGB just might be the CBGB that we deserve.
There's very little rockin' goin' on at the CBGB, and those unfamiliar with it will wonder what the fuss is all about.
The film has energy to spare, but the comic-book visual style is heavy-handed and the film merely skims the surface of the club's influence on the pop-culture landscape.
CBGB misses the opportunity to educate. But its biggest sin, unlike many who performed there, is that it also misses the opportunity to entertain.
CBGB generally feels like a misstep, with self-aware characters all stuck in a movie that can't decide what it wants to be stylistically.
It's fun, affectionate and certainly tuneful, but it doesn't get under anyone's skin.
Moments of nostalgic emotion are ever so briefly reached, and evaporate so quickly that your only desire will be to listen to the actual music of the cavalcade of artists paraded across the screen.

a moderately effective overview of the club's early years, distilled into sitcom-worthy vignettes without the kind of recklessness to make them seem truly dangerous, CBGB is the pop-punk version of a raucous, punk-rock story.
This is not a film for purists or quibblers.

Unless you're morbidly curious about how one of the loudest, strangest, and most irreverent and original moments in rock history can be transformed into a jukebox musical for the entertainment of precisely no one, there's no need to see CBGB.
The filmmaker floods the film with blood and growls, creating a mighty clang of history and gore. It's Herschell Gordon Lewis's I, Claudius.
Though seemingly content to be a B-movie director, Neil Marshall heads further into C-list territory with Centurion
Rousing if slightly predictable.
While some of the blood-spilling action scenes could have benefited from a little more dramatic shaping, it's a mostly satisfying effort.
The men get lost in the muddy palette of earth tones... and the staccato strobe-vision of battle scenes that simply confuses the action, and the story along with it.
Though it's technically impressive and has an epic sweep, the lack of suspense and emotional involvement makes this little more than a chase movie in ancient garb.
Centurion is like 'Gladiator' directed by Freddy Krueger
Questions arise. When exactly was eye makeup invented? Why do screenwriters still, after Life of Brian, give Roman characters names like Virilus?
By turns heroic, fearsome, funny, fateful and, oh, so brutal, with swords hacking off heads at every turn.
Soon, the action begins to feel monotonous and Marshall's answer is to pick off more victims...
Flaming arrows, spears, and knives have no problem finding their way to the back of a mouth. The profanity is delightful. And the general atmosphere is grim. The movie just isn't terribly inspired.
full review at Movies for the Masses
It's clear almost immediately that Centurion's biggest assets are its various performances and visceral, violent sensibilities...
Centurion treats arterial sprays like Sex and the City treats shoes.
mixes a thoroughly honorable high-mindedness with frequent and jarring examples of torture porn
Even for the seasoned gorehound, Marshall's films hack off body parts you've never seen hacked off before -- or ever thought you'd want to.
It's a cat and mouse game where we are stuck rooting for the cat even though it killed and raped thousands of mice.
Riveting. Pulsating. An action-packed Roman thrill ride from start to finish.
Marshall has cast a dream team of character actors and upcoming stars as supporting roles; the cameraderie and banter between the men is realistic, funny and rude.
There are beheadings, slit throats and eviscerations aplenty, but Marshall's real distinction is in the way he crafts a brawny action film without losing his own head in the process.
Reichardt has spun another breathtaking ode to life, and to the female experience, with easy humor and most of all, tenderness, that makes the phrase "Certain Women" one of rarified honor.
Small town stories that remind us that everything is important to the people experiencing them, and there is drama everywhere you look if you pay attention.
A piece of great syntactic complexity, where aesthetics is based on the masterful use of language and stylistic, rhythmic and euphonic resources. [Full review in Spanish]
This is an undemonstrative picture, richer in detail than incident, and ever-so-slightly wholegrain and dull.
The world of emotions that play across Gladstone as Jamie starts the long drive home is heartbreaking.
Besides Gladstone's performance, "Certain Women" doesn't have anything going for it that would make it memorable.
If the characters here are often sparing with their words, or even withholding, the visuals speak volumes.
It's difficult to grade a film when the subject matter, and the subjects, feel so incomplete.
While Certain Women is focused somewhat on the nuance of dialogue and its intertwining with body language, it's a deliberately quiet and reserved little film.
Like Reichardt's directorial hand, the performances are understated across the board, but deeply felt.
A movie in which it becomes very possible to respect the intent and yet be frustrated by the result.
Kelly Reichardt elicits every nuance from her small-town characters and leaves the viewer on the verge of reading their minds.
With so much on its mind, it's this devotion to mood that keeps Certain Women as satisfyingly visceral as it is excitingly cerebral, and as flavorfully classical as it is tastefully new.
Even as the four protagonists struggle, often in vain, to get someone else to pay attention, Reichardt's camera is right there, watching and listening.
Reichardt doesn't have the same narrative conventions to fall back on, but like the women she follows with her camera, she forges her own path and in doing so, comes up with something bewitching.
Some movies punch you in the gut. Others barely graze the skin but gnaw at you long after they finish. Certain Women is the second kind.
A tender, meaty and startlingly beautiful portrait of the American Northwest and the trailblazing women that toil fearlessly against its rocky terrain.

Director Kelly Reichardt, who made the great "Wendy and Lucy," likes stories that unfold slowly and simply. Sometimes she'll just let the camera run, making us watch the awkwardness of people who can't connect.
The threat of feeling slighted links every small and large ripple of drama in Kelly Reichardt's film.
The type of work that requires patience for the quiet intersections and confrontations of simple lives.
Downey should have won BEst Actor
Worthwhile for Downey's magnificent portrayal.
The decades haven't erased the sense that "the longer it goes on, the worse it gets."
The movie indulges in a rather stale flashback procedure.
The movie was clearly made with a lot of love, and it has one deciding factor that sells it: Robert Downey Jr.
Robert Downey enhales Chaplin's Autobiography and wears the Little Tramp's persona effectively
Robert Downey Jr. is brilliant in this guilty pleasure.
It's a loving and often endearing homage to a man, but as with all things Hollywood, it ain't history
Downey's surprisingly dead-on impersonation of Chaplin is an absolute knockout and well worth the price of admission.

Downey has a perfect ear for the Chaplin accent, the way it climbed from Cockney to minced posh, and a perfect boot and fist for the slapstick; the one thing he doesn't have is an eye on his own brilliance.

A lot of loving care (but not much thought) went into this white elephant, and considering how fascinating a figure Chaplin is it's never exactly boring, but your time would be much better spent looking at any of Chaplin's pictures.
It's a monumental biopic that cheapens the hero's successes by glossing over the failures that surely also shaped the man.
What is stunningly good about Chaplin, despite the script, is the central performance by Robert Downey Jr.
Great bio-pic with Downey at his best.
An awsome Robert Downey. Excelent performance!
This is a disappointing, misguided movie that has all of the parts in place to be a much better one.
Actually, it's a pretty bad movie, but Robert Downey Jr. is so great that you can forget nearly all of the clunky storytelling.
Robert Downey, Jr.'s performance in extreme youth and decrepitude carries Attenborough's vainglorious project through scene after sketchy scene.
Great performance by Downey.
Might be of interest to fans of the great comic, but as entertainment it ultimately fails.
Fairly desperate military comedy.
Hawke's film, a boring, pretentious waste of nearly two hours, doesn't tell you anything except that the Chelsea Hotel today is populated by whiny, pathetic, starving and untalented artistes.
Hampered -- no, paralyzed -- by a self-indulgent script ... that aims for poetry and ends up sounding like satire.
The movie is essentially a series of fleetingly interesting actors' moments.
Deadly dull, pointless meditation on losers in a gone-to-seed hotel.
It is a film in which body language and unspoken human intercourse play a much more important role than dialogue.
With virtually no interesting elements for an audience to focus on, Chelsea Walls is a triple-espresso endurance challenge.
If Chelsea Walls builds a mood of boozy poetic disorientation, a crucial ingredient is missing: the scent of genuine artistic genius.
This is a very ambitious project for a fairly inexperienced filmmaker, but good actors, good poetry and good music help sustain it.
Movies like this do not grab you by the throat. You have to be receptive.
It's pretentious in a way that verges on the amateurish.
Ethan Hawke has always fancied himself the bastard child of the Beatnik generation and it's all over his Chelsea Walls.
Linklater fans, or pretentious types who want to appear avant-garde will suck up to this
The digital-video results play like a flatulent teenager's first discovery of jazz, cigarettes, and hooch.
Reeks with phony posturing and lot of talking without really saying anything.
...a disastrously ill-conceived drama...
A dreary, incoherent, self-indulgent mess of a movie in which a bunch of pompous windbags drone on inanely for two hours...a cacophony of pretentious, meaningless prattle.
I'm not suggesting that you actually see it, unless you're the kind of person who has seen every Wim Wenders film of the '70s.
Like the Chelsea's denizens ... Burdette's collage-form scenario tends to over-romanticize the spiritual desolation of the struggling artiste.
The film apparently takes place in a fantasy world where people in hotel hallways recite poetry in voice-over instead of speaking to each other.
As is most commonly case with projects such noble and lofty ambitions, the film is less poetic than simply pretentious.
There's genuine outrage behind Lee's angry blast of hip-hop agitprop, and his fury has good cause... Unfortunately, his film is also a gaudy mess.
Astonishing. Up there with Lee's very best.
If there's a hot-button modern American issue to be pressed, Lee jabs it. The common thread is vitality, energy and urgency.
[An] exuberant political satire.
[Chi-Raq], if often muddled, is rarely dull.
Lee is really letting it rip here. And although in a variety of ways Chi-Raq is overbearing and stilted, the thing is so unusual you can't help keeping your eyes glued to the screen.
In "Chi-raq," Lee mixes fierce agitprop with lyrical musical numbers and Greek-inspired sex farce in hip hop verse. It's a mad combination that fittingly addresses a world of madness.
It is more than a film; it is an anguished wail of grief and fury and the most important film of 2015.
The job of a movie like this one is to stimulate arguments and hook itself into the viewer's imagination, and "Chi-Raq" accomplishes that job brilliantly.
Lee, who birthed such memorable films asShe's Gotta Have It(1986) and School Daze(1988), is back at the top of his form withChi-Raq. Let's hope he stays there.
Chi-Raq is raucous and transgressive, but most of all, it's a lament. And lament is exactly what we-you and I-need to learn: right now, this year, this month, this week, today.
A wild-eyed, bumpily syncopated symphony in purple and gold, Chi-Raq is ragged and binary, for sure. It also is colorful in every way that our culture needs right now.
It's not Spike Lee's job to come up with solutions. His job is to engage our imaginations and stimulate our minds. It's up to us to be smart enough and strong enough to solve these problems.
Yeah, it's a mess. But what a glorious mess it is.
At its best, it's sexy and surprising. At its worst, it's preaching to the choir - literally. And it's a sermon we've heard before.
Its full, sardonic title is Chi-Raq, Drillinois -- not a subtle way of putting things, like the film itself, but undeniably effective.
Though not entirely successful, Lee's adaptation certainly has balls.
[Chi-Raq] is an in-your-face explosion of anger and vitality.
Hudson has nothing but sadness to sell, but she brings it across beautifully. Jackson has become strutting personified. No one sells raging melancholy like Bassett.
Something got Lee real mad, and when he's mad he's at his best.
Park's love for all his characters, good and evil, is literally palpable: These characters have been forged of clay, fussed over, posed, photographed over a period of years.
A witty, action-packed story.
Chicken Run should be seen by the whole family. Actually, it should be seen by everyone.
f a better, funnier, smarter, more endearing film than Chicken Run comes along this year, I will eat a live chicken and shoot the feathers out my butt.
The slapstick, quick timing, and colorful characters may keep the kids occupied, but the sharp dialogue and tender moments will make the adults enjoy it even more.
The stars of this fowl adventure also have hilarious foibles, eccentric habits, diverse personalities and a lot of spunk.
This chicken has legs -- lots of them.
Few filmmakers are better at setting up a sight gag than co-director/co-creators Nick Park and Peter Lord.
So great.
Everyone except poultry farmers and airline companies should rejoice at the creation of this wonderful Claymation movie.
Run to Chicken Run. This clay-animation comedy is the most entertaining animal story since Babe.
Funny in eggs-ecution and fabulous in design.
But there's something more going on here, an almost palpable joy in the ability of the animators to turn colorful clay into charming, amusing characters.
It's extraordinary how stylized chickens made of clay can exhibit such touching emotion.
Una de las mejores cintas del ao y una excelente muestra de lo que se puede hacer con imaginacin, talento y un buen cargamento de plastilina
An animated farce with... uproarious action
This first feature by Nick Park and Peter Lord, the team that brought you Wallace and Gromit, is a diabolically witty piece of work, a haymaker.
The lavish coops, detailed pie machine and realistic lighting are just a small thread in a beautiful canvas of stirring images.
The animation is executed with astonishing skill, considering every frame records minute changes made by hand in models of rubber and plasticene modeling clay. They even managed a spit-take!
Imagine Mel Gibson playing the James Garner role in The Great Escape. Now, imagine Mel Gibson in feathers.
Clearly made with the best of intentions but never anything but boring.
You can be 100 percent in favor of rescuing adorable orphans from war-torn zones and still find The Children of Huang Shi a tough haul.
A disappointingly detached and tame film for such a subject matter.
Such an old school bore that you'll be tempted to wonder if it's actually satire played inexplicably straight.
... an affecting portrait and a strong story with a compelling backdrop, and Chinese cinematographer Xiaoding Zhao makes the gorgeous locations look magnificent.
Director Roger Spottiswoode uses the children and action sequences to good effect, but a lack of chemistry between Rhys Meyers and Mitchell makes the love story fizzle.
With all the stories to be told about the war between Japan and China, it's hard to believe that this one was the most compelling or most in need of telling.
Tells an engrossing story of a remarkable man, but nevertheless it's underwhelming.
What should be a moving story is ruined by hideous acting and sloppy filmmaking.
In alternating between an epic remove and a pro forma romance, The Children of Huang Shi stints on the messy middle ground, where the unscripted human element resides.
A dull dramatization of -- and ill-fitting testament to -- British journalist George Hogg's experiences in war torn China.
...the film falls flat under the weight of its period-drama conventions and three performances that epitomize paycheck joylessness.
[Rhys-Meyers's performance is] the perfect microcosm for the entire film: capable but bland.
Very pretty but very stiffly written, The Children of Huang Shi strives for epic canvases relaying an intimate story.
It's a sturdy film, vivid if utterly workmanlike, that builds to a crescendo of personal sacrifice and misty noble uplift.
The best thing about Children is the cinematography by Zhao Xiaoding (Hero, House of Flying Daggers), which is so distracting because it so out-classes the rest of the movie.
An ill-conceived weeper that just won't say die.
The Children of Huang Shi is an old-fashioned story of courage and self-sacrifice in the face of war and deprivation. It's also sappy, boring and obvious.
Chow actually gets saddled with the line, 'You have to tell the world what's happening here,' which was hoary back when D.W. Griffith was making movies.
The Children of Huang Shi is so desperate to be the Asian Schindler's List, an example of atrocity draped in abject artistry, that it forgets to lay out the context.
While not necessarily diving too deeply into any of the underlying statements it might be trying to make, it is a film that's acutely aware of what it is and delivers.

While producers Seth Grahame-Smith and David Katzenberg may have found success in 2017's horror remake phenom, IT, the two struggle to find footing in Orion's latest attempt at playing in the playpen of '80s horror nostalgia.
A fantastic ride of a movie. This is a different Chucky, and the era he was born in is just appropriate. [Full review in Spanish].
All I wanted in this reboot was for it to recapture the campy fun of the original, and it does just that.
For a bad-taste violence-is-funny horror-comedy, Child's Play Twenty Nineteen is reasonably amusing.
This edition is jokey as well as gory, and it bows to the demented-possessed doll franchise without ever being really scary.
A better-than-average horror remake...
By the end, it becomes what it initially parodies: a dime-a-dozen slasher film with a silly-looking doll as the villain.
This splatterrific slasher can't figure out how to blend all its heady ideas into a cohesive, intelligent and terrifying narrative.
Though few were angling for a new Child's Play - sans-Brad Dourif, no less - this unassuming re-do offers a dementedly satirical modern take for the smart tech era.
A little is made to go quite a long way here.
A passable but plain remake that's saved by a blisteringly bonkers third act.
An unnecessary throwback that never really needed to be revived. We were truly spoiled by last year's Halloween.
Suspenseful and funny enough that you almost forget you're watching a film about an evil Amazon Echo that bends over backwards, and nearly breaks, trying to look like a Child's Play remake instead.
I preferred Chucky being demon possessed rather than a computer glitch - and bring back Brad Dourif as the voice of Chucky.
Paying homage to its B-movie slasher roots, Child's Play finds inventive ways to up the gore, at the same time skewering the current culture of consumerism and digital obsession.

Being an AI with faulty circuitry, Chucky 2.0 doesn't have the hilarious vulgarity or the single-minded murderous glee - the soul, if you will - that made Dourif's Chucky such an unnervingly human abomination.
The stars of the film are the gory effects, the doll's design, and Hamill's animated voice work. Child's Play is pure entertaining fun for the horror fan, but not much else.
It's a half-baked social commentary, but at least director Lars Klevberg has more on his mind than raising Chucky's kill-count.
The movie wants to take aim at corporate consumer culture, offering up a sly critique of our tech-obsessed times, but it ends up feeling like yet another defective product.
Destined to find life on DVD - as a coaster.

A blatant attempt to apply the winning 21 Jump Street formula to another television property, CHIPS instead winds up a standard hard-R action comedy that audiences will probably forget by the time they leave the theater.
Fans of the TV show will likely find this portion of CHiPs about as far from the source as the Starsky & Hutch movie.

One more R-rated pileup of buddy-and-body humor, slathered with chases and collisions for that empty-calorie sumpn' extra. If you're looking for a whip-smart, hilariously meta-rethink like the 21 Jump Street movies, you've made a seriously wrong turn.
Lazily plotted, puerile, nonsensical, it's also occasionally witty and blithely indifferent to meeting expectations.

Both Shepard and Pena are likable actors, and they do have chemistry together... But good-natured chemistry isn't enough to lift CHiPs anywhere near the ranks of the Lethal Weapons and Bad Boys that Shepard claimed to be aiming for.
An unrepentantly low-brow low point in the history of both buddy movies and TV remakes.
It's difficult to get too excited about yet another so-so TV adaptation.
A staggeringly unfunny comedy, the film mines homophobia, accidental decapitation and the objectification of women for lols.
I found myself curling over in such a paralysing cringe, my body had to be rolled out of the cinema afterwards like a dented bicycle wheel.
The weakness of this film is its simple plot and its political correctness. [Full review in Spanish]
In a low-life kind of silly way, the real laughs come from oversized personality clashes, hysterically pitched fights and a general awakening between our two misfits that they like each other.
Not everything has to be raunchy and rated R. Just because Sony did it doesn't mean you have to do it.
A movie that hates itself and its audience.
...there is, in the end, no denying the movie joins the ranks of several other misguided comedic remakes of '80s television series (eg 21 Jump Street).
A lazy, vulgar and painfully idiotic buddy-cop comedy that is as generic and predictable as they come.

The crudity flows as easily as the violence in this low-IQ outing, with a special emphasis on gay panic humor and an even greater emphasis on sexist humor (this is the sort of film that suggests that if a woman isn't a 10, she might as well kill herself).
Despite an at-times desperate desire to entertain, CHiPs never manages to transcend its juvenile baseline.
The new movie version of CHIPS is smart to have jettisoned just about everything about the original, except the basic plot ...
Toilet humor, cars exploding for no reason, random naked boobies, and gay panic... although, weirdly, also lots of awkward, unerotic nearly naked Dax Shepard.
Citizen Kane is the biggest cinematic landmark since pictures first started moving.
There can hardly be anything left to say about Citizen Kane, now revived on the big screen, other than to comment on sublime moments.
It is a work of art created by grown people for grown people.
Welles has found the screen as effective for his unique showmanship as radio and the theatre.

Citizen Kane has been cited as the greatest film ever made from so many different quarters, it's a wonder that a Congressional law hasn't been passed making it required viewing for anyone who claims they like movies.
Citizen Kane is an event in motion pictures. An intelligent and intellectual stimulus, and also an experiment.
If you haven't seen it on a wide screen, you should check it out. The breathtakingly innovative visuals are the point of this experience.

It is a triumph of the film, and proof of its solid value and of the sense of its director and all concerned, that a human touch is not lost. Sympathy for the preposterous Mr. Kane survives. Indeed, there is something about him which seems admirable.
It remains a gloriously entertaining classic.
A cinematic perfect storm of technique and sophistication, widely hailed as the apotheosis of all the innovations and advancements of the sound era.
It would be nice to be able to buck the critical orthodoxy and say how tired and overrated Citizen Kane is; but the dulll truth is, it's still, indisputably, one of the great masterpieces of cinema.
Citizen Kane may very well be the most talked-about movie in history.
Kids who watch this movie can never know how revolutionary it was.
Duh.
A film that actually feels more modern than most of what we see nowadays, sixty some years later.
The greatest film of all time now has a DVD to match.
I've always said that the greatness of a film is truly measured over time, and this is one of the few films that is truly amazing to watch, and actually lives up to all that damn hype.
It's a gripping and absolutely fascinating drama and Welles is utterly unparalleled.
Citizen Kane, written, produced, and directed by a young man of 25 whom America considers a genius, is an outstanding film, amazing in its presentation and vast in its conception.
Many of the novel techniques Welles developed with cinematographer Gregg Toland were calculated to offer new angles on film space.
It tosses out a lot of information and doesn't pull it into a compelling movie.
It has about four good ideas for a feature documentary, though none of them quite lands.
[Offers] up montages of Tea Party screamers rather than investigative reporting or rigorous argumentation.
The sad thing is, there are so many unexplored areas here that do deserve films, including a serious investigation of the Kochs.

"Citizen Koch" is preaching to the choir. Which might not be a pointless exercise, seeing how the choir failed to show up for the last midterm election in 2010, and might need extra motivation not to repeat that mistake this November.
[The] movie, which starts off shakily, is naggingly diffuse and bumps up against the problem of recounting the freshly remembered past.
Snaking through a tangle of interlocking ideas, threads and events, it never quite finds a unified focus.
If you have a shred of idealism left, it's hard to watch "Citizen Koch" without a mounting sense of despair and outrage over the influence that money has come to wield over modern elections.
Most of the movie is a backgrounder on the Citizens United case, in which a deeply divided Supreme Court opened the door to truckloads of campaign cash from tycoons and corporations.
Too bad they didn't turn a grudge [against PBS] and resulting freedom into a more hard-hitting documentary that would more effectively prove their points.
The movie bleakly emphasizes the sense of debilitating powerlessness of the average citizen without the means to bring anything but their vote to the ballot box.
Like their earlier Trouble the Water, Carl Deal and Tia Lessin portray men and women yearning for a simple place in society as they become casualties to the self-involvement of larger forces.
It's a simple story, with the Koch brothers as the obvious bad guys. But Deal and Lessin get too enamored of their on-the-ground reporting and lose sight of their main prey.
May not be the most smoothly organized documentary of the year, but it certainly fires a lot of arrows at its target.
If you value civic equality and civil liberties, Citizen Koch is a must see.
If you still don't believe that money drives American politics...
OK, but it drifts off base and gets a bit lost in Wisconsin

...a well-meaning documentary that is essentially unsatisfying because it takes on too many issues and allots its screen time unwisely.

Its chief pleasure is the acting of the big cast, notably Pacino. At 55, he has a haggard, life-wrestling beauty and a street eloquence that has more innocence than De Niro and more sincerity than Nicholson.

Director Harold Becker captures the political rhythms of the big city and keeps the rather complicated plot comprehensible. But audiences need to pay attention; this is not a by-the-numbers urban thriller.
Under the direction of last-minute replacement Richard Benjamin, the results are insufferable -- grotesque, chaotic, demoralized.
One of Mr. Benjamin's main contributions to the film is a good-humored buoyancy, even when things are at their most muddled.
How do travesties like this get made?
One wishes the only pairing of Clint and Burt were better, but City Heat is still fun.
It's certainly not a subtle movie, but with memorable performances, ludicrously over-the-top one-liners and amiable zaniness, it qualifies as a lot of fun.
An amiable but decidedly lukewarm confection geared entirely around the two star turns.
Bottom line: Good roles for the stars, nice production values, and an impressive supporting cast, but no thrills and only minor laughs.
... the movie's never as good as it might have been.
Imagine The Sting without charm, and you have a fix on City Heat.
Burt and Clint might not go down as one of the great comic teams in history, but as a private investigator and a cop in City Heat, they bring fireworks to a lackluster season.
There's little doubt that City Heat gets off to a distressingly disastrous start...
A lovely oddity.
It manages to leave a pleasant afterglow for those in the mood for its kind of loving.
City of Angels is the sort of compromised movie that could have been almost good, but decided to be a great big hit instead.
Standard-issue Hollywood romantic fantasy.
Why would anyone remake Wim Wenders' masterpiece, Wings of Desire? Certainly not for artistic reasons.

City of Angels requires a deft, poetic hand. It's a fragile story that needs to unfold slowly without sledgehammering its audience. Unfortunately, those behind the enterprise haven't the required skill.
A powerful, somber and highly intellectual picture, it is not even remotely the kind of thing one would expect to a Hollywood studio to mold into a star vehicle.
I know a movie is good when I totally cease taking notes and then can find no adjectives to jot down. I was enthralled and yet not stupefied.
Awash in angelic choruses and panoramic scenery, the movie aspires toward a solemnity that Dana Stevens's prosaic psychobabbling screenplay cannot support.
An unconvincing new age melodrama that plays like Death and Dying for Dummies.
Cage, Ryan and Franz are all quite good in their roles. The love story between Seth and Maggie is low-key, but it works.
Marries romance and faith in a love story as charming as a handmade valentine. It is so lovely to look at and so sincere in intent that its flaws don't matter much.
An old-fashioned, big-hearted movie.
Manages to update [Wings of Desire] so that the freshness and passion still exist within the characters and the story. It is a triumph of conception, camera movements, and emotional feelings.
Glossy but with no heart, City of Angels is a smooth, unchallenging bit of fluff, about as romantic as a Hallmark card.

Although City of Angels sometimes dances perilously close to the line between romance and schmaltz, it never crosses it, a nifty maneuver when you consider that the story deals with both love and spirituality, two areas land-mined with cant.
Surprisingly well-executed.
The movie's eerie, slightly menacing vision of black-clad angels lurking in the shadowy corners of unsuspecting lives is genuinely haunting.
Glossy romance as an angel falls for a surgeon.
Strains to achieve the enchantingly sublime, but ends up sinking to the depressingly ridiculous.
Muckraking mess of a movie.
If Civil Brand works ... as an updated women's prison melodrama with a strong whisper of political consciousness, there are some crippling flaws in the film.
A compelling, highly charged film that brings a contemporary perspective to classic prison picture elements.
The movie is every bit as exploitative as the old Roger Corman babes-behind- bars flicks without having nearly as much campy fun.
After two smart acts, the film almost becomes the exploitation flick it so desperately wants to avoid.
Hollywood still doesn?t seem to understand that just because someone can sing doesn't mean they can act. If this film doesn't prove that point, nothing will.
Although the film loses its way in the late going with a preponderance of melodramatic elements that dilute the more compelling social message, for much of its running time it packs a visceral punch.
If Civil Brand hopes to raise awareness or instigate reform, what it really needs is a greater focus on character over convention.
Without a scorcher like Pam Grier, the sub-NYPD Blue dialogue and acting dilute what could have been a shrieking wake-up call about for-profit prisons.
It presents a heated-up, awkward blend of earnest outrage and down-and-dirty exploitation.
Plagued by continuity problems, ham-fisted storytelling and a problematic voiceover by Da Brat, Civil Brand feels less like a prison movie than a prison sentence.
There's way too much of the usual bonding, beatings, petty humiliation by guards, cat fights in the yard and trips to the hole.
Barnette, a veteran TV director, means this as an expos of prison abuse and exploitation, but the film is too simplistic and derivative to succeed.
Artistically, its heavy-handed clumsiness undercuts its goals.
This is a film about the abuses of privatization and presents a negative view of what might happen if corporate America gets control of the business of corrections.
It's guilty of gross B-movie meltdown, but mitigating circumstances include honest anger and a scattering of vivid scenes.
It's impossible to ignore the strain of misogyny that taints the movie.
Wildly uneven, rife with a virtual checklist of human tragedies that build to easy emotional crescendos but fail to engage the audience well enough to evoke any meaning.

The great Dabney Coleman in TWO different roles? All right!

For a movie so obsessed with the line between reality and make-believe, it never knows which side it wants to be on.

Anyone expecting a serious reflection on gay or social themes or the current state of sexual attitudes in France will not find it. This sweet-natured movie is mainly for laughs.
A very clever and perceptive social comedy, brilliantly acted and exquisitely paced.
A tour de farce from France's funniest filmmaker, Francis Veber.
While there are laughs to be had, on a whole Veber's new film is an unfunny and offensive disaster, wasting a truckload of rich comedic talent in the process.
This sex comedy of errors is not only funny, it's sort of sexy, too.
One reason that Veber's comic ideas are so effective is that, in addition to being very funny, they hit on the sort of sociological issues that people really do think about.
Timely as it is funny.

Veber's career-best outing.
Mercifully, The Closet doesn't go for the easy laughs.
It is not often laugh-out-loud funny, but it is consistently amusing.
The remarkably thin plot works primarily due to Auteuil's disarming charm.
Survives the dangers of its risky premise.
An expertly acted divertissement.
I caught myself feeling surprised that such a banal movie could actually be off-the-cuff and entertaining.
A bright and breezy piece.
See The Closet now before somebody ruins an American version by casting Robin Williams and scrubbing clean all its wanton wackiness.

Genial, likable, and perhaps, in its own peculiar way, even thought-provoking.
Deathly-dull, but could this no-budget horror film be behind all the scary clown sightings popping up all over the country?
ClownTown is a fun, nasty, low-budget little horror romp that delivers exactly on its promise -- terrifying murder clowns running amok in small town America.
Even those who are deathly afraid of clowns will have trouble finding enjoyable bouts of horror in this survival thriller.
It's best to consider ClownTown more of a horror/thriller parody. Its generic by the numbers approach to terrors in the wood would be slightly more tolerable.
Arguably less scary than "Big Top Pee-Wee."
Totally trashy, several steps beyond creepy.
It won't take long for genre fans to recognize that the movie is as dreary as it is derivative.
Even diehard clown haters are likely to tire quickly of this fright flick's formulaic running, screaming and jump-scares.
"ClownTown" isn't fresh or ghoulishly inviting, easily making it the second best option for those in need of a homicidal clown extravaganza this spooky season.

It's all as generic and pointless as it sounds, with tyro filmmaker Nagel unable to muster up the sort of visceral thrills that a John Carpenter or Wes Craven would have been able to deliver in their sleep.

...maybe some years hence, Clowntown could be a therapeutic instrument designed to help poor coulrophobics overcome their deepest fear, once again allowing them the childlike joy that's eluded them at birthday parties and circuses.
It's Memento for dummies. But to this movie's credit, I couldn't follow it, either.
I'm sure by May Encore will be broadcasting it ten or so times in row on one of their various channels.
If you try to follow the plot, you'll be as confused as Jake is.
Beyond such amateurishly ill-constructed plot points, what should be a fast-moving film is slow and repetitious.

too clumsy to be the sophisticated parody of memory-loss films it might have been, too bland for its action sequences to kick any ass, too dumbed-down to make much out of the clashes of race, class and gender at the heart of its fish-out-of-water comedy

...the comedy half doesn't work without the intrigue half, and director Mayfield doesn't look like he would know intrigue if Martin Scorsese brought it to him wrapped in butcher paper with a bow on top.
From past experience, viewers know that Cedric the Entertainer can be very funny. While there are times when Code Name: The Cleaner highlights his comedic abilities, there aren't enough of them.
Get Lucy Liu better roles!
Cedric the Entertainer gets hit on the head and loses his memory in Code Name: The Cleaner, a condition likely to be desired by anyone foolish enough to sit through Les Mayfield's comedy.
There's potential in the story, but who was the casting genius that thought roly-poly Cedric could ever be mistaken for a man of action, or a possible love interest for Lucy Liu?

The Entertainer conjures up some charm, and DeRay Davis provides pyrotechnics as a janitor/wanna-be rapper, but like the teddy-clad bubble-bath square-off between Liu and Sheridan, it's just not enough.

The story is incidental to the comedy, but it is on the level of humor where the movie completely breaks down. It is almost never funny. Cedric has a few funny scenes, mostly when he is just allowed to joke, with the plot momentarily forgotten.
A bunch of small disasters, collected together and fed to Cedric the Entertainer.
The one laugh is in the production notes, where director Les Mayfield claims this is a comic take on the Jason Bourne movies. As if.
Cedric and Lucy Liu...may want to give their agents a good talking-to.
Makes you wish you had partial amnesia too.
where the number-one superguy used to solve crazy mix-ups like this in 15 minutes, The Cleaner takes a laboured, exposition-larded hour and a half.
A complete dud.

Furst's (maybe) supernatural tale unfolds in a manner that, without exactly breaking any new ground, makes the most of its backwards-looking classicism with a story that is similarly entombed in the past while looking forward to our present day.
COLD MOON has the feel of a horror novel and makes for a few unexpected chills.
An eccentric mix of veteran actors, Southern Gothicism and neo-noir lends "Cold Moon" a certain charm as a ghostly revenge thriller.
"Cold Moon" has its moments, offering odd, snake-infested visuals and creepy encounters, and it's sure to fit the average movie maniac's need to watch only horror features during October.
There's little fun to be had for the audience other than in some nicely executed special effects.
A bit of a mixed bag. Has several good jump scares and a few hard-to-ignore flaws.
Frustrations aside, Cold Moon is worth watching.
Cold Moon is a dark little tale that takes you into the heart of paranoia and speaks to the real and latent violence of a strange transitional period in the American South.
Cold Moon has its moments, but the complete lack of style, tone, and technique leaves it feeling more turgid than a movie about vengeance ghosts should ever be.

I have an affection for swampy horror movies, and Cold Moon is certainly that, with its Southern drawl characters and use of vintage locations. It has a handful of genuinely creepy, bordering on scary, moments, and I like the use of the lead actors.

as painful as kidney stones

[A] needlessly odd, unfashionably sentimental drama.

To paraphrase Groucho Marx, this is a movie where we watch Will Smith, Edward Norton, Kate Winslet, Helen Mirren, Naomie Harris, Keira Knightley and several other fine players bore holes in themselves so that we can watch the sap run out.

There is nothing wrong with a wide emotional palette, but director David Frankel leans too heavily on the healing and the homilies in the rush to closure; the smugness of the therapy-talk leaks into and wrecks everything else.
Collateral Beauty certainly has something to say. And it is a worthy something. It is just a shame to see it wrapped up in the form of an Oprah Winfrey Movie of the Week.
Chicken Poop for the Soul...

Two-thirds of a fine comedy of paranoia.
...even at two hours and 15 minutes, Conspiracy Theory is fast-paced and exciting, effectively mixing drama, comedy, ingenuity, suspense, revelation and a heartening sense of a triumph of humanity.
Conspiracy Theory is the smartest thriller of the summer.
What makes Conspiracy Theory interesting beyond its cleverness and currency is how the filmmakers manipulate our feelings about its protagonist, Jerry, a New York City cab driver.
I guess a Julia Roberts fetish can't overcome a crummy script and bad production values after all.

Seagal doesn't even look good when he breaks arms or chucks heavies down flights of stairs.

The script from writer-director Keoni Waxman ... confuses a stream of expletives for wit. There's little help from Seagal, who delivers lines like, "I'm interested. Tell me more," while sounding completely bored. We know the feeling.
Overall, he gives the kind of performance traditionally associated with stars who died during filming. And yet, Seagal is in almost every scene.
It's clear Seagal is no longer limber enough to whip all the ass that's flung at him.
Longtime fans will want to avoid Contract to Kill and instead dig out their old DVD copies of Under Siege and Above the Law.
Stephens's assessment of the way our sharp political divide has enshrined our most uncompromising attributes is actually rather perceptive.

A successful mix of scripted drama with on-location improv, and a rare instance of U.S. narrative cinema that engages the politics of the moment, Mora Stephens' Conventioneers refreshes on several levels.

One for the time capsule -- not just as an irrefutable visual record of the size, diversity, and vitriolic fervor of the anti-Bush protest movement, but also as a demonstration of how unbridgeable the red-blue divide seemed in those dark autumn months.
Directed by Mora Stephens and produced by Joel Viertel, the film was conceived before the convention and executed as it transpired.
They may stand in for two halves of a country split by irreconcilable political differences. But as a couple they make not one lick of sense, regardless of how desperate each is.

The homemade-looking Conventioneers can't decide whether it's a documentary about the 2004 Republican convention at Madison Square Garden or a love story about two activists from opposite sides of the aisle.
It is a sign of the times that audiences will watch these equally selfish lovers and find one infinitely more sensible than the other.
Hardly as thought-provoking as it imagines itself to be, and barely as exciting as the televised convention coverage itself.
Despite its contrived, predictable elements, the novelty of the setting and ingenuity of the filmmakers give the work a genuine immediacy.
Among the best micro-budget offerings of the year!
A smart, savvy film about the choices and compromises we make in our quests for fulfillment...
