Cook Off piles some better-than-this comedians into a culinary competition whose dishes look as unpalatable as the film itself.

Wafting into theaters after sitting on the back burner for the last decade, "Cook Off!" is a shrill, gloppy mess of a mockumentary being served up well past its "best before" date - if there ever actually were one.
While the humor is overtly silly and light, I found some of it quite troubling.
Melissa McCarthy has what amounts to as an extended cameo.
Although co-written by Vince Vaughn & Jon Favreau, their magic of past is scantly seen.

Couples Retreat is an unending parade of offensive scenes, a tedious cavalcade of miserable, shallow people with whom we are no doubt supposed to identify but with whom we should hope to see nothing in common.
It's one bland scene after another, played at medium pace with middling creativity, punctuated with a near-desperate attempt at a laugh
We just keep wishing they would get out of the way and let us enjoy the pretty scenery.
The debutant director is done no favours by a screenplay from Vince Vaughn and Jon Favreau which gives him little to play with and them few chances to shine as actors.

The only thing that will keep your attention for the duration is the stunning Tahitian scenery that acts the films setting. On reflection this is probably what swayed most of the cast to sign up to this inane guff of a film in the first place.

To avoid paying for a holiday to hell, don't see Couples Retreat. A prime contender for 2009's Worst Film, this star-studded but startlingly drab "comedy" is the kind of terrible trip you pray will be over long before it's time to go home.
The secret to a happy marriage involves falling in love over and over again with the same person. 'Couples Retreat' offers an amusing illustration of that old saying.

Watching Couples Retreat cowriters Favreau and Vince Vaughn play schlubby husbands is like showing up to your high school reunion to find that the once-sharply dressed cool guys with the fake IDs are now fat and bald. And married.
You know those comedies that hit a little dry spell and have a hard time recovering? Couples Retreat has one that lasts about, oh, 90 minutes.

Imagine that you are listening in on the marriage-counseling sessions of the dullest couple you know. Multiply that by four, and you've got a pretty good approximation of the experience of watching Couples Retreat.
For all its visual splendor, to say nothing of its likable cast, the movie never feels as liberating as its locale.

Couples is so formulaic, so fake and relentlessly bland, it's hard to care if any of these pairings get a divorce, drown or are eaten by sharks. It has neither the ring of truth nor the fun of fantasy.
That the wonderful French actor Jean Reno plays the therapist is a sign that his agent is not doing a good enough job finding him film roles in American movies.
Hugely disappointing, painfully unfunny comedy that completely wastes its talented cast and then compounds the misery with a dismal script.
The whole production just comes off as a paid vacation at Club Med for Vaughn and friends.
The former swingers settle for standard gags in the moderately amusing Couples Retreat
The twosome that sparks most agreeably is Vince Vaughn and Jon Favreau. ... The humor isn't always highbrow, but it works.
Retreat as quickly as possible.
Vaughn, Favreau and company phone it in - all the way from Bora Bora - in this lame relationship comedy.
Shooting in color and widescreen, Benicheti makes images that are as poised and attentive as are his subjects.
Approaching his lifestyle with ambivalence, the film still accords Jules enormous respect, showing an almost holy appreciation for the beautiful process of his blacksmithing work.
For 91 minutes, the pleasure of the Guiteauxes' company is ours. We are ultimately the richer for it.
Cousin Jules concerns the essence inherent in actions, the way quotidian existence can be suffused with poetic peacefulness - and overwhelming sadness.
"Cousin Jules" is in many ways a wonder to see and hear, but there is less to it than meets the eye.

The viewing experience is immersive and magical as the late filmmaker Dominique Benicheti, a film academic who had taught at Harvard and had a deep interest in technical advances for cinema, insisted upon his work being seen under maximum conditions.
An unabashed ode to the French countryside, Cousin Jules immerses the audience in mundane tasks that are transformed into unaccountably pleasing, tranquil ones.
A uniquely rewarding movie.
"Cousin Jules" is one of those rare experiences that's rooted in the past yet feels very much of the moment.
Cousin Jules might have been a documentary game-changer, had it not gone virtually unseen for forty years.
One of the wisest, most confident films about rural life, old age, love and humanity's relationship with the natural world, nonfiction or otherwise.
A moving lyrical meditative documentary.

A simple picture, but beautifully symbolic and endlessly fascinated with its subjects, looking to impart an appreciation for routine and its rhythmic elements, questing to manufacture screen poetry along the way.
Focusing on archaic farming rituals to the exclusion of nearly everything else, the film has virtually no dialogue, but each sight and sound is monumental, communicating an entire way of life.
The framed monotony of this dailiness show is transfixing.
Maestro-like, Benicheti coaxes mere footage of his cousin's routines into a transcendent quotidian realism.
... leads us to observe the true beauty and talent of the choreographers and dancers. [Full review in Spanish]
Ultimately, this is interesting filmmaking, but Wiseman's ultra-orthodox methods may put off viewers who are used to more interactive documentaries.
A fine complement to Wim Wenders's Pina, without the 3D, but with lots of tasteful T&A.
So warm, colorful, and sensuous that it seems like a real anomaly for the highly disciplined filmmaker.
Crazy Horse could be condensed to its advantage.
Sit back, relax and get an eyeful.
Wiseman's film captivates, like all backstage documentaries, with its instances of the banal ensconced amid so much fleshly and artistic perfection.
The Crazy Horse Saloon in Paris is famous for its "erotic chic" revues, but I found nothing either erotic or chic in this reduction of body parts to geometrical displays.
You doubt Wiseman's sense of pacing. Still, he must have had a good time shooting.
As with nearly all of Wiseman's films, Crazy Horse is a narcotic, fly-on-the-wall immersion in the rhythms and predilections of a peculiar industry.
For better or worse, audiences of Frederick Wiseman's undisciplined documentary about the Parisian nude review venue the "Crazy Horse" will never have to visit the landmark club.
Crazy Horse is the story of the interplay of commerce and art, the possibility of the latter always reliant on the support of the former.

The Cirque du -Soleil of strip joints, Paris landmark cabaret Crazy Horse may strike some as an inappropriate institution for a documentary by the great Cambridge-and-Paris-based filmmaker Frederick Wiseman
Wiseman's are the movies to show to the aliens when they arrive.
Mr. Wiseman's particular genius has always been to convey, through judicious editing and dogged filming, the tedium, busyness and quiet intensity of group labor.
The spectacle lodges somewhere between erotic reverie and the perfection of a revolving sculpture.
There's little sense of the discipline involved, or the struggle for perfection that makes dance docus so engrossing.
Every shot and edit in Wiseman's film also suggests without over-explaining, allowing a viewer to lose herself in pleasure...
Crazy Horse manages to achieve a kind of constant double image. When we watch the numbers we see both the fantasy and the labor that goes into simulating it.
There's a distinct lack of real-world tension in this particular Wiseman subject.
The rest of the film is all about the girls taking off their tops and getting tied up while the guys get chased around by a dude in a hokey alligator suit and monster mask.
Creature has no merits to speak of but I am comforted by my ability to overcome my disorientation long enough to recognize how lacking Creature is.
The script (if one was ever finished), was seemingly passed through a paper shredder, tossed in the air then randomly taped back together.

Assembles all the ingredients necessary for a tasty swampsploitation horror gumbo, but sabotages the meal with cheesy digital blur effects and a lame sinkhole ending that prophesied the movie's box office fate.
An awfully made, awfully acted, awfully plotted, and awfully boring more. In a word, Creature is awful.
Ends up unexpectedly reserved, which keeps the film at least approachable but never remarkable. It's a weird feeling to be yawning during a movie that spotlights a half-gator/half-man menace.
[It's so bad that] the footage should have been left in the swamp for the alligators to eat.
A seriously bottom-of-the-barrel horror effort...
Tedious and overly complicated...
Creature is refreshingly and intentionally silly, in an era when horror has devolved mostly into torture porn and high-tech, computer-generated assaults on our senses.
Parents should have it on their Netflix instant queue, ready to buttress their "If you go to acting school, you COULD end up taking your clothes off for some hack for a movie like this."
A nice try, but done in by an annoyingly convoluted script and an obvious dearth of resources.
... heaps on the gore and the T&A ‚Äí genre staples ‚Äí and can best be described as "Swamp Thing" with teeth, razor-sharp teeth ... Delivers the goods in old-fashioned, knee-to-the-jugular jolts.
As uninspired as its generic title, Creature works hard at being a direct-to-DVD-quality monster movie.
With dependably creepy character actor Sid Haig to goose things along as leader of the locals, "Creature" is delightfully dopey.
It is in no way a great movie. But it is a great reminder of what used to be so much fun about bad movies.
Not even House of 1000 Corpses' Sid Haig hamming it up as a hillbilly patriarch can pull this out of the New Orleans swamp it's set in.
One tiresome slog through one familiar swamp.
The sort of Z-grade trash you expect to come across on Syfy whilst channel surfing late one night, not something you'd expect to pay good money to watch on the big screen.
There is a perverse enjoyment to be had from something this cheesy, although not enough of one that I can recommend sitting through it.

The story is timeless, but when adapted to the modern age, it makes for a wrenching film -- never preachy or sentimental, and refreshingly non-judgmental about the fundamental and contradictory issues it raises.

critic_name: Cherryl Dawson and Leigh Ann Palone
content: I felt sympathetic and disappointment at the same time with these priests... The end of the road is terribly sad, but the journey is never boring.
The real crime is the way that the movie turns Gael Garca Bernal ... into a backwater Freddie Prinze Jr.

It's hard to be certain without the benefit of detailed cultural context, but one gets the hunch that Carrera himself isn't all that clear about where he draws the line between the dramatic and parodic.
Apesar das inmeras liberdades tomadas com o texto de Ea de Queiroz, o filme funciona maravilhosamente bem com seus personagens tridimensionais e questionamentos sobre a Igreja.
ordinary melodrama that is heavy on religious symbols but wafer-thin on dramatic substance
You can see the would-be surprises coming a mile away, and the execution of these twists is delivered with a hammer. Thumbs down.
A melodrama, a film that doesn't say priests are bad but observes that priests are human and some humans are bad.
The film winds up muffling its own powerful protest.
...it tries to do far too much [story telling] in the allotted time.
The film's most disconcerting element is its confusing mixture of satire and melodrama.
You may not believe everything you see... But you won't nod off, either.
The drama was so uninspiring that even a story immersed in love, lust, and sin couldn't keep my attention.
It's riveting and on-message, and showcases a new facet of a brilliant actor's burgeoning career.

The film is ... determined to treat its characters, weak and strong, as fallible human beings, not caricatures, and to carefully delineate the cost of the inevitable conflicts between human urges and an institution concerned with self-preservation.
Drama of temptation, salvation and good intentions is a thoughtful examination of faith, love ... and power.
long on licentiousness and short on subtlety...Amaro is given no arc - he simply leaps off one
Like Father like Son, for soon Amaro is giving the beautiful waitress, Amelia (Ana Claudia Talancn) ... her Catechism lessons in bed ....
Nothing more than a mediocre trifle.
Despite the melodrama, Crime makes for an engrossing film.

Criminal Law is a textbook example of a movie going wrong before our very eyes, because of the curious failure of the filmmakers to realize that you can toy with an audience only so long before the audience grows resentful.
Worth seeing for for the leading-man role reversal ... + it's always great to see Bacon play a bastard.
Oldman's good, and Bacon's bad? Yeah, you know you want to see that
The pretentious psychological thriller has nothing worth saying about the American criminal justice system.
Fans of its constituent novels will flock to see it, but they'll stay for the cinema - as rich and opulent as anything you'll see this year.
Crimson Peak is a vision that is del Toro's and del Toro's alone, and while it's not his most compelling work, it's very surely his most beautiful. That alone makes it worth the price of admission.
The real wonder is the sumptuous production design by Thomas E. Sanders, whose darkly colorful sets were inspired by Stanley Kubrick's The Shining.
A movie for people who love the old Hammer Gothics precisely for their stately goofiness.
This impeccably crafted Gothic horror tale... doesn't quite come to fruition despite some vivid elements.
"Crimson Peak" ends up feeling like a bit of make-work, a project to keep the visionary filmmaker busy until something that truly sparks his passion comes along.

Aesthetically stunning and armed with a sophisticated lining of suspense, Crimson Peak does not necessarily exude any real momentum of toxic scares or memorable chills. Still, it manages to rely on its Gothic-induced romanticism that is enough
Del Toro takes his time to get to the violence, but he never let go the audience and captures their attention with a magical and gothic aesthetic. [Full review in Spanish]
You don't go to a del Toro movie for the story (he co-wrote this one with Matthew Robins) or even the characters. You go for his all-encompassing imagery ...
It's the sets and impressive atmosphere that stands out, the impecable production values, too bad it's hard to identify yourself with the characters. [Full review in Spanish]
The master of magic has created something wonderful to look at but emotionally null and void.
[Indulges] the senses with its gore, set design and costuming, and drawing on the skills of its cast...
You can feel Del Toro's seal and personality, but it unfortunately misses the level of his better works, and you can feel the studio's pressure all around. [Full Review in Spanish]

Urgh. Another slice of over-designed pseudo-gothic crud from the criminally over-rated Guillermo del Toro, who has dutifully followed up his Transformers knock-off Pacific Rim with a bloated, empty-headed haunted house jaunt.
Enormously entertaining and one of the most beautifully designed films you'll see all year, though it's not especially scary - opting instead for brooding atmosphere.
It's the most gorgeous thing I've seen all year.
one fascinating creep show
A lavishly-made retro-thriller. Further proof that Guillermo del Toro is one of the best genre directors of our era.
Sadly, while this gothic throwback is big on design it's shockingly short on actual scares.
Where is the humor, the propulsion, the story sense of del Toro's best work?
"Crown Heights" plows forward, steely in its resolve, and forgoes the emotional fireworks in favor of subdued, straightforward storytelling.
The tragic story of Colin Warner doesn't so much come to life on the screen as it is responsibly recalled in Crown Heights, aided by effective performances and some streamlined storytelling.
Crown Heights is a pretty good movie about a great subject: the sheer backbreaking labor necessary to force the system to even acknowledge a terrible injustice, much less make it right.
Stanfield, in a performance of quiet power, fully inhabits Warner's agony at the injustice that is being done to him.
Yet the film, full of good intentions and compelling performers, fails to find a dramatic structure for its considerable timespan.
Righteous, but plodding.
Ruskin eschews character development, context and depth in favor of brevity.
Stanfield's performance is the solid foundation for the film.
This is a difficult story to tell on film, to be sure, but 94 minutes hardly seems like enough time to properly convey the torment and loneliness of two decades behind bars.
This is an incredibly important story and a film that needs to be seen.

Writer/Director Matt Ruskin never lets the audience get a sense of the characters outside the mechanics of the injustice they are currently suffering through, which he often skims over like he's trying to race to get to the end credits.
Morally, there's black here, there's also white, but the prevailing color is bureaucratic gray. Bringing that to the screen and making it work is an accomplishment.
Strong central performances make this harrowing chronicle a gripping tale.
Colin Warner's story deserves to be heard, but it also deserved a better presentation that kept its audience's engagement.
The two men's relationship, and others in the film, might have been explored in greater depth, but Ruskin rightly keeps his focus on the judicial system as it fails Warner again and again.
Most of Crown Heights ... suffers from structural confusion.
It feels especially rewarding to experience such an emotionally resonant and dignified series of immigrant portraits.
The film plays like a human-interest story in which all of the humanity has been gutted in favor of deadening narrative efficiency.
The performance by Stanfield is exceptional.
"Crown Heights" is soul-shaking only in the abstract. In execution, it's deathly dull.
In a country busier than Chile with oppression, violence and subjugation, the story of Woods' slow awakening is certainly not the most exciting, or revealing.

For the first half of this movie... Interesting things were happening, the performances were good and it is always absorbing to see how other people live. Most of the second half of the movie, alas, is taken up with routine clock-and-dagger stuff.
Biko was unflappable, logical and witty in life, and Washington conveys that solidity onscreen.
a Hollywood whitewashing of a potentially explosive story

These are fine methods for delivering a civics lesson, which to some extent is what the Attenborough approach is all about. But for a film that aspires to entertain as well as educate, they are less helpful.
One of the best films of 1987 with its searing condemnation of racism and violence in South Africa.
Often harrowing and naturalistic but ultimately self-important in its indictment of police-state politics.
Sincere and movie - but not enough Denzel.
An implacable work of authority and compassion, Cry Freedom is political cinema at its best.
A historical document as well as powerful, disturbing drama

Washington does a remarkable job of transforming himself into the articulte and mesmerizing black nationalist leader, whose refusal to keep silent led to his death in police custody and a subsequent coverup.
One of the best films to come out of the 1980s. Simply amazing.
As a biopic, anti-Apartheid chronicle, the film is mediocre, but the young Denzel Washington is excellent, rendering an Oscar-nominated performance.
'80s drama about apartheid has violence, language.
Attenborough maintains firm control of the narrative, and Cry Freedom is a triumph of dedication.
[Richard] Attenborough manages to skillfully balance entertainment with didacticism. [Full Review in Spanish]
For a superior picture about the horrors of apartheid, see 1989's A Dry White Season instead.
A highly intriguing thriller, coupled with some ingenious plot devices and some lavishly built settings..it's a worthwhile tutorial in quantum physics and slash-dash
The sequel has turned completely and irrevocably bizarre to the point of utter nonsense.
While this sequel may be as unnecessary as they come, Cube 2: Hypercube is unexpectedly good.
All of the original's hokey set design, none of its subtle existentialism.
O mais fraco da srie, este filme praticamente ignora a maior parte dos conceitos que tornaram o original to interessante (como as armadilhas) e ainda conta com um elenco homogeneamente ruim.
A sleek continuation of an unexpectedly good franchise.
Not exciting enough to make me love this, but interesting enough to keep me watching.
Sporadically compelling yet ultimately disappointing...

Lambert stages it with a matter-of-factness that shrewdly undercuts any sense of excitement; like his camera's early serpentine trip through a laundromat ringing with foreign voices, his handling of the finale is restrained and assured.
While clearly limited in budget and a little too blunt in its hectoring message, Cuck also has an agreeably cultish intensity and newsworthy urgency.
Cuck is a hard watch but [Rob] Lambert's willingness to look directly at a social phenomenon frequently trivialised or abstracted from the human does him credit.
A smarter group of filmmakers might have wrestled this deliberately repellent material into a decent black comedy. Lambert and company can only manage an ugly and self-congratulatory wallow.
...this overlong movie would have been more effective if it had trusted its strong performances and atmosphere to provide sufficient tension, rather than piling on too many contrived reasons...

Throughout, the narrative keeps arcing inevitably toward a predictable and tedious eruption of violence. But the way the movie ends isn't as powerful as where it begins: with one lost boy, adopted by wolves.
With that first impression alone, it's a failure. Upon delving deeper and watching the film, it's a dangerous and offensive failure.
Lambert's film makes its point by delving deeper into toxicity and committing to the most unattractive parts of itself.
Much more resembles the movie those panicking about Joker had in their heads than the actual movie does.
Cuck is a far more engaging and daring film than it has any right to be.
It is unfortunate that Cuck does go down the route that audiences may expect from a film such as this, however as this story is as relevant now as it ever was.
Content to skim the surface, subtlety is forgotten in this portrait of an extremist loner...
The film runs out of steam and becomes heavy-handed and ugly in parallel with Ronnie's gruesome descent.

Though it hints at moments of wit, Cuck never feels serious enough to be a convincing character study and not garish enough to head into genre territory. Ultimately, this sordid tale feels both real and inconsequential.
I'm afraid I spent most of Cuck rolling my eyes.
There are fascinating textures along the way, but the finale is relentlessly shocking, partly because it's so inevitable. It's also frighteningly recognisable, and surprisingly moving.
The movie that started the Hammer horror craze. Really rather dull.
Beautifully portrayed by Christopher Lee, the Monster is almost heartbreaking, flailing confusedly with a pained expression on its patchwork face.
[A] routine horror picture, which makes no particular attempt to do anything more important than scare you with corpses and blood ...
... established new style for horror -- bold, bloody, beautiful-- that completely broke tradition with the cobwebby classics of the 1930s and 1940s.
Peter Cushing gets every inch of drama from the leading role, making almost believable the ambitious urge and diabolical accomplishment.
Further developments of Hammer Studios as a spook-house Ealing
A sterling exemplar of the best of everything that made Hammer so special.
Revitalized the British film industry.

In its best scenes, it adds dynamism and British grit to a genre that had previously tried to get by on atmospherics and mood alone. It manages to be shocking without being especially frightening, and its virtues of performance and style remain striking.

The immense possibilities of the Frankenstein story have here been sacrificed by an ill-made script, poor direction and performance and, above all, a preoccupation with disgusting - not horrific - charnelry.
This was the classic that single-handedly revived traditional British Gothic and firmly placed the "Hammer House of Horror" on the global gore map.
A movie with a distinctive mood and style that finds its own niche.

An excellent photography of Jack Asher, and also a concise montage of James Needs, which exemplifies Fisher's synthetic character, creating a kind of tension and surprising visual emotion. [Full Review in Spanish]
Unaccountably a box-office sensation, this plodding and distasteful horror melodrama from Britain has only a few really eerie moments.
I love all of Tourneur's work.
This was a first-rate classic horror story, whose richness is enhanced because the shock scenes are understated and left mostly to one's imagination.
As a horror film, there may never have been a better one.
Eerie, low budget horror classic.
It's a movie that many people remember with affection and respect from their childhoods -- because it scared the crap out of them.
Classic with extraordinary atmosphere.
One of the most intelligent and thoughtful horror films ever made.
Night Of The Demon packs a powerful punch despite featuring no gore or, demon excepted, much in the way of special effects.
A film that survives even its most unsubtle special effects to earn its place as not only one of the great films of British vintage cinema but also a classic supernatural thriller.
Intelligent, delicate, and actually frightening.
This essay in the occult is handled with much of the assurance the same director brought to Cat People, and is well above average.
It's a beguiling and enveloping tale of the power of the occult and the susceptibility of the human mind to suggestion.
A faulty screenplay makes the principal character's connection to the past cloudy.
"Curvature" wants to get the heart racing and the mind bending simultaneously, but flatlines in both departments.
"Curvature" isn't "Primer." It's not even "Hot Tub Time Machine." It's far more pedestrian with tempting working parts, frequently coming up short on thrills and intrigue.
The film becomes caught between a cerebral drama about scientific discovery and a more generic cat-and-mouse potboiler, ultimately leaning toward the latter.
Could use some straightening.
Once it sets up its "What if?" premise [...] it doesn't do a whole lot with it...at least, not a whole lot that's especially interesting.
It's ultimately a little remarkable just how little there is within Curvature that works...
A bit too pandering at times when things that read visually and emotionally are also explained verbally, but I don't think these moments ruin the over-arching narrative.
Curvature is a handsomely made, well acted, intricately constructed sincere science fiction indie.
Curvature delivers, if not a home run, at least a fast-paced triple of a thriller.
Mexican director Diego Hallavis presents a science fiction story that entertains... [Full Review in Spanish]
The story is not really new, but it has enough science fiction to satisfy viewers tired of superheroes.
Curvature never generates the energy it needs to succeed, held back by its leaden script, but it's still an indicator of talent and one hopes that more refined work will follow.
An intelligent, well-crafted, science-heavy time-travel thriller with a little romance thrown in.
It's mostly entertaining but can't find a consistency to its mysterious take on time travel.

While the majority of audiences are spending their time watching spandex-clad heroes clogging up the multiplex and binge-watching on Netflix and Amazon, there are a few of us out there seeking something a little different.
A decent, if slightly frustrating, experience but worth your time if you like stories about time.
This silly comedy isn't very original or deep, but it's surprisingly endearing.
It's pretty much gay business as usual.
The film barely transgresses racial boundaries.
Things tend to sputter about, feeling disconnected and episodic.
[Director] Yeung handles [his characters'] parallel journeys of self-discovery with humor, grace and an occasionally heavy hand, with Leow giving a winning performance as Ash.
Despite original touches, Cut Sleeve Boys is mostly a mediocre gay-themed movie plagued by tired humor and slapdash filmmaking.
Something of a surprise: a gay-oriented feature that is genuinely touching and sincere.
The performances are fairly static, but Lim and Leow are charming enough to hold our attention.
Terrible soap opera that not even the most ardent admirers of the most high-camp aspects of gay culture will find anything to their liking.
this territory has been covered dozens of times before
Cut Sleeve Boys tries to parade a Norma Desmond-sized ego without the emotional underpinning of exactly what transpires when a man becomes a mensch after donning a dress.
Northam is perfectly cast - with every swill of scotch he transforms from shy and retiring to the debonair sophisticate he has always wanted to be.
Kind of like a whole season of Alias boiled down to a 100-minute film.
I liked it during the scenes when something "cool" was being revealed on screen, but the moment that "cool" ended, my interest waned.
combines industrial espionage with alternative reality in a satisfyingly mind-bending plot reminiscent of Philip K. Dick at his best.
Natali can't be bothered to fashion an actual human story around the perpetually buzzing toys and non-stop backstabbing and double-crossing.
...confounding...
It might be just another "DTV dump" title for Miramax, but I'd call Cypher (easily) one of the best direct-to-video titles I've seen all year.
...it declines into high-tech gizmos, whizbang hardware, and hairbreadth escapes, leaving the brain behind for the sake of sheer, overinflated thrills.
Just like the spies' mission as they hunt for secrets and significance inside massive corporate databanks, [Cypher's] point is unclear.
An under-the-radar sci-fi action thriller...
High style and noirish overtones about mind control and brainwashing in corporate America. Nothing new there, so nothing new here.
A bit too clever and precious for it's own good, it's a fairly decent yet predictable near-future thriller.
Wildly ill-conceived on-screen with a droning, derivative, mind-numbing, and incredibly bad film.
Brian King's screenplay make this a fast paced science fiction adventure very much of the style of Philip K. Dick.
Dorothy Arzner's best film, Dance, Girl, Dance, spotlights women's inner worlds.

Arguably Dorothy Arzner's most personal film, this chronicle of female friendship is an anomaly: a feminist film made before feminism existed, directed by Hollywood's only female director, and a buddy picture before the genre was invented.
As a piece of Hollywood history, the film's worth seeing, but it's no unsung masterpiece.
The themes are female friendship and a woman's fulfillment, and it is one of Arzner's most coherent and accomplished films.
Arzner's internal critique of Hollywood ideology (woman as silent object of male scrutiny). It works within the confines of a stock vaudevillian golddiggers comedy-drama.
Dance, Girl, Dance is just a clich-ridden, garbled repetition of the story of the aches and pains in a dancer's rise to fame and fortune.
Without rising out of the cinematically conventional, the movie's self-reflexivity continually questions the gaze of the camera.
This jaunty RKO musical... was directed by Dorothy Arzner, and has been reclaimed over the years as a film of relevance to the feminist movement.

Pioneering female director Dorothy Arzner, who took over at short notice after filming commenced, does her best with an inadequate script and a miscast O'Hara; she manages to bring the film to life from time to time -- usually when Ball is on screen.
Arzner films it with fascination and enthusiasm, and the choreography is marked by the point of view of the spectators and the dancers' awareness that they're being watched.
Not surprisingly, the scene where O'Hara's character directly lambasts an audience for its collective "male gaze" retains its topicality.
With this release and its wonderful supplemental interviews, an opportunity is created to shed some light on a forgotten director and her work.
Dark Blue World's warm story and beautiful photography almost hits the mark, and it has a great ending.
Visually sumptuous and hopelessly romantic...
Gawky and precious as the film can be, its context is nothing less than the 20th century.
The problem is that Casablanca is Casablanca and Dark Blue World is not.
Recycles some of the aerial combat footage shot for Battle of Britain (1969) and indeed some of the same old-fashioned war movie cliches.
Flawed by a screenplay that promises a war epic but delivers only a predictable love story with the war as a backdrop.
You might remember the film's plot and character archetypes from Pearl Harbor, although Michael Bay's war turkey, in retrospect, lends itself to camp revisionism.
A bittersweet world, and it's frankly one to which we've been before, but seldom do we see it rendered with such exquisite, if pained, craftsmanship.
It hopes that its mundane structure is enough to keep up with its soaring aspirations. Like its lovesick protagonists, it hopes in vain.
The picture's stale and flimsy romance sends this otherwise stunning and profound combat story into an unrecoverable tailspin.
Fitzgerald is a fine bit of Brit, the men are truly men, England shines, the sky is streaked with courage. And attention is owed.
Uneven and mediocre to the point where you wonder why anybody bothered to cook up this film.
The movie's ambitions ... are not matched by the actual story.
Forgive Dark its timeworn cliches, and the film succeeds on a certain level as a saccharine-free slice of good old-fashioned, life-affirming escapism.
Does the world really need another painstakingly old-fashioned World War II saga?
"Pearl Harbor" Czech-style...a more authentic mixture of romance and battle.
A complex story with a number of twists, it possesses a fatalism uncommon in American films.
This Czech-made drama demonstrates that American filmmakers haven't completely cornered the market on hackneyed World War II romances.
Pearl Harbor without the product placements, without the Hollywood bombast, and certainly without the $100-million-+ budget.
An effective journey through a little-known World War II story.
Although it has many a tragic scene, the ultimate message made me feel like I had just heard Beethoven's Ode to Joy being sung - very uplifting.
Director Margarethe von Trotta effortlessly weaves history and personal events into a tapestry full of emotion and irony.
Shattering film about loss.
It becomes too fuzzy when it tries to explain in 115 minutes the history of modern Germany.
The film's forced quirkiness and repeated displays of bro-ism in action hinder the potential for a more subtle approach to the potentially challenging issue the story depicts.
Lame jokes (even when delivered by comedic vets like Megan Mullally and Nick Offerman) mixed with painfully paced sequences make this potential-filled rom-com fall flat.
A largely enjoyable and credible coming-of-age romp, despite some forced broadness and uneven pacing.

Like a fresh ripple in the near-stagnant high school movie pool, Chris Nelson's "Date and Switch" balances formula with winning performers, genuine humor and a generosity of spirit that this genre too often lacks.

In its sloppy humor and unabashedly earnest expressions of friendship and romance, the movie feels like any likable, and generally forgettable, teen comedy. And yet with its casually handled twist, the genre ambles forward just a little bit.

It's a movie about being true to yourself that's reluctant to let its real character show. At any point that it looks likely to tweak sex-comedy convention or get truly weird, it reverses course at the last minute.
The subject certainly isn't dated, but the film's dull post-John Hughes, sub-Judd Apatow style of comedy is like a just-buried time capsule full of accumulated clichs.
Date And Switch is a plucky step in the right direction for diversity in teen comedies, but it lacks the extra oomph to stand on its own merits.

In place of authentic emotion and searing personal communication, there's cliche and passivity, plasticizing the kindly nature of the picture to a point where all the tension begins to resemble a bad sitcom.
"Date and Switch" should have had something new to say about high school friendships. It doesn't.
Bloodline can't figure out its message, and the characters are nowhere near interesting enough to overcome the muddled themes of the film
Would that Romero could arise like one of his creations, just to take a nasty bite out of this cheap "reimagining" of one of his movies and consign it to a genre graveyard where nothing comes back.
Day Of The Dead: Bloodline somehow dethrones 2008's earlier remake attempt as an even more forgettable "reimagining" (aka rip-off).
A complete waste of time, taking part in what's now become a bad movie tradition: watching dismal filmmakers botch Romero's relatively simple zombie outbreak.
Buckets of stale blood in zombie apocalypse tale.
If you're hungry for a good zombie homage to Romero's work, look no further than Zack Snyder's Dawn of the Dead. Bloodline is just plain rotten.
Day of the Dead: Bloodline is dead on arrival, with no hope of reanimation.
Day of the Dead: Bloodline  tries to update the classic with a 'Me Too' angle and the results are mixed, but the classic zombie carnage makes up for it.
The peak moment of Malick's career where he found the perfect blend of a respectful command of storytelling versus the more abstract submission to a cinema of the senses.
Ethereal, gorgeous, and evocative.
A truly beautiful photographed film.
It is the closest to poetry in motion that I have ever seen.
This is the towering, unconventional power of a true artist.
The images of workers in their landscape look like impressionist paintings that cinematographer Almendros creates on the screen with the natural light of his locations.
Days of Heaven (1978) is an exquisite, lyrical film of exceptional visual beauty and only the second film of writer-director Terrence Malick,
[A] masterpiece.
One of the most visually impressive American films ever made, Days of Heaven fulfilled the promise that Terrence Malick had shown in Badlands
For Malick, Man is just a small part of a world which just keeps going round with or without his petty squabbles, crimes, loves, or melodramatic plots.
This is a movie made by a man who knew how something felt, and found a way to evoke it in us.
Almost incontestably the most gorgeously photographed film ever made.
You can feel Terrence Malick drifting away in this follow-up to his acclaimed debut.
It is among the most startlingly beautiful of color films. But it is not beauty for beauty's sake... The seemingly random shots have a divine order to them.
One of the great cinematic achievements of the 1970s.
A love story that despite its dramatic ending, skies, fires, and ode to nature doesn't manage to move us much. [Full Review in Spanish]
Wholly divine.
What remains is a haunting sense of waywardness, of the drifting millions who have toiled away on fields and in factories, fading into the American past, unnoticed.
So beautiful that it touches heaven itself.
Malick's magnum opus shimmers with the sensuality of a languorous summer afternoon.
Completely preposterous (I had no clue that Nascar allowed essentially bumper car antics), but nevertheless entertaining.
Whatever they call this movie, it's nothing more than a puffed-up sequel to Top Gun. If you saw Top Gun, you can anticipate every twist and turn, every screeching spinout of Days of Thunder.
It oughtn't be good, at least. Not with that script. And yet it's so much better than the combined quality of its elements.
There are plenty of soulless movies around. What's special about Days of Thunder is that it works overtime trying to convince you it's not one of them.
The story is predictably pedestrian, the conflict laughable and the dialogue too lifeless to be laughable, but closer to that than convincing or compelling.
For race car enthusiasts, Days of Thunder is a treat with great action scenes.
A vanity piece for Tom Cruise, who makes sure that he looks even prettier than co-star Nicole Kidman.
An unofficial "sideways sequel" to Top Gun...except with national treasure Robert Duvall in the role of crusty mentor.
An earthbound Top Gun. In circles.
'90s race-car blockbuster has sexism, profanity.
The flash is still there, but Towne has added a layer of substance underneath, and in generous enough helpings that you can let the picture vamp you, ravage you, without hating yourself afterward.
An entertainment of great skill but predictable construction.
If you liked Top Gun, you stand a good chance of liking Days of Thunder.
Dispensing with all notions that Days of Thunder is a critical work of any sort reveals its hollow and misogynistic underpinnings.
For die-hard Cruise fans and car mechanics only.
Producers Don Simpson and Jerry Bruckheimer have raised formula films to a science.

Like the previous Simpson-Bruckheimer pictures, it's designed to give audiences an overdose of the thrill of victory; it wants us to jump out of our seats, pumping our fists in the air and roaring for the hero to pulverize his opponents.
Exactly what it promises to be: Not Much -- but at dizzying speed, stripped down and free of wind-resistant subtlety. There's a certain integrity to that. A certain deafening integrity.
Cars. Cars cars cars cars. Vroom! Vroom vroom vroom! Crash! Tom and Nicole have sex! Cars cars vroom vroom! Crash! Vroom!
The most awesome technical feat of Days of Thunder's massive gadgetry is Cruise in close-up.
Branagh's contemporary American accent is annoying, and the film's constant inter-cutting of past and present lives becomes laughable.
Awesome mystery. The afterlife subplot works perfectly and sells the surprise twist.
Dead Again marks a wise career move for Branagh, who was touted the new Olivier after the triumph of his surprisingly good remake of Henry V two years ago.
Kenneth Branagh constructs a lush, compelling romantic noir, working beautifully with then-wife Emma Thompson.
A big, convoluted, entertainingly dizzy romantic mystery melodrama. It's also another coup de cinema for Mr. Branagh.
A film that is filled to the brim with energy, bravaura, and unbridled passion, a film that speaks only in broad strokes and leaves one feeling completely satisfied by its wild conclusion.
The movie isn't just unpretentious; it's garishly, thrillingly vulgar.
A decent thriller with a more than decent twist.
Really pretty lame.
A miscalculation from a prodigious talent who has forgotten that you squeeze the life out of romance when you don't give it space to breathe.

Deadpool is at once a welcome antidote to the played out superhero universe and an anomaly, destined to be trapped in its spandexed outliers.
Deadpool is essentially the world's first superhero fan movie.
[Reynolds] brings a ton of compassion and manic energy ... [but Deadpool] is a cartoon in the real world that never goes crazy enough.
What makes Deadpool a very, very special member of the Marvel Universe is that he rides that Bugs Bunny plane of existence where he has a direct, ongoing conversation with us, the audience.
The LGBT movement gets an ostensibly unwelcome filmic addition in the guise of Ryan Reynolds's wisecracking bi-sexual mercenary Wade Wilson.
"Deadpool" is the fast-paced (gory), action-packed (violent) and hilarious (incredibly off-color) comic book movie that we needed, but had no idea we did until it came along.
For a film obviously positioned as a franchise starter, its sardonic antihero takes a new path during his origin story, and his big-screen debut stands capably on its own.
Tries to rebel but it's as insubordinate as a kid wearing a Megadeth T-shirt to Church on a Sunday, but an okay break from saving the world.

Irreverent, outrageous, and strewn with self-aware commentary and dark humor, Deadpool (2016) is as different a comic book superhero movie from the self-serious Man of Steel and Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice as you'll find.
Something incredible has happened. Ryan Reynolds has finally found a vehicle worth his talents: bringing Deadpool to life and giving the superhero genre just the right smack it needs.
DP is a lot more fun than most superheroes, but the film is barely able to take advantage.
kudos to Fox for having the stones to give this one the full inappropriate R-rated treatment.
Deadpool is the perfecto film for those who want a superhero movie that embraces everything that's polliticaly incorrect. [Full review in Spanish]

You've heard the story Deadpool tells a million times before; but the attitude with which it is told here makes it feel fresh and as close to innovative as you're going to see in a tentpole blockbuster anytime soon.
Ryan Reynolds was born in a damn lab to play this role, and T.J. Miller is equally good as possibly the most realistic superhero sidekick ever.

From the moment the film begins and you see the words "directed by an overpaid tool" and "produced by a-hats" on screen, you know "Deadpool" isn't going to be like any other superhero movie you've seen before.

A lively and deeply funny course in Race in America 101: Intro to White Privilege.
Sadly, Simien would rather introduce confrontational mischief than actually show his homework.
It holds a comic lens up to the love-hate relationship between the races in all its contradictions. And it is a portrait of post-racial America as the symbiotic clashing of opposite polarities.
Clearly a work by a young director, the film comes at you with a torrent of sharp dialogue, multiple characters and a traffic jam of scenes and story points.
Dear White People is less than the sum of its very polished parts -- a first feature that's just impressive enough to be frustrating.
The film takes a clear-eyed approach to the complex subject of racial identity and leavens it with wit.
Good films create buzz, but movies like Dear White People create conversations.
There won't be a smarter or funnier screenplay this year (or more striking feature directorial debut), and that is just the basis for this surprising , wonderful and quite definitive college film.
An astute and funny film built around an impressively layered script and an appealing ensemble cast that broaches the delicate issue of race in an honest, sensible way.
Smart, unique, and distinct, this feature won't be easy to forget.
Dear White People succeeds because it delivers its message with common sense and wisdom instead of a heavy hand.
Simien's caustic message resonates at many levels: If you want to change the world, be sure to bring good snacks.
Where it scores big is its wealth of ideas-visual, emotional, cultural-and its deep well of bitter, voice-of-experience rage
Viewers will spend more time waiting for the next witty retort than feeling moved or challenged. Dear White People is not sure whether it's an essay or a film, which means it's not quite either.
It's true that satire is the perfect weapon of reason, and Justin Simien deploys it with resourcefulness, cool assurance and eagle-eyed aim.
Simien helms with style to spare but makes sure the emphasis is firmly on substance, as he offers great insight into the contradictions and concerns of young black culture.
Sufficiently provocative to raise important issues and cheeky enough to remain entertaining while doing so.
For this sort of satire to land, it needs pace and energy that the oddly whispery "Dear White People" lacks.
As straightforward of a satire as Dear White People is, it also can be looked at as a symbol of the problems it is trying to tackle.
A film that's as honest about the complexities and contradictions of identity as we're likely to see in a movie theater this year.
A mannered guilt trip melodrama made with a great deal of difficulty under the Franco regime.
[Transposes] the ugliness of power relations in a repressive society to the spheres of sex and gossip.
Explicitly designed as a shock to the system, Death of a Cyclist too often settles for academic subversion.
Imagine a Michelangelo Antonio drama of upper class disaffection by way of a film noir...
The film is a leftist commentary on bourgeois Spain under Franco, but its passion and sensitive observation transcend its political intent.

Juan Antonio Bardem still manages to paint an unflattering portrait of the Madrid bourgeoisie, with its self-indulgence, hypocrisy and shameless ambition contrasting unfavourably with the dignity of the poor and the anger of the young.
The result is a dramatic story that deeply resonates with the cultural anxieties that Spanish society endured under the regime of General Francisco Franco.
Death Of A Cyclist addresses all the grievances that Bardem mentioned at Salamanca, and it succeeds most at capturing the general climate of fear and oppression in Franco's Spain.
The critical voice and audacity of some scenes... suggest that the censor, Pascal Cebollada, fells asleep during its projection. [Full Review in Spanish]
A very interesting work that contributed to the expansion of Spanish cinema. [Full Review in Spanish]

The concepts, struggles, and ideologies here aren't exaggerated. They're refracted, the film absentmindedly chasing its own tail while the world evolves around it.

By polishing the edges off, "Death Wish (2018)" fails to distinguish itself. It's just another revenge tale, where the deafening sound of gunfire neatly ties up all the loose ends.
Death Wish takes the original Charles Bronson film and updates it for today. Unfortunately, like most modern remakes of down and dirty movies of the 1970s, it feels so watered down.
This movie, a remake of the 1974 Charles Bronson film of the same name, is bad. But it's not the type of bad that's enjoyable or comedic - it takes itself too seriously for that.
Death Wish is a poorly timed rebuttal. And a pretty lousy one at that.
This should've been fun. Alas, it most certainly is not.

That rare made-for-Netflix comedy funny enough to have found an audience on the big screen.

A family adventure of the classic variety, with fresh talent in control, especially director Freeland.

Even with all the bells and whistles, and the introduction of a clever villain, Despicable Me 3 wears out its welcome quickly and turns into an overstuffed excursion that eventually becomes more exhausting than entertaining.

Exemplifies [Michel] Ocelot's lifetime contributions to a medium that, more and more, settles for fluff.

It's absolutely astonishing to look at, a lovely visit to the City of Lights that quite literally glows... but the [English language] voice actors are all so wooden, they sound like the result of a translation program.
'Dilili in Paris' is a kid-friendly, family film that takes viewers on an epic journey throughout Paris. Ocelot's attention to detail makes this animated film a must see.
It is both an old story, and one that we must continue to tell.
The English dubbed dialogue is wobbly, but the progressive themes are brought to life by the charming young protagonist and the evocative hand-drawn visuals.

Dilili in Paris won't completely fit the bill for its expressed modernist purpose, but children and adults would enjoy it for its staunch defence of just causes and its more than loveable main character.

Photorealistic backgrounds consistently stun as they clash with the more low-res CG characters, which emulate designs from early 21st century video games rather than fully accomplished animated characters for a production made this decade.
"Dilili in Paris" is instead an awkward misfire, the more regrettably so for showcasing a kind, smart and brave mixed-race girl from New Caledonia as its young protagonist.
A kind of artistic and scientific amusement park. [Full Review in Spanish]
First off, let me praise "Dilili in Paris" for its outstanding CGI animation that captures perfectly, the City of Lights."
A French animated film about justice for women.
At the end of the day, Dilili in Paris reaches its intended demographic with grace and a liberal amount of playfulness, truly embodying the gleeful period of French history it embeds itself within.
Too cerebral for children, yet too haphazardly constructed to satisfy adults.

Playfully celebrating Asian cuisine (every scene displays food), this family melodrama deals with the erosion of traditional values.

...the performances are all note-perfect.

We get to know the people - mostly women, but a few men - whose hands create these intricate, beautiful garments.
The excess detailed in the Saint Laurent films is well behind us - which is good for Simons' health, but perhaps not so good for documentary viewers looking for something beyond formulaic structures.

This exceptional [cross cutting] structure allows the past to continue informing the present, reaching a climax after lights out in the ateliers, Tcheng projecting old Dior imagery over the white toiles that are the blueprints of Simons' first collection.
"Dior & I" is just good drama, quite moving and suspenseful as it shows talented and creative people pushing themselves to the edge. No matter how nice our clothes are, we're all human underneath.
The heart of Dior and I is with these seamstresses and cutters, artists in their own right.
Access to an institution like the house of Dior is a rare and precious thing, and Mr. Tcheng has paid for it with a flattering portrait dressed up to look like cleareyed scrutiny.
As Tcheng gets his cameras into the day-to-day operations of the Dior atelier, the movie becomes a portrait of the process - the hierarchies and traditions that turn ideas into wearable art.
Tcheng gets under Simons' skin - we see the designer's methods of work, insecurities, vulnerabilities and his ability to cut through the noise.
Much more than a documentary about a fashion house, this film finds real resonance in its central characters
J'adore "Dior and I."
This undramatic and flat peek "inside" the sewing rooms of Christian Dior holds little in the way of entertainment.

Of special interest to a limited audience, this backstage look at fashion design at the house of Christian Dior will tell you what you always wanted to know about the most elite segment of the rag trade.
If only "Dior and I" told us why we should care.
As carefully crafted as the clothes is Tcheng's well-considered direction, privileging the creative process over stereotyped glamour or backstabbing (this is no Ready to Wear).

A film in an almost journalistic documentary format or reality show and also, almost, a dedication of love. But here, the object of that love is much nobler than we could imagine at first. [Full review in Spanish]
One does come away with a grudging admiration for the toil and ingenuity of the many players who bring it all together.

A few gauzy montages of black-and-white archival footage glorify the fashion house's founder and namesake, providing a welcome interruption to all the self-serving confessionals and stage-managed conflicts.
Dior and I expertly observes all aspects of Simons' stressful transition, especially in the minutiae of being both an artist and a manager.
Though the film is unquestionably a flattering portrait of Simons, it is also more broadly, and more fruitfully, a testament to a tradition and to those who have upheld it for decades.
Viewers become so involved in their proficient, collaborative activity that the catwalk spectacle is almost dull in comparison.
I awaited the closing scenes of Disgrace with a special urgency, because the story had gripped me deeply but left me with no idea how it would end. None -- and I really cared.
A perfectly cast John Malkovich gives a superb performance in a powerful and intelligent study of a man coming back from the brink.
The film struggles in its attempt to balance the thought-provoking overtones with the human drama at its core.
The screen version does not disappoint and features an outstanding performance from John Malkovich.
This chilly film gets surprisingly close to the tone of Coetzee's precise prose.

It's not Coetzee's assertion that the white minority South Africans must go a ways toward assimilating into African life to remain relevant that invites deep scrutiny, but the narrow vision presented here of Africanization as something akin to wilding.
It's hard to say what this solid but unadventurous film adds to Coetzee's powerful source material.
An unfocused and contrived drama that lacks a palpable emotional core, but John Malkovich's raw performance makes it at least marginally engaging.
I cannot tell a lie. I derive great satisfaction watching John Malkovich act.

A worthwhile film which is concerned to do the right thing by a modern classic.
Desire and its consequences are at the heart of this complex drama that has the power to shred us emotionally.

Of all the people one might think of, watching this appropriately disturbing film translation of Nobel Laureate J. M. Coetzee's heralded novel, I never imagined I'd be thinking of Michael Vick. But there you have it.
This is a most unusual Australian film, but a very powerful one.
Surprisingly successful adaptation.

Disgrace is an ugly movie, at times torturous to watch. It probably needs to be.

A faithful, compelling screen adaptation of J. M. Coetzee's Booker Prize-winning 1999 novel.

Undoubtedly, the movie's makers sat down to several screenings of Divorce Italian Style with pencils and pads in hand and mapped out American counterpart situations. But the ideas do gain in the American translation.
Debbie Reynolds and Dick Van Dyke are gruesomely well-cast.
Brilliant comic turns from Christoph Waltz and Samuel L. Jackson help string together this audience-pleasing, highly uneven Quentin Tarantino spaghetti western/slave vengeance mash-up.
Ultimately enjoyable, if a little underwhelming, if nothing else we can be grateful to Django Unchained for allowing the phrase "that's the worst thing since Quentin Tarantino's Australian accent".

Yes, the sublime strays to the ridiculous. But all the while I just keep picturing Tarantino behind the camera re-imagining history and whispering to himself, This is so cool! If you like his style, this is another winner.
As hellish as its moral universe may be, those whose stomachs can handle the descent will find that even in Tarantino's world-perhaps especially in his world-those moral questions still matter.
Django Unchained is classic Tarantino.
Tarantino takes a no-holds-barred approach and delivers another well-written, ultra-violent spectacle masked as a spaghetti western.

Tarantino is, in essence, a classicist who invests the bulk of his drama and tension in lengthy dialogue exchanges that are infinitely more compelling that his elongated sequences of cathartic violence.
a better grindhouse tribute film and spaghetti western homage than his previous two movies combined
A supremely entertaining, richly cinematic treat, which manages to work in some fun (and often very humorous) genre subversions and engaging character nuance amongst the frenetic gunplay.
...as a fun-filled tribute to those older, cheesier genres, Django Unchained absolutely works, and aside from being overlong is a pleasure to view. But it isn't more than that
If you're willing to accept its utterly over-the-top attitude you'll find it almost absurdly enjoyable.
''Django Unchained'' is Tarantino at his most puerile and least inventive, the premise offering little more than cold, nasty revenge and barrels of squishing, squirting blood.
There's a lot of lunacy in Django Unchained.
Genre-movie-mad writer-director Quentin Tarantino's foray into Western World is a pretty grave disappointment.
The film's triumph is the manner in which Tarantino re-envisions cinema's selective appropriation of history and makes it entirely his own
"Django Unchained" possesses an unmistakable subversive power, its playfully insurrectionist spirit perhaps the modern-day pop-culture equivalent of far more high stakes rebellions of yore.
No-one does humour in violence like Tarantino.... Hell's bells, there is a lot to take in and soak up in this hotdog Tarantino Western. It's a killer
A fine example of unabashed bloodletting in the context of the two worst applications of capitalism in our history, bounty hunting and slavery.
A lesser work by one of America's most ebullient auteurs.
For pure movie enjoyment -- or movie geek (I plead guilty) enjoyment, if you insist -- I hadn't had this much plain fun in a while.
every once in a while, a movie will come along that turns me into that annoying specimen of humanity that I usually dread encountering the most - The Fanboy
There are brilliant practical effects on show, particularly in the shaggy lycanthropes, and all the carnage you could possibly desire.
Falls back mainly on army squad clich√©s and rote conflicts, along the way delivering a group of protagonists woefully short on personality.
One of the best, coolest, most action-packed horror films in years.
I'm convinced I could keep a family of five blind, crippled, Amish people alive in this situation better than these British soldiers do at keeping themselves kicking.
Gloriously goofy (and gory) midnight movie stuff.
There is a welcome lack of pretension about the film, which very simply sets out to entertain and ends up delivering in good measure.
Though it's derivative, Marshall has chosen wisely for his source of influence, fashioning an impressive action/horror hybrid with enough good ideas to overcome the faults.

Dog Soldiers is an incredible showcase of Marshall's (then) burgeoning talent, bursting with raw action & demonstrating you don't always need a huge budget if you know how to create a fiercely compelling story.
Dog Soldiers remains Marshall's most potent distillation of taut action, unrelenting horror, and gallows humor.
One of those 'exception to the rule' horror movies in which a little humour and a lot of effort go a very long way.
If you like blood, guts and crazy beasts stalking men with guns though... you will likely enjoy this monster.

A rip-roaring comedy action fest that'll put hairs on your chest.

For these poets, writing is a form of activism; poetry is their song. I found the film to be inspiring and moving.
Captures the revitalization of the artist in a world filled with doom.
The art of the spoken word, at its most powerful.

A documentary that reveals the power of poetry to speak truth to power.
Small - intimate perhaps a more appropriate word - but bursting at the seams with fire, creativity, rage and artistic love.
A finely observed documentary about a national slam poetry competition that rises above its traditional format to find the personal profundity in the art form.
If you ever want to slip into your local poetry slam, Don't Be Nice is the perfect primer for your experience. It will blow away your preconceptions and show you the art inside the artist.
Slam poetry makes the spoken word an emotional sport for a young generation of aspiring poets.
It's a fascinating combination of reality show, coming-of-age story, social critique, and literary boot camp.
Intense biopic full of drugs, sex and rock'n'roll.
Morrison is played with uncanny authenticity by Val Kilmer. The performance is utterly convincing without being terribly illuminating.
Lumbers semi-coherently through Morrison's life, touching only tangentially on those who were most important to him.
One of the great rock 'n' roll documentaries. Val Kilmer is astounding.
a pretentious movie about a man haunted by a naked Indian
Kilmer is convincing in the lead role, although he never allows the viewer to share any emotions.

Val Kilmer does, however, pull off a remarkable impression of the troubled vocalist, although he's more convincing on stage than he is in his drunken, drug-fuelled reveries.
Much of the movie is ridiculous: Stone has never known restraint. But it's also enjoyable in a jittery, hyperbolic way, and parts of it are undeniably moving.

Stone is not the most subtle of directors, but he has the ability to translate his passion for subject matter (he's an unabashed admirer of Morrison) to the screen with a strong visual flair. That talent in evidence here.
Watching the movie is like being stuck in a bar with an obnoxious drunk, when you're not drinking.

Whatever reservations one may have about this exhausting, dark-side-of-the-'60s epic, there can be little doubt that Stone has captured a particular, bombs-away brand of rock & roll excess with definitive candor.
It seems more the glorification of an alcoholic jerk than a cautionary tale.
Val Kilmer gives an amazing, almost pathologically correct performance in Oliver Stone's excessive but highly enjoyable biopic about Jim Morrison.
Ultimately, it's the music that tells you more about the nihilism of Jim Morrison than Oliver Stone ever could.
Oliver Stone's The Doors is a grandiose, highly kinetic, film that flourishes in its own excess.

For a while, the obviousness and flat-out vulgarity are sort of entertaining, and it might be possible to enjoy the movie as a camp classic if you could ignore the mean-spiritedness that keeps breaking through.
The movie is weighed down by its enchantment with the mythology, as opposed to the reality, of Morrison's life -- a mythology that needs to be explored, not simply reproduced on the wide screen.
The Doors plays out like an epic hangover one expects to never recover from.
The film really proves only that Jim was a bad drunk and a worse friend, and that in no way was his life exemplary.
I would rather suffer whiplash in a VW bug than sit through this film again.
Aimless and weird- like looking at a beautiful two dimensional picture postcard - but from the edge.

Not really all that much fun.
[Director Kris Isacsson] tries to bring a little enterprise to the inevitable scenes of bickering and moody silence, but by now the vitalising tactics seem out of place.

Down to You is filled with all sorts of hokey moments that ruin its attempts to generate a pseudo-real, romantic atmosphere.
Down to You is bad. Real bad.
Both Julia Stiles and Freddie Prinze Jr. deserve better.
Lamely written and directed.

Never rises above being merely skin-deep.

Beautifully shot and often moving.
A beautifully articulated and acutely perceptive work with impeccable, carefully shaded performances.
