...has real affection for the vaudeville world it depicts.
You'll have plenty of ammunition next time you want to tell some Bible-thumper where they can stick their Leviticus.
The case made by those interviewed in For The Bible Tells Me So is strong, and, at times, moved me greatly.
[For] The Bible Tells Me So must be the first liberal documentary to resist Bible-bashing for Bible-thumping.
[Director] Karslake balances the more emotional elements of the film together with the scriptural analysis and weaves them into a moving conclusion.
Its main surprise is the compassion shown toward everyone, on all sides of the debate. It does not vilify those who vilify gays.
With impressive conviction, vast intelligence and even humor, Karslake has made a vital, stimulating wor
Karslake has made a powerful film ...it addresses the fulcrum of the religious right's objection to homosexuality without attacking those who hold those beliefs.

Progressive clergy provide enough historical context to neutralize the handful of Bible verses prohibiting homosexual acts, but Karslake never confronts the broader issues of sexuality and procreation that bedevil even moderate Christians.

The point that the homophobic right is picking and choosing which parts of the Bible to follow, and which verses to look at in the context in which they were written, is both terribly familiar and rudimentarily argued.
A brisk, entertaining and even moving exploration of the sometimes frayed intersection where Christianity meets homosexuality.
More human interest than agitprop.
A gut-wrenching depiction of what truly defines Family Values.

For the Bible Tells Me So is never less than lively and stimulating in its arguments, even detouring into a very amusing cartoon dealing with the evidence that sexual orientation is biologically determined.

While the movie seems tilted toward Christian families attempting to work through issues of having a gay son or daughter, "For the Bible Tells Me So" fills a yet another heretofore blank chapter on Gay rights.

As long as it's dissecting the six or seven passages in the Bible that ostensibly disparage homosexuality, this documentary ode to tolerance takes a shrewd look at how speciously selective and ahistorical the church condemnation of gays really is.
A masterfully crafted, deeply moving work that could spark much needed conversations.
If imperfect, the film is also necessary.
The documentary takes a witty and compassionate view of what coming out in a religious family feels like, both to adult gay kids and their bewildered parents.

Daniel Karslake's remarkable documentary boldly takes on a loaded topic -- Christianity and homosexuality -- and examines it both intellectually and emotionally; the result may well leave you blinking away a few tears.
While you might not agree with all -- or any -- of the movie's conclusions, there's no denying that it's effective and often intelligent filmmaking.
This 1975 melodrama by Rainer Werner Fassbinder is one of his better middle-period films.
Fox's journey downward is more of a straight shot than a spiral.
Not for a moment does Fassbinder indulge our fantasies that Fox's tryst might be working toward a happy ending.
An ace snapshot from 27 years ago that still feels contemporary and pressing.

Make no mistake, this is the real Queer as Folk, but for all of Fassbinder's gripes with an elite gay culture's many sexual hang-ups, Fox and His Friends is first and foremost a riveting evocation of Social Darwinism in action.
Entertaining but oddly parsed coming of age tale. For Fassbinder enthusiasts only.
The film's stark relentlessness has power to move an audience.
Here is a movie about characters who define themselves by their sexuality, but the movie doesn't. It takes the sexuality as a given, and defines them by their values and morals.
It excludes all life that is not within the very narrow intentions of its author. Its pores have been painted over.
One of Rainer Werner Fassbinder's brilliant melodramas from the 1970s.
One of Fassbinder's own personal favorites, the powerful Fox and His Friends may also be the greatest gay film ever made.
This melodramatic fable of emotional extremes is sharp and precise-nowhere more than in Fassbinder's attention to the price of domestic comforts and industrial necessities.

the central relationship fits the dramatic requirements and dutifully fulfills its mission of acting as a microcosm for the insidious nature of social and economic manipulation, but it never feels real

Brute beauty... quietly savage 1975 x-ray of the exploitation of a simple man... startles with its dense, concrete tapestry of trashy fairgrounds and garishly tasteless apartments and bolthole gay bars and swimming pools and horrifying exploitation.

Offers the most intimate look thus far into the complex and probing psyche of [Rainer Werner Fassbinder] who, although only in his early 30s, is already making significant contributions to the art of filmmaking as an actor, writer and director.

Great cure for insomnia.
Not one of the better Hammer sequels, but still enjoyable for its wild concept.
Good horror treatment as expected by the Hammer folks.

hardly lives up to its promise, or even its title.
Blame producer Chad Troutwine for bringing together an array of talented documentary filmmakers to try to coax life into material certainly not suited to the medium of film.

Amiably passes the time.

Succeeds in provoking thoughts about ethics, pop culture, and human nature, and that isn't an easy thing to do.
An unusual cinematic experiment that comes off as a hit-and-miss collection of appetizers.
There's an appealing sort of crazy, on the surface, to Freakonomics... [But it] sounds for all the world as if [the film] is mocking Freakonomics [the theory].
With different filmmakers handling each segment, some obviously work better than others, but either way it is the book.
Look, I enjoyed Freakonomics, I just can't really say how much so mainly because I'm still having issues buying all the information past on here as mathematical fact.
Sometimes, it has all the answers. More often, it just asks the right questions. And in today's 24-hour froth of insta-pundit analysis, we need curiosity more than certainty.
Some parts of the movie are more satisfying and intriguing than others, but there are enough surprising and non-intuitive revelations that even the most jaded viewer will likely learn a thing or two.
A real hodgepodge of ideas and themes, directed by six different directors, it lacks cohesion. It does, however, have some interesting segments.
Moderately interesting documentary.
On this take from a statistician whose days are, um, numbered: the docu-omnibus engages, as we wonder what the next filmmaker might do. Proving Levitt's theory that incentives do indeed matter.
...while the resulting film is often entertaining, it's also random, it's ideas not well articulated.
At the center is the quietly exciting notion that numbers can be used to both mask the truth and reveal it, depending on the character of who's holding the calculator.
While not as thoroughly informative or entertaining as it could have been under the control of a single director, "Freakonomics" is a thought-provoking documentary that keeps you wanting more.
A parade of tasteless, stupid and utterly flat jokes.
[A] cynical creative and emotional vacuum of a movie.
In an industry of largely abject cowardice, Green's fearlessness is invigorating.
Green just comes off as one of those weird, fey guys who's a lot less interesting than he thinks he is.
Doesn't resonate the way a good slob-comedy should.
I have gotten better entertainment value from a colonoscopy.
A movie so unrelentingly gross, disgusting and imbecilic that one mourns for the state of humanity while watching it.
Offers nothing more than the chance for Tom Green the actor to just be as insane and disgusting as possible without an arbiter to help him sort out the funny from the way unfunny.
The writing is too weak to sustain the story between sight gags.
What's really disgusting about this movie is how easy, cheap and lazy the shocks it delivers are.

In a sense, this is a horror film, worse than anything Andy Kaufman could dream up, in which Green tries to outgross himself.
It slaps us in the face and asks us to hate it at every turn. Mission accomplished.
Doesn't push the limits of taste so much as the limits of how bad a movie can be.

Green's ever-upped ante of shock speaks of a desperation that borders on mental illness.
...the most sick and vile work of comedy ever put on the theater screen.
Watch this only if you'd like to see Green lick the exposed bone of his best friend.
A vomitorium consisting of 93 minutes of Tom Green doing things that a geek in a carnival sideshow would turn down.
This wasn't a 'movie' after all, but rather just some funny sketches that Tom Green thought would be humorous to incorporate into a motion picture.
There is a majesty to whales that the second Willy movie trivialized. Part three returns to some of the human elements that made the first movie so good.
A film that treats its human audience with as much respect as its less-evolved subjects.

Not exactly a whale of a time, but worthwhile
For devoted -- and young -- Willy fans only.

Glibly shocking, it would like you to think it deals with the hard realities of urban life, but in fact it uses its patina of social consciousness as a come-on for the most conventional kind of violent commercial filmmaking.
It takes a bit to get going, but once it does, Fresh never lets up.

[Fresh] is urgently lyrical, right down to its final, haunting image. And in lead performer Sean Nelson, first-time filmmaker Yakin has a 12-year-old breath of fresh air whose beatific face could launch a thousand scripts.
[Fresh is] made with a subtle precision that suggests a Vermeer landscape of the ninth circle of hell.

The strength of the piece is that it realises which aspects of its genre have been seen too many times, always coming back to Nelson's blank but expressive stare as he watches terrible things the director doesn't need to shove in our faces.
A stylish, affecting, ingeniously plotted first feature.
A hugely underrated crime drama, Fresh is worth discovering both for its air of authenticity and Sean Nelson's remarkable performance.
With a script as smart as the title character, Fresh keeps its viewers guessing.

An unpredictable and harrowing story that works on the surface as an unconventional thriller (an intricate plot) and underneath as a powerful story of love, sacrifice, willpower and the dehumanizing cost of violence and revenge.
The script by writer-director Boaz Yakin is fresh itself, marrying the physical violence of Fresh's world with the intellectual violence of competitive chess.
I left Fresh with my mouth literally hanging open, affected to the bone by a spectacular piece of storytelling.
Screenwriter Boaz Yakin makes a stunning directorial debut with "Fresh," the gripping, finely acted tale of a 12- year-old's life on the mean streets of New York.
A gripping story of survival on the streets and survival of the soul.
This directorial debut by Boaz Yakin works its disturbing magic with all-too-realistic violence and finely drawn characters.

Here's a movie filled with drama and excitement, unfolding a plot of brilliant complexity, in which the central character is solemn and silent, saying only what he has to say, revealing himself only strategically.
It's rigorous and quite depressing fare.
The movie's two instincts are at complete odds with each other.

I enjoy both Timberlake and Kunis; just this side of manic, they seem right together.

You should always be ashamed of yourself if you are copying Ashton Kutcher.
Though it aims to upend the increasingly defunct romantic-comedy genre, Friends With Benefits quickly falls prey to the same clichs.
For its first two-thirds, Friends With Benefits is a welcome tonic, a sharply funny and raunchy rebuke against the worn-out cliches of romantic comedies.
It's just sad that a movie suggesting an honest and zesty approach to sex and relationships builds to such a conventional ending...
The problem with Friends with Benefits is that its attempts to be more daring and clever than the average rom-com feel earnest and pretentious.
It is one of the freshest and funniest romantic comedies of the summer.
Gluck is clearly whip smart and he likes his films that way. This all to the good, but much of "Friends with Benefits" comes off as too showy in its cleverness.
Kunis and Timberlake really do have chemistry, as well as comic timing. When his tender glances meet her sly conspiratorial smile, it's genuinely fun to watch.
All of these quirky details felt like independent pieces crammed together for the sake of edginess.
Friends with Benefits is raunchy, funny and ultimately quite sweet - fluffy enough to stay fun and smart enough to stand out from the herd.
Justin Timberlake proves that his performance in "The Social Network" was not a fluke and Mila Kunitz is both beautiful and funny.

"Friends With Benefits" is often uproariously and profanely funny, and anchored in high-spirited performances from its central duo, who are well matched as comic foils if oddly lacking in erotic electricity.
In the world of the contemporary Hollywood romantic comedy, it is in fact not possible for two straight BFFs of the opposite sex to sleep together and not fall in love.
It's smart, sexy and moderately amusing.
The script exhausts its originality awfully quickly, with subsequent hookups recycling jokes from other movies.
It may be as predictable as a sunrise, but Friends with Benefits manages to rise above the familiarity of the material.
Timberlake and Kunis manage to bring sexy and funny back to the otherwise exhausted rom-com genre.
Lacks the courage of its anti-rom-com convictions, but still crackles with cleverness and wit.
The film's negative, narrow-minded opinion of anyone who isn't a Caucasian American is truly disturbing. Despite the title, the City of Light gets no love here.

one of the more entertaining and engaging pop entertainments to come along in a while despite its excesses and even because of them at certain points.

mayhem, intrigue, and the occasional, nicely calibrated, fits of whimsy

Frequently charming.

Gabrielle, the character and the performer, is someone to root for.
...an endearing and engaging little drama that benefits substantially from Marion-Rivard's captivating turn as the central character.
Archambault tackles potentially uncomfortable subject matter with both empathy and frankness.

On the surface, it's a simple love story: girl meets boy, girl likes boy, girl kisses boy. But Louise Archambault's Gabrielle is much more... a deeply affecting tale of difference, dignity and the healing power of song.
Quebecois writer/director Louise Archambault's sophomore feature is a skillfully told celebration of the human spirit.
Writer-director Louise Archambault uses a free and easy camera style and mosaic-like editing to suggest how intensely Gabrielle responds to elements of everyday life.
It isn't entirely free of sugar, and by the end loses sight of the qualities that initially made it so engaging.
Instead of a message movie, Gabrielle is a romance and an unusual kind of musical that seamlessly integrates special needs actors with the other cast members.
Archambault's handling of Gabrielle and Martin's sexuality is one of the pic's strong suits, presenting their desire with a refreshing, straightforward honesty.

A mediocre to average movie with a stellar performance by Keaton and cerebral themes about failure and fears that stay fuzzy instead of coming into sharp focus.
For fans of DeLillo, Keaton and/or either team in that classic Series, this curious little picture is worth tracking down.

As a Sox fan and a writer, Game 6 spoke to me. Viewers without interest in baseball, DeLillo or criticism, may feel that the movie is just a short trip to nowhere.
An acutely observed study of a man haunted by the looming prospect of failure, Game 6 turns out to be a small-scale triumph.
The big problem here is one of credibility, on a number of fronts.

The film is meandering and highly uneven, but Robert Downey Jr. is truly oddball as a venomous drama critic, and watching that ball once again roll through Bill Buckner's legs is torture (for Red Sox fans anyway).
as much crap as one would expect

... the sober approach slips into silliness with a giddy space age ending%u2014and ultimately that's the film's charm.
Gamera has no qualms about incinerating an entire club filled with anti-authoritarian beatniks with his fiery breath, but saves a small annoying boy from falling to his death!
Silly, nonsensical, incoherent, and wildly unconvincing, and there's not a single frame of it that isn't hilarious.
Moving, credible and tragic.
It's a beautifully shot and staged period reconstruction, and is at times impressively acted, at least in the secondary roles. What it lacks is fresh insight.
Decently acted but ponderous in places.
A film at odds with itself.
There's nothing here to seriously damage Gandhi Sr's reputation; if anything, he is made more human.
An insight into the flawed nature of a great man.
Melodrama is milked at every conceivable point.
A long-distance trek with refreshment breaks.
A worthy subject and a great looking film, tragically let down by a major lack of pacing and focus.
Debut director Feroz Abbas Khan adapts his hit play Mahatma v/s Gandhi for the screen with mixed results.
It's overlong and repetitive, but it impressively gives us a full-bodied portrait of the icon.
Jariwalla and Khanna's competent performances, and Khan's simplistic screenplay fail to grip and elevate this from an average to an exceptional piece of cinema.
Classy production values and a textured lead performance by Darshan Jariwala are undercut by a lack of real drama in Gandhi My Father.
Gandhi, My Father weakly opts for lionization at precisely the moment it should go in for the killshot.
promising concept ends up devolving into the ordinary
The film comes alive in playing off one personality against the other even as the audience keeps switching its sympathy between the two.
In Feroz Abbas Khan's remarkably assured debut feature, the Mahatma's complex, anguished relationship with his eldest son is explored in depth. The result is a fine, thought-provoking film.
A film divided into past and present sections that are ridiculously disparate.
...cool shots do not a riveting film make.
In an Oscar caliber performance, Bettany plays an explosive character who spends most of the time repressing an evil grin.
A movie that hovers somewhere between an acute character study and a trite power struggle.
The period -- swinging London in the time of the mods and the rockers -- gets the once-over once again in Gangster No. 1, but falls apart long before the end.
It's fascinating to see how Bettany and McDowell play off each other.
As a movie, Gangster No. 1 is bunglesome, but as a feature-length musing on a theme, it's bold and resonant.
Here's yet another cool crime movie that actually manages to bring something new into the mix.
McGuigan has assembled a stellar all-British cast in which there are no weak links.
The film has a kind of hard, cold effect.
Feels like pieces a bunch of other, better movies slapped together.
Dazzles with its fully-written characters, its determined stylishness (which always relates to characters and story) and Johnny Dankworth's best soundtrack in years.
...two brilliantly vile performances by two sublimely in-sync actors.
The performances are remarkable.
Clever, brutal and strangely soulful movie.
A stylish, confused and insanely violent gangster drama from a first-time Brit director.
Despite some really good performances especially from Bettany, this is a pretty terrible movie...
...works within its own pensive and penetrating element. Caustic and jaunty, Gangster No. 1 is a cynical sideshow that dismisses the notion that crime does not always pay.
As happily glib and vicious as its characters.

It certainly feels unique, and sets itself apart from most American gangster films in its stark refusal to paint the lead gangster as likable or indeed anything other than the vicious socio-psychopath he is.
Recommended, especially for those who still think the Gulf spill is just a local problem.
It's a powerful film.
Frankly it's overwhelming. But Fox finds a lucid narrative here with sharp editing, thorough research and a merciful sense of humour.
Essential viewing, especially New Yorkers whose drinking water is being threatened by the same kinds of corporate greed and government collusion that allowed the BP spill.
Virtually guarenteed to make your blood boil, debut documentariab Fox's remarkably likeable investigation pours forth a persuasive call-to-arms.
An exhaustive and eye-opening look at natural-gas drilling and its potential dangers.
Though becomes less interesting when it turns doctrinaire, personal angle and substantive investigation make it involving and entertaining enough to absorb its warning.
Gasland will no doubt spark the political debate it intends.
Gasland may be the first ever American film in which Nixon is the hero. It is the 101st in which Dick Cheney is the villain.
There's an acerbically straightforward, old-fashioned muckrake gurgling with righteous pugnacity beneath the mannered surface of Josh Fox's Gasland.
It's not pretty, but it works for some. Gasland won a special jury prize at the 2010 Sundance Film Festival.
While the hushed tones of Fox's would-be na√Øf commentary slightly grate after a while, his film's images, contrasting natural beauty with industrial horror show, are bracingly effective indeed.

With its jolting images of flammable tap water and chemically burned pets, New York theater-director-turned-documentarian Josh Fox's Sundance-feted shocker makes an irrefutable case against U.S. corporate "fracking."
GasLand engrosses as an informative and shocking look at the natural gas boom and the destruction it wrought upon the American heartland.
There is something seriously wrong going on here -- just remember the tap and the fire -- that needs to be fixed sooner rather than later.

With a remorselessness all the more powerful for its quiet unfussiness, Fox builds up a riveting portrait of near-apocalyptic environmental damage and a corporate mindset willing to ruin water sources irrevocably for the sake of a few years' profit.
It's raw and rough and flawed, but it's an important and deeply disturbing film and one that ironically highlights the importance of personal freedoms in democracies - however flawed they all are
GasLand shows ordinary Americans setting their formerly potable kitchen tap water on fire, it looks like a special effect, but sadly isn't.
GasLand works by effectively reminding you of that in slightly different ways again and again. It's not subtle, but it's effective.
With the hunt for natural gas likely to be heading to Britain, it's a topical film, although the point could have been made in less time.
Its focus is not instead on the art, but on the lead's romantic escapades. In the end, the movie offers only simplistic ideas about how art and artists work.
[Director] Edouard Deluc... does not go beyond the usual hagiographic profile of an artist misunderstood by the world he lived in. [Full review in Spanish]
Edouard Deluc's account of Paul Gauguin's first expedition to French Polynesia doesn't just gloss over the artist's flaws, it airbrushes them out of a story that bears little resemblance to reality.
The film has beautiful cinematography and occasional peaks of high drama, but lacks the kind of significant tempo necessary to sustain enough interest for nearly two hours to keep a viewer focused.
Deluc's trouble begins with an adapted screenplay which seems more inclined towards a travelogue.
The script must have had a lot of empty white space. This is a truly boring movie, in which barely anything happens.
The love triangle as depicted here isn't a strong enough structure to support either a traditional three-act configuration or a looser association of ideas connected to Gauguin and his life.
Gauguin: Voyage to Tahiti is mixed emotional experience that greatly excels in some areas, though ultimately doesn't quite go as far as it should.
Paul Gauguin's Tahitian paintings helped to forge in the West an imaginary of the southern seas as the territory of the getaway. [Full Review in Spanish]

Gauguin represents for the film no less an ideal Romantic subject than the Polynesians represented for the painter himself: penniless, chronically ill, and living in self-imposed isolation‚Äîthe very embodiment of the suffering artist.
This biopic might be uneven, but it's thought-provoking nonetheless.
Vincent Cassel lays on the tortured-artist schtick extra-thick in this ultimately tedious French-language portrait of the artist Paul Gauguin.
The other highlights come from France and, of all places, Ballarat. The first is the sumptuous cinematography by Pierre Cottereau. The best scene shows Gauguin riding alone in the lush landscape.

The film is too brief to be revelatory and is not the virtual museum experience it appears to aspire to, but does serve as a strong introduction to the artist for the uninitiated and offers a deeper dive into Gauguin's portraiture.

Such shonky rewriting of history - simply to bolster seductive notions of the artist as some kind of intrepid adventurer of the creative spirit - amounts to nothing more than a cynical confidence trick.
A fascinating period in Gauguin's life to explore, and couple that with the remarkable lead performance by Cassel, and you're left with a biopic that's most definitely worth catching.
Immersive, strikingly shot, wisely telescoped...
Cassel's Gauguin [is] both menacing and pitiable enough to make Gauguin: Voyage to Tahiti riveting on a moment-to-moment basis.
An ideal film for lovers of visual arts that shows different layers of Gauguin's personality. [Full Review in Spanish]
Neat and neat is the best thing you can say about this biographical drama. [Full Review in Spanish]
Despite problems, "Get on Up" is a crowd pleaser of a film, whose powerful musical moments can overshadow any smaller issues within the film.

There's more than enough here to recommend it, especially when you factor in Boseman's skillful portrayal and a phenomenal soundtrack that reminds you just how much of a musical genius Brown truly was.
[T]his show ultimately belongs to [Chadwick] Boseman. He captures the groove, soul and even [James] Brown's incompressible speech and his performance is electric.
Boseman captures his subject's voice and mannerisms, but perhaps most appropriately, he finds his soul.
Chadwick Boseman does a great job of playing James Brown who had so much personality and was such a loud character

A largely successful attempt to present the life story of the impenetrable and eccentric genius of funk in a way that respects Brown's memory and experiments with the biopic formula while also entertaining a mainstream audience.
...it can't distract us from how familiar the story feels, even if you know nothing at all about Brown. What makes the film worth seeing are the two lead performances.
Chadwick Boseman is sensational in this multi-faceted portrait of troubled, pioneering soul-music giant James Brown.
Entertaining but Brown's life is glossed over to the point that he's barely more three dimensional than he was in the old Eddie Murphy SNL sketches.
The film is undeniably entertaining from a music perspective. (Full Content Review for Parents also Available)
What the film seems to be running away from is the fact that for all his genius, James Brown was not a man you would want to spend much time around.

The movie is strongest when focusing on the co-dependent-before-that-was-a-term relationship between Byrd and Brown. Byrd worships Brown, but even he has his limits; Brown needs to be worshipped but believes in little but himself.
This "brand new bag" of a biopic is coursing with energy thanks to an electric, rousing performance by Boseman that simply must be seen.
The storytelling is mostly linear, with some confusing back-and-forth in the chronology, and it's a long slog. The Brown who emerges from this film has a monstrous ego to go with his monster talent.
These kinds of Hollywood pop stardom portraits usually flop or fly based on their casts and the ebullience of their musical scenes. "Get on Up" wins on both fronts.
Entertaining, somewhat overlong biopic has edgy material.
There's more drama in one track from Live at the Apollo than 139 long minutes of this.
Whatever else one may fault about "Get On Up," one thing that's faultless is its star, Chadwick Boseman, who plays Brown from age 16 to 60 with a dexterity and invention worthy of his subject.
Chadwick Boseman throws everything he has into his performance as the man who threw everything he had into his performance
Get on Up has elements of greatness but ends up being just one step above a standard musician biopic - as result of its fairly derivative narrative
A microcosm of women victimized by patriarchal institutions worldwide as well as an allegory of the universal struggle for freedom.

It may puzzle audiences unfamiliar with the Israeli system but the rigid religious bureaucracy devoted to keeping a married couple together at all cost makes for a superb way of adding layers of tension to this effective drama.
Ronit Elkabetz gives a lively and at times moving performance as Viviane.
Shlomi Elkabetz and his sister develop a strong narrative, free of melodrama. [full review in Spanish]
Some tonal changes lead to a few awkward, melodramatic moments, but at its core Gett impresses with its low-key, affective mode of storytelling.
Shot in intense close-ups, the better to study the emotions burning off the characters' skin, the film is all talk and gestures, but it begins to take your breath away like a chase movie would.
A highly compressed, exquisitely acted tale of two people who do not belong together plays out as a courtroom saga that, in story terms, runs longer than many marriages.
The set-up can seem frustratingly constrictive and redundant, but that's the point. The film is no more exasperating than the rigid, patriarchal legal system it depicts.

Almost all of the film takes place inside a courtroom, at irregular intervals over five years, but there is no sense of drag or slump; on the contrary, the action quivers with tension, impatience, comic heat, and, beneath it all, an irrepressible rage.
What the film, directed by Elkabetz and her sibling, Ronit, does, is cast a harsh light on a dark segment of Israeli society that is mostly obscured from the outside world.
The divorce-centered drama is so provocative it's become a lightning rod for debate inside the country. Even watching from a distance is unnerving.
An overwhelmingly intense film about an Orthodox Jewish Israeli woman trying to get a religious divorce.
Gett is holistic in its emotional captivation-it's funny, heart-warming, painful, saddening, tense, contemplative, and cathartic.
Ronit Elkabetz holds the camera with great skill. Through its claustrophobia and muted hues, this drama gives you a new appreciation of color and freedom.
Methodical and agonizing, much like the five-year dispute it depicts.
A serious and sometimes humorous and even compassionate consideration of spousal responsibility.
A frequently stunning examination of frustration and indignity.
Brought powerfully to life by Elkabetz, one of Israel's finest actresses.
In terms of themes, tone, and intensity, Gett most closely compares to Asghar Farhadi's A Separation--both are seamlessly exhausting viewing experiences.
Siblings Ronit and Shlomi Elkabetz bring their blistering trilogy of male domination in an Israeli family to a rewarding close with Gett, the Trial of Viviane Amsalem.
Girl Most Likely builds to a climax of such monumental stupidity that it destroys whatever slim pretense of realism the film has heretofore established.
Absolutely hilarious and absolutely heartbreaking. Kristen Wiig is brilliant.
Shoulda been way funnier, given the talent involved.
Even though this comedy has a tendency to dip into cartoonish silliness, it's anchored by a razor-sharp performance by Wiig as a woman forced to confront everything she hates about herself.
Whether "Girl Most Likely" intentionally satirizes its upending of conventions or suffers from a half-assed screenplay, the resulting hodgepodge at least livens up a clichd premise.
The kind of movie you root for to get its act together..Take the great Kristen Wiig out...and it would be unbearable.

If the first 90 minutes of Girl Most Likely grate and disappoint, wait until the final 10 or so, when directors Shari Springer Berman and Robert Pulcini try covering their maniacally depressive tracks like cats in a litter box.
Another movie about a woman falling into a deep funk because some narcissistic twit dumped her.
Like Imogene's early promise, "Girl Most Likely" is likely to be forgotten quickly. The sooner the better.
It means well and everyone appears to be having a good time, but so many things are wrong with the film, from a limp script to slack editing that leaves entire scenes hanging.
This film suffers, as you can guess from this prcis, from quirky-overload.
There is a trick to playing downtrodden, borderline-pathetic characters without putting off the audience. Kristen Wiig has mastered it.
Unfortunately, it's just not funny enough ...
Relentlessly artificial and broad...absolutely nothing in 'Girl Most Likely' feels remotely human.
Somewhere in this overstuffed mix, there's probably a good movie about a woman's journey to self-discovery and self-acceptance.
Flat and mostly unsurprising.
It is a deeply confused picture, and as a result, it's very hard to invest in to any real extent.
a flimsy, dreary debacle
Crushingly unfunny, it's a must to avoid.
Solid performances by its talented cast barely compensate for the lack of depth in the toothless, overly simplistic screenplay.
You've seen stories of substance abuse and its effects on a family, but rarely one as deeply unsentimental and candid as this one.
The film trudges along in Collette's wake, fumbling for something to focus on apart from the bleeding wound just offscreen.
Slow-moving and sometimes very bleak but benefits from two exceptional central performances.
Jack Reynor (future star) ably carries the movie until Collette intermittently pops up to seize the camera and devour her desperate son's entire life force.
Bring plenty of Kleenex. A nickel pack won't do.

A miscast, not fully convincing Collette hits some wrong notes along the way. Reynor, though, is superb, and his tightly wound, taciturn performance lets us feel the clenched desperation of the young cabbie's plight.
This sombre, artful but fatally unfocused Irish drama takes us to some grim places.
Glassland has a minimalist purity to it, and Barrett avoids manipulation and lets the images and characters speak for themselves.

Gerard Barrett has crafted a clear-eyed look at alcoholism, thwarted hopes and the ruts in which we get stuck.With its unexplained title, downbeat subject matter and deliberate pacing, it's not exactly Friday night fodder but it's absorbing all the same.
"Glassland" isn't the kind of film that will make a lot of waves. In fact, it's specifically designed not to.
A moving drama that reveals the struggles of a compassionate caregiver at the end of his rope.
A powerful study of the personal battles being fought behind myriad nondescript doors.

All we see is a good man in a desperate situation, and it's up to the audience to dole out any judgment to the character, or to perhaps realize that our own imperfect humanity disqualifies us of judging his actions in the first place.
A small but pretty impressive indie from Ireland with top-notch acting.

In the movie's best scene, as mother and son dance to an old pop song, the look on Reynor's face speaks volumes about loss and hope. It's a look that's going to be breaking hearts on screen for decades to come.
A thoroughly engaging and involving - albeit tough - viewing experience. Barrett's strong second feature marks him out as one to watch.
"Glassland" boasts a strong lead cast who help lift the film greatly and to soaring heights in its emotional richness. If not for this, it may have drowned in its dark themes and story.
While the cast masterfully shoulders the sad affair, their efforts are undermined by Barrett's unfortunate tendency to tell when showing has already done the job.
Glassland smartly plays off Jean's unhinged disintegration against John's tense, subdued control. In that contrast lies the power of this film.
Alternately alive and old-hat, and eventually maddeningly vague, it doesn't have much to recommend apart from fine acting and burnished, painterly cinematography. That may be enough. Sometimes it is.
Filmically it's more of a pleasantly diverting kick about in the park than a 90th minute back-of-the-net at the world cup final.
A game of two halves, both of them dire.
Cliched but nonetheless enjoyable - if you liked the first film, you won't be disappointed by the second one. Unless you're an Arsenal fan.
I won't tell you the result, but I will say that Arsene Wenger would be wise to avoid Goal 2 in case he suffers from terminal apoplexy.
Next stop the World Cup . . . can't wait.
Becker, who made the first instalment just about passable, is bland here while Alessandro Nivola, who plays his best pal, looks rightly bored.
Not quite the guilty pleasure the first movie was, Goal! 2 can't quite stick it in the back of the net, pull off the double etc, etc...
A machine might have directed this, but it has a few more welcome touches of comedy than the first one.
One long, product-placing, non-speaking-cameo-packed infomercial.
It's a game of two halves, and both of them suck in a flat-footed follow-up that doesn't bode well for the inevitable Goal! 3.
Ultimately, this is relegation fodder from start to finish.
Intriguing to watch and well-played by the engaging cast.
One isn't eager to see extra time played and the 'To be continued' line at the end is more ominous than enticing. Once again, film-makers demonstrate that old adage, never give soccer an even break.
The idea of turning a 10-minute idea into a trilogy of movies seemed imposing at first, but Goal II continues the franchise's recipe of personality over originality.
Despite the predictable, clich-riddled script, the soap-opera hokum that passes for drama, Goal II somehow works.

Bullet time, pixellation, flashy graphics, slow-motion-sweat, all wrapped around a rather flimsy story about the kid from the barrio dealing with paparazzi, millions of fans and a salary in the millions of Euros.
Goal II clumsily telegraphs all of its moves far in advance.
If your kids play soccer, they may appreciate this tall tale of Santi's rise from obscurity to shin-padded glory, but once you pop in the DVD, chances are you won't want to stick around.
A movie that isn't terrible, but--apart from the goat fixation and Duchovny's zonked-out turn--doesn't offer much that hasn't been done elsewhere, and often better.
The actors struggle to seem off-handed, much as the script does. Goats needs to be more goat-like in every way - unbridled, untamed, randy - and it never is.
A coming-of-age comedy/drama that unfortunately doesn't have much new to say on the topic of coming of age.
Mellow, but very much a work in progress, Goats has a bland but overcrowded menu that could benefit from a little feta.
This is a very effecting drama about a teenage boy buffeted by starkly contrasting role models from the adult world.
Loses the flavor of the journey.
If I were Holden Caulfield, I might call it lousy.
Bland and tepid, the passage of time will only reiterate that quirky scenarios don't provide the necessary backbone for a solid coming of age narrative.
A strong cast and the sweet and simple nature of the script (based on the novel by Mark Poirier) makes Goats a charming little indie tale worth the viewing.
"Goats" is just b-a-a-a-aad.
Despite the ever-escalating cost of private education, there are still some who feel that there's no character more empathetic than a boarding school lad.

"Goats" is standing on the shoulders of its coming-of-age predecessors, adding nothing except a reminder that every generation goes through the same thing - evidently, cinematically as well as personally.
If Mr. Neil had the tonal mastery of Wes Anderson, "Goats" could have been so much more than an episodic sequence of whimsical little psychodramas.
Nibbles on a lot of stuff it never gets around to digesting.
Genial but gratingly irrelevant and none too witty.
A sweet junket into the land of the new agers, and youth that refuses to grow old.
A capable cast can't elevate this mediocre coming-of-age comedy.

Christopher Neil directs with a mechanical blandness made more tedious still by a score of gentle guitar strumming so aggravatingly benign it might inspire you to partake in one of Wendy's climactic, cathartic primal screams.
Random and disappointing. Even Capricorns will give it a hooves' down. Rent "Running with Scissors" instead.
"Goats" is an amateurish coming-of-age movie made up scattershot ideas that are never developed.
Not only is indulgence a frequent subject for Jaglom, it also sums up what his movies do -- and what they demand from their audience, sometimes to tedious degrees.
Alleges support of women, yet fetishizes their objects instead of their relationships.
None of these is a character you want to spend much time with, and even with the diverting guest appearances, this is still strictly discount merchandise.
It's the last and least successful of indie director Henry Jaglom's trilogy looking at female issues.
The trouble with Going Shopping is that it's clogged with personalities and styles that don't congeal.
Dangerously close to tiresome. The comedic boutique framework is a little too frill and a bit understocked.

Jaglom's concentrated approach serves up some insight to be sure, but the movie states its case in the first 10 minutes and then proceeds to run out of things to say, almost as quickly as the women in this movie think they've run out of things to wear.
As breezy as window-shopping and reminds us that, in both shopping and love, everyone has buyer's remorse and few items fit right.
Like the funky little shop at its heart, Going Shopping may not look like much from its exterior, but a little browsing turns up unexpected treasures.
[Has] enough moments of insight to blunt charges of sexist stereotyping.
Typical Jaglom yakker, made fresh by winning performances from Lee Grant, Rob Morrow and Bruce Davison.
The film is less than two hours long but feels considerably longer, thanks to a few drawn-out scenes and some clunky character drama.
Henry Jaglom completes his informal trilogy on estrogen-laced obsessions with this seriocomic exploration of women and clothes.
This is a film that revels in its own irrelevance.
Comes as close as any film to explaining what the deal is with women and shopping.
[A] witty follow-up to director Henry Jaglom's Eating and Baby Fever.
Going Shopping can make a wonderful outing for girlfriends. It's fun.
[Henry] Jaglom's Going Shopping is a nifty little oddity, another of his unlikely, entertaining movie hybrids.
If this sounds like your type of thing, you'll probably get your money's worth.

Going Shopping...has enough smart, knowing touches and enough easy spontaneity among its well-chosen actors to make you wish it added up to more than what it turns out to be: a flighty, motor-mouthed cinematic divertissement.
Gone, Baby, Gone is not just one of the strongest pictures of the year, but one of the best debuts behind the camera for any filmmaker, moviestar or otherwise.

Lehane's superb plotting serves the director well, and Affleck's unblinking view of the world he seems to know, with an emphasis on ugliness, self-perpetuating despair and the wrong sorts of people having children, serves Lehane's story.
Director Affleck's noirishly stylized film weighs heavily under a dense vision of lies, secrets and corrupt agendas that will have you running for a breath of air by the time it ends.
In his directing debut, Affleck has found his calling, an avenue for using his obvious intelligence while getting out of the way of his own celebrity.
After a decade and a half of increasingly pointless acting jobs, Ben Affleck has finally found his calling.
The Affleck boys finally earn their stripes as cinematic artists
A thinking man's crime film, whose deeply etched characters and brilliant plotting have a near-Shakespearean power.
[Affleck] also has fun with detective movie motifs, the tough-guy talk and verbal showdowns, but he's more interested in the complex moral tangle the story becomes.
A satisfyingly tough look into conscience, to those dark places where some men also go astray.
It's cinematic excellence from Affleck, who takes Lehane's prose and splashes it with cold water, opening the senses of the story, turning it into an unexpected emotional sucker punch.
Affleck's feature directing debut is strong on atmospherics and moral quandaries.

Ben Affleck may not have made the wisest acting choices in recent years ('Gigli, anyone?) but here, in an impressive directorial debut, he proves he definitely has what it takes for a career behind the camera.

I'm torn between thinking there should be more films like this or fewer. I love the moral discussions, the difficult Sophie's Choice decisions. On the other hand, how bleak, how wretched, how depressingly realistic.

The film doesn't fully click into the register Affleck seems to be going for -- that of a talky, tense, intricately woven urban opera of greed (both emotional and monetary), ambition and ethical relativism.
Casey Affleck gives one of the strongest performances of 2007...
Ben Affleck does such a surprisingly effective job behind the cameras that someone unfamiliar with him would be hard-pressed to prove that this film marks his first time in the director's chair.
Mr. Affleck is laying the foundation, brick by brick, for a promising new career.
A dour, fairly intriguing mystery based on the fourth book in a series of South Boston-set detective novels by Dennis Lehane.

Pulp meets poetry on the Boston rooftops in Ben Affleck's directorial debut. This absorbing and complex neighborhood-noir, about a private eye on the trail of a missing girl, is easily one of the best movies of the year.

Strong performances from its ensemble cast can't compensate for undeveloped character-reversals, splashes of exploitation, and a broken storyline that feels like two different narratives stuck together.
Instead of inspiring children to be brave and loving, it will most likely send them cowering under the covers in terror. They've already got Chucky movies for that.

Entertaining for kids while slightly corny and silly for adults, but it's often harmless, bighearted and filled with inspirational messages about friendship, hope and the importance of family which everyone, young and old, can appreciate.
Its lack of a compelling storyline and overreliance on so-so slapstick will limit its appeal to easily distracted preschoolers.
This should be, by all accounts, a horror movie. It is instead a Canadian family comedy. So, you know, same difference.
If being innocuous were a crime, Gooby would cause Canada to reinstate the death penalty pronto.
A raunchy between-the-sheets peak at modern-day black sexuality...should woo urban audiences to the theater.
A worldly, knowing look at adult affairs.
Dortch's manipulation of stereotype and the associations embedded in everything from skin tone to music set him apart as a talent to watch.
A Good Day certainly shows Dortch as a talent to watch. Whether he does anything more with that talent will be up to him.
A kooky, kinky quintet of black bedtimes stories.
It has smart characters, and is wise about the ones who try to tame their intelligence by acting out.
Crass dialogue, the plot development of a Tom & Jerry cartoon, and a cast of instantly forgettable actors add up to a romantic drama that enriches your life simply by not being seen.
The Good Guy has a few half-cute moments, some chuckles, and enough pretty faces to cast at least two TV pilots. What it doesn't have is a clue.
It's network television drama, starring actors best known for their TV work and full of the petty gripes and mild worries of characters who really have nothing compelling to worry about.
Writer/director Julio DePietro's first effort is every bit as obvious as it sounds, thudding from one symmetrically perfect cliche to another.
High-reaching adult drama with lots of language, drinking.

There is a reason why McCarthy doesn't get hired to play a sharking alpha male very often. When he makes an effort to work his features into a frenzy of boiling testosterone, he looks like a petulant third-grader.
resh enough to provide the voyeuristic kick of glimpsing the frenzied lifestyle of aspiring masters of the universe.
The Good Guy builds its power as it goes, taking you places you don't expect. It's the rare movie that can surprise you in that way %u2013 but this one does.
A teensy, unoriginal young love triangle with a hint of subversion.
Even on a reduced scale of expectation, Good Guy is stunningly empty and obvious, missing its mark as a cautionary tale or a romantic sojourn, instead slogging along a preordained trail of clich.
New York-based love story that illustrates how old-fashioned virtues can still play a significant role in matters of the heart.
A light romantic comedy about a relationship between a hot-shot investment banker and a perky conservationist who learns in time that her boyfriend is a cad.
A fresh and original take on a familiar tale.

Mild, pleasant, obvious romantic comedy set on Wall Street that's most notable for its (maybe accurate) portrayal of young brokers as amoral idiots oblivious to the real-life consequences of their risky business.
The cast could not be better.
Handsome, well-done if too familiar look at the romantic and professional games played by upscale twentysomething Manhattan professionals working pre-recession.
There's too little difference between the good guys and the bad guys in Julio DePietro's uninspired debut, a slickly cynical romance destined to be quickly forgotten.

Drawing on his stint at a Chicago investment firm, DePietro creates characters, dialogue and situations that feel authentic, which makes the film relevant in unexpected ways, though not as deeply as you hope he'll do in the future.

A sort of much more polite, estrogenized filmic companion piece to a lost, mid-era Bret Easton Ellis novel, this movie has a different, interesting cant than most films of its ilk, but can't quite turn that positive into a deal-closing recommendation.
Directors Josh and Benny Safdie are again utilizing heavily synthesized music and electronic beats that propel momentum forward just as kinetically as each character's next, usually bad, choice
In watching Good Time, you forget that actor Robert Pattinson was ever involved with the Twilight franchise with what is the best performance of his career.
Good Time feels like a throwback to 1970s classics like Mean Streets or Dog Day Afternoon and has a nervous, edgy energy that keeps you on your toes.

You have to go back into the vaults -- maybe as far back as Dog Day Afternoon -- to find a movie about a New York bank robber more intense than Benny and Josh Safdie's ironically titled drama Good Time.
The urgent docu-style filming is impressive, but it's Pattinson's fearless turn that lingers.
[Hoffman is] no Pacino or Hoffman but he's more than good enough opting for a performance from their playbook.
Despite the recognizable elements, everything in Good Time is instinctive, unpredictable and disconcerting. [Full Review in Spanish]
(Robert Pattinson's Connie) is a pathetic mop of a man who always seems to be reaching for something - even if he does not know what that is.
The third feature film by the Safdie brothers takes us through a narrative constellation that expands as we travel through New York. [Full review in Spanish]
A fun, fiery, fatigue-defying ride.
The Safdie brothers' new movie with Robert Pattinson breathes life into a waning genre.
The masterfully scuzzy feel-bad Good Time is the kind of movie that demands consideration for all the post-YA choices Robert Pattinson has been making.
Pattinson nails a back-breaking role and the Safdies direct with an unrelenting visceral edge.
[Good Time] is sharp, flashy filmmaking that enthralls increasingly with each turn of the downward spiral.
This visceral crime thriller benefits from a fully committed performance from Robert Pattinson and a gritty visual texture.

The Safdie brothers prefer to entertain and maintain an agile rhythm instead of delving into their characters or their ideas, something that the film would have appreciated very much. [Full review in Spanish]

What follows is one of those all-night-long odysseys that's taxing for the characters but weirdly fascinating for the viewer (think Martin Scorsese's After Hours or even Harold & Kumar Go to White Castle).
The con man's lament

Good Time is a film about a destructive love - and loving someone despite not having the right kind of love to give them. Ignore the deceptively convivial title: This is the kind of thrill that sticks.

But ultimately, love is what fuels this traumatic night - brotherly love, the love of the chase and the freedom that money provides. GOOD TIME traps its characters in a world lacking empathy, and as a result, there is nothing left to lose.
A clever rearranging of Oscar Wilde's first great play, Lady Windermere's Fan.
[Tom] Wilkinson artfully deepens a character who in Wilde's original play was rather boobish. It's a marvelous performance in a pretty good film.
Not good enough.
Dragged down by the flat delivery of a grossly miscast Helen Hunt
With its jellyfish direction, A Good Woman throws its actors overboard to see if they can swim.
Writer Howard Himelstein should have left well enough alone.
As period dramas go, this Woman is accessible, but not nearly as delightful as the recent Pride & Prejudice.
...offers the stunning scenery of the Amalfi coast and the thoroughly entertaining, completely endearing performance of Tom Wilkinson..
Entertaining and stylish.
Oscar Wilde's bon mots are on display.
Passionate flair periodically turns theatrical but a snappy twist of a climax marks this social satire with a scarlet A for effort.
Lifeless
It might be empty calories, but A Good Woman is a tasty bonbon, the equal of the recent film version of Wilde's An Ideal Husband.
The production is beautifully costumed and cast, and Hunt acquits herself quite nicely while playing entirely against type.
Besides the consuming, universal glibness of its characters, A Good Woman is also undermined by some ditsy casting.

A Good Woman is such a dreary affair that it makes you wonder whether the last Wilde adaptation -- the critically lambasted The Importance of Being Earnest with Reese Witherspoon -- was really that bad after all.
While this film is certainly not a painful experience, it is certainly not up to the brilliance of Oscar Wilde's intent and voice.
Scarlett Johansson displays the same aptitude for period drama that she showed in Girl With A Pearl Earring
Strained of much of its Englishness...A Good Woman earns most of its good will from those Wildean epigrams.
All the fun in A Good Woman occurs off in the corners, while the action in center-frame does little to capture your fancy.
Nobody ever talks about the underrated Goodbye, Columbus, but they should.
A summertime love story tinged with dark humor.
This well-observed comedy knows the American Jewish bourgeois scene well.
Dated adult fare from 1969 with Benjamin and MacGraw.
Perhaps the most successful of the three Philip Roth adaptations on the big screen.
It is rich and wonderful; and although flawed and far from being the best film of the year, I think it will deeply touch more people than any other film this year.
Does it seem picayune to require that moves make sense on their own terms?
The movie version of Gray's material seems arch, contrived and starchy, not the spontaneous eruption that his theater work manages to resemble.
In spite of Soderbergh and the painful lack of an audience/laugh track, Gray's story is immediately compelling, proving that once again, a talking head can truly entertain an audience.
Not only is it interesting to follow the course of Gray's storyline, the movie is also equally interesting to view, even if the storyteller is just sitting in front of a desk most of the time.
Gray's Anatomy finds Spalding Gray turning a bout with a bizarre ocular condition into a dizzying, absorbing odyssey of the neurotic mind.
If you cannot see Spalding Gray live, then do see his monologue films. Gray's Anatomy can be infuriating, but Spalding makes it worthwhile.
Soderbergh is a gifted director (SEX, LIES AND VIDEOTAPE; KING OF THE HILL); Gray is a gifted monologist (SWIMMING TO CAMBODIA). They're just not a very good match for the creation of a film.
The film manages to come off like a dinnertime conversation with a friend -- albeit a one-sided and long but very good and very funny one.
There's something intrinsically insincere about the whole quest. Gray is on a search less for a cure than for material.
Gray's Anatomy is a triumphant reminder of the power of words to summon our deepest fears.

At best, Gray is a tragicomic Everyman who strikes an empathic chord in his admiring audience; at worst, he's a middle-aged, self-absorbed, hopelessly provincial New Yorker -- an urban hick who won't shut up.

A chatty, colorful, nicely sardonic account of how a crisis led Mr. Gray to assess his medical state, consider his mortality and take one more funny, self-dramatizing look at the eccentric world around him.
The late Spalding Gray's monologue is typically fascinating, and Soderbergh's creative staging is a treat.
Visually inventive version of Gray's monologue, though the material is not as interesting as that of Swimming to Cambodia.
Soderbergh does (Gray) no favors with a series of overwrought stylistic choices.
It is haunting, though. How could it not be, when the last lines of the monolog are "Ecstasy, despair, ecstasy, despair" and some mention of a big fish?
Becomes a kind of strange examination of human existence; frail, idiosyncratic, and ultimately a kind of cosmic joke.
If we have watched two hours of will they or won't they, by golly, we want to see whether they do or they don't. Still, it's a tail-wagger.
Depardieu's charm recognizes no language barriers, and MacDowell, the revelation of sex, lies, and videotape, proves a fine, sexy foil.

Silly and obvious as this romantic comedy is (and its script would have seemed dated in 1942), it might have mustered a considerable charm if Depardieu had been better matched in his first American film.
Peter Weir's talent, so evident in his Australian work, remained dormant here, but Depardieu's lively performance is a redeeming factor.
In terms of the genre's conventions, Weir likens this film to 'a light meal'. It's one to savour.
[I]t is a sound, entertaining work of craftsmanship, a love story between two people whose meet is not as cute as it might have been.
An appealing romantic comedy directed by Peter Weir.
Stop me if you've heard this one... too late.
Although a thin premise endangers its credibility at times, Green Card is a genial, nicely played romance.
It's slight and trite, but so what?
Engaging romantic comedy.
Depardieu and MacDowell are delightful together and "Green Card" is a real treat for anyone who enjoys light romantic comedy.
For "Green Card" seems much more enjoyable on a second viewing, after the ghost of Julia Roberts in Beverly Hills had been banished.
The story could have been turned into a plastic sitcom, but ... the crackling chemistry between Depardieu and MacDowell gives it considerable charm.
Even so, at its heart this movie is, like Pretty Woman, very tired stuff tarted up in glad rags.
It's funny, sweet - and utterly lop-sided.
Sickly sweet
[A]n effortlessly engaging love story whose ace in the hole is the almost indecent magnetism of Gerard Depardieu.
The movie is just pleasing enough to make you wish there were more to it.
It's instandly forgettable, but "Green Card," about a marriage of convenience between immigrant Gerard Depardieu and apartment hunter Andie MacDowell, is nonetheless pleasing.
Amusing enough to watch and passes the time, but it's the kind of movie you're content to wait for on your friendly indie cable channel.
There are many reasons to see GREENFINGERS. . . top of the list of reasons has to be its star, Clive Owen, a toothsome morsel of manflesh . . .
For those who appreciate low-key British comedies, Greenfingers is a passable entry -- a somewhat pleasant diversion, but nothing more.

Simply reheats a formula that relies on ordinary blokes who triumph.
It's hard not to be charmed by scenes like the one in which Briggs gives his posies a little pep talk.
As synthetic as a rubber rose.
An exemplary movie that makes you feel good about the human condition.
Each time you think the genre that brought us Waking Ned Devine, Saving Grace and Billy Elliot, has run its course, along comes another one.
I can't remember if i've ever seen a movie good or bad that wasn't made better by the presence of either of these actors.
A cloying, pedestrian piece of flummery.
A small enchantment of a movie, distinctive for both its freshness and finesse.
Not a breath of fresh air or originality comes through.
Succeeds in capturing the movement of a soul from hopelessness to humanity.
I was charmed and laughed at spots, but mostly I saw points where the story needed to take a turn to keep me interested.
There's something off-kilter and a little leaden about Greenfingers.

Greenfingers is by no means a poor film, mainly frustratingly pleasant, with any depth that could be applied to the redemption of a murderer cast aside to well-worn and all too familiar genre staples.
Overcomes credibility problems and its formulaic plot with its sheer desire to entertain in what can only be called a quaint manner.
Moderately entertaining but forgettable.
The movie gives some blooming satisfaction.
A wheezier replay of the 1993 hit geezer romp Grumpy Old Men.
This is, of course, a big-screen sitcom, and in fact I would love to see this material transplanted to the TV screen, where it belongs.
The heart of the first one is replaced by extra fart jokes.
Nowhere near as funny as the first film. Just a stale, tired rehash.
Not as good as the first, but it's seldom less than amusing.
Moderately successful sequel. Lemmon and Matthau always a great team to watch.
Insults and sexual innuendo dominate routine comedy sequel.
A quirky comedy about middle-aged burnout.
By the middle of the film, however, this cross between the original Bob Newhart Show and the James Bond films has hit it's stride and we can sit back and enjoy a really comfortable movie.
The direction is proficient
Gun Shy is a zany mobster/comedy film about a lawman who is suffering from anxiety attacks and is in need of seeing a shrink.
[Gun Shy is] not boring as much as it's...forgettable.
Sandra Bullock brings her sassy, bubbly schtick as a costar...
Not exactly what I'd call hilarious.
Gun Shy is the kind of movie that makes you laugh; then, as you think about it afterward, you feel ashamed you enjoyed it.
Not only is the script incomprehensible, the film wasn't edited or directed -- it was crammed into a Cuisinart.
The supporting cast is comical, and anyone enjoying the misadventures of dumb lawbreakers should get a kick out of this movie.
Sure it falls apart right at the end--but up until that point it's a gem of an underrated comedy.
It's a shame everything is so discombobulated, because some sparkling moments get lost in the mess.
Gun Shy can't rise on wobbly legs.
The movie is marred by an overreliance on unfunny bathroom gags.
Movies this badly botched are seldom released in theaters.
Gun Shy is also likely to be a bad career move for producer/co-star Sandra Bullock.
Gun Shy is worth at least a shot at a matinee.
A half hour in and still, the plot, tone, and setting are incomprehensible.
It is not funny enough to be the spoof it wants to be, not exciting or suspenseful enough to support the action scenes.
Neither romantic nor dark, neither humorous nor satiric, Gun Shy tries to be Bob Newhart, Goodfellas, Mickey Blue Eyes and Forces of Nature and succeeds at none of the above.
I daresay the results would inspire Eisenstein himself to proffer an affirming nod from the great beyond.
Gunnin' is everything the fatuous, condescending Hoop Dreams was not.

In the opening section of the film, we get to know them through interviews, game footage and scenes of family life. It's here where the film shines, giving us a glimpse into what it's like for young athletes being groomed for the NBA.

Hip-hop and basketball have never been so uninspiringly brought together as they are in Beastie Boy Adam Yauch's kinetic but shallow chronicle of the buildup to the first annual Boost Mobile Elite 24 Hoops Classic.

A funkier, shallower version of 1994's Hoop Dreams, Beastie Boy Adam Yauch's doc follows eight high school basketball phenoms as they head to Harlem's asphalt mecca, Rucker Park, to take part in 2006's Elite 24 tournament.
As each player's run through the same routine-hometown meet-and-greet, biographical sketch, hasty interview-the burden of the formulaic structure starts to wear.
It's as much a snapshot of the contemporary basketball scene as it is a love letter to the famed uptown court.

Gunnin' for That #1 Spot might intrigue hardcore basketball fans-several of these young players are newly minted NBA draft picks-but even then, you'll have to contend with the shockingly unimaginative soundtrack.

Unlike the 1994 basketball doc Hoop Dreams, which investigated collateral issues of education, race and money, this merely sets a twitchy hip-hop soundtrack to an unenlightening parade of eager sporting wannabes.

An impressive feat on every level as Yauch brings an unbridled passion to shining a spotlight on some of the country's finest young basketball players in a way that can be appreciated by anyone and everyone.
Easily the best movie of its kind since Steve James' Hoop Dreams.
Although this is never less than watchable, you can't help feeling that it would have been a better film if they'd waited a year or so and actually included details of the players' futures.

Although much of its archive footage from high school games shows up blurry, pixleated or in an otherwise raw form, it nonetheless clarifies the abilities of thoroughly committed young players executing their most impressive basketball skills.
At the heart of everything there's Yauch, directing with remarkable authority for someone who's pretty new to the director's chair.
The extraordinary athleticism and skills of these teenagers, all prime prospects for eventual NBA stardom, makes this a game you really want to see.
It's a fly-on-the-wall look at eight prodigiously talented kids hooking up to play ball in the big city, and as such, it's a great deal of fun.
A conventional exercise in documentary storytelling, not a rich and incisive assessment of youth and sports cultures.
Adam Yauch, Beastie Boy turned documentarian, turns in a crisp, insightful, but emotionally distant look at the best high school basketball players of 2006 with Gunnin' for That #1 Spot.
As a tribute to the game and its accessibility to all, Gunnin' is hard to beat.
Gunnin' for That #1 Spot is an on-the-fly record of a memorable moment in basketball history.
An unapologetic tear-jerker. You might resent being emotionally manipulated by this film, but I challenge even the most hard-hearted moviegoer not to spill some saltwater while watching it.
Bland beyond endurance.
If I had a car, this movie would inspire me to get a bumper sticker: 'The more I know people, the more I love my dog.'
It's not a story that could ever move me: all I see in it is a dumb animal who doesn't know any better.
This is mutt mush, pure and simple-minded, for those in the mood.
The man who once directed What's Eating Gilbert Grape? is now the Hallmark greeting card of movie-makers.
A simple, old-fashioned heartwarmer that all the family can enjoy.
There's not a whole lot going on, it's pretty much just this relationship,between this dog and this man and it's really touching and and beautiful.
Dramatic story of a dog's devotion is emotionally intense.
In the canon of recent canine cinema, there are far worse movies than this.
Even the manliest moviegoer likes to have a good cry from time to time.

Switching it up from his more familiar fascinations with hooker romance as in Pretty Woman, American Gigolo and Brooklyn's Finest, Gere gets into a very different kind of infatuation, pursuing puppy love in this man's best friend cuddly canine cinema romp
Come the sniffly denouement, it would take a hard heart not to be won over. Even cynics might find their noses a little wet.
It(TM)s an extraordinary and touching story but told with too beady an eye on the box-office for comfort - even if you(TM)re a doggy person.
A circular routine of smiles and tears, Hachi is delightfully gentle and engaging, refusing to bloat the material past an elementary message of canine loyalty.
We all know Marley & Me is the Citizen Kane of dog movies that can drain all tear ducts. However, this one (also based on a true story) runs an honest, heartbreaking second.
An immensely appealing drama about the extraordinary love and devotion of a dog for his beloved human companion.
Lasse Hallstrom dishes up more classy mediocrity with this brazenly uncomplicated treat for dog lovers.
This is warm hearted, well acted and nicely shot and the dog is undeniably cute but the story is ultimately too slight to sustain a 90 minute film.

Hachiko: A Dog's Tale is pretty pointless, and the director, Lasse Hallstrom, who made his name with the remarkable Swedish movie My Life As a Dog, continues to punch below his weight with another candied slice of sweet-natured Americana.
Treat Williams delivered a great performance as Berger, and showshe doesn't deserve to be stuck in TV movies like he is now.
Toe-tappin' hippie-shakin' fun.
Has more going for it than against it, not in the least the fact that Forman proves to have a natural affinity for filming musical numbers.
Hair is a zany blend of song, dance and parody with its giddy portrait of hippies.
Treat Williams in one of his better roles
My best performance as a movie star...if you can find me!
Hair benefited from the creative freedom of '70s cinema...at its best when it's most creatively subversive... [Blu-ray]
Milos Forman's screen version of the landmark musical production is uneven, though there's no doubt it would have been better received had been made earlier, during the Vietnam War.
It's the songs that make this film worth watching. Without them, it's a pretty uneven narrative that can be awfully slow at times.

Milos Forman's movie version of Hair is every bit as exhilarating and exciting as the original play. What's more, Forman has managed to recreate with amazing accuracy the rebellious mood and irreverent spirit of those confusing times.

Maybe it's just as well that this version had to wait a decade to be filmed so Forman could be hired to do it. He brings life to the musical form in the same way that West Side Story did, the last time everyone was saying the movie musical was dead.
Hair is brilliant and spectacular -- if at times a bit watered-down -- and will please the public, especially those who love its music. [Full Review in Spanish]

As it is, Arthur Penn's Alice's Restaurant - a film whose situations and even imagery Hair several times calls to mind - offers from its contemporary vantage-point a far more reflective impression of late-60s counterculture.
Dismissed by some as merely a time capsule piece, the film adaptation of Hair, seen today, proves to be an incredibly relevant and resonant work as well as an immensely entertaining one.
It gets my vote as the all-time best rock film and second only to 1935's Top Hat as the all-time best musical.
has enough vigor and raucousness to carry it past its various pitfalls while celebrating an age that, far from dawning, had already passed
More a reinvention than a retread, Hairspray is a pleasant surprise, a breath of fresh, whimsical air in a season that's been dominated by franchise entertainment.
I can't recall a movie with this many flaws that I liked so much.
Director-choreographer Adam Shankman has come up with one of the purest entertainments of the summer.
You'll come out of the movie happier than you went in, and humming a few peppy new tunes to boot.

Based on John Waters' 1988 satire of civil rights-era nostalgia, this movie-musical adaptation makes the same mistake as the 2002 Broadway incarnation -- it domesticates Waters' parodistic anarchy into general-audience silliness.
Much of the fun comes from director-choreographer Adam Shankman's happy acceptance of musical staples
Unlike Eddie Murphy's exploitively unfunny attempts at fat and female, John Travolta makes his character absolutely endearing and charming by playing it relatively low-key.
Takes the attitude of the original to a giddy new level.
In doing some constructive nip/tuck and staging the musical numbers in splashy old-musical style, Shankman has put some of the bang back into the genre.
Campy and sweet-natured, Hairspray will shake away any summertime blues.
The unexpected pleasure of Hairspray is that it doesn't beg to differ.
Hairspray is a fizzy and delirious high-camp message-movie musical that may just turn out to be the happiest movie of the summer.
Hairspray is the perfect movie distraction for the summer -- frothy fun, kid-friendly and relevant.

Bright, campy and wonderfully light, Hairspray reminds us that fun comes in all shapes and sizes. It's also one of the few 'event' movies this summer that doesn't outstay its welcome. That's worth singing about, no matter what your name is.
From the moment the first note of Good Morning Baltimore rang out I was hooked on the alluring wit of Hairspray and the infectious charm of Nikki Blonsky.
Despite Travolta's best efforts, he might as well be dressed like Vincent Vega or Danny Zuko. He just can't sell the second 'X' chromosome.
...just about the most joyous Hollywood musical since Singin' in the Rain...
Hairspray arrives as a big, bundle of fun, infectious to the core and accomplishes more often than not what the best musicals are prone to do.
With its zesty dancing, strong performances, goofball details and sweet message of acceptance for all, Hairspray might just be this summer's happiest hit.
I will confess that Travolta totally turned me around. A mountain of a woman in his female fat suit, he commits 150% to the role.

As beautifully smiling faces waver gently in and out of focus, the sound track drips honey and molasses and horehound drops. Oh love, oh life, ah happy fate, that we, who have split this sixpence in twain as mere youths, should meet again, etc.

The first half of the film is better than any fourth sequel in a slasher flick franchise deserves to be.
It seems the latest stage in some curious evolutionary pattern; the slasher species keeps proliferating and getting weaker at the same time.
Michael Myers may return in the series' fourth instalment, but the imagination and originality is mostly long gone.
You can tell that it felt very rushed and things were kind of clobbered together to make this movie at the last second.
Though it is a slasher movie at all points, it's an atypically intelligent example of the form...a quantum leap better than its two immediate predecessors.
Of all the Halloween sequels, including the irrelevant and unwatchable Halloween III, Halloween 4 stands out as the best of a generally uninspired lot.
Fourth entry in the Halloween horror series is a no-frills, workmanlike picture.
Although this is just more of the same old same, Halloween 4 is directed with some skill by B-movie specialist Dwight H. Little.
Feels more like an obligatory teen slasher than the previous films...but gets the job done.
Feels like the most genuine successor to the original Halloween of any of the sequels.
While Part 4 is better than Part 3, it is still worse than, say, being bitten in the retina by fire ants.
...[Donald Pleasance's Dr. Loomis] doesn't once refer to Myers as "pure evil," though he does call him "evil on two legs" which is almost as good...
One of the best chapters of the series...really novel
