H4 is very much the cheap knockoff of its prototype, but not half as visceral.

I need to state for the record that Donald Pleasence is a truly great actor... But he also loved to chew the scenery, and the middle period of the Halloween franchise gave him plenty to sink his teeth into.
Boy, this one's rich.
While it's definitely not the best of the series, it's an entertaining slasher film...
Young Ms. Harris is probably the movie's most powerful element.
And in the faint praise department: "Halloween 4" is just a little bit better than most of the sequels that followed.

The camerawork is impressively nutty and it moves like nobody's business, but it's ultimately just a wind-up toy, and once it's done going in its tedious circles, there's not much left for anyone who can vote and doesn't subsist on Red Bull.
A mostly dreadful piece of would-be #viral #content disguised as an action film.
More like Headache-Inducing Henry.
The power of its kinetic energy and its meticulous bloody choreography from the first to the last minute cannot be ignored. [Full Review in Spanish]
This movie has the shiny new techniques, but it suffers from a very old problem -- the lack of anything resembling a narrative.
The film is not all smash-em-up testosterone, adrenaline and bloodshed. Its viscera is comic-like camp.
If action movies are meant to be stunning, Hardcore Henry can proudly take its place among the giants. Even better, it lets you stand with them.
Is it much of a movie? Not really. It's more of an experience - a passive sort of virtual reality - that uses a bare-bones narrative as a vehicle for a big-time body count.
It's all about the ride, the relentless wallop and whoosh. But, hey, sometimes that's all a cine-junkie needs for a fix.
Its dour eccentricity gives Hardcore Henry a potency above and beyond that of standard-issue show-off action fare. That doesn't mean it's not still obnoxious, though.
The theater chairs don't come equipped with controllers, causing the novelty of the concept to wear off well before you get to "game over."
It's a shame the action genre is seen with such a prejudice - if it wasn't for that, this movie would be recognized as what it truly is: a great example of filmmaking. [Full review in Portuguese.]
Hardcore Henry would have you weeping for the terminal decline of culture and society if it weren't so much fun, or so deceptively thoughtful.
Soulless and headache inducing
Merciless but entertainingly auspicious, "Hardcore Henry" is what it is and makes no apologies. Adrenaline junkies not prone to motion sickness, take note.
Light on plot, high on braindead action, it turns out there's a reason hardly any films are shot in first-person view - it's just not a very good idea.
You could go see "Hardcore Henry" - or you could gulp down a pint of vodka, load in "Grand Theft Auto," then strap the TV to your face and throw yourself down the stairs.
The visual style of the film is the only thing it has going for it, too bad it gets old after 20 minutes. [Full review in Spanish]
This glorified long videoclip filmed with a "Go Pro" might be in the liking of the gaming community, but it's really just a strange product with no clear audience. [Full review in Spanish]

Hardcore Henry thrives on its original design and copycats will just be pale imitations. The only thing they could do better is write better dialogue, more plot, better characters and at least one scene that makes logical sense.
Deathly Hallows: Part 1 begins in eerie, chilling darkness and things don't let up from there, as director Yates crafts a truly terrifying spell over the Potter-verse.
Do your homework before walking in; you'll be better off for it.
There is much to love in the latest offering from the Potter franchise.
If the film's main job was to whet the appetite for the next one, it does that well.
It's just a lot of smoke - literally and figuratively - that evaporates into thin air without meaning or context.

The genius of why this film, like the book, resonates so deeply is that Rowling has found the perfect junction of pure fantasy and real politics gone horribly wrong
Yates and screenwriter Steve Kloves have done a fine job of building up a big, black foreboding cloud in this next-to-last installment.
All that drama in the tent and the weak attempt to make a love triangle happen doesn't work.
(VIDEO) A flawed decision to split the final installment of the Harry Potter books into two films results in a formless narrative that overstays its welcome.
To be fair to Deathly Hallows, the filmmakers have tried hard to fill the proceedings with battles and chases and debilitating curses. Genuine filmmaking excitement, however, is harder to provide.

The final book ... has been cleft in twain ... a move that is both cruel and absolutely necessary. Some will argue that the resulting product is merely half a film, and they'd be right. It's also one-eighth of the full story, so why start complaining now?
The magic is lost on the very young because of the films' even darker tone.
Childhood things ...[are] set aside as our three heroes, now young adults, set off on their own like resistance fighters in a World War II movie.
Frustrating as a standalone movie, DEATHLY HALLOWS nicely breaks the POTTER mold and gets us ready for the finale. But it feels like there should be an intermission, not a seven month wait.
If you're a fan, it's everything you've wanted. If not, be aware that this isn't the movie to get started with.
Although it feels far too long, Yates and Kloves thankfully mix the dark drama with lighter comedy, allowing the characters to grow organically

This is a Harry Potter film that functions as a dark, emotional character study more than a fun adventure, which will be disconcerting for some. But if you love these characters, as many of us do, you'll find a lot to admire.
The coasting comes in the middle of the movie, which is fortunate since it leaves the production with a vibrant opening act and a powerhouse final hour.
Part one of The Deathly Hallows is largely a rumble before the deafening storm.
More of the same, which means you probably already know if you like it. (I mostly did.)
Suffers from lamentable acting, murky cinematography and, for the most part, lamely unfunny dialogue.
a movie that operates with a certain, charming simplicity, but doesn't dig up much else of interest than gore delivered by the gallon.
There are many good movies opening this weekend. Hatchet II is not one of them. Tickets are not cheap and time is fleeting. Why would you choose this one?
Swift and amusingly brainless, Hatchet II more than delivers on splatter expectations.
We don't care about any of the characters. They're just video game obstacles to be dispatched as graphically as possible.

Where the original Hatchet was way ahead of the retrospective curve... now even Reagan-era slashers have been done to death, making Hatchet II seem as tired and shopworn as any of the endless Friday the 13th sequels that it pastiches.
This is basically an excuse to watch skulls crushed like melons, guts ripped from body cavities and torsos halved. And such things go on with relentless and disgusting regularity.
"Hatchet II" falls prey to a problem that typically plagues sequels: it's not just more of the same; it's WAY more of the same.
"Hatchet II" doesn't have a lick of wit.
While some of the kills seem more over the top, it's clear that most of the cast is there simply to become victims, and there's plenty of fake blood and gobby bits to go around.
By the time Crowley begins literally ripping Marybeth's posse apart, one is too numbed-out to cheer the gruesome ingenuity of the old-school special effects. Die, Victor, die. Please.

A lousy horror-comedy, straining hard to carry a tone of jovial brutality, with Green hoping to build himself up as a horror icon, using jagged fragments of formula that have become disturbingly commonplace in the DTV era.
Once you get past its relentless gore, Hatchet II just isn't a very good movie, and Green's struggles to get it released are far more interesting than the movie itself.
Only the most hardcore of gore fans are likely to be comfy with Hatchet 2.
Writer-director Adam Green offers another super-sized dose of bone-shattering, blood-splattering mayhem.
The movie is never as cheeky or as fun as Green thinks it is, but he tries with all his might.
Maybe [Adam] Green intended to parody how low-rent and awful slasher sequels usually are. If so, the joke's on his audience.
It goes for the jocular jugular, and if you want to see the human body mutilated in clever and amusing ways than this is the film for you.
Mosquitoes bite. Gators tear. But only Victor Crowley strangles a man with his own intestines until his head explodes.
First-time Sedona filmmaker Tommy Stovall can't bear to part with certain scenes, even if they lengthen his film and send the story in circles.
When the plot gets lost in irrational revenge fantasies, you'll wish you had stayed home watching reruns.

While Stovall's study of hate crimes is well acted, and with the right intentions, it can never get off the ground and feel like a unique dissection, and still comes off as an episode of a cop show in the end.
What is not entirely clear is what Hate Crime adds to the equation that hasn't been done before.
On the surface, Hate Crime may seem like a movie about violence rooted in religious bigotry, but underneath it's a poorly disguised argument for vigilantism.
Well-intentioned but convoluted thriller.
A well-meaning but hopelessly stilted melodrama, Hate Crime sacrifices good intentions with its mediocrity of execution.
... a flawed film that frequently tries to rise above standard TV dramas of the week.

critic_name: Cherryl Dawson and Leigh Ann Palone
content: It takes a turn toward vigilante justice, Texas-style, where everybody has a gun. They trade a hate crime for a crime of hate, and that mixed message overshadows the potential of this film.

The portrait of the Boyds is painted by Tommy Stovall, the film's writer and director, with such broad and venomous strokes that if the gay characters had been portrayed in the same way, the film would rightly be seen as bigoted.
The film never rises above its cry now-avenge later Lifetime Channel sensibilities.
Well-meaning but deeply flawed.
One day, a truly original screenplay will be written in which churchgoing, beer-drinking Southerners will be portrayed as something other than evil hypocrites.
First-time director Stovall renders all with the kitchen-lit, squarely composed aesthetic of timid prime-time TV, and his moral schema is no less ordinary.
An intelligent, well-acted, tense drama that is challenging in its moral complexity.
deserves praise, even the political viewpoints lack any subtlety whatsoever.
Call it too much fuel to the fire in a misguided effort to bring home the tragedy of gay hate crimes.

even if [it] finds an audience receptive to all the shock and torment, this repetitive series of fascistic taunts and visceral outrages becomes, in the absence of decent characterisation and an interesting story, surprisingly unengaging.

Influences of The Funhouse, The Strangers, and even Saw are all woven throughout, but without the innovation or imaginative set pieces that made those movies memorable. Despite what the premise suggests, there's nothing "extreme" about this haunt.
Haunt is a brisk and stimulating ride, one you'll likely come out of feeling spooked and quite satisfied.
Never scary, but the mystery of it all intrigues well enough to carry viewers through to an interesting ending... that doesn't quite satisfy as well as it thinks it does.
The promise of a fun, Halloween-set haunted-house movie is quickly dashed by a batch of weak, thinly drawn characters, poor decisions, and a preoccupation with torture.
Convincingly creepy while also slightly thought-provoking, it warns about deceiving facades, because what hides underneath masks is possibly much worse.
Dumb, gross and tasteless in all the wrong ways.
Beck and Woods absolutely nail the haunted house aesthetic and Haunt might be the scariest, and most realistic, movie about a haunted attraction.
A simple and effective bloody exercise in the old-school tradition of the slasher. [Full Review in Spanish]
Contrived character stereotypes, generic "deadly attraction" beats, and little desire to present more than outdated SAW rigs under the guise of macabre entertainment.
The tension here is pretty damn strong.
A spare premise gives way to thrills, chills and a singular horror treat.
...Haunt is a brutal Halloween horror that delivers on violence, scares, and will make you want to avoid haunted houses for the rest of the season.
A damaged young woman confronts her deepest trauma in an extreme haunt event from Halloween
There's some chillingly effective technique that keeps the premise going.
A treat for cinephiles and haunted-house aficionados.
What wins in Haunt for me is the villains. They're fun, imaginative, and creepy. And more importantly for a horror film, the kills deliver. They're to the point and pretty savage honestly.

Funny, frightening, endlessly entertaining, and with a whole host of horrible villains and genuinely likable characters, it's one of the best horror movies of the year and a slasher all-timer in the making.
A busted pumpkin of a Halloween flick.
Haunt ends up being a well-plotted, suitably sinister little shocker that proves to pack an agreeably malevolent little punch.
Though it's from the writers of A Quiet Place, the grisly horror gem plays more like a Saw movie.
I knew I was being manipulated and didn't care. It was a pleasure to see how well it was being done.
Given how insubstantial Headhunters is, stopping us from thinking critically may have been the point.
A nasty little crime thriller from Norway that twists you into a state of tense uncertainty right up to the end.
A sensational thriller that is both a satiric examination of the principal character's feeling of inadequacy and a scary look at a man's frantic attempts to escape a killer.
The good guy in the Norwegian "Headhunters" looks like a bad guy, and the bad guy looks like a good guy. And that's just one of the ways this dazzling movie messes with us.
Despite the added satirical depths, this is a movie that will only need a single viewing to 'get'.
See this version now before Hollywood spoils the fun.

[A] hilarious satire on male inadequacy disguised as an outrageously violent crime thriller. It's all the d*ck-measuring and overcompensating elevated out of the subtext to actively fuel the humor and the suspense...
Enjoyable, fast paced, blackly comic and occasionally horror-tinged thriller with a sharp script, impressive direction and a terrific central performance from Aksel Hennie.
Headhunters is ridiculous, macabre, fun - see the original before it's irrevocably ruined by it's Hollywood remake.
A fast and loose cat and mouse caper with a fair share of surprising money shots.
With the twists of a cyclone and humor that on occasion edges close to farce, it's a knife-cutting satire that's not above a bellylaugh.
Like a Teutonic techno band, this thriller is both skillfully familiar and chillingly strange.
The film has some fairly grisly violence, but also considerable humor and the sort of intricate, thought-through storytelling you'd expect from Hitchcock or the Coen brothers.
Clearly, there are streaks of farce in all this, as well as serious cracks in logic, and those who like their black comedy done to a crisp will happily feast on what Tyldum dishes up.

...extreme noir with two potential femme fatales, Tweedledee and Tweedledum cops, corporate intrigue, over the top escape plans involving out houses and tractors and an art theft expert always on the periphery.
Darkly comic thriller from Norway in which a corporate headhunter who moonlights as an art thief gets a terrifying comeuppance.
Whatever the cinematic equivalent of a kick in the pants might be, you'll find it at Headhunters.

This crime thriller from Norway has an entertainingly schizophrenic feel as it twists its way from daring heist movie to farcical black comedy, with a few drops of serious human drama thrown in for good measure.
...a sordid blast of delirious violence, brutal corporate satire, and male inadequacy.
Heartbeat Detector works on so many levels at once that its power is difficult to capture.
Begins as a dryly limp satire of corporate culture and ends as cruel and unusual punishment.
An intriguing thriller with strong performances and a dense, complex script.
A searing indictment of corporate responsibility that will intrigue conspiracy theorists.
As driven by linguistics and euphemism as this film is, it's also a slippery and wonderfully acted drama%u2014Michael Clayton with a far more troubling moral landscape.
Cold and intellectual philosophical expos√© of how European capitalism developed out of fascism through a mystery story of "corporate soldiers" intrigue.
Klotz walks a perilous tightrope between profundity and pretension without ever tipping into the chasm.
Director Nicolas Klotz combines an intriguing story with a distinctive ambiance that will appeal to an audience beyond French film aficionados.
It has haunted me ever since I saw it, with its implied foreboding for the future. Implied and justified in my opinion, and it may become yours if you choose to catch Heartbeat Detector.
Despite the failure to credibly connect modern corporate practices with Nazism, this exquisitely acted film is watchable throughout its 144 minutes.
At just under two-and-a-half hours, the movie is a horrible bore.
Heartbeat Detector doesn't really unfold; when it doesn't drag, it lurches about in fits and starts
Both pertinent and discomfiting, this sober, well-cast drama remains quietly riveting, despite its 140-minute running time.
A cinematic flatliner that was dead on arrival.
There's no killer revelation, just a graceful telescoping of past into present and a steadily accumulating dread.

Director Nicholas Klotz's subtle suspense film Heartbeat Detector comes across like a hybrid of Heart Of Darkness and Michael Clayton, digging into the roots of a psychosis affecting a veteran corporate lackey.
It's a thin line between 20th-century Nazism and 21st-century corporate culture in Heartbeat Detector, Nicolas Klotz's rewardingly chilly psychological thriller.
A chilling corporate thriller with an intriguing mystery on the surface and a deeply troubling idea at its dark core.
Intriguing, frustrating, exasperating -- the French film Heartbeat Detector succeeds best as a provocation.
A confronting examination of human evil in all its enduring banality, Heartbeat Detector takes a crooked path towards its bid for some straight talking.

Bakshi manages to offend nearly everyone from transvestites to mafiosi; but the comic distancing achieved by his army of animators manages to bring off a most difficult kind of humor: the humor of pain and despair.
A frenetic, over-the-top combination of live action and crude animation that explores the seedy world of New York's Lower East Side in the early 1970s.
Ralph Bakshi's cartoon Heavy Traffic ferociously mixes in live-action elements, tracing the schizophrenic journey of a struggling cartoonist through a crippling 70s New York City.
One of Bakshi's most brazen and bizarrely entertaining.
...deliriously perverted...
A cruel, funny, heartbreaking love note to a city kept alive by its freaks, and always, always dying.
A zesty abstract-jazz riff of a film.
There's something to offend everyone in this melange of crudely conceived, amateurishly animated stuff.
Heavy Traffic not only has an authentic tenement toughness but the rough feeling of unassimilated autobiography, of experiences and fantasies still keenly felt.
It's a downbeat, dark fantasia of urban life from a filmmaker trying to understand the darkness of the moment before it slipped away.

Heavy Traffic may be a bit dated in terms of its distinct '70s tone, but that doesn't make it any less fascinating. If you're a fan of the animation genre, this certainly qualifies as essential viewing.
It wants viewers to engage with it and think about its anti-nostalgic, scrapbook construction, and Heise accomplishes his ambitious goals with ease and grace.
In some respects, Heimat Is a Space in Time is the film that Heise was always leading up to.
German filmmaker Thomas Heise delves into his family's (and country's) tortured past in this transfixing documentary.

So, it remains up to the viewer to measure the continuance of the past while the actual family history - who died; who married who - becomes as riveting as a half-grasped soap opera, with lives and loves disappearing in the fog of time.
It's the seemingly insignificant details that should be meaningful to their family alone that really blow this thing wide open because they inevitably represent so much more.

Yet the overall effect of Heise's work is mesmeric, persuasive and cumulatively powerful, as each piece of the puzzle falls into place and he lands on overarching insights into a German century and what it portends for the future.
Out of great specificity come universal truths, and Heimat Is a Space in Time is as specific as it needs to be to be universally true.
There is something to get lost in that drift that physically and sensory transports us on this trip. [Full review in Spanish]
A serous, summative work. An ambitious formal achievement.
It is a dreadfully German piece of work. That is part of its power.
It is both aesthetically daring and narratively riveting, and the film maintains this feeling for the nearly three hours that follow.
Thomas Heise's documentary seeks to excavate real human thought and feeling beneath the haze of larger political structures.
Despite some tedious passages, "Heimat Is a Space in Time" takes an intriguing approach to history that remains refreshingly rooted in primary sources.

But although it is at times distractingly opaque, occasionally Heise's family's words, juxtaposed with his sounds and images, crystallize into something singularly wise about the nexus of place, history and trauma.
What begins as an entrancing experience becomes increasingly exhausting.
I would absolutely recommend seeing Heimat Is A Space In Time in a movie theater, where the visuals will hypnotize you, along with Heise's voice.

Through the use of family letters, photographs and government records, Heise attempts to piece together what remains of his family... The film serves as a sort of testimony of the [Germany]'s history, as well as, that of Heise's family.
...original and accomplished.
A worthwhile entry into the 80's mad-slasher wave.
Quaintly entertaining combination of slasher stuff and haunted mansion material.

You know a movie is in trouble when what is happening on the screen inspires daydreams. I had lasted through the first reel, and nothing had happened. Now I was somewhere in the middle of the third reel, and still nothing had happened.
Hell Night brought out the gimp at least a decade before Pulp Fiction was even a twinkle in Quentin Tarantino's eye.
In that rare company of slasher films that aren't just good by the standards of their subgenre, but manage to round the corner to being legitimately good works of horror cinema.
Hell Night may have an intriguing set-up, but ultimately it suffers from bland execution and a rather uneventful narrative, which results in just another forgettable slasher from the 80s.

This particular slasher set itself apart from the era's deluge of them by being somewhat of a genre-mashup with an old school haunted house movie ... you practically expect Vincent Price to step out and reveal himself from behind a curtain.
Candler's plotting is predictable and her characters should be substantially deepened, but her ability to capture the rage of male adolescence and the numbness of grief is nothing less than superb.
Hellion fits into something I like to call the "festival bubble".
Hellion offers Paul his most adult screen role so far, and he's very fine, but the movie belongs to Wiggins, a newcomer whose innate gifts are a perfect echo of Paul's.

If only Candler had trusted her characters enough to carry the story without the need for the requisite Act One gun and Act Three firing of same, Hellion would stand out more amidst an ever-growing pack of similar films.
A downbeat father-son story that moves too slowly to earn the viewer's continued forbearance.
Sharp performances provide a highlight in this otherwise muddled drama of family dysfunction.
An engrossing glimpse into a working class nightmare, a lifestyle of indulged biker-kids, guns, violence and beer that is every bit the trap we consider our inner cities to be. to be.
Despair is not quiet for a broken father (Aaron Paul) and his troublemaker sons in Kat Candler's brisk, transfixing drama, which takes place in blue-collar southeast Texas.
Texas-based helmer Kat Candler unpacks the inner turmoil behind acts of trespassing, vandalism and spontaneous aggression that threaten to send young Jacob down the wrong path in life.

Wiggins is a superstar in his debut, capturing the volcanic nature of teens harboring too much energy for their undeveloped bodies to contain. He makes good decisions and reacts well to what he's given his more experienced adult counterparts.
While the film is absorbing and not without pathos, there's insufficient insight or shape to the screenplay, which drifts between Hollis and Jacob without building momentum.
The acting overall is strong, but Paul, still testing the waters after "Breaking Bad," is extraordinarily controlled.
Dogged by a story that's both overstuffed and directionless.
Uneven but compelling...coming-of-age, troubled-teen [drama].
Both film and protagonist are troubled works in progress that shuffle and meander and frequently falter, but occasionally sing.

While there's nothing innately wrong with Candler's careful exploration of a troubled youth discovering the necessity and wisdom of doing the right thing, despite a pair of laudable performances, the essence of the film feels stagnantly predestined.
The acting is stronger than the rest of the film itself, which sports far too much shaky camera work and a conclusion that is obviously foreshadowed by the appearance of a gun early on.
"Hellion" just can't quite convince or coalesce its ideas of struggle, pain and fury in a meaningful or new way.

Though it may seem as if it's heading in the direction of being a feel-good movie Hellion doesn't go down that predictable road. It is more authentic than that, and that is indeed something to feel good about.
The relief you'll experience during the beautifully modulated ending to Hellion may elicit a heavy sigh, deep and gratifying.
Marks the superior feature film debut of Cholodenko, as well as Sheedy's strongest, and best, role to date.
The film feels superficial, with all its glib characters provoking an air of chic fashion.

As a once-acclaimed photographer who drifted out of the New York art scene into a private world of drugs and dead-end relationships, Sheedy is a genuine revelation; gone are the days when she coasted by on charm and her girl-next-door smile.
This affecting film is one of the year's more intriguing art-house entries, and doesn't deserve to be simply relegated to a niche audience.
A pseudo-intellectual film about the pseudo-intellectual world of art magazines, High Art is as wasted as its drug-addled protagonists.

Patricia Clarkson succeeds in creating a complete, complex character without ever overplaying the stoned behavior. Radha Mitchell is successful at suggesting the interaction of several motives: love, lust, curiosity, ambition, admiration.
Needed some naked Radha (don't we all?)
A solid if diffident, strongly character-focused drama worth the time of those who appreciate shoegazing introspection for the High Art that it is.
Who knew Ally Sheedy was so sexy?
Solid, sexy drama with a dash of wit. Fine performances especially by Clarkson.

A highlight of the 1998 Sundance Festival: Cholodenko depicts with unwavering veracity the breakup of one longtime lesbian relationship just as another, unexpected one begins. The acting of the three women, Sheedy Mitchell, and Clarkson, is superb.
Warmed-over Red Shoe Diaries episode wrapped in a blanket of pretension.

Clarkson's Greta... is wickedly funny, while Mitchell's ingnue convincingly combines puppyish idealism and steely ambition. But it is Sheedy's Lucy, nonchalantly sexy, sharply intelligent, tough and vulnerable, who is the film's heart and soul.
High Art is often compelling and uncannily accurate in its evocation of downtown demi-monde characters and druggy, entropic milieu-the art in this film is high in more ways than one.

The film's treatment of women's sexuality is a nice contrast to the lesbian-bed-death clich√©s (and anti-chemistry) of Julianne Moore and Annette Bening in [Lisa] Cholodenko's more recent The Kids Are All Right.
Director Carl Franklin, so crisp and economical in One False Move, bogs down in genre cliches here.
The movie's ultimate failure has more to do with its poor mastery of the basics, like keeping a tight rein on a complicated narrative.
Whenever a couple in a Hollywood film is so happy early on, it is predictable a reversal of fortunes is soon to happen.
Though glossy and formulaic, High Crimes ... proves highly entertaining.
Strong setup and ambitious goals fade as the film descends into unsophisticated scare tactics and B-film thuggery.
Apart from Blade II, High Crimes is probably the most entertaining commercial movie so far this year. And yet it's junk.
High Crimes is a petty theft of anyone who lays out dollar one to see it on a big screen.
Ludicrous, but director Carl Franklin adds enough flourishes and freak-outs to make it entertaining.
Ludicrous, but director Carl Franklin adds enough flourishes and freak-outs to make it entertaining.
The most grievous offense in the tiresome thriller High Crimes is the amount of talent squandered.
Like a stale loaf of bread that you can easily recognize has past its expiration date.
A formulaic thriller ending that's so predictable and ridiculous that it's hard to watch with a straight face.
Military whodunit isn't great drama, but director Carl Franklin's skill makes for an above-average thriller.
Consider the film a celluloid litmus test for the intellectual and emotional pedigree of your date and a giant step backward for a director I admire.
High Crimes steals so freely from other movies and combines enough disparate types of films that it can't help but engage an audience.
Stale and clichd to a fault.
'High Crimes' is criminal, criminal filmmaking. It's bad, and not in that '80s good way, just not good.
This is the work of a director who seems to have been as bored and uninspired making this movie as I was watching it.
Ashley Judd was gonna make a good movie, before she got High.
A military courtroom thriller with a simple, predictable story elevated by a strong performance from Judd.
The documentary isn't intellectually rigorous or academically minded, but it is engrossing, buoyed by the charm of Hockney and his cohorts.
A fascinating examination of the mind, motivations and legacy of one of the 20th Century's most important, modern artists.

Hockney has always been fascinated by sleights of hand, double bluffs and illusions. Wright's documentary is at its most intimate when it acknowledges a painful fact: our national treasure is bloody hard to pin down.
A life, work and spirited personality of acclaimed British artist David Hockney is wonderfully illustrated in Randall Wright's absorbing documentary Hockney.

The artist comes across as an affable raconteur, and his personal input gives this film a sense of humor and irony that is most absent in Wright's lamentable attempt to share the Hockney experience with the audience.
Hockney is a little work of art of its own, even if it's so very nice and happy about everything.
An amiable, agreeable study - as engaging and undemanding as a magazine profile with a great photo spread.
Despite ... sometimes dizzying artistic mood swings, "Hockney" remains grounded in the people and places that shaped the artist and his art.
"Everyone is looking all the time; you just have to train yourself to look harder," Hockney explains. This warm, affectionate, perceptive film makes looking harder look easy.

Randall Wright's documentary Hockney is as warm as the artist's chosen place of residence, laced with loving interviews by intimates of Hockney's which go back to his early youth in gray, drab Bradford, England.
You don't need to be a fan of the artist to enjoy this spirited celebration of his life and art. But you may end up a fan afterward.
What the film makes apparent isn't just Hockney's dandyism and brilliance, but also his formidable work ethic.
Wright's film is warm, entertaining, and a great window into Hockney's work.
Many erudite talking heads appear, but there is no satisfying overview of the artist and his complicated relationship to art history ...
A suitable portrait of one of Britain's greatest living painters, this artful documentary offers wonderful access to David Hockney, his family, friends, colleagues and of course his artwork.
Hockney is a work of artistic portraiture, one that is as refreshing and enjoyable as a spring breeze.

Pleasingly colorful assay, made with permission but pretty much free of puffery, of the lengthy career of seventy-eight-year-old English creative force David Hockney, son of Bradford, man of Los Angeles, purveyor of Polaroids, brusher of iPads.
A loving look inside the private life of a man who always remained true to himself and his art.
A documentary need not have a narrator, or be structured chronologically, but here either, or both, would have helped.
Mesmerizing documentary on an artist who is both modern and very old-fashioned in his painterly approach.

Holiday Inn, is, of course, filled with the kind of pretty Christmas songs and picture-postcard scenes of snow and horse-drawn sleighs that make for beloved holiday movies. But there's also some darkness lurking here.
Despite not being the success it could have been, this can still inspire a festive glow.
One of Astaire's low points, but with a sensational 4th of July dance number.
Great songs and stars and a pretty good script, too
Call it old-fashioned or old Hollywood fluff, Holiday Inn is a sweet, pleasant slice of another time in pop entertainment.
True to type, Crosby plays nice and Astaire shallow¬Ö The story writes itself, careful never to get in the way of big production numbers for every holiday on the calendar.
Bing Crosby and Fred Astaire. Want more? Stir in the first singing of Irving Berlin's 'White Christmas' and 'Happy Holidays.'
The Irving Berlin score, including 'Easter Parade' and 'Let's Say It with Firecrackers' (which gives Fred his best moment) makes up for the thin story.
Holiday Inn offers a reason for celebration not printed in red ink on the calendar.
Loaded with a wealth of songs, it's meaty, not too kaleidoscopic and yet closely knit for a compact 100 minutes of tiptop filmusical entertainment.
Not the best film for either of the film's stars, but Astaire proves that he can dance even without Ginger.
Classic musical with some controversial material.
One of Bing Crosby and Fred Astaire's most enjoyable and most commercially popular musicals, featuring Irving Berlin's iconic, Oscar-winning ballad, White Christmas.
Although all the holiday's are covered, this is really a Christmas movie at heart. Overshadowed by its more famous (and overrated) remake, Holiday Inn deserves more credit than it gets.
This classic musical paired Bing Crosby and Fred Astaire for the first time.
Between the toe twinkling and ivory tickling it's still a comfortable, cosy way to pass an afternoon.
Everything here is entertaining and attractive, with magnificent musical numbers and beautiful songs. [Full Review in Spanish]
Unoriginal and boring.
Compassionate and touching, but less complex and resonant than the book.

Farrell and his equally fine co-stars Wright and Roberts comprise an embattled but fiercely loving trio whom you care about deeply, even if A Home at the End of the World ultimately fails to realize the promise of its absorbing first half.
Lyrical, sweet-natured, touching, sexy and very funny, A Home at the End of the World is also beautifully served by an exemplary cast.
[Cunningham] has preserved his book's romantic, idealistic integrity, as well as its acknowledgment of the role music played in forming a generation.
An adaptation of another Cunningham book that, like The Hours, comes with its own set of challenges, which director Michael Mayer handles forthrightly, with precise emotional pitch.
I have to wonder how Colin's manhood could have distracted the audience from the plot, when not much of a plot exists.
Never less than watchable and often quite moving, especially when Colin Farrell (as Bobby) or Sissy Spacek (Alice) are on screen.
Farrell's portray of Bobby and author Cunningham's sadistic story, ultimately deep six A Home at the End of the World.
Like The Hours, A Home at the End of the World can't cover up its soap opera roots.
I never believed a minute of the story. And I never cared.
The film equivalent of the blind date described as 'really nice.' It's neither bad nor good, just sort of earnest and well-meaning.
The only thing to look forward to in At Home at the End of the World is The End
The jarring and crucially weak link is Farrell, a talented actor woefully miscast and comically uncomfortable here.
Michael Cunningham's film is an alluring look at how definitions of love, friendship and loyalty are ultimately self-defeating. It's got a few flaws, but a big ol' heart.
A perfect example of how a top-flight cast can compensate for unimaginative filmmaking.
It may be earnest but it is rarely convincing and never engaging.
Vital nuances are lost, and what's left, despite good intentions and some redeeming qualities, is cloying sentimentality wrenched from dated material.
Explores the structure of the family in its many possible forms and makes an argument that Colin Farrell is perhaps one of the most charming blokes on the planet.
shorter than THE HOURS and this is the main reason why Michael Cunnigham should be pleased with this adaptation of his work
What's interesting is pretty much unintentional, centering in the film's performances, which are excellent indeed.
The actors are tickled by their characters and have fun with them, and so I did, too.

Barrymore waddles through scene after scene in a variety of shabby housedresses and fussy, fluffy sweaters, the kinds of ridiculous clothes Hollywood seems for some reason to believe downtrodden young women in the Midwest actually wear.
It's one thing to be offbeat, and another thing entirely to be off-pitch.
The home fries are too salty for my taste.
For every good performance and delightful, well-written scene, there would be a large amount of off-the-wall material that did not work at all.
Drew comes through for us. Her easy charm and winning smile put us back on track, giving us something familiar and wonderful to cling to.
There's a good movie somewhere in here trying to escape... the audience can relate to that desire.
A dark comedy that's artificially dark and is never very funny.
Drew is cute as always and so's Wilson
A wonderfully hokey B-movie from the director with all the gimmicks, William Castle (Tingler).
Classic Castle exploitation rip-off of Psycho
Wildly plotted thriller
This devious little gem is an inspired twist on its inspiration...
I have to admit, it's a pretty good twist.
What's really surprising about Homicidal is that...it's an enjoyably bizarre film, making some of the basic elements of Psycho even freakier.
The plot's soon dawdling, a stuffy, overheated theatricality creeping in ... No pulpish curiosity but a mere footnote in the post-Psycho history of slasher movies.
There never was a Psycho knock-off quite as overt about it, yet at the same time as creative and effective in its own right,

While traveling along similar lines as Psycho, director William Castle and scripter Robb White manage to include enough originality that the shock ending still has the power to catch many viewers off guard.

Parents should take their children to "Hoodwinked Too! Hood Vs. Evil," if only because kids are never too young to learn the important and liberating skill of walking out of a movie and demanding a refund.
"Hoodwinked Too," which runs an eternity-risking 85 minutes, plays like a jaded rehash of other pictures. And none of those other pictures, sadly, is the original "Hoodwinked."
Once upon a time there was a substandard CGI secret-agent spoof with fairy-tale characters spouting unfunny dialogue and shoehorned-in pop-culture references.
The overblown title and exclamation point suggests an entertainment of the most stupendous! fantastic! thrilling! kind. Hence the concept of 'hoodwinked.'
A flat, plodding and largely mirthless affair.
...infantile humor, unrelenting wisecracks and popcult references, and flat characters who don't engage one's eyes or interest.
A modern fairy tale that will not have a happy ending for anyone paying to see it
While it seems there's no getting away from this marketing aesthetic, the resemblance at times to a video game is far, far too acute.
... bristles with funny, rapid-fire, mock-hard-boiled dialogue ...
If your little ones are clamoring for this then make them wait for cable.
Quick as a flash and just as substantial, the sequel to 2005's Hoodwinked aims to one-up the fairy tale universe and cultural references of Shrek in one go.
Apart from Hader and Poehler's hilariously overblown German accents as Hansel and Gretel, none of these actors seem to be having (or providing) much fun.
By the time a list of "Happy Days" plot lines are recited, it's clear that even as a hipster goof, "Hoodwinked Too!" is as fresh as a day-old Muffin Man.
A lame, time-wasting absolutely unnecessary sequel.
Why doesn't the Wolf just devour Red Riding Hood and put us out of this misery?
The film's ending sets things up for another sequel, and that worries me. Do you realize how many fairy tales can be Hoodwinked?!!!

A crazed, attention-deficit disordered blitz of one-liners that sees Red Riding Hood and the Big Bad Wolf chase evil fairy tale characters through a mad world in search of a secret truffle cake recipe.
cold and overwrought
The 3D surcharge gets you not just a temporary pair of glasses but 11 minutes of end credits, to pad the film to its dubious 85-minute running time.
The results are irreverent, fast, funky and funny. And hey, there may be a lesson or two in there for youngsters - especially girls - to pick up on along the way.
A near-miss, a supernatural romance-cum-whodunit that strains under the weight of its warring elements.
Will drive one to distraction with its histrionic acting, multipronged approach to storytelling and infernal attempts at social commentary.
There are a couple of decent movies somewhere inside "Horns." But here's the real sin - Aja has no idea in hell of what they are.
Horns is not quite a horror film, not quite a whodunit, not quite a comedy, indeed not quite much of anything, except a stuttering attempt to bring Joe Hill's source novel to the screen.
Aja's version is a blunt, Ghost Rider-esque superhero origin story about a kid and his devil-themed powers, punctuated by moments of weird comedy.
Radcliffe gives it his all and makes the film worth seeing. But the supernatural story feels scattered.
An effective, low-budget horror movie is lurking at the edges of "Horns" but never gets a chance to reveal itself.
Somewhere inside this lumberingly long fantasy-horror is a smart little black comedy trying to scuttle out.
The gimmick ... keeps us at a distance from the real toll on these characters.

Horns sometimes feels like a uncomfortable departure for Alexandre Aja, but Radcliffe's demonic performance strikes a devilishly indulgent balance between dark comedy and romantic tragedy that saves the day.
There are times when you will want to look away from the horrors shown on the screen but it will be hard to wipe the smile off your face.
Never lives up to the promise of its contemporary-Grimm-brothers conceit.
These Horns just aren't as sharp as they could have been.
It's not scary enough to be a horror, not funny enough to be a comedy, too "adult" to be embraced by the "YA" crowd and far too infantile to be embraced by the "A" crowd.
If it weren't for the sex and violence I would have sworn Horns was made for 13 year olds.
Seems most likely to please intense adolescents.
Predominantly a failure of tone, "Horns" has plenty of admirable traits and yet dooms itself from the outset. It's an admirable conceit stuffed into far less subtle material.
Horns appears to be of the persuasion that everybody is a liar and inherently evil, and it's a disappointingly one-note approach to a premise that could use a lighter touch.
The effect is less spine chilling and more eyebrow drooping.

The best material here is the film's satire of smalltown American values, of the modern media and of celebrity culture (the last embodied by Heather Graham's fame-hungry, narcissistic waitress Veronica)...
The only trouble is, too many of these jokes (and there are hundreds) are throwaways.
One of the pleasures of watching a spoof like this is to spot the references; it's like a quiz on pop art.
There are many instances when the film is too obvious in its attempts at humor.
A good deal of the fun is noting the film and/or television allusions and/or rip-offs.
On the whole, feels less satisfying than the original.
God help me, I laughed and slapped my thighs.
Falls into the common sequel rut; it exists but it has no real reason to exist.
Funny.
Is nothing sacred to the makers of Hot Shots! Part Deux? Nope. Not a thing.
Brilliant spoof. Right on target with Rambo III, No Way Out, Basic Instinct, and more. All clever gags.
It is what it is. The Saddam jokes get a bit tired by movie's end.
Unlike its grim predecessor, there are at least two chuckles this time round.
Pretty funny, but too much forced zaniness, jokes upon jokes, many tasteless.
This is a long way from the inspirations of Airplane!
As it charges along to its disappointingly hollow payoff, Part Deux grows increasingly violent, with a graphic in one corner of the screen toting up kills like a video game
Falling into the same trap as many nostalgia pieces before it, it stops being about a lived time or place, and seems content to just be about other movies.
For me, it mostly proved a waste of time.
Feels like a "Miami Vice" episode ripped out of some sensitive and nostalgic teen dude's diary.
Elijah Bynum's directorial debut, Hot Summer Nights, is a brazen anti-coming-of-age thriller that oozes with all the right confidence, chutzpah, and passion.
"Hot Summer Nights" doesn't have that special hook to pull viewers in, presenting feeble sensuality and overcooked dramatics, which only seem to emphasize the picture's substantial shortcomings.
Like the teenagers at its center, Hot Summer Nights tries too hard to look cooler than it ever could be.
[Elijah Bynum] solicits strong performances from his young cast - especially Timothe Chalamet as the teenage fish out of water - and blends humor and increasingly dark sensibility to good effect.
A twenty-second long sequence of a sticky and moist exchange of a lollipop is one of the most immersive sequences I have seen in some time.
Hot Summer Nights stumbles, grasping for meaning and mood, relying heavily on one of the more insistent soundtracks in recent memory.

Bynum swerves this story into gangster territory without an exit strategy. It's as if he felt the movie was always one ingredient shy of having a distinct taste of its own, and kept adding things to the mix until he ran out of time.
Hot Summer Nights is a sneaky slice of dark Americana, a gorgeously shot, hard truth coming-of-age tale rendered through a lens of innocence and grandeur, a sexy 20th century fairy tale.
There's plenty to look at, but nothing really works here.

Visually atmospheric but tonally all over the place, Hot Summer Nights, a first feature by Elijah Bynum, has much to appreciate but ultimately possesses the sampler-platter vibe of a director's demo reel.

Incredible truth and honesty are at the heart of this coming of age film, and those looking for an emotionally-charged and vibrant story about the complexities of youth and love should look no further than Hot Summer Nights.
In the end, Hot Summer Nights leaves the viewer with an an intoxicating aftertaste and a glow of enthusiasm long after the credits roll.
You've seen it all before. But you haven't seen, and should, "Hot Summer Nights."
I wouldn't call it the best movie of the summer, it is in fact the most ideal.

A sizzle reel of romantic vice and nostalgia that wears out its welcome fairly fast, leaving a magazine spread of flash, color, and play-acted anguished youth that you can tap your toes to. But jukeboxes aren't movies.
It winds up feeling anodyne when it should feel explosive.
Not terribly original, with it playing like the director watched Risky Business, Boogie Nights and Blow a little too closely - but still entertaining.
Hounds of Love is an absolutely brutal film done magnificently.
Hounds Of Love is a remarkable achievement in that it does exactly what it sets out to do, and what it sets out to do is traumatize the hell out of you. You just might not want to watch it twice.
Hounds of Love takes you to hell for two hours. No one could be blamed for wanting to be anywhere else.
Once you've seen Australian writer-director Ben Young's impressive debut, it's difficult to forget.
This is one of those undeniably great movies, but I feel like I never want to see again. Ever. [Full review in Spanish].

Australia has given us some impressive horror films over the years. More recently, The Loved Ones and Snowtown have made a real impact on the genre. Now, Ben Young's hard-hitting Hounds of Love can be added to the list.

Writer/director Young smartly focuses his efforts on the emotional destruction at play throughout Hounds of Love, making his film a standout amongst many of its peers that are more interested in pushing the boundaries of violence.
Devastating Australian horror thriller takes an unflinching look at a very sick relationship.

Each of the performances are solid, including Susie Porter who plays Vicki's mother. But it is Booth who steals the movie. As seductive as she is cripplingly anxious, she is absolutely mesmerizing to watch.
Ben Young's abduction horror says more by showing less.
Young is more interested in the abused than the abuser, and the result is an ambitious, tough-to-swallow drama fuelled by fearless performances and extraordinary empathy.
The brave actors are all superb. Curry, in particular, is a revelation: his sick, scrawny sadist is the most chilling screen killer since Hannibal Lecter.
If you can stomach its content, Hounds of Love is an undoubtedly effective work, an impressive calling card for a director sure to attract the eye of Hollywood.

With its harrowing peekaboo mayhem-Johnson turns the Whites' house into a cunningly compartmentalized stage set-and its ruthless psychological manipulation, Hounds of Love is a relentless exercise in terror.
The kidnappers are Emma Booth and comic actor Stephen Curry, playing his part terrifyingly straight.
Hounds of Love is a sinister, psychologically screwy thriller that stands on its own merits, radiating a dreamy, deviant vision of female subjugation, and empowerment.
Hounds is meticulously shot and edited, and its three lead performances elevate it to something not easily forgotten.
Anther inspired and noble entry in Australian cinema's rich ledger of suburban nightmares. In films like these, the villains wear thongs, and people get hurt while the sun brilliantly shines.
Hounds of Love is a terrifying edge-of-your-seat thriller...(with) a barbed psychological thread that pulls from such ripped-from-the-headlines horror a radiant string of hope and love.
Writer-director Ben Young, announcing himself as a name to watch, has done his homework by researching a slew of cases and considering the psychology of his story very astutely.
There is a teasing quality to Mamet's presentations that reminds me of a skilled magician, meticulously laying out his cards while telling us a story.
...will keep you on your toes and guessing from beginning to end.
What intrigues is the con games themselves, as Mamet's film explores with a certain joyous streak of mischief some of the tricks of the trade.
One of the finest Mamet adaptations out there.
Playwright David Mamet's directorial debut is a cardsharp con game full of tricks.
The best of the con game movies
A top-notch psychological thriller about sexual politics, trust and betrayal.
fiendishly clever

A conceptual film about con artists, Mamet's feature debut is a deadpan, deviously comic melodrama that proceeds with twists and reversals and builds like a poker game in which the stakes are higher and higher.
Since it would be unfair to spoil a moment of this perfectly-plotted masterpiece, all you need to know is that it landed on this critic's Best Movies of the Millennium List in 2000.

O roteiro  mais previsvel do que Mamet desejaria e seu primeiro trabalho na direo exibe uma teatralidade que ele gradualmente superaria, mas, apesar disso, a complexidade de seus personagens e a dinmica de seus dilogos so admirveis.

David Mamet's sometimes baffling, never less than fascinating glimpse into the dark underbelly of this world where it turns out that winning games of chance involve more skill (and con artistry) than luck.
Regardless of whether the film still delivers its intended zing, it's still hugely satisfying to watch all the moving parts click into place.
...Mamet has infused House of Games with exactly the sort of irresistibly theatrical atmosphere for which he's known...
Plastic Paris looks right at home in this melted down remake.
OK, guys, let's just cut to the chase: Paris Hilton does not bare all in "House of Wax." That said, the show isn't as awful as I had anticipated.
Enough of an original spin on the premise to make this the creepiest horror remake in quite some time.
Though this is a step up from the usual teen snuff-movie fare, it still very much wanes more than it waxes.
Expect lots of Slasher Movie 101 and putatively clever jibes at a certain high-profile hotel heiress (involving a video camera, of course, and a box full of cell phones that don't work).
Wretched excuse for a horror flick.
The characters are about as intelligent as their waxen alter-egos, making it impossible to care too much about what happens to them.
The new remake of House of Wax proves it's actually possible for a movie to get dumber as it goes along.
House of Wax is cheap, dirty entertainment, and it knows it.
Rookie director Jaume Collet-Serra concentrates on mild shocks, unpleasant bloodiness and a dank stickiness in the set design.
I've got some real affection for House of Wax and perhaps that, more than anything, is why I wish it were just a tiny bit better.
Meanwhile, the audience wonders when Paris Hilton will be eviscerated for their enjoyment.
Director Jaume Serra's feature film debut is chock full of everything a director shouldn't do in a film.
A standard-issue 'dead teenager movie.'
The set design is fairly elaborate by the standards of the genre, and the victims don't die in precisely the order you might expect, but everything else goes pretty much according to formula.
In this film, Paris is the brains of the outfit.
Gives new meaning to the term "snuff film."
The film's storyline has more in common with Manos, The Hands of Fate than the original House of Wax.
2005's House of Wax turns out to be a better reimagining of "The Texas Chainsaw Massacre" than last year's lousy remake
how seriously should any film be taken when it has Paris Hilton and her lacy red lingerie in a supporting role?
Provides a somewhat accurate historical framework for the period.
...most of this stuff simply isn't interesting.
"The House On 92nd Street" stands as a noxious example of patriotic pap disguised as faux docu film noir.
"Puke has a mind of its own." Issued by a kid named Plug, this assessment more or less summarizes the point of How to Eat Fried Worms.

With its universal themes about fitting in, How To Eat Fried Worms is an endearing family film guaranteed to provide a wriggling good time. While the premise has a certain gross-out factor which will delight eleven year old boys, the script is clever, and
When it comes time for the movie to impart its lessons, it does so in such a way that kids won't feel like they're being forced to eat their broccoli -- or live worms -- for that matter.
Yes, it's a gross-out comedy, but safe for younger viewers.
No worms were harmed in the making of "How to Eat Fried Worms," but one classic book was.
This is a story that could have gone way too far in the direction of the touching tale illustrating how kids overcome their fear of being ridiculed -- but instead maintains a buoyant irreverence.

Jettisons nearly everything about the book except a few character names and the gross-out subject matter¬Ö Didn't anyone involved stop and say, 'Wait a minute ¬ó this isn't overcoming bullying, this is bullying'?
This cute lesson in standing up to bullies, based on the award-winning Thomas Rockwell book of the same name, is still tailor-made for its target demographic.
Here's hoping its old-fashioned sensibility appeals to contemporary kids, because we could certainly use more movies as smart and sweet as this one.
An admirable children's movie that hides a surprisingly palatable lesson about growing up behind the gross-out come-on of its title.
As yet another children's novel-turned-big-screen flick, Fried Worms has all the wholesome goodness of tomato soup, while the side of crispy larva gives it an extra kick.
Bob Dolman sets dull-as-dishwater images to a straightforward adaptation of Thomas Rockwell's prize-winning kid-lit classic.
This is exactly what you want for your kids the last week of summer.
This is a delightfully snips and snails and puppy-dog tails-style movie, based on the book that has happily grossed out kids since 1973.
"How to Eat Fried Worms" is a tasty little treat for grade-school kids.
Unhealthy eating is paired with a wholesome message, as the story encourages youngsters to be themselves, keep their word and accept kids who are different.

What we have here is a 90-minute worm-eating contest, a spectacle that could be of interest only to robins, small-mouth bass and eight-to-11-year-old boys. Girls, don't bother. Parents and guardians, if you have to go, plan to take a nap.
Take the kids to see How to Eat Fried Worms, but hold off on forking over the usual princely sum at the concession stand.
It's a pleasant and well-intentioned end of summer diversion that doesn't possess the imagination-stoking qualities of a premier children's movie.
An appealing juvenile cast distinguishes this otherwise uneven live-action adaptation of Thomas Rockwell's 1973 young adult book.
You know where a film's heading when it manages to poke fun at Asians, the handicapped, and overweight people all within the first five minutes.
A crafty satire, but with a swashbuckling soul.
The plot is convoluted, the characters are silly and the ancient jokes, puns and sight gags are so low they make the Three Stooges seem sophisticated.
To say this megamillion Bruce Willis vehicle doesn't fly is understatement in the extreme.

Admirably insane. It's bad, but it's not all THAT bad -- and it's actually quite entertaining in a "What the HECK...?" sort of way.
Not as bad as claimed, but pretty damn bad

so implausible and so over the top that it lets inconsistency roll off like water on a duck's back

Let's be clear: 'Hudson Hawk' is, by most reasonable standards, a pretty bad movie. Yet you have to give it this much: in contrast to your typical summer blockbuster, then or now, at least it's got some personality.
...an exceedingly erratic yet generally watchable comedy...

Corman mini-classic featuring boob-happy sea monsters.

For your art-house pleasure and discomfort, here's one of the most talked-about film-festival triumphs of 2008, a disturbingly avid re-creation of the last six weeks in the life and slow, self-imposed wasting of Irish hunger striker Bobby Sands.
A gut-wrenching prison drama that can be compared to Jonas Mekas's brutal 1957 film 'The Brig.'
More pro-terrorist propaganda.

That a film this masterful is the product of a first-time filmmaker is astonishing. The harrowing, contemplative Hunger is, without question, one of the gutsiest, most self-assured initial films ever made.

Hunger is not about the rights and wrongs of the British in Northern Ireland, but about inhumane prison conditions, the steeled determination of IRA members like Bobby Sands, and a rock and a hard place.
An unconventional biopic that tells in an aesthetic no-holds-barred way the harrowing story of Irish Republican Army activist Bobby Sands.
Ultimately, the one thing that can't be questioned is McQueen's bold and unflinching talent.
Hunger is an intense movie-going experience, one that will leave you both drained and uplifted.

Em sua estr√©ia como diretor, McQueen exibe uma surpreendente seguran√ßa na concep√ß√£o de seus planos, alternando com intelig√™ncia entre elaborados planos-seq√º√™ncia e fascinantes planos est√°ticos e longos, jamais perdendo controle da narrativa.
Powerful, pertinent but not entirely perfect.
Yes, "Hunger" is a fairly nasty affair and we don't even get to the starvation part until the third act.

[The] unflinching camera, deliberate pacing and maddeningly long takes (including a 10-minute, single-shot conversation that, while hypnotic, belongs on stage) just amplify the story's innate harshness and test audience endurance levels.
A remarkable directorial debut from British artist Steve McQueen, who co-wrote the screenplay.
In the end, even though I recognized the need to be reminded of Guant√°namo and of crimes carried out there, I was awed but not moved by Hunger.

The film is stunning. Bare, minimalist, stark and based in a hardened reality that's as hypnotic as it is horrific, this is as gut-wrenching an exercise into documentary-like historical fiction as any I'm ever likely to see.
There's suspense here, but also a terrible sadness at the conflict itself and how men on both sides of the argument are destroyed by fanaticism.

Politically, Bobby Sands' suicide meant nothing, but it illustrated poisonous lengths to which someone would go in protecting the only reality he ever knew. This is terrorism's pox, and why the Troubles - though stabilized - still bear the scars of shame.
McQueen's film is not so much an attempt to reopen old wounds as a cinematic portrait of the wound itself, a visceral embodiment of politics at the very cellular level of those who engage in it.
As pretentious as it is engrossing...
Hunger is daunting and powerful work.
The plot demands some plausibility despite how fictitious it might be, but the script and the realization seem rushed and abandoned from the very beginning. [Full Review in Spanish]

The Hunt for Red October as made by a Michael Bay wannabe who can't even rise to the level of giving-a-propagandistic-crap. Absurd geopolitics and laugh-out-loud clich√©s abound; tension and excitement do not.
Listen, no one is going to walk into Hunter Killer expecting Tarkovsky.

Hunter Killer... won't win any awards for acting or writing but generates suspense when it needs to and tells an engrossing Tall Tale.

Save yourself some time and steer clear from this illogical excuse of mainstream cinema.
It's a flavourless, unoriginal, but occasionally charming bit of suspense in the tenor of a Tom Clancy knock-off.
Generic big-screen genre-fiction. Cliched but watchable.

The constant agitation and bone-deep respect for all things military is straight out of Clancy's playbook, but there's no Jack Ryan figure to humanize it all...There's very little to hold on to. For the most part, we just watch a lot of gears grind...
The film's second half kicks into gear and plays out like a moderately efficient popcorn thrill ride, even if it's not on the level of sub thrillers like "Crimson Tide" or "The Hunt for Red October."
Marsh is in way over his head with the thriller, but he manages a few creative achievements as he sets out to make a movie that's been done before, and much better too.

A middling sea thriller giving off big explosions and no controversy despite the Russians and Americans involved in an incident at sea.

Not to be a killjoy, but had Hernndez simply made a more straightforward, conventional movie about the life and loves of a rising gay Mexican film director, he might have had something.

(Director Julian) Hernandez provides loads of sexy scenery but not much sense. The film is heavy on slow, sensual storytelling that more often than not demands viewers' intuition rather than offer clearly delineated characters and relationships.

...Hernandez merely revels in his own pretentiousness, staging one dully limp encounter after another with self-conscious camerawork and absurdly stilted drama that renders the entire project a pseudo-porny slog.
If the film defies conventional form, it does so without the gravitas that conceptual cohesion brings, quickly rendering its experimentation into gratuitous aesthetic masturbation.
A film that is impeccable from a formal point of view, but that begins to stumble with the limits of its speech. [Full review in Spanish]
The key to enjoying this film is parking your narrative instincts at the door and allowing the masterfully constructed sensual images to wash over you.
'Roswell' meets Critters (and a dozen other ideas)... decidedly more 'Aliens' ass kicking than 'Twilight' tweening.
The film's best moments belong to Teresa Palmer as unexpected backup to Number Four, who makes a fiery entrance every bit as dramatic as Arnold Schwarzenegger in Terminator.

"I Am Number Four," the appealing new kid-on-the-teen-angst block, reverberates with much of the same dark combustible mix of action and romance that's been fueling the "Twilight" vampire mega-franchise for a while now.

A bastard hybrid of 'Smallville,' 'Twilight' and any number of other angsty teen-themed sci-fi shows and movies...feels like a co-production of the CW and the SyFy channel that's inexplicably escaped to the big screen.
Seriously, though, I Am Number Four may not be the greatest thing since sliced bread but I enjoyed watching it all the same.
I Am Number Four indeed. Cause this is a movie that just took two gigantic dumps on my brain.

When the dust clears, and the disjointed coda is tacked on, the way is paved for a sequel, or several, and the audience is left wondering if they will appeal to more than the tweens targets for this one
I Am Number Four doesn't even begin to start making sense until at least 20 minutes in, but as the pieces fall into place, the thinness of this particular fiction comes into clear focus.
A modestly interesting but mostly paint-by-numbers rip-off of better cinematic adventures.

I really hope a sequel comes along to answer our questions and close up some loose threads.

Four is a tease, promising muscular genre goods it never delivers, led by a painfully robotic performance from English actor Pettyfer, who spends the entirety of his screentime fussing with his unconvincing American accent.

This movie is so poorly written, with inexplicable characters making ridiculous choices, and the dialogue is simply cringe-worthy.
It's like eating a plain Hershey's bar on that supposedly most romantic day of the year. It may soothe your sweet tooth for a brief bit, but you'll still be longing for Godiva.
All I Hate Valentine's Day adds up to is an awkward, ritualized date between moviegoer and a still-learning triple hyphenate.
Is it too pat to say I Hate This Movie? That's about the level of creative energy Vardalos applies to a film that manages to be every bit as bad as My Life in Ruins.
The strength of Vardalos' movies is that she loves all of her fellow actors and allows large ensembles to flourish.
An unspeakable nadir in the career of its writer-director-star, My Big Fat Greek Wedding's Nia Vardalos.
The movie is set up as a valentine to Vardalos. She should try sending herself flowers.
I Hate Valentine's Day is a horror show masquerading as a romantic comedy. Maybe Vardalos is just in the wrong line of work.
A charmless rom-com about an exhaustingly vivacious florist.
Everyone who's ever seen a movie knows where this is headed... but getting there is breezy, fun, and most importantly, well-executed.
Put it this way: Children who see this film at an impressionable age risk inhibiting their social growth.
Vardalos doesn't write dialogue; she writes shtick...the whole thing is one long riff, with few laughs and an inevitable destination.
Vardalos calls her film "the ultimate indie experiment," and if that's what is meant by ham-fisted pacing, writing, and acting, this is as ultimate and as indie as it gets.
As a madcap comedy of existence, I Heart Huckabees is literally full of itself.
Such an entertaining bundle of chaos that you can't help but love it.
Russell is a cool and clever director, with a vision all his own.
It's a mad, mad, mad, mad, meaningful world, indeed.
In a way, the movie is about everything and nothing, but its real problem has less to do with its philosophical ambition than with its scattered, half-digested musings.
It's nearly impossible to sustain such flaky weirdness for 105 minutes.
The movie is disjointed and pointless. But its biggest shortcoming is that it's not funny.
By far the most original comedy of the year.
Trying to decode the film through its entertaining philosophical ramblings leads nowhere substantial... [Huckabees] is a vision of contemporary US divisiveness.
A sort of static whirligig -- too heavy to soar but too light to ever fall flat.
As with Russell's other films, Huckabees moves its audience from initial bafflement to a broader apprehension of a situation rife with complexity.
plays entirely by its own rules. Russell has never been a filmmaker who kowtowed to convention... and the satiric 'Huckabees' is no exception.
Careful, intelligent writing that is formally arresting, provocative and still wickedly funny.
Russell continues to be able to write to Wahlberg's strengths, steering him towards a believable mania encompassing some of the movie's best and most touching comedic moments.
An ambitious but disjointed spoof of New Age quirks and quacks that attempts to simultaneously put down and lift up. But, despite the A-list ensemble, it accomplishes neither.
There are plenty of attempts at absurdist, droll humor, but Huckabees is too eccentric for its own good.
So what's an existentialist comedy? Basically, it's a silly, irreverent, chaotic metaphysical farce about what it means to be alive.
Brilliant use of the screwball comedy form to represent and explore existential themes...fodder for dorm debates and cultural studies theses, it is also a ton of fun.
If it had the unwavering focus and clear-eyed vision of Russell's previous two features, I Heart Huckabees might have been brilliant.
Russell is a true original. It's not in his DNA to play it safe. He's a rebel Pied Piper, and Huckabees is one more reason to follow him anywhere.
A modest but engaging tale of friendship and survival.
A tour-de-force for Claire Danes
I Spy exhausts you with its derivative stupidity, leaving you weak and bored and weary of comedy that's not funny, action that's not exciting, dialogue that's not clever.
Just about everyone involved here seems to be coasting. There are a few modest laughs, but certainly no thrills.
Implausible, utterly ridiculous, and absolutely unfunny.
It's easy to watch trash, and although Murphy and his co-stars deserve better, it would be wrong for me to lie to you and say that I was bored.
Too much of the humor falls flat.
Banal and predictable.
It knows it's a lousy movie and draws attention away from the plot by focusing on the personalities
I cry for I Spy -- or I would if this latest and laziest imaginable of all vintage-TV spinoffs were capable of engendering an emotional response of any kind.
A sometimes very funny but mostly banal action-comedy that has only superficial links to its 1960s source.
An unremarkable, modern action/comedy buddy movie whose only nod to nostalgia is in the title.
The cast seems so intent on delivering the goods that you can't help wondering what this might have amounted to if it didn't have such an aversion to actual substance.
A tired old buddy comedy with laughs stitching together chases and explosions.
I Spy" made me laugh. It's a blast.
Nothing special, but for fans of Murphy or Wilson it'll be worth a look once it hits video stores.
A rather dismal, glaringly formulaic action-comedy.
If you're looking for nostalgia, you're in the wrong place.
A whole lot of fun and funny in the middle, though somewhat less hard-hitting at the start and finish.
Une comdie d'action o l'action est dficiente mais o la comdie fonctionne.
What's next: "My Mother the Car?"
I Spy is ample reminder that memorable comedy is, in its own way, as tricky to pull off as a good party.
A ghostly thriller that's all plot, no emotion and thrill-free, despite the presence of Belle Thorne, the hardest working woman in show business.
There's too much science, not enough fiction, in this sci-fi spook-show.
I Still See You is painful to watch, and having to learn all the new jargon only makes it feel like an academic chore.
Newcomers will find this adapted tale's fantasy logic arbitrary, its plot convoluted, and the sum effect wildly unconvincing...
The main reason 'I Still See You' doesn't come together is that Speer and Fuchs are so focused on complicating their already over-convoluted plot.
Kids with little experience and no discernible talent keep turning out bombs with alarming frequency. Add a dreary, post-apocalyptic mishap called I Still See You to the list.
Once all the pieces are in place, the film becomes a more conventional and less interesting thriller, with a single violent villain the heroes have to overcome.
It's probably a warning sign when a director's strongest feature is a Step Up movie.
If you're looking to be swept away in a sci-fi- thriller, you'll probably be disappointed.
Some violence, brief nudity in weak sci-fi horror.
I Still See You is an ideal early foray into the horror genre for the modern teenage girl and her slumber party pals.
An imprecise script that is continually disconnected from its fundamental purpose and makes the way forward tortuous. [Full review in Spanish]
A muddling disappointment.
I'll Always Know What You Did Last Summer is entirely worthy of the dismissive derision that you felt when you first read the title.
This one will not hook any but the most desperate of horror fans.
Somebody kill the Gordon's Fisherman, already...
Aggressively dull and downright unwatchable...
Not bad enough to be good.
Another violent and unnecessary sequel.
There are so many chances for Illegal Tender to get things right that it's depressing to realize that it misses all of them.
An entertaining genre piece boasting a terrifically sinewy lead performance from Wanda De Jesus.
A solid meat-and-potatoes B-movie with enough personality to spin it in unexpected directions.
The script is so formulaic, the atmosphere so bright, the acting so off, it's a bit of a mess.
Potentially compelling questions of ethnicity, privilege and societal inequities lurk in the background, but instead of addressing them, the film flounders in melodrama.
Illegal Tender has its moments -- including the aforementioned shootout involving Millie -- but it is ultimately undone by the litany of genre cliches it embraces.
Pure B-movie hokum...a cheesy, goofy combination of family melodrama and gangster cliche that strains not only credulity but patience.
Illegal Tender isn't a very good film, but it shows a genre filmmaker who is full of ideas and unwilling to settle.
De Jesus' outbursts are the only excitement in 'Illegal,' since the performances of most of the rest of the cast are barely amateurish and Reyes' story is not so much old-school as it is old-hat.
It's helpful if you walk in with the expectation that it is a genre picture -- not a parody, not camp, but a loving homage to gangster movies of the 1980s like Scarface.

It is fun to see Wanda de Jesus get all Pam Grier and shoot off two big guns at once after making a peanut butter and jelly sandwich for her son. But the big dumb story and the big dumb dialogue keep getting in the way.
A problematic but compelling exaltation of violence, privilege, and ethnic pride, Illegal Tender is incessantly but hotly scored, suggesting something of a Sirk melodrama for our Reggaeton times.
Grace is not the film's strong suit. But trashy -- albeit sporadic -- fun is.
For a second, the movie has the snap of a truly surprising thriller... But then we go back to following the kid, who manages to both mope and strut along the path to manhood.
Illegal Tender has the potential to be a better film than it is.
Clearly aware of the impact of visual style on the narrative, Jonathan Ogilvie uses a stylised 1920 Australian setting for a love triangle that involves all the basic drivers of human frailty
Over-the-top melodrama that offers lots of freewheeling gunplay and action in desperate search of a believable story.
A laughable low-budget mess about third-rate drug thugs, put together with the sheen and polish of a fourth-grade Christmas pageant. Except with really loud reggaeton.
This second-rate action drama features a mostly Latino but mostly wasted cast.
Brainless bloodsport, Cholo-style.
A tremendously provocative date movie for couples brave enough to face each other afterward.
If this is director Attal's attempt to dive into the complex world of marriages, he barely swam past the shoreline.
A meditation on the joys and frustrations of monogamy that manages to be a diverting and funny character study at least most of the time.
The repetitiveness is eased only in those sequences when Johnny Depp, Anouk Aimee and Claude Berri make cameo appearances.
Attal is creative in crafting cinematic mood, using focus and camera movements to subtly but deftly enhance and even anticipate emotions.
Bereft of the meta elements that characterized the filmmaker's previous My Wife Is An Actress.
There's little you haven't seen in any number of French flicks, but then, most of them didn't have Gainsbourg.
full review in Greek
Happily Ever After is never as insightful or as funny as Woody at his best. But the film has a fine-tuned approach to human behavior.
This is terrific filmmaking.
It is too bad that the [scenes that do work] remain only fleeting -- almost furtive -- glances into the lives of the characters, and are not part of a coherent and properly focused story.
This is a fetching piece of work, both comical and savvy, and Gainsborough's brisk, forward intelligence rescues Gabrielle from snags of marital self-pity.
If there is any doubt as to whether French cinema is in a state of free fall, Yvan Attal's Happily Ever After should put such uncertainties to rest.
Attal doesn't illuminate Vincent's motives for straying, and unwisely suggests Vincent's philandering and Gabrielle's daydreaming are somehow morally equivalent.
This is an affair to forget.
