Bartlett's use of blank verse, with the occasional exquisitely composed soliloquy, is also a masterstroke, injecting the drama with depth and humour through tantalising nods to Hamlet, King Lear, Macbeth and Henry IV.
The movie, like the Broadway show, is performed as a Shakespearean history play. The dialogue is spoken in verse, the scenes are rapid and punchy, and the actors are top-notch.
A perfect 90 minutes of television.
Perhaps this majestic, unmissable drama will send new audiences back to the source for meaningful encounters with Lear, Lady M, Brutus, Prince Hal and other forebears.

The late, brilliant Tim Pigott-Smith is mesmerising as Charles. It's not an impression, thankfully, nor was the actor made up to look like him (that would have been tiresome), but an interpretation of character.
It all feels a bit unfair to the real-life counterparts. And then King Charles III makes a fascinating pivot.

By turns bouncy, melancholy, arrogant and sore betrayed, the face little resembles that of Charles but, somehow, within its planes, there is conveyed the selfsame sense of insane privilege, niggling grievance and open, misunderstood humanity.
If King Charles III never quite escapes its ruling conceit, it nevertheless makes for a pleasurable experience.
Surely the boldest BBC show of the year.
Unfortunately it's not a movie about Green Party candidate Nader -- just a barely passable "funny fat guy" flick
Interesting premise of Goodman becoming King works as fairly funny comedy.
Filmmaker David S. Ward certainly does an effective job of establishing Goodman's affable protagonist and the situation in which he finds himself...
Once Liam Neeson's noble knight Godfrey exits, Orlando Bloom's lightweight Balian can't carry this message-heavy lecture.
The biggest shortcoming of this crusader story is not that Scott twists the facts (he does), but that he can't elevate the story to something more than an alluring re-creation.

One imagined that a movie about the Crusades would be gallant and mad; one feared that it might stoke some antiquated prejudice. But who could have dreamed that it would produce this rambling, hollow show about a boy?
Just isn't the larger-than-life, heartrending Crusades masterpiece we were praying Gladiator's director would deliver.
This Kingdom would truly rule with a Crowe or Gibson, not a middleweight like Orlando Bloom
The world's longest and most inscrutable luxury car commercial.
A war story that takes no sides because it takes all sides. And it's a period piece, set in the last decades of the 12th century after Christ, that resonates in a thoughtful way today.
Scott continues to be a master of chaotic mayhem.
A $130 million epic with much to marvel at and great battle scenes, but it dazzles the senses while barely touching the heart.
While it will soon be forgotten and its central message ignored by those in power, it's a great looking film that's better than recent 'epics'.
a film that tries to be something special, but ultimately fails because of an over-padded script and too many poorly-cast actors.
Even when the drama falters, the movie shimmers with palatial splendor, explodes with adventure and reeks with bloodshed and horror.
From watching the film, it's a bit hard to care who conquers.
Despite...weaknesses, 'Kingdom of Heaven' emerges an entertaining film...stunningly photographed, set and costumed...grandeur that evokes De Mille
An epic about Christian crusaders who happen to be liberal humanists willing to die for the sake of religious tolerance. That's just ... weird.
The consummate battle epic.
The Crusades lasted just over 200 years, which is longer than Kingdom of Heaven, although not by as much as you might hope.
Glossy, popcorn entertainment at best. And that wouldn't necessarily be a bad thing if the subject were anything other than the Crusades.
...an unmitigated disaster from start to finish, offering up a level of sheer dullness that's shocking...
A bewildering mishmash of battle scenes and tenuous relationships that calls for heartthrob Orlando Bloom to save the day in a rags-to-riches hurry.
Kings Row (1942) is a thought-provoking, emotional, melodramatic, 'Peyton Place'-like film with a turn-of-the-century, small-town setting that revealed evil, cruelty, duplicity and depravity.
The film is dark, incredibly so for a mainstream movie before World War II.
Unpleasant soap opera, but well made.
Classic soap opera, maybe all time best; certainly Reagan's best

A wonderful guilty pleasure potboiler enchanced by a magnificent Korngold score and fine acting from Ronald Reagan in the performance of his career. Only lead Robert Cummings is weak as Paris Mitchell; just imagine James Cagney in the role!
...while episodic and sentimental and filled with all kinds of unlikely turns of events, there is no denying the characters are endearing and the ending uplifting.
Sam Wood's Oscar-nominated small-town tale is one of the darkest melodramas Hollywood made in the 1940s, full of neurotic personalities and perverse secrets.
The film that made the future President Reagan a movie star.
Potent, artful cinema.
A film of very high quality that you won't easily forget. [Full Review in Spanish]
While several of the lesser ideas, such as pity and revenge, aren't demonstrated with as much tact, the sweeping melodrama is still a winning formula.
kink wonderfully achieves its goal of lightly educating and demystifying the world of BDSM, but for people that are already familiar with this world, you may find yourself left wanting.
More than just a thorough examination of hardcore pornography, Christina Voros's doc is also a sort of chronicle of the filmmaking process.
The doc is often terrific fun. But it is a work of observation and advocacy rather than journalism.
Kink may ultimately be too slight to rank as a great documentary, but it does suggest the arrival of a great documentary filmmaker.
The director, Christina Voros, adopts an educational approach that embraces the pleasure within the pain.
It's not all about catharsis and transcendence for these folks; sometimes it's just about providing sordid sexual fantasies to people who need them.
The movie often feels like a full-length ad for a great workplace, which just happens to stash whips and chains in the stationery closet.
I've never left a documentary so informed about a subject I had no idea I wanted to be informed about.
Great Danes 'Klown' Around
Denmark's answer to Curb Your Enthusiasm, with vestiges of Dogme 95.
Ultimately, Klown is just a comedy, and an excruciatingly funny one at that, even if at times it does veer into somewhat uncomfortable territory.
At its best, it's a sly dismantling of a familiar comedy template built on male cluelessness and female responsibility.
It can seem sometimes that Hollywood has a monopoly on stupid, obnoxious comedy. Anyone who sees "Klown" will learn otherwise.
Klown feels instantly fresh, taking bold chances with its characters and gags that pay off in uproariously funny and sometimes heartrending moments.
Story of a man's ill-concieved attempt to prove his merit as a father benefits from Frank Hvam's dry comic performance.
Raunchy, awkward, over-the-top and fun.
Every seemingly happy resolution sets up the next catastrophe.
While the jokes are utterly immature, the film actually offers a surprisingly mature portrait of masculinity in all its wondrous insecurities.
At some point, someone will write the history of this modern comedy of the uncomfortable, and when they do, I hope they devote an entire chapter to 'Klown.'
Situational comedies need some believability to be effective, and too many gags in Klown feel like punchlines whose set-ups were engineered in reverse...
Each gag has added appeal because it contains an uneasy humor that's often explored but never fully exploited in these parts.
Ultra-raunchy, sometimes hilarious...
[VIDEO ESSAY] Easily the most ribald and politically incorrect comedy to come out of the 21st century's second decade so far, Mikkel Norgaard's "Klown" hits funny bones you didn't know you had.
KLOWN may not necessarily garner Casper and Frank too many new fans, yet it will most likely please the target audience with its raunchy and sardonic humor.
I wouldn't say you need a strong stomach to handle some of the bits, but you certainly need to be able to have a sense of humor about some things that are legitimately awful.
It's the absurdity of the whole thing, combined with subtly brilliant comic performances and a richly warm centre, that make N√∏rgaard's film so thoroughly enjoyable.
A grim, desperately unfunny parade of dick jokes, masturbation jokes, dick jokes, paedophilia jokes, dick jokes, rape jokes, gay jokes and dick jokes
Denmark's charmless answer to The Hangover crosses the line between gross-out and just plain gross.
If you like exhilarating, escapist nonsense with personality, Knight and Day is for you.
In the traditional way, the story is a flimsy thing; and in the traditional way, that doesn't matter.
A stylish, globe-hopping, action-packed comedy that starts at full blast and never lets up. Cruise hasn't been this loose and comfortable on screen in a long time.
Apparently it's OK to have numerous corpses in a PG-13 movie, as long as none of them have names.
A highly enjoyable, breezy action film. Cruise and Diaz are fun to watch.
A high-energy, low-impact caper-comedy that labors to bring a measure of wit, romance and glamour to an overworked spy-thriller template.
Scattered and uneven, this action drama wastes a terrific Tom Cruise.
Falha em basicamente tudo que se prope a fazer, s no se tornando um fracasso completo graas ao carisma de seus protagonistas.
The miracle is that Patrick O'Neill was able to pitch his screenplay for Knight And Day and not get carted off to a home for the criminally insane.

Boasting fine supporting turns (Peter Sarsgaard and Viola Davis are both excellent), perfectly placed twists and turns, and enough star-shine to power a small city, Knight And Day is big time entertainment, with a capital E.
Knight and Day may cover familiar ground, but it does so with confidence and with two movie stars who were able to effortlessly summon their biggest movie star charisma.
Seven or eight years ago, maybe, this team-up might have been worth getting excited about.
The real purpose of the exercise is watching the two stars radiate charisma at nuclear levels while zipping through exotic locales in high-speed vehicles.
There's no kinetic rhythm, no From Paris With Love energy or craft, no Jonah Hex wit -- only a distorted, distended James Bondish marathon chase.
If you've ever heard a humorless man try to tell a joke, then you know everything you need to about James Mangold's straining, flat-in-all-directions foray into action-comedy, Knight and Day.
Knight and Day, his latest tilt in that direction, has its flaws, but at least it gives audiences a good time.
True, "Knight and Day" is preposterous nonsense. Just think of it as a spoof of one of Cruise's "Mission: Impossible" movies on crack.
For every female who's ever been infatuated with Tom Cruise... here's your love letter. Did this go wrong in the editing room, or was it always this bad of an idea?
Truly enjoyed Tom Cruise in this movie. Diaz...not so much.
Cruise and Diaz are both easy to look at and they work well together.
Succeeds mainly because of its hell-for-leather exuberance.
A young man with superhuman powers doubles as Krrish, a masked hero, in a Bollywood sequel that blends carefree romance, show-stopping action and sci-fi.
Hearty pulp cinema that really sticks to your ribs.
Hrithik has the right mix of brawn and emotional vulnerability to pull off the masked marvel convincingly.
Enjoyable, daffily improbable escapist romp further expands Bollywood's pop genre repertoire.
Bollywood through and through, but a noble and innovative attempt at a typically alien genre.
It's a minor joy to see a film so ingenuous as this, plainly wearing its corporate sponsorship on its sleeve.
The problem with Krrish lies in the fact that it lacks the fun quotient which Koi Mil Gaya was generously sprinkled with.
... the film is a mess, split between a bunch of characters and jumping genres at every cut, with a juvenile humor clearly aimed at younger audiences.
A joyous Bollywood dance extravaganza aptly wraps up the proceedings. It might not be part of Chinese tradition, but it is celebratory.
If you're going for the Kung Fu, chances are you'll end up in a meditative state instead.
With a generous runtime of almost 2.5 hours, Kung-fu Yoga does outstay its welcome.
Kung-Fu Yoga works because of the numerous scenes of fantastic hand-to-hand combat that are often punctuated with a comedic tone.
Not even Jackie Chan can save this ill-advised mash-up.

Kung-Fu Yoga scratches fans' itch for no-nonsense, no-pretense Chan fare - in which he isn't second-banana to a Western star, or married to a director who thinks VFX are required to make Chan's stunts more impressive.
If you have grown up watching Jackie Chan movies and loved him more for his comic timing and endearing goofiness or his expert kung fu, Kung Fu Yoga will leave you with a feeling of sadness.

By the time it all culminates in a Chan-led classic Bollywood production number, the cuteness factor may have been pushed to its limit, but good luck trying to stop that goofy smile from spreading across your face.
The globetrotting adventure yarn extensively, and energetically, riffs on Indiana Jones's signature moments. You'll wish that its storytelling polish matched its enthusiasm.
Kung Fu Yoga is a massive disappointment for fans of Jackie Chan, fans of cinema, Indian fans, Indian people in general and is just a complete embarrassment for all involved.

The fast-paced plotting, and typically silly action-comedy sight gags ensure that the 103-minute running time breezes by, but there is little here that hasn't been seen before, or that Chan hasn't done better.
An amiable, average-at-best caper-like quest remains just that, even with recognisable talent, and even more so when its combination of elements is clearly stretched.
Once in a while I see a film that is hypnotic in its awfulness; which means it's so bad that you can't look away. Kung Fu Yoga is one such film.
So miscalculated that it briefly made me forget why I love Jackie Chan films.
[A] harmless romp ...
A movie that combines kinetic stunts with exotic locations on a very grand scale.

The slapstick fight scenes and action set-pieces - particularly a car chase in Dubai punctuated by a languid lion's presence - elevate the film somewhat, but Kung Fu Yoga's broadness is not so much engaging as merely ticking the many boxes.
... the mediocre storyline and routine fighting bored me after a while, but the beautiful cinematography saves it all.
Tong embraces garish, conspicuous kitsch.
A vibrant and occasionally charming time-waster.
There is much to enjoy in this romantic comedy, especially real life lovers Oberoi and Rai who bring a certain camp charm to the breezy proceedings.
Too often Karnik's direction is only adequate when it needs to be more shaped for such mercurial material.
Bollywood comes with a twist of Shakespearian comedy in this rambling, laboriously sub-plotted but amiable family romcom.
Karnik is a fine technician who has taken care to dress each frame. What rankles is what might have been.
The spirited cast -- including Anne Wiazemsky, Jean-Pierre Laud, and Juliet Berto -- make all this touching as well as troubling.
Prophetic, powerful, disconcerting, infuriating, and surprisingly funny.
Not just a period film, La Chinoise...is a chunk of the period.
It's shocking to see Godard bite the hand that admires him, but this is what makes the movie relevant and timeless.
Maoism appears as the latest campus fad in Jean-Luc Godard's 1967 film.
Maybe Andy Warhol didn't make the quintessential Pop Art masterwork. Maybe Jean-Luc Godard did.
Best for Godard addicts.
Relevant at its theater release and when viewed some sixty years later.
Everything in this film seems to be constructed for its central purpose, which is to make you THINK. Sounds like a dare, doesn't it? One of Godard's lesser seen, but nonetheless essential films.
It's still easy to be wowed by La Chinoise's mastery of ideological back-and-forth as well as the pinwheeling sense of invention that constantly threatens to burst the constrants of the frame
Godard's stylishly assembled depiction of a young Maoist cell in Paris alternately interrogates, skewers and champions the political radicals of its time.
Only Godard could make a film so theoretical and so waywardly, persistently about people. Only Godard, certainly, could make this film.
What has to be made clear is that this is an infuriating but cagy film.
Deep, rich, profound, [and] overwhelming.

Its pace, for all the talk, is exhilarating, its use of primary colors hard and beautiful, its shifts of mood and action are both intricate and dazzling; while its feeling for its characters is always serious and affectionate, even when Godard is mocking.
As Mr. Philibert continues to pop in and out of different studios, in and out of the building, flitting from one face to the other, it feels as if he were searching for a story that never emerges.
Looking at La Maison de la Radio in the wake of the Charlie Hebdo crisis, what strikes you is how conventional and white French state radio seems.
There's a rhythm to Philibert's work, a tangible linearity - as he knows how to take every day life and illuminate it, find the subtleties, the nuances for us to appreciate and to resonate with.
In both its strengths and flaws, "La Maison de la radio" reveals a lot about the modern media.
Behind it all lies the sense that here is something worth preserving, a celebration of radio's unique conversational appeal, a unifying force in times of splintered televisuality.
The most memorable moments in La Maison De La Radio are purely visual, as DJs hold court from behind a stack of CDs, and broadcasters bustle their way through the curved halls.
A terrific docu from Gallic nonfiction filmmaker Nicolas Philibert, "La Maison de la radio" adds revealing images to sounds that will be familiar to millions of French public-radio listeners.

Superb camerawork ably captures the energy of the diverse activities taking place within this distinctive circular building ... but it's the wonderful sound mix that best conveys the immediacy and intimacy that makes radio so unique.
While it may be a colourful human study, the film also proves to be something of a frustration.
There is a resemblance between "La Maison de la Radio" and tuning in to a public radio station: You may not know what you're going to get, but there's a pretty good chance it will be worth your time.

Ninety percent of the success of any good documentary is in the editing, and Philibert is a master of the art, sifting through what one assumes must have been months of footage to give La Maison de la Radio an engaging rhythm and structure.
"La Maison de la Radio" gives us the pleasant experience of hanging out with people who truly love their work.
Access does not guarantee insight.
La Maison de la Radio is the kind of film that divides its audience into two camps: those happy to observe and those impatient to be told a story.
It's a film for Francophiles of the deepest dye, a grand tour of French culture and preoccupations.
As we watch hosts and announcers talk away on the air, the movie begins to feel like a series of communications between the speakers-and unseen millions.
[Documentary maker Nicolas Philibert's] admiration for Radio France's work and public-service ethos is self-evident, but this is a very hard film for a non-French audience to engage with.
Whether or not you consider this a banal topic, it's plain to see that the puttering documentary doesn't achieve magnificence.
It's not exactly a chore to sit through, but you'd hardly chalk it up as scintillating viewing.
A pleasant, undemanding, rather Wiseman-lite study of a day in the life of Radio France, with all its producers, announcers, editors and tech people placidly busying themselves about their work.

While Green's film is dense with historical fact and theory, it's not averse to plumbing life's mysteries. Suffused with warmth, it expresses a potent admiration for human striving and accomplishment.
This recalls Manoel de Oliveira and Eric Rohmer in its poker-faced style, deliberately archaic storytelling, and magisterial epiphanies.
If you can groove into this non-realistic mode, the film casts a spell.
On the surface, writer-director Eugne Green's film "La Sapienza" is slow, strange and awkward - but stick with it and it may win you over.
The uncomplicated narrative resists stylization; Green's presentation turns everyone into mannequins, rendering their emotions theoretical. That may well be his point, but it didn't work for me.
It's a nice entry point into a peculiar cinematic universe, and those willing to open themselves to it will find a lot to enjoy.

This kind of formalism needs to do more than walk through classical wonders. It should want to create cinema that can stand near or beside them. This movie defensively consecrates what's already there. You don't need a film to do that.
"La Sapienza" strikes this reviewer as easily the most astonishing and important movie to emerge from France in quite some time.
A picture that balances heart and mind with nuance.
Although a love-fiction crossed with documentary lecture and superb Raphael O'Byrne cinematography, 'La Sapienza' is as close as celluloid can approach to architecture.
This startling architectural juxtaposition feels like a wake-up call.
An exquisite rumination on life, love and art that tickles the heart and mind in equal measure.

Eugne Green's mannered direction doesn't work for every situation it's homogenously applied to, but at its most effective it inspires an enhanced sensitivity to the import of every gesture, visual or verbal.
Green's richly textured, painterly images fuse with the story to evoke the essence of humane urbanity and the relationships that it fosters, whether educational, familial, or erotic.
If architecture aspires to the condition of music, the acting in La Sapienza aspires to the condition of architecture. You will love the ending of this very original and elegant and arty work.
The movie is an unapologetically rarefied undertaking and at the same time a gracious and inviting film.
La Sapienza  alternately feels like a self-reflexive love story or a haunted history lesson -- its best scenes play like both.
Pretentious, stuffy and slow. There's some beautiful scenery here but oh, what you must put up with to earn it!
Green doesn't so much use his characters as mouthpieces as emotionally invest them in art, turning opinions into feelings.

The Sapience juxtaposes insights on how people are emotionally connected with ruminations on the buildings and spaces through which they move, in which they live and, in Alexandre's case, which they also create.
Denmark's so-called biggest war crime forms the historical backdrop of this nerve-jangling bomb-disposal drama
The film is sometimes too sentimental, too predictable in its drift, but electric in individual moments.
It's a well-intentioned movie that winds up favoring sentimentality over genuinely disturbing introspection.
Land of Mine's fitful jolts of suspense can't compensate for the story's wholly familiar trajectory.
A riveting slice of life in traumatized post war Europe leads to the miracle of human connection.
A wrenching portrait.
If you like moral quandaries, this one presents a doozy. And that's its chief asset.

After laying some considerable scripting groundwork in a patience-testing opening act of the movie, Zandvliet transports us deep inside the haunted, hunted psyches of these blighted souls with uncommon sincerity and compassion.
Zandvliet has crafted a handsome, affecting and questioning film about post-war revenge and forgiveness. On a tough field to navigate, he makes it to the other side, commendably.
(Mller"s) portrayal of a crusty sergeant rediscovering his humanity doesn't quite excuse the clichs that fill Land of Mine, but it makes the experience bearable.
An affecting film highlighting a little-known story, with the opening reels showing just how strong the impulse for retribution was against the Nazis.
It's a little-known story, powerfully told. The message is both timely and timeless.
This effortless picture is anchored by a barnstorming Roland M√∏ller; he and his director juggle motives and expectations to alarming effect.
It's the journey rather than the destination that's affecting.

Gaining in intensity as it moves along, "Land of Mine" combines the suspense of Henri-Georges Clouzot's "Wages of Fear" (1953) with the psychological complexity of David Lean's "The Bridge on the River Kwai" (1957) ...
An act of expiation, Land of Mine is honorable, harrowing and stirring.
There's a certain morbid and manipulative streak to a movie that generates its main suspense over which innocent kid will get blown up next.
...a well-done film about a little-known chapter of history ...
A thoughtful, poignant drama that is comfortably carried on the shoulders of an ebullient, heartfelt performance from Mller ...
Land of Mine delivers an epic story.
A slender indie sitcom, peopled by characters who are simply annoying rather than quirkily charming.
There's an affinity you form with the characters -- especially the budding camaraderie between Dana and Ali -- that enables the movie to involve and intrigue.
The blend of raunchy comedy and darker domestic drama is awkward, becoming caught up in final-act contrivances that essentially lead to ambiguous shoulder-shrugging.
Just NO to this kind of thing. Amateurish movies are one thing, but you start putting A-list people in...
A uniformly excellent cast and some genuinely moving moments make it easy to fall for, especially if you're a fan of Obvious Child's returning star, Jenny Slate.
A too predictable comedy distinguished only by some of the performances.
Ultimately, Landline registers as a push me-pull me emotional drama about four members of a family that are spinning uncomfortable semi-comic, barely-tragic circles around one another.
A forlornly funny and emotionally bruising dramedy that rarely misses an opportunity to reveal humans as the flawed and occasionally awful beings that they are.
Predictable, and pointlessly set in 1995, it's still a pleasant, lightly amusing showcase for Jenny Slate and screen novice Abby Quinn.
Heroin is to Landline what abortion is to Robespierre's Obvious Child: a dangerous little variable planted to strategically unsettle the pervading cutesiness.
There are an awful lot of layers to deal with, and more sensitive audiences will be turned off by Landline's ugly frankness.
In many ways, it feels like a romantic comedy from that era. But, the movie doesn't shy away from grittier real-life complications and adult language.
Like [Obvious Child], this one benefits from Slate's ample charm and comic timing, though they've been funneled into a more conventional coming-of-age story.
Slate cements her status as a kind of later-day Lucille Ball, gifted in physical comedy and possessed of a dithering combination of smarts and free-flowing emotion.
The show belongs to Quinn's Ali, with a strong assist from Slate and Falco.

A romantic comedy that soundly rejects the allure of charismatic assholes in favor of milquetoast romance; its platonic ideal is essentially the reading-while-your-boyfriend-plays-video-games phase in a relationship.
If Obvious Child offered a quick sketch of its broader universe, Landline, Robespierre, Holm, and Slate's latest collaboration, is a carefully rendered study.
Landline just dangles off the hook for most of its running time.
Too reliant on exaggerated characters and situations, and often looking and feeling like a TV show.
The real surprise is it managed to do something I never thought possible: make me feel nostalgic for the '90's.
This is a big screen movie, a whipsmart twist on a particular kind of romantic comedy typically associated with charmless big-budget American studio films.
Jet-paced, funny, classy, graced with moments of pure magic.
An American remake is already on the cards, though it's hard to see how it could improve on the original -- sparkling, elegant and wafer-light, if you could bottle rom-com, it would taste like this.
"Heartbreaker" has some amusing moments and gorgeous settings (the Riviera), but it never achieves the smooth slickness director Pascal Chaumeil aims for.
To fully appreciate the pleasures of Pascal Chaumeil's debut feature, Heartbreaker, it helps to know-and love-Dirty Dancing.
Skips along with a funny, stylish flair that only adds to a brisk yet breezy romanticism.

If this bright and nimble French comedy about a romantic mercenary hired to break up an engaged couple can't break the stunningly talented Romain Duris as a star in America, it's hard to see what could.
full review at Movies for the Masses

Worth seeing for Duris' athletic, charismatic and quick-witted performance, not to mention his snake-hipped recreation with Paradis of Dirty Dancing's pas de deux. And yes, he does dance like Patrick Swayze.
Not a complete waste of time, but close.
Duris and Paradis are a perfect physical match in this topsy-turvy environment -- her severe, spiky, almost-masculine features contrasting with his soft, feminine vulnerability.
The kind of romantic comedy that Hollywood doesn't seem to know how to make anymore...a souffl of a comedy, airy and tasty at the same time.
Like "How to Lose a Guy in Ten Days," only funnier, fresher. And French.
...convoluted and with inferior subtitles, a farce depends mightily on the music to frame the action and this score isn't up to the task.

Duris keeps everything on track, oozing sex appeal and displaying a gift for physical comedy. Heartbreaker is ripe for an American remake but you pity whoever has to follow in the gossamer footsteps of quicksilver charmer Duris.
At its core, the film fails to convince us
James Bond meets Don Juan in this charming French romantic comedy.
If it is guilty of any crime, it's the same one as Juliette's poor fianc√©: inciting boredom.
A romantic comedy that is charming and light as a souffle.
A romantic-comedy that packs charm, humour and warmth in spades.
There's nothing in Larry Crowne that Dan Harmon's Community doesn't do faster, funnier and with far more intelligence every Thursday night.

Here's a movie for adults that's warm and enjoyable, but has brains and ambition. Tom Hanks directs with a soft touch but not a soft head. "Larry Crowne" is like fancy French toast - comfort food with a dollop of aspiration.
What a pleasant, easy-going experience that was.
The film is sometimes gentle to the point of blandness, but it's never flimsy.
Tom Hanks confuses 'likeable and nice' with 'boring and pointless.'
"Larry Crowne" could have easily starred Spencer Tracy and be showing on TCM this very instant.
As much as you might want to like it, the lack of gumption makes it difficult to go all the way.

With its eager-to-please congeniality, it almost works, but with a pacing that is at once comfortably assured and frustratingly slack, like holding exactly to the speed limit on a stretch of open road, Larry Crowne never quite comes to life.

This infectiously entertaining summer movie makes you feel good. It provides hope that a fresh start is possible regardless of age. Hanks has oodles of charm, and he and Roberts have great chemistry. The real find in the acting arena is...

With Hanks sharing screenwriting duty with Vardalos, you can almost make a game out of which characters and plot elements were of her invention and which ones he eventually smoothed out into a comedy that once it gets going is hard to stop smiling at.
A likeable and light-hearted comedy that doesn't attempt to be anything more.
... engaging, constantly warm and funny, and very direct in its ambitions.
It's perfectly pleasant big screen comfort food -- meatloaf, potatoes and apple cobbler served as bubbly Tom Petty and ELO tunes waft from the soundtrack.
...there is a wholesome, even nave (by today's standards) outlook at work that really comes off as refreshing.
Too cute for its own good, Larry Crowne is nonetheless hard to dislike.
Larry Crowne makes losing your job, your car and your house look like the greatest thing to happen to a middle aged man.
This one coasts by on Hanks' immense appeal and charm, but more focus and a touch more sharpness are needed to make it really come alive.
Feel good and forget about it, that seems to be the goal of Larry Crowne, and it's something this Tom Hanks directed film accomplishes with flourish.
This charmer about late middle-aged renaissance is pertinent for these times and a perfect summer comedy for grown-ups looking to escape robots and superheroes.
How could a man so adept at comedy, and so savvy in general, be responsible for such a flavorless pile of glop?
This ridiculously contrived tale has holes so big in it that an entire prison population could escape through them.
Barely passable popcorn, but highly flawed as a serious drama.
Once you strip away the red, white and blue bunting, the film we're left with is one swell action sequence -- a prison riot -- and every prison movie cliche in the (1940s vintage) book.
Here, as in that overheated political circus The Contender, Lurie demonstrates his weakness for heavy-handed 'topical' dialectics.
What would ordinarily be called schmaltz is just what the doctor ordered in our present struggle against flag-burning terrorists.
An absurd movie, even though it's directed and acted with a skill that keeps your subversive thoughts temporarily at bay as you watch it.
Once you let the realism go (or lack of it), it's fun to see the Colonel get his just desserts, and Redford ... shows us what real heroism is all about.
The Last Castle often feels choppy, as if chunks of connecting narrative had been lopped off in the editing room.
Seems less than the sum of its parts.
...a well-crafted film that works most of the way through, but gives way to the bombastic ending that detracts from the overall impact.
A dull, borderline inept action-prison drama, in which lead star Robert Redford is totally wasted.
As the suspense builds, you'll be on the edge of your seat. And the ending, which involves the American flag, will have you wanting to stand up and cheer.
A rousing adventure film that entertains despite a raft of plot implausibilities.
Devolves into a mundane warden-versus-inmate conclusion.
The Last Castle takes [a] timeworn premise and steers it down a ludicrous and obvious path to a conclusion that will have most audience members rolling their eyes in disbelief rather than cheering.
A howler of a prison movie about a genital-wagging contest supported by a group of grown-up boys still longing to play with their toys in the sand.
The Last Castle, while engrossing in parts, might have benefited from more pre-shooting talk about what makes an intriguing character -- and what makes a star performance.
If Castle isn't offensive, it is deeply stupid.
From beginning to end, there's an awful lot of Cool Hand Luke in The Last Castle.
The Last Castle will likely do very well at the box office, not because it is particulary good, but becuase, simply put, timing is everything.
Funny, if you don't concentrate.
It's funny, touching, perceptive and one of the great undiscovered movies. Discover it.
Simple and modest in structure but delightfully rich in character.
The picture is surprisingly moving, delicately handled and full of lovely vignettes.
Alec Guinness is one of classic cinema's truly genuine curiosities.
the film would not register above passable if not for its central figure
Slight and mildly amusing dark comedy of rebirth and regret.
Like Don Coscarelli's Bubba Ho-Tep (2002), Late Phases uses an old-school monster of horror to allegorise the cruelly inexorable ravages of senescence and death.
There's always junk-food pleasure in seeing a questionably funky-looking werewolf take the business end of a silver-loaded shotgun to the face.

Less ambitious but more satisfyingly resolved than Bogliano's last effort, Here Comes the Devil, Late Phases is a reminder of how much monster movies rely on what happens when the monster's not on screen.
The narrative ends up working in a smaller scope than one might expect given the premise of a beast plaguing a community, but the journey getting to the finish is exhilarating all the same.

Adrin Garca Bogliano ends up merely toying with the death-steeped concerns of his characters, and taking the furious and bitter perspective that powers the narrative's ponderous dramatic core for granted.
Late Phases transforms from laughably non-frightening horror film to self-serious family drama and back again, all the while remaining ferociously, ravenously boring.
A sprightly horror movie about finding new purpose for old bones.
[Late Phases is] a sly, rueful rarity that plays its monster-movie tropes straight, but gives them a poignant little twist.
Late Phases fails to deliver either shocks or real drama.
Damici gives his memorable protagonist enough life to hold it together more often than it would have otherwise. He's great here. The movie around him, not so much.
Late Phases is a fun werewolf flick with a sweet, climactic last stand.
Features some great performances, a worthwhile sense of strange humanity, and, ultimately, a handful of truly cool werewolf sequences.
Without a doubt, Late Phases is one of the finest lycanthrope films of the last 20 years and a shining example of great independent horror.
As the film leads up to its bloody conclusion, there's a sense of peace that falls upon our hero, a reparation that he is unable to find at the local church or even with his son.
Its avoidance of dealing with the horror head-on leads to too much ambiguity.
While this is not my favorite werewolf movie, it was still well done. I appreciated the use of practical effects and it was a pretty unique storyline.
This bland take on werewolves has an excellent premise and a slow burn to its pacing that had a lot of promise, but unfortunately, it wrote a few checks the script couldn't cash.
The inevitable showdown is a hoot, but overall, a throwaway experience that should have spent more time in development.
Retains interest mostly for how much it will remind you of the films its clearly derived from.
It's never a good sign for a thriller or a horror film where the music is the most unsettling aspect.
[Cornish gives] a great performance, and it's disappointing that the movie around her isn't worthy of it.
Style trumps substance in this atmospheric and mildly creepy low-budget thriller.

Extra points to Gass-Donnelly for setting most of his scares during the daytime; even some of the familiar conventions of the genre (mazes, kids' lullabies, terror-fraught cornfields) seem fresh in the light of day.
Some movies are bad, mediocre and boring. This one is painfully annoying. [Full review in Spansh].
... that's fine and good if the viewer goes in knowing and just wanting to see a mystery unfold with not all of its questions being answered.
It's not always a tasteful film, eventually making positive accomplishments difficult to track by the third act.
A would-be psychological thriller with few thrills and even less psychology.
Lavender is often an effective and haunting atmospheric thriller that doesn't compound its twists with ADD-style turns that mimic a Billy Mays' sale pitch ("but wait, there's more!").
Beyond its unsettling intro, it steadily becomes a middling thriller.
Lavender won't keep you in suspense long about what's going on. In fact, it won't keep you in suspense at all.
Another return to "return of the repressed" ghost-story terrain, "Lavender" unearths few new surprises yet reconfirms the efficacy of its genre's most hallowed conventions.

While it succumbs to a lot of clichs that blunt its impact, Lavender shows that there are interesting ways to apply genre elements beyond the bump and chills, and in the service of story about memory, trauma, and resolution.
As old-fashioned as Hitchcock's Spellbound, Lavender presents the unlocking of suppressed horrors as a freeing experience, without the messiness of further analysis.

As with nearly every other machination of this shopworn plot, how the psychiatrist turns out to be involved in this story would surprise only someone totally unacquainted with the medium of motion pictures.
This is more an exercise in suspense than one of logic. And it satisfies neither suspense nor logic.
"Lavender" means well, but it ultimately proves that not all ghosts need a backstory. Often, just being scary - even inexplicably - is more important than being meaningful.
Boring, derivative, and infuriatingly illogical, Lavender is a ghost story with no thrills, no surprises, and no sense.
Leaves no clich unturned ...

The screenplay, co-written by Gass-Donnelly with Colin Frizzell, manages to be simultaneously lacking in coherence and utterly predictable, with viewers earning no points for guessing which one of the characters turns out to be the villain.
The Finnish director's sense of humor is dry and dark as pitch, as he consistently finds moments of absurdity in the midst of strife and tragedy.
Le Havre is not the filmmaker's best work (see La Vie de Bohme for that), but no matter the storm, we should be grateful to dock in this port.
It's a puzzle, and an intriguing one.
A gorgeous hymn to the struggles of the working man.
The latest work by Finnish cult director Aki Kaurismaki is is his strongst in a decade--and one of 2011 best foreign pictures.
Few filmmakers have such delicate command of the poetic potential of cinema.

In just a few minutes of screen time, the film establishes that specifically Kaurismkian world of sad-sack losers, humorously incongruous but uncommented-upon presences, and the director's trademark careful attention to visages.
Kaurismaki's movie about a shoeshine man and an illegal immigrant is nothing less than a joy
Does Kaurismaki believe in his own fairy tale? The movie, a humble delight, suggests the answer is yes.
If the name Aki Kaurismki doesn't mean anything to you, it should, and "Le Havre" may be the film to make it happen.
'Tis the season, so the saying goes. And when it comes to Aki Kaurismki, it holds true. The Finnish writer-director arrives bearing a gift wrapped in a contemporary immigration fable.
An easygoing story of human relationships with a sharp political comment about European immigration.
Aki Kaurismaki carves out another comically enchanted movie oasis from the real world where people can rise to the occasion and do the right things.
offers plenty of things to talk about but perhaps the most remarkable part about it is its confidence of style and its sober-eyed sense of uplift
"Le Havre" stands on its own fragile but considerable merits.
A stylized and sentimental fairy tale about the way the world might be, grounded in a frank recognition of the way it is.
Pitting that grandiose takeaway with the director's intentionally over-the-top stylistic dalliances, Le Havre maintains a fresh balance that never falters.

Le Havre could be described as the ever-quirky Aki Kaurismaki's 'wish list' film addressing today's tide of refugees who are usually faceless crowds or worse, corpses at the unintended end of their journey
Le Havre is brought to life by its raw, hopeful humanity; it feels close and real despite its deliberate distance.
"Le Havre" is a small bit of movie magic, a story that plays more as a fable even as it deals with something as topical as immigration.
An edgy French twist on the old Hollywood "meet cute" romance.
There's a taste of "Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind," "Something Wild" "Forces of Nature" and even "Bringing Up Baby," perhaps the best of the wild child-seduces-straight arrow romances.
In its joyful and high-spirited fashion "The Names of Love" suggests that we must learn from the past but live for the future, and that definitely doesn't just apply to French people.
Noteworthy...for wrapping a message about overcoming ethnic and political differences in the trappings of a conventional romantic comedy, and being largely successful at such a tricky task.
What is so surprising -- even exhilarating -- about The Names of Love is that it shucks off the desultory roadblocks that engine the modern romantic comedy.
The far-left lead character in The Names of Love is so enchanting even Rush Limbaugh would give her the time of day.

Instead of asking "What's in a name?,'' this slyly delightful piece of Gallic fluff wonders at all the ways that names - the labels we give to one another - bring us into the world and keep us apart from it.
A meretricious mix of lechery, kitsch, bad taste, and glib political correctness.
[A] delightful, sexy, and often audacious crowd-pleaser.
Every bit as anonymous and lost as its cartoonish, cookie cutter characters, who whittle down the cultural complexities of a diverse France into a stale and toothless romantic comedy.
A clever and creative French comedy about an unlikely couple trying against all odds to make a life together.

Semi-autobiographical drama from the improbable romance between a square, middle-aged French Jew and a fiery young "leftie" of North African descent is a cinematic descent into meandering self-indulgence and questionable taste.

...is a delight, a thinking person's romantic comedy which delves into the more shameful aspects of recent French history, the Arab/Jewish conflict, immigration and the ways people define themselves in a different culture.
...a thought-provoking love story about two people using their roots as a tapestry from which to build their lives instead of being a prisoner of them.
Too giddy about its own nonconformism to keep the laughs going from start to finish.
The film is sometimes funny and occasionally smart yet never quite what it wants to be -- funny and smart at the same time.
This cross-cultural comedy-drama sports a bubbly performance by Sara Forestier.
An oddball, pithy political romcom, The Names of Love has vigour, intelligence to spare, and a winning -- if unlikely -- romantic duo at its lead.
A film with such a clever premise could easily slide from satire to silliness. But "The Names of Love is fun without being too farcical.
It's commendable to want to mix serious ideas and emotional complexity into a light comedy, but you need to have a point that goes deeper than "bigotry is bad."
Lebanon, Pa. is a few strong moments of storytelling lost in a sea of indie cliche.
A transitional time in the life of a 35-year-old ad agency executive when he has a chance to take a hard look at his life.
A poignant portrait of an unlikely friendship and a pungent contrast of urban clamor and small-town murmur.
Lebanon, PA is a beautiful film with powerful characters and a story you can really connect with in a way that won't make you feel gross or manipulated.

Displays the delicate touch of a sledgehammer on an old sidewalk.
For the most part it's your classic character-driven movie - the antithesis of an "issue" drama - until a contentious issue surfaces that threatens to overwhelm the story.

Plays out like one of those dull message movies that TV networks used to crank out almost weekly, but the earnestness is at times almost appealingly old-fashioned.
This is a plea for self-described indie filmmakers to stop utilizing hyper-polished technique to talk about human misery.
An intriguing, beautiful film by a promising young director.

A heady blend of spy thriller, period piece political drama and martial arts action flick that reaffirms star Donnie Yen's quiet, universal charisma.

...a seriously misguided action epic.

quirky, off-beat and all around charming... has a lot of heart.
