The drama of the film is in Hardy's face...

In this car ... an entire story is richly told, whole characters are indelibly portrayed with nuance, ambiguity, precision, foibles, heroics and devastations, and we are thoroughly engaged, carried along as by the superior mechanisms of Locke's Mercedes.
Knight's structural experiment, its willingness to embrace chaos, and its ultimate emotional impact make it one of the most outstanding movies of the year so far.
You don't want this movie to end.
That solo time in the car, predictably, gets trying to watch.
Writer-director Steven Knight tries too hard to make us love his hard-working, old-school everyman.
You're almost as impatient to find out whether this will be a one-way trip as he is.
What should be a gripping narrative is uninteresting to the point of tedium.
Actually, LOL is a lot like an episode of Gilmore Girls, only the mother and daughter are total creeps and the characterizations are completely insulting.
LOL is DOA, a shapeless and charmless teen-skewing trifle stocked with trendy slanguage and social-network gimcracks that make it seem like something four years past its expiration date.
Humdrum all the way.
What's of real interest here...is the casual, unforced portrayal just how indulged, spoilt, undisciplined and self-centred these iGen teens are.
Miley Cyrus overacts in sex 'n' drugs high school drama.
It's a shame in a year that gave us "The Perks of Being a Wallflower," we have this tepid piece of junk.
All of this must have looked wonderful on paper, but somehow the joy of it got lost in the translation from page to screen.
Comedy as a form of torture.
Hackman mostly just stands around watching Aykroyd run through his exertions with the look of a man who has something unspeakable on the sole of his shoe.
Mr. Hackman and Mr. Aykroyd deserve much better. They really do. Each gives a thoroughly professional performance that is consistently undercut by the direction of Mr. Clark.
Quite embarrassing, really, especially with the overacting of Dan Aykroyd.
Not one of the best efforts from either Hackman or Aykroyd.
Fires nothing but blanks
Dan Aykroyd's dexterous multipersonality schtick is the only redeeming feature of this chase-heavy comedy.
It seems less concerned with Tolkien than the West Coast drug culture of the mid-1970s and as a herald of New Ageism.
It looked terrible then and it still does: cartoon characters move differently from live actors, and the attempt to duplicate natural movement ends in stylistic incoherence.
The hobbits all look like Joey Lawrence -- what's up with that?
Tolkien fans, who are familiar with novels, will find it enjoyble, while others may be confused by the action.

What most people remember is the mix of the live-action tracing within the traditional animation and just how effectively creepy it managed to be, but for the time this did a pretty good job of adapting the dense novels.
A showcase for inspired imagery and sheer strangeness, a near-miss magnum opus from another era, before the cult of Tolkien went Hollywood.
Quite interesting and rather original.
Innovative and beautiful, cheesy and disjointed.
Even the most magical fantasy falls to earth if it's not clear who's who and what's happening, as every maker of fables should know.
Bakshi's version, using animation and live-action tracings, is uniformly excellent, sticking closely to the original text and visually echoing many of Tolkien's own drawings.

Full of epic effects and breathtaking battles the film reflects Bakshi's ingenuity, with photographic imagery and light show effects expanding the limits of the palette used in previous animation features.
An atmospheric fairytale romp across the landscapes of Tolkien's imagination.
It is here we see Bakshi "jump the shark..."
Ralph Bakshi's imagination was on the Fritz; his animated version of Tolkien's fable made Middle-earth look like Grand Central Station during the rush hour of the Ores.
Ralph Bakshi achieves spectacular effects. [Full Review in Spanish]
I didn't like this film version of Lord of Rings. If it's any comfort, fans won't like it either.
... dark and fantastical with a mature approach rare in animated films of its day, and Bakshi's rotoscope process creates an unusually fluid and expressive style.
The live action version trumps it in every conceivable way; there simply is no comparison. And yet Middle Earth is still better off for its presence.
It's a divisive film but I appreciate some of the choices that it made.
[W]e should be grateful that Bakshi has tried so hard to be faithful to the original that its spirit and inspiration often shine through to stir the blood.
Like first love, this study of the growing pains of the leather jacket-bobby soxer Brooklyn high school set of 1957 is, by turns, cheerful, confused, juvenile and never fully realized.
A small masterpiece that places the mood and general ethos of the '50s with absolute precision and total affection.
Not too much finesse distinguishes the script, which carries neither warmth nor particular interest for the various characters.

The movie is adept at portraying aimlessness, getting at the greasy anomie that was so much a part of that time. But there is a lack of ambition, as if no one involved in creating the film wanted to cut deeper than a little double-edged nostalgia.
Harmless coming-of-age-teen gang pic.

All this made the movie both a hit and a very fondly remembered artifact of its era... And like American Graffiti before it, and Dazed & Confused after it, it had a cast of young actors of its era who would go on to distinguish themselves in the future.
An early nostalgia tour of the 1950s, The Lords of Flatbush is a rough sketch of a bigger, better movie that is mostly remembered today for the careers it helped launch.
Everything in it passes before the eyes before seeping out of the memory, which, given how ugly some of it is, is just as well.
Lost River comes across as the work of a poseur, but it's not that far away from being the striking, left-field cult vision Gosling clearly hoped it would be.
Overall, Lost River isn't worth its rental fee, unless you absolutely must see Gosling's effort for yourself. Otherwise, take my word for it-wait until Ryan Gosling makes another movie.
For Gosling, Lost River has treacherous waters indeed.
Ryan Gosling's directorial debut is avowedly arty and rich to the point of bursting its seams.
Mediocrity, in this instance at least, denotes complacency, and Lost River exhibits on every level a "will-this-do?" quality.
It comes across like the college coursework of a film student trying to convince the girl of his dreams that he is 'deep' and that he 'gets stuff'.

Lost River is a film whose reputation precedes it. Viewers have decried it as a mess or lauded it as an artistic achievement ever since it premiered at Cannes 11 months ago. Ultimately, the film is really neither.

"Lost River" is one of those weird films that I think some people will absolutely adore, grabbing on to its performances, imagery, and ideas, without really caring that they haven't been stitched together in an interesting enough way.
Gosling gets points for style but Lost River proves he's not quite ready for prime time as a filmmaker.
When it premiered at Cannes last year, Gosling's urban fairytale was greeted with jeers. It should have been met with cheers.
Lost River is little more than "cool shots, bro."

"Lost River" is indeed a mess, but it's the best mess possible, an evocative grab-bag of images and moods with a heartfelt sincerity and conflicting impulses of romantic melancholy and hardscrabble hopefulness.
That Gosling is so serious about his inconsequential pronouncements, makes this mess more of a mess.
An often dazzling and always thought-provoking modern fairy tale that's never less than beautiful to look at.
[Gosling] seems to have dug up some lurid offcuts from a Nicolas Winding Refn movie, and mashed then up with David Lynch and Edward Hopper.
Plays more like a curious, sincere experiment of a promising new storyteller rather than the egotistical self-indulgence of an A-List actor.
A pretentious burlesque of a film in which you are never entirely sure what Gosling is trying to say.
An over-cooked affair that lacks much needed wit and humour to go alongside its self-aware art intentions.
While Lost River isn't some misunderstood masterpiece, neither is it as awful as advertised.
This is the first film I see Jesse Eisenberg really acting, contained, paused, mature, without the nervous blabbering that characterizes his work. [Full review in Spanish]
A moody and riveting study of loss.
Trier's delicate use of flashbacks and sound allows the narrative to inch along like a cortge.
Often entertaining and accomplished, Louder Than Bombs bites off more than it can chew, weaving among the points of view of several characters and gradually losing its intensity.
One of the finest family dramas I've seen in a great long while.
The quality of the performances smooth over the rough edges of an honourable attempt to capture the casualties of a family at war.
The emotional conclusions here can be a little pat, and catharsis too easily come by. It's more cautiously sound-proofed than its title implies.

Old wounds never fully heal and catharsis comes in small drops, not big dramatic moments. But it's a film about people who love each other even if they're angry, people who are trying even if their efforts are fruitless.

What could be a more tired cliche for an indie drama than a family struggling to grieve the loss of a parent? And yet you'd think Joachim Trier's "Louder than Bombs" was the first film to ever explore this emotional territory.
It plays like a jigsaw puzzle whose pieces are scattered before they come together, this internal, complex film about realities and perspectives
Moment to moment, it buzzes with excitement.
Beneath the well-worn dysfunctional-family setup are bracing observations of the human coping mechanism.
A serious and sobering drama about the solo journeys of grief by a father and his two sons.
Louder than Bombs subverts preconceptions so slyly, many audiences and critics will be easily forgiven for thinking it is nothing more than a work of morose egotism.
A good drama that works. [Full review in Spanish]
[A] flawed yet intriguingly off-kilter oddity ...
Intimate, mature drama deals with a family's grief.
Tells a familiar story in a new and vital way.

The people aren't people here; they're not even types - just instruments for conveying words and pictures, some of which are artful, but not nearly enough to make up for the dire drear and maudlin indulgence.
Beguiling and fascinating.
Kate Beckinsale is perfect in the leading role of young widow Lady Susan Vernon, a beautiful and cunning woman who makes Machiavelli look like a bumbling innocent when it comes to scheming.
The most refreshing take on Austen's work ever put on screen.
Together, Kate Beckinsale and writer/director Whit Stillman ensure that "Love And Friendship" charges along at a cracking pace as Lady Susan drives a coach and horses through polite society.
Stillman keeps it all afloat in a froth of quick wit and beautiful costumes and cinematography.
Stillman's rounded-out and embroidered telling is the kind of movie people call "delicious," "sparkling," and "a comic romp," and it is indeed all of those.
It's a novel transformed into cinema, but it's also a film that has allowed itself to be contaminated by literature. And that is the rarer, and greater, achievement.

With his ebullient and scaldingly droll latest - a superlative screwball adaptation of Jane Austen's novella 'Lady Susan' - Stillman may have finally located an ensemble of characters who exist in their own time.
Not among the best of Jane Austen's novels is given a decent adaptation.
Lady Susan is infuriating in her ability to justify whatever she wants to do and you want all her romantic plans to fail, but Beckinsale nevertheless makes her into delightful company.
Immensely charming and laugh-out-loud funny.
Calling all Jane Austen fans: 'Love & Friendship' is a don't-miss.

The delight of its director, Whit Stillman, enlivens every scene, so what might have seemed stilted is full of human faces in exquisitely subtle states of panic. Heretical as it sounds, Stillman has improved on his source.
The language, a lyrical blend of Jane Austen and Whit Stillman, bewitches even as it stings. A sublime Kate Beckinsale digs into the role of her career. Pure pleasure.
Without a doubt the best comedy I have seen in a long time.
Whit Stillman's Love & Friendship is a strangely misguided attempt at bringing Jane Austen's novella "Lady Susan" to the big screen.

...has about it something of the feel of a screwball comedy. There's a bit of Preston Sturges in the film, and while the dialogue is set in period vocabulary, it's delivered in a way that feels quite modern.
The film is meticulous and quiet, giving each actor a moment to play against the shining perfection of Kate Beckinsale's scheming Lady Susan.

It takes a little time to acclimate yourself to the stylized language and the fast pace at which the dialogue comes at you. Once you get into the rhythm and get involved in the subterfuge, this is a smart, funny film.
It is often laugh-out-loud funny, it's beautiful to watch (it was shot around Dublin) and has far broader appeal than standard period drama.

Whit Stillman said that his primary filmic influence for Love & Friendship was the Steve Martin and Michael Caine slice of genius Dirty Rotten Scoundrels. Scoundrels would be proud to see the result of his love and friendship.
All of these people are, of course, terminally cool about their sexuality. That's too bad, because a little uncertainty and doubt can make a great contribution to a comedy.
Breezy and freespirited Australian comedy.
The verbal ping pong of a Kevin Smith joint crossed with the good-natured repartee of a Nora Ephron movie,
This romantic comedy presents a sassy overview of sexual politics where men and women expect so much of each other.
An insufferably dull retracing of romantic comedy's steps, with none of the relationship insight or genuine humanness that can make the formula such a joyful one to follow.
Janssen and Favreau provide enjoyably consoling company for those still dating their way through life.
Refreshing depiction of today's dating game does for single women what Swingers did for single men.
By no means a great film, but a zippy little comedy with a lively pace and a nice supply of laughs -- and occasional moments of genuine feeling.
This one tastes like a sour apple I had on a blind date many eons ago.

The strengths of the screenplay don't translate to the screen. Well-written one-liners lie dead, killed by the lax timing. Everyone tries so hard to be ingratiating and witty that the charm curdles into smarm.
Scenes seem designed more for cuteness than believability. And never is the chemistry between Adam and Kate genuine, which is the kiss of death for a romantic comedy.
Janssen sparkles serenely.
It's tough to watch immediately likable actors endure such a mercilessly dull screenplay.
[S]trives for the meaningful exploration of how Xers sabotage their romances, and falls horribly flat...
This jovial and knowing aperitif of a movie is a charming example of what has come to be known as the date movie.
Love & Sex is capable of making even the most cynical Gen-Xer watch with an involuntary smile.
Marred by some soppy sections, casting that undermines the story's believability and a kind of self-consciousness that makes it hard to really care about the characters.
The thing is, nothing's at stake here.
Already burdened by Kate's clichd voice-over observations, the movie eventually sinks beneath the weight of Kate and Adam's utter charmlessness, a huge liability in bickering romantic-comedy couples.
It's slick, polished to perfection, derivative and stripped of any of the real quirks or idiosyncrasies that make a romantic comedy fly.
Aren't Annie Hall calibre, but they are remarkably more recognizably human than what passes for most movie romantic comedy.
Wait until it hits cable.
As a date movie, it's hard to find a better selection.
The message is more pedestrian than passionate: Life is long, and full of instant messages.
There's not one clever or original plot device in Love, Rosie, and not one believable character or line of dialogue.

Ditter has made a handful of popular comedies in Germany, and while he's able to maintain a certain rhythm and polish, there's ultimately nothing in Love, Rosie that distinguishes it much from your average in-flight movie.
The problem isn't that Rosie and Alex aren't charming; in fact, they're both thoroughly nice and endearing and attractive, so much so that I lost interest in them pretty quickly.
Love, Rosie leaves conventions behind and the stories flows at a phenomenal rhythm. [Full Review in Spanish]
If you can treat the experience as an extended bubble-bath and remember the whole affair is to depth and substance what Boyzone were to Bob Dylan, you won't go far wrong.
Besides the fact that it's full of near-misses, the movie's charming leads salvage it from being just another predictable romantic drama.
Cynics should steer clear, but Love, Rosie boasts two charming leads, a genuinely sweet tenor and such a warm blend of humor and heart that it could easily become a new teen favorite.
In the end it all feels rather heavy-handed and over-laden with music cues to the extent that the story rarely gets a chance to breathe and properly develop.
Predictable romance has teen sex, drinking.
Likeable leads and the odd good joke makes this romance an amiable time-passer.
Love, Rosie succeeds well enough on its own, largely due to the fabulous chemistry between the leads, who bring their flawed, well-rounded characters to life in a funny, warm and amiable manner.
That it wastes the talent of two young actors with star potential is upsetting, that it insults its audience is frankly unforgivable.

Watching lifelong friends, clearly destined for each other, miss the romantic boat over and over is entertaining at first, but soon their tortuous and silly road to the inevitable provokes only impatience.
[A] brightly moronic young adult romance.
"A Styrofoam heart and an embarrassingly juvenile worldview guide 'Love, Rosie,' the latest pit stop for rising stars Lily Collins and Sam Claflin."
A soapy heartstring fiddler ...

As romantic-comedies go, this worthwhile, incident-packed effort deserves credit for spending the balance of its time exploring the underside of love...The last time we saw that done this well was 27 Dresses.
A thoroughly likeable English-language debut for German comedy helmer Christian Ditter ... elevated by vibrant visuals and the winsome chemistry of Lily Collins and Sam Claflin.
Celia Ahern's chick-lit novel about two friends who are secretly in love has been made into a not-quite-rubbish Brit romcom.
Honor's Demy-glazed attempt to stage a contemporary romantic musical rarely attains the genre's giddy heights or sense of genuine catharsis.
For a film roiling with so much turmoil of the heart, Love Songs generates dismayingly little emotional frisson.
Whereas Umbrellas of Cherbourg has become timeless in its depiction of romance, Love Songs strikes a strongly contemporary note in its calm acceptance of the fluidity of desire and emotion.
This deconstruction is daring and should be intoxicating; but, instead, what Honor brings to the movie-musical genre doesn't improve upon its past bold experiments.
An entertaining view of love in Paris becomes a compelling story of dealing with its loss.
... writer-director Christophe Honor ... fashions a 14-song musical about love and loss.
There's little doubt that Love Songs' reliance on mind-bogglingly ineffective musical numbers inevitably triggers its downfall...

It's a story which Honor describes as personal, so we must assume that there is some truth at least in the premise. But the decision to set the story to music undermines the emotional honesty that the piece might otherwise have had.
The terrific credit sequence sets the tone and the movie almost catches up.
Sensitively using song to express grief, passion and ennui, this is a cineaste's delight.
It's one thing to emote through singing, but competing with the memory of a beloved classic is more than his gorgeous and talented cast can overcome.
It is an erotic narrative whose characters express their innermost feelings in bursts of song, but it never sacrifices its heartfelt, often painful moods on the altar of irony.
Love Songs finds the magic that the great screen musicals have -- the way a sad song can nonetheless leave an audience happy, or the way two voices blending seems to create something so much bigger.

Stylistically Honore favours a naturalistic approach to choreographing the composer Alex Baupain's thirteen songs, thus avoiding the pitfalls of kitsch and irony, whilst his young and beautiful cast, deliver appealingly vibrant performances.
It's an uneven affair, but with the delightful Garrel at the center, it's also unexpectedly charming and occasionally even moving.

Boy loves girl and sings about it, boy loses girl to tragedy and sings about it, then boy considers the possibility of new love with a new boy and sings about it -- and the whole thing works, in a delirious French way.
a light and playful story about sex and love but doesn't really say anything specific about either one
An affecting, vibrantly-acted work.
I don't know that achieving this kind of sexual freedom would be worth having to live around all these exhaustingly precocious people.
The result is mixed.
[Wood is] well matched by McQueen and even better served by Mulligan's unsensational direction.
Quaint, old-fashioned, and overwrought.
The picture itself is diverting, but weak on that main romantic point.

Familiar in theme, but given a delightfully fresh flavour by Mulligan's atmospherically low-key direction, excellent performances from Wood and McQueen, and vivid location shooting in New York's Little Italy.
Fortunately the film survives these shortcomings through its sheer breezy good nature and the animal magnetism of its two stars.
Underrated romantic drama, with rich NYC atmosphere and a trenchant look at sexual mores.
Co-starring with the charismatic Steve McQueen, Natalie Wood received a second Oscar nomination for this well acted melodrama about pregnancy out of the wedlock
Exemplifies the lacerating realism that cinema had just barely invented.
[Love with the Proper Stranger] seemed to me so curious a mixture of old-fashioned schmaltz and up-to-the-minute grubbiness that I could conclude only that I was the slightest bit over the hill.
A moving true-life reminder that the rights most Americans take for granted weren't always rights for millions of people.
The tale is moving, and you wouldn't want it told with any more bells and whistles, but it'll leave you wanting more. The good news is that you'll want more of Jeff Nichols.
A true love story that is not afraid of compromises or silence as a way of expression. [Full Review in Spanish]
Intimate, moving and superbly underplayed, "Loving" is every bit as soft-spoken and subtly implacable as its protagonists.
Inspirational true love story.

With Loving, writer/director Jeff Nichols takes on an historical court case, one which has been dealt with on film before, in documentaries and a previous dramatization, but never with such a deft touch - or with such accuracy:
[This is] all about Joel (who somehow even looks American here) and Negga, both of whom were obviously deeply committed to the material and deliver excellent performances.
I like this movie a lot, but it may be too intimate, too slow for some moviegoers. The approach feels organic and wholly intentional, though ...
A hammy performance and moments of dramatic contrivance cannot undo Nichols' touching and tender depiction of a marriage.
It doesn't trumpet its importance obnoxiously, and it's packed with performances of quiet power, with Negga as the breakout.
Nichols doesn't much embellish this true story, instead simply observing two lovers standing their ground on what will slowly become the right side of history.
The depiction may be true to life, but it's deadening to drama, which here is mainly situational.
Nichols's understated approach to the story, devoid of dramatic grandstanding, chimes with the dignity of the Lovings who "won't bother anyone" if only they can be left alone to live their lives.
There's no swelling music, no histrionics, no eloquent speeches, no impassioned pleas. Loving is as workmanlike as bricklayer Richard. And it's all the better for it.
You will end up "Loving" the couple at the center of an important moment in American history.
It's a movie so powerfully told it has the potential to act as a gateway to greater acceptance and tolerance.

Loving is, in form and substance, a silent cry for the simple right to be. That, in these days, in the next years, is and will be a demand that although quiet will be present at full volume. [Full review in Spanish]
There's understatement, and then there's Loving, a film that tells its real-life story of 1950s interracial marriage with a tone as stubbornly restrained as its subjects.

'Loving' is a gentle reminder that love is powerful enough to overcome even the greatest obstacles thrown up by a state ... and myopic people who are more interested in divisiveness than embracing the bonds that unite people - in marriage and in life.
A gripping, inspirational biopic with simplicity, tact and intelligence.
Luciferina is a worth export. [Full Review in Spanish]
Luciferina is a horror film that confounds polarities, taking conventional oppositions - Christian vs pagan, angel vs devil, good vs evil - and merging them into a complex, potent unity.

Calzada's vividly atmospheric film is itself a space in which reality and dreams overlap, in which formal narrative structures break down as our heroine strives to gain control of her identity and destiny.
Luciferina is a slow burn with a couple of lovely horror moments that only really stutters when it offers up unnecessary jump scares and an extraneous villain in a movie that's already about Satan.
I wanted to love Luciferina because there was a real sense of craftsmanship to the proceedings yet the story arcs seemed to suffer at the expense of other elements. Oh well.
Luciferina is a worthy offering in its sub-genre and in horror for fans of films that are more than just about a final girl or just about a simple demon possession.
Culminating in the endurance of memories and hope for the future, "Lullaby" strikes an unforced, resonating chord. It is so much more than just a sad tale.
This is one melancholic little ditty that has a few too many extra verses, a bit of overreach rendering it emotionally ineffective.
The digital photography is crummy, and the characters who most need to convince ... feel created out of whole cloth. Polyester cloth, at that.
Jenkins and Hedlund do great work here but it's the unnecessary supporting characters who undermine what could've been a strong drama.
The movie falls flat in its attempts to show how moments of absurdity break familial tension, as Levitas interrupts every bit of weary comic relief with more histrionics.
Writer/director Andrew Levitas needlessly pads this captivating theme with over-used tropes ...
It's easy to picture the principal action staged as a more taut and powerful play.
The kind of manipulative, clich-infested hokum that alienates moviegoers by its insistence on hogging all the tears.

You'll walk away feeling sombre and slightly downtrodden but, thanks to a handful of strong performances and a strong emotional core, the central debate will linger in your mind, which is exactly what "Lullaby" sets out to do.
Grim and grief-filled with little that's uplifting to redeem the prevailing mood of despair.
Lullaby is the kind of film that's best described as a having been cobbled together from an indie scrapyard.
Inspired by events within his own family, Andrew Levitas' feature directorial debut transforms his own script into a movie that wears its heart on its sleeve.
The film seems endless and sentimental, and the writing is too philosophical to keep the audience awake.
Rarely has the terminal seemed as interminable as it does in Lullaby, writer-director Andrew Levitas's tedious saga of a family reuniting at the deathbed of their paterfamilias.
This feature debut deals mainly in clichs, never transforming the tough question at its center into compelling cinema.

A raft of fine actors -- including Amy Adams, Richard Jenkins, and Downton Abbey's Jessica Brown Findlay -- are wasted in a sour, callow family drama that mistakes constant yelling for emotional tension and fortune-cookie aphorisms for wisdom.
Garrett Hedlund's performance throbs with an anguish that's far more honest than the sentimental euthanasia subplot at the center of the film.
Lullaby gives a heartbreakingly realistic portrayal of the disease and not just what it does to the body, but to the family as well.
Family reunites for dying dad in warm drama; some swearing.
After about ten minutes of enduring this manipulative, seemingly-endless weeper you'll just wish he would go ahead and die already.
A decent thriller about a hunt for a serial killer.
A lustrous essay on the alluring trapdoors of the romantic image
The plot is wonderfully knotty, Lucille Ball is appropriately spunky, and there's a scene-stealing turn by horror heavy George Zucco, atypically cast as a crossword-loving cop.

The juxtaposition between [humor] and the grimmer elements such as forensic examinations ... feels super, super weird, but the film remains compelling for plenty of other reasons that can smooth out the jarring switches.
The picture is too busy with laughs to worry much about chills, but no one ought to complain about that.

The movie is about two ways of seeing things: the child's and the adult's. It shows how children construct elaborate play worlds out of dreams and fantasies, and then plug their real worlds right into them.
...just the right recipe to leave a smile on your face.
This bright and touching drama celebrates diversity as one of the enchantments of life.
Director Alain Berliner and screenwriter Chris vender Stappen have created one of the most authentic, touching households ever put on film.
About the unimaginative struggle to maintain conventional respectability, and the transgender child who is having none of it...

Queer movies can run adjacent to or parallel to other Queer lives, but it's rare that a movie will ever intersect with my life or even contain numerous scenes that I have personally lived. Ma Vie En Rose does that.
Theaters showing this should install seatbelts, because audiences are in for the ultimate wild ride.
An orgy of red meat and confused filmmaking
This gonzo mashup of romantic comedy, political paranoia, and B-movie adulation is more confounding than thrilling.
It's safe to say there will not be another movie this year like Mad Cowgirl. Whether that's a good or bad thing depends on your tolerance for copious bloodletting, hardcore pornography, and C-SPAN.
Mad Cowgirl is an underground movie with little sense of grounding, and lots of a multicultural weirdness and inchoate meat metaphors.
Slick and often incomprehensible, it certainly gives you your money's worth, if blood, gore and blasphemy are what you're buying.
There's a lot happening here, perhaps too much.
Absurd, dirty, powerful and disturbingly hilarious.
It gives screenwriter-director Gregory Hatanaka an excuse for a lot of scene jumping -- and a chance to make the case for adopting a vegan diet.
This indulgently puerile waste of time plows ahead with pointless mayhem masquerading as 'art.'
Endlessly entertaining, though not recommended for anyone uncomfortable with soft porn, eroticized violence or graphically-depicted slaughter.
Fiercely personal and unique.
The kids loved it. The adults loved it. This means it's a sure thing if you're looking for a family movie outing. Go check it out in 3D and everyone should be happy.
It's not a great film, but it'll do for a silly summer lark...Oh, and CIRCUS AFRO!

A neon-saturated, high-flying trapeze act with enough frenetic funny business that it's a wonder the folks behind this zillion-dollar franchise about zoo critters on the lam didn't send the animals to the circus sooner.
[It] may be the best of the bunch, simply because it busts the leash that tethers it to anything resembling reality.

In what could have been an extreme reaction to a paranoid fear of going stale, the film's directing triad - Tom McGrath, Eric Darnell and Conrad Vernon - have dialled up the crazy big-time; the pace of Mad3 is relentless.
The combination of kid-friendly boingy action, annoyingly catchy musical numbers and cutesy, simplistic life lessons is never dull to the kindergarten-and-down crowd.

If you want to see a family film that tries to make kids laugh by throwing lots of loud scenes with obnoxious characters doing annoying things and features the latest crappy pop songs, then MADAGASCAR 3 is for you.
Easily the best of the series.
Entertaining "threequel" has some mild violence, innuendo.
...off-kilter wit and smarts to an animated bestiary that keeps you laughing while eloquently re-defining where home is.
This is that rare thing: a franchise that grows more winning with each instalment.
It's silly, and it's lazy. And yet, again, it's pretty funny.
This is a movie that's constantly in motion, with slapstick flair.
The movie is fast-moving enough to make you forget that it doesn't make a lick of sense.
For now, it is a downright delight to sit back and watch the likes of the loony lemur king Julien do anything and everything to entertain you.
Set at a frenzied pace meant to connote fun, it mostly feels like a frenetic spectacle.

"The best of the Madagascar films" might not be the most ringing endorsement ever committed to newsprint, but DreamWorks Animation has finally found the franchise's groove in this pyrotechnic third instalment.
The animation is grand, and the lovely images may be enough to send really young kids away happy. Their parents might leave feeling they've been taken in by some carny sleight-of-hand, though.
You don't have to be a child of four to enjoy this series, but it helps.
Perhaps the spectacle overwhelms the characters at times but this is a fun addition to this particular series.
It's filled with silly slapstick and scattered plotlines but it should satisfy kids who have been eagerly anticipating this sequel.

Stiller has an ear for mainstream projects that keep a few steps ahead of the crowd, like Meet the Parents and Tropic Thunder. Escape 2 Africa is tame by comparison but it never treats us like dumb animals.
This much-anticipated sequel is a frankly disappointing piece of opportunism, with a non-plot which shamelessly rips off The Lion King.
Madagascar's flock of Mafioso penguins will crack you up. Not much else will.
The characters seem better developed this time and the story lines are stronger.
It has everything Madagascar had three years ago, but also two things the original was woefully lacking: a good yarn and genuine yuks.
The sequel to DreamWorks' computer-animated family hit Madagascar offers more drama and a lot more animals but fewer laughs and not quite as much fun as the colourful summer 2005 original.
The first Madagascar was surprisingly enjoyable, thanks to high energy and playfully dark material, but the returning writing-directing crew doesn't seem nearly as invested this time around.
Take the flat tire that was Madagascar. Retread it with The Lion King storyline. Pump it up with air. Now you have Madagascar: Escape 2 Africa.
In Alex the Lion and Marty the Zebra, we finally have the first unabashedly gay characters in a major Hollywood animated feature.
A film whose blend of madcap exploits and generosity makes it both hilarious and endearing.

A trip to Madagascar is better the second time around.
Whenever the penguins pop up for their welcome routine, the movie takes flight.
The militaristic flightless fowl four returns in Africa, and, no shock here, the penguins steal the movie yet again with their resolute antics.
There's not enough of the first movie's super-erudite monkeys. Yet the sitcom-style silliness is still there.
It that has all the strengths of the original. It also has all of the weaknesses
Punches its key themes of friendship, togetherness and family amid a hyperactive swirl of jokes, musical numbers and physical gags.
This is an inferior sequel, but one which still contains plenty of laughs.
It's still primarily the supporting cast that's funny, not the leads -- but hey, if Dreamworks were capable of doing everything right it would have to change its name to Pixar.
Surprisingly watchable, given its iffy subject matter.
...not only a tribute to a great pioneer of science, it is a lasting tribute to good filmmaking and a most entertaining motion picture.
one of the most engaging biopics of its era
...undone by its emphasis on scientific matters and unmistakable Oscar-bait sort of vibe.

With an eye on the Oscars, this typical MGM biopic of the 1940s, a chronicle of the famous French scientists, is middlebrow and inspirational, teaming for the third time Greer Garson and Walter Pidgeon.
Has exceptional merit. [Full review in Spanish]
Fits the '80s slasher blueprint to the letter. It's only adequately made, but it happens to feature a handful of scenes so knee-slappingly bad that the film ranks as a party favorite.
Frightfully inept fright film.
At least the DVD is a worthwhile package, even if the flick is better left to the annals of your vague memory.

Deliberately paced and far from frightening, but for slasher aficionados and viewers looking for solid laughs of the unintentional variety, there are few bloodied romps of its type with quite the same level of charm.
It doesn't reach the iconic highs of "Friday the 13th," but "Madman" has its simple pleasures, including attention to character and an unusual interest in music to help secure its creepy intent.
Fair enough, the dialogue is a bit cheesy and the characters aren't the most complex bunch of people you'll ever meet, nevertheless Madman has its stylistic accomplishments...
Anyone compiling a supercut of the slasher genre's greatest hits would be wrong to exclude Madman's super-creepy shot of the shaggy Marz silhouetted up in a tree.

There's nothing remotely enjoyable about the experience of Madman, which misses the opportunity to exploit unlikely punchlines and buries its situations in a compost pile of muck, boredom and insufferably miscalculated technical merits.
Joe Giannone's one and only feature hangs up some sophisticated ideas before being dragged into slasher routine.
Minutes after reciting spoken lines for lamentable character development, essentially indistinguishable roles are disposed of at axe point.
There's something in the self-aware approach that's worth exploring, but Mewes doesn't want to be entirely honest with himself.
Madness in the Method is a solid first directorial entry for Jason Mewes. There were enough laughs and surprises that I was thoroughly entertained. Looking forward to his next film.

But as bodies pile up and Mewes becomes more frazzled, the movie's already-modest sense of gravitas slips away in favor of overacting, smirky violence, and a misplaced sense of amusement over men acting in any way effete.
Jason Mewes' satirical metabiopic sees 'Jason Mewes' turn to method acting to escape his stereotyping as stoner sidekick Jay

Shamelessly self-indulgent film-as-therapy for director-star Jason Mewes, Madness in the Method will fitfully entertain Askewniverse fans, though it's ultimately too scattershot to consistently satisfy.
It seems that in this sense, perhaps Mewes would have been better off in making his debut about someone other than himself...
If anything, fans of Kevin Smith's View Askewniverse can use this as something to hold us over until Jay and Silent Bob Reboot.
Messy, tonally inconsistent, offensive, and ultimately pointles

The film somehow manages to fulfil its own legacy as we see Mewes take on an unexpected and scene stealing role and you could draw comparison to this recent trend in films challenging stereotypical casting such as Uncut Gems & Mandy.
Much like Mewes' career, the film is stuck in a sort of arrested development in which jokes about smoking joints and Vinnie Jones are automatically hilarious.
A stillborn May-November seduction makes for sexual tension and fascinating dialogue.

A perceptive, ultra-wordy stab at catching the zeitgeist at a time of change in Spain, David Trueba's two-hander nonetheless feels like a working-out of social and personal themes that hasn't quite achieved the full leap from page to film.
Miguel uses her beauty and placid demeanor as a screen against which to project his memories of past adventures and the ghost of his libido.
A sweet, sometimes dull and certainly overlong film ...
Madrid, 1987 operates on a dizzying number of levels - as a romantic comedy, a sex farce, a study of culture clash, ageism and idealism.
The actors give their characters a resonance beyond the symbolic, but the action doesn't quite transcend the stagy setup.
Seldom has a great film accomplished so much with so little. Well, that's if you consider an insanely quotable screenplay so little.
Lead characters are fully realized, if never exactly likable.
Has the challenge of taking place almost exclusively within the confines of a not very fancy bathroom.
A soapy, flashy confection that juxtaposes Mr. Hough's tap dancing with the Japanese drumming style Taiko, tossed with liberal helpings of contemporary hip-hop moves.
Whenever actor Derek Hough and BoA stop leaping and twirling ... "Make Your Move" is an underwritten mess.
Scenes from the competing clubs include impressive choreography and gravity-defying moves. If only the poorly delivered, trite dialogue and predictable plot aimed as high.
It's cheesy fun for sure, but fun nonetheless.
A fantasy with dance and PG-13 sensuality, making it easily digestible, but its familiarity is deflating, making the movie feel about as impulsive and energetic as a dance step diagram.
An entirely generic drama in which two characters actually say to one another, "What if this doesn't work?" "It has to."
The average person's enjoyment of this dance flick can best be gauged by starting at the feet and progressing upward, with the brain coming in last.
Doesn't move nearly as smoothly as anyone on screen thinks it does, but at least it takes us along with it.

The plot is completely shallow and endlessly derivative, but the performers manage somehow to pierce through the clich-ridden morass and offer some charm...Make Your Move delivers a reliably good time.
"Make Your Move" shows us the whole dancer. These sequences really move in a way that feels organic.
A slick, disposable soap opera about a poor white boy and a spirited Korean girl who fall in love despite hailing from rival corners of Brooklyn's club scene.

[...] The irresistibly dopey Make Your Move drops the spectacle endemic to most dance films in favor of a forward-thinking sweetness. [...] What the film lacks in authenticity, however, it makes up for in good intentions and simple pleasures.
Here is the central reason why dance movies work so well: They cannot be faked.
Star-crossed dance romance doesn't have the best moves.

The type of film that could very well turn into a guilty pleasure or could have gotten a lot of ratings had it aired as a TV movie, but doesn't have the chops to keep its hold on audiences on the big screen.
Its lack of sparks on the dance floor are matched by the sense of alienation when the dancing stops.
Very European in its direction, aesthetic and narrative, Mama possesses a strong, emotional core that will surprise those jaded by some of the lazier horror titles of late.
Why does it always have to be moths?

The fact that Guillermo del Toro is an executive producer of Mama is a tip-off that this won't be just another horror film with misbehaving and soon-to-be-dismembered teenagers or a drooling, slime-soaked monster.
Mama is something of a throwback, and at times a stunning one.
The filmmakers manage that rare trick of weaving a pervasive blanket of dark mood, an almost suffocating sense of dread that sets up the boo-gotcha moments.
Had it come out last October as originally scheduled, head-to-head with Sinister, it would have been a mistake. As it is, it's a perfectly acceptable slice of January horror.
Despite fizzling into conventional drama, much of Mama is pretty creepy.
Mama is a throwback horror movie -- but don't throw it back. It has something powerful to offer if you like genuinely creepy, scary ghost stories.
Connoisseurs of a more classic thriller/horror vibe will embrace the emotionally resonant and thought-provoking Mama.

If you like your scares to be of the traditional variety, this might just be right up your alley. If you're looking for something more interesting, this is mediocre at best. (Full Content Review for Parents also available)

While its finale gestures at something emotional, getting there involves mucho familiar multiplex filler: loud screeches and some pretty silly business involving the girls' sinister way with wax crayons.
Mama never delivers the primal terror its premise would suggest.
Mama is not a gross out horror film and it's not trying to terrorize you. But it does deliver an elegantly creepy ghost tale that might subtly insinuate itself into your nightmares.
The dull, cliche-filled Mama is the kind of movie in which you don't fear the demon in the main character's bed, only envy that she gets to lay down.
Even if the beats are familiar, Muschietti sustains a remarkable mood throughout: wintry, elemental and stark, like a late Sylvia Plath poem.
... there is a sadness that ultimately defines who or what 'Mama' really is, and that seems more important than the scares.
Maternal-instinct-versus-the-monster is such a horror clich√© that it feels almost subversive to watch a movie where the protagonist is a reluctant 'mom.'
Mama is an old-fashioned offering that's low on gore and high on atmosphere, not unlike some of the better Japanese shockers that came out after The Ring.
Extended from a 2008 short and starring Jessica Chastain, this has become a proficient, machine-tooled horror flick.
Cliches mount until the climax, which is strangely satisfying and anything but the happily-ever-after conclusion we have been bred to expect.
Like writer director Mike Binder's previous film, The Upside of Anger, there is bite in this comedy as it looks at relationships, inner-demons and resolutions.

A documentary every bit as entertaining and rebellious as the real life figure at its center.

Marsh uses a combination of interviews, film of Petit as a young man, authentic newsreels and enacted reconstructions to produce an unforgettable experience.
A generous, visionary gesture supplanting the communal memory of the site's unspeakable horrors with an image of human achievement that's head-spinning, heart-leaping in its absurd purity.
A model of documentary storytelling, 'Man on Wire' is as gripping and suspenseful as a good heist film...

A fascinating time capsule: a combination of talking-head interviews, actual footage, and re-creations that evokes a kinder, gentler world and provides insight into one of the most audacious stunts of the 20th century.
Petit showed us that a dream, no matter how risky or dangerous, is often its own reward. It's an important lesson, but one that's obviously easy to forget, and Man on Wire is a stunning reminder.
Man on Wire should be watched on the biggest screen possible; it's an utterly thrilling exploration of one man's mad dream.
A compelling and subtle documentary about Philippe Petit's sensational walk on a wire between the World Trade Center Twin Towers in 1974 and the missteps he made on earth afterwards.
One of the most amazing cinematic experiences and achievements in terms of recreating a single event in history in the most comprehensive way.
A definite candidate for documentary of the year.
Petit transforms his stories into mini-masterpieces of performance.
It mines recent history in a way that makes it seem new and invigorating, reminding us of how wonderfully, blissfully deranged human behavior can be
Are these people inspiring, talented stars, pursuing a difficult and dangerous athletic feat, or are there they disturbed nuts with a death wish? The film doesn't judge and doesn't take sides.
[A] breathtaking documentary about that mad-genius coup achieved over three decades ago.
...cheekily irreverent.
The erasure of the towers adds poignance and irony to a documented event that is inherently thrilling and beautiful.
It's a great deal of fun, playing not unlike a crafty caper film with loads of spine-tingling suspense.
Builds a remarkable degree of suspense...and along the way it manages a good deal of humor and charm as well.
Even if what the very idea of such a stunt gives you is a knot in your stomach rather than a lump in your throat, Man on Wire is pure delight.
Ultimately, 'The Man Who Knew Too Little' will be the undiscerning movie patron.
forgettable fluff, but it's hard to slam any film in which the villains take a break from chasing and shooting at each other to play the old Kerplunk! game.

A shallow, disposal trifle about beards and waxing: the People magazine version of anthropology.
It does not shed much light on the topic it's nominally interested in.
Spurlock seems to be wholeheartedly interested in the motivating factors behind manscaping and other choices men make about their appearances.
It's a cute enough, au courant idea, though the Spurlock matrix of interviews + graphics is wearing a little thin, the probes less probing.

This complete waste of 82 minutes finds documentarian Morgan Spurlock taking a look at current trends in men's grooming, featuring interviews with a random sampling of people who have no idea what they're talking about - but they're famous.
Mansome is arguably [Spurlock's] most insignificant, lightweight effort to date. Never mind that it doesn't provide any answers; it barely even asks a question.
Reality TV lacks Spurlock's sly willingness to let the eccentric explain themselves, rather than letting them appear foolish. It's not deep, but then, it's about vanity.
While making a priority of squeezing in every usable bit of celebrity face-time, Mansome passes by potentially interesting digressions without more than a wayward glance.
In terms of laughs 'Mansome' is thinner than the hair on a bald man's scalp.

It's a movie so late in noticing a shift in American male grooming that for a documentary on the subject to work, Spurlock would either have to pitch it to our grandparents (or be a grandparent) or trace the arc of the shift and unpack it.
There's no real center to the film's potentially insightful topic, with Spurlock never zeroing in on a cohesive message.

The movie purports to be a lighthearted look at changing notions of masculinity and appearance. But unless you find something intrinsically hilarious about a man getting a pedicure, laughs are scarce.
Their charm is undeniable, though it mainly resides in the source material: the late 60s, when these were made, were Disney's darkest days for craft and commitment.
Quaint and fairly lovable kiddie adventures.
What a peculiar genius was A.A. Milne¬Ö Milne's distinctive voice retains its quality in with a clarity and integrity exceeding that of any other author Disney adapted.
...it's always nice, anytime, to renew one's acquaintance with A.A. Milne's delightful characters.
The product of marketing genius, but at its core, this movie is entirely true to A.A. Milne's wonderful storybook intentions.
While Blustery Day won an Oscar, all three cartoons deserved it.
One of the most charming of all Disney features... like anyone else, when I see it I am swiftly and inexorably carried back to childhood, in accordance with the drippy clichs.
[Blu-ray Review] Lush and lovely to look at with a number of solid extras, "The Many Adventures of Winnie the Pooh" on Blu-ray is easily recommended for both the young and the young at heart.
Disney has made a number of features by cobbling together shorter stories, but none more cleverly and successfully than this one.
This is actually one of my favorite Disney movies.
Just watching the film again for this review I was surprised how I still remembered almost every second of the movie, even though I haven't seen it in years.
This is packed with enough charm and whimsy to make you feel like a child again.
You'll enjoy reuniting with childhood friends, and for the next-generation fans of The Book of Pooh, this batch of honey couldn't be sweeter.
it would be necessary to add the immense quality of the animation, an authentic preciousness, or the constant metalinguistic games the action allows. [Full Review in Spanish]
People are beginning to question the bohemian sexual politics of Sixties counterculture. To the credit of Broomfield's film, it acknowledges the darker side of sunny Hydra.
Ihlen never quite comes into focus as a person, and neither does the relationship that is the ostensible purpose of the documentary.
Mixed in with their story are a damaged child, a paradise lost and eye-popping tales of drug indulgence. Words of Love balances the romanticism with the reality.
... provides more than just a career retrospective by tapping into how love can be a calming influence amid the pitfalls of fame.

Through several illuminating interviews, shot as talking heads, Broomfield also paints a picture of the time, the free love of the 1960s, the indulgence of artistic talent and the suffering of children.
In its final passages, Marianne & Leonard gives justice to a woman who has too often been reduced to Cohen's "muse."
This latest documentary by Nick Broomfield (who knew Ihlen) is meant to be a love story, and it sorta is. But it's the kind of one-sided love story that you wouldn't really wish on anyone.
It feels tacky and ungallant of Broomfield to be parading his old relationship around like this.
A melancholy valentine to this love story and the times in which it flourished.
Words of Love fails to heed many of the lessons that he may have learned along the way.
[Marianne & Leonard: Words of Love] is an elegiac romance that casts new light on a legend.
It's not just indulgent and self-serving, it's as boring and unenlightening as staring at a patch of grass while stone sober.
Even if Cohen is not your man, however, it's worth seeing for its sometimes rather frank discussions of life on Hydra.

[W]hile it's clearly also intended as a celebratory tribute to Marianne, she continues to be presented more as a mythological figure than as a human being with thoughts, feelings and desires of her own.

[Nick] Broomfield too tries to layer in his appreciation for [Marianne] Ihlen, even capturing her last, infirm moments, which, because of the remote presence of [Leonard] Cohen, come off more as a liberating fist pump than sad, agonizing whimper.
Made after their deaths, this film is a tribute to them, their enduring romance, and the culture that sparked it.
Never do we learn how it felt to be the woman to whom [Leonard] Cohen would say "so long" every night on stage.
Using personal photos and brief snatches of home-video footage, [Broomfield] has tenderly delved into the Leonard-Marianne relationship and assembled one of his most poetic, beguiling films.

It sounds like a Nicholas Sparks novel, but this true story of legendary folk singer Leonard Cohen and his Norwegian muse Marianne Ihlen features amazing footage, audio snippets, and interviews to tell this enduring love story. Captivating.
Really, it is hard to fathom what the point of this is beyond, say, noting that the Hydra survivors have aged quite badly so, kids, stay out the sun.
A standout performance from Karolina Gruszka elevates this exploration of grief and love, giving breath to the life of a true pioneer.

Curie deserves the recognition and there's an honourable attempt to colour in the historical context with references to the Dreyfus affair and the political state of play in turn-of-the-century Europe.
If we don't always know what drives Curie, we see the determination itself. That's enough to keep the film moving along.
"Marie Curie" gets the look right - the costumes, the re-creation of early 20th century Parisian streets and classrooms. But the film is lifeless.
... biopic of a French icon that's beautifully photographed, sensitively acted and punishingly dull.
With more sexy baths than any movie about a male scientist has ever seen, this biopic undermines the battle Curie fought to be taken seriously that is depicted here.
No√´lle has a dreamy visual style that pulls us into Marie's emotional reality, and we find ourselves captivated by this fascinating, pioneering woman.
Storywise, MC: TCOK is mostly underwhelming.
It is the sort of film that manages to incorporate languid baths and a duel (!) with obtuse conversations with Einstein and an overt feminist message.
Mesmerizing, heartfelt and powerful with an Oscar-worthy performance by Karolina Gruszka. It's one of the best films of the year. Marie Curie is a true "Wonder Woman."
The film addresses the existence of the Polish researcher from the double condition that led to the headlines: as a scientific woman and as an adulterous woman. [Full review in Spanish]

A fascinating life is reduced to a series of skittishly edited and visually stylised vignettes that do scant justice to Marie Curie's scientific achievements and Karolina Gruszka's laudably intense performance.
Honestly, you'd be better off finding the MGM version from 1943.
While the drama could have been more engrossing and substantive, the evocative period detail greatly enhances Noelle's selective and intimate portrait of a loving wife, mother and workaholic.
A Schubert-esque score and an extremely pretty, dappled cinematography make Marie Curie a compelling portrait of an undeniably important woman.
Talk about an exquisite film! Visually stunning. Fascinating story and solidly engaging construct.
Noelle fills the story with passion, debate and human contradiction. If the material ultimately eludes the director's grasp, wandering off on unfocused tangents, it's because of its ambition.
As biopics go, "Marie Curie" is a beautifully rendered sketch, rather than a fully detailed painting.
This is a film with both beauty and brains, though the latter has a stronger presence as Marie pushes forward in her research and encourages others to seek and learn.

Anchored by Karolina Gruszka's vibrant performance, Marie Curie: The Courage of Knowledge melds a story about scientific discovery with a passionate look at the struggles of a woman whose life should have been a good deal easier than it actually was.

In college they warn you against the kind of history where things had to happen because they happened the way they happened. Thus we miss the question of what kind of plotting Mary had been up to -- real or imaginary.
In spite of being handcuffed by uninspired storytelling, [Ronan and Robbie] excel in communicating strength, vulnerability and isolation as two monarchs ruling in a man's world.
Mary Queen of Scots isn't revolutionary, but it is about one, and she's played brilliantly by Saoirse Ronan.

Willimon's screenplay is generous to both women, succeeding in allowing us to comprehend the motives and thinking of them both.

Ridley Scott proves that he can't suppress his frosted side forever, thanks to this spirited and undeniably sweet look at the con game spliced with a family drama -- his best work in years
Unusually intimate outing for director Ridley Scott glides along a slick, shiny, Hollywood-style surface. But the actors keep it real throughout.

I wish "Matchstick Men" kept me in the dark longer than it does leading to the climax. It is a real pleasure, though, to see Cage in thesping form again.
The acting and dialogue and story are all good, but somehow the whole thing feels really poky and tentative.
A tale so complex, so absorbing, and so cerebrally titillating, you won't want to look away for two seconds for fear of missing something.
the fact that the film ends on an image of sublime sentimentality and gets away with it scott free is enough to make it worth seeing twice, just to appreciate how it got there.
It is great to see Cage go from comedy to sentimentality to drama.
Matchstick Men is really two movies brilliantly spliced into one, each enriching the other.
A delightful dark comedy.
Not since Thelma and Louise has Scott showcased such wonderfully eccentric and memorable characters.
Cage's performance earns nothing but applause from me.
A clumsy, heavy film, its most profoundly expressed emotion is greed.
Delivers some trickle-down emotional benefits.

...entertaining throughout...
A delightful comic fantasy.
A consistently happy comedic fable which should please romanticists drawn to a teaming of Neil Simon, Marsha Mason and Herbert Ross.
Crowd-pleasing domestic comedy that's based on a Neil Simon screenplay.
Comic, clever, and satisfying fairy tale of redemption.

The best kind of independent filmmaking to shame the somnolent mainstream.
In the end, you just feel good about these people, and that's a nice sensation these days.
Fine performances almost redeem sentimental slop.
[A] tangled, tortured mess.
Linney's finely calibrated, low-key performance as Callie goes a long way towards making it more interesting than it might otherwise be.
The main plot line ... is pretty weak.
[The script] is a predictable tear-jerker.

A movie that both Oprah and Hallmark would be proud to stamp with their seal of approval.
Shows promise as a first feature ... but overall it feels a little too safe, a little too careful.

There's a by-the-numbers inevitability to every scene, and it never clicks into place to be anything special.
Becomes a vanity project bathed in poignancy.
The movie has a sweetness and care that is touching.
In one of his last acting roles, the late [Bill] Paxton does an amazing job capturing the essence of a true villain - and it isn't because of the guns or moustache.
Here comes Nathan Morlando's Mean Dreams to remind us all that things are bad in the heartland of this here good ole U.S. of A.
Paxton's terrific, keeping "Mean Dreams" as unsettling as it can be, adding terrific punctuation to a movie that needs his unusual take on menace, giving the hunt and the heartbreak welcome urgency.
Aided by his fresh and engaging young actors, Morlando is turning into a master of mood. And credit Steve Cosens with making the fields and forests look spectacular.
A beautiful, dangerous picture of rural America with echoes of Terrence Malick.
Mean Dreams starts with promise. It doesn't live up to that promise.

Mean Dreams is a coming-of-age drama that evolves into a crime thriller. There's too much going on here, and the story eventually falls apart under its own weight, but there's still a lot to like about this engaging film.
A rather generic thriller...
Tepid teen romance turned implausible thriller is just about saved by a powerful, and unusually disturbing, performance from Bill Paxton (one of his last).
Watching Paxton play pure evil is to just be reminded of his exceptional range, never stereotyping this corrupt cop and keeping us off balance.
It's refreshing to see a Canadian film that embraces a genre with unapologetic passion, and with no ironic asides.
And as the stakes are heightened, the filmmakers too often short-change dramatic verisimilitude with movie-ish clich√©, implausible plotting and cumbersome dialogue.
Mean Dreams is compelling, driven by the fearsome performance of Paxton, whose legacy is only strengthened by one of his final performances.
The shadow of 'Badlands' falls a little too long over Nathan Morlando's initially promising but fatally derivative teens-on-the-run thriller.
It's the acting that carries the film, together with the sweetness of the under-written central romance. Viewers who relate to these young people will find themselves gripped.
Familiarity doesn't always yield tedium, but it's hard to muster much enthusiasm for Mean Dreams' sleepy regionalist remix of genre tropes and images.
An uncomplicated film sustained thanks to its magnificent naturalistic photography and the loyalty to its humble beginnings, without pretentious tricks or devices. [Full review in Spanish]
A thrillingly dark fable draped in beautiful images and a layered, menacing performance from Paxton.

Spiritual questions and thoughts on the importance of flesh-and-blood relationships are raised, but the strength of the you-can-run-but-you-can't-hide drama is the dewy charisma of the two young co-stars. T
Paxton, in one of his last performances, is a diabolical blend of fresh-faced wholesomeness and pure evil.
he love scenes are cringe-making. Actually, any scene where Statham is not breaking necks is cringe-y.
A mechanized story focused in kicks and one of Statham worst films. [Full review in Spanish]
A flat and tedious action film.
This film is exactly like any other Jason Statham movie you may have seen before.
His [Statham] indisputable charisma is unable to overcome the film's many weaknesses.

"Mechanic: Resurrection" is the movie "The Mechanic" should have been - a bite-sized Bond film, or maybe a grittier homicidal knockoff of the "Mission: Impossible" series, with a lone-wolf renegade as the entire team.
Statham is almost saved from looking like a ridiculous comic superhero thanks to his charisma and presence. [Full review in Spanish]
With a bar this low they might as well hire Tommy Wiseau for the next one.
A relatively entertaining but helplessly cheesy action romp.

The Stath, alas, is following orders throughout: given his revelatory comic turn in last year's Spy, he may yet return to material that allows him to raise smiles and smash heads, but this shrugging afterthought isn't it.
For the most part this plodding, far-fetched bubblegum fare loses sight of what the ever-impeccable Statham does best.

Unnecessary second-shot Mechanic: Resurrection, playing like a third-rate remake of Bond scenes, can't resurrect the ghost of a thrilling action sequence, the spirit of a high-calibre assassin adventure, even the faintest whiff of originality.
The amount of idiocy and ineptitude on display throughout this sequel is absolutely astounding. (Full Content Review for Parents - Violence, Sexual Content, Profanity, etc. - also Available)
No one buys a ticket to a Jason Statham movie for the love story.
Mechanic: Resurrection is a mindless B-movie with little substance of note, but those who enjoy Statham should have a fun time.
This sequel manages to meet expectations providing a good time and not much else. [Full review in Spanish]

There's some pleasant globe-trotting - Brazil to Thailand to Australia to Bulgaria - and a lot of over-the-top fights. But don't be surprised if after a few rounds, you find yourself wishing for the bell.
Statham is wasting his last good years as an action star in Z-movies like this.
For the most part, it's not worth it.
If the last decade hasn't already sold you, Mechanic: Resurrection solidifies Jason Statham's status as a monotone cardboard cut-out excuse of an action star.
...will appeal to little kids with its bright colors and animation, older kids will like the story and most adults will be entertained.
You'll enjoy it. And then you'll forget it.
Megamind manages to be both commentary and comic book, and I have no doubt audiences will eat it up.
It's a harmless, inoffensive, moderately likable throwaway of a cartoon that you will probably start forgetting as soon as it's over.
The film appropriates elements from Shrek and The Incredibles and produces an entertaining hybrid that should have parents chuckling with glee.

This is a harmless animated movie that's full of empty laughs. The main problem with all those empty laughs is that they arrive wrapped in a package you've seen before, probably even if you're still a kid.
There's nothing wrong with animation aimed at adults, but this may be the first kids' movie that throws fewer bones to its supposed intended viewers than to their parents.
Megamind is full of good ideas. But they never coalesce into a satisfying whole.
Megamind is fast and funny, with excellent use of 3D.
Not exactly ingenious, but certainly an entertaining way to spend an afternoon at the theater with the family.
This is a great-looking (and sounding) toon, one definitely worth seeing in 3D, but it's ultimately the story, characters and humor that makes Megamind such a pleasant surprise.
This set-up is bright and amusing, even if it does feel recycled from bits and pieces of such recent animated landmarks as The Invincibles with its superpowers and Despicable Me with its villain.
A fun ride but just that.
A complex story with very sophisticated forward momentum... It's about what makes people a hero or villain,and the answer is not just simply one is bullied and the other is revered.
Would be lost in the crowd, perhaps deservedly so, if it didn't pull aces on its execution.
...an OK entertainment that's instantly forgettable.
For a film whose stock in trade are tongue-in-cheek reversals of comic-book clich√©, it too often settles for trite audience-pleasing.
What Megamind lacks in apparent laughter it makes up for in sheer cleverness.
This animated feature is what Yogi Berra called "d√©j√† vu all over again," its shopworn premise most recently having served the marginally better "Despicable Me" this summer.
one of the year's better animated films which offers a surprisingly engrossing nature-versus-nurture question about mythic origin stories: are heroes born, or are they made?

Resolutely somber, and self-aware about its deliberately tight and opaque visual style, it's presentational more than lived, a series of filmmaking choices instead of something deeply felt and conveyed.
This is a haunting film about the agony of uncertainty, in which hope is dwindling and there is no guarantee of truth...
Despite its pedigree, Memoir of War does not guarantee safe passage.
Memoir of War is a film that is aware of that its fabric is not that of history, but rather of a besieged subjectivity where reality becomes phantasmagoria. [Full Review in Spanish]
Marguerite Duras's semifictionalized memoir of psychological survival and emotional endurance in Paris during the Nazi occupation makes an uneasy, listless transition to the screen.
The problem isn't the idea, it's the lack of modulation... [Full Review in Spanish]
There's a spectral tone to this film that works. [Full Review in Spanish]
It's a strong film addressing a common yet seldom dramatized wartime experience...
Pain, it turns out, can be unbearably dull.
It's more daring than it seems, less academic than it could have been and almost as inclement as the source material. [Full Review in Spanish]
If, at over two hours, it is an undeniably onerous watch, that is by design: Finkiel's film certainly understands the taxing nature of sorrow.

Memoir of War is at its best when it focuses on the complex inner life of its compelling protagonist, but even she can't prevent this film from feeling unnecessarily drawn-out by the time it reaches its conclusion.
Fortunately, M√©lanie Thierry manages to fill the screen almost on her own. [Full review in Spanish]
Buoyed by an astonishing central turn by M√©lanie Thierry.
The film signals the arrival of another major French star actress. Memoir of War is a great film.
Though writer-director Emmanuel Finkiel has made a valiant effort, 'Memoir of War'...is dedicated and respectful but rather chilly and remote.
Liberation of Paris from Nazis gets a new, personalized perspective, where it serves as the background for one woman living through this fraught period, Marguerite Duras.
Overall, this mood piece is too impressionistic, elliptical and wobbly about its chronology and details.
The fact the film failed to convert any of its eight C√©sar nominations says much, but this still represents a bold bid to recreate a highly distinctive recollection of a unique time.
A punch to the gut - but also remarkable for its specificity.
As an insider, I know that GOATS is not 100% true, but true enough to enjoy.
"The Men Who Stare at Goats" falls into the politically impotent sub-genre of lightweight satire of which "Charlie Wilson's War" and "The Informant" are recent touchstones.
A likable, lightweight, absurdist comedy.
It's ... two-thirds of the way to being awesome. Had Heslov eased back a bit, Goats might've made it the rest of the way.
It's smugness -- unleavened by wit -- that makes Goats so offensive.
Even at a brief running time of 87 minutes, the film feels stretched, leaving you as "the person who blankly stares at the screen"...until it's finally over.
If looks could really kill, this film would already be dead.
It has a quick pace and plenty of laugh-out-loud moments, though you might wish it had tried to do something a little more substantial.
Intended as a farcical antidote to big-screen bores about Afghanistan and Iraq, it's twice as pompous and endlessly tedious.
Not the acerbic, Strangelovian satire one might expect but a pleasant, good-natured film that adopts the happy hippy vibe of Bridges' far-out Vietnam vet...
A nearly apolitical farce where Clooney's combination of wide-eyed lunacy and steely-eyed conviction mesh nicely ... and where Bridges is quite Dude-like in his hippie-dippie demeanor.

There's not much action in The Men Who Stare at Goats, despite ostensibly being a "war movie" -- but then again, that's about what you'd expect from a film about a military unit trained to fight with their minds instead of guns. And while the satir
The Men Who Stare at Goats doesn't stay with you long, but it's good fun while it lasts.
A laidback, slightly underwhelming farce on the madness of the military.
Clooney and Bridges model an assortment of wigs and facial hair as they labor to put across their outsize characters.
The oddity of its subject matter can't quite find a suitable groove between weird believability and preposterous put-on.
Through the whole film one has the feeling that the real story is just about to begin, but like the original military project, we go nowhere and nothing ever comes of anything.
A quietly wacky military satire good for scattered chuckles and laughs.
The actors were having a much better time making the film than I did sitting in the theater watching it.
For a movie about people learning to focus their minds, [it] proves to be strangely and disappointingly unfocused.
A perplexing example of promise unfulfilled, despite many charming moments.
Perhaps not since Nelson Eddy crooned his Indian Love Call to Jeanette MacDonald has there been a movie so unabashedly Canadian, not afraid to risk American scorn or disinterest.
While much of the cast has charm -- especially Allodi and Nolden -- the performers are sunk by the film's primitive approach to the mechanics of comedy.
This isn't exactly profound cinema, but it's good-natured and sometimes quite funny.
Someday, a creative filmmaker may make an involving movie on the unique sport of curling. Men With Brooms, however, is not that movie.
Curling may be a unique sport but Men with Brooms is distinctly ordinary.
It makes you believe the cast and crew thoroughly enjoyed themselves and believed in their small-budget film.
This is a winning ensemble comedy that shows Canadians can put gentle laughs and equally gentle sentiments on the button, just as easily as their counterparts anywhere else in the world.
Call this The Full Monty on ice, the underdog sports team formula redux.
Scores a few points for doing what it does with a dedicated and good-hearted professionalism.
Not completely loveable -- but what underdog movie since The Bad News Bears has been? -- but certainly hard to hate.
The plot of the comeback curlers isn't very interesting actually, but what I like about Men With Brooms and what is kind of special is how the film knows what's unique and quirky about Canadians.
While curling enthusiasts may be delighted to see their little-known sport featured in a film, actor-director Paul Gross never manages to make it seem interesting to newcomers.
Serving as director, writer and lead, Paul Gross -- who enjoyed brief fame in the TV Mountie show Due South -- imbues his film with that series' same languid Canadian charm.

Think The Full Monty on ice: Canada's most famous TV Mountie Paul Gross (Due South) puts tongue firmly in cheek as he applies the old underdog sports team formula to that great Northern obsession: curling.
The filmmakers have great fun mixing and matching the game's metaphors. With such gags as a sweat lodge of hot curling rocks, they send up and glorify its rituals all at once.
Comparisons to "This is Spinal Tap" abound in this inside look at the heavy metal rock band Metallica, but "This is Spinal Tap" was a heck of a lot of fun also.
One of the most intriguing films of the year.
Joe Berlinger and Bruce Sinofsky could hardly have known what they were in for when they set out to make a movie about Metallica.
There's an almost soap-opera aspect to the story, about people with deep affection for each other, but also 20 years of hard history and a candidness one can't help but respect.
Carefully structured from 1600 hours of film, yet still an impressive insight into Metallica's world.
The polar opposite of a puff piece. It's raw and sometimes ugly, but strives for honesty and intensity -- kind of like Metallica's own music.
Don't let anyone spoil the surprises of this thrashing, thrilling chunk of cinematic gold. It's one for the time capsule.
Berlinger and Sinofsky manipulate almost two years of raw footage into one coherent, riveting and educational piece.
Transcends the rockumentary genre and becomes something uniquely its own.
Some Kind of Monster is some weird kind of wonderful.
It's great emotional fodder for old-school Metallica fans and smart, tugging drama for people unfamiliar with the band.
The movie permits us to hover from first riff to last encore, during which Metallica finds a new record and itself just as it all seems to be coming apart.
Overkill to anyone who never flashed the group's devil horns salute.
The result will stand as one of the most intense, in-depth, warts-and-all rockumentaries ever made -- VH1's Behind the Music cranked up to 11 and beyond.
It's head-banging entertainment from start to finish.
What ties each moment together is the fascinating and emotional tale of rock and its heroes growing up yet trying, against the odds, to stay genuine.
No rock doc has burrowed so deeply into the bruised egos, arrested development and internal conflict that make up a superstar band.
Uncompromising but never hateful, Some Kind of Monster is a very good movie and, within its own surprising logic, ultimately a victorious one for Metallica.
Dude, where's my therapist?
A magnificent documentary! I talked about it for seven days afterwards.
This is a band who has done everything there is to do in the world of music; they took a bold risk with this new style directed by Nimrod Antal.
Watch Some Kind Of Monster instead.
If you're looking for an orgasmic trip to heavy-metal heaven, this is it.
For a loyal fan, this is something of a godsend.
