The songs still sound great here, but the instruments aren't amplified nearly as much as the nostalgia and vanity of the men who wield them.

If you're big into Metallica, you could very well eat this up. For the casual viewer who might have gotten a kick out of watching them in 'Some Kind of Monster,' this comes off more like 'Some Kind of Nothing.' (Full Parental Review also available)
"Through the Never" is a jaw-dropping, eye-popping, ear splitting reminder that the aristocracy that is heavy metal has only one true king: Metallica.
DeHaan's possession of the spotlight might well best the band itself, since Metallica never completely catches fire live.
Giddily preposterous.
Metallica, those thrash virtuosos of doom, get the grand 3-D opera they deserve: a godless-apocalypse-meets-Vegas spectacle, full of fireballs and electric chairs.
Lets viewers feel like they're sliding up and down the fretboard of Kirk Hammett's guitar, volleying between the cymbals of Lars Ulrich and swallowing spit spewed by singer James Hetfield.
Metallica Through the Never succeeds as an enthralling and visceral concert movie experience but fails to use the medium for a deeper level of artistic appreciation.

Metallica are a lean, mean business machine, still ballsy enough to pull off something as silly as Through the Never but seasoned enough to never let the genre-bending concert film distract from their one true saving grace - their musicianship.
Metallica is as fierce and intense as ever, and the greatest hits set the band performs is a barrage of heavy riff-age that captures the band at its most vital.
This movie is basically "Spinal Tap" - the jokes.
However mindless and heartless it may be, Through the Never succeeds as pure sense-swamping spectacle.

Its buzz saw execution is magnificent, making sure the audience exits the theater with melted brains and blood pouring out of their ears, but director Antal leaves the movie with more than a few question marks.
A gigantic spectacle, a virtual-reality experience that is both ridiculous and sublime, sometimes in the same moment.
If Through the Never's attempts at creating a story-and-performance hybrid are only partially successful...its concert footage remains its prime selling point and strength.
"Metallica Through the Never" is an experience best seen and heard in IMAX. It will blow you away.

Philip Saville, who directs from a screenplay by Adrian Hodges, starts with a straightforward story of life choices and slips in teasing asides... What Saville doesn't do, mercifully, is depend on sentiment.
The film flips back and forth between the Beatlemania-era of the early '60s and their suburban period of the '70s...
There's nothing extraordinary about Metroland.
An affectionate but barbed tale about a pair of suburban-bred Englishmen
likely to strike a chord with a lot of young husbands, especially those who find themselves sometimes envying their single friends. ...Bale and Watson are utterly credible...
With terrific performances from Bale and Watson, the film is memorable and unique instead of plain and watchable.
A deft morality tale about the engines of sexual desire and jealousy.
A moving film about the compromises of adulthood, but perhaps a little too earnest.
For all the nudity and sexual content, Philip Saville's unoriginal and predictable film is, at its core, no different from one you'd find premiering on network television.
Underrated.
What's the difference between documentary and hagiography? Directors James Stern and Don Kempf don't seem to have given the matter much thought.

The usual collection of television spots, trailers, and crew biographies are also included, as well as detailed stats on Jordan's regular season and postseason careers -- a nice finishing touch to a classy digital tribute to a living legend.
Michael Jordan is one of the few athletes big enough to deserve a film such as "Michael Jordan to the Max."
An honorific but unmoving portrait of the Chicago Bulls' No. 23.
Unlike Michael Jordan, this large-format movie demonstrates mostly unrealized potential.
A fantastic portrayal of His Airness' on-court heroics -- not to mention visually stunning
This triumphant story of an extremely positive role model is a rewarding treat.
In this authorized look at a great athlete, we are confronted by a man who has no weaknesses and no imperfections.
All about its star power, the kind that even appeals to a theater full of Jazz fans who would wish for a different kind of changed history.
Felt like one big highlight reel
IMAX is a format where the sheer scale overpowers its flaws.
Score's big in the hearts of Mike fans.
The filmmakers give us what we always want when it comes to MJ: images of a man caught in the act of being superhuman.
The film is more like an infomercial in which the pitchman is also the product.
It's brilliance is to put you in the moment, some of the greatest moments in modern sports history.
Essentially just a promotional film for Jordan as a product. It plays like a commercial for itself.
Michael Jordan, sports icon, gets another buffing. Michael Jordan, person, remains private and just a little bit richer.
Jordan was born to be an admired all-star. But as the film so eloquently shows, he worked hard to be the classy superstar that he turned out to be.
IMAX practically puts you on the court and magnifies everyone.
Recommended viewing for any kid who's ever dreamed of the big leagues.

Deepa Mehta's respectful approach to the material may meander and simplify, but it gradually gains in emotional power, building into a moving account of a man whose many experiences mirror the growing pains of an independent India.
The film is stunningly beautiful. And the story retains at least some of the elements that made the novel so special in its imagination, ambition and scope.
A sprawling, lumbering epic that manages to preserve a substantial amount of the book's content but achieves little of its magic.
Teeming with personality and digestible flights of fancy, only to be crushed by the overall narrative responsibility, unable to juggle faces and places to satisfaction.
A movie that, if never exactly dull, feels drained of the mythic juice that powers the book, which won the Booker Prize in 1981.
In its steady great-books way, the film is often truthful and moving.
The general consensus was, while it was beautifully shot, it lacked heart.
Solid may ultimately be the best word for this pleasing, middlebrow adaptation of Rushdie's 'unfilmable' book.
The film is beautifully shot, with vivid production design. But because of the tale's lack of cohesion, it doesn't carry enough emotional heft.
The cinematography is memorably vibrant, and the performances are solid, even if they pass by too swiftly. Most of all, of course, the subject matter remains fascinating.
Rather more virtuosity behind the camera was required to induce the desired hypnotic effect. Deepa Mehta just isn't up to it.
Preserves much of the novel's intricacy and human drama, perhaps due to Salman Rushdie's involvement as co-screenwriter, even if it remains singularly unremarkable from a cinematic perspective.
A pretty but staidly linear epic drained of the novel's larkish, metaphorical sweep, and a collection of multi-generational love stories lacking their originally eccentric, fizzy charm.
Rushdie adeptly trims his sprawling tale down to a still-substantial 2 1/2-hour movie, which only occasionally seems to hurry.
Particularly thanks to Rushdie's involvement as a co-screenwriter, it is easy to feel not only the characters of his novel coming to life, but indeed, the mystical quality of its history.
Deepa Mehta's film is only intermittently engaging: it is limited in scope and imagination, and in parts it becomes plodding and stagey.
Amidst all the exuberance on screen, a major literary work has been given a new and accessible form of life.
Thanks to Rushdie's sensitive handling of his own material, this is an adaptation big in both ideas and heart.
Considering Midnight's Children is bound up in notions of identity, it is faintly disastrous that this adaptation should be so lacking in one of its own.

[I]t's almost never a good idea to let novelists adapt their own fiction for the screen. A cold distant appraisal of what works onscreen and what doesn't is required, and it's not fair to expect writers to be so brutal with their babies.
A poor second fiddle to stuff like Porky's.
This Midsummer(TM)s Night is fun, witty, and wild, although ultimately forgettable.
Not among Woody's most memorable, but it's still pleasant enough to warrant a visit.
Top-flight Allen. Probably his most gorgeous color film.
A Midsummer Night's Sex Comedy circles around the nuances of love-a web that both tantalizes and confounds Americans.
Picturesque but uncertain.
There doesn't seem to be a driving idea behind it, a confident tone to give us the sure notion that Allen knows what he wants to do here.
It's one of Allen's lightest trifles, but it too contains enough funny jokes and fantasy moments to make it a small treasure.
It's funny and sweet in spots, though the light moments get lost in the haze of imitation and ambitiousness.
A pleasant disappointment, pleasant because he gets all the laughs he goes for in a visually charming, sweetly paced picture, a disappointment because he doesn't go for more.
Allen has no affinity for Renoir's robust generosity, yet this study does wonders for his filmmaking

Inspired by Bergman's Smiles of a Summer Night, andwith a touch of Renoir's Rules of the Game, this period comedy is a minor work, a trifle in Allen's career, worth seeing for some of the supporting acting.

Pure mid-period Allen, a muscle-stretching ensemble comedy with dramatic undertones and playful philosophical musings...Allen's characters ponder the permeable divide between lust and love, and the meanings of sexual intercourse... [Blu-ray]
It's all very pleasant but also all very slight, with the humor and the romance both kept at too low a simmer.
It's Allen's refusal to bask in the spotlight -- his willingness and determination to preserve and enhance the ensemble -- that makes Sex Comedy the delight that it is.
The film is flawless, but Woody Allen's genius is absent. [Full Review in Spanish]
A welcome sign that Allen has recovered his good humor after the corrosive misanthropy of Stardust Memories.
A claustrophobic look at dangers some workers face every day.

...here's a film about something real, not a horror picture about a group of shapely cavers who descend into the earth and get trapped with monsters chasing them. The monsters in the effective, streamlined thriller "Mine 9" are all around us.

Mensore's film aims chiefly to highlight the typical plight of an American underclass that rarely gets big-screen attention. That it does with honesty and conviction, if not a great deal of inspiration.
An impressive piece of work that deploys low-budget filmmaking techniques with cleverness.
Mensore does his due diligence in showing us the claustrophobic, perilous conditions of the mine, even before disaster strikes...
A satisfyingly intense and efficiently filmed bit of counterprogramming for those suffering from superhero fatigue.
A survival thriller works if the tension is authentic and the actions are believable. You get that and more in director Edward Mensore's immersive nail-better.
Mensore dedicates his scant resources to creating a visceral experience, emphasizing the lack of visibility, the gassy haze and the constant, terrifying creaks and moans underground.
Mine 9 juggles too many characters, but it works in just about every other way. The acting is fantastic, the editing is dynamic, the directing subtlety builds tension, and the ending is really good.
The movie's implication that the untenable conditions are just "the way it is" is complacent at best.

An indie film about a team of Appalachian coal miners trapped two miles down, trying to crawl their way up with an hour of oxygen, Mine 9 makes maximum use of the dark in all its frightening implications.
Mine 9 is the most poignant and terrifying sort of drama: a film about good, hard working, sympathetic people in a life or death situation.
Eddie Mensore has not made a masterpiece of the genre, but there's a poignancy to his gritty calamity tale that makes Mine 9 worth watching.
The results aren't golden, but this mine strikes a solid vein of silver with its subterranean drama.
The simple storyline and real-life backdrop were fundamental to success, in a drama equal parts tragedy and compassion.
Unfortunately, the film begins to lose its once-solid footing in the third act, leading to a rushed and disappointing ending.

The film works as a character piece, a message piece, and a tension filled film. It's one of those that should be viewed on as large a screen as possible and in the dark to get its full effect once the miners end up caught in the mine post explosion
Everything you want an indie thriller to be - topical, regional, well-acted and harrowing as all get out.
One of those films that grabs you early on and never lets you go.
There's enough here to make a thrilling, dynamic and even moving war movie, if only Lee could have kept his excesses out of the way of his filmmaking strengths.
I admire his passion and technique, but I hope he rediscovers the discipline that made movies such as The Inside Man so good.
St. Anna is as disorganized, unfulfilling, and lifeless a picture as Lee is capable of making. That's right, it's She Hate Me bad.
As another example of Lee settling scores, it ruins its own premise by attempting to out-do Saving Private Ryan.
Spike Lee has created what may be his weakest film to date.

Lee shows a knack for combat scenes and both the brutality and brotherhood of man. Opportunism, barbarism and hope mix in the most piercing, cathartic scenes. But his grudge match with Clint Eastwood weighs too heavily, and it's an ambitious mess.
even at a bloated 155 minutes, Lee's picture seems to aimlessly tread water
Along the way, Mr. Lee has some gripping moments. But for every striking irony, there is a hammer-handed scene driving the same point into self-parody.
This is like the 'Where's Waldo' of war films: Find the story, locate the characters. You have three hours. Good luck to you.
As is often the case, Lee seems to relish biting off more than he can chew, and the ambition and scope of this effort is worth the bits that don't quite fit.
Ultimately, the film falters -- due to its length, some unconvincing European characters and too many turns that depend on sudden supernatural intervention.
The long and the short of it is Lee and McBride plant the seeds of something incredible, they just forget to add the requisite nurturing and care required to see it grow.

There are many mysteries on hand in "Miracle at St. Anna" but the biggest mystery of all is how anyone could have deemed the rambling and seriously undisciplined screenplay by James Baldwin ready for filming.

By choosing for his definitive portrait a tale based on a fictional novel rather than an actual true story, Lee has undermined his own efforts to properly depict the wartime experience for WWII-era blacks.
Too long, but picks up after an abysmal start.

When Miracle at St. Anna falters, it's in the moments that seem like they could have been crafted by any other film maker; when Miracle at St. Anna succeeds, it's in the moments that could only have been crafted by Lee.
As a theoretical corrective, it's salutary; as a movie, it's a frickin' blooper
Lee clearly has magical realism, fable, and historical enormity on the brain, and even though he stuffs the film with everything but the proverbial kitchen sink, his ultimate point is anyone's guess
There's a good two hour movie here. Too bad it's lost in a disjointed, meandering narrative.
Little imperfections prevent it from being the classic epic it wants to be, but Lee accomplishes quite a lot here.
It's a miniseries awkwardly stuffed in the body of a two-hour drama about the Palestinians' long struggle against the Israelis.
Rambles its way through several decades of major events with blunt expository dialogue and undercooked dramatic conflicts.
Miral never feels like a hot button issue movie, or the even more dreaded "important social" movie. It's just a moving drama about a world that's foreign, at least to me, and probably many audiences.
Schnabel is free to make a film sympathetic to the Palestinians, of course, but such distortions and selective history make this little more than an arty propaganda film.
While Hind's (Hiam Abbass) story is only background for events to come, this first chapter is the best in the film.
Meant to celebrate the heroism of Palestinian women, Julian Schnabel's decades-spanning drama is mostly stilted and incomplete.
...sporadically engrossing yet thoroughly uneven...
Is this a joke? Or a film art 'happening'?
The lack of a compelling lead figure, combined with Schnabel's tentative approach to the material, casts the film's later stretches in the balmy glow of soap opera.

Schnabel dedicates Miral to "everyone on both sides who still believes peace is possible"-a noble sentiment, to be sure, but will anyone on either side really see themselves reflected in such a simplistic, ham-fisted treatment?
A middlebrow stew of distracting star cameos, stilted speechifying, and references to The Battle of Algiers.
What "Miral" lacks in performance art, Schnabel attempts to replace with design.
How can you appeal to both sides when you tell only one side's story?
Like its star, it's pretty, but that's about it.
Impassioned, but also dramatically disjointed and emotionally parched.
[T]here are plenty of nonpolitical reasons to frown upon Miral: it's simply not a very engaging film, even to those sympathetic to the Palestinian cause...
...if you're going to ask the audience to piece together the meaning of a scene for themselves, don't cue the conclusion with a soundtrack full of familiar emotional cues.
Schnabel's signature blend of splintered storytelling and sobering humanism feels misapplied to this sweeping multigenerational saga of four Arab women living under Israeli occupation.
The last thing propaganda should do is make its audience work. "Miral" is a lot of work.
Like so many other well-intentioned movies about politically contentious issues, it is hobbled by its own sincerity and undone by a confused aesthetic agenda.
It's nice to see an unlikely actress going the Liam Neeson route. But when it comes to Miss Bala itself, the film is sure to leave audiences feeling taken.
A compelling cross of Taken (2008) and Miss Congeniality (2000)!
Even if you erase the messy gender politics, you're still left with a mildly watchable actioner defined by unremarkable set pieces, a generic script, and flat characters.
While Dunnet-Alcocer tries to give Lino some humanity, with a backstory to explain why he chose the cartel life, the script forgets to give Gloria the same consideration.
I almost feel bad hoping [a franchise] eludes her for at least this one more attempt. It's nothing personal, I just can't imagine sitting through 'Miss Bala Returns' in two years.
More miss than baller.
Rodriguez and her fans deserve better than "Miss Bala," a disappointingly bland and formulaic Hollywood remake of a much grittier and bleaker Mexican thriller.
Miss Bala not only loses the realism that made the Mexican version so powerful, but also its social commentary about the drug war. [Full Review in Spanish]
The emotional oomph of the original is stripped away in this sanitized version of the story of a woman caught in the web of violence of drug cartel. Gina Rodriguez is good, but for naught
Say what you will about this remake of a 2011 Mexican crime thriller, but the American version has a kick-ass elevator pitch: Miss Congeniality meets Sicario.
Miss Bala is 10 kilos of narrative in a five-kilo bag; there's far too much story for the film's modest 106 minutes ... essentially a darkest-timeline Miss Congeniality.
Tone deaf, directionless, a slog to sit through, no visible heroes masquerading as complex narrative writing, Miss Bala is one of those prime January stinkers we have come to expect
Overall, the film is no more than adequate, which unfortunately feels like a disappointment, given its potential. It's a shame that it never comes together.
It's a good time but it's not a good movie.

Hardwick's film is gleefully entertaining in a B-movie kind of way, zesty yet also corny at times....For those who go along for the wild, undemanding ride, it makes for a good Friday night action flick.
Even though parts of the film are predictable, the cast manages to make it work and elevate the film. [Full Review in Spanish]
There is absolutely room for female action stars in the contemporary film canon but Miss Bala fails to make the case.
Although the new Miss Bala gives its lead character the agency to fight back and outsmart her captors, the film overdoses on its own message of pop feminist empowerment.
It's hard to say if Hardwicke's unwillingness to ugly things up is a feature or a bug.
This film suffers from its Hollywood-ization... It's all so slick.
Much more convincing than Mike Figgis's 1999 screen adaptation, starring Saffron Burrows, it is a grueling slog through a hell of torment, cruelty and suffering.

It starts off as a will-they-won't-they as to whether Chastain's baron's daughter will sleep with Farrell. It ends up as a will-they-won't-they ever shut up. Should have been called Shouting Miss Julie.

Miss Julie feels stubbornly theatrical, rather than cinematic; Ullmann's dispassionate camera conveys little urgency or momentum, and her use of cutaways to highlight details like photographs and knives is painfully heavy-handed.
The film's themes - sexual power, class struggle, money, gender, - are as relevant as ever.
A compelling clash of upstairs/downstairs class values, this is one of the rare examples of filmed theatre that is able to move well beyond the usual static frontiers of that genre.
Rife with mawkish histrionics and a thoroughly overwrought script, it's hard to maintain interest in what should be an intriguing watch.
There are many things worth commending, one of which is the strength of the performances. But as I step back and think about it as an overall piece, I find myself overwhelmingly ... unaffected.
What Ullmann's done is create the ideal conditions for these three to do electrifying work with each other. She maintains control so they can lose it.
Strenuously acted dramas make for strenuous viewing, and Liv Ullmann's rigorous adaptation of Strindberg's Miss Julie, which uproots the action to 19th-century Ireland, is no exception.
The result is decent rather than spectacular.
All the tremendous claustrophobic intensity of the original is scattered to the winds. And that will not go unnoticed by theatre lovers, who should be the immediate audience of such a film.

Ullmann's version of "Miss Julie" exists in a special cinematic category; it's toxic, it's hypnotic, and passionately translates Strindberg's genius instinct for enlightening the multi-layered psychological spectrums of human desire for lust and power.
Morton, one of the least artificial actresses in the world, charts her character's heartbreak without any of the self-pity normally assigned to ordinary women.
The film has a singular focus on these characters and their power struggles of class and gender, but fails to ever feel like it's really going anywhere.
Claustrophobic, basically unexciting and heavy-handed.

Chastain's electrifying performance places among the great female dramatic turns in a literary tragedy, from Nina Pens Rode in 'Gertrud' to Nastassja Kinski in 'Tess' and Isabelle Huppert in 'Madame Bovary.'
All talents are ill-served by the unambitious handling of the material.
Liv Ullmann's worshipful but static adaptation of the classic Strindberg play fails to work as a film, despite impressive perfs.
While Farrell, Chastain, and Morton flex their theatrical muscles in entertaining ways, a 129 minute runtime proves to be bloated, exhausting, and unnecessarily drawn out.
A film which aims to leave a bad taste in your mouth, for Miss Julie the question is whether that's a fatal flaw or an unrelenting examination of the ugly human heart.
Perhaps Karen Leigh Hopkins's intent was to subtly suggest the surreal aspects of the story, but ultimately she underplays her hand.
It exists somewhere between serious character study and satirical fish-out-of-water story, never figuring out which it wants to be.

Miss Meadows is an interesting character study of someone just trying to make the world a better place through murder, and questioning whether her methods may actually be the cause of the world's decay.
Tonally awkward and a bit too underwhelming to fully succeed as the black comedy cum violent thriller character study it is trying to be.
May we be excused, "Miss Meadows"?

Director-screenwriter Hopkins is unsuccessful in navigating the absurd storyline's jarring tonal shifts, with the result that this kinder, gentler variation on Ms. 45 mainly emerges as off-puttingly bizarre.
The earnestness brings the movie from mildly irritating pastiche status to actively awful, and that is all she wrote.
Katie Holmes is on target, but this tone-deaf film misses the mark.
It's so relentlessly upbeat and deliberately artificial that it admits no cynicism or judgment, and it makes the film daringly weird.
It's a shame the odd-for-oddball's sake of a plot had to overshadow Holmes' charming performance, for this could've been the role that kicked her relatively safe career into gear.
Hopkins fails to fulfill the potential of her own script.
Dainty and dark, and Katie Holmes, lest we forget, can play both.

As an ostensible work of satire, it lacks bite, never truly questioning or complicating its heroine's actions; the film isn't even outrageous enough to be appalling (which paradoxically makes it appalling).
Middling "Miss Meadows" blends black comedy, character study and thriller elements into a mixture that doesn't quite gel, though it's watchable enough.

Sinister sitcomish Katie Holmes does Uzi And Harriet. Suggesting a daffy while disturbing schizoid mix in this culture - at ease with exporting a blend of Hollywood and war, and a system increasingly in bed with death squads and self-righteous torture.
... struggles to find a consistent tone, and doesn't offer sufficient context to give emotional resonance to a female-empowerment fantasy that ultimately feels too detached from reality.
Despite an eccentric streak (which turns erratic), the script doesn't allow much room for the premise to take flight.
Isn't a terribly convincing movie, but it does feature a refreshingly twisted turn from star Katie Holmes.
An uneven mix of exploitation, satire and misguided social commentary.
It takes a committed performance to make a character like Miss Meadows fly, and Katie Holmes goes all in.
Mission: Impossible doesn't give bread, but offers a good circus. [Full review in Spanish]
Despite the shortcomings of the plot, 'Rogue Nation' is a summer blockbuster that delivers the popcorn movie goods.
Whether a follower of the series from the start, or just hopping aboard, it's hard not to get a kick out of Rogue Nation.
Could there be a more surprisingly pleasing spy franchise than this action adventure series? It doesn't allow James Bond or Jason Bourne to take all the accolades.

...audiences will have the pleasure of being swept away by the actor's unbridled charm sparring with Ferguson's upstart attitude in a flawless duet of deceit and determination. All is fair in love and espionage.
Jokey, derivative, the weakest of the MI movies, but still fun in most of the usual ways.

This M:I is entertaining in its schematic way; it's impossible not to respond to the theme music on a Pavlovian level. There's a sentimental attachment. But like Tom in that almighty opening plane stunt, I'm finding it harder and harder to hang on.
For about 90 minutes or so, Rogue Nation is grandly exciting. But in the final half-hour, McQuarrie makes a critical mistake: He starts taking this enjoyable nonsense seriously.
So many ridiculous action set pieces and unfollowable plot lines that it's basically a blockbuster splatter painting.

Rogue Nation is terrific fun, the best action movie of the summer without Mad Max in the title. It's also, arguably, the best Mission: Impossible movie, impressive for the fifth installment in any movie series.
Great summer movie entertainment.
Rogue Nation is everything we've come to expect from a Mission: Impossible movie: A plot with an above average intelligence wrapped around big stunt sequences.

You sure get your bang for the buck with this one. Tom Cruise, and his team deliver an action packed espionage thriller that's so eye popping you hardly notice you have no idea of why they're really doing all that stuff.
A precision-tooled action gizmo made by talented people who still take professional pride in turning this sort of thing out.
"Rogue Nation" is pretty much like most of the "Impossible" movies in that it's an immense machine that Mr. McQuarrie, after tinkering and oiling, has cranked up again and set humming ...
Once again, Cruise accepts this mission with open arms and audiences everywhere should follow suit.

The story is clear. The characters are appropriately hyper-real, but grounded and their behavior follows logically. There are mysteries that keep unraveling. And it doesn't choke you with details that can't be deciphered without 27 watchings.
Mission: Impossible - Rogue Nation has some of the best-shot action sequences of the year - a cinematic thrill ride in the best possible sense.
Rogue Nation's opening scene is as thrilling as anything we've seen from those "Furious" films. And your brain won't hurt minutes later.
...pure, relentless action. It's fun without being dumb, full of punches and kicks and explosions that never wear out their welcome. [Full review in Spanish]
A hollow concept gussied up with a few big names, a pretty set and some fancy clothes.
A potboiler in the quick-and-dirty tradition of the B movies of the '30s, it may not win any Oscars or garner rave reviews, but it's consistently entertaining, nevertheless.
The problem is in the script, which is so complicated and violent that the credibility of the entire enterprise is undermined.
The seemingly can't-miss premise of teen-heartthrob gangsters gets lost in self-important direction, a shoddy script and muddled storytelling.
It's an excuse for the latest crop of media-spawned personalities -- the male equivalent of starlets -- to invade the heavy-duty genre of the gangster film. They don't come up to Cagney's spats.

In an attempt to find the origins of infamous gangsters Charlie "Lucky" Luciano, Meyer Lansky, Frank Costello and Benny "Bugsy" Siegel, Karbelnikoff has rendered lame caricatures instead of meaty characters.
Although things like character development are sometimes lost in the crossfire, the lead actors have enough charm to sustain the film.
It feels like a history lesson from a particularly inept substitute teacher, hitting only a few highlights before it returns to a flat read of gangster specifics.

To say that production designer Richard Sylbert, costume designer Ellen Mirojnick and cinematographer Lajos Koltai give the settings a handsome, authentic look is like saying that the Titanic had nice chandeliers.
It's like Young Guns with mobsters ... only stupider.

The whole movie seems to be about hair, slicked-back hair, hair so meticulously coifed and lacquered that bullets would bounce off of it. Your first thought is that the budget for mousse must have climbed into the zillions.
Despite competent production, despite-or perhaps because of-a high and inventively mutilated body count, the film is ultimately boring.

Mobsters is a bloody little fairy tale that makes good guys out of Lucky Luciano, Frank Costello, Bugsy Siegel and Meyer Lansky. According to the film, a largely plodding affair, they were just four kids who liked to kill people once in a while.
There isn't a moment when you simply sit back and share in an actor's joy at revealing himself through his role.
High concept, sleek stylishness, low content.
It is extraordinary that, with gangster-era America providing such a natural source of drama, director Michael Karbelnikoff should turn gritty reality into such an empty tale.
Cool guys mob flick
None of these boys looks particularly grown up in their trench coats and fedoras and they shouldn't be playing with guns.
For all its machine-gun hits, Mobsters seems to have run out of energy soon after casting.
A noisy, silly, rather immature film.
A film of vitality, with imagery as haunting and romantic as it is intense.
...devoid of emotional resonance, despite a full-bodied performance by Andy Garcia.
Modigliani is slow, shamefully cliched and disjointed as a cubist portrait.
Thanks to writer-director Mick Davis, the film, like its subject, dies young.
It's hard to take this oddball movie seriously, right down to the undisguised streetwise-American accent of Andy Garcia as the Italian Jew Amedeo Modigliani.
Instead of trying to provide insight into this genius's debilitating madness, Davis prefers to wallow in incoherent and clichd misery, punctuated by poetically oblique imagery.
It ain't pretty but you have a choisa: See Modigliani or rent Derek Jarman's Caravaggio instead.
Mick Davis' prosaic art biopic Modigliani is a tiresome, hammy and ultimately annoying portrait of the artist as a young drunk.
Despite some nice shots of scenes converting into well-known art, Modigliani is plainly, badly directed.
Both Modi and Jeanne are genuinely tragic figures. But the movie so trivializes them as adolescents, lacking control of their own emotions, that their tragedy never takes hold.
No one expected a documentary, but serious art-history students may feel let down.
It is a tidy stack of snapshots, unencumbered by a point of view.
Failing to invest famous characters with the depth to break free of a made-for-TV feel, earnest misfire does make one want to read up on the real Modigliani.
Director Mick Davis shows little if any imagination in presenting the troubled genius or the remarkable Montparnasse art scene of the World War I era, and that's the real bummer.
Just another artistic sacrifice to life's ironies, cruelties, and bad filmmakers.
A third of it is an episodically disordered string of scenes that coalesce into a narrative. The remaining two thirds is melodrama.
A fantastic reminder that the only thing worse than a bad movie is a bad, pretentious movie.
Modigliani's problems lie in its contentment with superficial clichs

Modigliani may have been noted for his drunken volatility and arrogance, but once you get a dozen years or so of Behind the Musics and E! True Hollywood Stories behind you, it's hard to get worked up about that sort of thing anymore.
The real-life Modigliani did indeed live a short, tragic life, but this factually inaccurate, plodding film makes it feel twice as long.
If the concept of a moms' night out is premised on the notion that mothers can never get away for fear their families will collapse in their absence, then this movie cruelly confirms that fear.
One of those films you can't really hate on because it does try very hard to be likable.
Ugly sexism in what's trying to be a harmless feature, pandering to the female audience with a mean-spirited attitude toward men and their habitual boobery.
A frenetic but none too original comedy with a vaguely religious theme and a cast of mostly TV names.
A beautiful, touching, truthful idea that deserves so much better than this generally obnoxious, unfunny movie.
What ensues is frenetic and never as funny as it should be because directing brothers Andrew and Jon Erwin are not skilled enough at pacing the action and varying the volume.
Needed more Patricia Heaton, More Trace Adkins, more mayhem and more laughs
Outrageously enough, the moral of Moms' Night Out seems to be that moms should never get a night out.
Moms' Night Out seems, despite the technology, curiously dated and a leap backwards for moms.

They aren't caricatures, per se, but in the behavior-reinforcing fashion of simple sitcom, we see an unflattering portrait of brittle, hostile, hustling, neurotic modern suburban control freaks. Who ought to listen to their man, and the Father.
It's wacky fun rather than raunchy and its PG rating makes Moms' Night Out pretty safe for all audiences.
A shrill feature-length sitcom for the faith-based family values crowd, if nowhere near as good as that sounds.
Basically, the moral of the story is: Don't go out. Because if you do, all hell will break loose - or rather, all heck.
A very funny movie with an exceptionally likeable cast and a warm-hearted, surprisingly touching tribute to moms and their families.
Moms' Night Out is the kind of movie you can take your mother to without worrying that she'll get offended, and you can still have a good time with it.
Being a mom is hard work. Having to sit through "Moms' Night Out" is even harder.
Very much intended as a celebration of motherhood.

The Christian agenda here is far more welcoming and less assaultive than previous attempts of its kind. As a movie, Mom's Night Out has more practical problems than the gentle sermon buried between the lines.
It's rare that a movie fails on absolutely every level, but "Moms' Night Out" is a remarkably vivid example.
Moms' Night Out looks back nostalgically to a time when both gender roles and women's vaginas remained effortlessly tight.
Fans of Nicolas Philibert's immaculate chronicle of the learning curve, √ätre et Avoir, are sure to appreciate the warm lessons of this award-winning Canadian film.

Notions of class, cultural, ideological and emotional violence - or perhaps a little of each - take on vastly difference meanings in this sensitively woven French Canadian journey through Algerian exile, student angst and outsider alienation

Fellag, a comedian and himself an exile from Algeria, makes Lazhar both a sensitive and an amusing figure. And the kids are just terrific, especially Emilien Neron as a boy who carries the guilt of the whole school on his shoulders.

There's great potential for the kind of issues that are taken on, but nothing is resolved, and the biggest questions, of guilt and shame, the gulf of understanding between the first world and the third, remain unengaged.
This is a good movie about teaching, but more importantly, a good movie about the loss of a loved one and how to cope with death.
What makes the film enthralling is the wisdom and grace with which it addresses the twin subjects of grief and healing, and the quiet beauty of Mohamed Fellag's performance in the title role.
It's a subtle meditation on catharsis, and a gentle indictment of over-regulated education...
Sensitive, imbued with melancholy
"Monsieur Lazhar" is good. Really good.
Impressively directed and superbly written, this is an emotionally engaging, deservedly Oscar-nominated drama with a terrific central performance from Mohamed Sa√Ød Fellag.
The film leaves you hopeful, and even exhilarated, that even the most painful wounds can sometimes heal.
The movie's tonic lack of sentimentality binds the various griefs together into something moving.
Should appeal widely to arthouse audiences and lovers of smart, international cinema.
One of the most touching films of the year. A brilliant tragedy that transcends boundaries of age, country, race, religion and gender.
Works awfully well, managing to be sweet and distinctly easy without feeling the need to talk down to the viewer at the same time.

An exquisite, humanistic and subtly topical work of cinema art that manages to keep the intimate, revelatory sensibility of a one-man play intact while fleshing out the characters and creating a very realistic and richly detailed school community.

[Philippe] Falardeau's unobtrusive direction, and the restrained performance of Fellag and the child actors, make this a powerful, unsentimental film that doesn't make you feel like you're hearing a lecture.

Falardeau's adaptation of fellow Qu√©b√©cois Evelyne de la Cheneli√®re's play honours the power of the written word (a motif reinforced throughout the film), and expands on its stage origins via remarkably-assured cinematic touches.
Monsieur Lazhar never pretends to be anything but a grown-up fable, and it's a captivating one.

... the perfect school drama for people who hate the Hollywood version of the genre, but are open to simple and moving stories about people doing the best they can in a world that doesn't always seem to encourage that approach.
The film seems so freshly ripped from today's headlines that it feels like there's still more of the story to be told, which in a sense, there is.
A well-acted film,Reinaldo Marcus Green is able to set apart Monsters and Men from other films with similar material.
Despite its ambitions, "Monsters and Men" makes its weighty subject matter feels thin and slight.
Green hammers the audience with his message, instead of letting us find it ourselves. Nevertheless, this is a watchable and relevant film.
This is a hugely impressive calling card from [writer and director Reinaldo Marcus] Green, and one that deserves to be seen by as many people as possible.

'Monsters and Men' will go down as a Black Lives Matter film that upended the format and presented us with a direct mirror as to what black and brown folks feel during this pivotal and crucial time in our society.

Its innate intelligence and matter-of-fact sensitivity are the kinds of storytelling assets we need more of, especially when the fabric of life for many continues to fray and tear in ways that demand a larger societal reassessing.
It's not simply about doing the right thing from one point of view. It's in realizing that, for each of the men, the right thing is different.
While some perspectives were more valuable than others, seeing the viewpoints of tragedy from people who are typically undervalued is a gift. And we shouldn't ignore it.
Writer-director Green creates superb characters with complex internal lives.
It sets itself apart, though, by not dramatizing the issues themselves but rather focusing on the individual fallouts felt by those in the afflicted demographic.

Despite its many loose ends and overblown title, Monsters and Men is a memorable first film that has an air of having wafted in from the streets. Infused with tenderness and humanity, Green's film ultimately encourages empathy and understanding.
Monsters And Men will convert no one, because it's hard to care about anyone in the frame.

John David Washington is at his forceful best in this racially-charged drama from debuting filmmaker Reinaldo Marcus Green that uses the perspective of three persons of color to examine the shooting of an unarmed black man by a white cop,
Well acted and compassionate.
The plot evolves through the three stories but despite the subject it focuses less on outrage and more on the moral aspects of doing the right thing. I loved it.
A smart and refreshing look at the race, masculinity and police brutality in 2018 - do the right thing and see this film.
Too insipid to justify its creative choices, it feels likes a victim of its own civility.
Seems to be quite deliberately attempting not to enflame but inform.
... Monsters and Men gestures to the vast scope of what's really being spoken about here, and yet still maintains its arresting immediacy, its particular beauty.
The film's segments move seamlessly from one topic to the next with the unselfconscious ease of a good dinner party.
Weber's expertise, tenderness, and taste for the absurd become clear.
Mr. Wechsler's film might be loose to a fault, but Mr. Weber's work yields its share of gratifying, blink-and-you'll-miss-it New York moments.
Well-balanced, witty and illuminating. A must-see for anyone who's even remotely interested in photography
Lacks focus, and doesn't even recognize its own best material.
Morgan is frustrating because it does exhibit some early promise.
An initially intriguing but ultimately flimsy sci-fi action thriller.
Even though it has an amazing production, this film could have been a lot more. [Full review in Spanish]
The film, directed by Luke Scott and laden with high-tech eye candy, should have been a lot more complex and psychologically interesting than it is.
The result is a mediocre showdown with a guessable twist.
Before the midway point, it is pretty obvious what the eventual outcome and supposed big reveal will be.
There's something nostalgic about Morgan, not in its technology or direction, both of which are aggressively modern, but in its structure.
It would be a stretch to call the movie any kind of feminist statement, but it does boast an equal-opportunity nastiness alongside its enjoyable stupidities.

A high-minded film that wants us all to ponder what it means to be human. Alas, the most ponder-worthy thing in this film is wondering how Kate Mara managed to do all that running through the piney woods in those very high heels.
As yet another riff on Frankenstein and those overreaching scientists who want to play God, Morgan offers dread, androgyny, gore and violence but no magic.
"Morgan" ... is creepy, and sometimes pretty smart. And sometimes not.
Its cinematics are sleek, performances are solid, and the narrative is mind-numbingly simple. Yet the filmmakers infuriatingly manage to mess it up at almost every turn.
Morgan had the chance to do something interesting with its sound building blocks but instead settled for punch-ups and trite hijinx.
A base, sleepy exercise in horror that doesn't deserve its cast or an audience.
It engages but falls a good deal short of Ex Machina's fierce intelligence... [However,] the performances are robust.
Scott's pacing, building an early foundation of uneasiness, starts to collapse as the script resorts to illogical actions in service of the plot.
Alex Garland's 2015 cult hit Ex Machina, with Alicia Vikander as the robo-girl, trod similar ground; it proved more intellectually ambitious, though Morgan is a dash more fun.

Morgan is not as boundary-pushing as it could have been -- it's nowhere near as original as last year's Ex Machina, which explored similar themes but felt completely fresh in a way that Morgan doesn't.
There are few cinematic pleasures greater than the smart, well-executed B movie. Count Morgan among them.
Terrific and highly entertaining. Its a smart, aggressive thriller. Luke Scott has arrived.
The impressiveness of skill is lost in the technical production.
In the realm of movies adapted from video games, "Mortal Kombat" sucks the least...
It's a movie rife with mullets, gratuitous gymnastics, screamed lines, and terrible CGI. But it all just contributes to the charm.
...a one-note gimmick that comes with everything but a joystick for the viewer to control the robotic characters.
Far too predictable to recommend to anyone not predisposed to this type of propulsive but vacant entertainment.
If the forces of darkness win ten mortal kombats in a row, the world will be subjugated to a tyrrany of evil and bad spelling
cheesy but still, kick ass

British director Anderson does a fair job with what he was given: four good-looking leads, some very impressive sfx, Babylonian sets, a bone-crunching soundtrack, and a battery of well-choreographed fights.
Offers a visceral jolt of pleasure for those who formerly believed the martial arts movie genre belongs exclusively to Hong Kong's John Woo.
It's silly, of course, but more importantly, it's a hell of a lot of fun, with plenty of above-average gags.
Anderson does a good job of edging humour into dumbness - Lambert gets a few witty looks - and the art direction and effects are okay.
Just looks and plays a lot like Johnny Mnemonic, Double Dragon and other video-game-inspired, mayhem-filled messes.
Like watching a lot of sweaty fist fights while trapped in the world's loudest night club.
The only decent video game turned into a movie. Why? Obviously because the filmmakers have really tried to offer some eye-popping visuals that can provide the same stimuli as the video game itself.
We'll concede that four-armed Prince Goro is a hoot, Christopher Lambert looks fabulous in a flowing white wig, and Talisa Soto, who plays some kind of princess, can lord it over us anytime.
The characters are cardboard, the humor is lame and the heroes are all so unlikable most of the way that the audience won't be able - or want - to identify with them.
This is a Mortal Kombat movie made for Mortal Kombat fans.
Hardly award-worthy entertainment, and pretty visually dated, but probably one of the better video game movies ever made comparatively.
Likely to satisfy only the core audience already hooked on video and arcade games, and even that's not a sure thing.
What it's missing, ironically, is the edge that's made Mortal Kombat the video game such a powerful icon in American pop culture.

Does the film work? Not really. It loses itself in comic caricatures of the loonies that Campbell meets in New York; and its melodramatic double-reverses, by making the plot seem arbitrary, rob it of importance.
Wonderfully mysterious and emotionally draining.
A serious drama that is also funny without crossing into burlesque.
Helps us to see that there is no escaping the burdens of living in a political world.
Surprisingly good Vonnegut adaptation
Nick Nolte is excellent in Keith Gordon's ambitious but flawed adaptation of Vonnegut's fascinating novel.
Director Keith Gordon emphasizes the speeches more than other issues, and his otherwise thoughtful movie needlessly romanticizes hate.
Frankie Faison comes the closest to Vonnegut's spirit in his bold caricature of the Black Fuehrer of Harlem.
Mr. Deeds Goes to Town (1936) is another lighthearted classic Frank Capra screwball romantic-comedy regarding the broader philosophical themes of individual innocence
The tedium of Mr. Deeds Goes to Town outweighs its message of freedom and charity.
It's tough enough to film a credible morality play without being laughed out of town. It's altogether mind boggling to do so and provide a grade A romantic comedy to boot.
Essential Capra and one of his best. Cooper and Arthur are luminous.
A wonderful Capra vehicle; Cooper is superb; Arthur luminous. A comic movie with heart and a point to make. True Capra-corn, and that is not a criticism. A fine example of populist art.

Capra advocates populism and egalitarianism, underlined by values of Christianity. For him, every person is "God's creation" in his/her own right, evert person possesses some talent and should do his/her best with that gift.
Snappy lines, stellar performances, Capra classic.
Mr. Deeds is really a very intelligent and beautiful affair, a film no less charming than Mr. Capra's It Happened One Night at the same time that it is definitely more profound.
Playing the part as if born to it, Cooper is at the top of his game, imbuing Deeds with just the right blend of empathy and intelligence.

Frank Capra's Mr. Deeds Goes to Town features a pair of great performances from Gary Cooper and Jean Arthur, and a story that is partially compelling, but it's ultimately let down by an overlong runtime that the film isn't able to sustain.
Half an hour longer than the average picture, but, thanks to Frank Capra and Gary Cooper, seems at least half an hour shorter.
Mr. Deeds Goes to Town, with Gary Coooper as the rube with the heart of gold being sacrificed to the malicious media, is no less outstanding.
Nice satire, wittily underscored by Gary Cooper.
There has been a debunking tendency in Holmes films and fiction since Wilder... But Mr. Holmes plays a subtler, more affecting game while retaining a fondness for Doyle's characters and their depths.

What makes it progressively more moving is a complex, multi-layered script and the performance from Sir Ian, which is reminiscent of Victor Sjstrm in Ingmar Bergman's Wild Strawberries as another old man looking back on his life.

Despite a brilliant performance from Sir Ian McKellen, Mr. Holmes is a little too scattered in its plot to leave much of an impact, making you wish that there had been more focus on its intriguing mystery and less on the less satisfying parts of the tale.
It's a fairly compelling tale, but the intrigue we expect of a Holmes story is conspicuously lacking, even with three different mysteries unfurling onscreen.
McKellen is masterful, in a multilayered tale that navigates the no man's land between memory and fiction.
What a pleasure it is to be in the presence of Ian McKellen, who dominates the screen in Mr. Holmes.

Gentle and autumnal, 'Mr. Holmes' will undoubtedly strike younger viewers as overly decorous, but it's a perfect antidote to the loud, vulgar bastardizations of the character starring Robert Downey, Jr.
Sherlock Holmes may have never really walked the earth, but Mr. Holmes humanizes him to such a degree, you walk out of the theater practically convinced you've just watched a biopic.
Condon does a fine job stewarding the basic satisfaction to be had from this casting.

While the good detective himself hobbles about with a cane, "Mr. Holmes" the movie glides smoothly back and forth across decades and continents as it follows these disparate plot strands through to their eminently logical conclusions.

The story is an intricate puzzle though never even slightly difficult to follow. But in the end, it's a testament to the process of writing as a way of coming to terms with one's past, and a celebration of the redemptive power of fiction.
Sad, gentle and often very funny.
McKellen nurtures his character's changing nature with affection and grace.
Great performance in a thin mystery.
this is the kind of film that you should go into cold and let the beautiful and touching story unfold afresh.
An elegant puzzler that presents the sage of Baker Street dealing with the one thing he's never had to contend with before: his own emotions.
A charming but fatally slow exposition of yet another real Sherlock Holmes.
Mr Holmes isn't bad, but it's no thrill.
Just as they did on Gods and Monsters ... Condon and McKellen work hard at building a character that looks to have had a real life outside the confining frames of cinema.
A tender deconstruction of Holmes and of the process of crime solving.
It's a very personal project; [Crystal] not only stars, but co-wrote the screenplay and makes his directing debut. This is like an autobiography of how he might have turned out.
It's not wholly successful, but one can respect Crystal's intentions.
A good idea, but somehow unfocused. Crystal can't make up his mind if he wants you to love or hate his Buddy Young Jr.
Great performances, flawed script.
Maybe a guitly pleasure, but I really enjoy this movie.
One of the best, if not the best, film of Billy Crystal's career
Billy Crystall's feature directorial debut is a misfire: As an actor, he's too likable to play the egotistical comedian who torments everyone around him for the sake of his career.
in Mr. Saturday Night, Billy Crystal nimbly makes the big leap from amiable (if sometimes irritating) funny man to serious, but not-too-serious filmmaker.
terrific performances make it a must-see
How the story resolves itself is a bit unusual and not near as tidily wrapped up as we have come to expect from our films. More like real life.
Fine Judi Dench starring drama.

Centering on a lesser-known chapter in the reign of Queen Victoria, this richly detailed drama about her intimate relationship with her servant that scandalized the country is extremely well-acted; Judi Dench deserves an Oscar nomination
A highly resonant testament to the redemptive power of love--one that transcends traditional romantic definitions.
There is something missing in the film. It is flat.

The political nuances of Mrs. Brown may be obscure to most Americans, but you need no expertise in British history to appreciate Ms. Dench's honesty or Mr. Connolly's ferocity,or Anthony Sher's sly turn as the sharp-witted Disraeli.
Unfortunately, the performances are not enough to carry this film, which feels much longer than its 83 minutes running time.

Mrs. Brown' is a love story about two strong-willed people who find exhilaration in testing each other. It is not about sexual love, or even romantic love, really, but about that kind of love based on challenge and fascination.
Before you know it, you're caught up in a difficult but touching friendship, and enjoying a history lesson more than you ever thought possible.
Mrs. Brown is reserved yet spirited.

Despite a few passing similarities to "The Madness of King George" and "Carrington," "Mrs. Brown" succeeds bravely on its own terms, owing much to freshman scribe Jeremy Brock's outstanding blending of fact and speculation.
Assuming that rich human insight, great production values, and topnotch acting still count for something, Mrs. Brown should have no trouble finding an appreciative audience.
Explores the platonic friendship between the Queen of the British empire and a Scottish servant.
''Mrs. Brown'' transcends its period setting not only with a keenly observed struggle between love and duty but also with the kind of controversy that envelops the Queen and her servant.

Even as the historical and emotional incongruities threaten to derail the film, the acerbic and witty prose gives Mrs. Brown a humorous dimension that, at times, makes it feel like an English response to Ridicule.
If the movie crumbles under its own stiffness at times, at least it has the two old pros' good performances to cheer us along the way.
Judi Dench's glacial, reserved demeanour contrasts beautifully with Billy Connolly's natural, rebellious exuberance, and their resultant spark of chemistry is undeniable.
This discreet drama failed to get to me emotionally.
Helping things greatly is the film's talented cast, which not only includes stunning performances from the leads, but a scene-stealing turn by Sher as well.

An opportunity missed for an entertainment of more substance, but Frears keeps it light and Dench keeps it afloat for a charming and stylish, if essentially forgettable, excursion into British nostalgia.
Although Mrs. Henderson Presents takes a promising running start, only Dench manages to soar on 'show must go on' wings.
Frears' lazy directing and Sherman's meandering script insistently go for the safe, for the cozy, each and every time the film shows a glimmer of potential.
A charming piece that entertains without getting heavy, yet dares to make poignant statements when the moment is right.
...a wonderful tribute to the notion that you're never too old to shake things up a bit.

Mrs. Henderson Presents does present opportunities for Dench to point her nose in the air. But then the film loses track of her character to an extent and begins concentrating on others that are less interesting.

The film may be as slick as a snake-oil salesman, but you have to have a very hard heart indeed not to find it irresistible: It's funny, touching and crammed to the rafters with clever dialogue, splashy production numbers and stiff-upper-lip charm.
Dench keeps a lid on her performance, not pushing the comedy over the top, so that behavior that would seem cutely impish in another has the more appealing sparkle of subverted refinement.
Curious as to why Judi Dench has been nominated for 4 Oscars, 5 Golden Globes, 8 SAG Awards, and 20 BAFTAs? See this film and you'll understand why.
A sloppy vaudeville turn by those glorious troupers Judi Dench and Bob Hoskins in what amounts to a silly orgy of nostalgic patriotism and the titillating naughtiness of stationary nudity.
There isn't much going on in Mrs. Henderson Presents beyond the odd-couple routine, some gaudy musical numbers and artful nudity.
The always-reliable Stephen Frears, a master of symmetry and narrative coherence, has come up with another jewel.

Dench's Oscar-worthy performance is a delight. She turns Mrs. Henderson into a cross between the stereotypical little old lady and a hurricane. As Guest's character discovers, you've got to love her even as she's steamrolling you.
Stephen Frears seems constitutionally incapable of making an uninteresting movie.
No actress has been as purely delightful to watch all year as Dench is tromping her way through this effervescent comedy, which falters only during its inevitably somber final act.
A delightful confection with something more bubbling away under the surface in the way the film normalizes sex and sexuality in a refreshing manner.
Mrs. Henderson Presents begins with zippy animation but cuts immediately to a funeral, and that's exactly how you should expect the movie to go.
Although technically not a musical, Mrs. Henderson Presents is filled with musical numbers, some of them quite accomplished.
... perfectly pleasant and exceedingly predictable ...
Una comedia dramtica con iguales dosis de picarda y emotividad, sostenida en dos buenas actuaciones de Judi Dench y Bob Hoskins.
...a terrific homage to the elderly, told in a touching, sometimes humorous, but always sensitive, manner with terrific performances by Joan Plowright and a charismatic Rupert Friend.
It's an altogether satisfying drama -- the sort of movie some people complain they don't make anymore.
Not deep but much fun, it gives Plowright possibly her best role in the flickers.

critic_name: Cherryl Dawson and Leigh Ann Palone
content: It's funny, poignant, sweet, heartbreaking, and thoroughly entertaining. These are the kind of rich characters that make you want to pop round for a spot of tea.
...if it weren't for Plowright, things might fall quickly apart.
Despite the measured pace and the predictable bitter sweet mood, the film is only occasionally enchanting
Unfortunately, much of the story is thin ice beneath her feet. It threatens to buckle beneath sheer improbability.
Under the seamless direction of Dan Ireland, Mrs. Palfrey is enriched by the real-life parallel of watching a veteran actress in her 50th year of films.
[A] terrific, long-overdue vehicle for Lady Olivier.
It's funny," Ireland notes. "The intellectual critics always like to give me a smack about being too weepy. But then the audiences that go see it seem to embrace it, which has been great.
Too often confuses gooey sentimentality for legit compassion.
Harold and Maude as reinterpreted by Masterpiece Theatre.

Like a cup of strong British tea with a sugar cube tossed in, Dan Ireland's Mrs. Palfrey at the Claremont is at once sweet and bitter, a fairy-tale friendship in the context of an achingly lonely life.
Mrs. Palfrey at the Claremont is not a loud, fast-paced, over the top film, but one to be viewed with patience, anticipation and an open heart.
The glorious Joan Plowright is reason enough to pay to see any film, and Mrs. Palfrey at the Claremont is no exception.
Dame Joan Plowright endows Mrs. Palfrey with stoic charm and decency in this unabashedly sentimental film.
Ireland, who made the brilliant, equally unfashionable The Whole Wide World, respects the kindness and concern his characters show each other.
Dame Joan Plowright has been cast here in the most dominant and demanding role that she has ever undertaken in a 54-year career on stage, screen and television.

The story may sometimes overpower you with its honeysuckle sentiment and spiced bathos, but it's a movie that's self-aware enough to make winking references to such films as Harold and Maude and Brief Encounter.
[Mrs. Palfrey] is a stroll off the beaten path.
It's a private party, for Whedon fans only.
From its very first scenes, Mr. Whedon's film crackles with a busy, slightly wayward energy that recalls the classic romantic sparring of the studio era.
I actually got a lot more out of Whedon's Much Ado About Nothing than I did when my 9th grade English class went to see a production of the play.
This is an intimate and giddy romantic comedy with only a hint of seriousness, one that is as elegant as it is fun.
Even if thou dost not much care for Will Shakespeare's style, methinks The Bard himself would approve mightily of this paean to his comedic work, "Much Ado About Nothing".
Almost everyone seems at ease in this feather-light production which eschews the Bardolatry that accompanies more declamatory Shakespeare movie versions.
So, when can Whedon do the rest of the plays?
Joss Whedon's fresh and cheeky adaptation of "Much Ado About Nothing" is a minor miracle - the first filmed Shakespeare comedy in decades that's actually funny.
It's a pleasant, engaging version of probably the closest thing to a sitcom the Bard ever penned.
Whedon's work is fluid and fast-paced, with an obvious love for Shakespeare's intricate language - no surprise from a man famous for great dialogue.
The wine flows freely throughout the film, and likely, all through production too.
It will require no conspiring to make you fall for this one; Whedon and Shakespeare are a perfect match.
The film's biggest problem is that its Beatrice, played with spunk and spark by Amy Acker, is far more engaging and enchanting than its Benedick.
I enjoyed Whedon's film both as a species of stunt and also as a legitimately entertaining entry in the voluminous Shakespeare adaptation sweepstakes.
Anyone giving the benefit of the doubt to the man who created Buffy The Vampire Slayer won't be disappointed.
With its interrogations of gender, feminism, and marriage, Shakespeare's comedy is an apt vehicle for Whedon's own storytelling agenda.
This inept modern-day version of the classic Shakespearian comedy comes across as too contrived.
These kids know the words, but not the music.

The film isn't as fast and funny as it could be, although Nathan Fillion's easily offended constable injects some sorely needed comic relief. Still, give Whedon credit for trying to expose his Comic-Con fan base to a different kind of Hero.
[VIDEO ESSAY] Josh Whedon's sophomoric attempt at swimming in Kenneth Brannagh's waters of expertise - namely adapting Shakespeare plays to film - is akin to watching a wet cat lick itself dry.
It's not ironic, amusing or clever.
One of the most obnoxious horror pictures in recent years, a low-rent cinematic charade that goes beyond spoofery and into a realm of distasteful, tacky, IQ-shrinking tedium.
If they handed out awards for misogyny, "Muck" would win effortlessly. Most horror movies are a bit sexist. It comes with the territory. But, this is simply the undressing and mutilation of women.

The gonzo assault becomes an uneven straddle of Evil Dead camp and rote splatter, leaving Muck to hobble along disjointedly like Jamie Lee Curtis' battered heroine as she tries to escape Michael Myers in Halloween.
Muck isn't a horror movie - it's a wannabe skinflick that would ignore an on-screen kill if the actress' breasts were jiggling in the slightest. Because bewbz!
The plot is as scant and demeaning as the costumes...
Overall, do yourself a favor and avoid Muck.
Uneven, to put it mildly. But when it is funny, it is priceless.
Waters shoots the bravura blasphemy for shuddering passion and keeps upping the fervor
John Waters interweaves his critique of noxious domesticity into the characters at the core of Multiple Maniacs.
Waters's legendary second feature, made in 1970, is back to show popular culture what punk provocation really looks like.
For newbies, this is the ideal place to start. Just do your best to pretend you're seeing it somewhere that isn't directly adjacent to a Jamba Juice.
Is it some kind of lost masterpiece? No. It's merely an interesting milestone on the path to Mr. Waters's better-known works ...
Negligible budget and poor framing and crap in the film gate and shots that go in and out of focus and all, "Multiple Maniacs" is a helluva movie.
This being a film by John Waters no stunt is too outrageous and no idea is too grotesque, and whether you'll personally leave shocked or delighted is as always a case of your-milage-may-vary.
This genial, sometimes literally obscene mess is strictly recommended to hard-core John Waters fans.
For all its ostensible unpleasantness, Multiple Maniacs is cheapo, indie, queer American cinema at its most adversarial and thrillingly vicious.
Shot for $5,000, this '70s black-and-white curio was the "trainer wheels" for Waters' shockfest Pink Flamingos.
Only John Waters could stage a Charles Manson-style slaughter then think: "This could really do with a giant-lobster rape scene to spruce it up."

Multiple Maniacs' grimy cinematography, bonkers performances and showstopping turn from regular collaborator Divine make this indispensable viewing for aficionados of the strange, the surreal and the downright depraved.

"Multiple Maniacs" wallows in perversion for perversion's sake because that's what it's there for. You can fight the ideas, but you can't fight the feelings that John Waters puts out there because his respect for filth runs so deep.

Waters has a hard time figuring out where to point the camera in any given shot or how to keep his actors in focus, but he never loses sight, for even a moment, of his ultimate goal, which is to shock the world and crack himself up at the same time.
Multiple Maniacs is a subversive movie atrocity that cries out to be seen to be believed. Enjoy.
More than forty-five years after it made its bow on Baltimore's underground scene, this cult classic's trashy profanity retains its spark.
Waters, as always, doesn't fall short of his promise in this sleazy, tawdry, hilarious harpooning of manners and mores.
Ramis and his quartet of writers, including City Slickers shtick factories of Lowell Ganz & Babaloo Mandel, can't find much to do with their simple premise.
A buoyant domestic farce.
Starts out with a great premise, but fails to deliver on its promise.
Groundhog Day had a certain sweetness and even a sly philosophical depth, but Multiplicity is more of a ground-level comedy, in which we can usually anticipate the problems for Doug and his clones.
Michael Keaton is very funny, but the comedy itself isn't worth his efforts.
True to its title, Multiplicity keeps multiplying the fun and compounding the pandemonium.
Multiplicity exists because it's now possible for an actor to appear on screen with himself and not by means of anything so quaint as double exposure.
More is not better, in this case.
If ever there was a movie that showed off an actor's versatility, this is it.
A desperately unfunny comedy lethargically directed by Harold Ramis, and boringly acted by Michael Keaton.
Great premise, great work by Keaton, but the script lets them down.
The comedy itself, however, is uneven and, more often than not, obvious.
Multiplicity is more concerned with its special effects of multiple characters than any satisfying conclusion to its provocative premise.
Both assuredly funny without being forced, and smart without being smug, this is one comedy that deserves to go forth and, indeed, multiply.
A showcase tailor-made for Keaton and his maniacally comedic persona(e).
Multiplicity, while far from a great comedy, did provide this critic with a lot of laughs and made for a thoroughly enjoyable time at the movies.
Multiplicity cheats itself by not letting its imagination run as wild as its star.
Largely due to Keaton, the movie is consistently funny.
Some sexy stuff in dated, but entertaining '80s comedy.
Simply a laugh-out-loud comedy about clones running around, and the mayhem which ensues.

Jolson sang, Barrymore spoke, Garbo laughed, and now Kermit the Frog rides a bicycle... If you can figure out how they were able to show Kermit pedaling across the screen, then you are less a romantic than I am: I prefer to believe he did it himself.

Jim Henson, Muppet originator, and Frank Oz, creative consultant, have abandoned the successful format of their vidshow, and inserted their creations into a well-crafted combo of musical comedy and fantasy adventure.
Great tunes, funny cameos, snarky puppet freaks ... what's not to love?
Slapstick chases and weak movie references look tired, while the attitude towards Miss Piggy and Camilla the Chicken is, well, less than progressive.
One of the funniest family films of the 1970s.

What in the world can you say about this? The purest, funniest and most endearing Muppet flick--it's simply the pinnacle of extant evidence we have to the genius of Henson and those he surrounded himself with. Highly recommended.
They make a lot of road-trip movies now, but I still like this one the best.
Not only was The Muppet Movie a great children's movie in 1979, one that viewers of all ages could enjoy, but it's still a great children's movie today.
The Muppets were formally inventive long before Charlie Kaufman came on the scene.
genius!
The cast are all here, along with the technical wizardry, but the dialogue staggers from one leaden gag to another and there is an unmistakeable note of desperation throughout.
A great movie to watch when you want to feel like a kid again, which is why it is such a cult favorite.
The Best Muppet movie ever made...well, almost.
As expected, Fozzie the Bear and the old geezers Statler and Waldorf receive the lion's share of the choice lines.
There's all of these cameos that are so fun.
A good-sized dose of likeable Muppet fun.
Click to read the article.
There's always room in movies for unbridled amiability when it's governed by intelligence and wit.
First Muppet movie is a classic.
This isn't about one sock puppet's search to be all that he can be. It's about a community combining their talents to bring joy to the world.
Limited, but inspiring portrait of a true American hero.
"Murph: The Protector" reminds us of the valor expended on distant front lines and the holes left at home.
A moving chronicle of some of the traits that should be more widely venerated in a media and pop cultural landscape too driven by the elevation of the trivial.
By celebrating an actual American hero, "Murph" reminds audiences that bells and whistles, budgets and effects aren't necessary so long as filmmakers have human stories of bravery and valor to tell.
One wonders if the filmmakers ever asked themselves who their film was intended for, or if it was at least a consciously self-serving effort from the outset.
A poignant and inspirational tribute to Lieutenant Michael Patrick Murphy.
A one-note hagiography, no matter how convincing and affecting its portrait of unimpeachable courage.

... a documentary with the limited but entirely honorable mission of commemorating the life and sacrifice of Navy Lt. Michael P. Murphy, a Navy SEAL who died in a firefight in the mountains of eastern Afghanistan in June 2005.
The story of Lt. Michael P. Murphy's life doesn't need to be hyped, and Murph: The Protector does a good job of staying out of its way.
Supremely enjoyable, Muscle Shoals doesn't add much to the record, but it will probably induce you to flip through your collection for a few to spin.
Camalier doesn't offer any theories as to why Muscle Shoals happened, his film nicely sketches what did happen, and why it mattered.
Do not leave the film until the last credit rolls by.
Emotionally moving but messy, it survives thanks to its superb songs, great cinematography and insightful anecdotes - in spite of its lack of a satisfactory conclusion.
Has funky magic in it. Ooh, baby, does it ever.
Even fans who don't know Muscle Shoals by name know its music by heart. Now they can also see how much soul went into it.
The director wisely doesn't turn this into cavalcade of stars, keeping the focus as much on the man who built this hotbed of creativity and the musicians who played behind the household names.
It all makes for a pretty glossy package and a treasure trove for music geeks, but there's a human angle to this story that will appeal to just about everyone.
As the documentary demonstrates, knowing it when you hear it is one thing, but trying to explain the origin of the Muscle Shoals sound and its qualities is like dancing about architecture.
Even if the Muscle Shoals sound isn't on your iPod, you'll like seeing where it came from
A mesmerizing documentary ...
The film mixes an impressive array of interviews with plentiful archival footage.

Featuring interviews with R&B and rock royalty while exploring the uniquely American sound that crossed racial boundaries, Muscle Shoals is oddly paced and tone-deaf to its own message at times, but still important viewing.

..Muscle Shoals and its presentation doesn't reinvent the wheel...the treasure trove of stills and found footage makes for a compelling and effortlessly watchable film that even the casual music fan should find themselves totally engrossed in.
A well made, endlessly fascinating and impeccably researched documentary that tells a riveting story and is packed with great characters, terrific anecdotes and fabulous music.
The movie doesn't mention the contemporary Christian or gospel albums recorded at his studio. But what's there is so uplifting it's still well worth your time.
A stubborn charmer whose life was a magnet for tragedy, Hall is the emotional centre not only of the Muscle Shoals sound but of this film.
It is hands down one of the best music documentaries ever made.
[A] charming, reverently shot ramble.
Two new docs on American culture merit attention
Visually striking but dramatically confusing animated feature from Korea.
Softly sensuous from afar, but rather flighty on closer acquaintance, My Beautiful Girl, Mari is an extremely oblique animated feature that may, in fact, be about very little at all.
While familial subplots, schoolyard showdowns and a climactic sea storm feel somewhat detached from the narrative, the deep sense of longing that underlies this sweet-natured tale rings true.
Lee Sung-gang's exquisite tale of childhood remembrance and imagination is... a patient fantasy painted in swaths of color...
This is a funny movie, with just enough edge to keep you off-balance.
My Blind Brother is slight and a little easy, but it's powered by sincere affection.
A faintly edgy if feather-weight rom-com built on guilt, pity and the self-absorbed disabled.
Though My Blind Brother clearly isn't aiming for the feel-good realm, the emotions never ring true enough to make any of the purposely flawed leads relatable, never mind likable.

Writer-director Sophie Goodhart, who based the film on her 2003 Palme d'Or-nominated short, has crafted three cleverly flawed and dimensional lead characters, all vividly brought to life by their astute players.
A dark comedy with too warm of a heart to be as ruthless as it should be, especially since the cast is so good at playing nasty elsewhere.
Sophie Goodhart's My Blind Brother has clear eyes on full hearts.

My Blind Brother explores this unconventional dynamic with gentle humor and a refreshing amount of sensitivity, brushing up against the more cringe-worthy aspects of its premise without reveling in them.
The politically incorrect jokes, while often funny, wear a bit thin as director Sophie Goodhart lays them on with naughty glee.
Goodhart's brilliant cast elevates some very breezy material into something that will resonate with siblings of all sorts and sightedness, and even the minor characters leave a mark.
My Blind Brother works better as an exploration of toxic narcissism than a laugh-generating device.
Frequently hilarious farce, and it winds up having just enough real emotion to keep it grounded.
So fitting that a movie with such a large and benevolent heart comes from a writer and director of the same name.
