First-time director Sophie Goodhart coaxes a grown-up performance out of Kroll, and Scott's smarmy contentiousness has never been put to better use.
There's just something missing at the heart of My Blind Brother. It never coheres as intended on every comedic and dramatic level it aims for.
Nick Kroll and Jenny Slate nail the nobility of resentment in this winningly featherweight romantic comedy.
These are intriguingly damaged individuals who are nonetheless shortly put through the motions of a rather forgettable love-triangle comedy.
A thoroughly harmless comedy that spaces its one-liners a bit widely. It's made watchable by an appealing cast ...
... breaks down taboos with sardonic wit and surprising tenderness, and the result is both mischievous and heartfelt in its examination of sibling rivalry.
My Blind Brother puts these characters through the comic wringer, but the humor is founded on the characters and their flaws, not the circumstances.
An utterly pointless and unimaginative remake based on the classic '60s sitcom...a meteoric misfire
It is a movie that contains laughs, but they are more of the embarrassing type than ones created by humorous situations.
Only the total collapse of Hollywood can save us from a reprise of My Mother the Car.
There isn't enough nostalgia for the old series to recommend for any beyond the most juvenile mind-set.
Dire.
A terrible movie -- beware.
What we have here is a highly agreeable cast goofing around within the familiar parameters of the alien-lost-on-Earth story, to absolutely no purpose except killing time.
This is filmmaking not for children, but for idiots of all ages.
My Favorite Martian represents the very worst in mainstream American cinema.
a light-hearted silly movie aimed at showing kids a good time. Disney makes no serious attempts to keep this film reasonable from an adult perspective.
Travel from Mars to Earth is an amazing feat, but not much more remarkable than reviving a sitcom that had been dead for a third of a century.
a spiffy-looking but empty-headed update
The movie is clever in its visuals, labored in its audios, and noisy enough to entertain kids up a certain age. What age? Low double digits, I'd say.
Everything else in the film, which was directed by Donald Petrie, is either cute or irritating.
Doesn't even have the little spark of life that actors with a certain measure of lunacy and chemistry can deliver.
This is entertainment of the lightest, most inconsequential sort.
Almost entirely predicated on low-brow misfires and the thinnest of story precepts.
Walston displays a crisp wit and blithe sense of whimsy otherwise lacking in this loser.
It's not a pretty sight.
A clever and well-written screenplay is what saved this thing from being just like any other failure in the remake experiment.
Scene after scene suddenly rings with a resounding falseness [in the second half].
The actors earn the couple of salty drops you may shed at the end -- the script sure doesn't.
Lahti has undermined her stars and delivered dreck.
It will have you smiling so much, that you may not even notice how close it comes to sliding into mediocrity.
Harold & Maude it ain't.
The plot ducks the obvious sexual pitfall that would make us squirm, but falls into another one: morbid uplift, out at the golden pond where dreams may come and you can sweetly pay it forward.
Franklin's gooey, implausible script is too ridiculous to support unexpected bouts of sincerity, and the darkness is seldom as profound as it should be.
While the movie loads on too much sap in the final third, it is still a funny and moving first-time effort.
These two characters are so particular and sympathetic that the whole movie could simply observe them.
the film abandons Randall's store completely to more effectively segue from an unsuccessful comedy into an equally unsuccessful tearjerker
Though I wanted to hate My First Mister and felt guilty about those telltale tears mopped up with a shirt sleeve, the darn thing did work.
60 minutes into My First Mister, I was thoroughly engrossed. A half-hour later, I desperately wanted the whole mess to end.
Despite the sloppy final act, My First Mister is worth seeing for Brooks and Sobieski's performances.
A human-scale comedy that reaches across generations to tickle, connect and embrace.
A good small movie featuring a different kind of love story..
A small movie full of good intentions and wildly erratic execution.
When a movie starts out as trenchant as "Ghost World" then turns into something as mawkish as "Steel Magnolias," it's been botched, plain and simple.
Brooks' work in actress Christine Lahti's directing debut ... is the finest acting he's done since Broadcast News.
Offers the curious experience of being able to believe in a screen full of first-rate actors yet not believe in anything that's happening to the people they're playing.
Distinguished actress Christine Lahti's feature directorial debut...suffers from a touch too much structure and a script that pedals a tad too hard on sentimentality.
A fascinating documentary.
Maddening and more than a little thought-provoking.
Amir Bar-Lev's documentary is fascinating on all kinds of levels: as a movie about the nature of art, the lure and pitfalls of celebrity, and the complicated conundrums of parenting.
A probing film not only about the subjective nature of art but also about the hypocrisy of the intelligentsia, the pervasiveness of modern media, and the sincerity of parents.
Mais interessante do que a provvel fraude envolvendo a encantadora Marla  a reveladora sombra que o documentrio projeta sobre o universo da arte moderna.

Documentarian Amir Bar-Lev began making a film about whether Modern art is a scam and whether a 4-year-old painter from Binghampton, N.Y., might not be as good as Picasso. But Bar-Lev ended making a film instead about whether the 4-year-old is a scam.

... the storytelling is a little crude, the filming equally so, and in the end, audiences may feel that those who were prepared to pay thousands of dollars for one of Marla's paintings must be philosophical: if they love the work, the money is justified.
As cunning as a double-sided Kandinsky but ultimately as shallow as a few layers of oil.
That Bar-Lev takes such care to depict them as complex, foible-laden individuals who can't be pegged either good or bad is one of the great strengths of this intriguing and provocative documentary.
More than a standard child prodigy profile, My Kid Could Paint That turns into a priceless examination of modern art, celebrity and what it means to be a kid.
A fascinating film which touches on a captivating range of subjects.
Bar-Lev proves to be a remarkably sensitive filmmaker, one who asks questions with fairness and insight and who is constantly asking himself what effect he's having on the story.
Marla's story is a sobering illustration of the way children can be exploited by adults who should know better %u2013 journalists, filmmakers and especially their own parents.
Like the best of the new wave of American documentaries, it becomes about far more than the human-interest angle at the center of the story...

[A] mysterious, gripping meta-documentary, a movie that reflects upon the thorny, unpredictable process of capturing a real-life story on film at the same time it's trying to figure out what the story is.
A highly engaging documentary that recounts a remarkable tale.

The self-reflexive narrative is particularly fascinating because Marla's story is so critical to selling her art; everyone involved, the filmmaker included, has a vested interest in proving it genuine or fake.

Questions of authenticity surrounding four year old Marla Olmstead's paintings occasion filmmaker Amir Bar-Lev's insightful investigation about media frenzy and public perception, and the very nature of nonfigurative art.
A fascinating exploration of art, creativity, and family dynamics that takes an unexpected right hook.
The open-endedness of the film makes for a rather unsatisfying non-conclusion to the story ... but like the best documentaries, it leaves you asking questions without trying to answer them for you.
My Life as a Dog succeeds on an intimate, human scale that is entirely appropriate for a story covering about a year in the life of a pretty ordinary boy in a pretty ordinary place.
A lot of the movie is routine coming-of-age stuff.
Good coming-of-age movie for older kids.
The frequent collision of comedy and drama is breathtakingly real, and Anton Glanzelius is terrific as Ingemar, a smart 12 year old with a philosophical bent
Splendidly acted, and directed with touches of visual poetry by Lasse Hallstr√∂m.
A simple and captivating Swedish movie that has no precedents, especially when it comes to its masterful command of humor or pathos. [Full Review in Spanish]
Touching, funny story of childhood in Sweden.
Ingemar, as the other children in the film, is depicted with a noticeable respect and maturity.
Sweet and sincere.
My Life as a Dog is not just a fine portrait of childhood and how children react to life's problems; it is a comparison of philosophies of life.

This is a coming-of-age film in the fullest sense of the term: we watch Ingemar grow up before our eyes, and turn into a human being who can live with the harsh memories as well as the more lyrical ones.
The gentlest direction that director Lasse Halstrom has ever demonstrated.
Director Halstrom has a nice touch in working with the youngster.
Hallstrm acknowledges that the film is his best work, the one he compares all his other films to.
A tad overrated, but still charming.
An affecting and authentic portrayal of a young boy's attempt to understand the adult world.
By the end of the movie, you care enough about the characters to want a sequel, even though life probably goes on predictably for them in Smaland.
This bittersweet Swedish film captures childhood as good as any ever made.
One of the greatest and most sensitive films about children and the turbulence of childhood...
Wonderful Swedish film set in the 1950s showing how a 12-year-old boy learns to cope creatively with substantial losses in his life.
My Life's in Turnaround details the misguided yet strangely sincere journey of these two filmmakers as they each struggle to find their movie, a direction, and a girlfriend.
An amiable spoof of independent filmmaking.
Weird? To say the least. Funny and insightful? Without a doubt. A success? That depends on what you enjoy in a movie. For me, it is.
[An] endearingly lackadaisical, merrily aimless little movie.
A scrappy low-budget comedy with lots of insouciant charm.
Part spoof, part farewell to the frontier myth, it's kind of a slapstick version of The Gunfighter.
La.rgely successful with some gaping flaws, and deeply experimental in a way that verges on upsetting
While it all feels like a step down from the grandeur of Leone's spaghetti Westerns, that's part of the point, and part of the charm.
A classic film with a stunning soundtrack and a pretty magnetic and elegiac personality. [Full review in Spanish]
The movie is a good-natured delight.
Director-writer Gus Van Sant sets up disturbing -- and, often, oddly comic -- situations and then gives his characters (and actors) the freedom to explore them.
My Own Private Idaho might be the perfect cinematic time capsule for '90s aimlessness, universal in its details.
Apparently Van Sant believed the reviews anointing him as a genius, and this time he has cheekily dared comparisons with the Bard of Stratford.
Gus Van Sant's best movie.

Van Sant photographs the story in his trademark dreamy-surreal style, fusing elements of Warhol with the classic American road movie, and interpreting the Western as the refuge of society's maligned fringe.
a unique, poetic work of great intimacy and sadness
The achievement of this film is that is wants to evoke that state of drifting need, and it does.

Van Sant takes a lot of chances, and, visually, the movie is so imaginative, so fiercely alive, that it carries us along. But when the over-all design of the picture becomes clear, we feel cheated rather than enlightened.
If played straight, this would have had depth, but been an awful cinematic experience.
The film's uniqueness lies in its remarkable emotional open-heartedness.
A simultaneously heartbreaking and exhilarating road movie.
Van Sant's sensibility is wholly original, wholly fresh. My Own Private Idaho adds a new ingredient: a kind of boho sweetness. I loved it.
Holding all these elements together is Van Sant's sensibility, such an elusive thing it instinctively squirms away from any attempt to pigeonhole it.
Even though it falters toward the end, it soars above the fray.
One of those ambitious, over-reaching disappointments that is more interesting than some more conservative successes.
An essential testament to the beauty and chops of the late River Phoenix...
...a great enough idea that it almost doesn't bother me that these stories don't really illuminate one another.
Cracked and beautiful, stranger than strange, yet in some assuring way so pulsing with life that it embraces you as warmly as Father Knows Best.

[Van Sant] disdain[s] narrative. He got away with Drugstore Cowboy because its band of drugged-out dodoes were engaged in a petty crime spree that almost passed for a plot. But My Own Private Idaho is a different story. Or rather nonstory.
My Own Private Idaho lacks the dramatic punchiness of Drugstore Cowboy, yet it's a rich, audacious experience.
Even as history changes to accommodate current needs and frameworks, it's crucial to remember those who lived it.
... altogether gripping film.
Nanking does justice to this tragedy even though it makes the mistake of mixing the testimony of actual participants with staged readings from actors subbing for real people.
War and violence are never pretty, and this is not an easy film to watch -- there is brutal and gruesome footage of the death and destruction that happened there.
Highlights both the best and the worst that humanity has to offer.
The documentary is an effective and moving account of civilization gone amok.
a documentary that may well rank among the greatest re-tellings of a historical event put on film

A deft and dramatic melding of talking-head documentary, historic photos and film footage and readings by a cast of actors, the film is a devastating depiction of man's inhumanity to man. It is also about how some of us are brave enough to say 'No.'
A harrowing look at how war takes its terrible toll on the innocent.
There won't be a more powerful, horrific or inspiring film this year than Nanking.
The personalities it brings to light -- many of whom were forced to remain silent about what they'd seen after returning to their homelands -- are worthy of widespread exposure.
One of 2007's most important documentaries.
While at times the film begins to feel like a laundry list of bad deeds, the first-person accounts pack a wallop.
I have rarely, if ever, seen a documentary reconstruction of a historical event that is so rich in firsthand (and well-preserved) photographic material.
This painful documentary ends on a hopeful note, although with a clear view of the cloud over human nature.

The filmmakers employ a powerful technique of interspersing newsreel footage with wrenching on-camera interviews of survivors and sequences of actors reciting from the letters and memoirs of the Westerners on the scene.
A somberly effective look at one of the most shameful events in human history.
an important historical record
The lesson here is not simply to vilify the Japanese soldiers of that era, but to make sure that we never forget who we are and what our country stands for today.
Nanking both calls attention to a horrifying set of war crimes that remains little known in the West and crafts an impossible-but-true hymn to the power of the individual conscience.
There are plenty of funny moments in this comedy that introduced the world to bumbling everyman Clark Griswold. The second best in the series after Christmas Vacation.
National Lampoon's Vacation is an outrageously hilarious road-trip comedy filled with tons of heart and goofy moments that still stand the test of time.
National Lampoon's Vacation is a comedic cross-country adventure like no other, thanks to Chevy Chase and the rest of the Griswold family.
Thanks largely to Chevy Chase's zaniness and comic timing this is a very funny movie.
Though lacking in narrative and comic sophistication, National Lampoon's Vacation has something arguably more important: built-in, instant audience identification. [Blu-ray]
Relive some of your own dreadful family vacation moments with National Lampoon's comedy classic, Vacation.
The first and the best, only rivaled by CHRISTMAS VACATION. Revel in the days when Chase was funny!

The result is not so much a comedy about American values as a 2,500 mile skid on a banana skin. The visual gags come thick and fast, and are about as subtly signposted as the exit markers on a freeway.
Director Harold Ramis, who went on to make Groundhog Day, keeps the silliness coming at a fast and furious pace.
A timeless comedy. Hysterical.
It's a pleasant diversion with a few memorable bits and a likable cast, but true comic invention is hard to locate in the meandering screenplay by the late John Hughes.
Oh, is this a guilty pleasure. It's also the first R rated movie featuring nudity that I was allowed to see at the theater, which may have something to do with my fond memories of the picture.
...a zany, lighthearted look at numbskull American tourism at its most chaotic.
Every bit as fun as you remember.
Do you remember when Chevy Chase was funny? Yeah, (sigh), me too.

Half-baked but occasionally hilarious, National Lampoon's Vacation gets a reasonable amount of mileage out of depicting the disaster-prone journey of a "typical" family of four, the Griswolds of suburban Chicago.
Chevy Chase is hilarious once again.
A perfect marriage of collaborators on both sides of the camera.
Funny family comedy, but dated and risque.
The humor in Vacation also taps into something beyond the trials and travails of a road trip gone wrong.
A slapsticky buddy action-comedy so bad that it's hard to decide who's dumber: the two guards at the center of things or the filmmakers who've put them there.
A boring and unnecessary throwback to the big and boisterous action comedies from the '80s.

"National Security" is another in a string of indistinguishable dumb action comedies that would all run together in the mind of anyone unfortunate enough to watch them if they were not so instantly forgettable.
One of the lamest and cheapest-looking buddy-cop movies to come along since... well, since Blue Streak.
If... Martin Lawrence and Adam Sandler [were] in the same movie, it might... create an anti-comedy field so strong that both their careers would be sucked into the vortex...

critic_name: Cherryl Dawson and Leigh Ann Palone
content: Somebody needs to write them up a ticket - for impersonating a great movie.
The plot settles quickly into a conventional buddy movie framework.
Boneheaded throwaway.
I'll give ten bucks to the first gypsy willing to curse anyone even suggesting a sequel.
Has a none-too-subtle racist agenda that is thoroughly unfunny and repellent.
The less you engage your brain, the more you'll enjoy National Security.
Has an off-putting racial subtext that makes it difficult to simply sit back and enjoy.
A patently offensive, racist and repulsive waste of celluloid, an affront to blacks, whites and human beings in general.
Its acrimonious message lies in the way it depicts black oversensitivity and an atmosphere of political correctness as the only obstacles to harmony.
It's not really clear what's being stolen or why, but reason isn't as important to the screen writing team of Jay Scherick and David Ronn as getting to the next car chase.
A truly inane and flat action comedy.
Someone has to save us from Lawrence's onslaught of cinematic dross.
All the good stuff can be guffawed at in the opening half-hour. After that, you're on your own.
This is a two-star movie dragged down a star because of its unrepentant racism.
It's meant to wear down and demoralize critics who are about to launch into a whole new year of worthless buddy comedies.
Overall I liked Never Say Never Again but it fell far short of the movie it could have been. The makers should have been more adventurous instead of simply trying to beat Broccoli at his own game.

Can we just consider 1983 a lost year for James Bond? First, "Octopussy," then Sean Connery's return in a depressing dilution of the 007 brand - one that ends with a fourth wall-breaking wink indicative less of arch fun, more of bored indifference.
The slick production values impress and Barbara Carrera and Klaus Maria Brandauer are good value villains, but Irvin Kershner appears to have nodded off in the director's chair.
It's a major disappointment that, having lured back the original 007, the film makers couldn't offer him something better than this drawn-out, hackneyed story.
An ugly, unwanted epilogue [to Connery's Bond], in which the character who was so iconic and perfect is reduced to a self-conscious joke.
Connery
As dull as dishwater.

Superior to 'Octopussy', it shows that Connery is, for the moment, the actor who best treated the character, the only one who even took it seriously, possessed the necessary humor to make us laugh at him. [Full Review in Spanish]
In Never Say Never Again, the formula is broadened to accommodate an older, seasoned man of much greater stature, and Mr. Connery expertly fills the bill.
The rank pall of opportunism hangs over this sorry rogue enterprise from producer Kevin McClory, as he tries to assemble the component parts that make up a Bond movie and fails.
The film's photography is pretty slick and the stuff in the Bahamas in particular has aged very well.
I know Bond fans were furious about this movie cause it wasn't an Eon production, and I think they're wrong. They should be furious at it because it's a horrendous film.
...one of the most sophisticated of the Bonds.
Connery proved plenty fit for one more outing...a likeable but somewhat mediocre adventure handsomely mounted in the traditional Bond style...[Blu-ray]
It's an aging and unenthusiastic Connery who returns to play Bond, who doesn't have the physicality to do justice any more to the demanding muscular role.

Essentially, it's a remake of the less successful Thunderball, also with Connery. but Never Say Never Again, in the original Bond spirit, concentrates on the people rather than the gadgets -- at least for the first half.
Aside from some minor flaws, the film is a surprisingly standard Bond film, one that could easily be integrated into the "official" franchise with very few adjustments.
It may be Bond, but without the use of the gun barrel graphics, the booming theme music, and the opening title silhouettes of nude figures, it just doesn't feel the same.

After a 12-year hiatus, Sean Connery is back in action as James Bond. The new entry marks something of a retreat from the far-fetched technology of many of the later Bonds in favor of intrigue and romance.
Never Say Never Again is the best acted Bond picture ever made, because it clearly surpasses any predecessors in the area of inventive and clever character delineation.
I've seen much funnier films from Mike Epps.
I barely detected moments that even seemed like they were supposed to be funny, let alone ones that actually were.
Far from the worst of Taran tino knockoffs, Next Day Air takes the standard formula of dimwits chasing bags of drugs to the 'hood.
I like Donald Faison, Mos Def and Mike Epps - but I really disliked this movie and them in it.
He may be a first-time feature director, but music video master Benny Boom clearly knows how to pull a midlevel movie together. That's harder than it sounds.
With a script that snaps and characters that pop, Next Day Air nears neo-blaxploitation perfection.
Next Day Air can't decide whether it's a broad stoner comedy or a gritty Tarantino-esque action flick. The humor is there, but violence brings the laughter to an abrupt halt.

Next Day Air is sort of bracing, though it isn't very good: Its total lack of dramatic and comic bearings, to say nothing of a point, keeps you wondering about the next fatality, in a half-interested way.
Air is an interesting misfire, but often an irritatingly erratic viewing experience that would've profited greatly from a good old-fashioned dose of clear-headed concentration.
Next Day Air is a talentless travesty, a trying torture fest that wants to believe it's cool and contemporary.
This is one package that should be returned to sender.

Next Day Air is a stylish movie that smoothly shifts from genial comedy to violent action and back again, almost like a Missy Elliott song cramming together four different snippets that magically mesh.

First-time feature director Benny Boom and writer Blair Cobbs get a lot of help from their cast, and the banter is often akin to a thug Three Stooges routine. But blood and predictability sour things in the end.

Next Day Air is well-intentioned but ill-thought, an amateur work by a first time filmmaking team trying to make the kind of film they like to watch, but ignorant of what makes those kinds of films work.
It's an oddly lethargic production, heavy in foul language and gun-pointing, but slow-witted and uninspired.
Best to refuse this delivery
It's hard to make a movie that ends with blazing guns and dead bodies and still send the audience away laughing, but Next Day Air finds the right drive-in movie tone.
Forty years from now, this may be fascinating for its relentless early 21st-century 'urban' slang and attitude. Let's hope it also seems antique for the idea that guns are as accessible as Kleenex...
Falls flat as both a dark comedy and action film. It's often lazy, dim-witted and tedious while low on laughs, verve and imagination.
a rare type of disaster... putrid
The football is dreadful but the colourful players - like transgender defender Jaiyah Saelua - make this hilarious documentary a big-hearted delight.
A shining example of how sports aren't simply about competition and domination, but about camaraderie, self-discovery, and love.
A crowd pleaser in every sense of the word.
Both predictable and shamelessly heart-warming.
As an antidote to Premier League cynicism, it couldn't be bettered.
There's possibly more terrible football on display than even Scottish audiences can stomach, but like the team, it's a documentary with heart.
"Next Goal Wins" is an irresistible underdog story - sports-fan credentials not required.
A genial documentary crowdpleaser about the world's worst international soccer team.
Captivating, moving sports docu; some swearing.
Watching this was the first time I have ever punched the air because a football sailed into the back of a net. And very probably the last.
Even folk who don't give a hoot about football will find their hearts warmed by inspirational documentary Next Goal Wins.
If you're a person, and you find other people worth your time and attention, Next Goal Wins will stir you ...
The pace is a little leisurely, and it doesn't demand to be seen on a big screen, but much like the characters it portrays Next Goal Wins is an unassuming winner.
Next Goal Wins lingers rather too long towards the end on drawing out its message, but it is a thoroughly engaging exploration of sport, culture, community and the nature of achievement.
In some ways, this is just another underdogs-go-for-it sports movie. In others, it is as sensitive and observant as an Edith Wharton novel.
Next Goal Wins is a classic underdog story, but it is entirely original.
A triumph-of-the-underdog documentary so amusing and inspirational you'll have to Google events to ensure it's not a mockumentary. Back of the net.
'Tis the season for over use of sporting cliches noting the romance of the World Cup. But if you can't find it in Next Goal Wins, you're not going to find it anywhere.
Slightly muted closing stretch lets the air out of the ball ever so slightly, but by then it's already in the top corner.
One of the smallest triumphs in world sport inspires one of the year's most moving and entertaining documentaries...
Haggis [has] padded the film out with more action, but every extra minute makes the film an extra bit implausible.
Ultimately, the film sinks due to pacing issues, some truly manipulative storytelling and a whole bunch of glaring plot holes
A bomb in no uncertain terms, an ill-formed, stupidly plotted, morally unclean thriller.
Crisply acted, smartly directed and patently absurd, The Next Three Days is a high-tension thriller wound so tight it seems ready to snap like a stressed guitar string at any minute.
Consistently entertaining, the picture nevertheless has a nasty habit of wandering aimlessly, disrupting the visceral extravaganza at hand.
Ambiguous, heavy-handed morality tale with a pretentious plot that's implausible.
Thrillers don't need to be 100 percent believable, but staying above 10 percent usually helps.
Meandering and a little silly
Crowe fans, perhaps more than anyone, are the most likely to be satisfied.
The characters are so vivid that the suspense never lags.

...The most effective scenes employ the Hitchcockian maxim that you can show a couple kissing for as long as you like provided there's a bomb under the bed. Haggis has plenty of bombs and plenty of beds to put them under.
Although involving, this remake of a recent French film never reaches the anticipated heights of excitement and suspense.
In the end, it's a satisfying thriller with crisp action sequences, once it gets around to that part of Haggis' story-telling agenda.
...watching Haggis simply work the pulses, guts and adrenal glands of the audience is decidedly more pleasant than having him clamber into our laps to appeal to our hearts, minds and souls.

In the end, you get a thriller that's basically about nothing and not that thrilling. This is a product made to place in theaters like a can of Del Monte Sliced Peaches is manufactured for a grocery shelf.
Terrific performances + clever and suspenseful twists you never see coming.
This is a terrific film with a final reel guaranteed to have you digging your fingers into your armrest.
Hats off to Paul Haggis. He's got to be the first person to do a Hollywood remake of a foreign movie that turns out to be MORE waffly.
A laborious thriller that lacks wit, intelligence, and, most unforgivably, thrills, The Next Three Days continues the steady decline of Crowe's career.
The biggest crime isn't the husband's attempt to steal his wife from jail. It's that with Paul Haggis' remake of the taut French thriller Pour Elle, the story's been robbed of its bite.
Night at the Museum, based on a kids' book by Milan Trenc, is so wonderfully energetic it doesn't leave much time for questions.
Though not quite as funny, clever or exciting as it thinks it is, this remains a watchable adventure comedy with good comic performances and the occasional moment of inspiration.
Like the institution it portrays, Night at the Museum comes alive after dark. It's a perfect movie to take the kids to. Who knows, it might even inspire them to want to visit an actual museum.
With this cast, there should be more laughs, and that blame falls partially on the script, but equally on how awfully Levy paces the film.
What a dull, nice movie, wrenched from a wild premise and battered into docility.
Night at the Museum is not just a wild runaround of computer-generated creatures. Well, OK, that's mostly what it is. Still, there is something of a plot.
A id√©ia central √© suficientemente interessante para prender nosso interesse durante a maior parte do tempo, transformando o projeto em uma divers√£o inofensiva, ainda que burocr√°tica.
Cavemen and dinosaurs, cowboys and Roman soldiers, lions and zebras, all running amok, sounds like more fun than it is.
Night at the Museum fails to hit a completely comfortable stride.
It's hard to argue with the movie's knowledge-as-power message: To outwit the living artifacts, Stiller has to bone up on history.
It's a fun ride, and the big payoff -- that history turns out to be way cooler than its reputation suggests -- is even more gratifying.
I want to see a prehistoric man shoot Ben Stiller in the face with a fire extinguisher. Why the hell not?
Ben Stiller may just be his generation's Woody Allen.
Rarely has so much production value yielded so little in terms of audience engagement.
Sure, Night At The Museum isn't about to win any awards for originality, but this is a flick that exhibits a fine sense of fun.
It's repetitive and strangely invested in its silly explanation of how the animated creatures phenomenon comes about (something about an Egyptian pharaoh's tablet).
Ben Stiller and gang still manage to give the delightfully entertaining Night at the Museum a little edge.
The special effects rule, yet they don't overpower simple, character-driven slapstick.
Jumanji Lite

Rarely entertaining, the movie is at least instructive. The statute of limitations on loud, dumb movies with Robin Williams and computer-generated animals is 11 years. It bypasses brand-name coattails right to the level of a straight-to-DVD sequel.
This potentially powerful material is unfortunately dealt with too melodramatically.
Cornel Wilde's grim, fatalistic end-of-the-world thriller... is a forgotten dystopian classic of its time.
A bleak, violent and humorless but provocative survival post-apocalyptic sc-fi film.
On the level of grade‚ÄêC ad venture it works well enough, but on the several other levels not which it aspires, it does not work at all.

No Blade of Grass lacks the primitive power of Wilde's earlier films... in its social attitudes and theorising, it exposes the shallowness of Wilde's conception of man as an animal dressed in civilised trappings that can, all too easily, be slipped off.
Russo-Young's characters simply feel like complex, confused people trying desperately to be happy without also destroying their lives with their poor impulse control.
The acting ensemble is crucial. Everyone's really fine.
Interesting but unsatisfying film about infidelity.
An underwhelming comedy about the clash between East Coast edginess and laid-back LA which rarely rises above the formulaic.
Nobody Walks is a film of acutely observed little moments that unfortunately don't add up to anything of substance. It's a forgettable shrug of a movie, pleasant enough, but unlikely to linger.
Sensitively written, nicely shot, expertly acted, and intelligently ambiguous, "Nobody Walks" still manages to send you out with a shrug.
Insightful look at how a young woman serves as a catalyst for sexual mayhem within an L.A. family unit.

Nobody Walks may be a guilty pleasure. But the pleasure of its empty calories is tangible in the heat of the performances, the lush visuals, and a sound design that riffs on the story's central conceit...
The direction is decent, and the film is handsome. But it's finally frustrating, enigmatic in a way that suggests emptiness more than mystery.
Nobody Walks is like mumblecore with stars.
Nobody Walks looks and sounds great.
[A] lackluster indie drama ...
A young woman's arrival creates sexual upheavals in a cool, artistic L.A. household, in an unsatisfying drama that might have worked better as a comedy.
Nervous, intriguingly sour little character study.
Full of humor and humanity, Nobody Walks is an emotionally complex, acutely observed and sensual film and one of the best at Sundance this year.
A few scenes hint at the potential of the piece, while the rest of the effort seems more interested in curling up for a nap.
If you allow yourself to drift with it, rather than get frustrated by all the non sequiturs, "Nobody Walks" becomes a more enjoyable film.
Like a lot of films in the chatty genre labeled "mumblecore," "Nobody Walks" glides by on little money, few incidents and a lot of conversations -- some of them without words.
A movie made by women about men who misunderstand sexual signals, behaving badly, and the women who are stuck dealing with their bruised egos.

You feel the characters' pangs as they spin out of control, and you are reminded of how easy it is for a careless sexual adventurer to destroy relationships and families on a whim, without even fully realizing it.
Not up to Rob Reiner's usually high standard.

It is a childish world seen through the ponderous eyes of adulthood. All the children in it, including Elijah Wood as North, seem over-directed, reacting with programmed cuteness. Their lines have a hack's glibness rather than a child's innocence.
North, a playful modern fable about a boy in search of new parents, doesn't always work, but much of it is clever in amusingly unpredictable ways.
There's schmaltz a-plenty and the odd, rare laugh but even the normally dependable Wood lacks enthusiasm.
The screenplay by Alan Zweibel and Andrew Scheinman packs more on-target social satire than any film in recent memory, and zesty performances keep it clicking along at a rapid pace.
Elijah Wood has fast become the most appealing young actor making movies today, turning in consistently solid performances in a variety of roles.
Have you ever seen a rich Texan before? How about a Hawaiian who lives near a beautiful beach?
How could director Rob Reiner, whose touch for what pleases a mass audience is usually unfailing, have strayed this far?
It's rather surprising to note that - for its first half, at least - North is actually quite engaging and entertaining...
A brain-dead curiosity piece.
It's depressing enough to see a director turn into a button pusher. But what can you say about a director who just keeps hitting the same button?
The amalgams of TV stereotypes that satirize foreign and regional cultures are embarrassing.
The premise of North sounds flat, the previews look insipid, and, while the movie doesn't turn out nearly as bad as either would lead you to believe, North is still a lackluster production.
A witless exercise in adult-bashing.
Woeful and meandering...Reiner's direction is uncharacteristically choppy and uneventful
The intrinsic failure of Alan Zweibel and Andrew Scheinman's script is that it tips its hand from the start.

Reiner is undecided just how fantastically he should treat this ludicrous plotline. Added to which there's a dire musical number, a silly thriller subplot, and much maudlin didacticism from narrator Willis in various guardian angel (dis)guises. Misery.
It's a prime example of what can happen when hip, slightly cynical establishment filmmakers try to make a deeply sentimental movie.
A smug, tedious and wrong-headed mess.
It's strange and oddly distasteful, at its best managing to be bad in some original and unexpected ways.
...the film itself exhibits the same generous, accepting attitude that was one of Page's great appeals.
But still, who was Bettie Page? The film offers not a clue.
Because its interest is in Page as an inadvertent erotic icon, Harron's movie plays more like a gentle conceptual satire on all-American 1950s hypocrisy than an attempt to probe the person herself.
A small, strangely sweet tale well told. But this is all about Mol, who puts in a performance that gives her a very early lead on next year's Oscar race.
We exit with too clear a sense of the filmmakers' flaws, but Mol's nuanced character triumphs and can firmly situate itself in the milieu of Bettie Page.
Smugly anti-erotic in the extreme.
Turns out to be a movie with little to remember despite the precise craft and efforts of its creators. It's as if they worked hard for nothing.
If you could give an Oscar for radiating joy while clad in knee-high, spiky leather boots and a corset, Gretchen Mol deserves it.
The Notorious Bettie Page's arid fixation on period over character comes at a price.
Page [is] played as if on a mission by Gretchen Mol.
A comedy of high freakishness that invites us to climb deep into the mystique of Bettie Page's image, her phenomenon.
The movie's exploration of its supposedly sleazy milieu from a distinctively female point of view is invigorating, and the recreations of the period ... are a retro-kick.
It's a handsome, often funny piece of work with a nearly fatal inability to settle on a tone.

Turner and Harron load Notorious with the details of '50s-shutterbug and nude-modeling culture and surround Mol with a talented supporting cast, but otherwise let Mol's faded smiles and enigmatic glances suggest what's going on inside
The film is a superficial biographical drama that reveals next to nothing new about its subject.
Shots of the later-in-life Bettie dressing for a day of street evangelizing remind us that standard woman's fashions can be as binding as Irving Klaw's getups.
Astute -- even frisky -- as it is, Notorious Bettie Page never shakes being enamored of the mystery of Page.
Doesn't give us any more insight into her life than the voiceless, glossy photos we have seen time and time again.
Gretchen Mol is amazing as Bettie.
The tone of the movie is subdued and reflective. It does not defend pornography, but regards it (in its 1950s incarnation) with subdued nostalgia for a more innocent time.
A provocative, emotionally resonant, and powerful drama. Melissa Leo gives a commanding, tour de force performance. Margaret Qualley is radiant.

Betts appears to have started out with a rather mundane idea and then stumbled, over the course of her research, onto something much more fruitful. The result is as intriguing and frustrating as that suggests.
A most recommendable film. [Full review in Spanish]
Overlong...dramatically a mixed-bag, but moving.
The film raises interesting questions, but the answers remain elusive, and whether that makes for a compelling cinematic experience is entirely in the eye of the beholder.
Intense nuns-in-training drama has language, sensuality.
Though it's shot beautifully, Novitiate's pacing, focusing on the sisters' daily routines, is slow.

It's hard to imagine a film that more thoroughly passes the Bechdel Test than Novitiate, a period drama about nuns coming to terms with the changes Vatican II brought to the Catholic Church in the 1960s.
The anguish of Margaret Qualley is riveting, and Melissa Leo delivers a powerhouse performance in this solemn, soulful melodrama, pulling back the curtain on the secrecy of convent life.
Novitiate is filled with wonderful young actresses who are given the chance to create complex and complicated characters, with unique issues and personalities.
Flaunting an all-star cast of impeccable actresses, Betts intrigues the viewer to surrender to the film's intoxicating tale of obedience and self-discovery. It's one of the year's most vivid dramas.
First-time writer/director Maggie Betts mostly manages to involve viewers in exploring why young ladies actually might want to take the spiritual plunge.
Betts ... undercuts the characters' passion and transcendent devotion with audiovisual commonplaces, familiar acting styles, and a merely anecdotal narrative.
The inner lives and spiritual struggles of Catholic nuns are examined in Novitiate.
A strong premise and protagonist can't fully elevate this tale about teen nuns.
Novitiate is a scandalous, shameless anti-Catholic freak show.
Stern on the surface, yet entirely human look at religion, femininity and faith.
Questions of faith may sound dry but they often make for intensely dramatic, even pulse-pounding cinema. "Novitiate" is the latest case in point.
Deeply enthralling, it's as provocative as it is progressive.
Narratively speaking, there are no climaxes, no anti-climaxes, just a methodical commitment to establishing the context of one big question: can a woman live without physical love?
An independent film with characters you'll care about as well as a rare silver screen attempt to at least begin to try to understand the nature of abortion.
Quirky, funny and GUTSY.
A dark romantic comedy that has plenty of the first, a little of the second and none of third.
A well-realized, straight-ahead rom-com, one with the potential to reinvigorate a genre that's been flagging for decades.
The humor gets dark but the future looks bright for Robespierre and Slate.
Moment to moment, you believe what's happening in Robespierre's film, which is funny and rueful in roughly equal measure without being despairing in the slightest.
The movie doesn't present itself as some kind of secular equivalent of a moral lesson. It's not callous or weepy or preachy - or self-consciously not those things. It's a naturally told story.
Jenny Slate demonstrates the gift that sets apart the great actors from the good ones: The ability to move you to tears without saying a word.
A film that is confidently vulnerable and genuinely honest while acknowledging the masks that we so easily wear in our daily lives.
Director Gillian Robespierre arranges this as slice-of-single-life comedy, and it works well ...
Beyond the identity politics and humor, Obvious Child goes the extra mile to represent a seldom voiced, moderate position about a hot button topic.
This film deserves to be seen as a major breakthrough for Jenny Slate who commands the kind of humor and honesty that stars possess.
It zigs when you expect it to zag.
"Obvious Child" is being promoted as a groundbreaking topical comedy about abortion. But it's less than that. And more. And, basically, not.
A prime example of what "indie" means, mid-2014.

The heroine can't seem to come up with any material that doesn't involve bodily functions; she never goes near the subject of motherhood, which proves that the filmmakers are scared to death of their own story.
Hats off to any film that tries (and succeeds) at presenting challenging, off-putting characters from whose palms I'm reluctantly persuaded to eat.
The sisterhood is here and seeing it at work, getting on with the business of living, is actually very moving.
Slate is truly something to behold.
A cross between a Woody Allen farce and a one-woman show by Sarah Silverman.
The very worst Roger Moore Bond Film, and one to avoid unless you really have to watch every single film in a marathon, like myself, sadly...

James Bond is old. Wrinkled-forehead old. Lecherous-coot old. Strategic-hairstyle old. Senior meal-discount old. Simply ... old. That's the biggest takeaway from Roger Moore's second-worst outing as 007, hot on the heels of his second-best.
There's a fine line between wit and absurdity, and this particular movie too often falls on the wrong side.
Bond had degenerated into a male model, and something of a genial anachronism.
Bottom-drawer Bond.
The joy of a great Bond movie is the way it pushes the limits of believability -- and knows when to stop. Octopussy fails.
Octopussy is a very minor entry in the Bond franchise.
One for the die hards. The saving grace here is a knowing sense of humour so lacking in its predecessor, For Your Eyes Only.
Octopussy features 2 stand-out action sequences but for the most part, it's an overlong, sluggish, and schizophrenic entry in the Bond series.
I've never been a big fan of this Bond flick. Catchy name, though.
The naffness that was prevalent in the Bond series around the time of Moore still abounds here.
...more than a bit silly compared to its immediate predecessor.
Great Bond. Lousy title.
"Octopussy" is the 13th of the James Bond movies, and it is one of the best.
For the first time in the series, the story unfolds like a true mystery, instead of merely having some eccentric billionaire devising a plot to take over the world.
Too long
Makes no pretense of being based on anything except the Ian Fleming character and the high good humor and wit of the film makers.
Hardly Mr. Bond's finest hour.
More sexual innuendo than usual in provocatively named film.
This was the 13th Bond movie and it's possibly the most frivolous in the series to date (it's certainly the most careless).
The film was in some ways spoiled but not ruined by the pretentiously arty way it was directed by Sidney Lumet.
Although the story has become a staple of films and TV police dramas since this, it still hasn't been done quite so well.
It's highly theatrical -- perhaps just a little too highly theatrical for the more or less realistic context -- but it's been staged by Lumet for maximum effect.
A fascinating and intense psychological thriller. This is one Connery fans should seek out.
Embedded in a 'realistic' police scene, dialogue and situations now have a ring of arty melodrama. Fascinating, nevertheless, with outstanding performances from Connery and (especially) Bannen.

There's a powerful confrontation of authority and accused between police sergeant Sean Connery and suspected child molester Ian Bannen in Sidney Lumet's The Offence. A brilliant scene, however, does not in itself make for a brilliant overall feature.
The Offence presents audiences with an overwhelmingly bleak rumination on evil.

The third collaboration between Sean Connery and the director Sidney Lumet is an unsettling glimpse into the toxic mind of a policeman who has been polluted by the horrors witnessed over the course of his career.
A great disappointment.
Lumet's direction strives to give to material that is neither edifying nor suspenseful a fake profundity, stretching it to unconscionable lengths.
Gritty police programmes are now so much a part of the TV landscape that it is hard to realise that a feature like The Offence once packed quite a punch.
This unrelentingly somber policier inaugurates a newfound force in Lumet's work.

As the Iraq War recedes into our rear-view mirror and our current news cycle spins blindly from one world crisis to another, films like Official Secrets, bland as they may seem, will serve as crucial efforts to keep our past mistakes in our minds.
Silly thriller music is occasionally resorted to, but not necessary: this is a story that tells itself.
With a stellar cast, this true story is brought to life and illuminates one of the important whistleblowers of modern times.

Gavin Hood's Official Secrets isn't a poor film so much as an unremarkable one, and if there is any suspense or stylistic innovation to be wrung from this important story then the director is keeping it under his hat.

It should be said that all the actors do well here. And the screenplay is responsible and economical in boiling down the complex issues the movie tackles. It's a fair, understated film about things we ought to care about.
The revealing 'Official Secrets' is intelligent entertainment.
A bit slow, but utterly engrossing thanks to its subject and an A-list Brit cast.
There's something interestingly tough and forthright about this slow-burner from director and co-writer Gavin Hood.

A straightforward, solidly old-fashioned slice of real-life espionage, journalistic and legal intrigue that gets the job done in engrossing, clear-eyed fashion even if it lacks much in the way of stylistic verve.

Yet another instance of filmmakers of courage and conviction stepping up where unfortunately and unlike Gun, politicians and the press (including critics) fear to tread. Which is the reason you likely never heard of this best female action hero this year.
The telling of this true story is a straightforward, almost perfunctory, procedural

Although Knightley's Gun often seems to be a passive figure, buffeted by the machinations of those around her, the film's honesty about the enormous personal costs of whistleblowing is a welcome relief from more romanticized heroics.
[A] very solid, totally respectable, well-cast, well-acted, slow burn political thriller potboiler.
Official Secrets has a metaphorical impulse that goes beyond the specific. [Full Review in Spanish]
The cast are excellent, especially Ralph Fiennes, and the story is told with compassion.
The end result is a professionally made film that is whistle-blowingly relevant, starring an excellent actress who successfully comes in from her Pride & Prejudice past.
Hood knows how to crank the tension and a certain fury ticks under the story.

And without spoiling too much, if you think the cries of war criminal lobbed at Blair, Bush and Howard are lefty hysteria, the powerful courtroom finale is a timely reminder where that accusation comes from.
But what's the point of all that furious profanity, all those feet on desks, if nothing changes?
As concisely informative as an Economist article and as gripping as a beach read.
It is a film of indelible portraiture... All throughout, the film looks hard at that which we're accustomed to turning away from.
Rogosin's famous, if underseen, landmark wades into the notorious human ruin as no other film ever did.
...the raw footage captured by cinematographer Richard Bagley's Bolex is so powerful that any concerns about moviemaking conventions simply fall by the wayside.
The film is a fascinating bit of Americana, an indelible portrait of another time and place...stunning
The remarkably crisp black and white photography shows what life on the street was really like for the down and outs living on the Bowery.
Feels real, even amid the sometimes awkward non-professional performances. Rogosin masterfully tells the untold stories of the people society left behind.
On the Bowery runs only 65 minutes, but by the end you can feel skid row in your bones.
This is a primal story of survival and trust set in what was one of the worst places in the world.
A fine-grained picture of stasis, both on the street and in the faces of lifers shuffling into gin mills and flophouses.
Lionel Rogosin's semi-documentary is an unflinching document of skid-row denizens, and humanist cinema at its unsentimental best.

"On the Bowery" offers some of the most indelible faces in an American docudrama, faces ravaged by alcohol and poverty, creased by defeat and self-deception, surrounded by a New York City that does not care. Yet no one on screen asks for pity.

Shot on Manhattan's virtually resurrected street of broken persons, the film is a snapshot of gin mills, flophouses and human wrecks, once known as "winos" for their addiction to cheap, fortified wine.
This is a temperance lecture on film that makes no new points.
Shot on 16mm in black-and-white with a Bolex camera, the results remain stunningly authentic.
The result is harrowing and heartrending, and all the more so when you realize that the people on the screen died mostly miserable deaths, with only this little-known work of art to memorialize them.
Fascinating for urban and film historians, but also a moving tribute to film's timeless power to illuminate social issues. See with new The Perfect Team:The Making of.
A vivid portrait of a New York that's long since vanished.

As a record of a time and a place in the history of New York, it's essential. As a depiction of men at the bottom of their lives, it has the same sorrowful, accusatory force as a great Depression-era photograph by Dorothea Lange or Walker Evans.
This landmark documentary disturbs and compels as much today in a new 35mm restoration as it did when it opened in 1956 to both criticism and acclaim.
A landmark documentary.
The youthful cast is lively enough to make the enterprise almost work, presenting a time capsule of cyber- communication that should be more interesting 20 years from now.

Doomed by Weintrob's passion for the Web, his passionless characters are little more than manipulated 'bots' -- and audiences, absenting possible hipster appeal, may vote more zeroes than ones for this digital tale.
A smart, well-made film that treads new ground in the relationship wilderness.
Watching On_Line is a dispiriting experience that leaves you with a nagging 'Is that all there is?' feeling about sex in general.

This would-be erotic thriller suffers from the same problem that afflicts so many computer-oriented movies -- namely, that watching characters staring at a screen and typing hardly makes for a thrilling cinematic experience.

The movie epitomizes the problems inherent in attempting to depict new (and constantly morphing) media -- the inevitable obsolescence, the intangible particularities that resist or get lost in translation.
A fun, insightful and sensuous romp through a world in which few of us have traveled.
Writer-director Jed Weintrob is so busy trying to make important statements about human relationships in the cyber age that he loses control of his whiny, unlikable characters.
At its heart, On_Line is just an old-fashioned movie about people, relationships and making connections in an isolated world. And in this sense, the movie is very successful.
A fine example of digital filmmaking.
Amateurish drivel, which is headed for Skinemax in a hurry.
The raw sexuality sometimes clangs loudly against the glib comedy, but by the end On_Line makes you love it.
It's really just about a bunch of pathetic losers whiling away the hours with their hands jammed down their pants.
A 90-minute hairy-palm horror show, one that will strike terror into the heart of anyone who shares a keyboard with a lonely, Web-crazed roommate.
Although far-fetched at times, On Line gives us likable enough characters and several laugh out loud moments. Director Jed Weintrob has a distinct visual flair.
The same old 'people are lonely' whining, only with new technology.
A triumph of formula over substance.
...a savvy, shrewd commentary on the listless self-absorption of modern computer cocooners.
A pleasant, small comedy that will have you smiling.
If you like scenes of characters sticking hands down their pants, this is the film for you.
A hybrid musical romantic fantasy, lavishing giddy heights of visual imagination and technical brilliance onto a wafer-thin story of true love turned sour, then sweet.
There's not a moment in One From the Heart when Mr. Coppola isn't after something romantic and glorious, something inexpressibly grand. At times, he even gets what he's after.
A grand tribute to the power of love.
A bold experiment in style and technique that doesn't work.
An interesting production but not a good movie.
If any film from the 1980s needs to be re-examined, it's Francis Ford Coppola's One from the Heart.

With more than 200 salaried employees on a 10-acre lot that included 9 soundstages, 34 editing suites, and a gigantic trailer that the mogul dubbed the Silver Fish, Coppola videotaped rehearsals in an effort to cut down on film costs. Alas...

It's attractive and fascinating but at the same time full of false notes, erroneous choices, and corniness. But it couldn't be another way in a film that has as its theme or obsession to declare its love to cinema. [Full Review in Spanish]
A great big beautiful bore, ornately directed by Francis Coppola, with little charm and less meaning.
A 1982 curio about feeling, not the weighty machinations of plot... but one that offers only moments of studied amusement, not rapt absorption.
An ambitious misfire by a brilliant filmmaker.

It isn't very good, but at least the highly touted technology is put firmly in the service of the (sometimes painfully sincere) emotions that Francis Ford Coppola wants to communicate, which is more than you can say for Apocalypse Now.
An integral piece of the oeuvre of one of America's great directors.
[An] often maligned, giddy, superlative romantic musical.
This has matured over the years into a very likeable and moving romance with much to recommend it.
Coppola surrounds his lovelorn characters in a dizzying virtuoso display, but he knows what all this cinematic excitement adds up to: escape.
At times the project seems in danger of being scuppered by its own lavishness; the saving grace is a light heart.
Underwritten and overdirected.

critic_name: Cherryl Dawson and Leigh Ann Palone
content: There are plenty of movies out there that deserve to be re-released for a whole new generation of moviegoers to enjoy - this is not one of them.
A musical without singing and too little dancing.
...thoroughly robust within its own skin. Visually involving and vibrantly executed, fight fans will definitely get a rousing kick out of Ong-Bak
The time to catch Tony Jaa is now.
If you're a fan of old-style Hong Kong martial arts movies, you should find Ong-Bak a blast. And even if not, you may be surprised at how much dumb fun it is.
You can rightly say that Jaa has yet to establish much of a character, but give him a chance.
Your jaw will hit the floor and stay there as (Tony) Jaa persistently defies both gravity and physics.
Already a much-bootlegged, beloved martial arts film in Thailand, Ong-Bak delivers a new world action star in Jaa.
Tony Jaa is the real deal; gently charismatic but gifted with a fierce passion for his sport and its balletic but brutal grace.
Mr. Jaa is a gifted athlete, and there's something to be said for a fighter who dances on heads only for the honor of the Buddha.
Tony Jaa is the real thing.
Imaginatively plotted destruction abounds.

[Tony] Jaa has an impressive physique, a steel snap to his delivery, and a gymnastic prowess to his style, and director Prachya Pinkaew puts it all on display in an endearingly na√Øve martial arts adventure.
Jaa's screen time is largely about athletics, not building a character.
Jaa's moves are impressive, but the choreography ranges from bland to ridiculous (as when one dirty fighter resorts to using major appliances as weapons).
The meat of the matter is fight sequences, and rather than being goosed with now-common digital effects and Hong Kong-style wirework, it's all real and all breathtaking.
The only reason to see it is for the action. In that arena, on a scale from 1 to 10, it's a 20.
The movie's strong points are its clever chase sequences, in which Jaa outruns (or levitates over) gangs of murderous baddies through obstacle courses of everyday Bangkok commerce and street traffic.
Vile, humorless, distasteful, sickening.
Whether or not he becomes the next Jet Li or Van Damme, Jaa can at least lay claim to not only having the martial arts moves, but also the haircut to match.
I have the feeling we'll be hearing from Tony Jaa again.
More than anything, Ong-Bak is a primer in techniques for hitting people with your elbows.
Perhaps more than any other Chan movie, this one suggests that he's most at home being a clown.
With its reliable combination of humor and martial arts, this is one of Jackie Chan's most entertaining projects.
The final fight scene in an underground Nazi wind tunnel is a work of absolute genius and not to be missed for any reason.
There's a by-the-numbers feel to much of the action.
Terrific, fun.
Another exhilarating, jaw-dropping romp.
[Jackie Chan's] goal is to recover stolen Nazi gold, but his real goal is to wow us, which he does more often than not.
Lots of fun from start to finish
A flawed but forgiveable pleasure.
It's far from his best work, and holds together about as well as a Clinton cabinet, but it's still thoroughly entertaining.
Far and away 1997's best comedy.
Disposable entertainment? Yes. Fun? You betcha.
A laughably dubbed, awkwardly plotted variation on Raiders of the Lost Ark.
One of Chan's most exciting and complete films to date.
If I were Pierce Brosnan, I'd be looking over my shoulder right about now.
The fight scenes lack spirit and the stunts just don't hold the awe that they do in his better pictures.
Neither the best nor the worst, Operation Condor makes for a slap-happy medium
For those of who are not fans, its laughs will be forgotten minutes after we exit the theater.
Hey, even Jackie Chan has to pay the rent.
If Jackie Chan had written, directed and starred in Raiders of the Lost Ark, this would be the result.
Smart and compelling analysis of self-medication in the age of digital manipulation.
Operator is sleek, stylish, and downright honest.
Emotionally engrossing if not 100% persuasive in its last act, it balances techno-alienation and warmth in ways that will resonate with art-house audiences.
See it because it's uproarious and lyrical and (aha) human.

Begins as a very funny comedy, but its two lead performances (including the best work of Whitman's career) carry the film to uncommon insight into how we relate, emote and will always need the spontaneity of the human experience.
More droll than funny, more interesting than charming, but a couple of killer scenes and engaging leads let this romance pay off.
A visually sensational two-hour extravaganza...
While there are but a few action sequences, they are spectacularly rendered and made doubly exciting due to the emotional involvement generated by the rest of the film.
Almost as if Ingmar Bergman decided to direct animated movies.
There are moments when the English dubbing seems at odds with the visual action, whether because of specific dialogue or its delivery.
Ambitious and daring in its seamless melding of color, depth and detail.
The Wings of Honneamise: Royal Space Force showcases the strengths and weaknesses of Japanese adult-oriented animation...

It is these visions, and the narrative, which also has a strong religious subplot, that make the program so compelling, a work of fantasy that is designed to make you think and contemplate. The artwork is outstanding

As fascinating as this peek into daily life at the Nixon White House is, the real power of Our Nixon is its poignant insight into how the impeachable situation unfolded within the president's inner circle.
[S]hows the precise moment when new image technology would alter power.
It's an exploration of the banality of evil that constantly puts banality first, but this is a relatively narrow experimental film designed to supplement rather than replace more thorough histories.
There are those among Nixon antagonists who can never get enough of Watergate lore so this film is definitely for them.

Mundane movies of events like the president's daughter's wedding and his groundbreaking trip to China are juxtaposed with Nixon's rants about his enemies and the "homosexuals" he believed were leading the US into decline.
This highly personal view of the Nixon years is, for obvious reasons, a sad and wrenching one-a film that is nonetheless filled with spirit, humor and a bountiful sense of irony.
Never before or since has a U.S. president left behind so much self-incriminating evidence. This doc gives us a solid look at tapes hidden for forty years.
Trick Dick and Watergate revisited via lost tapes.
What proves most fascinating is that the three White House cinematographers appear to have been as deluded as their boss.
A collection of home movies so pathetic and shocking that the viewer cannot help but feel at least temporary sympathy for Richard M. Nixon.
The videos fail in their promise of revealing intimate moments, but the doc highlights how close Nixon, Haldeman, Ehrlichman, and Chapin were in other ways.
Rather than a typical by-the-numbers doc, it gives an unconventional slant on an endlessly intriguing figure.

While Our Nixon is not trying to exonerate or prove anything other than what has already happened, it is trying to understand this other side of the Nixon administration...but one of a complicated man...
There has never been an uninteresting angle on Richard Nixon - the man was too twisted - but Penny Lane's documentary sees him from several especially compelling new vantages.
Portraying Nixon as the same anxious, fearful man that's become his rep, the film never fails to add an extra dimension to that image.
Often plays like a mortifying companion to the Nixon-period sitcom "The Wonder Years."
Our Nixon provides an intriguing reverse-angle view of Nixon's time in office by presenting him both as a larger-than-life figure of Shakespearean contradictions, and as a supremely weird boss.
The retrieved home movie footage creates a lambent prism through which the '70s seem like a simpler time. It also makes Our Nixon a uniquely dynamic time capsule.
Born from a miracle of found footage, the documentary Our Nixon provides an inside portrait of the 20th century's most scandalous presidential administration.
The results are akin to seeing the Nixon presidency through the eyes of his top aides; it's as much a portrait of innocence lost as a behind-closed-doors expos.
It looks great, and touches on some important issues, but doesn't seem sure what to do with them.
While this feels like a missed opportunity, it could be worse.
The characters never convince and it spirals into plain silliness.
An ill-thought out film where raw, electric violence sits uneasily with moral posturing. It's time to call the cops...
It's not the explicit violence and primal anger that is worrying, it's the fact that Love may be tapping into something simmering in the nation's psyche.
Death Wish meets the Daily Mail
The kind of film the tabloids will call to ban. Don't take that as a reason to see it.
Potentially interesting premise and some good performances, but it quickly falls apart.
What were the capable cast thinking?
Crime-revenge-porn without any style or wit or convincing narrative.
Strong language and bone-crunching tear-ups won't appeal to the faint-hearted - but for fans of in-your-face action, this is the business.
Leaves you wondering what it wants to say and whom it's supposed to be aimed at.

Both the pic's power and its problems stem from Love deliberately taking no moral position nor offering any solutions; he gives his audience what it wants at a gut level and doesn't wimp out at the end.
Give me a bit of the old ultraviolence any day. Just make me care about it.
Racho-macho vigilante action with a cockney accent, Outlaw is made to seem more important than it really is by the presence of Sean Bean and Bob Hoskins in key roles
Outlaw commits an unforgivable offense. It makes the vigilante genre boring.
