Never patronising nor begging for sympathy, it attempts to show how this couple experience the world, from the sensual delights of walking along a seashore to the very real ordeal of changing a light bulb.
A portrait of practical symbiosis in both domestic and emotional terms.
Gentle, simply told love stories are as rare in documentaries these days as they are in narrative film. That alone makes Yi Seung-jun's "Planet of Snail" a standout.
A deeply moving documentary about love, living with disabilities, savoring the senses, and being present.
There is a psychological complexity to this simply-made film that speaks quietly about great things.
This is a unique love story with a universal resonance.
The senses of taste, smell and touch aggregate to create a new perceptual cosmos.
An engrossing slice of modern history.
Quietly heroic in every way.
Here is an intriguing documentary, with some impressive talking heads, all about the secret history of South Africa and the end of apartheid.
You'll need a rewatch to understand what's going on, but the filmmaking is not exciting enough to really warrant it.
Momentous!
Unless you think bored rich men who want to place themselves at the centre of history are intrinsically virtuous, Plot For Peace will leave you fizzing with frustration.
This documentary prises out French (but Algerian-born) businessman Jean-Yves Ollivier into the light and reveals the remarkable role he played in the end of apartheid.
Revisionist history doc chronicles Frenchman's secret role in toppling Apartheid.
Plot for Peace proves enthralling.
That rare documentary that both augments the historical record and is paced like a thriller.
If you're not steeped in the recent history of southern Africa, the timeline can prove hard to follow.
Illuminating, but too dry and exhausting.
It's just as thrilling as it is edifying.
Not everyone is an unalloyed fan of Ollivier, but it's hard not to admire his effectiveness.
A surprising reassessment of troubled times.
All the major players are interviewed and the directors of Plot for Peace are canny enough to allow the arguments that still remain to get equal airing.
It's a remarkable story, one very few know about. This exciting documentary reclaims this man for history, while showing us how a belief in peace and diplomacy can sometimes make the impossible real.
It is so peculiar and doesn't seem to care that it strays from the usual western, that therein lies its charm.
A mildly diverting modern western and buddy-buddy movie.
Pocket Money is a real curiosity, all style and no movie.

A nondescript movie that never takes flight despite the initial interest that the plot of twilight tints seems to have, due to the tone of its photography, the music or the endearing song of Carole King. [Full Review in Spanish]

This second Ka-Kui adventure rests comfortably in-between the others, overflowing with Chan's patented stuntwork and comic high jinks, and as such, it's a fine introduction to the Jackie Chan phenomenon.
Judged on its own merits, it outstrips just about every other action movie of the past fifteen years.
As seqncias de ao so intensas, mas a trama  maante e as piadas, infantis demais.
Even though Police Story 2 is the weakest of the franchise, it's still great entertainment.
It's not Chan's most memorable film but if fits neatly into 90 minutes and packs in lots of fun along the way.
Chan is the heart and brain of the Police Story films, and the lengths he goes to in order to impress and entertain extend beyond what we see on screen.
...[shows] writer-director-star Jackie Chan in his finest fighting style -- along with his usual over mugging for the camera.

[Police Story 2] features all of the hallmarks of a great Jackie Chan film - lots of crazy action, visually clear direction, and wacky sensibility that once again sees Chan taking on the spirit of Buster Keaton and Charlie Chaplin.

Arresting fight scenes well orchestrated. Whatever area the fights take place in, everything in the vicinity will be used to fight with; whether it's a shoe, two small steps, or a sock - Chan will find a way to use them creatively during the fight.
If the comedy routines occasionally fall flat, there's nothing second-rate about the fights, falls and other stunt-dependent routines that are the bread and butter of this series.
the dexterity of not just Chan's physicality, but his balancing of comedy and suspense and violence and intrigue is what makes his films so consistently enjoyable
Police Story 2 saves a lot of the action for the third act, and that third act is a doozy
The film's paralytic self-seriousness fails to mesh with its outlandish characters and scenarios.

Evidently, the extreme focus on action takes a toll to the narrative, although I found this aspect beneficial to a point, since this tactic does not allow much space for the illogicalities that formed a large part of the first's story.
A poorly balanced, overlong picture that is neither outrageously funny in its levity nor incredibly awe-inspiring in its action sequences.
Pointed social commentary shines through in this uneven but amusing pregnancy farce.
An amusing screwball comedy with a refreshingly complex female lead, but unevenly blended with drama at times.
Preggoland is a pale, predictable comedy that makes one laugh and feel too rarely, despite the best efforts of a strong ensemble.
There's satiric comedy to be mined from the conflicting messages society still sends about pregnancy, motherhood, and women's worth, but the script isn't smart enough to explore them.
Throughout, Sonja Bennett embodies slackness as an affectation, not a raw response to a culture of authenticity-killing productivity.
[It's] constructed exactly like a middlebrow studio comedy but lacking the directorial verve that might make it play like one.
...Bennett, a prolific character actress, deserves a much better starring vehicle than this.
There's satiric comedy to be mined from the conflicting messages society still sends about pregnancy, motherhood, and women's worth, but the script isn't smart enough to explore them.
For all the implausible, coincidental and slapstick moments, there's a caustic veracity and trenchant social commentary in "Preggoland" that rings particularly true ...
Bennett creates a memorable character in feisty Ruth and there's enough comedy and redemption to make Preggoland an enjoyable romp.
A compelling, periodically amusing look at conformity and misunderstanding, finding some fresh material to mine with a plot that's already informed a wide range of comedy projects.
Preggoland is a pale, predictable comedy that makes one laugh and feel too rarely, despite the best efforts of a strong ensemble.
The script slyly pokes fun at the beatification of pregnant women and is smart enough to consider the serious issue of infertility at the same time.
Pointed social commentary shines through in this uneven but amusing pregnancy farce.
Part Todd Solondz, John Waters, Nicole Holofcener, and Bridesmaids, the bitter and cynical Preggoland is a unique comedy.
...Bennett, a prolific character actress, deserves a much better starring vehicle than this.
[It's] constructed exactly like a middlebrow studio comedy but lacking the directorial verve that might make it play like one.
Let's not belabour this. Preggoland is a misguided comedy about a thirtysomething woman who pretends to be pregnant on a whim.
The movie's flaw is that it mixes tones. Ruth, her relatives and her fellow workers are realistically played, but her gal-pal buddies are caricatures.
For all the implausible, coincidental and slapstick moments, there's a caustic veracity and trenchant social commentary in "Preggoland" that rings particularly true ...
Light on its feet, frequently hilarious, and wonderfully entertaining.
Stop laughing long enough, and you'll see that it's a picture about compromised lives and love for sale. But no one who watches Priceless will stop laughing for that long.
This broadly amoral take on Breakfast at Tiffany's suffers from a serious case of who-should-we-care-for: He's a sap, she's a soulless vamp, their patrons are either cruel, self-deluding or both.
The outcome is as predictable as a high summer electric bill, but chemistry and charm go a long way.
The scene in which Elmaleh's Jean is caught waiting tables is alone enough to make the script's eventual romantic-comedy pitfalls forgivable.
Priceless is a bauble -- an art-house diamond made of paste that somehow still gives you good glimmer for the money.
There's not much substance to "Priceless," but what is there is effortlessly crafted and entertaining, and the locales in Nice and Monte Carlo are just spectacular.
Under director-writer Pierre Salvadori, Priceless provides lightweight, predictable entertainment that will make you yearn for the Tautou of yesteryear.
A pleasant little piece of puffy French pastry reminiscent of many other pleasant little pieces of puffy French pastry.

As we watch Irene and Jean prostitute themselves with their weathered, moneyed marks, the vibe isn't playful or mischievous but tedious and vulgar. The accommodations might be four-star, but the movie is strictly Motel 6.
It has the feel of a classic French farce, and it's as cute and upbeat as a comedy set on the French Riviera ought to be.
Tautou positively sparkles as a crafty master of the French Riviera sexual-favors-for-financial-rewards shell game.

It's Tautou's showcase and if her endlessly calculating Irene displays little of the childlike innocence Hepburn gave the role, she brings her own magic to the table. Every move she makes is endearing and she's never looked more stylishly beautiful.
A hilarious, class-conscious French farce which features more coupling and uncoupling than you might be able to keep track of.
Priceless begins as standard, unconvincing, assembly-line French farce and ends as a cop-out, feel-good rom-com. In between, it develops into something considerably more interesting.
The film has a lot more grace than you'd expect; it's not frantic, but actually rather breezy.
A charming French romantic comedy that salutes love as the only thing that can truly turn your world around.
[Tautou] makes this sometimes creaky, comic creation work better than it should.
A breath of champagne on a warm summer night.

It's Tautou's showcase and if her endlessly calculating Irene displays little of the childlike innocence Hepburn gave the role, she brings her own magic to the table. Every move she makes is endearing and she's never looked more stylishly beautiful.
Primer's notion of time-travel creating multiple identities and an uncontrollable mise en abyme reminded me mostly of Christopher Nolan's masterly and underrated The Prestige.
An unapologetically cerebral movie of ideas.
Like the 'time boxes' in the film, 'Primer' is a meticulously constructed and compact homemade wonder...
A brilliant little indie thriller.
It's easy (and exhilarating) to be caught up by its possibilities.
Shane Carruth's Primer is a science fiction movie like no other, pushing its experimental tendencies as far as they can go without betraying the genre
It takes a lot for a movie to surprise today's jaded, seen-it, bought-the- PlayStation-version sci-fi fan. Primer can. Let it.
This movie manages to be effective about a topic as complex and difficult to render as time travel.

critic_name: Cherryl Dawson and Leigh Ann Palone
content: The movie is hard to describe and even harder to fully grasp. It's not for everybody, but could be a cult hit amongst the pocket-protector crowd.
A jigsaw puzzle made of pieces that may or may not fit together, it assumes the intelligence and interest of its audience, a brave move that pays off big.
Carruth's worthy entry in the Blair Witch Project/Pi sweepstakes is inordinately clever in making the most of modest resources.
There have of course been time-travel movies before, but never one in which the ramifications are so visceral and raw.
One of the best science fiction films I have seen, and certainly as one of the genre's best in recent years.

Certainly there are many flaws with this project, most from a technical standpoint and obviously due to the budget, but despite those shortcomings, Primer still stands out as the most intellectually stimulating film of the year.
Almost by definition problematic and difficult to follow, and being hard to understand is not the same as being smart.
In steady, assured hands and a well-thought-out script, time travel can make for sizzling tension and paradoxes that present mind-wringing puzzles.
Even as Primer's plot ends up seeming contrived, that is, arguably, the thematic point: stories are always unstable and untrustworthy.
A back-to-basics indie upstart that gets the job done well.
It's one thing to admire what writer/director/composer/actor Shane Carruth wrought on his $1.98 digicam budget; it's quite another to have to sit through the mind-numbing results.
Shot for a begged and borrowed $7,000, 'Primer' looks it: grainy-ish, fuzzy on details and effects, acting running the gamut from A to B, and clipped incomprehensible technobabble for dialogue.
Here is a film that reaches for unforeseen heights, and surpasses them.
Hayao Miyazaki has created a world simply unlike any you've seen.
[Miyazaki understands] the myriad complications of being a person in this world, a world with too many layers for a word like 'evil' to suffice, and Princess Mononoke reflects that.
A haunting, beautiful film that holds your attention despite its length and its complex plot.
A wonder to behold!

'Princess Mononoke' gives empowered voices to women (in a time where they didn't have any) & doesn't make them victims in need of a savior. It also forces audiences to look inward and question the way we consume things from the world around us.
From the very opening frames, Miyazaki proves himself a total master of the medium...
Even if you lose track of the story -- and it is sometimes a challenge to keep up with all the developments -- the movie's steady flow of exotic, powerful images remains riveting.
It's an art film, a densely plotted and visually stunning piece of animation, and not a movie for everybody.
Hayao Miyazaki is a great animator, and his Princess Mononoke is a great film.
There's ten times as much imagination in this film than in The Phantom Menace, and there's a much more engaging and multi-faceted story to boot.
The result, while not a substitute for the original, will still astound audiences with its mesmerizing vision.
The movie has a scope that makes Hollywood's homiletic, follow-your-dream fables look even more solipsistic.
It is too ambitious, too sure of its own vastness to love it; it demands respect more than affection.
It is too ambitious, too sure of its own vastness to love it; it demands respect more than affection.
Its imagery is never less than breathtakingly beautiful, and is occasionally truly awesome...
The smartest, most thoughtful, best-made cartoon you√¢(TM)re likely to see in a long time.
Absolutely breathtaking!
The movie does have potential, but in its present state it's a disappointment that few will enjoy immensely.
Princess Mononoke's greatest feat is in crafting a story that could've been so easily simple, but manages to be more morally complex than even the most epic live-action films.
It's basically a one-joke effort, but that joke has Hawn throwing herself with great gusto into the role of a bewildered spoilt brat who comes good and her Oscar-nominated performance has huge charm.
Goldie Hawn gives a charming, Oscar-nominated performance in this lightly feminist service comedy.
Great first half, boring second half.

Another depressing example of the big-screen gag-string sitcom, it turns exclusively on a plot that grew from a concept that developed from an idea that somebody should never have had - Goldie Hawn joins the army.
[Hawn's] not so gifted that she can carry a heavy load of indifferent material on her own two little shoulders, without considerable sagging.
Ugh! I lose faith in Americans when they make garbage like this into a hit.

content: This isn't the army in the commercials, but it's Goldie at her best.

Within the limitations of the genre, this story of private Benjamin ends up being entertaining at times. It doesn't add anything new, but it brings to us a new and special performance from the brilliant actress Goldie Hawn. [Full Review in Spanish]
Great first half, boring second half.
Military mockery featuring Hawn as a spoiled princess in army boots. Private Benjamin deserves combat pay for its slaphappy fish-out-of-water premise...a real hoot-and-a-half
This is arguably although unfortunately Goldie Hawn's most memorable role.
...a fairly familiar premise that's mostly employed to affable effect by filmmaker Howard Zieff...

critic_name: Cherryl Dawson and Leigh Ann Palone
content: This isn't the army in the commercials, but it's Goldie at her best.
Private Benjamin is a comic fairy tale with a delightful performance by Goldie Hawn.

Mr. Zieff demonstrates great skill in keeping the gags aloft and in finding new ways by which to free the laughs trapped inside old routines about latrine duty, war games, forced marches and calisthenics.
Funny fish-out-of-water comedy with lots of sexual content.

"Private Benjamin" seems coarse, sluggish and interminable as a comedy scenario, but the profoundly depressing aspect of it is that Goldie Hawn appears to be receding as a comedienne and emerging as a boss lady.
An aggressively obnoxious and laugh-free stupid-fest that Mr. Depp will probably cringe at the next time he's walking through his favorite DVD shop.

Enjoyable thanks to three fantastic performances, a handful of fairly amusing moments, and an interesting glimpse behind the scenes of the stand-up comedy industry.
Enjoyable thanks to three fantastic performances, a handful of fairly amusing moments, and an interesting glimpse behind the scenes of the stand-up comedy industry.

Unfunny, at times morose, comedy-drama about standup comics.

Though Punchline defies the Hollywood penchant for producing either pure comedy or straight drama, its view of those with the guts to stand before an audience and dare them to laugh is oddly uplifting.

Though Punchline defies the Hollywood penchant for producing either pure comedy or straight drama, its view of those with the guts to stand before an audience and dare them to laugh is oddly uplifting.
As someone who prefers her comedy with a side of melancholy, I'd say that the performance from Tom Hanks alone makes this a worthwhile watch.
As someone who prefers her comedy with a side of melancholy, I'd say that the performance from Tom Hanks alone makes this a worthwhile watch.

A Pyromaniac's Love Story starts out like a lighthearted charmer, and then it goes on and on and on -- circling the same plot idea so doggedly that I began to wonder idly what it might have been like as a short subject.

A precise versification ruled by the unbearable beauty of youth at its ter- and decisions for a lifetime made at the trembling moment of crisis.
A sublime achievement on every imaginable level.
Hou Hsiao-hsien's latest movie has a much quicker pulse than several of his other recent films, but it is not nearly as rich or resonant as his other work.
There is artistry and a fabulous ambiguity coursing through Hou's meditative film.
There is artistry and a fabulous ambiguity coursing through Hou's meditative film.
We get far too few opportunities in the U.S. to see Hou's gorgeous films on the big screen. If this one comes to your town, don't pass it up.
A work of uncommon emotional density.
A great companion piece to Hou's masterly Flowers of Shanghai and fresh evidence of his status as Taiwan's greatest filmmaker.

Not much happens on the surface of Hou Hsiao Hsien's latest film, a black-lit, Taipei nocturne shot in velvety tones of purple and black by ace cinematographer Mark Lee Ping-bing. Nevertheless, it can break your heart.
Recalls the unease that crept over the world's youth back at the turn of the last century.
Vicki's extensive narration is emotionally distancing and her character is too passive to sustain interest.
The combination of the thick sensuality of Mark Lee Ping-bing's cinematography and the gradual fascination that Hou's measured rhythms exert keep you watching.
Recalls the unease that crept over the world's youth back at the turn of the last century.
A ravishing bauble about la dolce vita in Taiwan.
It's not only a masterpiece, but also Hou's most accessible film to date.
Unlike most coming of age films, it is wise enough to realize that there isn't some magical epiphany in which a character instantly moves from childhood to adulthood.
Amazing film.
A hypnotic, provocative film.

Lavish and disturbing, if somewhat cold. Adjani is typically solid.
Queen Margot is one of the great modern historicals. This is not a polite drawing-room story of men in tights and women in ruffled collars.
It's Romeo and Juliet knee-deep in carnage, staged with Jacobean fury, lurid sensuality and high style by the recklessly gifted Chereau.
Queen Margot is like elaborate illustrations for a book we haven't read.

Serving as opening night of the 1994 Cannes Festival, this bloody account of French royalty divided critics, often along national lines, eliciting debates of French versus Hollywood cinema; good production values help this overlong violent saga.
Among its many other accomplishments, 'Queen Margot' deserves a special prize for its inventive use of poisons - one receives "death by book."
A model of heaving, combustible history, in which period lavishness and performance energy aren't mutually exclusive.
Is Alex Ross Perry America's best contemporary filmmaker?
It's a one-note drama of simmering resentment. That note is sustained with impressive conviction.
...both a self-conscious homage and a frustrating dither.
At times, the style is very mannered but Moss and Waterston give rich and subtle performances as the two feuding friends who provide a twisted reflection of one another.
Its effects will stick with you, even if you don't quite understand them.
The bitterly hilarious barbs that defined [Alex Ross Perry's] prior work have curdled into something darker than black comedy (but not totally without humor).
Interesting, arty riff on early Polanski and Bergman's Persona.
Queen of Earth plays like a horror. Yet, at its heart it is a devastating story of depression and its impact.
[A] delicately calibrated portrait of dissolution which points to the versatility of writer/director Alex Ross Perry.
Not all of Queen Of Earth gels perfectly, but when it does, it can be breathtaking.
... throws acid on its off-putting characters and their hopeless situations and rubs moviegoers' faces in it rather than offering any substantial insight or depth.
For some viewers, the acidity level of Perry's movie will be too high to stomach. For others-anyone who thinks that there are too many warm hugs in Strindberg, for example-"Queen of Earth" awaits.
Queen is as much about the bitterness of women as it is about the cruelty of men.
If only Perry's direction had been as brave as the performances, Queen of Earth would be unmissable.
You have to be in the right mood for it, but this is one of the season's finest films.
It may sound unpleasant to watch, and there are moments of discomfort, but Perry and his performers draw you into this raw chamber piece.
Elizabeth Moss gives a scorchingly down-to-earth performance as Catherine, a woman on the cusp of a colossal mental breakdown.
Unlikable drama about so-called best friends has cursing.
What should be a weekend of bestie comfort becomes fraught with expectations, assumptions, and resentment.
The film isn't a thriller per se, but it has the tension and atmosphere of one, only with emotional violence substituting for the physical kind.
A wonderfully refreshing slice of urban ghetto life.
There is a raw tenderness at the heart of the film that actually catches us off guard at the end.
A marvel of closely observed, intimately captivating moments.
Tender and funny.
A beguiling coming-of-age story set in New York during one sweltering summer when teenagers are seesawing between bravado and timid vulnerability in the face of sex's mysteries.

critic_name: Cherryl Dawson and Leigh Ann Palone
content: There is so much going on in this movie: first-love, painful adolescent moments, family drama [and comedy], -- and every aspect of it works.
Every frame of this movie feels real.
Contains some of the most loose-limbed, realistic dialogue ever uttered in a film about teenagers.
ultimately, it lacks the backbone, the thematic heft, to be anything beyond a sweet redemption story
The R rating is understandable, but absurd. This is a family film in the most complicated and, ultimately, most cheering sense.
A comedy in the best sense -- it draws its life from the pitch-perfect authenticity of its characters.
It wonderfully captures both the innocent side of teenage puppy love and the posturing that always threatens to end that innocence.
Protagonists Rasuk and Marte are very good here, as are the others.
Raising Victor Vargas gets everything just right.
Real, sweet and often really sweet.
Packed with the type of pyrotechnics that come from the purest of sources: good performers and worthwhile material.
It is throughly involving, depicting the real and recognizable frustrations of teenagers and the grown-ups who have responsibility for them.
A coming-of-age movie that really nails it.
Raising Victor Vargas gets everything just right.
Sweet-natured, charming comedy-drama.
Why not the automatic alliteration Ralph Wrecks? At just shy of two-hours, many younger kids will end up as bored & restless as their parents & grandparents.
Ralph Breaks the Internet is the cinematic equivalent of clickbait - you just can't help yourself but follow it down the rabbit hole.
Visually it's absolutely stunning, the colorful world of the Internet universe is mesmerizing, and the way the characters are 'transported' from one site to another is so fun and clever!
It makes for a cute, engaging movie with seemingly endless opportunities for Disney brand synergy.
There are enough good moments in Ralph Breaks the Internet that you should not delete any ideas of seeing it. Just be ready to hit escape when things turn to the dark web.
The highly witty original was about learning and appreciating the groove you're in; the sequel seems stuck in it.
It's pretty incredible to see how the filmmakers easily and boldly slip concepts right from the therapist's office into the wild rumpus through the internet.
In what sometimes feels like a dare for the most advertising space in a single frame, Disney's latest delays its emotional core too late in the game.

An awesome movie for pre-teens that uses hip humor to comment on our world while being unafraid to make us feel real emotions. Add Disney princesses freed from their corsets, and you've got the feel good Disney ethos updated for our electronic age.
...the scene featuring the princesses dispelling their girly pre-Me Too-era images is worth the price of admission alone.
Yes, there are a lot of in-jokes, but they are consistently funny, and Ralph and Vanellope have a gift for turning standard tropes sideways.
With the help of Reilly and Silverman's performances, Ralph Breaks the Internet brings more compassion than you're likely to see the next ten times you go online.

Ralph Breaks the Internet is firing on all cylinders and repeat viewings will be a must to catch every gag, while John C. Reilly and Sarah Silverman are just as heckin' delightful as they were first time around.
Though Ralph Breaks the Internet is marketed to kids, its PG rating and pop culture references make it a fun ride for childless adults too.
This charming sequel is a creative, sweet adventure tale of loyalty and friendship that will delight adults and kids alike.

In a sense, Ralph Breaks The Internet is like most things online these days; it's amusing while you're engaged with it but as soon as your mind is elsewhere, there's not all that much about it to hold on to.
Fear not, because as much fun as Wreck-It Ralph is, there's no doubt that Ralph Breaks the Internet is better - smarter, funnier, and with a message that resonates for kids and adults alike.
Ralph Breaks the Internet suffers from the same insidious problems that sink almost every internet-related movie.
Colorful, clever sequel tackles complexity of online world.
Ralph Breaks the Internet works because it doesn't pander, and it doesn't simplify.

Seen in a flashback through the eyes of an adolescent, this uncommon coming-of-age tale, which raises poignant questions about the mysteries of sex and love, flaunts a superb performance from Laura Dern as the promiscuous girl
The movie is all character and situation, and contains some of the best performances of the year, especially in the ensemble acting of the four main characters.

Nobody expects this to be, say, The French Connection, but it should make a little more sense.
The overall pace is slack enough to make the movie's 93 minutes feel twice as long.
There's nothing here that's new to rush to the theater for.
Chan does his thing; Tucker does his, and everyone who buys a ticket gets exactly what they paid to see.
A lukewarm serving of similar material, microwaved long enough for audience consumption, but one that will leave you unfulfilled and hungry for something else.
This sequel is, like most sequels, a watered down version of the first film.
The outtakes that run over the end credits [are] the only spontaneous thing about the movie.
Despite Tucker's valiant energy and Chan's ever-game clowning, just not as funny as the original.
Succeeds as a slightly convoluted, paint-by-the-numbers buddy/action comedy with fast, funny banter and well-choreographed fight scenes.
Gives mindless entertainment a bad name.

In this film about murder, the last 10 minutes are enough to kill me.

V/H/S/2 is by no means a perfect movie; unlike its first installment, however, its hits far outweighs its misses.
None of the chapters use the unifying formal conceit to any real advantage; only one, directed by Timo Tjahjanto and The Raid: Redemption's Gareth Huw Evans, is worth a rental.
If it's not great V/H/S/2 is still a vast improvement over the first; brutal and efficient and immensely entertaining.
The wraparound hour may not be very good, but those middle 40 minutes are a lot of fun.
The final product is a lo-fi, handheld hellraiser with a varying success rate but with more ballsy gusto than most mainstream horrors.
The horror movie equivalent of a wimp who relies on steroids to lend him a fearsome appearance while his eyes still tell the truth.
A fine string of scary installments that makes the original V/H/S, even its better entries, pale in comparison.

If you're a fan of the original V/H/S production, this is bound to compel you, however if you left the last feeling somewhat disgruntled and underwhelmed, don't expect enough of an increase in quality to sway you this time around.
VHS 2 is an improvement on its predecessor in just about every way possible - though, it still suffers as an uneven mix of parts (with varying quality).
Agreeable, but the tape's been slightly chewed since compilation #1.

Safe House may be faux Bourne, but for those counting the moments till the release of The Bourne Legacy next August, it might seem better than no Bourne at all.
Even at its most frantic and mechanical, the movie relies on Washington to provide a visual anchor, some sociopathic calm amid the storm.
Ultimately, it dashes into so many close-ups of carnage and neckbreaking, it skids scuzzily close to spy-snuff. Call this Bourne-porn; Safe House needed a safe word.
Ryan Reynolds is in a decent movie!
The action scenes are drawn out so long that it's like watching a live action re-enactment of Peter Griffin battling the Giant Chicken on "Family Guy!"

[Safe House] is utterly predictable stuff, in case you haven't already figured that out by now.

A flat thriller that could use a little danger.
It's sharply well-made and acted, but nothing about it remotely scratches beneath the surface.
"Safe House" boasts not one but two highly engaging stars in Denzel Washington and Ryan Reynolds. Unfortunately, their chemistry is disappointingly underused in favor of gunbattles and car chases.
Excellent performances from both Washington and Reynolds can't can't save Safe House from its boilerplate-thriller bones.
It is loud and entertaining enough to watch, even if it does all feel rather familiar.

While director Espinosa hones in on the ambiguous battle between Weston's idealism and Frost's cynicism, British cinematographer Oliver Wood - who filmed the last two Bourne movies - shoots the hell out of everything.
This is a film filled with lines like, "Everyone betrays everyone." But the banality of those words almost disappears when Denzel Washington utters them.
Action-oriented blur of movie relies on Denzel Washington to hold it together
Safe House will never be over, we think, as we watch Denzel Washington and Ryan Reynolds rush around Johannesburg and points east, west, north, south.
It's ultimately difficult to recall a mainstream Hollywood movie saddled with as obnoxious and rage-inducing visuals as Safe House...

Theoretically, Saint John of Vegas may look good from a distance, but when seen up close it's only a house of cards.
[Its] randomly flung-in episodes are just quirky padding around a thin, one-twist story.
A funereally unfunny comedy by debut writer-director Hue Rhodes.
A dark comedy that drolly tweaks idiosyncratic versions of the American Dream as a hilarious assortment of characters tempt a sad sack gambling addict in the Nevada desert.
It's a kind of cinematic purgatory, halfway between eternal reward and eternal damnation. The question is: What did I do to deserve such mediocrity?
Rhodes doesn't find much more for them to do than flit from one quirk-filled vignette to the next.
The promised quirkiness is muted and dull, and the stakes seem much lower than they ought to.
As a portrait of one man's journey toward dignity, Saint John isn't bad enough to create its own special circle of hell. As a comedy, though, it's anything but divine.
Such an inventive and quirky film, it's hard to ignore what a distinctive voice Rhodes brings to indie comedy. Casting Buscemi in this role couldn't be more perfect.
A dark comedy that drolly tweaks idiosyncratic versions of the American Dream as a hilarious assortment of characters tempt a sad sack gambling addict in the Nevada desert.
The performances are strong--even the minor characters--and the atmosphere and tone are spot-on for a dark comedy.
Not quite heavenly, despite uniformly excellent performances and an effective, Tarantino-esque balance of humor and menace.
Saint John of Las Vegas was a bad script that somehow got made into a bad movie with good people in it.
The writing is semicoherent at best, and the buddies of this meandering road trip are not only mismatched but dislikable.
It's minor, but I enjoyed it, largely because of the people on-screen, but also for the sneaky sincerity of writer-director Hue Rhodes' chronicle of one compulsive gambler's slouch toward redemption.
The oft-used ploy of forcing an odd couple into a car and sending them off to uncharted territory is trotted out yet again here, but to minimal comic or emotional effect.
I don't think that this movie has a coherent sense of what it's about, what its characters are doing, what kind of tone of comedy or drama or quirkiness it's trying to strike.
John's last name notwithstanding, his journey through the underworld is not exactly a divine comedy. It's not in the top 50 percent of Buscemi movies, either, but it's not bad.
Steve Buscemi cuts so droll and heart-wrenching a figure in Hue Rhodes's deadpan road movie Saint John of Las Vegas that the plot -- shaggy and inconsequential as it is -- gets in the way.
Theoretically, Saint John of Vegas may look good from a distance, but when seen up close it's only a house of cards.

Exactly the movie you suppose it to be, except in one, absolutely crucial regard: it's weirdly allergic to fun.
It's hard to appreciate San Andreas as much more than a series of special effects vistas: impeccably detailed, completely plastic.

The special effects may look real but the relationships are made of much less sturdy stuff - it doesn't matter how impressively a building collapses ... if you don't believe the scriptwriter is prepared to kill any of them in the name of tension.
Succeeds at exploiting a proven disaster-movie formula without troubling itself much with little things like plot, character, and dialogue.

The end result might be a melange of scenes taken from other films, but in a summer season groaning with sci-fi and superhero sequels, this survival epic must be given credit for striking out on its own.

Paul Giamatti is perfectly cast as the rumpled scientist and his scenes are by far the most interesting. It causes one to wonder if San Andreas might have worked better if the entire film had focused on his character.
The main problem is that the film can't decide whether it wants to be a proper disaster movie or a Dwayne Johnson action vehicle.

San Andreas just wants to show destruction and it wants you to revel in it. That's nearly impossible given the timing of the release and the fact that reveling in nothing but glorified destruction got old at least five years ago.
The special effects aren't bad for a lower-budget ($100 million) blockbuster, though director Brad Peyton and his writers often deploy them in downright laughable ways.
In San Andreas, The Big One finally hits California, and not even Dwayne Johnson's mutant biceps can keep those infamous tectonic plates from separating.

Like a tsunami, the special effects are omnipresent and overwhelm the weak story line. They are absolutely, definitely worth the price of admission, regardless of the totally erroneous science. But see it in 2D not the color-muting 3D.
When you're watching the impossibly charismatic former wrestler on screen, you'll not only forgive the movie around him, you'll want to throw Pulitzers, Nobel Prizes and even Miss World crowns at it.

San Andreas may CGI-shake the digital earth, but it's really stray bits inside a hollow shell, and the Dolby howl of the sound design is just to mask the empty rattle of the film, a flimsy shell filled with cliches and summer-dumb spectacle.

I was pleasantly surprised. This is a highly entertaining disaster film. It's a scary, pulse-pounding thrill ride...also emotional without getting overly schmaltzy, which is difficult for a lot of movies to accomplish, let alone an action film.
The plot is implausible and the situations even more preposterous.

There are things in San Andreas that no one would have dreamed of seeing 40 years ago, when Earthquake (with its tacky, plaster-cracking "Sensurround") represented the state of the art. But nothing means anything.
Mid-movie Dwayne Johnson's Ray is told if he can't save his daughter no one can. He saves her but can't save the movie. A disaster of a disaster movie.
Sets out to prove that The Rock can go toe-to-toe with two earthquakes and a tsunami and come out on top by the sheer power of his biceps and a helpful screenwriter.
Who'd have thought that the demise of several cities full of unnamed people would act as a perverse sort of marriage counselling for a couple in nuptial distress?
Although it exhibits a heartfelt connection with the city's half-invisible population of illegal immigrants, its myriad inconsistencies and strained plotting are increasingly frustrating.
Zalla wants to know the point where boys become cynics, men become vultures, and the hardened become vulnerable.
[Director] Zalla prefers to wallow in the dead-end, an approach that's initially powerful, then numbing.
Eventually, of course, all the characters will have to collide for a final reckoning, but that moment strains credulity to the breaking point and sabotages the entire enterprise
Justifiably bleak, exquisitely acted drama of a Mexican teen who seeks his dad in New York only to find that a young man who befriended him claims to be the son.
Plot flaws and all, we can be glad that the picture was made -- because of its acting.
The grimy elegance of this Sundance award winner elevates it well above the standard-issue immigrant drama.
A suspenseful movie with no intention of sugarcoating the daily hardships of New York's underclass.
Stands out from the recent wave of movies about the plight of immigrants coming to the United States...because it's more suspenseful than heart-tugging.
Stands out from the recent wave of movies about the plight of immigrants coming to the United States...because it's more suspenseful than heart-tugging.
An intriguing, if flawed mystery set in the shadowy subterranean world of undocumented Mexican immigrants.
[Director Christopher] Zalla may have provided his characters with a overly constructed tragedy, but his eye for city life and his seeming gift with actors promises astute, generous work to come.

A moving story combined with first rate acting and a great screenplay by a new, but determined, writer/director make this an indie film not to be missed. Modern film noir from the streets of Mexico to the streets of America.

Sangre De Mi Sangre could have done without a few plot coincidences and the film's relentless mean street look seems studied at times. But the film's behavioral honesty pumps vibrant, undeniable life through every frame.

Sangre de Mi Sangre stacks up as an original achievement in its own chosen genre, that of the troubled immigrant in a land of advertised promise, who too often is inflicted with pain and exploitation.
[Jesus] Ochoa is such a masterful actor that he makes things fairly interesting despite the script, with Hernandez and Espindola well-cast as two young men operating by different moral compasses.
To write Sangre off as an unglamorous fairytale devalues what screenwriter/director Zalla achieves.
Stumbles through a maddening screenplay but nevertheless generates true emotional energy.

One of Kurosawa's lesser works, but still well worth a rental.
The charm of this fascinating Toho production, stylishly directed by Akira Kurosawa, is the personality of the hero, powerfully played by Toshiro Mifune.

This is fun but, compared with Kurosawa's other 60s efforts, relatively slight.

Rather than simply repeating the successful formula of Yojimbo, which incorporated humor but largely played it straight, Sanjuro flips the script for a largely comic action picture punctuated by a dark, rug-yanking conclusion. [Blu-ray]

A step down from the superior Yojimbo, but still enjoyable thanks to Toshiro Mifune's scruffy rogue.

I was afraid the same plot of Toshiro Mifune as the unwashed vagabond who cleans up the town wgs becoming monotonous... But director Akira Kurosawa added something new in the incongruous humor injected.
The relative linearity of the film can't help but come as something of a disappointment after the feast of Yojimbo.
Short and sweet. If you haven't seen Yojimbo, go rent that before this. If you haven't seen Seven Samurai, go rent that before Yojimbo. And once you've done those two, graduate to Sanjuro.

It holds up beautifully, mainly because it puts the characters and their flaws first and the disco nightlife second. Travolta remains an amazing, graceful presence on the dance floor.
Saturday Night Fever is wonderfully honest and completely accurate when it comes to depicting that stagnant environment that keeps young people like Tony pinned down.

A very intelligent character study that just happens to have some of the coolest dance scenes ever made.

A black comedy that frequently goes down like the most bitter coffee imaginable.

Two fine performances, a subject close to all our hearts and a screenplay that manages to be both brilliantly witty and almost unbearably poignant add up to the best family comedy-drama since Little Miss Sunshine.

Darkly hilarious, Tamara Jenkins' The Savages captures the cruel demographic joke facing many boomers who are forced to take care of aging parents at a point when they haven't entirely figured out their own lives.
This bittersweet X-ray of American family dynamics may not be a Hallmark-card notion of a holiday movie, but it's one any son or daughter can take to heart.
One of those small, perfectly crafted, bittersweet family dramas it touches on so many truths it's almost painful to watch at times.
Jenkins walks this dramatic tightrope with breathtaking ease. The humor is never forced but always springs from the characters and situations naturally.
Ordinarily, Linney plays annoying characters. This one is a lot less annoying than most of them.
The latter half suffers from degenerative indie-itis, that epidemic syndrome whose main symptom is unwarranted interest in the ennui afflicting well-read urban misfits.
Excellent performances mark "The Savages," with Linney and Hoffman each navigating characters who could have become unlikable had they not been shaded with nuance.
With the help of acting giants, [director Tamara] Jenkins turns The Savages into a twisted, bittersweet pleasure.
These are fascinating, three-dimensional individuals brought into the foreground by a pair of today's finest actors.
Assured and sharp, The Savages is only Jenkins' second feature-length film. You'd never know it.
Tamara Jenkins' writing and direction are superb.
The Savages is funny in the if-you-didn't-laugh-you'd-cry way and superbly acted by all involved
Draws its strength mainly from the complex, familiar character of the sister, as written (and directed) by Tamara Jenkins and played expertly by Linney.
Linney and Hoffman deliver two more creatively textured performances in this story about the strain and comfort of family relationships.
Reality wounds but also heals in The Savages, writer-director Tamara Jenkins' cuttingly funny-sad family drama.

Director Jenkins handles this tricky material with tact and a nuanced touch -- there are laughs, but the circumstance is real enough to resonate with anyone who's experienced the confusion, guilt, and disorientation that such a circumstance imposes.
This is a modest, thoughtful, independent production of exceptional insight and quietly devastating power.
A melodrama better suited to the Logo network than to theaters.
Save Me doesn't poke fun at anyone's beliefs. It takes a more nuanced humanistic approach.

Allen brings such conviction to the part that it's almost possible to look past the gaps in Mark's development. In the end, you may not buy each step he takes, but you respect Allen's attempt to make the effort seem genuine.

Sounds like a great idea for a gay porno, but the soapy Save Me actually takes itself seriously.
While Save Me does seem like a TV movie, it is refreshingly honest and heartfelt.
With a sensitive, intelligent screenplay and extremely honest performances, this drama goes far beyond its issue-of-the-week premise.

As disagreements continue to heat up between red states and blue states, and liberals and evangelicals in this country, Save Me makes its debut as a story that may be in search of unlikely middle ground.
Here after a long dry spell is an example of queer filmmaking at its best. Hallelujah my gay brethren!

Interesting, provocative film about one of the most polarizing issues in our culture.
Too much of the film involves set pieces of two characters' awkward dialogue or a single one's halting monologue-confession about life problems.
The ostensibly final movie in the increasingly preposterous Saw series offers neither much drama nor horror, unfortunately for audiences.
The central storyline is starting to feel really played out, but there's a palpable sense of actual fun to this alleged final film.

The filmmakers continue to regurgitate the same pile of puke each and every year for us to lap up. Sure, those chewed chunks of bile-soaked carrot are now in "eye-popping" 3D, but that certainly doesn't make them taste any better.
They're just going through the motions, only this time they try to compensate for a lack of ingenuity by having the guts splatter in three dimensions.
Saw 3D is sicko-exploitative, viscera-spewing trash, but at least it has a lean and mean pace and focus, and it isn't clotted with backstory.
It's kind of amusing in the sheer silliness of its splattery shenanigans. I don't think that was intended, but I'll take whatever value I can get out of the thing.
With all the money this series has behind it, couldn't the studio have hired a director and writers who had the ability to set a little mood? Make at least something of an effort? Obviously, not.
Goes down in history as the most unnecessarily convoluted horror franchise of all time, and that's the nicest thing you can say about it.
It's the same old grisly song and dance, and even the 3-D fails to breathe new life into its tired bones.
a sloppy, subpar slasher flick
Saw has shown a ferocious unwillingness to evolve.
The same old putrid corpse.

I was actually rather bored by this listless and, if you'll excuse the pun, lifeless sequel, and if it is the concluding chapter in my humble opinion it is a final cut that couldn't have come soon enough.
It's the kitchen-sink chapter.
This repetitive round of mind-numbing, stupidly-elaborate traps will have you pleading for your soul to be saved by Tinkerbell, not Tobin Bell.
It's all bunk and has been for years.
Aside from the clever engineering of the traps (and perhaps one two-timing trollop that had it coming), the story is formulaic at best.
Like a stumpy limb requiring quick cauterization via steam pipe (our first cringe), the Saw series is begging for closure.
I would have preferred a better written film with relevant action that hinged on Jigsaw's original spirit than this mess of a splatterfest.
I'm grateful that I (presumably) never have to see any more of these ever again.
Saw IV has a nice twist ending - actually three twists in one - and might be the best of the sequels.
At a certain point you have to wonder how long audiences are going to keep flocking to this stuff.
If we must get a new Saw movie every Halloween, at least the franchise is evolving and not just regurgitating the exact same formula.
If it ever had a prime, the Saw franchise is well past it...a mess...and an ugly mess at that.
We now find ourselves in the downward slope of the Saw series as Saw IV stretches credibility to the breaking point.
Were it not for the saving grace of Tobin Bell's mere presence, there's little doubt that Saw IV would come off about as well as a typical straight-to-video horror sequel.
With Saw IV, the pieces have all come together and [it's] the best of the lot.

The reports of torture porn's demise may have been greatly exaggerated, but this fourth entry in the mutilate-yourself-or-die series joins what may be the worst genre of the decade: the lamely ''sympathetic'' serial-killer backstory.
Over the course of [its] sequels, the Saw franchise took a novel, if distasteful, idea and basically tortured it to death.
The absurdity reaches new highs in Saw IV, which asks us to swallow developments that simply aren't logistically possible, never mind realistic.
as cheap and cheesy as its brethren, but oddly boring for long stretches
This gruesomely efficient horror sequel shows noticeable wear and tear.
Jigsaw is an interesting character with an interesting worldview and an interesting way of carrying out his will. It's too bad the movies themselves aren't worthy of him.
Might be the best since the first, but still a task to watch. A painful, meaningless task.
The games, the traps, are still the thing and as long as Jigsaw's flunkies continue to build 'em, we will come.
The dullest Saw in the shed.

Michael Douglas surges ahead in Solitary Man with the best work he's done in the decade since Wonder Boys.
A worthwhile watch even if an overlooked film.
The film's knotty relationships and crisp dialogue are surpassed only by Douglas' captivating turn as a troubled heel whose pathetic behavior fools no one, least of all himself.

Movie often romanticize people who live every day like it may be their last, who live like there is no tomorrow. "Solitary Man" shows the other side of that, the loneliness, the broken relationships, the burned bridges, and the pain left behind.

Douglas' performance should not take anything away from this terrific cast.

If weapons and wizardry get your blood up, and you prefer your movies dark and brooding and - the sandals, Solomon Kane fits the bill. It may lack The Lord Of The Rings' majesty, but Robert E. Howard fans will lap it up.

If weapons and wizardry get your blood up, and you prefer your movies dark and brooding and - the sandals, Solomon Kane fits the bill. It may lack The Lord Of The Rings' majesty, but Robert E. Howard fans will lap it up.

Mr. Basset is too enamored of the usual action film clichs ... But he has a graphic visual style that suits the simplistic material and he keeps you watching even as the wet, sucking sounds of skewered flesh grows tedious.
...a wet blanket of gloom and humorlessness.
Dark and brooding, and fairly Lord of the Rings-esque in a smaller budget kind of way. Purefoy deftly handles the action like any A-lister leading man can. Great fun.

It grinds along on the dubious strengths of its generic battle sequences and midbudget special effects, whipped up around a stone-faced hero who's part Christ figure, part embodiment of wickedness, all crippling bore.
It's doubtful Kane will ever rival Conan--Howard's other creation--in terms of fame, but his world is definitely one that I would be willing to visit again.
James Purefoy is excellent as Kane, his natural charisma and charm ably compensating for the fact that Solomon does some pretty terrible things.
A hugely entertaining adaptation of the dark comic series.

There's plenty that's good here: a serious tone, steady pacing, muddy and bloody scenery and a convincing turn by Purefoy in his own west country accent. But Kane is an ill fit into the origins tale template; it's a story with few surprises.

A thoroughly entertaining demon-slaying romp set in 16th Century Britain. Boasting an impressive lead performance by James Purefoy as the anti-hero seeking redemption, the film bears enough individual traits and dynamism to overcome its numerous flaws.
A hugely entertaining adaptation of the dark comic series.
Uneven and far less deep that it believes itself to be, Solomon Kane is nevertheless a solid B-movie diversion that excels when sticking to its pulpy, action-fantasy roots.
It amalgamates action, drama, horror and fantasy into a unique hybrid that thrives on all parts at once, while not betraying the core of Howard's original character.
A borrowed mlange of Lord of the Rings pomp, weightless CGI sorcery, artfully smudged cheekbones and exceedingly dull sword slicings.

Sort of a neutered Todd Solondz comedy. No sperm shots, murders, or pedophilia. Just lonely people trying to reach out now and then to each other, + numerous shots of the sun's rays reacting on soap bubbles.
McCormick builds a delicate web connecting ordinary Portlanders who share loose, accidental narrative connections but are chiefly united by a wispy, dreamy texture of life and their common home...
Some Days unspools in a depressive deadpan that might be more effective were the characters' plights not so clearly of their own making.
Like the characters, the three stories show only the most tentative signs of going anywhere.

[Matt] McCormick's eye for the small things that change a day, or a life, is sharp and compassionate; he finds the moments that initially seem unremarkable and follows them until they gradually transform into something greater.
This movie throws in a healthy dose of "quirky" shots and montages as if they were required.
Although this always interesting film doesn't quite come together at the end - it couldn't decide exactly what it wanted to say - McCormick has done a lot of things right.
The kind of American independent quirkfest that needs to be quarantined and examined, not valorized.

In an era of big studio 3D CG films, The Song of the Sea offers a lovely reminder of the personal visions drawn animation can offer.
This superb Irish animation from the director of 2009's The Secret of Kells is a treat; an enchanting and very moving "family film".
You'll leave the film knowing more than you might have imagined about Irish culture, but never once feeling subjected to anything Very Special or Good for You.
It's an absolutely visceral stunner: you may find yourself wishing you could interact with its characters, live in its vividly realized world, participate in its defining ancestral conflicts.
A quite delightful piece of magical animation.

"Song of the Sea" is a wonder to behold. This visually stunning animation masterwork, steeped in Irish myth, folklore and legend, so adroitly mixes the magical and the everyday that to watch it is to be wholly immersed in an enchanted world.
The outcome is animation so imaginative and rich that I'm sorry to admit I longed for a bit more Pixar-brand pizzazz to perk up the sluggish plot and characters - just a bit, mind you.
Song of the Sea is a stunning, magical piece of animation and an entertaining return for Tomm Moore and Cartoon Saloon.
[Tomm] Moore keeps it (un)real with painterly imagery, a Point-like narrative (whereby that which seems strange turns out to be pretty special), and two appealing kids at the center of it all.
Prettily animated family adventure infused with Irish folklore and traditional Celtic design makes for a change of pace from slick Hollywood cartoons.
A quite delightful piece of magical animation.
Aided by stellar voice work from the inimitable Brendan Gleeson, among others, Moore's gorgeous sophomore feature is steeped in a transformative sense of sadness and longing.
Beautiful Irish tale explores myths, sibling relationship.

Song Of The Sea is visually lush, but it's story is never too cluttered or busy. It doesn't depend on manic sugar rush energy to keep its intended audience of kids attention, but rather seeks to draw them into a fascinating, unique world.
Visually, this is an exquisitely composed film, and it teems with curiosities and compassion. If on occasion the story seems to wander, it arrives at an enchanting destination.

Irish director Tomm Moore's animated beauty Song of the Sea tells the sort of story that makes you crave the flickering of firelight or wish for the warmth of a blanket pulled up to your chin while mom or dad reads a bedtime tale.
Enchants on every level: story, voice work, drawing and music.
A gorgeously crafted take on Celtic myths and sibling bonds, "Sea" is a soulful smash.
This beautifully animated Irish fable has a grace and emotional resonance ...
The Celtic-influenced animation, with its leprechauns, giants and scary owls, is stunning.
Just how joyous is it - just how life-affirming, even with satire as dark and urgent as this - when a lightning bolt of a film like this comes along?
It works fine as an outrageous comedy, but the perceptive commentary will likely give it staying power. This is the fearless satire that America desperately needs right now.
Each shift in tone is Riley's way of both heightening reality... and commenting on an economic hierarchy that disadvantages people of color.
The acting is effective and the story moves right along. Director and writer Boots Riley has produced a wonderful screenplay and an extremely impressive debut film.

Pinballing frenetically between amusement, absurdity and anger, this is an unruly piece which takes pointed pot-shots at coercive capitalism before galloping toward an impressively unhinged third act.

Telemarketers as targets from which satire flows eternal were spigotted about the same time as mall cops, and that's not all this jammed-scattergun approach to comedy has in common with the terminally dopey Paul Blart.
Boots Riley...delivers a social comedy that is satirical, surreal and, thankfully, at times very funny indeed.
Sorry to Bother You is unapologetically of the moment, and yet is a madcap, gonzo masterpiece that we will still be talking about in twenty-+ years.
Sorry to Bother You will surely strike a chord with any viewer, even if it doesn't fully cohere.
It's a hugely ambitious project that ultimately caves under the weight of its own artistic intentions, but that shouldn't stop this revolutionary statement from making its mark.
An outrageous and uncompromising assault on capitalism, consumerism, racism and other unpleasant -isms that have come to define these United States of America.
Refuses to be shrugged off, ignored or overlooked.
Sorry to Bother You mixes biting socio-political satire and excellent performances from a varied cast with outlandish imagery and imaginative direction.
Will at once delight and rattle you to your bones in equal measure.

The African-American perspective that runs so powerfully through this work is the essential component that gives it its battle cry. Norma Rae gets its shoutout, but that was then. Sorry to Bother You and the saga of Cassius Green is our now.
One-part dystopian satire, one-part Faustian-morality tale, but mostly a hard-edged comedy/horror set in a world so absurd, it might just be the truth. Hugely recommended.

Anchored by his working-class angst, Riley takes broad aim at the slippery target of 21st-century capitalism, that hydra-headed dynamo with its endless powers of absorbing dissent and selling it back to the disaffected masses as neutered heroism.
An adrenalin-shot of a comedy and a fearless dissection of identity politics, corporate malevolence, and the American tendency to look the other way when confronted with horror.
A brave and radical departure from many a filmmaking norm, highly recommended to those who appreciate chances taken and rules broken.
Caustic, sharp and funny as hell, director Boots Riley's acerbic take on surviving (just) in the contemporary business world assumes its rightful place beside O Lucky Man! And Putney Swope.
In dialogue, song and story, Music still contains too much sugar, too little spice.
To enjoy director Robert Wise's Best Picture winner you must overlook the bloated, sugar-coated story, and even then it's an uphill slog.
one of the last and most successful products of a less-cynical cinematic age

Starting Out in the Evening has the feeling of a film in which the actors, left to direct themselves, played into their own self-indulgent instincts, and the only one who resisted was the old pro who knew better.

It would be easy to pass by Starting Out in the Evening through any one of a number of possible snap judgments -- too New York-y, too low-budget, too digital -- but you'd also be missing out on three of the best performances of the year.
It's a thinking person's movie in the best sense of the phrase.

It's an intimate drama -- a chamber piece, really -- that deals intelligently with intriguing themes and provocative ideas regarding the ambiguous motives and borrowed-from-life material that fuel the creative process.
Grace. Sophistication. Intelligence. Heart. We should all be so fortunate to be Starting Out In The Evening of our own lives.

The film's range of subjects and ideas quickly expands to probe the exhilaration of city life itself.

Stations of the Elevated plays like a time capsule, particularly for having no dialogue or plot. It swings to Charles Mingus's hardest bop and evokes a long-gone city, somehow more adult and confrontational even in silence.

Brian Jun makes a strong feature debut with a blue-collar drama rooted in character and community and focused on the everyday over the dramatic flare-ups...
While the territory of Steel City is as well-worn as the roads of this tiny town, the people and performances are interesting enough to warrant the detour.
It's not always a success, but the ensemble actors are fine at fleshing out purposely underwritten roles.
Writer-director Brian Jun makes it clear that Steel City isn't about big events, even crucial inciting ones. It's about day-to-day decisions and how they change and inform relationships.
Steel City is gritty, blue-collar and surprisingly dry-eyed. If it hadn't been a movie, it could have been a song off Bruce Springsteen's Nebraska album.
Soulfully in tune with the bruised blue collar lives of a Southern Illinois town where fractured existence and dead end futures conspire against the humanity of its characters.
For big chunks in the middle of the movie, Steel City seems lost and styleless, but it builds a cumulative power as we get closer to learning what's up.
Mostly Mr. Jun's script is sharp, and Laurie Metcalf, James McDaniel, America Ferrera and Raymond J. Barry in supporting roles help keep the tale mesmerizing, in a small-scale sort of way.
Brian Jun's directorial debut exhibits enough unfussy familiarity with its tattered blue-collar locale.
