Talk about a winner! Jake Gyllenhaal's gritty, multifaceted Oscar-worthy performance gives us a realistic and profound sense of what it means to be a true hero.
The story is inspirational, but predictable. It is the talented actors who carry it to another level with their outstanding performances.
Never manipulative yet always captivating, this portrait of one ordinary man is an extraordinary motion picture.
Gyllenhaal is outstanding in this inspiring warts-and-all story of a Boston bombing survivor's recovery battle.
Catches one off guard with the characters' open-hearted gestures under duress...feels as if it single-handedly restores humanity to the movies.
A conventional film worthy of Hallmark Entertainment. [Full review in Spanish]
So contrived and tidy that it's not remotely believable.
Writer-director Josh Boone populates Stuck in Love with smart characters breaking from emotional holding patterns of varying contours.
Starts sit-comish but as it becomes more complex it takes on a somewhat literary tone.
The film has its sharp moments but is invariably glib when it comes to literary matters and the relationship between books and life.
But all too soon, Boone's questionable taste level and constant, very self-conscious but none-too-deep emphasis on the what, how and why of Writers becomes oppressive and extremely precious.
This is Kinnear's best role in a few years, and Connelly's, too: her attempts to win back Collins's stroppy prodigy have an emotional generosity her acting has lacked lately.
The sharp edges of the story are sentimentally sanded down; there's a fair bit of slush, and it's a pretty quaint view of what writers and a writer's life are actually like.
[Boone's] semiautobiographical film is a confident, at times wonderfully nuanced, and often well-paced rewrite of his own parents' divorce.
The film has its sharp moments but is invariably glib when it comes to literary matters and the relationship between books and life.
This is the heartfelt indie-schmindie piece that The Perks of Being a Wallflower desperately wanted to be but wasn't.
Immensely likable but a little too tidy in its emotional payoff, the movie benefits from its charming, empathetic ensemble.
Three writers in one family explore the different shades of love.

Enjoyable and engaging relationship comedy drama enlivened by likeable performances, a strong script and some appealing location work, though it's also a little too pretentious for its own good in places.

Enjoyable and engaging relationship comedy drama enlivened by likeable performances, a strong script and some appealing location work, though it's also a little too pretentious for its own good in places.
It all plays out a bit like a feature-length episode of Dawson's Creek - pretty teenagers wandering around romantic locations spouting over-written dialogue.
This is the heartfelt indie-schmindie piece that The Perks of Being a Wallflower desperately wanted to be but wasn't.
The sharp edges of the story are sentimentally sanded down; there's a fair bit of slush, and it's a pretty quaint view of what writers and a writer's life are actually like.
Perfectly adequate airplane reading.
This disarming romantic comedy-drama is far more likeable than the ho-hum romcom title suggests.
Nicely acted, but a bit all over the place
There are a lot of empty calories in this cheapie, but it's so outrageously indulgent it rises above so much other B-movie fluff.
'Are you eating it? Or is it eating you?' I love it!
The Stuff probably won't make anybody's list of best films of the year, but it is an inspired, goofy, fast-moving piece of sci fi silliness, probably destined to become a cult favorite.
Peopled by leaden or hackneyed characters...The Stuff is further burdened by special effects of the most pedestrian kind.
Peopled by leaden or hackneyed characters...The Stuff is further burdened by special effects of the most pedestrian kind.
Though The Stuff isn't as effective as Cohen's more heralded titles (including the first installment of his It's Alive trilogy), it has all the hallmarks of his perverse sense of eco-terror.
Totally resistible horror comedy by the playful B film filmmaker Larry Cohen.
At razoavelmente divertido em sua poca, tornou-se (ainda) pior com o passar do tempo, sobrevivendo apenas como mais um dos inmeros momentos embaraosos da cinematografia norte-americana dos anos 80.
Likably goofy Larry Cohen horror satire.
The Stuff is a wildly ambitious movie that fails because it forgets to attend to its bottom line. Before you can make a clever, funny, satirical horror film, first you have to make a horror film.
There are a lot of empty calories in this cheapie, but it's so outrageously indulgent it rises above so much other B-movie fluff.
Totally resistible horror comedy by the playful B film filmmaker Larry Cohen.
The Stuff is a wildly ambitious movie that fails because it forgets to attend to its bottom line. Before you can make a clever, funny, satirical horror film, first you have to make a horror film.
At razoavelmente divertido em sua poca, tornou-se (ainda) pior com o passar do tempo, sobrevivendo apenas como mais um dos inmeros momentos embaraosos da cinematografia norte-americana dos anos 80.
Though The Stuff isn't as effective as Cohen's more heralded titles (including the first installment of his It's Alive trilogy), it has all the hallmarks of his perverse sense of eco-terror.
Playful comic-horror is a fine diversion. Consumers, beware!
Likably goofy Larry Cohen horror satire.
Its execution never lives up to its scrumptious satiric premise.
Its execution never lives up to its scrumptious satiric premise.
The Stuff probably won't make anybody's list of best films of the year, but it is an inspired, goofy, fast-moving piece of sci fi silliness, probably destined to become a cult favorite.
An ambitious yet flawed effort, but one executed with undoubted style and verve.
Gun-toting hotties combat assorted villains and their robot henchmen in this tawdry, repellent action fantasy.
The film doesn't live up to the exciting spectacle of watching a steam-powered mech with a cute little kitty painted on the front mow down a giant zeppelin.
Unfortunately, however, the film mainly shows that if you give a filmmaker the world, he often won't have the necessary skills to navigate it.
Snyder's accomplishment is to drain that of any erotic heat; he generated a lot more with the glistening-with-sweat abs in 300 than he manages here.
Sucker Punch is superficial and erotic visual stimulation, much like the kind of experience some might have when they immerse themselves in a video game to do battle with the enemy.
So bad that when the film's friendly lobotomist shows up to do his thing, I almost found myself standing up in my seat and shouting "I'll have what she's having!"

'Sucker Punch' is a film filled with emptiness and a hodgepodge of other films, it's like watching an unofficial sequel to 'Showgirls' with some 'Kill Bill' and 'Battle LA' thrown into the mix. Avoid at all costs.
Gross and skeevy, not to mention painfully long and repetitious.
Snyder's film is a warped mash-up of different genres - Gothic nightmare, psycho horror, steam-punk, Japanese manga, video game. File, though, under Guilty Pleasure.
While the visuals are quite impressive and go a long way towards helping the film, it's just not enough to recommend that you take the time to see "Sucker Punch."

All you need to know is that Sucker Punch is awful, probably on my shortlist of the worst motion pictures that I have ever seen. That's it, nothing more; as far as I'm concerned it's more then enough.
Ambitious and visually impressive as a pop-video mash-up, but, lacking a strong emotional core, it doesn't quite cohere as a fully satisfying movie.

Snyder's made something authentically confused and moderately offensive, apparently eager to place this dodgy film at the feet of young girls in search of heroes -- his own glossy brand of marketable rebellion.
Imagine the mind of a guy who has spent a good 20 years reading manga & watching anime & fantasy & sci-fi...and imagine that guy's id. That's pretty much what the film is.
A comic book cabaret that not even a 30 year old fanboy, living in his mother's basement, could love.
Every character is a throwaway part in this story. Since there isn't any substantial attempt the lay the groundwork for emotional investment in any of these characters, it is a pretty empty film.
Its multiple reality constructions are far more tingling than Inception's wannabe mind****.
The worst kind of bad film -- a lazy one that never seems concerned about anything more than cashing in at the box office.
Zack Snyder's storytelling skills remain in question in his latest CGI spectacular.
Hepburn and Taylor both earned Oscar nominations for their work; it's hard to pick which turns in a more compelling performance.
A lurid adaptation of the 1957 Tennessee Williams one-act play.

This is the best film adaptation of Tennessee Williams' oeuvre. A prodigious work from Katharine Hepburn, Montgomery Clift, and Elizabeth Taylor. This is one of Joseph L. Mankiewicz's best films. [Full Review in Spanish]
Fine version of the story with Hepburn as a fascinating monster.
I found Suddenly, Last Summer hollow, unproductive, unalive, and above all stagey, not cinematic.
Superbly adapted with blistering performances from Taylor and Hepburn.
Very controversial for its time, and still packs a wallop.
I found Suddenly, Last Summer hollow, unproductive, unalive, and above all stagey, not cinematic.
The battles between the imperious Hepburn and the presumed-mad Taylor are pure theatricality, while sensitive shrink Clift observes it all and emotes.
It is hard to know what to say about this misguided tour through the dank recesses of Mr. Williams' subconscious. It's all clearly nonsense, the rankest kind of Victorian melodrama.

The cast packs enough sexual ambiguity to satisfy the most rabid Williams fan (not to mention a screenplay by Gore Vidal), but Mankiewicz leaves much of the innuendo unexplored -- thankfully, perhaps.

Suddenly, Last Summer (1959) is director Joseph L. Mankiewicz' compelling adaptation by Gore Vidal of Tennessee Williams' 1958 Southern drama-one act play. This lurid, somber, ground-breaking and fascinating melodrama concerned terrible secrets...

This is the best film adaptation of Tennessee Williams' oeuvre. A prodigious work from Katharine Hepburn, Montgomery Clift, and Elizabeth Taylor. This is one of Joseph L. Mankiewicz's best films. [Full Review in Spanish]
It has some very effective moments, but on the whole it fails to move.
Hepburn and Taylor both earned Oscar nominations for their work; it's hard to pick which turns in a more compelling performance.

Suddenly, Last Summer (1959) is director Joseph L. Mankiewicz' compelling adaptation by Gore Vidal of Tennessee Williams' 1958 Southern drama-one act play. This lurid, somber, ground-breaking and fascinating melodrama concerned terrible secrets...
It has some very effective moments, but on the whole it fails to move.
It is hard to know what to say about this misguided tour through the dank recesses of Mr. Williams' subconscious. It's all clearly nonsense, the rankest kind of Victorian melodrama.
Very controversial for its time, and still packs a wallop.
Suddenly, Last Summer remains a remarkably salacious descent into madness, thanks to Mankiewicz's harrowing direction and two towering performances by Taylor and Hepburn
Too often the film retreats from the complexity of its debates in favor of comprehension.
The movie isn't as dynamic as it could have been, but it gets to the core of what big, important social change means - and how little glory there is in ground work.

What is the point of the silly, histrionic teatime drama Suffragette? Certainly not to focus on the actual suffering of the suffragettes, who a little more than 100 years ago were sent to prison and force-fed after a string of "terrorist" attacks.
This is a film so heavy on message that it forgets to tell the kind of rousing story it hopes to be.
This is a superbly acted and sharply written drama that manages to be powerfully emotional without resorting to manipulative sentimentality.
Sarah Gavron's film is, amazingly, the first ever to be made about the Suffragettes.
Suffragette is exemplary in its attempt to depict the harrowing experiences of the British women who risked their lives to win the vote.
An astonishingly tedious drama...

The backlash against Suffragette for white-washing history, and against the cast for being tone-deaf, is unfortunate but not unwarranted. The movie is good, but not good enough to rise above its own prejudices.
An interesting story, sadly we have too many loose ends at the end. [Full review in Spanish]
Surprisingly gentle, considering it is a film about the moment the suffragette movement in the UK turned militant, Suffragette is nevertheless stirring and moving.
Suffragette is a worthwhile reminder of how far women have come and the price they had to pay to get here. We're left to imagine how much more there is to be done.
It is such a shame that Sarah Gavron's well-appointed film ends up in such bourgeois heritage territory.

The film does gain power as it moves along. Partly because the obvious injustice of women being denied the vote for so long becomes overwhelming and partly because of some very nice acting along the way.
This is a beautiful film, not just in its narrative but also in its astounding cinematography and production design.
Carey Mulligan is always inspired, even when faced with basic material like this.
Overall, Suffragette is compelling, emotive filmmaking with [Carey] Mulligan delivering a standout performance.
Stirring and cleareyed - the best kind of history lesson.
The best picture of 2015. Certainly the most important.
The supporting cast, including Helena Bonham Carter, Romola Garai and Anne-Marie Duff, are all top notch, and a reminder of how few films like this exist anywhere.
As sumptuous as it is immensely shallow, the film practically revels in its attention to lush English landscapes as a means to distract from its derivative storytelling.
We're supposed to be saddened that their world is ending and that the first World War, with its awful human toll, looms. Instead we're thinking where are the bloody Germans when you need them?

Engaging and enjoyable British period drama enlivened by a strong script, stunning locations, some impressive production design work and a trio of great performances from Emily Browning, Dan Stevens, and Dominic Cooper.
In the end, it's a miserable movie about miserable people, and we're left to wonder why. But any further time spent considering this forgettable romance feels wasted.
Gorgeous scenes along the Cornish coast are impressive, but the film lacks the dynamic chemistry between lovers that's so important in a romance-themed movie.
Lifetime movie with English accents.
A simplistic approach undermines this intriguing true story about a romantic triangle among artists in pre-WWI England.
A simplistic approach undermines this intriguing true story about a romantic triangle among artists in pre-WWI England.
The wind swept Cornish coast sings of dramatic romance.

Cooper stomps around ineffectually, Stevens makes for a blandly tame suitor, and Browning is unable to ignite any chemistry with either. The scenery is stunning. But the swooning has all the heat of a midwinter's swim.

For the last half-hour, the director uses every trick in the book (rain machines, epic music, close-ups of sobbing girls) in a bid to jerk our tears. It was too much, too late. I was already looking at my watch.
Blah Britpic offers scenery but little else.
Characters' motivations often make no sense at all and people veer wildly between being likeable and ghastly with little attempt to provide explanation or context.
It's not a particularly interesting or revealing story but there's plenty of plein-air painting and plein-air nudity ...
It's old-fashioned for sure, and the characters are a tad under-written, but the picture looks lovely, is very well acted and quietly moving.
[I]gnores the work... of important painter Florence Carter-Wood to focus on a tediously tragic romantic triangle.
Compared with the tepid contretemps of "Summer in February," the soap-opera theatrics of "Downton Abbey" have the depth of Chekhov.
Characters' motivations often make no sense at all and people veer wildly between being likeable and ghastly with little attempt to provide explanation or context.
The performances are but one eye roll-inducing aspect of a period drama so generic and formulaic that it verges on parody.
It's old-fashioned for sure, and the characters are a tad under-written, but the picture looks lovely, is very well acted and quietly moving.
Superfly has a long way to go to be considered a great movie, but it's not a particularly bad one, either.
You'll have fun, but you won't be challenged.
The aesthetic may have changed with the passing decades, but this superfly guy remains the man of the hour.
A competent yet glossy and hermetic street-hustle drug thriller, less a new urban myth than a lavishly concocted episode. It holds your attention yet leaves you with nothing.
The film results in a slow grinding drama that holds its heavy artillery, as far as action is concerned, until the very end. [Full Review in Spanish]
A flashy but strangely flaccid remake of a movie that became iconic, despite (or perhaps because of) its grubbiness.
You never lose track of where Priest is trying to go, or why he's trying to get there.
It's one thing to update a movie for modern sensibilities. It's an entirely other thing to miss the point of what you're remaking.
It's simultaneously aesthetically impressive and astoundingly unappealing, shockingly straight-forward and hopelessly convoluted.

It just goes to show if you're going to remake a blaxploitation movie, it's best to temper that revolutionary edge with the right amount of pulp. SuperFly doesn't get that balance quite right, but it comes a lot closer than one would expect.
The film's strip-club-and-slo-mo aesthetic is yanked right out of any number of hip-hop videos - and also about as deep.
Superfly wants to bank off the title of a genre classic without keeping the spirit of the genre alive. It needs more verve than gloss and more brains than bullets.
... the film brings an approach that stays true to the source material and updates it for a newer audience...
It is the rare drug dealer film with brains. It is an astute, sharp modern take on a story that deserved an update.
I was less troubled by such moral ambiguity than with the screenplay's remarkably tidy ending. But the cast made the trip worthwhile. I'll confess, I couldn't take my eyes off Priest.
What's intriguing, and occasionally even thrilling, about Director X's movie is that it's also as unabashedly cheesy as the original.
Did the world need this loose reconception of the original? Not really.

Superfly features an appealing lead, and captures small tastes of amazing, striking cool, but is also bogged down by plot and characters that reduce an otherwise slick flick into something that is more capable than amazing.
An insufferably goofy piece of storytelling, yet it lacks any of its predecessor's campy charm.
Director X nods to the original movie but also smartly insists on finding more within its violently pursued "American Dream" narrative.
Subtitled The Quest for Peace, this Superman sequel should have been called the The Quest for a Plot.
The impoverishment here is not merely of means, but of spirit.
Bargain basement caper.
With the passing of the production torch to infamous budget tightwads Golan and Globus, it was clear that the worst was yet to come.

For sentimentality's sake, it's great watching Reeve and company reprise their roles even if it's in the bastard child edition of the series, but this isn't just one of the worst comic book films, it's one of the worst films ever made.
Quickly followed by Superman V: The Need to Explain What The Hell We Were Thinking.
Somewhere between the cheesy special effects and lame story the whole movie falls flat.
Predictably awful fourth installment.
The overall effect is of a story atomized and dying before our eyes, collapsing into smashed pulp, ground down into big-budget Kryptonite ash.
That this movie is how the Superman movie legacy ended would be a depressing thought if the movie weren't so endlessly hilarious.
As bad as Superman 3 is, Superman 4 is even worse.
More sluggish than a funeral barge, cheaper than a sale at K mart, it's a nerd, it's a shame, it's Superman IV.
Godawful, pointless, preachy sequel.
Terrible '80s sequel has violence, nuclear weapons.
"Superman IV: The Quest for Peace," a confused and cheap-looking movie that evidently was butchered in the editing room, would be better titled "Superman Farce: The Search for a Quick Buck."
One of the cheesiest movies ever made.
Avoid!
...this final sigh of a movie manages to send the series out with a feeble yet breathing dignity. It's bad, but it's better than III in that it does try to rise above itself.
Of course, Superman saves the world, but the real news is that there's still some life in the series.
Superman IV is cinematic kryptonite. Not only could it kill the Superman series, it might also leave filmgoers feeling weak.
No, it's not "Maverick" but an amazing facsimile.
Not bad Garner vehicle.
Classic comedy-western gem, with fantastic performances from Garner and the supporting cast. Not quite as good as SUPPORT YOUR LOCAL GUNFIGHTER, though.
Garner brings a variation on his 'Maverick' persona to this classic satirical Western... does for Westerns what The Princess Bride did for fairy-tale fantasy.
It's essentially a lousy TV situation comedy dragged out to feature length for no good reason.
Veteran Western director Burt Kennedy shoots a pleasing irreverent parody on the genre.
Garner is a master playing the easy-going straight man with a mix of wit and practicality...
Kennedy deftly uses character interplay and Garner's no-nonsense sass to bring natural comedy from a familiar western plotline, so the result is less parodic and more authentic.
An absolutely riotous Western.
In Support Your Local Sheriff Burt Kennedy and William Bowers remind us that it is possible to make a comic Western and yet love and understand the genre.
Mindless Entertainment Department: veteran screenwriter William Bowers has written a funny script for a film with the suspiciously corny title of Support Your Local Sheriff.
There's virtually no suspense in the rote hostage drama, which, contrary to the title, takes place over a night and much of the following morning.
A particularly forgettable example of a tired sub-genre that, like so many of Willis' recent efforts, squanders his still estimable movie-star charisma.
A flabby hunk of meat that the director, Matt Eskandari, hasn't bothered to season.
This movie looks and sounds like a real thriller, but the premise and the characters' behaviors and interactions are so stunningly absurd that it's nearly impossible to turn your brain off and enjoy.
Survive the Night is a straight-forward thriller where cliches abound. But despite an overly familiar plot, it remains an entertaining ride.
Watching Willis in Survive the Night, you'd think he was already dead.
Screenwriter Matt Eskandari's predictable plot abandons realism - along with any unexpected character revelations. There's no shocking, jolting violence or queasy ick-making accidents.
Eskandari does relatively well for the first hour of the endeavor, especially with lowered expectations for a brisk display of antagonism and family issues.
Not a thinking person's movie. But a perfectly adequate "efficiency movie."
The dialogue is as dull as an Ikea pencil, often to the point of being unintentionally hilarious.
Pacing is a problem here as this attempt at a home invasion/hostage thriller takes an eternal amount of time getting going.
It proves to be an extremely challenging experience to survive this empty slog of nothingness for us viewers. Just don't bother with this one.
This hostage thriller has a slickly violent sheen to it, but is essentially a substandard B-movie.
A wayward mess.
No one seems to have paid any attention to the screenplay or to have considered the awful truth that Mr. Matthau and Mr. Williams, each performers of great charm, don't play together very well.
It's an aimless, self-indulgent, confusing comedy that never comes to grips with its material.
Dumb, forced comedy wastes talents of Robin Williams and Walter Matthau.
An aimless, unfocused social comedy, The Survivors misfires on just about every level.
This is a movie that has all of the right stuff in the soup, but no lightning.
Presents a slow and leisurely look at sexual politics in and out of marriage.
Underrated sweet story of what happily ever after really means.
Had director Robert Greenwald tightened-up the scope and made the characters more than static word vessels wasting air, I might have felt a gentle tug inside.
An immensely likable comedy-drama.
Not only is the cast terrific, but there is a conscious attempt to evoke the feel of the season
Feels like every other action thriller we've seen in the past three years, only it's more annoying.
Computers that flash 'Access Denied' until the last possible second, then say 'Access Granted,' are not quite the hair-raising suspense vehicles that screenwriters seem to believe.
The story ... is just what fills in the gaps between slow-motion fireballs, Matrix-style frozen mayhem, and Halle Berry's notoriously undraped breasts.
Jaded, cynical, dumb and degenerate.
Swordfish drowns in cliche, implausibility and cryptic little mysteries and misdirections that viewers are supposed to accept as intricate and edgy storytelling.
Like an issue of Maxim come to life.
With all due disrespect to Freddie Prinze Jr., John Travolta is fast becoming the new harbinger of bad cinema.
A series of set pieces that grow progressively absurd, climaxing in a thoroughly perverse ending.
Swordfish may run just 99 minutes, but that's enough time to keep mulling how silly it is.
A good movie? Hardly. But more than enough to pass a dog day afternoon.
I'm willing to buy the idea of a flying bus, but a movie had better distract me from all logical thought while I'm doing it. Swordfish can't pull that one off.
[Travolta] is back on his game again as Gabriel, a dark angel of destruction.
Stylish dreck disguised as a hard-core action flick.
Too much routine stuff amid the excess relegates the hyperactive Swordfish to the level of costly dross.
It's skillfully mounted and fitfully intriguing, but weaves such a tangled web that at the end I defy anyone in the audience to explain the exact loyalties and motives of the leading characters.
Action movies are supposed to be dumb, but they're not supposed to be stupid.
Bang for your buck.
Techno tosh, but fitfully great fun all the same.
Sena's action lacks personality and focus; it comes off like someone who blares a stereo while constantly switching channels.
It's the adrenaline rush of the year.
The plot is typical fluff -- Kelly and Sinatra join Esther Williams's baseball team at the turn of the century -- but the production values are, as always, worth the price of admission.
The American pastime was never more fun.
What matters is the stylish ebullience, and the excellent score by Roger Edens, Adolph Green and Betty Comden.
It must be said, too, that Mr. Kelly and his side-kick do right nicely by a brisk thing called "Yes, Indeedy," as well as the title song.
It's brilliant music, and the comedy is a snap.
There is no pretense that Ball Game is anything more than a romp for Kelly's virtuosity.
An enjoyable, snappy period baseball musical comedy.
This wonderful MGM musical has super songs, ravishing Technicolor and extraordinary talent both behind and in front of the camera.
Seldom has there been a film loaded with such fine entertainment.
With its French Canadian setting and strong (rather, strong-looking) cast, Taking Lives is elevated above its genre cliches.
Taking Lives is actually an effective thriller, on its modest but stylish level.
This multiple-twist thriller gets off to a fine, creepy start but eventually becomes too preposterous for its own good.
Taking Lives is a foolish thriller full of actors who deserve better.
Unfortunately, Taking Lives doesn't add any brilliance to the exhausted spot-the-serial-killer psychological thriller, but get props for a clever ending.
Suspenseful, nail-biting thriller with not enough Olivier Martinez
While it's not in a league with The Silence of the Lambs, it works in a similarly efficient way.

This is more disappointing than it might have been because Taking Lives has a low boil but constant simmer that has been rarely present in previous attempts to revive the insinuating creepiness of The Silence of the Lambs and Se7en.
surprises and satisfies beyond initial expectations
If Taking Lives starts off with a modicum of wit and creepy-crawly scares, it winds up somewhere else altogether.
There are too many flaws to count in Taking Lives.
[W]e're meant to believe that [Hawke] is so intensely seductive that [Jolie] cannot resist him. Which would be laughable if it weren't so boring.
Tediously conventional and ho-hum.

To buy this picture, you have to buy Jolie's character, and the actress succeeds much of the time. But once her contained, job-obsessed agent gets involved with a man close to her case, much of what came before is negated.
From the opening credits, Lives seems bound to recapture the queasy mood of 1995's Seven. But it's too dull to even pull off quease until a notably unpleasant climax.

critic_name: Cherryl Dawson and Leigh Ann Palone
content: It isn't as bad as it could be or as good as it should be - I would wait to see this on video.
[A] generic pulp thriller.
Like so many brilliant detectives before her, this FBI investigator is aggressive and intuitive, prone to odd behavior and arrogance.
Jolie's detective ... seems to be merely one more graduate from Inspector Clouseau Academy.
How Ashley Judd failed to pounce on this script, I'll never know.
A beautifully animated film with a gorgeous soundtrack.
The Tale Of Despereaux may be a little slow for the very youngest kids ‚Äî though the messages it imparts are certainly ones you'll want them to hear.
The lesson learned from The Tale of Despereaux is that an overabundance of vocal talent does not a good cartoon make.
Rata-terrible.
Parental Content Review
It definitely has some charms and enough action and intrigue to keep the kids interested √¢" and enough of both to ensure that their parents aren't completely bored.
The Tale of Despereaux may not be a classic, but it still has a lot of class.

The imagery is colorful and artfully rendered, but the filmmakers, favoring technological wizardry over story, have beefed up the narrative with teeming rodent civilizations, a seafaring sequence, and gladiatorial action pieces.

The Tale of Despereaux gathers a host of vocal talent for a relatively complicated story of heroism and loyalty, requiring that its young audience pay attention and is all the more rewarding for it (for kids and grown-ups).
Visually it's special, but while the characters may inhabit a wonderful environment, they just don't inhabit a satisfying narrative.
The rodent worlds are painted with flair and invention, but the characters - with the noble exception of Watson's princess - are as dull as dishwater.
This film is a triumph and will delight everyone in your family. Superb.

[A]n absolute delight, sweetly inventive and surprisingly dark and dedicated to making you forget how many times we've seen similar stories before... with its wit and cleverness...
[The directors] can't quite locate a core of buoyant energy in the film as a whole.
A curiously lifeless motion picture, its emotional content so stuffy and its tone so understated that it almost becomes a chore to sit through.

A film that seems less interested in telling a story than in moralizing to its young audience about the value of individuality, the danger of prejudging someone, the folly of jumping to conclusions, the joys of altruism, the sorrows of pettiness.
Warm, wise CG animated fable.
Laboured and disjointed, the film has none of the charm of a Ratatouille or a Shrek, but seems derivative of them.
The film likely contains enough of DiCamillo's spirit and intelligence to please fans of the vastly superior novel.
The stories do get better as they go along, though all of them will seem overly familiar to fans of the genre.
E.C. Comics-style horror films are the LAST place one should attempt serious social commentary.
Both fails to be the witty satire that it was promoted as being and the serious scarefest it actually aspires to be.
As uneven as anthology films often are, but occasionally good, goofy fun.
Decent concept. Poor execution.
One of the smartest genre offerings of the era and, quite possibly, the best anthology of its decade.
A landmark genre picture.

If Get Out is about the way racism now hides behind America's grinning, faux-liberal facade, Tales is about how poverty and ignorance are causing young black men and women to rage war against themselves.
The irony is that nothing Fishman and his cohorts have come up with is really as funny as a two-hour slice of MTV itself.

Silly fun.
It's the kind of harmless breezy film that's easy to take on late night cable TV when you don't feel like using your noodle.
A painful attempt to satirize the making of rock videos that runs aground with a puerile plot and bombastic, self-infatuated delivery.
If it's fair to knock Disney for churning out what's clearly some inferior product, I think it's only right to take note when said product starts to show signs of improvement.

I'll take Tarzan II for the enjoyable kid's movie it is and pray Disney doesn't go for a Tarzan trilogy.
Another needless Disney sequel, but it also happens to be animated pretty decently.
...it seems fairly obvious that adults will find Tarzan II tedious and tiresome.
The general level of technical accomplishment is so high that it really stands out badly whenever something briefly drops to the normal level of DisneyToon animation.
In its own twisted, unique way, this is one stunning film.
Fast, fresh, funny and entertaining for all.
May not be a Disney classic, but it's certainly unique enough to warrant at least a rental, if not a spot in the permanent library.
A very high-spirited family comedy that will play just as well on DVD in approximately three months.
This completely random creation is essentially an adult's cartoon cut for a kid's short attention span.
Originality aside, parents expecting a mainstream film may want to wait until another Disney cartoon featuring happy woodland creatures comes along.
Weird and lively; the kind of movie that would never get made if it wasn't an extension of a preexisting franchise.
An entertaining treat that proves there's plenty of life left in traditional 2-D animation.
If nothing else inventive, at the very least perverse, and at moments transcendently bizarre.
By deftly blending silliness and sophistication, this little movie does its part to stem the technological tide.
Give Teacher's Pet a C-.
Crammed full of small jokes and visual puns.
It was a bad enough TV show; moving this puppy to the big screen was a huge waste of space.
Has a non-sentimental appeal for that ... crowd that fancies itself too cool for kiddie stuff.
It's part sugar, part spice and all-around brilliant.
I felt as if the theater had tapped into a cable broadcast coming into a house down the street.
A one-joke movie based on a one-joke Disney TV show.
It's smart and character-rich, and the size of its musical / conceptual ambitions belies its small-screen origins.
A small-scale charmer that gives audiences a healthy dose of silliness.
At home, the movie will probably play like the pleasantly dull video babysitter it is. As a big-screen feature, however, it just feels superfluous.
45 of the funniest minutes I've spent at the movies this year. Too bad this weapon of mass diversion runs more than twice that in length.
The film is only intermittently funny and truly does raise a question of how often can one resort to the same foul words for laughs without becoming tiresome.
Although it can get a bit wearing on me to watch puppets, this is so well written and so tongue in cheek, that it was a pleasure.
Boasts the best and funniest vomit scene since Monty Python and the Meaning of Life.
[Team America: World Police is] a roller coaster ride that works most of the time and keeps the laughs coming.
By turns hilarious, idiotic, thoughtful, scatological, and occasionally all of these at the same time.
The irreverent duo plays it surprisingly safe here.
Political junkies have long been wondering if there would be an October surprise... Now we know the answer. Team America: World Police is that surprise.
Juvenile? Sure. Funny? Certainly -- though not nearly as often as one might reasonably expect from these guys.
A delightfully vicious film that's bound to piss off everyone.
Surprisingly good natured given its take-no-prisoners lampooning of ethnic and cultural stereotypes, the war in Iraq, homosexuality, AIDS... not to mention Hollywood's finest.
The satirical sharpness that defines the duo's at-times incandescently brilliant "South Park" has been shunted aside in favour of vomit gags and screaming homophobia.
If you're not a fan of naughtiness for naughtiness's sake, Team America is this week's must-miss movie.
Forget about Fahrenheit 9/11; this is the most incisive political film of 2004.
The film is extremely hit-and-miss.
Profane and sometimes bitingly funny.
... one of the funniest films you'll ever feel (this) uncomfortable about laughing out loud at... remember: if you laugh, the terrorists win.
More satisfying as a straight-ahead blow 'em up than as a satire.
Everything, even the explicit puppet sex, has a satirical message.
The left testicle certainly gets it where it hurts, but the right is just centimeters away and is skewed so perfectly that they may not even recognize it.
In the end, Ted Bundy's only justification is the director's common but unexplored fascination with the frustrated maniac; there's no larger point, and little social context.
This piece of Channel 5 grade trash is, quite frankly, an insult to the intelligence of the true genre enthusiast.
Disturbingly superficial in its approach to the material.
A trashy, exploitative, thoroughly unpleasant experience.
The feral brilliance of [Michael Reilly Burke's] performance lies in the way he evokes the subtle wrongness beneath the facade that gripped the public imagination.
An artsploitation movie with too much exploitation and too little art.
As Bundy, Michael Reilly Burke (Octopus 2: River of Fear) has just the right amount of charisma and menace.
It's possible that something hip and transgressive was being attempted here that stubbornly refused to gel, but the result is more puzzling than unsettling.
Exploitative and largely devoid of the depth or sophistication that would make watching such a graphic treatment of the crimes bearable.
Bright seems alternately amused and disgusted with this material, and he can't help throwing in a few of his own touches.

Instead of accurately accounting a terrible true story, the film's more determined to become the next Texas Chainsaw Massacre. But what about the countless other people who'd merely like to watch a solid tale about a universally interesting soul?
He was psychothic but somehow I doubt that he was the world's biggest luser...
One of the rare movies that spend 100 minutes with someone only to glory in his protracted death.
The low-key drama is well-crafted and likable as far as it goes, but there's not enough narrative impetus or depth to maintain more than passing viewer interest.
From its title to its closing caress, Teddy Bear skates perilously close to the cliff's edge of mawkish sentiment.
A largely likable tale about a 38-year-old man-child trying finally to grow up.
A sweetly muted domestic drama struggling to contain a fierce and ancient folk tale.

It's only a slight exaggeration to say Kold gives what may be the performance of the year -- one that not only offsets the movie's momentary dips into self-conscious quirkiness but adds a genuine sweetness to the proceedings.
A good tale, simply told.
Kim Kold's Dennis is such an unconventional character it's not hard to be drawn into his world.

Matthiesen and his cast have created a believable space, and that ultimately helps give Teddy Bear the tension of a fine suspense film once Kold sits down across the kitchen table from Steentoft to speak his mind at last.
A heart-wrenching central performance anchors Mads Matthiesen's intimate, empathetic drama about a Danish bodybuilder who aims to grow up as he nears middle age.

Not exactly a movie about lurid sex tourism, though coming awfully close, the film does risk credibility at times with a protagonist so out of touch, that he seems to hardly have a clue about the difference between hookers and potential housewives.
This wispy story is distinguished by its sweetness of spirit, and it comes straight from Kold.
A straight-forward telling of an affecting, devastatingly funny tale, topped by a magnificent lead performance from Kim Kold as Ken, the gentle giant.
It's Paddy Chayesky's Marty drenched in silent emotion.
Its hulking gentle giant non-professional acting star, the real-life bodybuilder Kim Kold, brings the muscles, heart and sensitivity to his role.

The sex and filial troubles of 308-pound persons are not exactly common. But Matthiesen has evoked both the pathos and courage in these troubles, and, with the help of this reticent giant, explores them enticingly.
A familiar formula with some finely wrought characters we can't help but wish the best for.
For audiences intrigued by, if not addicted to, stardom's nature, Grenier's film proves an entertaining, satisfying excursion.

Naturally, to broaden the appeal of his documentary, Grenier appears on screen regularly; however, a good-natured fellow, he 'fesses up about his motives in the opening frame, then opines on the irony of so much reflected glory.
Adrien Grenier's engaging documentary shows that a picture may be worth a thousand words, but it ultimately cannot capture a human being in all their complexity.
...an entertaining, surprisingly informative look at the relationship between celebrities and the paparazzi...
Teenage Paparazzo establishes at least a couple of foci, namely, Adrian Grenier's relationship with the picture-snapping press and his relationship with that relationship, as he portrays it on TV.
Teenage Paparazzo is a personal, point-of-view doc from Adrian Grenier, the star of HBO's Entourage, who shows there's an inquiring mind behind the pretty-boy charm.
It settles for interesting when it might have been insightful.

Presentation is key and the use of a shifting gallery of eternal youths, dryly recited by people well outside of their teens, combined with the score and bygone images, create a haunting, ghostlike quality.
What makes Teenage truly special is the way it tells its story through the voices of the young.
[Director Matt Wolf] has transformed Jon Savage's book into a visionary cinematic statement.
Ambitious but also confusing and often trite ...
The engrossing, sometimes frustrating cine-essay Teenage offers occasional moments of thrilling revelation ...
Mesmeric work, informative and engaging, allowing an understanding of juvenile appetites as they were shaped through decades of dismissal and war.
The collage effect recalls Ken Burns' documentaries for PBS, particularly since Wolf also occasionally inserts still photographs towards which he zooms in slowly in order to approximate movement.
It botches itself out of its own epic ambitions, an aesthetic slickness that seems to contradict, if not betray, its subject matter, and a maddeningly subdued critical spirit.
If Teenage delivers a sweeping generalization or two (or three) ... Wolf's documentary makes up for it with footage that's just too good to be ignored.

Granted, the film's title is taken from Savage's book, but for a documentary which concludes that the teenager is all about the future, it spends too much of its time covering WWII. "Teenage" is a niche historical document.
The history of teenagerdom feels like the history of a revolutionary artistic movement, like surrealism or situationism, full of wild clothes, new music, provocation and excitement.
Deftly weaves together various media in a way that breathes its own youthful, stream-of-conscious life into the documentary genre.
We were expecting a light-hearted, fact-filled look at the phenomenon of the "youth market" Western pop culture, but Matt Wolf's documentary is much more than that.
Like adolescence itself, Teenage is educational, scattered, and over much too quickly.
Both informative and entertaining [though] less a straightforward cinematic argument than a dreamlike, multilevel evocation.
"Teenage" does what a good documentary should: educate and entertain.
The film makes its point ingeniously.
It's a terrific distraction, but it ultimately leaves you unfulfilled.
This rich historical documentary chronicles the emergence of the teenager as a distinct social and cultural group.
Equal parts sensitive and overwrought, intelligent and preachy.
The cinematography by Ben Kutchins works more from grime than grim, capturing a battered backdrop for the characters rather than a cartoon battlefield of drugs and crime/
Boasts a strong cast but not enough focus.
'80s-set teen drama has lots of drug use, profanity.
A unanimously well-acted film.
Very John Hughes - right down to the eighties setting and the compassion for its troubled teen characters. Well-worth seeing.
Part teen romance, part awkward love triangle, part generational-clash portrait, and almost all powered by nostalgia ...
It's a sensitive and interesting film.
An achingly perfect evocation of New York's East Village in the 1980s and an amazing cast cannot make this tale of adolescent anxiety catch fire.
Steinfeld is lovely, and sometimes heartrending, as a young woman whose independent swagger masks swirls of uncertainty. And Hawke, who becomes a better actor with each passing year, is marvelous ...
Lacks resonance and a steady directorial hand.
Heart-warming, funny, and real, which means at times it can be desperately sad, this is a fantastic new development for Springer Berman and Pulcini. This one's going to go far.
We're told that characters are drawing closer to each other or changing their lives for the better, but we don't often feel it.
The emotionally uneven film is more intriguing in parts than as a whole, with the periphery characters often more compelling than the somewhat passive protagonist.
There's a lot wrong with [the movie], but I forgive it because most of the actors carry the movie's awkward melodrama--and because it's a reminder of an East Village that's quickly disappearing.

Although it may not come to great conclusions about all of the issues it raises, it does affirm that people are inherently good without coming across like it's selling you something. And that's a very sweet thing to do.
The cast all do well with banal material that's beneath them, especially Emily Watson, as Eliza's mom, and Hawke, who's everyone's dope-smoking, curfew-less fantasy friend-Dad.
A very fine film, full of quietly impressive performances and young characters who register as authentic.
The film shows all the earmarks of a story too heavily compressed; the complications among the entwined families pile up after a while, and the period milieu feels arbitrary.
Ethan Hawke is so funny in Ten Thousand Saints that he nearly keeps the movie afloat.
...a routine police thriller that is, for the most part, slow moving and uneventful.
A real button-pusher with a dynamite ending. Gene Davis is memorable as the sicko villain.

This is a scummy little sewer of a movie, a cesspool that lingers sadistically on shots of a killer terrifying and killing helpless women, and then is shameless enough to end with an appeal to law and order.
Feels like a big turning of the tide for Bronson's character, who unlike other action heroes of the period, might have had to face harsh repercussions in the end.
Is this is a good movie? Not really. Is it entertaining to watch? Absolutely.
An alternately nifty and nasty police procedural.
Lee Thompson's 10 to Midnight is identical to its predecessors. [Full Review in Spanish]
Both a murder/mystery and a teen-oriented slasher, before morphing into a very unlikely revenge picture.
Twisty plot, unconvincing storytelling and bad pacing.
Visually and sonically Terminal is enjoyable, but the story isn't up to the par. [Full Review in Spanish]
Everything and everybody else just seems here to support Robbie: If nothing else, her performance here is a compelling argument for her to get that Harley Quinn stand-alone film made, already.

Bad accents, accents that just didn't suit characters, dialogue that sounded like it had been taken from student film, the overuse of Alice in Wonderland references, all these things, overshadowned what I think Stein was trying to do.
This stylish-but-grating pastiche of far better crime flicks is as soft-boiled as they come.
The main mystery here is how so many smart actors ended up in this stinker.

About three-quarters style exercise and one-quarter story, this occasionally intriguing but mostly frustrating film is one example of a work that would have benefited greatly from better control of tone and more careful casting.
Not even Margot Robbie's flashy, on-the-nose performance can save this disappointing noir wannabe. [Full review in Spanish]
It's all such a "movie-movie" that it never becomes quite the thriller it wants to be.
Robbie... may have gotten an Oscar nomination for I, Tonya, but this is a film that really showcases her range.
What's Terminal about? It's about 90 minutes. That's a cheap shot, but since the film doesn't establish a baseline of reality, it's hard to pick out a premise.
With a terrible script and horrible dialogue, there is much to see but little to remember. [Full review in Spanish]
The stories never connect in a satisfying fashion and both tales are undone by a series of increasingly ridiculous twists that fail to work because there's no emotional investment in the characters.
The neon-soaked scenery is undoubtedly intoxicating but there just isn't enough meat on the bones to ever get lost in the hollow underbelly of the film's setting.
By no means a success, Vaughn Stein's debut has a form over substance allure to it. And then there's Mike Myers...
A great calling card for TV commercials, or fashion layouts. It's just not much of a movie.
The strength of the stylistic elements and Robbie's performance aren't sufficient to overcome the deficiencies of an initially derivative and ultimately off-kilter narrative.
A film that makes the viewer feel as if their brain has been extracted through their nostrils with a drinking straw: an inane and relentlessly boring future noir...
It's all noise, complicating without complexity. It is all setting, little heart. Without Robbie's live wire act, I doubt the film would have a pulse at all.
A neon-drenched film noir steeped in film clich√©s, Vaughn Stein's tale of femmes fatales, hitmen and suicide cases feels as terminal as the title suggests.
Had style and the expressions of an auteur filmmaker to make it standout from other westerns.
Blistering left wing Western, with unique surreal final showdown.

Arguably, its depiction of American's sour, rotten capitalistic core may be nothing new in the annals of the Western. But no one does it with such devilish relish and provocative panache as Trumbo, Young, and Lewis and the nightmare they conjure.
A Trumbo screenplay all the way.
Simply put, Gameau's one-man experiment is not rigorous enough to prove anything at all, however striking his results seem.
Gameau builds his case well, and by the end of the painfully dorky musical number, you may be swapping your smoothies for berries and plain, full-fat yogurt.
While "That Sugar Film" is filled with powerful and what should be downright alarming information, it also suffers from distracting bouts of cinematic candy coating.
Damon Gameau copies the Super Size Me model for an investigatory experiment [with] more style and pizzazz and inconsistency.
a lively and eye-opening documentary on a subject that needs as much attention as it can get...That Sugar Film attacks its subject from every conceivable angle.
I know I'll be looking at food packaging labels a little more closely from now on.

With its peppy, pop style, complete with silly, colorful special effects and animation, this documentary should prove accessible to school-age viewers, who might profit the most from its frank information about sugar's effect on their minds and bodies.
There's really nothing fresh in terms of news or science about sugar's potential for addiction, obesity and disease.
While one never expects this experiment to turn out well, the results are still alarming.
My main problem with this documentary, which Gameau says is a quest for definitive answers, is that it is so one-sided.
Glib but sometimes entertaining and informative recounting of everything we know about why sugar is bad for us.

In a sprightly, highly entertaining tear-through of the sugar load embedded in so-called health foods, Melbourne actor Damon Gameau does a Morgan Spurlock by submitting himself to 60 days of increased sugar to match the average of 40 teaspoons a day.
It's important to probe the Western world's overconsumption of sugar, but Gameau's attempts to do so while being hip and fun feel condescending and trite.

The documentary will certainly appeal to kids with its colour, movement, clarity and humour. Adults, meanwhile, will take pause at the knowledge that the food industry has exploited our hard-wired love for sweet things to sell us unhealthy products.
One senses that all of these kinds of documentaires are finally aggrandizing shrines made by artists trying to erect something out of nothing.

Even ignoring the documentary's more obviously imitative aspects, this is far too gimmicky to persuade viewers to put down their soft drinks and pay more attention when reading the ingredients listed on packaging.
Quirky documentary about food industry engages, educates.
That Sugar Film's message is one well worth hearing, there are better, more informed messengers out there.
A great documentary, a great night out, and a great eye-opener. You'll never look at an ingredients list the same way again...
Spirited but unconvincing stunt documentary about the perils of a high sugar diet.
The saga of small-town strip mall taekwondo instructor Fred Simmons, The Foot Fist Way is the sort of nimble oddball discovery that one wishes would come along more often.
Not bad for a one-joke movie, but still unmistakably a one-joke movie.
The Foot Fist Way signifies the most original comic vision since Hot Fuzz.
Google the trailer. That should be enough.
From a bunch of minor Judd Apatow prot√©g√©s, a dispiriting low-budget series of witless, misogynistic sketches masquerading as comedy.

Some bits fall flat well before they're driven into the ground, such as when Simmons tries to seduce a new female student. Others are painfully telegraphed so that when the payoff arrives, you've anticipated the blow and have become inured to it.
Apparently the writers thought Fred was so inherently funny they barely bothered to write jokes for him - and then thought those jokes were so funny they didn't need well-timed delivery.
We've all met this guy or someone close, and that makes him all the more deserving of that derision and a bit of empathy, too.
Performances are uneven and sometimes self-consciously amateurish, and Brian Mandle's photography seems to be only a couple of notches above cell-phone home movies.
This discomfiting low-budget comedy v√©rit√© can be painfully funny, but the emphasis is on the painful. This goes Way below the belt a little too long and too often.
The film stops when the jokes do, making for an anti-climactic finale. But if The Foot Fist Way is more about promise than delivery, its creators are off to an impressive start.
It's almost funny, or theoretically funny. It's just not actually funny.
This sleeper hit in the making is sweet and sour in all the right proportions, the best thing of its kind since Napoleon Dynamite.
It's also pretty funny at times, even if its central joke wears thin.
A very cool comedy based on character -- real, and really self-deluded characters -- and not on shtick.
Fred is a sadder, more recognizable version of Ferrell characters like Ricky Bobby or Ron Burgundy, a pompous manchild with delusions of masculine dominance.
While most of the deadpan remarks hit the spot, the erratic sketch-like editing and overall slapdash structure give it an air of incompleteness. Fun in parts, slipshod in others.
This is irritainment, something you snicker at while covering your eyes, praying that this guy never gets loose in the real world, when, in fact, he's your next-door neighbor. Or you.
A semi-hilarious nonformula movie that makes you realize why formulas are born.
There are enough droll moments to spark cult status, and McBride's commitment is impressive.
It does what it sets out to do, which is turn a horrible tragedy into feel-good fodder.
An entertaining and earnest chronicle of the 33 with solid performances - one that is undercut by otherwise standard docudrama throughout.

This unabashedly crowd-pleasing movie gets to its uplifting but also somewhat disquieting conclusion and coda (which, as is the custom these days, introduces the audience to the real-life miners) with its integrity intact.
This movie packs an emotional wallop.
It's a relatively solid outcome for The 33 and sure, it's got its kinks and flaws, but there's enough human drama to warrant a watch.
Production design is superb -- the size of the tunnels and how deep they are are shown in a way that is both realistic and awe-inspiring.
The characters and situations are so exagerated to the point it gets irritating or even ridiculous. [Full review in Spanish]

The resilience of these men and their families, who would not back down from a fight with the Chilean government, which was forced to do the right thing, is remarkable, and deserves to be brought to life in this inspiring film.
The familiar beats of the tale are comforting, rather than galvanizing, because we know what's coming.
The 33 is a stable studio job about a recent headline, one that sympathetically gets away from its legacy and focuses on the human element.
Director Patricia Riggen efficiently touches all the bases without doing what Ron Howard did so well in Apollo 13 - creating an air of uncertainty despite the final outcome being known.
It is simply recreating TV images that are familiar to us. It takes a very safe journey towards its obviously predictable outcome, ticking all the boxes on its way.
Corny as it was, I cried when the men were rescued.
One of the great things about "The 33" is the too-rare portrayal of South Americans as decent, hard-working people with loving families.
Strangely cast and melodramatic, but Antonio Banderas' commanding performance makes this worth watching.
At the very least, it doesn't resemble a television movie, with enough style and thespian bigness to transform the meager tale into an event.
It focuses on painting emotion that was there anyway, missing a chance to exploit richer plot elements. As a result it is not as powerful as it might have been.
A peculiar combination of dutiful recreation and souped-up Hollywood disaster movie.
Cutesy. Patronizing. Overlong. But it still works.
It's as though Riggen directs from a checklist of proven emotive shots. However there is no question that this is an extraordinary tale of human fortitude and resilience ...
The Absent One is a consistently engaging thriller which manages to build momentum to a violent and intense conclusion.
Tense right to the end.
Finding a certain majesty in the murk, The Absent One is unashamedly derivative but remains a class act regardless.
An awful number of cliches are being ticked off here (the Fincher-esque lighting, the dogged and socially inept cop), but it's a diverting potboiler for crime drama completists.
A lacklustre and clich-ridden Danish crime sequel.

Moves along smartly enough, and manages the Nordic Noir trick of appearing very classy at all times while unspooling an incredibly lurid plot featuring lashings of schoolgirl sex and sadistic violence.
This compelling sequel makes for a nail biting murder mystery that skilfully presents a relatively clichd story that we have all seen countless times before in a unique manner.
[A] grim treat, mining suspense and urgency from intensely plotted dual timelines of brutal criminality. A must for fans of rumpled, cynical, bitter detectives.
Mikkel Norgaard, the director, propels the story by smartly sticking to the formula he used in the previous film: hints of menace, gorgeously shadowed shots and long flashbacks.
Although each of the first three films tells a full, discrete story, they work best cumulatively, as the ongoing adventures of one cranky, conscientious cop.
Another unsavory journey into contemporary Denmark's seamier underbelly.
Lie Laas' furrowed lead and Nrgaard's taut orchestration of flashback-pumped plotting help flesh out old clichs - at least until the climax takes a glum turn for the overwrought.
...The film's simplistic and episodic plot put a major dampener on what could have been a welcome breath of fresh air for family animation.

"The Addams Family" builds to a generic "be yourself" message that could have come from any animated tale. In doing so, "The Addams Family" does the last thing the Addams ever wanted to do: it fits in.

With its clich√©d diversity message, blander than it might have been, but the striking visuals and general good humor-combined, of course, with the nostalgia factor-should make it an agreeable pastime for both kids and adults.

If all you require for your entertainment needs at the moment is 90 minutes of cheerful silliness that will amuse kids and adults in equal measure, The Addams Family is fleet and funny enough to make such a task seem like a snap.
Now the mirthfully macabre clan known as the Addams Family - an iconic creation of legendary New Yorker cartoonist Charles Addams - have been fed into Hollywood's cartoon woodchipper.

There have been a fair few Addams Family adaptations over the years but, following a clumsy set-up, this latest entry (the first in two decades) ends up as exultantly kooky, spooky, and consequently ooky as its predecessors.
The Addams Family isn't a scream, it's a painfully generic kids' film.

Cooky, spooky Addams Family is an entertaining memory lane walk for fans of the franchise. Pacing is slow, but it's still fluffy, good old-fashioned animated fun with the best entrance ever from Snoop Dogg and humanity lesson on embracing differences.
Like the Addamses themselves, the film comes of as well-meaning but more than a little off. Still, even a brief visit from the Addams is better than no visit at all.
...with the Halloween season right around the corner. the tired novelty of serving up these frightening funny faces in a packaged kiddie comedy is moreso a tepid trick than it is a treasured treat.
Even children will understand that the theme of encouraging individual expression would be more compelling if the storyline wasn't so resolutely dull.

This isn't a film only for children or old-school fans. There's something here for everyone. It's a clever, funny movie with a message about family, even the quirky ones who we want to belittle or make fun of.
Throw in a fantastic vocal cast... and the result is a terrific way to temporarily escape festive season madness.
It feels like a long time since Addams-style wordplay was last in cinemas and it feels good to hear it again.

There's frenetic energy in this animated revamp of the iconic comic strip, and it's both engaging and exhausting. Thankfully, along with the kookiness, the filmmakers make sure the film is creepy and spooky.
"The Addams Family" has been done to death. Enough already, give it a rest.
Digs deep to the roots of what made this series so entertaining and lovable since it was introduced.
Despite its infantilized treatment of the family it still provides enough creative set-pieces and heart-warming character moments to please both fans and newcomers.
Can't help but feel like a wasted opportunity to truly embrace the source material's dark yet likeable temperament.
A fun reboot that leaves one wanting more adventures from this mythical clan. [Full Review in Spanish]
Despite being 50 years old, there is still something refreshing about watching The African Queen.

The performances by Humphrey Bogart (who earned his lone Oscar for his troubles) and Katharine Hepburn, along with John Huston's astute direction has produced a high spirited and highly entertaining adventure movie.
This movie is in the DNA of rom-coms and buddy-cop comedies and fish-out-of-water tales and Indiana Jones (he bickers and fights Germans too! Plus, dirt beard!).
Huston understands the majestic savagery of his surroundings well enough to let it exert some dramatic pressure on what is primarily a buoyant romantic comedy.
This is a film where pretty much everyone is serving aces.
Annually gets some votes for best film ever made.
...one of those films that have been so assimilated into the collective unconscious that they feel ubiquitous,to the point that even those who have never seen it probably feel as though they have.
John Huston's film wavers disconcertingly and a little aimlessly between life and fairy tale.
Almost painfully entertaining. The textbook definition of "American Movie Classic."
There are not two better actors to tackle these roles, and director Huston keeps their story moving without lulls.
As a paradigm of why certain actors and filmmakers remain revered several decades after their death or greatest success, The African Queen is more than merely exemplary.

The African Queen (1951) is the uncomplicated tale of two companions with mismatched, "opposites attract" personalities who develop an implausible love affair as they travel together downriver in Africa around the start of World War I.
Bogart and Hepburn are truly amazing together.
The action scenes are expertly handled, the film was a hit and Hollywood liked it so much that it remade it in 1975 as Rooster Cogburn, with John Wayne opposite Hepburn.
These are not "pretty" characters, but they are beautiful and their affair is a natural force outside of society and the church.
Bogie and Hepburn, a dynamic duo! A love story, adventure story and comedy, all rolled into one rollicking and perilous river ride. You never get tired watching it.

A classic journey adventure, with a series of obstacles that they meet with resilience and resourcefulness, but the story is how they move from "Mr. Allnut" and "Miss" to Charlie and Rosie, opposites who find strength, support and unexpected love...
Five minutes in, and cowriter-director John Huston has already set the stage for something besides your typical '50s jungle-bwana boogie.

Both of the actors who portray protagonists -- Bogart and Hepburn -- were past their prime when they made this film, but they gave superb performance nevertheless, often using humour to make their on-screen chemistry more believable.

[Writer/director Jennifer Kent] skillfully keeps us locked into the moment-by-moment thrills of a monster movie, but also insists that this Babadook is clearly a stand-in for the other problems that inflict the lonely household.
...about the dark side that any bone-weary parent can sometimes feel creeping up within.
The Babadook lures you in with the familiar childhood fears about something lurking under your bed but delivers something fresh and even surprising.
Writer/director Jennifer Kent has created a modern horror masterpiece in this film. It is about as creepy as creepy can get.
Rest assured, Jennifer Kent's debut more than lives up to the hype.

There's a grand divide between what Kent has done here and what most of us consider horror. You'll spend your first week after the experience sleeping with the lights on. You will also come away enriched and provoked.
It's brilliantly acted, beautifully shot, has loads of tension and announces newcomer Jennifer Kent as a writer-director of real class and depth.
The Babadook is impressive for its focused script, acting as a giant metaphor about either letting our demons take over of our lives or learning to keep them at bay, no matter how scary it may seem.
An engrossing Australian ghost story.
Let a law be passed, requiring all horror films to be made by female directors.
Come for the dread, stay for the subtext, and top it all off with a little nightlight shopping on Amazon.
No matter how successful The Babadook turns out to be - and Jennifer Kent's horror story deserves all the success it gets - the prospects of a best-selling kid-lit tie-in don't look good.
It's almost a shame it turns into a ghost movie at all, but not quite.
For all its otherworldly flourishes, it confirms that the most terrifying monsters are remarkably local -- domestic, even.
The Babadook is an incredibly well-made movie, with each aspect of the film fitting neatly into an overall theme.
The Babadook will stick with you. It is brilliantly done, imaginative horror that grips us where most of us live.
Manages to deliver real, seat-grabbing jolts while also touching on more serious themes of loss, grief and other demons that can not be so easily vanquished.
Rich in mental metaphor, the monster knocking at the door only exists from the power we give it.
The Ballad of Buster Scruggs is a well crafted, if narrow, anthology about life in the West, with a hefty gloss of cinema-magic.
The inspired moments in Buster Scruggs and the thought provoking arcs in the proceedings are testament to the Coen brothers' filmmaking talent.
Tragedy is at the forefront of the Coen Brothers western anthology. The wildly entertaining yarn incorporates many of the Coen's staples, quirky characters, witty dialogue, and plenty of misfortune.
The opening segment might be the best 15 minutes of any film this year. Unfortunately, the film never reaches that level again.

Distilling the finest and most absurd tenants of the Western genre and the most indulgent concessions to the Coens' idiosyncratic filmmaking yet, the film is not just the most essential film in the brothers' catalogue.
The Ballad of Buster Scruggs is a pop fantasia that's interested in the meaning of what a brutal place the Old West really was.
All in all, this "Buster" is something else.
Consistency isn't always there, but "Scruggs" is pure Joel and Ethan Coen, and that always offers something fascinating, even when they get lost in their own creation.

Despite the snark and irreverence, genre specialists will eat up the devotion to detail here, from the relish the Coens take in writing colorful 19th century Western vernacular to the musical choices and the lovely between-acts artwork.
Even the spottier moments are enlivened by the Coens' knack for myth-spinning, ably assisted by Carter Burwell's eclectic, evocative score.
There is undoubted power and entertainment in these stories, a harkening back to the quintessential American genre that manages to also play with and undercut its own myth-making power.
It offers as much satisfaction as an unstable advent calendar. There's definitely something sweet behind every door, but it rarely tastes as fun as it looks.
Any full-length Coen brothers' movie beats these six shorts, but they're all gorgeous, original and often funny.
Ballad may not be a TV series, but if the Coens wanted to open that fake book back up and spin some more yarns, more episodes would be welcome.
The Ballad of Buster Scruggs is a formidable first outing for the Coens on a streaming format, but there is no doubt that this narrative six-shooter has a couple of duds.
The storytelling is so delicate and precise, like a beautiful poem squeezed of every superfluous word. This is some of the Coen Brothers best work and it deserves to be seen.
The Coen Brothers' latest movie is a hoot.
Seems like a lark at first, but taken in totality actually gets to the core of who the Coen Brothers are as storytellers.
An unconventional masterpiece.
The Coens' love of westerns is well established and each of the stories is impeccably crafted...
...just another run-of-the-mill low-budget horror effort.
Blair Erickson's The Banshee Chapter is a relentless bit of horror that mixes governmental conspiracies and psychedelic drugs for one hell of a traumatizing trip.
H.P. Lovecraft's From Beyond gets a 21st century revamp in Blair Erickson's solid first feature.
A smart, clever, and diverting little mash-up of numerous sci-fi and horror tropes.
Scare-for-scare, the most frightening film I've seen this year.

Although it relies to a large extent on found footage, fear not the format -- The Banshee Chapter is actually a well-made, delightfully acted and best of all honestly scary brain twist of a horror movie.
The Banshee Chapter can't seem to decide if it wants to be a found-footage horror movie, or a more traditional one. To its detriment, it splits the difference.
ambitious horror film, but too much of the time the viewer is just waiting for something horrific to happen.

The twist ending doesn't quite impact as it should, but that is mostly because Erickson's imagery and storytelling has scaled such convincingly offbeat heights up to that point. He is a filmmaker to watch.
"The Banshee Chapter" is both elegant and terrifying.

X-Files style horror movie based on MK-Ultra drug experiments. Ted Levine as a Hunter Thompson character is superb. On a budget, the film is a lot scarier than most of the more expensive "apparition" type movies showing up at the Cineplex.

It works as a gonzo expos of some of the 20th century's madder moments - but perhaps more importantly, this psychotropic remapping of history never forgets to be proper jump-out-of-your-seat scary. Think of it as Fear and Loathing in Chamber 5...
Although no single strand within it can be called original, Banshee Chapter blends them flawlessly, delivering the most convincing piece of otherworldly horror for years.
Ultimately, Banshee Chapter isn't a game-changer, but it's a tight, neatly constructed little shocker that delivers what it promises -- would that many bigger films could say the same.
Director Blair Erickson surely has style to burn, even if he oftentimes betrays his atmospheric shorthand and gets cold feet at the most inopportune moments.

Although it doesn't push the limits of horror as far as it could, the feature offers a mildly unnerving journey into the abyss of the brain, dialing up the creep-out factor as it investigates a nightmare rooted in reality.
A moody horror film from an immensely talented new director.
The film avoids any real attempt at constructing scarily effective set-pieces in favour of having one of the unnamed entities pop screeching out of the dark whack-a-mole-style every few minutes.
The central drama never fully engages, but the jolts that "Banshee" delivers are check-the-locks scary.
More unsettling than actually scary, this slow-burning horror movie is directed and acted with style even though the script feels rather under-developed.
Really creepy showcase for Lorre with a botched ending.

Wastes a captivating original premise and some fine performances with a stiff script and a cop-out ending.

It's like an Easter egg hunt for adults, joyous and sweet. The Big Year competition may be fierce, but the movie is as soft as a bunny.
Steve Martin, Jack Black and Owen Wilson all have made a great film or two, surrounded by tons of bad ones. "The Big Year" is closer to the latter.
A game of Angry Birds is far more enjoyable than this flocked-up mess. A script written in wingdings would have been preferable.
If The Big Year does anything, it highlights how far Martin, Black, and Wilson have fallen from the giddy, off-kilter humor they used to bring to projects.
The result is an offence-free, mild entertainment in which everyone from cast to scriptwriter seems to be winging it.
For less ambitious bird watchers, these details may be fascinating... but for most of us, it's strictly for the birds.
Yes, the characters are razor-thin and the dialogue wooden, but there's some light comic fun to be had with the batty birders.
It's funny, has a plot and its lack of profanity and violence is a welcome relief.
The movie feels rushed ... and in the process, it solves its minimal conflicts too easily.
The characters are just as two-dimensional as they sound, but damned if Wilson, Martin, and Black don't make those dimensions pop.
Owen Wilson and Jack Black appear on the verge of succumbing to the same terminal blandness that's gripped Martin for so long.
Faintly amusing, not wacky at all, considering this cast.
This movie stubbornly refuses to take flight, or generate more than a few chuckles.
Considering the high-flying talent attached, The Big Year is a big letdown.
If the mere mention of the blue-footed booby sends you into paroxysms, The Big Year is the film for you.
In some alternate universe, a much better version of The Big Year exists, one that embraces the essential, insular weirdness and romantic fanaticism of the birding community it chronicles.
If you go into it not expecting big comedy, "The Big Year" can be an enjoyable diversion for an evening. But it helps if you like nature.

"The Big Year" proves yet again that comedy isn't just magic that happens when funny people stand next to each other. They actually have to be doing or saying, or not doing or not saying, something that might inspire humor.

While Sheridan (who co-wrote) weighs in with gutsy, gritty direction, shooting the fight scenes with panache and cutting sharply throughout for suspense and pace. Politically, too, it's sensitive and sensible.
