The third collaboration between director Jim Sheridan and actor Daniel Day-Lewis, The Boxer is an involving but rather prosaic report from the Belfast front with a melancholy undertow of romantic yearning.
Sheridan is very good on the ways and means of the IRA.
Brian Cox is strong as the tough old IRA chief who realizes that change is essential. The choices his character makes are surprising. Cox resembles a more muted Albert Finney in this role.
The characters were sullen and taciturn. When they did speak, they didn't reveal anything useful.
In this dull film, poignant characters caught up in histrionics flail with one glove, while much emotional shadowboxing is done with the other.

Day-Lewis is superb. His boxing scenes are every bit as credible as his love scenes, and his performance throughout hums with intensity wrung from stillness and restraint. Ms. Watson proves equal to her co-star.
There is little chance for the movie's talented stars, Day Lewis and Emily Watson to establish and develop their characters, beyond their set-piece declarations of love.
The gravity of this environment, though, unfortunately highlights the insipidity and artificiality of Sheridan and George's screenplay.
A well-acted drama that salutes the moral fiber of a pugilist fed up with violence.

If The Boxer doesn't quite score a knockout, that's because of such flaws as the too-sketchy development of the character of Maggie's son, who turns out to be pivotal. But the movie carries the day by aiming its strongest punches straight at the heart.
The acting is amazing, with Day-Lewis and Watson giving excellent performances and showing great chemistry.
The Boxer would be only a strongly-directed special interest film if it wasn't for the emotional intensity provided by Day-Lewis and Watson.
Daniel Day-Lewis is such a consummate actor that every film he makes, and every blood- and-sinew performance he delivers, tends to have the stamp of prestige about it.

We never figure out, though, what drives Day-Lewis' Danny. We just take it on faith that he's stubborn and sick of violence. The filmmakers don't help much, offering just a twist on the star-crossed lovers story, mixed with standard boxing melodrama.
Director Jim Sheridan teams up again with Daniel Day-Lewis for another Irish saga. But this one, while enjoyable, doesn't quite live up to their prior films.
This film is a satisfying marriage of a thoughtful screenplay, insightful direction and a powerfully skilled cast.

An inept, misanthropic melodrama written by novelist Bret Easton Ellis and funded mostly through a Kickstarter campaign.
Considering this is a film directed by Paul Schrader and written by Bret Easton Ellis, The Canyons is a limp and toothless piece of work from two artists who should know better.
...takes the shards of a tacky Hollywood soap opera and transforms it into a pointed, sometimes brutal comedy.
There's no feeling, no energy, no sense of the internal lives behind these zombies. It's nihilism, personified.
Paul Schrader and Brett Easton Ellis don't have the sense of play this kind of narrative of one-upmanship requires, as we're never allowed to enjoy the characters' misdeeds.

Ellis throws in lots of references to social media in a desperate bid for cultural currency, while Schrader intersperses the drama with pretentious shots of boarded-up movie theaters to suggest this is all a metaphor for the death of cinema.

Lindsay Lohan's raw, passionate, haunted performance is easily the best thing about "The Canyons," a film that depicts the superficial and passive-aggressive without finding any deeper comment or point beneath the surface.
If Schrader is right and cinema is dying, The Canyons functions as one of the nails in the coffin.
The Canyons is inept and de-energizing, and Lindsay Lohan is enough to make you cry.
Resembling the all-time dullest episode of MTV's 'Undressed,' The Canyons unfolds like Lifetime tried to make a Cinemax movie.
This pitiful would-be-sleazy melodrama is so terrible it can't even manage to be cheesy.
Despite rumours of diva-like demands and general flakiness on set, [Lohan] gets the job done, which is more than one can say for her co-stars.
Despite its impressive pedigree and unorthodox methods, "The Canyons" is hopelessly thin, clumsy and dull.

The film is clear that no struggle is small to those who engage in it, be they people or nations, and the repercussions of careless decisions can be catastrophic.
It's an art film version of "The Bad Seed," where the antics are minor but the outcome is even bigger: One never expects the kid who acts up a little bit will one day almost destroy the world.

With expressionist leanings, bilingual dialogue and Scott Walker's strings, it may leave some cold, not least Twi-hards (Robert Pattinson co-stars). But submit to Corbet's vision and you'll find something original and unsettling.
Brady Corbet's disturbing psycho-historical melodrama is like the Stanley Kubrick edit of The Grand Budapest Hotel.

Although it canters down a well-trod path toward a predictable finish line, The Cup sustains interest through the smooth efficiency of its storytelling and the engaging performances of its lead players.
A big heart and fine performances counter clumsy filmmaking in the patchy true life Australian drama The Cup.
It's a shamelessly old-fashioned picture but if you like horses and fancy cantering off into the land of wish-fulfilment for a couple of hours, why not?
A tale of heart-wrenching tragedy and uplifting triumph that never quite hits its stride.

I found The Cup to be a pleasant-enough viewing experience. At the same time, I was never as riveted as I have been by other, similarly-themed films. It makes you feel good without ever truly stirring the soul.
True sports tale about overcoming tragedy has mature themes.
There's a lot of interesting stuff here but in the end it's a bit disappointing.
The script by Wincer and Eric O'Keefe is a maudlin mess right from the word go, and if any film this year has been filled with more treacle-laden melodrama I certainly have not seen it.
Driven by Stephen Curry's brilliant lead performance, this deeply moving story is told in an accessible but powerful manner.
Tale of a Melbourne Cup triumph is reduced to a corny horse opera
Even the most ardent lover of feel-good biopics would have a hard time backing this horse.
The Cup doesn't dig deeply enough into its characters. Everyone is portrayed in a positive light and it's as if the writers were too afraid to challenge the audience.
It won't stop the nation, but it will while away a Saturday afternoon.
The Cup has certainly been released at the right time to cash in on Spring Racing Carnival fever. But not all paying punters will be pleased with the final dividend returned.
Dull? You don't know from dull.

Writer/director David Freyne's The Cured is a different kind of zombie film.
Debut director David Freyne has obviously seen entirely too many George Romero movies for his own good.
The Cured marks an auspicious debut for Freyne, who showcases an impressive eye for detail.
David Freyne creates a thoughtful and provocative zombie film.
Post-zombie-outbreak horror flick is strong on atmosphere, weak on plot and character.
Page, also credited as a producer, is largely pushed to the sidelines, but the shifting power dynamics between Keeley and a menacing Vaughan-Lawlor effectively elevate the material.

There's a sneakiness to this film's first two acts, as if writer-director David Freyne is desperately trying to convince you that "The Cured" isn't headed for the zombie-movie third act that it obviously, inevitably is.
"The Cured" drops the politics to become a straight-up zombie flick not nearly as intriguing, though no doubt better for box office.
David Freyne has created a social drama crafted within a genre film.
Mostly it plays as a somber drama about grief, guilt and self-loathing, with both lead figures shell-shocked in their way.

Though The Cured loses its way a little in the final act, it offers delicious variations that facilitate new (if not exactly fresh) flavours of creepiness and great scope for socio-political metaphor.
Bitterly disappointing.
There's enough originality to give the film punch, and it's gratifying to see the Irish setting so well integrated.
Struggles to move beyond genre clichs.
The gory details of this imagined world are just too specific to have any resonance. We're left with a solemn yet pulpy horror flick.
My tolerance for zombie acting and zombie drama in the style of Danny Boyle's 28 Days Later is never all that high, and the tropes are a bit familiar here.
"The Cured" isn't light, bloody fun, retaining an impressively curated heaviness about it, with Freyne laboring to making something different with familiar working parts.

When a thoughtful film like "The Cured" takes advantage of classic zombie elements, we are inspired to talk about larger questions that actually confront us. Fear of the other is a disease still in need of a cure.

The Cured is a fantastic zombie film with intelligent writing, precision direction, top-tier acting, and sincere sociopolitical themes and parallels that are essential in elevating horror films to something greater than just scares and gore.
a fresh idea in a genre where too many ideas are overused and stale.
A fascinating film with eerie background music, a believable cast, and creepy atmosphere. This dark contemporary version of a Grimm fairy tale is very intense and not for kids.
For viewers who are not into genre trappings, The Curse of Sleeping Beauty [...] is dull and silly beyond belief.
Director Pearry Teo, who scripted with Josh Nadler, pushes the brooding atmospherics, entrapping us in so many dingy, dustily lit spaces that, like Thomas, we just want to escape.
The film feels like a fairy tale as re-imagined by the staff of your local Hot Topic.
This is one sluggish curse that wouldn't wake even Sleeping Beauty.
The latest in a long line of horror films shamelessly ripping off the Brothers Grimm won't leave you believing in fairy tales.

This movie is just over 80 minutes, and it feels like (a) they're stretching to fill that much, since so much of what happens is redundant; and (b) that they didn't actually do a lot of takes, since so many of these conversations are stilted.

It doesn't build up enough mythology to be a pure fantasy; it doesn't do enough with the original Brothers Grimm story to be a pure fairy tale; and there aren't enough scares or enough gore to be pure horror.
The Dark Red is a smart little film with a more sophisticated understanding of its subject matter and more to say than past stories of this sort might lead you to expect.
The Dark Red is an interesting way of exploring the hysterical mother trope. Helped massively by a great lead performance, The Dark Red may just have birthed the next screen Sarah Connor.
Dan Bush's The Dark Red is a tale of maternity and madness, vampiric predation and class exploitation.
The Dark Red isn't afraid to get a little bloody, and it's all the more entertaining for it.

[A] still potent 1981 documentary about Los Angeles punk rock.

Spheeris' film of the L.A punk scene circa 1980 remains a fascinating document of an era when the words 'alternative' and 'independent' meant something other than niche marketing terms when they were applied to music.
The Decline of Western Civilization' is a shrewd and engrossing documentary even for audiences who have absolutely no patience for the music it includes.
the documentary is quite enjoyable
The interviews are mostly very funny, probably not always intentionally so. It's far from unmissable, but it's valuable rock history with some great noise.

A bracing, stimulating and technically superb close-up look at the LA punk scene, pic is pitched at a perfect distance to allow for simultaneous engagement in the music and spectacle, and for rueful contemplation of what it all might mean.
...a perfect symbol for the nihilistic hardcore punk rock that developed in Los Angeles - an angry and unwholesome scene that grew parallel to the more intellectual New York scene
The result is both insanely funny and very frightening.
Spheeris doesn't stand at the remove some documentarians do; you feel like you're in the scene, at those shows, and in those rooms.
This is the first in a trilogy of rock documentaries made by Spheeris that, viewed today, seem like valuable cultural documents. But your granny won't like it.
This was the first time anyone had seen a mosh pit on-screen, and Spheeris somehow gets right in the scrum, capturing a blur of flailing bodies.
You can't put a price on a filmic document such as this one.
The ingenuity and appeal of this bizarre, riveting and compelling film lie in its value as reportage.
The film's greatest strength is Spheeris' knack for fitting comfortably in with her subjects; it's clear they trust her, which enables her to capture the rawness on tape.

Director Penelope Spheeris neither champions, patronizes nor condescends to the participants' stylized fury. The result is a film that will appeal equally to the furious and the curious, assuming that both enter the arena with an open mind.
The Decline of Western Civilization remains an essential documentary and one fantastically weird slice of life.
Growing up a punk kid in a small or at least smallish town, this was your primer, your roadmap to being an outsider.
Clever but manipulative.
Rescue-dog purists may not approve of the line "The Dog Lover" takes, yet to this dog lover it comes off as compassionate and realistic: a plea for a place where good care can become common sense.
The film's prevailing theme may be that nothing is black and white, but the execution ... proves spottier than a kennel full of caged Dalmatians.
At best, The Dog Lover is like a bad Hallmark Channel or Lifetime movie, so bland and vanilla it would be inhumane to canines to call it a "dog" of a movie.
The Dog Lover looks less like a cheesy drama destined for the Lifetime Channel than it does a piece of anti-government propaganda. In this movie at least, the businessman is the underdog.
The movie is shamelessly manipulative on several levels, and the cast members do their respective bits effectively.
It's all as clunkily melodramatic as it sounds, with the climactic trial sequences proving particularly slow going.
Heavy-handed drama is well-acted but manipulative.
The Dog Lover may be "based on a true story," but everything about it feels so artificial and agenda-driven that it's impossible to enjoy unless you're already firmly on its side.
Poorly constructed with grossly misplaced performances and intentions.
The Double, with its inviting alienation, nails a curious mood that's been too long absent from contemporary film ...

Who says you can't have fun with a self-consciously arthouse film? Director Richard Ayoade mashes the styles of Terry Gilliam (lots of ducts), David Lynch (lots of lamps) and the Coen brothers (lots of dim corridors) in this diverting style exercise.
[Ayoade] starts to come into his own as a filmmaker.
Bleak dark comedy about contemporary urban alienation.
When The Double lets us marinate in its distinctive visual aesthetic, it's provocative, occasionally fascinating.
The kind of movie that may have been more satisfying to make than it is to watch.
Its clever moments outweigh its contrived ones, twisting into an atmospheric package that's both subtle and haunting.
A dank and dour drama contrasting the woes of a sad sack loser to the triumphs of an ambitious and self-confident winner.
A painfully funny odyssey of personal ineffectualness that is bitterly wonderful in how it revels in the decrepit horror of the everyday world.
The Double draws on past literary giants to nail a current malaise with offbeat humor and visionary flair.
Ayoade's difficult second film shows the directorial skill - and daring - of a major player, even if it can't quite escape being swallowed by its influences.
The familiar elements of "The Double," which Ayoade co-wrote with Avi Korine, coalesce into a unique whole that turns the material into a contemplative nightmare.

This workplace-as-hellscape is not new territory, exactly - the story's based on Dostoevsky, plays like Kafka, and looks like an Orwellian nightmare. But who'd complain, since it lets Jesse Eisenberg offer what amounts to an acting master-class.
Ayoade bravely avoids lightening the tone, instead utilising impressive sound editing and cinematography to craft a moody, paranoid psychological fantasy.

The Double speaks rather metaphorically to the horrors of the homogenization of post-industrialized society, creating an Orwellian environment that is bogged down in the quagmire of ridiculously absurd bureaucratic processes.
The film's bleakness is almost satirical. It's Brazil drained of the daydreams.
Ayoade's breathtakingly realized oddity will appeal to fans of David Lynch and the comic surrealism of Terry Gilliam's "Brazil."
If The Double never fully succeeds, it's still exactly the sort of challenge and risk one wants out of a filmmaker as promising as Ayoade.
As a pure head-trip visual and auditory experience it feels like one of the biggest discoveries, and biggest surprises, of 2014.
It's a fantastic looking picture, but images are the only memorable element of this psychological puzzler, which works extremely hard to register as mischief.
This ludicrous costume shoot-'em-up only inflates its whopping clich√©s and anachronisms by placing them in the incongruously deployed IMAX format.
...a swashbuckling, exciting tale.
A tiresome but meticulously detailed and visually sumptuous Russian melodrama about romance and intrigue amid the nobility in 19th century St. Petersburg.
Decidedly retro and spectacular to look at.
Eye for detail makes The Duelist's protagonists just as compelling as their setting.
Mizgirev's script is an indigestible, soap-operatic mess of backstories, clich√©s, and the kind of ambiguous mystic overtones that have become an unbreakable addiction for Russian film.
The clich√©d story line pursues turgidity with a relentless determination.

Writer-director Mizgirev has a sharpshooter's cold pair of eyes. His lens adds an antiseptic quality to the many deaths... It's Fyodorov's performance that communicates the emotional burden of killing.
Dazzles and provokes as it makes little real sense beyond the confines of its hermetic milieu.
The look of the movie is still the most appealing thing about it. Whether you watch a film on a giant screen or an iPhone, the format doesn't untangle messy plot threads.
Most fans of costume drama don't head to the movies expecting explosive exit wounds, and few action fans are going to be wowed by ostentatious lapels.
A welcome indication of the current Russian cinema's commercial ambitions and potential.
Gorgeously empty, The Duelist is more interesting as a reflection of the Russian sociopolitical climate today than it is as an actual goddamn movie.
I didn't care much for its grandiose self-seriousness and the dour focus on masculine honor above all else.
Has more to offer than your average US thriller.
Entertaining, suspenseful thriller with an engaging script, strong characters, some intriguing ideas and a pair of terrific performances from Brit Marling and Alexander Skarsgard.
Zal Batmanglij and Brit Marling, creators of the creepy Sound Of My Voice, once again explore underground movements, this time without the SF trappings.
Marling and Batmangli are smart enough to know that character and ideas matter, and how the presence of those things can improve action and suspense.
A crackling good political thriller, made in the spirit of some of the best espionage films, and with themes like eco-terrorism and whistleblowers that make it feel immediate like few recent dramas.

Why was the opportunity for true commentary or even character development within this fascinating world discarded in favor of an awkwardly-staged and poorly-written love story laden with genre tropes?

The second picture in a fascinating collaboration with producer-writer-star Brit Marling, this clever, involving spy drama builds to a terrific level of intrigue before losing some steam in its second half.
Another project that proves this actress and filmmaker has the chops that will guarantee her longevity in the movie industry.
This well-paced story is tense and thoughtful, and is anchored by a trio of terrific performances.
Batmanglij and Marling's expertly cultivate mystery, especially when Sarah first meets the members of East.
The political content ends up being a little simplistic, but the characters are well-drawn, and the movie has a haunting atmosphere that carries it past some rough plotting.
The filmmakers seem to believe the mere fact of their earnestness makes their movie more worthwhile than a more exciting 'escapist' spy thriller.
Fascinating drama set in the shadowy world of ecoterrorism.
The reason the movie works, despite some "movie-stupid" developments in the second half, has everything to do with the low-key and unaffected quality Marling brings to the screen.
The East makes for a passable thriller, as 1 percenters get theirs in satisfying, if incrementally implausible ways.
Almost but not quite the truly terrific movie that Batmanglij and Marling are going to make one day ...

The East suffers from a critical identity crisis, squandering an initially intriguing premise to veer awkwardly between intimate character study and formulaic espionage thriller. It satisfies on neither count.
It all adds up to an intelligent romp which keeps one eye on timely issues (activists or terrorists?) and the other on entertainment.
The whole movie has the smugness of a cult. At one and the same time it's devoid of reality and insufferably full of itself.
Audacious.
an archetypal romantic comedy that reshapes the mold
Though Almodovar touches on many of his favorite absurdities, he does so with surprising subtlety.
I found this dramatization a mature Almodovar work, perceptive and cutting through in an incisive way to the everyday problems in life that wear people down.
Dramatizes the contentious relationship between fiction and reality.
If it isn't as successful as his very best work, neither is it a failure -- and there are certainly enough Alomodovarisms to bring a smile to anyone's face
There is not much of a plot; just real, romantically entwined lives -- a world away from the gaudy camp Almodovar had begun to tire us with.
Likely to be disappointing to Almodovar's admirers, and inexplicable to anyone else.
Almodovar has created a film that offers hope to all mad lovers who need it.
If Leo appears to be doing some more or less orthodox movie-style suffering -- crying jags, a suicide attempt and the like -- perhaps that's just what she's supposed to be doing.
Seems to go in a dozen directions at once but ties up in the final reel into a tight, cohesive and enjoyable whole.
An intimate, beautifully wrought work, it reflects a new maturity in Almodovar's work and is one of his best pictures.
For the most part it is an absorbing story.
A ripe, entertaining soap opera.
It's bland as often as it is affecting, and presents little that's new or original.
Secret isn't the usual romp, but it's Almodovar's most committed work in years.
It's a witty, intelligent scramble, and it's beautifully mounted.
My kind of bouquet.
Though The Flower of My Secret is a slight work, it is a pleasing return to form.
It slowly unfolds from a narrow satire into a romance that's rich with real-life bitterness.
The movie is full of familiar Almodovar fare, but it feels freshened.
Halloween brought classic genre style into a new era, and The Fog goes even further in that direction.
It's one of the director's most atmospheric, the shots of a wave-lashed cove and fog-choked headland making the town's impending reckoning almost poetic.
Though the plot is implausible and the unfolding story hardly makes any sense, Carpenter stylishly presents an eerie atmosphere for the zombie invasion.
The evidence for John Carpenter's artistry is right there on the screen. Most moviegoers will be too scared to notice.
Carpenter also relies heavily on cheap scare tactics (supernatural mists and people jumping out of the dark) rather than subtle suspense, but some sequences do turn the tension dial up quite high.
Fairly dull ghost story occasionally given a boost by the cast and by Carpenter's proficiency with the genre. Occasionally.
The rich color cinematography by Dean Cundey gleams with shadow-drenched goodness in its new digital life, heightening the crisp confidence of Carpenter's Val Lewton-like atmosphere.
Story exposition and setting are well-established before the opening titles are over, and The Fog proceeds to layer one fright atop another.
The Fog still holds up.
Not much gore, but still too intense for kids.
Carpenter's confidence is outrageous; the range of his models even more so (from Poe to RKO); and the achievement is all his own, despite ragged moments and occasional hesitations.
Let's just hope that your theater and your town don't have any dark secrets that may be carried in along with The Fog.
If you're the sort who can enjoy an old-fashioned ghost story without speeding right to the 'good parts,' The Fog is a highly recommended little shocker.
Creates a sense of near-apocalyptic gloom.
Was enough to keep a teenage boy awake at night, and can still give a grown man the creeps.
The Fog is pivotal to the cementing of Carpenter's aesthetic.
Sure, this is a ghost story, though because it is a film images display the action, and in result the intended horror is subsidized.
... makes the most of the dramatic possibilities inherent in an isolated coastal town, as well as the scare potential of darkness, fog, and silent strangers bearing longshoremen's hooks.
...a sporadically arresting yet lamentably uninvolving horror effort from Carpenter.
...a good, old-fashioned ghost story.
A morally ambiguous story since its script raises a problematic subject but it manages to remain in a point of neutrality, which makes it interesting. [Full review in Spanish]
It is a cautionary tale handled in a workmanlike fashion but Keaton is sharp and compelling as we watch the rebirth of a salesman.
You may find your McDonald's burger distasteful for a whole new reason after watching The Founder.

A fascinating story about a man's reckless determination to achieve success, but unlike similar films about greed, it fails to plunge into the depths of Kroc's complex psychology. [Full review in Spanish]
It succeeds most in exploring how business ambitions can ruin craft and ingenuity.
It's a classic story of American corporate steamrollering with the little people flattened on the way to dishonestly-earned but unimaginable success ...
A great modern fable where the pursuit of a dream can be sapped by greed or selfishness. Keaton's character represents the best and the worst of the American dream. [Full review in Spanish]
A generic "rise to the top" story without even the decency to suggest Kroc lost his soul along the way.
One of the most accurate and incisive radiographs ever made on cannibal capitalism and, of course, the shadows surrounding the American dream. [Full review in Spanish]

Hancock swallows Kroc's story whole, seeing it as an inspirational tale of gumption and determination, which makes Keaton's typically nuanced performance increasingly difficult to reconcile with the storytelling.

Is it possible to be ethical and win at business? Were the McDonald brothers too stuck in the past to succeed? These are among the questions you'll ponder after seeing The Founder, a movie that will change the way you see Big Macs.

... more than just a nostalgic crowd-pleaser about greasy griddles and deep-fat fryers, proving itself equally effective as a cautionary tale about the perils of growing a business and the dangers of capitalism run amok.
The Founder feels like a noble and worthy attempt to set the record straight, and on that front, it completely succeeds.
Makes one hungry for In-N-Out, if I'm being honest.

All that greasy money sliding around on the griddle of destiny. All that grain-fed optimism dusted with a hint of salt. It's undeniably delicious; manna for the masses...[that] leaves you feeling deep in your gut, something's not right.
"The Founder" examines a kind of bigger-is-better, bullying capitalism that is, for the moment at least, celebrated. That doesn't make it a better movie, but it does make it a timely one.

People ask me all the time to recommend nonviolent movies, and now I have a solid option. You'll see nothing happen, good or bad, that will keep you up at night, but you will find yourself thinking about it after it's over.

Hancock tells the story in an engaging enough fashion, and watching Michael Keaton is never a waste of anyone's time. But as a look at big business versus small, the old America versus the new, The Founder is disappointingly bland fare.

[Hancock has] cast the film with splendid actors who can handle that kind of breezy energy. It's never laugh out loud funny, but we're invited to enjoy Kroc as a rascal, not a villain... almost til the end.
Despite a tendency to veer toward something out of the McDonalds PR department, a briskly entertaining look at Ray Kroc's sleazy business practices.
I missed the train when The FP was first leaving the station, but I'm firmly on-board now...
Infinitely better as a beer-goggled pitch than as a feature film, The FP never gets beyond the studied novelty of its own pose.
The FP is a mostly serious, straight-faced spoof of misogynistic gangland B-movies and sports dramas, and rarely does it fail to deliver sparks of originality and sly comedy.
The film only embraces the most superficial aspects of the genre. The heart, the soul and the melodrama are all missing.
Creative, wild, and absolutely depth-free...
One of the loudest, most ridiculous, entertaining movies I've seen in a long, long time.
You'll have more fun hosting your own Dance Dance Revolution battles than watching The FP.
It falls all over itself to lampoon its midnight-movie forebears even as it borrows their contrivances.
The FP has a one-note joke of a conceit, and when that runs out, it has few actual jokes to fill the humorless void.
The FP functions perfectly as a cult movie, but its ambition never feels bigger than to achieve that benchmark.
"The FP" so desperately wants to be cultishly admired for its bad-taste rollout of wacko characters, ugly costumes and vulgar slang that it forgets to be genuinely offbeat or funny.
Just a crazy creation by original artists who show up out of nowhere.
The film's goofy heart and soul (yes, it has one) is what sticks with you in the end and makes this crazed film into a potential cult-movie masterpiece.
Neither obliviously dreadful enough to be "so bad it's good,'' nor intentionally tongue-in-cheek enough to be funny.
You need to find a room full of people who get the joke and see this movie there, because audiences will be laughing so hard they'll be screaming.
People talk repeatedly about street cred and say 'For realz,' which I can only assume the script spellz with a z ... The FP means to be terrible, and it is.
It does so much winking, it could be diagnosed with an eye infection.
Rather than crafting a movie that's so bad it's good, writer-director brothers Jason and Brandon Trost have come up with something that's just plain bad -- and boring, and repetitive.
"The FP" works best as an operatic parody of mixed genres with lunacy on the fringes.
There is some serious talent in front of and behind the camera and with a better script they might be able to create something funny and unique.
Mann raises the bar for westerns, making them more adult and dramatic.
Of [Mann's] various transitional films, none is more consistently fascinating or misunderstood than the masterpiece The Furies.
A decisive building block for the Stewart westerns, but with an Athena-like force of its own
... a genre hybrid: a psychological western by way of a Gothic melodrama, with a dark, shadowy style right out of Mann's earlier film noirs.
The movie's jarring violence pales beside the clashes of egos and the disputes between new banking interests and age-old claims on the land.
The rotund dialogue is uttered by the late Walter Huston and others worthy of better material.
Joel Edgerton is a legitimate triple threat.
Likely the strongest actor-to-director debut since Ben Affleck's Gone Baby Gone.
A grilled-cheese sandwich of a thriller, The Gift slaps a slice of Jason Bateman in the middle of a white bread story and throws him in the skillet until he ... starts to melt.

Begins as a familiar 'Cape Fear'-type suspenser but twists into an unusual psychological drama that challenges the viewer's presumptions while critiquing a me-first culture that rewards deception and bullying.
The Gift is a commendable, character-driven genre film and we look forward to more from Edgerton as actor and director.
It's a taut psychological thriller that serves up a series of sickening jolts and a queasy sense of menace.
The Gift sets up as a stalker movie, but there's something in the smart writing (Edgerton directed and contributed the screenplay) and the performances that hint at more.
The Gift is categorically not the film you first think it's going to be, but it has fun teasing you with the prospect.
More than anything, Edgerton's script and direction demonstrate a keen understanding of tension and what puts an audience on edge.
"The Gift" is a movie full of surprises - and one of them is that it is surprisingly good.
This indie pulse-raiser is more of a stealth shocker than an overt one, even if the twisted payoff is telegraphed to anyone paying attention.

Joel Edgerton's feature-length directorial debut is a pleasant -- or pleasantly unpleasant -- surprise, hitting its genre marks in brisk, unfussy fashion and raising a few hairs on the back of your neck along the way.
It's a psychological thriller and it does what thrillers are supposed to do; create a sense of genuine dread out of those murky, unwanted thoughts that we all share about who we are and what we want.
Haunting "Gift" one of the year's best.
It's a haunting piece of great cinema. [Full review in Spanish]
The Gift lacks either Fincher's talent for dense plotting or Hitchcock's elegance. Long passages in the middle seem repetitive, as Edgerton leans on jump-scares over and over.

The Gift is one of those rare movies that doesn't really work at all but keeps you watching as the mistakes and bad calls keep piling up. You want to see where it goes, you want to see if it can pull out of the dive.
A dynamite psychological suspenser that plays like a greatest-hits compilation of Alfred Hitchcock, Michael Haneke and John Carpenter. This is classy filmmaking with inventively devilish intent.
Smart, unexpected and beautifully directed, 'The Gift' is just that for fans of psychological thrillers.
The Gift is a sleeper film that will most likely fly under the radar for a lot of moviegoers, but it is well worth the time to give it a watch.
Eighty-five years young, "The Gold Rush" is still an effective tear-jerker.
What's surprising when one takes a fresh look at The Gold Rush is how much else there is, too, not just in terms of set pieces.

Emotionally robust and genuinely hilarious in ways that transcend time and culture, it balances the witty and the sentimental and still finds plenty of room to inject the moments of underdog social commentary that were so crucial to Chaplin's worldview.
The Gold Rush presents us with this unique mixture of heartbreaking comedy in its most perfect balance.

When it hit cinemas in the summer of 1925, the Berlin-premiere audience applauded Chaplin's 'dance of the dinner rolls' for so long that the film was rewound and replayed, while the BBC recorded 10 straight minutes of audience laughter at one screening.
Vrios momentos clssicos de Chaplin esto neste filme.
The passage of 80 years has not dimmed its humor, or Chaplin's creativity.
One of Charlie Chaplin's most endearing and popular works.
The result is a sight for sore eyes, for old-style Chaplin fans and novitiates alike.
...quintessential Chaplin: sweet, semi tragic, comforting, and most of all funny.
The Gold Rush (1925) is the quintessential Chaplin/Little Tramp film, with a balance of slapstick comedy and pantomime, social satire
No one can mix slapstick and sentimentality quite like Chaplin.
A quintessential Charlie Chaplin silent film...
The Gold Rush is Chaplin's greatest picture.
Chaplin's greatest comedy is also his most recognizable.
Even with its (likely dictated) propaganda on behalf of the now-superfluous 1942 edition, this set restores a high watermark in cinematic comedy to nearly full glory.
Perhaps the defining Chaplin film, and certainly his funniest.
The Gold Rush was one of [Chaplin's] purest comedy-fantasies, with some brilliant set-pieces including Charlie changing into a chicken and the 'dance of the dinner rolls.'
Charles Chaplin scores once again one of his greatest triumphs. [Full Review in Spanish]
The Gold Rush is a distinct triumph for Charlie Chaplin from both the artistic and commercial standpoints, and is a picture certain to create a veritable riot at theatre box offices.
It's in the same pasta bowl as the Sergio Leone films, only with even more red sauce.
The frozen setting heightens Corbucci's severity
It's been called "great" and "Corbucci's masterpiece." It just might be.
The mood is sometimes jaunty, but "The Great Silence" is no joke, and the fatalism of its ending serves as an implicit critique of the sentimental optimism of many Hollywood westerns.
Corbucci constantly subverts the generic tropes that he dabbled with two years earlier in Django, that blood-soaked and oft-imitated riff on A Fistful of Dollars.
Even 50 years later, The Great Silence stands majestically as both a blistering comment about its era and a creatively revisionist genre piece.
Nothing works out the way these people, not to mention audiences who love classic Hollywood westerns, expect. Not even close.
Make no mistake, the ugliness of violence and greed comes through a dark, savage story with an incredibly brutal conclusion.
It is simply, breathtakingly bleak.

Corbucci's terse, elemental and rugged direction compliment a world shook by corruption and evil, and plagued by treachery so pervasive it enfolds as powerfully through its cold setting as does its even colder characters.
With the help of a typically stellar score from Ennio Morricone, The Great Silence is one of the prettiest, most thoughtful movies you'll ever see with a body count in the dozens.
Something must also be said about the wintery setting - a rare choice for a Western.

Clearly a commentary on the shifting status of rule in modern day China, the prolific Lau's latest is nevertheless an obtuse work that buries much of its subtext and historical relevance beneath overstated dramatics and cacophonous staging.
[The Guillotines] offers a little of everything - action, drama, propaganda, romance - but spread frustratingly thin under a thick glossy sheen.
[The Guillotines] offers a little of everything - action, drama, propaganda, romance - but spread frustratingly thin under a thick glossy sheen.
A corny saga of social and generational conflict, it's ultimately yet another Chinese period epic that functions as a thinly veiled treatise on the nobility of socialist equality.
All the solemnity is deadly: Not one of these superhuman gang members registers in memory, and you feel stiffed on gory giggles. Talk about having your chain yanked.
A historical action epic set during the Qing dynasty that amounts to a bait-and-switch for wuxia fans stoked for steel-meets-flesh mayhem.
The blades fly as do the heads, but the movie remains disappointingly aground.
The Guillotines expends most of its energy in its first 30 minutes, leaving the audience with roughly 90 minutes of soapy Qing Dynasty fan fiction.
Despite the multitude of cinematic tricks the prolific Andrew Lau has up his sleeve, the film is a disappointingly rote entry in the wuxia pantheon.
Although a bit too gory for me and difficult to follow at times, the film also boasts some gorgeous visuals as well as intriguing characters played by Ethan Juan and Xiaoming Huang.
The plot is of little importance - the spectacular action and gorgeous landscapes and costumes are what matter.
Any topical relevance for the material is compromised by a script that is woefully clumsy and melodramatic.
The lack of rip-roaring martial arts or even a half-decent storyline will leave genre aficionados feeling short-changed.
This is an action movie with very little action, a period piece with very little history, and the story of brothers and betrayal with very little earnest emotion.
"The Happy House" is nothing if not a fresh mixture of colorful characters, questionable manners, and rusty, suddenly-new-again horror conventions.
D.W. Young navigates his varying moods with an ease that's particularly impressive for a director making his feature debut, but he never capitalizes on his ability to coax down our guard.
The only surprises in D.W. Young's tiny low-budget debut are how mildly he satirizes this thinnest of genres and how sincerely he treats his clichd characters.
Wonderfully droll horror comedy with a memorably weird cast of characters.

The film, a sleepy, low-budget affair, merely enacts a series of horror movie clichs, as if that were enough. Its bland actors and wit-free script do nothing with the familiar elements but present them.
This adaptation of Stephen Fry's comic novel relies so heavily on voiceover that it's practically an audiobook.
Lacking the zeal and comic energy that the material requires, The Hippopotamus feels like a souffl that has failed to rise, leaving a film that can only be recommended to diehard Allam devotees.
Brought to the silver screen by director John Jencks, the flavour and indelible, idiosyncratic tone of the author is imbued in this faithful adaptation.
A laboured blend of Agatha Christie-style sleuthing and PG Wodehouse-style country house high jinks that feels very dated.
An old-fashioned romp through the eccentricities of the upper classes, it's a fun mystery with a nicely filthy mind.
The writing here is sometimes arch and laboured but Allam puts across even the most stilted lines with enormous brio.
Despite a wonderfully witty voiceover and the bullish playing of a willing ensemble, this bawdy romp consistently stumbles over its more contrived excesses.
It's still a pleasure, and often a joy, to watch the star measuring out and savouring Fry's rich wordplay like fingers of scotch.
A towering, at times monumentally good central performance from the character actor Roger Allam stands at the heart of The Hippopotamus, but it is entirely alone.
This adaptation of Stephen Fry's novel leans heavily on the elegant profanity of the source material.
This British satirical comedy may be a bit of a mess, but since it's based on a Stephen Fry novel, the snappy wit in the dialogue zings with his specific brand of intelligent humour.
The rest of the supporting characters are little more than targets of Wallace's diatribes. That's not to say that the A plot lacks appeal. But Wallace is, without a doubt, the star of the show.
Sex, alcohol and a generous helping of four-letter invective all feature in a comedy-drama somewhat over-reliant on large gobbets of fruity narration and totally indebted to Allam's stand-out turn.

Director John Jencks does a great job highlighting the cognitive dissonance resulting from the human race's uneasy blend of practicality and credulity. And Roger Allam is terrific as the self-loathing Ted Wallace, drunk poet turned drunk sleuth.
...it really does expose how class-based so many of our horror tropes are.
The scary Halloween house at your local amusement park is child's play compared to the "extreme haunts" that fill this uneven but intriguing found-footage horror flick.
If you're relatively easily scared or are in a theater full of people who are, the film might be good for a few screams. But only if you're the patient sort.
IF the filmmakers had made a documentary about haunted houses, I might have liked "The Houses October Built." Instead, they opted for a knockoff of "The Blair Witch Project." What a mistake.
While there's much to admire, the film also falls victim to the pitfalls that plague many found footage movies.
Never transcends a predictable narrative trajectory to deliver much in the way of creepy atmosphere, let alone actual scares.
The Houses October Built" proves one of the more successful attempts at the found-footage horror flick since Paranormal Activity: The Marked Ones.
An incredibly sloppy found-footage flick that's awful enough to give Halloween a bad name.
Despite sitting through an endless parade of found footage stinkers, every so often there's a movie like The Houses October Built that proves that the subgenre is far from dead.
Tis the season, kids, and this is a great Halloween-time tale of absolute terror. Revel in it!
This is a somewhat tiresome found-footage excursion admirable in how it came together, and disappointing that it couldn't have added up to more than it ultimately does.
What sets this film appart from other found footage movies is the fact that it tries to be a documentary at times, adding more credibility to what we see on screen. [Full review in Spanish]
In my opinion, this film did not get as much credit as it deserved. While the ending was a bit lackluster, the overall storyline was very interesting and creepy.
The Houses October Built is an entirely worthy Halloween film and it may legitimately make some folks think twice about off-the-map horror excursions.

Kathryn Bigelow's explosive, edge-of-the-seat thriller is one of the best war movies ever made. After years in the wilderness, the director's stunning return to form is set, fittingly enough, in the arid landscape of a scorched Iraq.

Provost delivers Ozu by way of Chantal Akerman in this razor-sharp portrait of troubled, dreary, ordinary lives.
Yes, this French drama has a treacle problem. But its lead actresses generate more than enough spark to offset the sentimentality over the movie's surprisingly enjoyable two-hour running time.
This is the sort of film that starts you off without a net and leaves you to find your own footing.
Mirror, a new film by Andrei Tarkovsky, the controversial and unorthodox Soviet director, is delighting, puzzling, disaping serious Muscovite movie enthusiasts.
Tarkovsky shoots for the moon and for the most part succeeds in trying to make his personal story also a lesson in political art.
One of Tarkovsky's most impenetrable films, it nonetheless left me staggered and awestruck.
Cinema as art as cinema as art.
Made in the tradition of Resnais and Bergman, The Mirror, Tarkovsky's personal meditation about his childhood, scandalized Soviet authorities with its self-reflexive tone and poetic visual style.
It is a film that is difficult to adequately describe -- and one I believe is impossible to process in one sitting.
It's an awesomely simple idea, and yet hugely complex.
There isn't a scene here which isn't strikingly shot and the final impression is of something personal, mysterious and yet frequently profoundly resonant.

The smallest details (a stammering child, the wrinkle in the turned page of a book) stick like burrs, and we are left to wonder if any director has delved with more modesty and honesty into the heartbreak of the past.
No tidy resolutions, no easy steps from here to there. But what The Mirror lacks in simple logic it makes up for in satisfying emotions.
Tarkovsky goes for the great white whale of politicised art -- no less than a history of his country in this century seen in terms of the personal -- and succeeds.
Yes, it sounds like hard work. But Tarkovsky gets away with the doleful pace and elusiveness thanks to one thing -- his breathtaking eye for simple, stunning beauty.
The Mirror deserves a big-screen viewing, with its smorgasbord of memories in dream, drama and newsreel form from the life of a dying poet.
[D]eeply, sometimes abstrusely impressionistic... What's real and what isn't, what's past and what's present is difficult to untangle... [O]ften seductively beautiful to look at...
Its imagery and mysticism have by no means lost their power to astound.
The film about the subjective experience of how human memory is (dis)organised that every other film about memory strives to be and cannot quite reach.
In The Moth Diaries, we're just left with a half-baked morality tale that seems to suggest that young women are so hungry for daddy surrogates that they seek them in each other.
The lacklustre script is so determined to spell out thoughts and emotions that it becomes insulting.
If you think Twilight moves at a plodding pace and makes you wish for a death that will not come, wait till you see this.
While there's plenty of promise, there's no payoff with this would-be horror.
It's a missed opportunity for Harron, who can't figure out a game plan for the source material's mysteries, leaving the picture to spin helplessly, wasting enticing genre ingredients.
The problem with a movie this unimaginative and amorphous that tries to be ambiguous is that we're not sure how to take anything it shows us. Ambiguity becomes meaningless game-playing.
Defeats Harron's talent for exploring darkness on the edge of kinkiness.
Not enough psychology to be intelligently creepy, and not enough schlock to be viscerally scary.
Good overall plot and production that do not come together in the sharp focus of a conventional horror film. Entertaining nonetheless.
American Psycho director Mary Harron's latest is unfortunately a middling J-horror outing.
This is one vampire film whose sexless, generic ending betrays a promise of revisionist complexity.
Disastrously mishandled adaptation of a neo-Gothic novel set in a posh girls' college.

Those incredibly volatile days when a teenage girl comes to terms with her own family history, her changing friendships, her sexuality, and more make for interesting fiction but often come apart on their way to the big screen.
Bubbles of nascent arousal froth at the film's feminine surface.
Sex, blood, and death may be the givens of any Dracula-inspired fright film. The Moth Diaries skimps on all three.
While no one would mistake "The Moth Diaries" for being as potentially dangerous, there's definitely a case to be made for being as careless.
Ostensibly made as an angst-filled teen horror movie in the vein of Twilight, it doesn't really have an idea of its own identity.
The Moth Diaries serves up a great helping of symbolism and interesting suggestions in what could have been an exceptional story, but that is about as far as it goes.
A total miss thanks to poor performances and a weak story. Harron never builds any tension and is unable to get her cast to bring any life to their characters.
I'd give this moth-eaten nonsense a miss.
'The Island/Hadaka no shima' could be depressing were it not for stark poetry of conception and realization by cinematographer Kiyomi Kuroda.
The Naked Island borders on kitsch. Still, once seen it is not easily forgotten-the myth of Sisyphus transposed to Tahiti.
Graceful goodbyes are said, then life moves on. The characters' urge for survival wins out, even if you're left shattered.
Once its rhythms are set and we get to know the characters through their actions and interactions, The Naked Island develops a surprisingly strong narrative and emotional allure
It is a monumental study in the mute determination, unfaltering dignity and monastic strength of the human being's day to day battle with life.
Director Kaneto Shind√¥ relies on his imagery to craft an engrossing realist drama. This is one of the most sophisticated, and powerful, of modern silent films.
A striking study on humans attempting to usurp command of Mother Nature, it's a sparse but visually poetic title from a unique, underrated auteur.
Getting in and out of the asylum is a fairly intriguing bit but the entire movie has some holes in it, holes that might have been covered by superior direction.
The thing that makes The Night Visitor less than thrilling is its compulsion to give away its own plot.
Who precisely was this made for?
A lackluster thriller.

Laslo Benedek's methodical direction and Henning Kristiansen's astonishing photography-a gothic mix of melancholy blue landscapes and pale, crumbling interiors-only serve to underline the film's deficiency, the utter lack of logic.
The dark comedy of manners and political upheaval almost feels like a prequel to The Purge franchise.
I also liked the willingness of The Oath to stick its nose into the ongoing civility/rage debate...

Some might balk at the idea of seeing a comedy about the heightened political tensions of our times, but as someone who has had a few of those arguments with family members myself, I found "The Oath" to be utterly cathartic.

The Oath is (at first) a scarily realistic and darkly funny depiction of the political argument feedback loop that rips some families apart. But the violent last act allows Barinholtz to slip away without an idea for leaving that loop.
It works for the most part, and captures the tenor of an era when "divisive" politics have grown bad enough to break up friendships, families, and quite possibly our status as a democratic republic.
The movie's dystopia-meets-family-dinner mix feels like it's building to something bigger than the sum of its rants ... and then it doesn't.
The Oath is a clumsy, but ambitious directorial debut for Barinholtz and provides a blisteringly satirical examination of the modern political divide.
[T]his is a comedy about the here and now. Let's hope it's not about the future.
"The Oath" manages to raise the moral stakes along with the mortal ones, ultimately arriving at some pretty tough questions.
What we're left with is undeniable promise, and a film that's the very epitome of falling just short of greatness.
[Writer/director/star] Ike Barinholtz might lose focus during the second half of the movie, but the film lands a good amount of solid gut punches before flying off the rails.
There's a steady miscalibration to both its laughs and tension, the rhythms of the film seldom clicking into place...
A blistering political satire that may rip the bandage and the scab, as well as a lot of the skin, off a political wound that has barely had time to heal.
Mr. Barinholtz has enough cachet to assemble an excellent cast, although he's not as canny about using it.
The laughs laced with a sigh as we watch arguments play out that have brought us to a collective national state of exhaustion and despair.
The Oath lands in an unpleasant middle ground that is too close to reality to feel like escapism, and too antic to feel equipped at anything like incisiveness.

Even while it asks us to recognize ourselves in a world not too distant from our own, The Oath seems to say that the worst part of a full-fledged American dystopia would be the ruined holiday dinners.
[The Oath] serves as a perfect reflection, skewering and rumination of our times.
The Oath is an impressive effort at satire that mostly hits the mark before venturing into weird darkness that almost knocks it off the rails.

Political satire is one of the trickiest of genres; this one, running out of steam and nerve, ultimately becomes a too-familiar example of another genre: the 93-minute movie that feels way, way too long.
Frequently fun and generally harmless, "The Outcasts" doesn't bring anything new to the teen comedy, but that's the nice thing about the sub-genre for its viewers.
Before it was even over, I was already forgetting about it.
Amiable but underwhelming.
Performed with a lot of brio and filmed with humor and sensitivity to all involved, it is fun to watch and worth discussing afterward.
Smart girls vs. mean girls comedy has swearing, drinking.

This innocuous, mildly amusing wish-fulfillment fantasy comes right off the assembly line of this unfortunate subgenre, destined to bore even the least discriminating teens with its aggressive barrage of clichs and stereotypes.
There's something comforting about watching teens talk about friendship and dating and college applications, subjects that actually make The Outcasts an outcast among current teen films.
Perfunctory, ponderous and peopled with the oldest high schoolers since "Twilight."
The film has some gentle fun with high school archetypes without ever being mean-spirited.
Judging by her edgier scenes [Nicole] Kidman is clearly uninterested in currying any favour at the multiplex. And all credit to her.
So bad it isn't even good-bad.
...a calamity.
The Paperboy provides a lurid spectacle, but it's one that leaves you wanting to scrub yourself clean in the shower afterward.
Watch it with Killer Joe for the ultimate sweaty, twisted double-bill.
Daniels' uneven, lopsided narrative goes too far in spots and not nearly far enough in others.
It's a film of vivid colours, steamy atmosphere and sexual desire rather than tight plotting, but no less entertaining for that.
Lewd, ludicrous and utterly convinced of its own gritty artistic merit, The Paperboy's closest cinematic cousin may very well be Paul Verhoeven's Showgirls.
The Paperboy deserves to be seen for its pulpy, well-executed excess, but as a filmmaker, Lee Daniels seems ignorant of how the shocks distract from the story.
Like Anatomy of a Murder, The Graduate, and Daniels' own Precious rolled into one wacked-out bloody Southern Gothic that's considerably less than the sum of those parts...
Lee Daniels' The Paperboy is a steamy, sweaty and trashy piece of cinema that rarely gets by on its filthy and wild performances.
The Paperboy is flawed, more deserving of a rubbernecking than a viewing. But it's hard to tear your eyes away.
Set in the late 1960s, the movie is tactless, shameless and almost proudly seedy. Nevertheless, it is always highly watchable, prone to truly fascinate an audience as it also genuinely appalls them.
The Paperboy is a triumph for its lead actress and a failure for almost everyone else involved.
The movie as a whole is a rather grim, dismal experience where the elements never quite gel.
Sometimes hot messiness has its charms.
Filmmaker Daniels follows up his acclaimed hit Precious with what might be the trashiest movie in recent memory: a swampy thriller packed with desperate characters hiding grisly secrets.

A seething, swampy murder investigation infused with the sweaty smell of bodies and driven by a casual force that is seductively unstable, darkly funny and strangely exhilarating. Daniels is a visionary.
It's as though Daniels looked at all the elements he had and, unable to figure out how to sort them out in a coherent fashion, instead chose to toss them like a salad.
Lurid, touching, and not quite like anything I've ever seen.
Feels lazy and dashed off, as if getting it into theaters was more important than actually crafting any suspense or creating believable characters.

Director Grgory Levasseur never gets to grip with the shifting sand plots as we are led down one dead-end sequence after another. And, it's not just the stranded scientists who are desperate for daylight, I too was left running for the exit.
The Pyramid plods through its conventional generic tropes in increasingly aggravating fashion, any tension dissipating in the face of unscary cats and rubbery monsters.
"We need to find an exit right now," someone shouts early on. Audiences may well find themselves sharing the sentiment.
Like so many filmmakers before him, Levasseur doesn't seem to grasp that in the horror genre, less can be more.

Grgory Levasseur takes on directorial duties for the first time and though he ramps up tension at the final hurdle, for the most part this effort is hampered by a rote script from Daniel Meersand and Nick Simon.

Levasseur understands the claustrophobia of being locked inside a stuffy pyramid with collapsing floors and sand traps. Unfortunately for him, Indiana Jones turns out to be incompatible with Alien, and the bad acting and atrocious script don't help.
As far storylines go, this one is as gormless as they come.
Where The Pyramid falls short most spectacularly, in its distinct inability to scare the viewer.
Levasseur plants and executes the pic's exclamation-point scares with grinning, squelching gusto. It matters little that most of the jolts have been lifted from previous movies ...
The few scares are rote jumps copied from a dozen other films, with one moment that echoes both Alien and Deep Blue Sea.
Avoid at all costs, unless you need a good nap, or a bad history lesson on ancient Egypt.
The ancient curse of Tutankhamun is merely a dusty irritant compared with this tale of supernatural bloodletting beneath the shifting sands of the Egyptian desert.
Ah, found footage: my old nemesis. We meet again.
[The Pyramid] does not bring anything new to the table or to the horror genre in general.
Maybe you've seen the trailers, or television ads, which make 'The Pyramid' look a run-of-the-mill horror movie. There is truth in advertising.
The Pyramid overcomes thin writing and an inconsistent found-footage format to deliver a horror movie experience that actually fulfills its promises.
A stinker in every sense.
This could've been an absolutely excellent horror romp if there were better practical effects and not so much reliance on the bad CGI.
These B-movie touches aren't especially scary, and the characters are too paralyzed with fear to have much fun with the silliness.
This Hitchcockean farce puts the dead in deadpan.

Œë film almost nonsensical as it unfolds like a collage of episodes rather than a solid story. However, these episodes are quite entertaining as they combine minor violence with black humor, based on the family's mischievous but naive characters

Although there are some script holes and unanswered questions, and yes, some of the unavoidable horror tropes, at the end of the day, there's nothing quiet about The Quiet Ones. It screams frightening terror.
There is simply nothing more Hammer than Jared Harris in The Quiet Ones.
Pogue jacks up the decibels so often to manufacture frights that you fear a punctured eardrum more than anything else.
Well-shot, well-acted and, well, kinda boring.
A little too quiet
For all the set-up and atmosphere, the story completely unravels in the final act.
A satisfyingly spooky horror offering that tenderly unspools its tension.
As an exercise in retro pastiche, it impresses. But as a postmodern genre reinvention, it fails to deliver.
Though The Quiet Ones does not quite work as a throwback to Hammer's heyday, it does, however, serve its purpose as a decent time-waster.
Campy and creepy - it's sinister but not scary enough.

You have the bits and pieces of a lot of old horror movies. They've been nicely polished by director John Pogue, but they have been assembled into a kind of Frankenstein's monster of a film that never comes to life.
The arrestingly fierce Cooke, in particular, is surely a star in the making.
Pogue repeatedly allows tension to dissipate, and only a handful of moments come close to inspiring actual fear. Otherwise, it's cheap jolts all the way.
There aren't many outright scares here, and when they do come, they are curiously circumspect, but the old-fashioned Hammer Horror atmosphere is appealingly spooky.
The problem with the film comes from a tendency to not be able to deliver on its attempts at the Big Scares.
A script crying for a horror backbone is frustratingly weak for the most part, its tedious jump-scares no substitute.
The film seems to mimic [Professor] Coupland's scientific method: Throw everything into the beaker, crank up the Bunsen burner, and hope the experiment works. In both cases, it doesn't.
An abysmal horror movie that apparently wants to evoke the spirit of paranormal thrillers of the sixties (like 'The Haunting') but quickly degenerates into a chaotic mishmash of modern genre tropes.
An enjoyably half-baked foray into the paranormal.
The story doesn't make much sense, starting with a professor blithely being awarded custody of a dangerous mental patient, and just going downhill from there.
Here's a terrific genre movie splashed liberally with tension, scares and just enough humour
Taut, suspenseful and finely acted, this delivers both thrills and strong characterisation.
Considering what most low-budget shark flicks look like, The Reef is a welcome sight indeed.
Supposedly based on a true story, The Reef does a good job of portraying tension while keeping the shark hidden (and simple). [Full review in Spanish].

For most of the time, Traucki manages the horror well, with the menace inferred. Particularly spine-chilling is the scene in which Walshe-Howling is exploring the air pocket in the upturned boat. Sound tells the story.
It's short, sharp and to the point, and the careful, measured use of shark footage is exemplary
The Reef is that rarest of treats: an "animal attack" thriller that is as dramatic as it is horrific.
The film is good at what it does, goes to plan and concludes in a modest 88 minutes. Yet if that's success, it's also a failing, for it's not particularly memorable or distinctive.
The Australian tourist industry will hate it but The Reef is an extremely effective watery horror/thriller.
...the film's final stretch is unexpectedly engrossing...

Fortunately, the lengthy scenes in which the four frightened swimmers are menaced by a white pointer are chillingly well handled -- not since Jaws 35 years ago has the horror of this sort of situation been as well captured on film.
There is something fun about being scared by a movie and The Reef offers that sort of safe danger that, for some reason, most of us occasionally crave.
Terrible scripting, unconvincing acting, wonky continuity and feeble atmospherics induce an overpowering feeling of tedium that cancels out any potential for true terror.
Once that journey happens it is tremendously effective and, honestly, it's like you want to get out of that cinema.

The tropes of survival (or otherwise) in a watery wilderness may be familiar from Open Water, Adrift and even Andrew Traucki's own crocodile-themed debut Black Water - but when directed as thrillingly as this, these tropes prove all too easy to swallow.
Traucki manages to keep the tension running throughout the film's 94-minute runtime even before the shark ever shows up to make dinner out of the cast.
Jaws it is not, but it's well worth the hour of suspense to see which one, and only one, will survive.
... squirm-worthy survival adventure ... Go ahead, take the plunge. 'The Reef' is an authentic nail-biter (toe-nibbler?) that lives up to its fun come-on: 'Pray that you drown first.'
Lacking the compelling drama and survival horror kick of its cousin Open Water, The Reef is brisk and reasonably involving, but pretty middling, too.
As for suspense, there isn't much. When the only thing at stake is the size of the body count, suspense becomes the first casualty.
Although The Salesman isn't always the subtlest film... the movie has a balance of reticence and outspokenness, of nuanced observation and easily deciphered symbolism, that is highly effective.
Creating tension that ratchets up in sly increments, Farhadi steers his narrative to a shattering conclusion about the quality of mercy and vengeance.
A complex, compelling film from Iran - modern day Iran as we Americans never get to see it - it well deserved its win.
It's an effectively feel-bad story, deploying a torrent of wounded, retrograde masculinity to make uttering the word "rape" an even greater transgression than the event itself.

Despite the specificity of modern-day Iran, The Salesman can transpire anywhere, any time. After all dysfunctional families, messy relationships and marriages on the verge of breakdown can't be confined either by national boundaries or time zones.
With exquisite patience and attention to detail, Asghar Farhadi, the writer and director, builds a solid and suspenseful plot out of ordinary incidents, and packs it with rich and resonant ideas.
As usual, Farhadi constructs a noose of a narrative that tightens the more the characters unravel...
Intensely observational.
Slow moving and emotionally involving, Farhadi's The Salesman is immaculately crafted but lacks the power and potency of A Seperation.
It's a terrific movie.

The film finds Farhadi now inhabiting a strangely transnational place in cinema, one where bridging Gholem-Hossein Sa'edi and Arthur Miller is more a playful, aspirational gesture than a purposeful strategy.
The reliance on Arthur Miller's play feels like a bit of a reach, and the climax is more than a little manipulative. But Hosseini and Alidoosti find the truth of every scene.

The Salesman is more contemplative and in many ways smaller, more contained [than Farhadi's other work.] ... Of his four [major] films, I rank it number three, but it still towers above eighty-eight percent of the films that reach our silver screens.
Farhadi is a master of his craft, a nuanced chronicler of the human condition, whose work unfailingly offers moments of truth and beauty.
It's wellacted and full of low-key pain and humour (you would expect nothing less from the man behind A Separation, one of the most excruciatingly humane and nuanced films of the decade).
Farhadi's films are suffused with an oppressive atmosphere, and there is something increasingly formulaic in his storytelling.
While The Salesman is not quite as good as [Farhadi's] other Oscar-winner, A Separation, it's a very strong piece of work.
A classic whodunit with Asghar Farhadi's characteristically impeccable plotting and buildup of suspense.
As with Farhadi's best work, such questions of humanity and morality linger long after the particulars of its plot have dissolved from memory.
[The Salesman] depicts a masterful chronicle of the Iranian middle class.

The Shed offers a version of the vampire mythos that is deeply rooted in fears and concerns of today and has a valuable lesson: don't be a bully, because you never know what is hiding in the bullied kid's shed.
This indie shocker starts strong but doesn't know how to leverage its slick premise.
Sheds are where murder happens. That's just a fact of life. If you go into a shed, you're probably going to die a grisly death of one sort or another.
"There are a million different paths writer/director Frank Sabatella can take with this idea, but they choose the least interesting one. "
An interesting morality tale, by way of vampires, about the nature of power between the bullies and the bullied.
It operates on familiar tropes ... and then it twists it in very dark directions. It's just unfortunate it ultimately devolves into a stereotypical battle with an ancient evil.
Part angsty teen melodrama, part gore-soaked vampire film, the offbeat horror picture "The Shed" should appeal to anyone who likes their genre stories imbued with personal feeling.
The social subtext doesn't carry much weight alongside the supernatural nonsense, and it's difficult to find sympathy for these characters who consistently lack common sense.

Along with the jump-scares and general viciousness, there's a refreshing amount of clever storytelling. This offers a continual stream of witty touches and twisted details that pull the audience in before the overwrought mayhem erupts.
He mixes childhood terrors with adolescent angst with smalltown rebellion with something aching and lonely.
In the end, The Shed is not quite good enough to be worth seeing, but it is just good enough to make one curious about what Sabatella might have to offer the next time around.
Without turning into a cheesy after school special, Sabatella spins a classic '80s yarn into brilliant social commentary.
There's nothing to make your hair stand on end in The Shed because it's not convincing.
It's more concerned with how the traumatized people act when facing danger rather than just telling about the vampire's urge to kill.

Although the horror tropes here are familiar ones, The Shed is well put together and, unlike many films of its ilk, actually has something to say. There's a solidity at its core that will endear it to fans and see it linger in the memory.
The Shed is a vicious little bite into the genre, a friendly reemergence of ghoulish vampires and hormonal teenage angst sharing their DNA yet again.
If there's one thing The Shed gets right, it's reassuring viewers that vampires can be savage, malicious creatures of nightly fury.

The Shed isn't terrible and it does have promise as a concept but thanks to its lethargic execution there isn't a great deal to recommend it beyond adding it to your queue if it pops up on your streaming service of choice.
Most of the gore is neatly paired with sight gags to neutralise the terror, and it's an efficient enough machine for generating scares.
RIP sparkly moody vampires, as The Shed takes them back to the monstrous beings they have always meant to be.
suggests the sheer impossibility of ever knowing the Holocaust while simultaneously reassuring us that we can always know individual human beings
Mesmerizing and heart-breaking...
Tense and emotionally brutal.
The noted Polish actress Ida Kaminska was deservedly nominated for an Oscar for this serio-comic fable, set in Nazi-occupied Czechoslovakia.
One of the more memorable films about the Holocaust.
Paul Newman makes an altogether likable person out of the central character, and I soon became so engrossed in watching him track down the daddy-nappers...

The Shop on High Street has modest but solid virtues. It treats seriously -- that is, with a quiet realism that doesn't exclude humor -- a theme I can't recall having been attempted before except in documentaries.
It's a quiet, contemplative story that offers no harsh judgments, just the genuine ordeal of growing up and coming to terms with the past.
Authentic coming-of-age road trip drama has teen pot use.
This is a little gem of a movie.
A film that has so much empathy, truth, and realism, especially when it comes to its portrayal of sudden loss and grief
The Short History of the Long Road is more engaging than it should be, considering the movie's sanitized portrayal of being a homeless teenage girl.
...a lovely movie filled with disarming, soft-pedal performances in-keeping with the narrative's laid back vibe.
So much of Ani Simon-Kennedy's soulful film exists in the space between necessity and aesthetics - what you need to survive and what you need to be alive.
Although it rambles like the endless roadways it follows, "The Short History of the Long Road" is a perceptive low-key character study.

The Short History of the Long Road is an interesting coming-of-age film that had potential to be a grittier look at being homeless and alone, but still comes across as a beautifully shot examination of van culture and found families.
Throughout, writer-director Ani Simon-Kennedy keeps The Short History of the Long Road in gear - but a lower, slower one than you might expect.
Creating an environment that adequately expresses all of this could be a daunting process for any filmmaker, but writer/director Ani Simon-Kennedy expertly takes us on this adventure...
This indie drama may walk (or more aptly here, drive) along a previously explored path, but it does so with ample amounts of heart and humor.
The Short History of the Long Road would have benefitted from having a lengthier run time. Yet, its naturalistic performances as well as its momentous yet moderate handling of parental mistakes.
Seemingly rambling about without a destination in mind at the end of the film you realize you have traveled somewhere.
This is but a small jaunt of a bigger journey for this broken family led by an evolving Sabrina Carpenter.
The story's start-stop-and-start-again rhythm, with almost all consequences elided, becomes tedious and unbelievable.
A gentle road trip well worth taking.

Thanks to her wonderous work here, as well as the outstanding screenplay and direction from Ani Simon-Kennedy, The Short History of the Long Road is a captivating coming-of-age tale unlike anything you'll ever see.
The Short History of the Long Road is a more contemplative coming-of-age drama than most, but despite its frequently weighty subject matter, it never drags or becomes oppressively dark.
Between Simon-Kennedy's writing and Carpenter's performance, Nola makes for a compelling character, gently pushing the story along at her own steady pace.
A film that is somehow at once brutal and nihilistic, beautiful, sweet and funny.
John C. Reilly is one of the most underappreciated national treasures we have.
Audiard gives the whole movie a very bizarre feel, crafting a western that feels at once a part of the genre and something entirely different.
A knockout, one-of-a-kind western from French director Jacques Audiard in which odd-bird frontier hitmen are played by Joaquin Phoenix and a hot-damn he's great John C. Reilly. Saddle up.
As humanist and hopeful as it is violent, The Sisters Brothers presents a grim, dog-eat-dog world with a surprising amount of hope and tenderness.
If this is Audiard's first major foray into stateside filmmaking, one can only hope it won't be his last.
At the heart of the film are two pitch perfect lead performances. Though Reilly and Phoenix don't look particularly like brothers, they certainly behave like them.
The movie turns out, in the end, to have an idealized sense of closure in mind, one you both can and cannot see coming.
By turns intense, hilarious and casually contemplative, it draws you in on the promise of simple thrills then wins you over with a sophisticated, all-around surprising ride.
It's a Western. We're starved for a good one. This isn't it but - hey - it's a Western. BTW, John C. Reilly is REALLY good in this.
It's a warped dream of the Western that successfully subverts and delivers a ravishingly beautiful spectacle.
A dusty, squint-eyed Western ramble full of wry cowboy humor and sudden death.
A revisionist Western road movie comedy with a heaping side of existential drama and great performances.
It's wordy, slow-moving and reflective but it's also funny, well written and nicely played out by a cast firing on all guns.
The film's picaresque jumble of tones...could have done with a little tightening around its middle. But we do at least finally know How The West Was Won. With indoor plumbing.
'The Sisters Brothers' is a more than recommended snack, not at all complacent and with an extraordinary final shot that makes clear what we have seen. [Full Review in Spanish]

It aerates what's already been well-trod, offering an alternately pitiless and tenderhearted lens on such hardy themes as character, filial loyalty and American progress at its most naive and voraciously destructive.
[Jacques] Audiard finds gore and even a few grace notes in his American myth.
...not precious about challenging tropes, and like so many Westerns, fundamentally about change ... How do men who make their living out of such brutality evolve - or not?
A great revisionist Western from acclaimed French filmmaker Jacques Audiard (A Prophet). Phoenix and Reilly make great gunslinging brothers. Gyllenhaal and Ahmed also fine.
A Russian animated adaptation of Hans Christian Andersen's fairy tale, Snow Queen proves both visually cruddy and narratively muddled.
Don't be surprised if your child asks to watch Brave or Shrek again when it's over.
CGI fairy tale remake features the occasional fright.
