The message gets muddled with plot strands going every which way, though the real culprit is some awkward animation.
The visuals are poorly conceived, with characters that are hardly more expressive than Weebles. The vocal performances are uninspired and uninvolving.
unlikely to stay long in your memory, but Snow Queen might sustain younger viewers
This movie is such a mess, and is clearly a cash grab because Frozen is coming out from Disney this winter. It's like when Transmorphers came out on DVD right when Bay's Transformers came out.
The film keeps you guessing by offering scant and unconvincing details, but the more it progresses, the more you realise it doesn't have any answers at all.

For all the considerable nous assembled either side of the camera, no one can rescue it from its own mediocrity: if this were the opening act of a TV miniseries, you'd be exploring other channels some time between the second and third ad breaks.
Even Fassbender's typically intense and well-schooled performance can't elevate this muddled mess from the mundane.
It's unusual for a whodunnit to have such a powerful sedative effect as The Snowman.
One of the worst thrillers of all time. An ugly mess that clearly no one saw before releasing. [Full review in Spanish].
It looks great, but only as a triumph of style over substance. I'm sorry to say it left me cold.
When a film's reputation behind the scenes is more interesting than the finished result, that's not a great sign.
Dreary as a Nordic winter, and almost as long.
I wish I was exaggerating with this review, but The Snowman is genuinely one of the worst cinematic experiences I've had. It's laughable, yet is trying to be the furthest thing from a comedy.
Despite a top-notch cast, Alfredson's spin on the murder mystery is painfully convoluted and thematically incomplete.
The Snowman ruined both snow and Michael Fassbender for me.
There have been more exciting episodes of procedurals like Criminal Minds.

The overall outcome of "The Snowman" is definitely disappointing. Parts of this movie are gripping --- and even terrifying --- but the script and Alfredson's direction never capitalize on those moments.
It's easy to see the The Snowman's appeal, but the reality is a hidden hole in the ice, sending talented actors and filmmakers to an icy grave.
[The Snowman] is two hours of uninterrupted, snow-caked boredom.
The mystery develops in directions that aren't remotely interesting, leaving the entire movie feeling flat. At least it's beautifully photographed in stunning Norwegian scenery.
How did a delicious Scandinavian noir novel go so spectacularly wrong on screen?
Despite these moments, the storyline is coherent, mostly. I also loved the rugged intensity of Fassbender as Harry Hole.
Such abundant talent, yet what we get on the screen is like a snow cone made with horse urine.
This film may well be the last gasp of Scandi-noir for the international market...this phase of Nordic has gone from original to dutiful emulation to dreary self-parody.
It's mesmerising in the way a snake mesmerises its prey before striking.
Terrific performances, especially from the menacing, lazily charismatic Henshall, and debut director Kurzel's expressionist storytelling make for an Aussie film well worth hunting down.
A truly effective film that will stay with you long after the credits roll.

Few films can rightfully claim to offer its audience the opportunity to spend a couple hours in the bowels of hell, but Justin Kurzel might as well print up t-shirts saying as much to promote his feature film debut, Snowtown.
This distressing infiltration of a family of young boys by a charismatic psychopath rewards with a stylistic talent that feels entirely new.
It reminded me, oddly, of Richard Fleischer's sordid history of John Christie in 10 Rillington Place - here is the killer; here is his shabby habitat, and here are his crimes.
Powerfully directed and superbly written, this is a genuinely disturbing, emotionally draining serial killer drama with a stunning central performance from Daniel Henshall.

As for the crimes themselves, most take place off screen and between scenes - a terrifyingly protracted murder excepted. Yet even when the violence isn't shown, a mood of clammy dread and horror pervades the film.
[U]niquely distressing... This is a hard movie to endure. It is hugely emotionally suspenseful, and all of the suspense is of the dreadful kind...
'Snowtown' is an uncomfortable film to watch, but its sickening suburban horror is made bearable by Kurzel's rigorous restraint...
Snowtown offers a bleak, brutal exploration of the way morality can be skewed and innocence corrupted by neglect, hardship ... and the presence of a charismatic psychopath.
If, however, you want to know how violence, intimidation and prejudice can thrive unchecked for a very long time, The Snowtown Murders is here to show you in tragically credible terms.
Authentically, viscerally convincing in its performances and milieu, Snowtown throbs with tension and a deep sense of wrongness from its first reel onwards.

Unflinchingly nasty, graphic and gut-wrenchingly powerful, Snowtown is a film that dares you to look away, but compels you to keep watching. As portraits of serial killers go, this deserves to be hung on the wall next to Henry.
Whatever one ends up thinking about The Snowtown Murders, it's difficult to deny that it's a deeply impressive work.
It's slow but atmospheric and memorable.
It's a truly shocking experience that ends suddenly, just when we're expecting a final atrocity and some climactic revelation, and we're left to ponder the events.
A cast of mostly local, mostly first-time film actors is chillingly convincing.
This is one of the most unsettling films that I've seen in a long time.
the ghastly glee of The Snowtown Murders comes not in the kills, but in the stalking of one's true prey.
It's taken longer than expected for The Space Between Us to make it into theaters. After now having seen it, however, it is understandable why this film has been dumped in mid-February.

It's the kind of processed-cheese tearjerker, completely devoid of shame, that can harden even the easiest criers into heckling cynics. You want to take its lunch money or at least introduce it to better music.
The science is sidelined in favor of a Nicholas Sparks-style doomed romance, with cheesy sentiment in place of philosophical and ethical concerns.
Won't come close to troubling your heartstrings, let alone the space between your ears.
Honestly, the only reason the film didn't grate on my nerves more than it did had everything to do with Robertson.

One expects plotholes and impossible occurrences in science fiction films. But this one breaks the mold. The silliness of these scenes is what really keeps this movie from being as entertaining as it could have been.
Manages to at least partially eclipse its many tropes.
This is a movie where I found myself wishing that each and every one of the characters met some grisly fate that would allow the credits to roll and myself to leave.
It doesn't help that Butterfield and Robertson have little charisma and even less chemistry. Two hours is too high a price to pay for this saga that goes nowhere.
The movie often delivers on its promises. It is also, however, one clumsily plotted flick, with a screenplay by Allan Loeb that gambles everything on a twist ending you could spot from a galaxy away.
This is a film that doesn't stick with any genre, but instead clumsily navigates between three, ultimately leaving the viewer feeling shortchanged in every area.
The twists are just unbearably ridiculous, which drains all the power out of their supposed catharsis.
There's a sweetness -- not to be confused with a saccharine quality -- to this pic, made all the more appealing by its two young leads and a story that hurtles right along.
... requires an outrageous suspension of disbelief in a strained attempt to be poignant and profound.

The Space Between Us is romantic science fiction with zero gravity and less to recommend. Its space is between its ears, a YA fantasy cribbed from alien fish-out-of-water flicks by the guy who wrote Collateral Beauty. Yeah, him again.
It presents a compelling situation, genuinely touching moments and pockets of strong acting ... and dialogue that has people in the audience turning to each other and laughing because it's so absurd.
The Space Between Us certainly had potential. However, it fails to reach the same lengths its very characters already had.
[Director] Peter Chelsom ( ... ) keeps the movie firmly grounded in maudlin mediocrity.
More boring than a six-month trip to the Red Planet. (Full Content Review for Parents - Violence, Profanity, Sexual Content, etc. - also Available)
Sluggishly paced and tonally wobbly, the pic, much like its teenage protagonist, suffers under its own weight.
This family friendly movie shows with beautiful Colorado backgrounds how a 57-varieties mutt saves a man's life and possibly his marriage.

The desire to tug at your heartstrings starts to feel desperate after a while. The Stray doesn't just want to make you cry, it wants to reach right into your eye sockets and squeeze your tear ducts until there's not an ounce of moisture left.
A family's love for their pet pooch is reciprocated mightily in writer-director Mitch Davis' The Stray, a movie with a gentle spirit and tone shifts that go all over the place.
Offered as a warm-hearted dog yarn, this gentle but tendentious fact-based family drama goes astray into agitprop for family and Christian values.
An underpowered, white-bread sermon on the importance of family and faith.
It's a dramatic start for a film that means well, but can't quite make its pieces fit the story it wants to tell.
Faith-based family drama could distress dog lovers.
Cut-rate faith-based tale of a dog that just HAS to be a family's guardian angel makes for grim going.
It is a sweet look at a wounded family and how a dog brings them together.
There is no doubt The Stray has its heart in the right place and that gets it far.
If you're a parent who ever, for one cold-sweat second, lost sight of your child at a playground - "The Tall Man" will tap into your darkest fears. And then make them even darker.
The final reveals of the plot are so ludicrous and poorly told I am a little bit shocked. Biel does a fine job and the film looks like a real movie. It just has a nonsense script at its heart.
There's plenty to like about it in hindsight once it's all laid out, but it isn't enough to lift this mystery-thriller out of the realm of the mundane.
The Tall Man is a fine thriller that tragically falls off the rails, spiraling into dark, morally corrupt territory.
The Tall Man's twists and turns make for a fun time, but its attempts at provocation fail miserably. Laugier's ambitions are commendable, but they just don't succeed.
Pascal Laugier's film illustrates the problem of class mobility with a dark, troubling premise that holds a harsh light up to our own assumptions and expectations.
Almost to the same degree as Laugier's Martyrs, it changes its game midway through and makes audiences radically shift sympathies as its plot develops.
"The Tall Man" spits out enough scares and twists to maintain our interest, but the film's psycho-sociological layer is almost as cheesy and unconvincing as its low-rent action scenes.
A colossal waste of time built around tricking us with illogical plot twists, and a convoluted hard to follow narrative.
Laugier, as was the case with Martyrs, takes the story in a completely unpredictable and, for a while, baffling direction.
Half-baked and dismally executed.
A sly, strange and subtly engaging horror story that will no doubt leave several viewers angry, confused, or arguing on twitter.
The result is tedious instead of suspenseful.
What begins as an intriguing Stephen King riff devolves into a Lifetime Original, effectively burning off the potential of the complex misdirection.

Laugier's toiling with the seed of a good idea and interesting moral questions, but his own commitment to constructing the first half like a horror film (despite it not really being a horror film) leads to pacing issues as the film progresses.
Long on atmosphere and short on sense, "The Tall Man" becomes less gripping as it grows more ridiculous.
Despite the excellently creepy subject matter, The Tall Man contains very little actual horror and ends up being quite a dud.
... can't decide if it wants to be 'High Tension,' 'Jeepers Creepers' or 'The Piped Piper of Hamelin' ... results are arty, jumbled and, ho-hum, Sunday School preachy.
The Tall Man comes as close as anything in recent years at matching the better monster-of-the-week episodes of The X-Files.
Child abductions plague a rural Washington State town, but the more pressing affliction in Pascal Laugier's film is the absence of chills, logic and coherence
A trite and tangled potboiler that, despite its polemical pretensions, is just a glorified Korean domestic drama with classier couture and shapelier champagne flutes.

There is no real story to tell here, just a bunch of old fashioned, tired clichs spiced with references to various sensational front-page scandals, all of it reprocessed to look like an original script.

As the sexual, financial and criminal shenanigans get ever more complicated, absurd and melodramatic, the film becomes increasingly tiresome; it's not even possible to enjoy its excesses in a 'so bad it's good' way.
Is there such a thing as "tastefully smutty"? Director Im Sang-soo's moody and semi-Shakespearian The Taste of Money walks that line with some artfully lit humping and cross-generational seduction.
For all the revelations about the way the rich operate, there's little juicy pleasure to be had in the proceedings.
Both bitter and delicious.
This is a completely unenlightening cri de coeur against the most obvious targets of financial-spiritual discontent.
It's a feast for the eyes that starves the brain, filled with unsympathetic characters and clichs straight out of Wall Street and other corporate thrillers.
The story bounces about in a fashion that's as chaotic as the film's visuals are placid, suffused with sumptuous malice.
Im Sangsoo seems too much in love with what he seeks to condemn for The Taste Of Money to have real bite.
It is a strange slo-mo farce, well directed, highly sexualised - shallow, but sleek.
This grotesque, luxe white-collar chamber drama from South Korea is often laughably bad.
A glossy, heavy-handed soap opera with all the complexity of a four-piece jigsaw puzzle.
A veritable orgy of vulgar melodrama, The Taste of Money might pass as satire if the conclusions drawn were not so broad and unsurprising.
It's ultimately wearing, yet somehow memorable.
It feels like Im intended this as a moral fable. He should have played for laughs; material this blunt works best as satire.
Sex, death, greed, corruption: they're all here in handsomely mounted and highly polished cases. Taste the money - smell the glove.
The director seems uncertain whether he is making a slow-burning character drama or a satirical gangster movie about modern-day Seoul's answer to the Borgias.
Back when Im Sang-soo presented The Housemaid, he felt like he had more to say about the rich, but it's hard to tell what that is...
The film does communicate enough of Hawking's discoveries to let us know why he's an important thinker. But this movie about a great woman and a great man ends up merely good.
Many moviegoers may think they already know a good deal about Hawking's achievements, but they would do themselves a disservice to miss out on Redmayne's almost perfect performance.
Pleasing to watch... but [leaves] little lasting impression.

Whether it is perfecting the delivery of a slurred and often unintelligible voice, or struggling to simply lift a spoonful of peas to his mouth, Eddie Redmayne is awe-inspiring, bringing forth one of the most surreal performances of the decade.

It would be easy to fall into the trap of wishing this look at one of the greatest minds on the planet was something more, dare I say, intellectual. But this movie is a love story. And a fine love story it is.
This is sheer poppycock, of course, but it makes for fine drama, and that's all Cupid and Oscar care about.
A well-written, well-directed movie an average person like myself can grasp. If I want a more complicated explanation of the universe, then I can refer to Hawking's book, "A Brief History of Time."
Redmayne is phenomenal, helped by his uncanny resemblance to the young Hawking. He captures the great man's famous sense of humour, likeable eccentricity and resilience.
The Theory of Everything is surely inspirational, but it glosses over some ugly chapters in Stephen and Jane's relationship.
Prettily shot and glossily produced, this is a film that's easy to like but equally easy to forget, being almost entirely content free.
It's a creative innovation, I suppose: frictionless filmmaking for a movie about physics.
Redmayne and Jones are terrific in a mature look at the marriage of Stephen Hawking and Jane Wilde
The problem is that it's a reprise of a relationship designed to meet the approval of the living-breathing counterparts.
Follow up by looking into the real story, but this is a moving film about what a complicated thing a marriage is.

These days "everything" has also come to serve as a lazy synonym for "no one thing in particular." And while that usage may not describe Steven Hawking's theory of everything, it certainly does fit the movie about his life.
Despite handsome production and two brilliant lead performances, The Theory Of Everything stumbles into virtually every pitfall that afflicts biopics about geniuses.
A by-the-numbers biopic fronted by two incredible performances.
Captures Hawking's intellectual vigor as well as his comical spirit
This is the adult, classy version of The Fault in Our Stars.
This is a handsomely produced, sensitively acted picture, one that's eager to have you wipe away a tear with one hand while handing over gold statues with the other.
It's a little too silly to sustain a significant character journey, but 'The To Do List' is still a successful overload of nostalgic and incredibly raunchy humor.
It's refreshing to see a movie aspire to a little more than just raiding the cliche bin.
Sweet-tempered even while telling the story of a teenage girl's quest to lose her virginity, its heart is definitely in the right place...
The To Do List should be on every comedy lover's must see list for 2013, because awkward sexual encounters have never felt so right.
The To Do List is an American teenage sex comedy set in 1993, which may have been the last year in which any of the cast members could have convincingly passed for a teenager.
The raunch itself may be enough for a teen audience. But The To Do List is no American Pie.
In its exuberantly smutty way, "The To Do List" is revolutionary: A teen sex comedy where the girls get to play nasty and the boys stand around looking terrified.
The film feels a little like what might happen if the producers of films like Bridesmaids found a lost John Hughes script and adapted it for 2013 audiences.
It shows how far the teenage sex comedy has come, and how different it looks when a female writer or director is behind the camera.
Unfortunately, the movie as a whole isn't nearly as nimble as Aubrey Plaza's charming, self-deprecating performance.
It's... got more insight and honesty behind its use of expletives than any other piece of writing to hit the screen this summer, and as a result, the humour finds different layers to bounce through.
That the movie not only refuses to apologize for its frankness, but rather seems to revel in it with defiance, turns this rollicking comedy into a screw-loose, cock-eyed feminist mini-gem.
It's no 'American Pie.'

I'll admit I laughed several times at some of the material. But considering the rare gender reversal approach at telling a tale in the sex comedy genre, this could have been so much more. (Full Parental Review also available)
The To Do List is not just a hard R sex comedy, but also an important player in film diversification.
Plaza, of TV's "Parks and Recreation" fearlessly puts it all out there as a teen put out that she hasn't "put out."
Above all, The To Do List announces the arrival of Aubrey Plaza, movie star, with a role that takes full advantage of the awkward persona she's now best-known for.
The To Do List peters out to a lamentable degree in its padded-out final half hour.
This isn't exactly the vehicle I'd have picked for Aubrey Plaza, but proving her immense talent once again she makes it work.
I didn't believe any of it.

It's not a thriller and it's not a whodunit, although it contains thriller elements and at the end we do find out whodunit. It's an exquisite short story about a mood, and a time, and a couple of guys who are blind-sided by love.
Disappointing follow-up to Chinatown
feels a lot like a retread of Chinatown, only without the style and panache that Polanski brought to the table
Of course it's no "Chinatown," but it is satisfyingly moody and atmospheric.
Points out that we may think we're done with the past but it almost never is done with us.
The Two Jakes allows Nicholson to reprise one of his most memorable characters as a way of seeing whether he's still got it.
The Two Jakes is the best Chinatown sequel anyone could reasonably expect, and it's very much worth a look.
Nicholson's turn as Gittes is enjoyable, but it never quite feels like the same man from Chinatown. Yet The Two Jakes is admirably dense in a manner that's satisfying rather than frustrating.
This snail-paced, convoluted excuse for crime drama is a pathetic way for the highly revered Jake Gittes to fade away.
None of this is the least bit funny. Or in any way entertaining. It's just another teenage-clown-in-a-dunk-tank flick. Everyone fire away.
There's no suave dork or sensitive jock. Rather, the high-school kids act like high-school kids -- relentlessly immature and all the better for it.
Repugnant.
Crass and detestable, a combination of American Pie, The Blair Witch Project and crap.
A thoroughly depressing teen farce in which Internet voyeurism has replaced human intimacy and where privacy is *so* 20th century.
While there are a handful of throwaway laughs scattered here and there, the film otherwise fails its mockumentary test in that it simply isn't that funny. (Parental Review also Available)
observant, to be sure, but curiously, not that funny
Hilariously chronicles the missteps and triumphs-and everything in between-of four teenage guys in their efforts to get laid for the first time.
Equal parts bold experiment (in sustaining a YouTube aesthetic for an entire film), and shallow redux of well-worn teenage sex comedy tropes.
The tricky chemistry of a likable, funny ensemble cast is the biggest thing The Virginity Hit has going for it.
It feels real, even if in the back of your brain you know it's about as authentic as the girl who quit her job via dry-erase board.
This Web-inspired Superbad rip-off is simply super bad.
Crass and vulgar, of course. It's supposed to be funny, too, but it isn't...It makes a movie like 'Superbad'...seem like Shakespeare.
If there were justice in the world -- and there isn't -- the film would quickly crawl back under the rock whence it came.
The mockumentary format lost its freshness decades ago, but it perfectly suits an exploration of a form of narcissism unique to the YouTube generation.

"The Virginity Hit" is a completely unfunny, mind-numbingly dull experience that focuses on one uninteresting thing and one only: the attempt by some friends to get another friend to lose his virginity.
Every generation deserves silly smut of its own
This, my friends, is soft-core porn at its rancid worst. Shame on you, Will Ferrell and Adam McKay for producing this swill that features some of the most unlikeable characters ever put to film.
A film with a handful of funny moments and a whole lot of filler.
It's crass, senseless and, consequently, void of humor.
The mythological aspects of The Void don't always mesh neatly with the monster-movie scares. But, in the moment, it will scare you silly -- which is really all that matters with a good horror movie.
It's tempting to grade The Void on a bit of a curve, if only because [directors] Gillespie and Kostanski do more than a competent job with the material's inherent obstacles.
A striking neon/noir montage of menacing clouds and effervescent organs makes The Void's visuals stand out like an infected zombie thumb from the modern horror rigmarole.
It's gloriously off the rails, unhinged, absolutely bonkers. If you're a fan of a certain type of horror film, that's a good thing.

It's an often riveting descent into darkness that will probably leave an impression on you on the other side... Just don't let its hyperbolic praise from some outlets make you put The Void on a pedestal - you'll likely come out disappointed.
Gillespie and Kostanski follow their influences and utilize their talents, transforming a spare, low-budget endeavor into something quite special and haunting.
It's a nightmarish descent into insanity that's as depraved as it is entertaining.
Wickedly entertaining, and disturbing in all the right ways.
Through Kostanski & Gillespie's inspirations and vision, they have crafted a work with The Void that serves as a decent blueprint for where to take their craft next.
You may not only find yourself craving the seedy elegance of Lovecraft or Carpenter, but also the jolting liveliness of Sam Raimi's Evil Dead.
A splurge of gruesome effects and cosmic mumbo-jumbo that neither makes sense nor provides anything approaching a real scare.
I can't promise that it will all come together and make sense after one viewing. The rewatchability factor is, I'm happy to report, extremely high...
Aesthetically nice with some really great practical effects, it shows that Kostanski and Gillespie have the talent and potential for a truly exciting future.
the fans of the horror-scifi-drama genre will probably enjoy "The Void." I, though, am not a fan and just feel a void.
People live, people die, monsters creep out of the shadows, but it's all a little too formulaic, cynical, and ... well, boring.
From what little I did know about The Void, I thought that the film would look a lot more low-budget. In truth, the film looked fantastic and I was once again surprised by the overall quality.
If you're looking for answers and a linear plotline, then The Void isn't for you. Go see it for the ominous feel, mysterious characters and the creature effects. And hope for a sequel...
The Void is a portal back to the 80s, hinged on immersive practical effects work that picks up the slack of a slighter story.
Thanks to some noteworthy visual flare from the directors, enjoyably creepy effects, and a game cast (especially Welsh), The Void warrants a recommendation. But just barely.
In the Eighties, released widely in theaters, The Void could have been a franchise-starter. It'll probably be harder to find today, but it rewards the effort.
Thomas and Rose ricochet from one boneheaded, depressing escapade to another, and by the end you may start to feel as eager as the mobsters they're tormenting to get rid already of these babbos.
Few films are better titled than The Wannabe, a portrait of a Bronx kid who would have done anything to be part of the mob world he knew from the movies.
Arquette shines, but this unmade-man mob movie lacks the energy and brutally dark humor of "Rob the Mob," which was about exactly the same story,.
The film is less a revisionist take on the circumstances of John Gotti's 1992 indictment than a tedious love child of Bonnie and Clyde and Goodfellas.

Mr. Piazza offers a persuasive portrait of decline, but it is the crumbling beauty and flailing hopes of Rose that resonate. Ms. Arquette comprehends the character inside and out, and her aim is true.
The mix of callous humor and romantic doom doesn't always hold up, but in its best moments, "The Wannabe" finds real spikiness in the pitfalls of anti-hero worship.
Its taste in antiheroes doesn't inspire fascination, just a desire to see a different movie.
The Wannabe is too derivative for any insight, offering little more than tired tropes and bad accents.

The narrative, abot a black lesbian director, is elliptical and circular, borrowing its format from Jim McBride's seminal David Holtzman's Diary, at the end of which, the viewers realize they have been watching a fake documentary.
...a unique film and a real time capsule of the 1990s when movie geeks hung out at video stores.
It's a film of such multitudinous interests and storytelling pursuits that its unfolding replicates the ecstasy of newfound romance.

Funny and smart, full of biting humor and astute observations about identity and history, Cheryl Dunye's audacious, joyous debut feature captures the process of falling hopelessly in love with the movies.
[A] sweetly sardonic, pretension-busting look at an African-American lesbian filmmaker negotiating our multi-ethnic, multi-cultural, multi-sexual, multi-multi world.
The Watermelon Woman can be awkward and clunky, and its shoestring budget sometimes shows. But it's also fresh and frequently very funny.
By the end of the film, the lines between reality and fiction are blurred in that Cheryl in the film and Dunye herself with the film itself are both making points about black women in film.
A masterful blend of documentary style and self-reflexive personal narrative, peppered with sweet stories of friendship and romance.
The film is very aware that the lives of the people who did manage to create will always be a mystery to a certain extent, but the film refuses to reduce any of its subjects to mere victims.
[Shatters] the boundaries between the act of creation and the finished creation itself, pulling the audience into the disorienting dialectic of artistic production.
It's a refreshingly tasty lesbian flick
A playful approach to the truth; history with the suggestion of manipulation.
The Wedding Ringer is a mixed, but overall enjoyable, dramedy - one that includes a number of laugh-out-loud scenes couched in an often clumsy story.
Crass comedy swings between gross and better than expected.
The predictable script lulls you into laughing at some very tired gags, but at least Hart refrains from screaming through the whole thing.
The premise isn't all bad --- but the execution could use some tweaking. There is simply too much silliness and not enough big laughs.
The whiff of stale leftovers ... hangs over the movie from start to finish.
This 'Wedding' is by no means a classy affair, but in the post-'Hangover' era it's not the worst comedy to come along.
"The Wedding Ringer" feels about as forced as a guy shopping for his bride's wedding gown.
For the first time ever Kevin Hart mellowed out and didn't scream his lines like a chipmunk on amphetamines. It's an improvement but not enough. I laughed just once.
Basically a Men's Rights Activist meme passing itself off as a motion picture.
The director Jeremy Garelick, who wrote the script with Jay Lavender, takes the shortest route whenever possible, which usually means a gratuitous insult.
What saves the film are its two leads, who aren't afraid to show their sensitive sides -- along with other parts of themselves.
The movie often plays like a mid-2000s Jennifer Lopez rom-com forced against its will to be a hard-R guy comedy.

Hart's manic comic style is actually a good mix with Gad's uptight Doug, but the chemistry never quite clicks largely because Jeremy Garelick and Jay Lavender's script constantly aims for the lowest denominator possible.

For a moment, the film gives the impression of well-intentioned shagginess. But as The Wedding Ringer progresses full steam ahead, the only daring it shows is in its willingness to offend with ignorance.
Love hurts, but Jeremy Garelick's The Wedding Ringer is truly painful.
The rest of the film is a mess of mixed messages, perpetuating homophobia and sexism at the same time it critiques them.

While I agree studios historically save January to release their not-so-entertaining movies, Hart and Gad make you laugh simply by showing up. Add a moderately funny script, and The Wedding Ringer is a winner
Breathing great comedic life, The Wedding Ringer just rings my bell with laughter, heartfelt honesty and humor.
Ringer is completely abysmal, devoid of even a single shining moment of absurdity.
There's some real emotion at the core of this vulgar comedy that makes for a wholly satisfying raunchy romp.
Great gangster comedy . Classic Eddie G.
A sheer joy to watch.
...generally an amiable little comedy that benefits greatly from the charisma of its two leads.
Satirically yet trenchantly embraces a wide range of modern experience, from the political to the intimate.
Odd bur rich mix of the visionary, comedy and the darkest side of gangsters.
A great showpiece for Robinson and one of the most offbeat curios in Ford's jam-packed filmography.
...the closest thing director John Ford ever came to making a screwball comedy.
The movie tips its hand just a little too much a little too often, which takes what could be an exceptionally satisfying thriller and turns it into an acceptable one.
I don't know if it was a budget thing or just inexperience which resulted in this film having the look and quality of a bad movie of the week.
The film's closing minutes offer some parting pieces of information that upend some previously laid assumptions, but it's a grafted-on coda rather than a well-choreographed gut punch.
Courtney Hunt's film is minor in scale but remains entertaining and modestly engaging throughout, and though it lingers a bit too long on its big reveal it never overstays its welcome.
Tense courtroom drama has violence, sex, language.
Compelling, supported by an unusual cast, but Hunt doesn't bring grit to this mainstream event, which gradually evolves into Grisham-esque nonsense.
[W]hat might have been a tantalizing whodunit about the less-than-gleaming gears of justice ... is instead a curiously uninvolving exercise in procedure.

A total disaster that's been hanging around the editing room gathering dust for more than a year, you can't call it deadly because that would imply it's still alive. This one is already dead on arrival.
In this current post-John Wick phase of his career, Keanu is giving off a little gravitas (and the odd sly aside at his own expense) that was never evident before.
There is some good acting here but I think the script done them wrong.
When a "trial" movie ends up being predictable, chances are very bad. [Full review in Spanish].
Marked by the legalese and narrative pivots demanded by the genre, but lacking enough verve to offset its familiarity, Courtney Hunt's film returns a verdict of Not Bad.
If you want the whole truth, Courtney Hunt's new film is not so bad.
This engaging courtroom drama aces the trick of grounding its ludicrousness in a convincing facsimile of reality.

Viewers who've spent any time watching TV courtroom dramas will probably believe they've figured out "The Whole Truth" from practically its opening scene, and despite a few minor twists along the way, chances are, they have.
The only real anomalistic quality to Courtney Hunt's long awaited sophomore feature The Whole Truth is why she chose to undertake this derivatively formulated courtroom drama in the first place.
Usually, with a movie as mundane as The Whole Truth, it's tempting to say that a better cast and crew would've made something more special. But on paper, this film had the goods.
There's nothing monumental at play in The Whole Truth, but it's not entirely without merit, satisfying on the same level one would digest a grocery store paperback.
The script for The Whole Truth is an "airport book," although it contains even less sizzle and grit than most of those.
We can tell the kind of movie The Whole Truth wants to be - Southern noir, full of cynicism and sorrow. Here, ambition outstrips achievement.
Forgettable talking-animal adventure has some scares.

This one is utterly, doggedly, defiantly undistinguished, designed only to play for a big opening weekend, cashing in on those millions of parents out there with nothing better to do with their kids on a Saturday afternoon.

One is likely to wish that as much attention and effort would have been put into crafting an engaging story and characters as making the visuals pop. (Full Content Review for Parents - Violence, Scary Stuff for young kids, etc. - also Available)
A film with an absolute lack of enthusiasm, rhythm and movement for adventure. [Full review in Spanish]
The rendering of the animation itself is decent, without being over-saturated. Fun fare for kids.
Though hardly terrible, the movie is imminently forgettable. Once it's over, it feels as if it never happened.
It doesn't have the technical resources to compete with other animated films. [Full review in Spanish]
The sort of uninspired international pre-sales item that usually goes straight from a basement booth at the Cannes film market to a Netflix parent's peripheral vision.
A confused, charmless take on the Robinson Crusoe story.
Taken all in all, The Wild Life is a harmless but instantly forgettable children's movie.
All things considered, this pitifully plotted Belgian-French production represents the nadir of animated movies released so far this year, a farrago of frantic action and mindless cacophony.
A film that reproduces the recipe for a more commercial cinema for adults, adapted to children's profitable market. [Full review in Spanish]
There is some visual appeal and sporadic energy, but the lacklustre script and dull storytelling make for a blandly forgettable addition to an already overcrowded field of family entertainment.
As animated extravaganzas go, it lacks rhythm and a captivating sense of escalation.
Smaller children might be moderately entertained, but I saw it in a cinema full of families and there was neither much laughing nor engagement going on.
In a year where animated entertainment has had an embarrassment of riches, The Wild Life is merely an embarrassment, and a pretty grand one at that.
There's more than enough here to keep younger children quiet over a rainy bank holiday weekend.

The best thing to be said about this pedestrian, sedentary storyline is that it contains no bathroom humour. But since it also contains practically no humour at all, this isn't much of an endorsement.
I personally would rather watch this film than a lazy unambitious effort like Ice Age: Collision Course but that's just me.

The animators are clearly trying to craft something bubbly, but they misguidedly go all in on imitating the contemporary Disney model - or DreamWorks', at least - rather than offering anything different.
While The Wind Rises isn't top-shelf Miyazaki, it features more than enough gorgeous imagery to make his loss feel acute.
The Wind Rises is a masterpiece of light, motion and transition.
Hayao Miyazaki's hauntingly beautiful historical epic draws a sober portrait of Japan between the two World Wars.
'Airplanes are beautiful dreams' is a phrase reprised throughout Hayao Miyazaki's The Wind Rises, and the same could be said about Miyazaki's films.
The brilliant Wind Rises is another Miyazaki masterpiece - evidently his last. He couldn't have picked a more perfect way to sign off.
On the subject of less is more, the film shines in smaller moments.
Jiro dreams of...Zeroes? Lovely, but an animated, fictionalized and sanitized celebration of Japanese WWII fighter design is a dubious use of the medium.

The swan song in an illustrious career. With its reference to Thomas Mann's "Magic Mountain", this is obviously a film geared to adults. But bring the kids since they will be enchanted by the airplanes, just as I was.
Miyazaki successfully immerses us in an analog world where the human hand -- not a machine -- bridges the gap between the imagination and the mechanical reality.
To see "The Wind Rises" is to simultaneously marvel at the work of a master and regret that this film is likely his last.
It's not the director's best, too much meandering off course, but it's still a fine work of animation.
The result is a timelessness and warmth that computer graphics have learned to mimic; the difference being that Miyazaki has never strayed from the traditional in the first place.
A beautiful, less whimsical, but gently romantic drama about chasing your dreams. Mature in its themes but breathtaking nonetheless. Requires but rewards patient attentiveness.
The movie's story and visuals are all of a piece. The incidents are layered; the wind reveals their secrets.
It is everything Miyazaki loves and does best on full display.
The film, like the wind it references, has wonderfully soaring sequences.
An engineer pursues his dreams in Miyazaki's latest (and hopefully not last)
A wonderfully animated fantasy based on the actual life of the designer of the Japanese Zero aircraft.
Certainly no one else would render such a story in old-school, hand-drawn animation instead of surrendering to modern CGI. But that's what makes Miyazaki unique
If The Wind Rises has the unhappy distinction of being Hayao Miyazaki's last feature, it shows the director at the height of his powers making a premature but glorious exit.

It's unfortunate director Roland Joff fails to capture real emotion and passion within the religious narrative. Without that perspective, there's no way he can breathe any life into the biopic, much less fire.
I like grandeur and richly nuanced storytelling. I also like lobster bisque. But I don't want to drink a gallon of it in a single sitting.
Even with its modern ambiguity, "There Be Dragons" feels stodgy.
A Spanish Civil War story ill-married to a saint's biopic, Roland Joff's muddle is sunk by three unfocused narratives, clunky dialogue, and Wes Bentley.
Rarely has a film with so much melodrama been so unengaging.
The geriatric pacing, flat-footed Old Hollywood pastiche, and Joff's inexplicable penchant for tear-jerking Catholic mysticism make Dragons more punishing than a hundred Hail Marys.
The interweaving of the two storylines is fumbling, fragmented and contrived - unless you're a devout Catholic and well-versed in Spanish history. Watching it was like doing penance.
Yes, the film looks beautiful. But unfortunately is stumbles over itself too often to fully realize greatness.
Joff is out of depth when it comes to Escriv's religious experiences. It's clear he wants the film to show how faith works within us, but he does it by resorting to the most hackneyed imagery.
It's the kind of simplistic movie that features a benevolent chocolate maker and desk drawers containing both crucifixes and pistols. Which to choose?
Dragons may not be perfect, but it plays to the helmer's strengths, demonstrating an increasingly rare sense of scope and pageantry best served by the bigscreen.
Clunk, clunk, squish. That is the sound of the dead language in Roland Joff's screenplay for "There Be Dragons" as it tramples his would-be epic of the Spanish Civil War into an indigestible pulp.
From its baldly overwritten dialogue to its claustrophobically stingy use of locations, Dragons is underdone in every way.
It offers good production values, name performers and insights into the chaos of civil war. But it's too stiff, too cautious, too calculating to feel genuine.
A movie doesn't need CGI dragons to be exciting. But it does need real characters and conflict -- it needs to be a real story. Here, that story always is just beyond our grasp.
Despite its high-mindedness, an almost complete misfire...a lopsided film as well as a turgid, boring one.
As played by Cox, Escriva is earnest, heartfelt and full of tolerance, driven by his message of love and forgiveness for all, regardless of where their politics lie.

There's a great film to be made about Josemaria Escriva, the founder of the controversial Opus Dei. There are more great films to be made about the complicated Spanish Civil War. This movie, however, is neither.
There's an interesting story here, but Joffe never firmly wraps his arms around it.
"There Be Dragons" tries to echo "For Whom the Bell Tolls," but this instrument is tinny and tarnished.
David Wain does the world a solid by giving glossy romantic comedies the Wet Hot American Summer treatment.
It's still pretty nuts; it's just never transcendent and sometimes downright familiar. But, as we said, funny's funny.
You'll laugh yourself silly

As artificially sweet as one of Molly's lollipops - and about as satisfying one too: They Came Together is a breezy romp through the rom-coms of yesteryear that might just leave you craving the real thing.
It's not as raunchy as the title suggests, but Paul Rudd and Amy Poehler pull off a hilarious sendup of every rom-com clich√© with only a few (easily forgivable) missteps. I laughed a lot.
Everyone involved seems above the rom-com conventions they're satirizing, so anxious to get to each punch line that they let the connective tissue languish.

A film that's as funny as it is silly, twisting every clich√© in the rom-com cannon to impressive effect, so much so that you'll never be able to look at a Katherine Heigl movie in the same way again.
Simply recreating what we know to be hackneyed and safe doesn't suddenly make it hilarious and surprising. There has to be a spin to it; there has to be some innovation.
It's a light-hearted film that is smarter than it seems-or as Wain once said, "a deliberately terrible romantic comedy."
A truly biting satire, full of gut punches and belly laughs.
At times laugh out loud-inducing, but ultimately feels more like a promising Saturday Night Live skit (the romcom couple?) than a standalone piece of entertainment.
It's amusing enough summer entertainment with a winning cast ... and some genuine laughs thanks to its puppy-dog enthusiasm. And who doesn't like a dressing-to-impress montage?
What results is chaotic but ultimately focused, bound by an intense devotion to disassembling genre and narrative standards.
Without a baseline for the comedy, the layers of spoof in "They Came Together" don't have the foundation to carry even a short movie.
When I think of the great comedic directors currently working in cinema, David Wain tops my list. Another big laugher from a very funny guy.
This rough-edged parody feels both distinctive and handmade, and for those reasons alone it's a hard movie to hate, even when it temporarily loses its comic footing.
Even if the laughs peter out, your enjoyment doesn't, thanks mainly to a comedic cast on top form
Adorable, acidly funny and absurd in equal measures, this bouncy, gag-packed romcom spoof ain't quite as funny as it thinks. But when Paul meets Amy, they'll have you at 'Hello'...
It's all mildly entertaining (mostly because of the two leads), but too often comes off like either an extended Saturday Night Live sketch or an actual (and bad) romantic comedy.
An enthusiastically zany comedy, made in the reality-bending tradition of a Zucker, Abrahams, and Zucker production.
Surprisingly rich film is one of the best war films ever made.
The most unfortunate thing about John Ford's excellent, elegiac war film, with a strong turn from John Wayne, was its release date, December 1945, since the war was over.
The real star of the film is the gorgeous, luminous, mostly outdoor black-and-white cinematography.

The film moves along curiously and cautiously, prideful of the crews of the PT boats but also aware that each victory was achieved at a great cost and that sacrifices would have to continue to be made as the war trudged along.
They Were Expendable was the first time [Ford] would loose the weight of his experiences on a general audience.
The human element triumphs in almost every foot of They Were Expendable.
Social journalism of the highest order, They Will Have to Kill Us First is by turns horrific and front-loaded with sonic heroism.
The film blossoms in its efforts to show how much music means to the Malian people, and how they might use it to heal wounds and overcome strife.
It's a rare and inspiring thing, in contemporary culture, to witness artists in action who are willing to die for their art.
Although many of the stories told here are deeply harrowing and the film sometimes seems to be trying to bite off too much, at least there's a happy ending of sorts.
Be fair warned: this film will make you want to hug your record collection, and add to it.
Schwartz ... expertly captures the sights, sounds and general bustle of Mali, imbuing her sometimes harrowing film with warmth, intimacy and vitality.
A cautionary expose capturing the ugly fallout of an unavoidable clash of modern and medieval civilizations.
Delivers a vibrant testimony of resilience under oppression.
Beautiful music and a good introduction to the complexity of Malian/Tuareg politics.
A profile in courage but also groove.
Stirring yet overstuffed ...

Whether musicians or scientists or authors or artists, humans who just want to create and discover, and not hurt or take advantage of anyone, may well be the same all over -- and seem a lot better to have around than... extremists of any type.

Johanna Schwartz's worthy documentary follows some of Timbuktu's most prominent musicians as they flee south to avoid the violence, join forces for concerts of protest, and eventually return in muted triumph to their liberated lands.
A documentary affirming the soulful meanings of music in Mali where jihadists have banned all music-making.
Much like the transporting 2014 Oscar-nominated narrative film Timbuktu, which dealt with the same topic, They Will Have to Kill Us First is both bracing and beautiful.
Mostly, the film documents how a rich musical tradition continues to captivate listeners around the world even as its practitioners are struggling at home.

They Will Have to Kill Us First sends a clear message from Mali's musicians to their oppressors-you can turn cities into ghost towns, take away radio stations, and destroy instruments, but we'll never stop making music.
A celebration of music and the human spirit, They Will Have To Kill Us First gives an intimate and personal insight into lives of these displaced musicians.
Rather than offering simple, and simplistic, explanations of the country's political strife, the film is unafraid to tackle the complexity of the warring factions...
Things Change is a neat little exercise in wit and deception.
It's a film that comes with a perfect shoeshine and smile underneath its ludicrous and cynical premise.
David Mamet-Shel Silverstein collaboration is funny, touching and tense.
A gangster fable about keeping one's word.
clever, funny and thoughtful
Things Change is like the careful telling of a sly and spirited joke. Everything builds slowly, and the telling is as important as the punch line.
This Is England grabs you by the scruff of the neck and yanks you into the Thatcher 1980s with brute force.
This is English cinema.

Like all of Shane Meadows' work to date, his latest captures the simple pleasures of hanging out with a big group of friends, laughing at nothing. And it shows how easily that camaraderie can shade into hooliganism.

critic_name: Cherryl Dawson and Leigh Ann Palone
content: This is not the England that makes you want to hop on over for a visit, but the movie is worthy of a quick look.
It's only a half-great film, which is to say that its best moments are more perceptive and powerful than any other movie this summer.
A modest, near-flawless gem, This Is England is a humbly, if insistently political, autobiographical homage to a lost world of youth.
Even if the story is misty in its didacticism: No matter how tough the times, just say no to racism and hatred.

The director's affectionate warts-and-all portrait of his milieu and subculture is blistering, cogently capturing how England's early-'80s skinhead movement was driven less by blind racial intolerance than by intense socio-economic tensions.
A gripping bit of British drama.

The movie is taut, tense, relentless. It shows why Shaun feels he needs to belong to a gang, what he gets out of it and how it goes wrong. Without saying so, it also explains why skinheads are skinheads.
It doesn't seem the slightest bit like real life, even though writer/director Shane Meadows reportedly based it on his own.
A riveting English film about a fatherless 12-year-old English kid who joins a band of skinheads and is initiated into a world that rocks his being.
With bad boy conviction and feisty demeanor, Turgoose ably shows us sharply responsive nerves bared to the erratic side of reactive behavior.
An honest, emotional, funny and deeply moving portrait of growing up. Don't miss it.
A hard-fisted punch of reality based on the filmmaker's experiences growing up in England's Midlands in 1983.
It is the war within him--and by extension, within the minds of many embittered, working class young men left behind in Thatcher's England--that Meadows's film most strikingly portrays.
This Is England may be set in 1983 but it's as relevant today as it was then.
It's one of the simplest and best re-creations of downscale urban England during the gritty post-punk years ever put on screen, and it's both upsetting and very funny.
Deeply impressive, as both a recreation of (TM)80s working-class England and an intimate tale of one childhood(TM)s brutal end.
Meadows' recollections of his own youth...lend a terrible immediacy to an unusually potent coming-of-age story.
The Norse gods are off to a decent, though not divine, start in Thor, the latest movie in Marvel Comics' big-screen expansion of its superhero pantheon.
This film was not painful to watch... but it was no pleasure.

It's still inconceivable that people could look at the shabby Iron Man 1 and gaudy Iron Man 2 and be satisfied. The latest addition to that Marvel studios franchise is Thor, and it, too, suffers from filmmaking without wit.
Thor is Marvel Studios' best movie so far. This is exactly the sort of movie you'd want to kick off the summer.
Many things within Thor must be accepted at face value, but these very things are what make the whole enterprise feel inconsequential.
Branagh was meant to work on this scale. And even if ambition doesn't always equal vision, with Thor Branagh brings the two pretty closely in line.
Although it looks quite beautiful and has enough gorgeous space shots to make Nova green with envy, the movie is too weighted down by exposition to ever really get interesting.
By Odin's beard, the gods seem to have smiled on this one.
First is worst in Thor appearances, but since he gets better every time this one's valuable as a part of the whole. Also, just say NO to Dutch Angles & bleached facial hair.
While the plotting of Thor is decidedly cheesy, the action sequences it spawns -- particularly whenever tensions heat up with those terrifying Frost Giants -- hold their own in awesome fashion.
This is twice now that Marvel Studios has made me care for a comic-book figure who initially struck me as dopey.

Though occasionally wry it's not as out and out fun as some of the best comic films, but Thor rises to the challenge on the back of solid storytelling and a focus on character more action films could do with.
Marvel's Thor may be silly, but that doesn't make it any less entertaining.
This, my friends, is what a summer movie should be: exciting, clever, comedic, and a joyride.
Marvel's ambitious plan has taken one more step, and it has yet to take a false one.
I can't tell you if it was entirely faithful to the comics, and at this stage, I don't care. I want to see good movies, and Thor delivered.
Will it catch lightning in a bottle and become the next great superhero franchise? By Odin's beard, I think so! (Parental Content Review also available)

Thor suffers from Iron Man 2 syndrome: too much backstory, too many subplots and character introductions, and not nearly enough full-frontal nudity from Natalie Portman, who frankly is given very little to work with here.
Take an eight year old boy with you to increase your chances of a rollicking, if more-than usually ridiculous, time.

If the rest of the popcorn movie entries exceed expectations on this level, then the forthcoming shirtless hero worship season might give me washboard abs - "Conan," "Captain America" and "Sinbad" are yet to come.
Slight and sweet.
Cimino was already making an aesthetic of inarticulateness, and the film is by turns surly, incoherent, and provocatively mysterious.
Remember seeing this as a kid and loving it. I don't know if it still holds up, but I loved it way back when.
So-so medium budget actioner for the drive-in set
...a simple story with interesting characters, told in a laid-back fashion.
Early Cimino shows promise to come.
The Eastwood team has pulled off a modest enjoyable winner.
A fun classic, the likes of which they don't make anymore
Cimino is so into making his images glow that he forgets to make the film move.
Debuting director Michael Cimino obtains superior performances from Clint Eastwood, George Kennedy, Geoffrey Lewis and especially Jeff Bridges.

Eastwood is in good, if not great form, Bridges steals the whole show, and Cimino displays a sense of unpretentious fun and appealing grasp of character that should have held him in good stead for a lengthy career. It didn't.
Eastwood e Bridges estabelecem uma boa dinmica, mas  este ltimo, com uma composio jovial e inconseqente, quem d alma a um filme menor, mas ainda assim divertido.
Both Kennedy and Lewis turn in colorful performances, but it's Eastwood and Bridges' film, and their ill-defined, tender friendship makes the movie.
Thunderbolt & Lightfoot is an action film, but it's one where explosions, car chases, and violence seem almost beside the point.
Oscar-nominated Bridges is terrific, with his funny, freewheeling turn effectively loosening up Eastwood and allowing the superstar to appear more relaxed and less tight-lipped than usual.
'Thunderbolt and Lightfoot' has the ingredients of a high-dollar buddy comedy, but it also steers toward quieter, more mature territory that ultimately gives it greater cinematic electricity.
Director-writer Michael Cimino seems a master of offhand humor and bizarre characterization.
A great buddy heist movie that gets pulled down by some angry interlopers.
...a criminals-on-the-road movie that shifts toward a dazzlingly elaborate and painfully realistic heist tale.
Film noir at its best, with an intriguing blend of law and order, sin and sex, violence and sado-masochism.
Fine later Eastwood starrer

Tightrope may appeal to the Dirty Harry fans, with its sex and violence. But it's a lot more ambitious than the Harry movies, and the relationship between Eastwood and Bujold is more interesting than most recent male-female relationships in the movie.
Eastwood cria um personagem complexo e interessante, mas os elementos policiais da trama, aliados ao ritmo frouxo da histria, prejudicam seus esforos.
A surprisingly tightly wound serial killer mystery.
Eastwood took a chance at the height of his stardom to play a less-than-heroic cop in this gutsy serial-killer thriller.
A sharp-edged slightly offbeat crime thriller for the masses.
On an action fan's gut level, I like Eastwood. There's no other star who can pull off tense, John Wayneish moments so well.
Flat biopic of Jerome Kern salvaged by some production numbers.
MGM's bland musical biopics about Kern distorts basic facts, and lacks energy and imagination; the only good sequences feature Judy Garland and are staged by then husband Vincente Minnelli.
Star-packed MGM musical is more about Jerome Kern's music than Kern himself.
OK Jerome Kern musical, with some well done Vincente Minnelli musical numbers added to the mix.
Doesn't try to be anything more than a soft-serve pull of treacly pandering.
So bland and maudlin it'll have you crying "uncle"

Dedio undoubtedly wrote Ray Ray as a star turn, but the character is so forcefully written to be likable - in this case, as a nebulously defined everyman - that he never feels human enough to empathize with.
Too predictable for adults and too saccharine for even very young kids, this family-oriented comedy is strictly dullsville.
[A] well-photographed, lively and lightly comic film.
[a] by-the-numbers feel good story
Bittersweet family comedy involves parental loss.
A lush and terrifying spectacle of romantic doom.
It is filmmaking at its best.

You will walk out of Titanic not talking about budget or running time, but of its enormous emotive power, big as the engines of the ship itself, determined as its giant propellers to gouge into your heart, and as lasting as the love story that propels it.
Sure, it's corny, but there's something endearing about the tale of young love and its earnest lack of irony.

Take one of history's most compelling tragedies, tell it through the lives of two engaging young lovers and show it with some of the best-ever special effects and you have a dazzling, exciting movie that is also poignant and personal.
Titanic is indeed a ship of dreams. Climb aboard and bon voyage.
The re-release is keenly timed with the 100th anniversary of the actual sinking of the RMS Titanic, yet another factor to validate the 3D film's existence.
Titanic is a good, often stunning movie caught in a three-and-a-half hour drift.
The dialogue may be unspeakable, but the film remains unsinkable.
There's a lot to like here.
Titanic will give you your money's worth.
It's for old-fashioned romantics who want to see a classic love story on the grandest scale.
No other film has made the horror of the ship's sinking so palpable, and none other has dared to dramatize the night of the living dead that followed after it sank beneath the North Atlantic.
Titanic is not a perfect film, but it is a great film nonetheless.

What I can tell you, risking puns, is that it swept me off my feet almost from the get-go, a grand epic romance-disaster that reminded me, in the middle of my overstuffed-with-movies life, of what we mean when we talk about the power of cinema.
A wonderful masterpiece of a film.
It's so easy to see how this film that's still so enjoyable from start to end has become so iconic.
Titanic is a terrific balance of realism and romanticism.
An overwhelming cinematic experience which stuns, moves and entertains.
Titanic is big-budget spectacle and director Cameron brings it off with high-tech bravura, placing us aboard the ship in real time.
[Titanica] is based largely on footage filmed at the Titanic's grave. Seen on the giant, five-story, curving Omnimax screen of the Museum of Science and Industry, it is a sight to inspire awe.
Given the subject, this documentary is stunningly boring.
not quite enough actual Titanic

The movie is entertaining in its own right, and representative of the era in which it was produced, but, aside from the legendary interaction between Bogart and Lauren Bacall, there are only moderate reasons to recommend the film.
Bogie and Bacall make an engaging onscreen duo, delivering their lines with just the right amount of cynicism and coyness.
A qumica entre Bogart e Bacall (numa estria impressionante)  motivo suficiente para que este filme se mantenha vivo na memria dos amantes do Cinema.
This one is a must: they don't come better.
Asking an audience to laugh for two hours at the delirium tremens of a man suffering from alcoholism is a grisly thing.
colorful, believable, varied characters, a story that moves right along..., and dialogue that snaps right off the screen.
The effortless chemistry between Bogart and Bacall help distract from the fact that To Have and Have Not has little more going for it.
A victory of style and star power over substance.
Lauren Bacall has cinema personality to burn, and she burns both ends against an unusually little middle.

Bogie and Bacall fell in love while making the film, and their scenes reflect this, giving To Have and Have Not a degree of emotional presence that is unusual in the 'bite on the bullet' world of Hawks.

To Have and Have Not (1944) was director Howard Hawks' wartime adventure masterpiece - a minor film classic loosely based upon part of Ernest Hemingway's 1937 novel of the same name. Jules Furthman and William Faulkner partnered their talents
The dialogue crackles (including the legendary "whistle / blow" line), Bacall sizzles, and Bogart captivates.
As the hard-boiled professional fisherman who gives his ample ingenuity to a cause, Mr. Bogart is almost as impressive as he was as Rick, the Casablanca host.
Director Howard Hawks made a bet with Ernest Hemingway that he could make a good movie out of his worst novel. I don't know who won or how much the bet was for, but my money is on Hawks.
[Bogey & Bacall's] onscreen chemistry is palpable, all but overshadowing the fictional back story that made Rick and Ilsa's dance in Casablanca so memorable.
In many ways the ultimate Hawks film: clear, direct, and thoroughly brilliant.
Bogart is in his usual metier, a tough guy who, no less, has the facility of making a dame go for him, instead of he for her. That's where Bacall comes in.
While there are moments implying breezy, spontaneous improvisation in virtually all Hawks pictures, no other has such an all-pervasive sense of a floating party...
...an intriguing, romantic, sometimes exciting, predictable but entertaining motion picture.
You know how to whistle, don't you?
What's on screen is a collection of clich√©s intermingled with outlandish farce or surreal fantasy.
[It] generates no particular excitement or surprise, but it provides the sort of pleasure [Allen] seems able to generate almost on demand.
Frivolous, schematic, and overlong, Allen's valentine to the Eternal City is one of the weakest entries in his European film tour.

It's not Nero who's fiddling, but Allen, bopping and dithering around the city like a tourist so desperate to cram in all the sights that he comes away only with a few crisp highlights and a lot of out-of-focus snapshots.
This stale and flaccid exercise looks as if it has come from one of those old notebooks in which [Allen] keeps discarded ideas.
Even Allen's most loyal of fans must be starting to wonder why the once great director keeps on producing such dull material.
Even loyal fans have to admit this isn't so much a movie as four little one-page New Yorker stories, strung together with "Volare" and one-too-many shots of the Trevi fountain.

He's still the same curmudgeon obsessed with mortality, and he doesn't really have any zingers this time, but it works and it never hurts hurt the film. Only now he wears his pants too high. Pull your pants down, Woody.

A gorgeous setting for what is essentially warmed-over Woody... unrelated stories focus on familiar themes of romance and celebrity... a clashing assortment of signature styles, as if Allen emptied his notebook and crumpled thin ideas into a script.
A cannoli with an international cast, To Rome With Love is looser-and sillier-than Paris, but still a treat.
Palatable overall, if vaguely inauthentic and unsatisfying, like an allegedly local meal bought at a tourist restaurant.

Woody Allen's new movie, To Rome with Love, is light and fast, with some of the sharpest dialogue and acting that he's put on the screen in years. The picture gently but surely moves back and forth between romantic comedy and satirical farce.
None of the storylines are very funny or have any notable bearing on one another.
In his late '70s, Allen only has so many working days left in him, and if he has stories and ideas that he's eager to get down on film, he's earned the right.

To Rome With Love invites comparisons with Midnight in Paris - to the former's detriment. Opening and closing with Volare, one of the corniest in the Italian pop song repertoire, Allen wears the corny badge with pride throughout
An affectionate but meandering comedy that contemplates romance, fame, legacy and longing.
Honestly, "Rome" is a clear step down from "Midnight." But it's a fun, breezy film audiences will enjoy while it lasts and forget soon after. Heaven knows he's made worse films.
Allen lauds Rome in neurotic but teen-friendly comedy.
Overall, the storytelling is jumbled, the movie is in fragments and too much time is spent with boring silliness.
Weak fluff but a devastating looks at no-talent celebrities. Only the harried, suddenly anointed celebrity tale was beautifully crafted satire.
Seems like the first episode of a TV mini-series rather than a stand-alone feature film.
Sciamma's capturing of children at play is disarmingly accurate, perfectly showing the freewheeling nature of prepubescence in all its glory.
Celine Sciamma is a filmmaking force to be reckoned with in the coming years. Her story-writing ability, deft hand at directing and understanding of her young actors makes her someone to watch.

For much of the film, Mikhael is prevailingly happy. They have no label for their new gender presentation, and perhaps it's too early to define it, although as an adult, modern audience we may see them as trans or non-binary. [TOP 50 FILMS OF THE DECADE]
Although only a small film and one that barely runs to feature length, it raises some unique and thought-provoking ideas.
Tomboy captures a delicate moment in time before issues of sexuality so much more complicated and calculated.

Against a backdrop of overly programmed 'issue dramas,' this superb movie is notable for its strong foundation in character and wholesale investment in psychological motivation, rather than salacious plotting.
There are nevertheless some marvelous moments.

Should make people sit up and pay attention, not only due to Sciamma's naturalistic script and instinctive directing, but also the remarkable ensemble of young talent that she has consolidated into one film.
Quiet and naturalistic in the best way, the French film "Tomboy" rolls out a tale of malleable pre-adolescent identity with a marked absence of sensationalism.
There's an absolute naturalism to all the performances here. That's crucial, especially from Heran, who's playing a character who does not yet know herself.
Sweet and well observed, the film takes us inside a typical family in a typical Paris suburb - and gives us a spin

As the sisters come to see that dresses and haircuts and behaviors are a means to create a self, to communicate with others, Tomboy doesn't offer an easy answer; instead, it lets you wonder why gender must be so definitive.

Tomboy reveals a side of pre-adolescence rarely (if ever) depicted on the big screen, yet it never feels like a curiosity piece, nor is Laure (Zo Hran), the titular character, portrayed as an outsider from a troubled home.
Each day is a suspenseful challenge of how [the kid] keeps up a freeing masquerade; it's striking to see how gender casually figures into the daily life of children at play.
A tender, sensitive French drama rich in hazy atmosphere.
Its young heroine is proud to be herself; there's just not much for her to do beyond that.
Sciamma pictures the story in dappled sunlight and wooded fields that, though not far from dull apartment blocks, have an out-of-time seductiveness.
Tomboy is a lovely reminder that the French have long been famous for a quite different sort of film-about children.
This exquisite film is as pure as you can get; it's observational, it's minimalist, there's no intrusive music except where it is part of the action.
Jools and Linda left my giggle chain unyanked and their backstory, for all its nuance and aspects of tragedy, failed to stir my soul.
A fond, uncomplicated love letter to two irrepressible good-time Charlottes.

Leanne Pooley's delightful profile of Lynda and Jools Topp, New Zealand's top comedy duo, entertains while giving biographical background and full disclosure about their lesbian lifestyle. The performance clips are hilarious. Read full review.
Sometimes corny, often funny and just as often touching, their act has been wowing Kiwis for decades.
I cannot imagine anyone who would not like the Topp twins.
They've been performing for 30 years and it's safe to say that if they had any appeal here, you would have heard of them by now.
Pooley's approach is a bit paint-by-numbers, but her film is upbeat without being calculatedly feel-good.
A rare, purely fun documentary with a purely fun subject that reaches both the funny bone and the heart in equal measure.
Pooley could have been more probing in her interviews with the twins and their supporters. But the fact of the duo's success is so astounding you're gripped all the same.
I dare you to leave without the title song firmly stuck in your head.

Merging old-fashioned comedy routines with up-to-the-minute politics - all of it enabled by fun-loving personalities and a gift for rousing original songs - the ladies emit a genuine warmth that reels audiences in.
It's a great act that makes for a spry, likeable movie.
Given most people's unfamiliarity with New Zealand idiosyncrasies and politics, much gets lost in translation here.
The talent, the humor and the dedication of these amazing sisters is a gift to the world.
The Topp Twins: Untouchable Girls is the greatest movie ever made about a lesbian twin sister country singing, yodeling comedy act.

These butch lesbian sibling farmers, who have a comedy singing act (acoustic country songs), are shown fighting for gay rights and surviving cancer over the decades, and they are endearing in their suits and fake moustaches.
Warm and charming, if hardly essential.
One secret to the Topps' widespread acceptance is in plain sight: their remarkably old-fashioned act.
Pooley successfully conveys that joie de vivre, erring only when including too-invasive scenes of Jools's breast-cancer treatments.

Terrifically entertaining documentary about New Zealand's lesbian Topp Twins and their extraordinary career is a heart-warming eye-opener that provides insights into so much more than the sexual orientation of its two remarkable subjects.

[Ball] succeeds admirably and with dramatic force, blending themes of racism, liberalism, emotional betrayal, abuse, hate speech and pedophilia into a confronting adult drama peppered with shocks and black humour.
Boasting ten-dimensional characters and the sophisticated juggling of difficult themes, Ball's powerful, complex movie is a must-see.
As it becomes clear that Ball, in essence, has just restaged American Beauty with a socially conscious paint job, the sensationalism of Towelhead looks more and more like a dramatic tic.

Screenwriter Alan Ball is no stranger to daring stories, but in his awkward film directorial debut he seems unable to capture the soul of Alicia Erian's novel ‚Äî and with a story like this, that's disastrous.
I understand what the film is trying to do, but not why it does it with such crude melodrama.
Not since Splendor in the Grass has there been such a candid and sympathetic account of the mixed messages, double-standards, giddy highs and hormonal free falls experienced by teenage girls.

Too much of Towelhead is pitched on a hysterical, one-dimensional note, with Jasira being consistently mistreated in one way or another by pretty much everyone she encounters -- a reverse Candide for our cynical times.
Towelhead needs more breathing room in order to allow the central relationships to grow, but it's a movie that sticks with you.
Screenwriter Alan Ball ("American Beauty," HBO's "Six Feet Under") makes his directorial debut adapting Alicia Erian's novel from a particularly repellant male perspective.
Towelhead is too eager to shock us, and it's therefore only stupidly offensive instead of cutting and insightful.
The most deeply disturbing, downright discomfiting movie about teen sexuality since Thirteen.
It's too much, too heavy-handed. Disturbing is one thing. Prurient is another.
It's Ball's complex and frank approach to subject matter normally depicted in black-and-white terms that distinguishes Towelhead from so many coming-of-age dramas before it.
An exceedingly promising first effort from a novice filmmaker.
Towelhead is definitely not for all tastes, but it shows a bravery that's increasingly rare in American movies.
The film is superbly acted, but it's hard to know what to feel except, 'How can any girl navigate this oversexualized culture?'

[Director] Ball's trying to be honest about adolescent coming of age, but since he's dishonest about everything else, the movie collapses in on itself, ending with a laughably pat resolution that renders Towelhead a Bizarro World After School Special.
How is it that Alan Ball wrote some of the most nuanced, layered, dynamic characters on TV in
Ball falls prey to his own inadequacies and makes a movie audiences are going to feel awfully uncomfortable watching.
There is hardly a scene that does not produce exquisite discomfort and a strong desire to be somewhere else.
Puerile, gross and pandering to the lowest impulses of teenage boys.
If the take-no-prisoners humor of Citizen Toxie is very funny, the movie's relentless comic excess is ultimately a little exhausting.
Laughs are few and far between, and the film feels brutally long.
Though not up to the heights of whacked-out insanity established in Kaufman's last two films ... the film does have its moments.
Uncle Lloyd has done it again! Hell, he's welcome to come by my place to kick the dog any day!
suffers from peterjacksonsyndrome, but very entertaining.
Three stars. Joe Bob says check it out.
Parental Content Review
Honestly, it gave me a headache.
It's a wad of chaos puked onto the big screen, an arbitrary collection of explosions and machismo posturing.
The movie is formulaic and routine, which suits (Michael) Bay's directorial style. Creativity is anathema to this by-the-numbers cinematic traffic cop.
Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen is what it is: a big-budget spectacle with an incredible amount of action, a frivolous plot, and one hot chick.

If when you were a child--either with Mr. Wizard or alone--you had passed a magnet over a pile of iron filings, you would have unknowingly created the action scenes of Michael Bay's latest blockbuster, Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen.
Bay seems to think that just showing us a bunch of brightly clashing metallic limbs (accompanied by lots of noise) is enough to make us faint in our seats with excitement.
Bayformers 2 is a mess of a story loosely glued together with lame jokes, fighting pixels and Megan Fox's ass.
... there's no time to digest anything going on or in anyway connect with it because (Michael) Bay just HAS to show you something else... right now.
Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen dazzles the eye, numbs the mind and may cause deafness in some cases.
I saw Revenge of the Fallen at Imax, which is probably why I managed to stay awake in what for me was the world's most boring movie.
It's not so much that the story is inherently bad; it's more that it seems no one bothered to put one in at all, and worse, that no one seems to have cared.
Action fans won't feel cheated by director Bay, but beyond the rousing scenes and special effects, this sequel offers little.
Leave it to Michael Bay to take the fun out of explosions.
The dubious, tasteless humor and awful dialogue don't help. Neither does having a leading lady who can't act -- Fox seems to be regressing in her development as a performer.
It finally occurred to me that pyrotechnics are Bay's pornography: massive, fiery money-shots. I hope he had a sufficient supply of tissues in the editing room.
