Even longer and noisier than its predecessor--as well as dumber and more incoherent...like a big, unsightly, clattery toy powered by a battery that just wont quit, even though you devoutly wish it would.
Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen is everything that made the first film awesome and terrible at the same time... to a factor of ten.
Mostly it's punch-your-face loud.
The movie rages on for a hundred and fifty minutes and then just stops, pausing for the next sequel.
Disney guarantees a certain standard of entertainment that will doubtless satisfy several hundred thousand families.

If you don't have a youngster handy to give you an excuse to see Treasure Planet, hire one, just so you can step off this mortal coil in turmoil for 95 minutes of terrific adventure, with hardly any corn or schmaltz to distract you from a ripping good yar
A spiffy animated feature about an unruly adolescent boy who is yearning for adventure and a chance to prove his worth.
As action-adventure, this space-based homage to Robert Louis Stevenson's Treasure Island fires on all plasma conduits.
Treasure Planet is certainly suffering from creative schizophrenia.
[A] raucous adventure into infinity.
I've got nothing but praise for the work put into the art of this film, including the coloring, details, excitement and originality.
This is exactly what animation should be about, presenting us with a thrillingly imaginative adventure that is utterly liberated from trivialities like the laws of physics and possibility.
Despite more betrayal and loyalty than a Chris Carabba box set, there's no real good or evil here.
The techs are, simply, outstanding in every way.
Although Disney follows its standard formula in this animated adventure, it feels more forced than usual.
It's not one of Disney's greatest, but it's solid entertainment.
A splendid adventure film that doesn't mistreat its characters under the weight of the most hackneyed archetypes of the company. [Full Review in Spanish]
Visually rather stunning, but ultimately a handsome-looking bore, the true creativity would have been to hide Treasure Planet entirely and completely reimagine it.

'Treasure Plane' starts with the clever idea of transforming the story into an old-fashioned space opera, and the animated visuals are handily up to the studio's best. Yet the film's total appeal may be undercut by a script that rarely feels inspired.
Enjoy the spectacle.
Dazzles and delights, like a billion bits of gold bullion strewn about the caves of a rampaging buccaneer.
Esta curiosa releitura do clssico de Robert Louis Stevenson conta com um visual impressionante e boas seqncias de ao. Ainda assim, est longe de se equiparar aos grandes clssicos da Disney.

This is a good script, good dialogue, funny even for adults. The characters are interesting and often very creatively constructed from figure to backstory. The film will play equally well on both the standard and giant screens.

...spiced with humor ('I speak fluent flatula,' advises Denlopp after a rather, er, bubbly exchange with an alien deckhand) and witty updatings (Silver's parrot has been replaced with Morph, a cute alien creature who mimics everyone and everything around)

leave[s] us, much like the characters in the film who attend the all-night horror-thon, worrying about just who might be sitting around us in the theatre - because, as Jayne puts it, "any one of your costumed moviegoers could be your killer".
This film would feel desperate to be socially relevant if it were not so incredibly lazy in just every conceivable way.
Trick isn't much of a Halloween treat, and like a sour apple stuffed with razor blades washing the bad taste of this one out of my mouth is going to be difficult to do.
This is a film that feels like it was made a couple of drafts of the script too early. Trick entertains the viewer, at least during its opening act, but fails to engage them overall.
The pic might have proved mindless fun if it had least displayed a sense of humor, but everything is played with deadly seriousness.
It's like someone wrung all the satire out of the Scream franchise and replaced it with cheap edgelord viciousness.
It's messy, it's loud, it's violent. Sadly the mixture does not work this time, and Trick stays away from being a worthy 'slasher' film. [Full review in Spanish].
Trick is a fun Halloween film for fans of slasher films may they be hardcore or casual; it's gleefully violent and doesn't make apologies for it.
Trick is all treats from start to finish.
Those searching for Halloween viewing treats won't find it here. At every level, from technical to story, Trick is a joyless affair.
Coupled with the potential victims' unbelievable lack of survivor instincts and Trick quickly becomes a horror movie that cheats on delivering authentic scares and thrills.
..the shoddy plot, paper thin characters, and poor pacing sinks what could have been a solid slasher.
The film is a bit all over the place at times, but it's also quite charming.
Patrick Lussier's film is an incompetent, nihilistic exercise in gore and pseudophilosophy.
Trick is savage, brutal and twisted in all the best ways. It's a razor sharp, slick as hell return to form for Lussier and an absolute must see for any fan of the slasher genre.
Inferior seasonal splatter film.

One whopper of a plot-twist briefly gives "Trick" an original hook. But by the end of the picture it's clear the filmmakers aren't really interested in exploring any of the potentially interesting sociopolitical implications of their big surprise.
Trick is playing a much grander game than your run-of-the-mill, killer on the loose story.
The things that Trick gets right, it gets very right. The kills and the element of surprise keep it a quickly moving fright fest.
Shot simply but compellingly, it feels like a polished and practised portrait of rekindled bonds.
A mesmerizing talk-a-thon with smart, useful things to say about life, love and rock 'n' roll.
...an aimless and stagy piece of work that fizzles out to an increasingly (and distressingly) demonstrable degree as it progresses.
No one does a rock 'n roll movie quite like [Bruce] McDonald.
... you totally buy that these women have a history together and they've both been through some heavy, heavy sh*t.

Witty, moving and immensely satisfying, Trigger is a real gem, and far better than a movie so quickly slapped together has any right to be. It says a lot about what can be accomplished when filmmaking is fired with urgent devotion to a common purpose.
A brilliant, unique, unforgettable film.
Weir and Niccol have come up with a bracingly original cinematic experience.
Funny, moving, imaginative and wickedly smart about the addictive power of comfy illusion.
A thought-provoking, original movie that works on many levels.
although there are flashes of humor throughout, the film is more often funny-weird than it is uproarious.
It is one of the best films ever made about the dangers of mass-media...
Weir presents The Truman Show as a fairy tale, not an Orwellian nightmare
The Truman Show is one of the most startlingly original American movies in years, enough to give one faith in the salutary and inspiring nearness of the new millennium.
A stunningly original, deeply disturbing, surrealistic nightmare of a film the likes of which I haven't seen in a long time. [SPOILER!]
The film is very funny, but also touching and thought provoking.
[A] masterfully executed cautionary tale... Yet there's something missing here: While Weir delivers both sharp wit and gentle poignancy, Truman's end catharsis needs greater emotional heft.
One movie you can pronounce a modern classic with absolute confidence.
This is a film that can stay with one for a very long time after a viewing, and even slightly change the way one looks at life and the world.
The underlying ideas made the movie more than just entertainment. Like Gattaca, the previous film written by Niccol, it brings into focus the new values that technology is forcing on humanity.
Extremely original, well-written piece that ultimately left me emotionally detached, and feeling bored at certain times.
With the reality TV boom, it brings forth more thoughts as to whether our society could ever be this extreme, and with each viewing, its themes deepen.

The movie might have been a soulless exercise without [Carrey]. With him, it has an authentic tremulousness, and also a dread, as if Pinocchio needed to take on Gepetto and Jiminy Crickett to become a real boy.
The Truman Show is not perfect, but it's interesting, and has its funny moments.
A subtly layered, perceptive, and pointedly truthful commentary on the media and its and our own voyeuristic tendencies.
The premise of Peter Weir's The Truman Show is both reasonable and ludicrous, its execution sublime.
Director David Schwimmer's cautionary tale of the very real dangers posed by manipulative paedophiles grooming young kids on the internet scores some direct hits.
Online predator targets teen in mature, creepy drama.
What Trust conveys, at its best, is that ultimately parental protections are not foolproof, and that is the greatest horror of all.
Even if it's a mite clunky, Trust does a decent job and avoids the regulation happy ending.
An exercise in sober drama and a middle-class cautionary tale which explores a family ripped up by the roots after the rape of a 14-year-old girl.

The psychology of trauma and the trauma of familial psychology are densely interlaced and vividly portrayed in Trust. It's a feat of unexpected difficulty from David Schwimmer, and it earns the elusive commodity invoked by the title.

Schwimmer directs with sensitivity and restraint, and gets excellent performances from his cast. Owen pulls off some heart-wrenching scenes, although it's Liberato's revelatory performance as the emotionally confused teen that holds the film together.
Schwimmer's handling of the multifaceted emotional and psychological terrain on display here is delicate and utterly compassionate.
[A] challenging and provocative must-see movie that provides no pat answers and will surely have audiences talking long afterwards.
Schwimmer directs with intelligence and a minimum of hysteria, deftly handling the shifts in atmosphere this creepy story requires.
An exciting 14-year-old actress anchors a gripping tale of statutory rape and its impact on a family. (What upset the victim is not what you think.)

Schwimmer, for all his film's limitations, deserves a lot of credit for finding a gifted actress the same age as his central character, and sculpting Liberato's blazing, wounded, needy and all-round award-level performance into the gem it is.
The whole section of the plot dealing with Will's shame and rage at failing to protect his child is hammily and unconvincingly acted.
Committed performances and a masterful first act bolster this structurally flawed handling of an impossibly tricky subject.
A gripping, if at times melodramatic, family drama.
Great performances and an intelligent treatment of a hot topic. Profoundly moving.
This is a very good, thoughtful film and an important one.
He's adept with actors, but Schwimmer has yet to locate his strengths behind the camera.

Trust is heartrending in its depiction of the gulf between the female teenage victim of such a coercive assault and especially her father, as well as the manner in which adolescent judgment is reasonably fallible.

The script is blaring and obvious at all times, and in his second directorial effort, David Schwimmer doesn't have a clue how dull it is for the audience to endure scene after scene of anguish, crying and screaming matches.
Strikes a tone that deftly mixes comedy, wistfulness and bawdiness. The finished product is something to be proud of.
Nivola makes an astounding left turn from his nice husband role in Junebug and Hutton loses himself in the sort of part fit for a Walter Hill film.
It's clear that Mr. Hutton enjoyed every minute of doing gruff, gross thugishness and boorish simplicity.
An Irish-set comedy-drama, Turning Green is not particularly comic or compellingly dramatic.

With the help of first-time performer Donal Gallery, this mix of gangster drama and quirky comedy boasts a modest charm that should appeal to young men around same age as the 16 year old lead character, despite a lack of focus and familiar twists.
suffers from a strangely lazy narrative and a bizarre waste of notable actors
Turning Green is, if nothing else, the world's loneliest teen sex comedy.
Both Project Greenlight runners-up, directors Michael Aimette and John G. Hofmann get the teen angst and Gaelic aesthetic right; too bad their third-act thuggery isn't just routine, but ridiculous.
Initially engaging, witty and charming, but ultimately ends up contrived and bland with an unfocused, half-baked plot.
Sometimes sweet but invariably slight and old-fashioned coming-of-age tale set in 1970s Ireland.
A whimsical dirty joke of a movie set in a picturesque Irish village.
Turning Green has been on the shelf for so long that I'm afraid this forgettable film has gone bad.
For the Disney Princess crowd that's moving into their teenage years, Twitches should work. It's not bad, per se. But it is just another Disney Channel Original Movie.
...though the Mowry sisters are personable enough, they simply cannot act...
Twin Sister Sisters' magic made for tweens.
Twitches had the perfect mix of what I love: magic, drama, and the return of 90's teen stars, Tia and Tamera Mowry.

But where Romero goes for the cheap, linear approach, Argento's storytelling is painfully poetic, with ever-shifting points of view and asides... There's a madness in Argento's method and it's always appropriate.
It was a match made in hell, a dream realized for many horror fans.
You can't go too wrong with these directors. Maybe just a little bit wrong, but it's still good.
It's a tough call as to which director's episode is lamer.
Cool cats kill!
I wasn't too surprised to find that I liked both parts of this film, regardless of the negative buzz.
The one directed by Argento is clearly better than Romero's.
While far from the worst adaptation of Poe's work... Two Evil Eyes breaks no new ground.
Two Evil Eyes is a flawed project. Romero's segment doesn't pull its own weight. While it is creepy in spots, the majority of the story is overlong and ho-hum in the execution.
It is amazing what Argento has been able to do in his 65-minute "The Black Cat," which is the more ingenious--and gory--of the two parts.

Playing out like a mediocre episode of Tales From The Crypt, it's slow, largely uneventful and not particularly exciting when something does happen... The Black Cat is a much more solid film, with a considerably better screenplay and some excellent acting
All in all, Two Evil Eyes is one evil eye with perfect vision. The other eye has a cataract.
a grim, uneven affair that highlights its respective directors' strengths and weaknesses in relatively equal measure
An empowering, optimistic experience, humanizing the issue through poignant profiles.
Its issue is the debate over gay marriage, and director Jim de Seve does an outstanding job of humanizing the issue.
When de Sve tries to rope in a wider context, the film flounders to an extent that will keep it from reaching much of a wider audience
Activist filmmaking... but neither strident nor plaintive.
The film attains its greatest impact in the most specific cases.
A lively, cogent docu.
Exhibits an accomplished maturity from the first-time director, deftly applying a dry wit, a healthy sense of irony, and a nonexploitive approach to emotionality.
Has the good sense to take a large step back from the emotional debate surrounding the issue and scrutinize the history of marriage itself.

It may not be the most meticulously crafted documentary in the world, but what Tying the Knot lacks in finesse it compensates for in making a heartfelt case for the hot-button topic of same-sex marriage.
Like most hot-button documentaries, its impact is debatable, but filmmaker Jim de Seve makes an effective, an often moving case, for tolerance.
Offers a refreshingly strong and lucid examination of the issue, even if it's edited a bit chaotically, cross-cutting between its various strands.
Ironic & powerful, delving beneath bluster and bigotry to explain what the institution of marriage really means in the context of today's society.
Seve's absorbing documentary about gay marriage is most persuasive when most specific.
Not only offers useful information but contains moments of gravity and pathos that genuinely touch the heart.
Tying the Knot is effective ... in its depiction of the struggle for same-sex couples to achieve legal equality, but it gives short shrift to the opposing arguments.
Makes the case that it is not just societal recognition that same-sex partners lack without the official decree of a marriage -- it is the legal rights that married couples share.
Documentarian Jim de Seve's cogent pro-gay-marriage argument appeals equally to emotion and reason.
The movie, directed by Jim de Seve, personalizes a ferocious political debate, never losing its (frequently sad) human face.
De Seve brings together the stories, documenting them and not drilling rhetorically.
Personalizes the political with two heart-rending real-life cases.
This film is a cinematic hate crime.
Boo 2! A Madea Halloween is a profoundly miserable low point for the Madea franchise as a whole.
Perry has made a sequel based on a film that was based off a joke Chris Rock made in his movie and it is as pathetic as it sounds.
When you try too hard to make the audience laugh, it hurts -- physically.
A disappointingly tired retread that brings no new ideas to the table, and runs on recycled jokes that quickly wear out their welcome.
A few rows in front of me, someone is snoring loudly while the No. 1 movie in the country unspools before him.
Crude, tired jokes and drug use weigh down Madea sequel.
Even if you're just looking for a Tyler Perry night out, be very afraid.
Like Madea, Perry's getting away with attempted murder.
While its predecessor at least pleased his fans, writer-director-star Perry's latest offers few laughs and embarrassing post-production work.
Of course, all of the problems with the first film also continue in the sequel, from cringey performances by a cast of social media personalities... to the flimsy, often nonsensical plot.
If nothing else, and there really isn't much else, this feature provides a startling glimpse into the interiors of Perry's imagination.
As a pure Perry apologist, this critic found Boo 2! boring, frankly.
This is not the fun/insane Tyler Perry movie you're looking for.
"Boo 2" is terrible, but you know that already, though it does identify just how little Perry cares about the look and content of his features.

It's already a general rule that Madea movies are never all that funny whenever Madea isn't on screen, but even when she and Joe are at the center of the action, they're batting about .250 when it comes to punchlines.

The anarchic buffoonery is where the dust shakes off. A long jittery sequence in which the nervous old-timers drive the woods at night, acting both brave and terrified by turns, might even rank up there with Abbott and Costello Meet Frankenstein.
Sometimes it's stupid-funny, but mostly it's just plain stupid. And sloppy. And that won't matter one bit to fans of Tyler Perry's films.

So much of the film goes on and on and on and on and on and on, and on, until you find yourself nodding off, having a nice nap and waking up to find yourself stuck in the same scene you fell asleep in.
In the end, the scariest thing about Boo 2! is the idea that A Madea Easter might be next.

Tender, warm, witty and refreshingly honest. Hctor Bonilla gives a bravura performance.

A low-rent cousin to classic films like Blade and The Matrix.

The settings and tony atmosphere of Underworld are more than a screen fantasy: they're a conceit, and they're offered to us humorlessly.
It's hard to recall a more sexless vampire flick.
