Dark Shadows for the Playstation 2 generation.
A dark, Gothic romance set among lots of Matrix-style action, ably executed by first-time director Len Wiseman.
However much Underworld recycles elements from other films, it carries us into a well-constructed, convincingly scary world worth visiting.
Kate Beckinsale is the hottest vampire I've ever seen.
Leather-clad Kate Beckinsale is smokin' hot in this stylish, action-packed showdown between the denizens of the dark.
Tony Pierce-Roberts's moody camera work and Martin Hunter's rat-a-tat-tat editing give it an electricity that horror buffs will enjoy.
slap it on the posters: "NOT THAT BAD!" - Arizona Daily Star
One can see it on the actors' faces: This was a mistake.

Jammed between pratfalls that include a man's face and a penis coming together is a sentimental story about the challenges of being a good, supportive dad. The movie wants you to hug your family - but wait, whoa, look at those tatas!
A wacky, hijinxy, dick joke-filled sex romp that inadvisably keeps trying to be touching.
A tonal mess that jumbles elements of PG-rated fare with Eurotrip-esque shenanigans.

Certainly has the potential to tear through madcap Euro-based misadventures, but it would rather stick to sobering reminders of real-world behavior, draining most of the fun out of a feature that aims to please.

The film's biggest issue is its awkward lurching back and forth between the goofy and/or risqu material and more serious issues. (Full Content Review -- Sex, Profanity, Violence, etc. -- for Parents also available)
Painfully humorless.
Going through the motions and never uncovering any funny material to play with, "Unfinished Business" is just that: a film that had loads of potential but isn't able to muster any laughs with it.
This is one mess of a movie with just enough lowbrow laughs to stave off the narrative malaise threatening to freeze the story.
This is a movie that treats everyone like grey specters in a faceless corporation. Not that you would expect much else from a movie that openly admits its premise is boring.
If Unfinished Business represents Vaughn's desperate attempt to run whatever's left of his career into the toilet, then we can safely say that he's indeed finished.

But I can't bring myself to hate Unfinished Business as it gives Vaughn, Franco et al. juuuuust enough funny stuff to do while being agreeably mediocre; it'd be like kicking a dog for its failure to be a cat.
If only I could have left Unfinished Business unfinished... Five minutes would have been enough with this dull, dated tosh, so flaccid were the jokes.
A sort of unfinished idea that could have been interesting, could have been funny, could have been something other than the jumbled mess that it is.
The problem with "Unfinished Business" is not that it is outright terrible, but that it is so terminally bland.
Rude, crude but often delightful and fresh business farce.
What are we to say about a comedy that makes you walk out feeling lousy, that's like a parade of beaten virtue and (mostly) sadistic power?
This hybrid vehicle may take a unwise detour here and there - even hitting a mud-filled pothole or two - but in the end you just might find that it's been an entertaining ride.
The most important unfinished business here is Steve Conrad's slapdash script, with its shifting tones, forced jokes and gaping plot holes.
At times so shoddily made you'd swear it was actually unfinished, the charm of Vaughn, Franco, Nick Frost and the rest can't compensate for a shocking lack of jokes.
Up the Yangtze is a reminder that every little family matters and that economic miracles are zero-sum games.
There's plenty for the director to focus on. Examining the dam's environmental impact alone would take another whole movie. Instead, [director] Yung trains his lens mainly on the cultural impact.
The most effective scene is Chang's brilliant time-lapsed filming of the Yangtze River rising and engulfing the embankment.
almost unbearably intimate

China is on the world's mind. The once-mysterious communist "enemy" is now the economic friend of all the essential profiteers. Up the Yangtze is a new documentary that expounds upon China in transition.
One of the real +es of Up the Yangtze, aside from its empathy with its subjects, is its striking visual quality.
For all its tranquil pace, Up The Yangtze captures perfectly a sense of frenzy and discontent that permeates everything.
Chang's fluid camera captures the river's vanishing beauty, as well as the dichotomy between Yu Shui's rural poverty and Chen Bo Yu's urban lifestyle.
[Director Yung Chang] and lenser Wang Shi Qing use powerful images, subtlety and a little humour to apprise the viewer of the human and cultural issues at stake.

In doing so he photographs a landscape and country going through profound change on an almost unimaginable scale, all of it building to a final scene that's chilling in its Joseph Conrad-like uncertainty.
The tone is finally one of wistful resignation.
With all these lyrical elements in play, [director Yung] Chang's extraneous voiceover narration is baffling, and all but unbearable.
Up the Yangtze provides a devastating view of top-down, broad-stroke social programs.
A gloriously cinematic doc of epic, poetic sadness.
This is a sad film to be sure, but highly accomplished and very effective.
Chang gracefully juxtaposes the country and the metropolitan to express the knotted-up mixture of anguish, anger, hope, and trepidation of those in the dammed river's wake.
Modernization is a double-edged sword as this superb documentary illustrates.

This, the film argues, is the way of the future: One form of poverty-stricken squalor replaced by a tackier, more plasticized life of similarly deadend subservience, all in the guise of economic progress.
If Up the Yangtze makes you think, 'How can a film so lovely be about something so horrible?' then it has done its job.
Up The Yangtze goes from sleepily hypnotic to riveting over the course of 90 minutes.
A movie that's as empty and unlikable as the characters themselves.
The lack of any likable characters ultimately undoes "Urge." Kaufman and Stahl have made a classic party-throwers mistake: overrating the entertainment value in watching other people get high.
It's a terrible movie, incoherent and absurd, with Kaufman completely incapable of inspiring anything besides a headache with what's sure to be one of the worst films of 2016.
Drugs can kill, but in this tawdry thriller, you just wish they'd get it over with a little quicker.
The absurdity of Urge is awfully difficult to put into words -- it's just one big mistake.
In his directorial debut, Aaron Kaufman makes a few mistakes, but, overall, offers a decent view of this indulgent lifestyle.
It feels obligatory, like the boss barged in and said, 'I want a movie about pigeons who help the British war effort on my desk by Monday!,' and so everyone had to do it.
Doomed by its script to a sort of tedious mediocrity, this pigeon's as dead as a dodo.
Too inoffensive to engender the hostility once reserved for Howard the Duck.
[E]xactly as cozily silly and as charmingly touching as you'd expect from a nation that gives medals of valor to birds.
Ever noticed how many pigeons look like John Cleese? Me neither.
Stick to the genuinely delightful Chicken Run -- this one's for the birds.

critic_name: Cherryl Dawson and Leigh Ann Palone
content: An animated war epic - it doesn't sound like it would fly but it does.
It's no Shrek, but what Valiant lacks in looks, it makes up for with its perky winged heroes and high-flying concept.
Valiant may not fly in the stratosphere of Pixar or the best of DreamWorks, but giving these plucky birds their due is not a bad way to wind up the summer.
Harmless but generally uninspired.
Animated pigeons? British wartime humor? Disney? The mixture is ripe for something amiable, if unremarkable. Sadly, the production forgot the amiable part.
Valiant does the job of providing some suitable entertainment for youngsters but not much more.
It's a tale with plenty of spirit and a good heart, and yet, this story doesn't so much soar across the screen as it does waddle.
...Serves its purpose as end-of-the-summer entertainment for the young ones...it will likely be viewed once and forgotten in favor of other films with better repeat value.
People who liked the Shrek flicks may actually try to prove their sophistication amongst themselves by rejecting this pale imitation of an embarrassing cultural artifact.
No matter how hard the CGI animators try, the idea of Ricky Gervais as a bird is not as funny as the idea of Ricky Gervais as a human being.
Even young viewers will recognize Valiant as second-tier Disney.
A passable animated feature that will entertain small children, but feels as if it was thrown together quickly.

Arguably the blandest of the burgeoning crop of big budget digitally animated films, Valiant aims to prove that the death of traditional animation has simply pushed lackluster screenplays into the digital realm.
This animated WWII story may not engage all kids.
not a 'normal Tom pic.'
[A] spectacular film!
The film, whether they like it or not, is about being beautiful and then losing it. Hollywood's penultimate nightmare.
Why does it seem like the kind of misfire only Hollywood can produce?
Surreal, mysterious, engaging, clever and most of all, entertaining.
The relatively few American viewers who saw the Spanish film will find Crowe's version more artful and better explained than its predecessor.
Bland and lacking flavor.
There is wonderful chemistry of two quite different kinds between Tom Cruise and Cameron Diaz on the one hand, and Cruise and Penelope Cruz on the other.
As pretentious as it is preposterous, Vanilla Sky needs its own wake-up call.
The director and his leading man vest David with just enough endearing humanity to suck us in to his tale.
Imitation can indeed be the sincerest form of flattery by being so bad in comparison.
A decent film that isn't as good, thrilling or haunting as the original, but should still mesmerize viewers unfamiliar with Amenbar's version.
It's not really a bad film -- it couldn't be, given the high level of talent involved -- but it is a rather pointless one.
The film is seamless, surprising and erotic, mixing the best elements of romance, sci fi and drama.
Expect top notch work by Cruise, Crowe and Co.
Stands as a genuine existential idyll, a movie that muses rather than demanding, 'Solve me.'
It makes you wonder where 'a cover' ends and karaoke begins.
Inevitably, the film seems as hollow and pointless as David is.
For all its shortcomings, Vanilla Sky exerts a hypnotic, otherwordly attraction.
A ravishing stunner that never loses its way once...Director[Cameron Crowe's] most stunning work to date.
Brad Anderson... whips it into something gorgeously terrifying, creating a sense of menace out of shadow and darkness... the likes of which I'm not sure I've ever seen on film before...
Probably it would have made a much better "Twilight Zone" episode at one-third of the length, but there's enough good, solid genre work here to make it worthwhile.
There are a few moments in the film that suggest just how a subtle, creepy version of that film might play. This is not that version.
The film has a few eerie chills, but they're chills in anticipation of a payoff. There is no payoff.
Overall, Vanishing on 7th Street was just randomly ridiculous and utterly asinine.

Mr. Anderson has evidently watched a lot of old Twilight Zone reruns. So much of the film's dense, murky palette evokes menace without mayhem, but the wrap-up at the end by Rod Serling is sadly missed.
Prediction: Vanishing on 7th St. will vanish from theaters very quickly.
An extended scavenger hunt for portable sources of light: flashlights, candles, gas generators, road flares and so forth. Have one go out at your own peril.
A little more polish in the writing could have made it a must-see, but as it stands, it's a fairly solid B-movie matinee with a nicely calibrated mix of intellectual dread and visceral shock.

Anderson does a lot with very little - a wavering light, a patch of darkness - and Jaswinski's script tries to break up the stage-bound monotony with a few well-timed (if not particularly informative) flashbacks.

Working from a script with diminishing returns by Anthony Jaswinski, Mr. Anderson smartly frontloads the movie, drawing you in with long shots of deserted cityscapes, the quiet punctured by periodic bird calls and dog barks.
It doesn't really progress beyond what happens in the first forty minutes.
It's a hell of a premise that proves effective at immediately capturing the viewer's interest...
The star player here is Anderson, who proves that he can do his job even when other members of the creative team don't.
There's one easy way to keep people from criticizing a Hayden Christensen performance, and that's to cast him opposite John Leguizamo.
This is The Twilight Zone as written by Jean Paul Sartre. What audacity! What vision! And, alas, what a failure.
It's not particularly scary, but it's still a very moody and effective flick.
Those streets full of empty clothes hold a special kind of terror. More's the pity that the film can't do anything with them.
Brad Anderson plays off cinema's light and shadow for existential, apocalyptic horror.
provides little raw material for the performers to work with
This deliberately paced Brazilian historical drama rewards patience with its sumptuous black-and-white cinematography and affecting story of prejudice that carries contemporary resonance.
Any director this far along in developing an assured visual style truly is a director to watch.
[A] darkly mysterious period fable.
Some scenes are languid, while others are seemingly pointless, yet they culminate toward a final shot as striking and powerful as anything in the usual crop of Oscar bait.
At two hours, Vazante has an unfortunate tendency to drag.
Thomas implausibly upholds the romantic trope of a doomed heroine.
Transfixing in its formal rigor, impressive craft and striking visual beauty.
It's preoccupied with textures and touch, with fabric, food and foliage. Yet it's a sensuous telling of a rather pessimistic story.
Every composition, each image of her epic endeavor, especially in close-ups, comprise sensual, atmospheric marvels.
Brazilian drama about a misogynistic slave owner and those suffering under his control.

The various interpersonal dynamics at play, though manifested quietly, manage to evoke modern conflicts nearly effortlessly, and in this way the film succeeds as a meaningful journey onto the plantation.
A minor Greek tragedy transposed to colonial Brazil.
Slavery corrupts owners as well as their enslaved as this starkly beautiful, dreamlike fable assures us.
Under the supervision of Linha de Passe co-director Daniela Thomas, this emotionally wrenching period drama is culturally and historically valuable.
An engrossing film from veteran director Daniela Thomas.
Thomas makes her solo directing debut with this striking study of racial and gender politics in colonial Brazil.
The languidly-paced picture has a staggering array of beautiful images and vistas.

Daniela Thomas previously teamed with other directors, most notably Walter Salles, but "Vazante" marks her first time behind the camera alone. With those decades of experience in mind, this film never feels like a debut.
There is no way that the story of Vazante ... could end well. The genuine shock is how badly and horrifically it does end for all of these characters.

It can test the patience of a viewer. But the beauty of the images and the underlying power of the story, especially when Beatriz begins to emerge as the focus of the film, make Vazante an immersive watch.
It's as thought writer and director Peter Berg couldn't face following through what he suggests in the early moments of the film.
...the film wages a war against one's moral senses in a story that's unforgettable.
...uneven but frequently funny...
a blood-soaked parody of the American dream
There are some hysterically funny bits, but the excessive violence sometimes kills the laughter.
...unpleasant and extremely unfunny...
It's the eternal question.
Berg is so in love with his escalating shock tactics that they quickly cease to shock.
His [Berg] one serious mistake is to confuse gore with terror.
A scabrous black comedy like no other I've ever seen...
Aiming for the giddy gruesomeness of Shallow Grave, [director Peter] Berg piles one sadistic thrill on top of another without noticing how flat and charmless the whole enterprise feels.
The most delightfully morbid film of the year, a movie that goes so far over the deep end with its outrageousness and violence that I couldn't help but be won over by the material.
There is a line between gallows humor and tastelessness, but Very Bad Things apparently doesn't have a clue where that might be.

'Very Bad Things' is one of those nightmares that one part of the brain recognizes as such and assures you that it is not real, while the other hemisphere advises you to fasten your belt and enjoy the evening. [Full Review in Spanish]
A very bad movie.
Shameless, eager-to-shock energy, with a crafty script and a flawless ensemble cast to match, make this beyond-black comedy a very good thing indeed.
...Berg's listless direction brings the film so little point of view that it doesn't much matter who lives or dies.
Very Bad Things is a well-constructed study of the human psyche and how it eventually cracks under intense pressure.
A vicious, disturbing black comedy that delivers a wickedly entertaining ride if you don't take it too seriously.
...one of the more effective black comedies to come around in quite some time.
The movie ultimately all comes down to Dench, and the film becomes a frame of her performance. It's a great performance.
Frears' film is all nostalgia and inertia - a tale ablaze with historical import and contemporary resonance, reduced to commemorative biscuit tin proportions.
Even if it feels like a missed opportunity at times, the film is handsomely mounted and spotlights an intriguing historical footnote with flair.
You already know what it will be like - but that is a + in this case.
Lacks any depth or heart, too busy with irritating and racist hijinks.
Dench's imperious performance keeps the film afloat, but as a piece of storytelling, Victoria and Abdul is disturbingly glib.
Dench is comfortable in her role as the queen, and Fazal also seems to carry Abdul well, and the chemistry between the two actors is good.
This is more a film about Victoria than Abdul, but their relationship has a timely message about acceptance and understanding between different cultures. Very pleasant indeed.
As gorgeous as the film is, it is still Dench's performance that really rivets.

Abdul doesn't seem to fear the loss of his homes and station - he appears mainly to want to stay close to his special friend. Ignoring the rich complexity of these circumstances diminishes the history and its participants.
Judi Dench's performance rules over the production just as surely as Victoria rules over her subjects.
"Guess Who's Coming to Dinner" served with mango chutney.
The kind of film that knows where its strengths reside, and how viewers are likely to react.

With no desire to explore the political dynamics, the film is prevented from achieving anything more than a slight comedy of manners. But how mannered they look in those impeccable costumes and with the occasional self-effacing wink.
Despite an uneven narrative and historical inaccuracies, Victoria and Abdul is a delightful film that deserves to be watched for Judi Dench.

Awareness is where Frears balances both humour and drama because it's the core of the story, emotionally and politically. We can laugh at the politesse disguising denial, at the court's love of the crusty status quo, but Abdul is the emissary of change.
Led gloriously by Dench...the British point of view is portrayed vividly but the Indians' too simplistically...Fazal acts the naif...The film is attractive yet sadly shallow.
It's surprisingly effective.
We are somewhat amused. Not a lot. But somewhat.
Judi Dench's Oscar-worthy second turn as Queen Victoria is a poignant portrait of fading power and human connection.
Just sits there, barely bubbling, substituting Day-Glo costumes for wit.
The whole thing feels like a botched rewrite, or a script distorted by casting decisions.
Such a godawful mess that you honestly can't tell if it was meant to be a comedy or not.
It dances into Spoofville, then jerks back into straight romantic comedy.
A mild, genial comedy that nobody will love and nobody will hate.
It's undone by narrative and continuity turbulence.
This sweet little comedy is a coming-of-age, small-town-girl-makes-good saga. ... Rooting for an underdog that you expect will win is always satisfying even if the result is never really in doubt.

[Wald] never figured out whether he wanted to make a snarky send-up, an elementary romantic conflict (career or love: what a clever dilemma) or a you-go-girl empowerment fantasy. In the end, he failed at all three.
Even though there are funny people like Mike Myers making cameos (payback for Paltrow's brilliant cameo in "Goldmember") this comedy about a budding stewardess just doesn't take off.
About as manufactured a fluff-piece as I've seen this year.
[It's] as if the script had either been sitting around for 40 years... or was written recently by someone whose entire experience of airline travel was gleaned from movies of the 1960s.

Might be productively -- and quite reasonably -- assaulted on a number of fronts (for its class condescension, its lack of humour, its waste of talent or even its sheer visual ugliness), but it seems both cruel and unnecessary to do so.
A flat, superficial comedy that never establishes a tone.
Stinks like it was made by rank amateurs, and particularly incompetent ones, at that.
Given the weakness of the script, it's surprising how many top-flight performers participated.
View From the Top is one of those misguided movies that mistakes wackiness for depth.
Barreto concentrates on character development over cutesy shtick, and his cast rewards him with a fleet of charming performances.
[A]n airy bit of fluff, a soap bubble of a movie.
Virtually every clich and stereotype is on parade, culminating in the career-vs.-love choice.

bears all the tell-tale signs of a movie that's been put through the wringer: voice-over narration to cover choppy continuity; scenes that end abruptly; an end credit sequence containing scenes that didn't survive the final cut.
Director [Chanya] Button has a terrific eye and a witty sense of knowing observation, but seems to struggle against the over-written nature of this screenplay.

That it builds to the writing and publication of Woolf's landmark novel Orlando, whose title character Sackville-West inspired, only makes one wish to be watching Sally Potter's 1992 adaptation of Orlando (starring Tilda Swinton) instead.

Vita and Virginia also affords us the chance to watch smart women banter, philosophize, argue, and aggressively pursue their own desires, leaving the men to play the supportive worrying spouse for a change.
Sincere performances from Gemma Arterton and Elizabeth Debicki help.
It's ... a shame that Eileen Atkins and director Chanya Button's screenplay seems uncertain as to how to frame this tale...
The makers of this biographical romance clearly adore Virginia Woolf and want viewers to engage with her personality, sexuality and lightning-bright words.
an articulate and complex character study
"Vita & Virginia" is ambitious but imperfect. It takes an interesting tale of queer literary history and teases out the spirit of the women's relationship, but not its heart.

Vita & Virginia is disappointing mostly because it takes one of the most beloved, influential, and strange lesbian relationships of the 20th century and makes it into something basically ordinary, a mannered clich√©.
The film, despite director and co-writer Chanya Button's cinematic flourishes, such as repeated close-ups of Vita's sensual mouth, never really detaches itself from its theatrical roots.
"Vita & Virginia" takes a passionate, real-life affair between two enormously gifted writers and proceeds to throttle the life out of it.
Without Debicki, this wouldn't have worked, and it's with much gratitude that I write that her presence made all the difference for me.
[T]here is the feeling that there is still not enough drama in the story, as well-acted as it is.

The two writers narrowly skirt scandal, unlocking each other's potential to scale new professional heights. But the film seems to skirt along with them, hanging on every word like a groupie too overawed to interject.
The legendary literary lesbian romance, starring the incendiary duo of Gemma Arterton and Elizabeth Debicki, is criminally blah, lacking all sexual and intellectual passion. How does this happen?
Quite irritating...not entirely successful, but it does have things in it that work, not least the performances.
Vita and Victoria could have been a wonderful addition to feminist literary film. But it's just so disappointing.
The movie's editing undermines both lead performances. Scenes end abruptly, or seem set up for a moment that never arrives.
It's not a pretty picture, but it's a true one, ad same-sex couples who've "been there" are sure to be thankful for Vita and Virgina as much as the Bloomsbury adepts who'll be certain to flock to it.
Flawed but fascinating and fresh way to approach Woolf and Bloomsbury, benefiting from an alluring turn by Gemma Arterton as Vita Sackville-West.
Jaw-droppingly stupid.
A mountain of self-love, revealing stunt biker Knievel as a saintly combination of Batman and Billy Graham.
Evel the actor emerges from the wreck in better shape than the bent careers of his veteran co-stars, Gene Kelly, Marjoe Gortner, Red Buttons, Lauren Hutton and Leslie Nielsen.
This amazingly kitsch one-off stars the man himself, a non-actor if ever there was one, in a movie so absurd it simply has to be seen to be believed.
If you're into a giggle Viva Knievel! may appall but I don't think will bore you.
Voice from the Stone wants to pay homage to the great gothic horror films and stories that came before it, but you'd probably be better off just watching and reading them instead.
With a solid performance from young Dring as well, Voice From The Stone is an accomplished piece of work.
Emilia Clarke's Voice from the Stone is buried in a rich Edgar Allan Poe soil, but it still makes for a shallow grave.
'Voice from the Stone' offers suspense. Though some parts fail to make good sense, gothic romance and mystery add much to this film's strange beauty.
... strives to use all the classic tricks of a horror movie... [Full review in Spanish]
Something like 20 minutes of action is spread out across the 90-minute running time, and the thing feels sluggish even when something is going on.
an eerie and uncanny mystery, engraved upon evocative locations, some subtle sound design, and Clarke's endlessly expressive eyebrows.
Clarke's thoughtful performance makes this an easy watch, even if the plot is often tiresome.
...a film that is poetic and subtle, a slow-burn, perhaps too slow at points, that culminates in a difficult, yet compelling ending.
The film suffers from pacing problems and an unfortunate usage of its female lead.
Fans of haunted-house movies may be disappointed. But anyone who knows the depth of grief ... will feel the chills that this movie delivers deep in their bones.
In none of its manifestations is grief as tidy and meticulously arranged as in Eric D. Howell's film.
An old-fashioned Gothic mood piece whose craftsmanship holds one's attention, but proves disappointing in the end.
a late extension of high gothic, complete with atmospheric castle setting, ghostly presences, and a young visiting governess who could come straight from Henry James' The Turn of the Screw (1898)
Emilia Clarke gives a solid performance in this beautifully-crafted romantic horror film.
Voice from the Stone is a strange, slow-burning supernatural thriller.
The story instead of keeping us on the edge of the seat makes us yawn or, at best, laugh. [Full Review in Spanish]
The film suffers from pacing problems and an unfortunate usage of its female lead.
A ghost story without a pulse or a perceptible purpose, "Voice From the Stone" strands its cast, led by "Game of Thrones" star Emilia Clarke, in an airless series of darkly lovely tableaux.
There's little substance beneath the atmospheric surface of this slow-burning thriller.
With Danny Way almost never weighing in directly, the film's attempts to portray his story as an inspirational tale of triumph over adversity scarcely registers.

Director Jacob Rosenberg interviews Way and many of his friends, relations and peers, but he never digs too deeply or draws out of them much more than the clich√©d "this is what he was born to do" talking points.
While providing a fantastically visual diversion for aspiring skateboarders, this documentary lacks any personal insight into or commentary about legendary Danny Way.
The construction is more like a TV reality show than a work of journalism or personal exploration; it's meant to keep you tuned in without actually revealing anything.
It's quite astounding to see Way taking huge spills at some of his jumps only to get back on his board and try again.

Rosenberg's approach is heavy with archival footage and interviews, yet oddly features almost nothing from Way himself; his puzzling absence for most of the film turns the project into less of a biography than a one-note hagiography.
It's not many Americans whose names are engraved on the Great Wall of China. Daredevil Danny May certainly deserves the honor. Get stoked.
Little more than an extended piece of lifestyle merchandising, a long montage for monitors in sporting-goods shops.
A kind of "Behind the Music" for the skateboard set (only without much input from the main songwriter, as it were).
Even without its central subject actually weighing in, this likeably scruffy documentary tells you a lot about the impetus behind shredding and being gnarly.
A slickly produced, unabashedly celebratory pic about professional skateboarder Danny Way.
Waiting for Lightning is a true underdog story that will make anyone feel invincible, even for just 90 minutes.
IIf it's a god on a skateboard you want, a god on a skateboard you'll get in this hagiography ...
Pretty boilerplate doc material.
The line between fearlessness and idiocy can be a thin one, especially in this sport, and the doc never gets too far under Way's skin.
Colorful folks and cool stunts abound, but casual viewers may still utter a big "Why?"
Another descendant of Stacy Peralta's influential Dogtown and Z-Boys, but more stylish and engaging than most of its less inquisitive, like-minded, hagiographic stunt spectaculars.
It's enjoyable enough, but how much you like it will depend on how much you like skateboarding and extreme sports.
Only for the converted.
The person we want most to hear from, Way himself, is largely missing. Go figure.
Charming performances and easygoing humour are the strengths of Jones's enjoyable Oirish romp.
If this film doesn't make you want to smile, you've no one to blame but yourself.
A slight, sleep-inducing "comedy" that plods so deliberately from gag to alleged gag that nothing comes as a surprise.
Perfectly competent new Irish working-class comedy.
The story does not delve deeply into the corrupting influences of wealth, but then, it is a comedy, not a tragedy.
A good-spirited film, it features lovely pictures of the Irish coastline and countryside.
Whimsical, mischievous.
You'll love Waking Ned Devine.
The film is as cute and enjoyable as it sounds.
Now tell me, how many films have you seen lately that can get away with such a corny but happy ending and still be critically well-thought of?
The beauty of this film is its simplicity. It's good old-fashioned story-telling, following the increasingly desperate attempts of a group of lovable rogues to fill their pockets.
It's worth seeing. Parts of it are truly moving, and one wildly comic moment with Michael on a motorbike will not be soon forgotten.
A rollicking and playful comedy that encourages us to catch joy as it flies.
One of the better cookie cutter British imports.
A lyrical tale as sweet, simple and refreshing as a summer shower.
A pleasure.
A riot of a film that's also very sweet, focusing on community
Breezy little comedy.
Like the hit movie The Full Monty, this British import has its funny shots of naked men.
Jones' knack for precision timing and comedic flair enables him to stretch his simple premise into a sharp, concise film.
Stone is never content to just make one movie; he always makes several, then squeezes them all together into one engorged package.
[Oliver] Stone uses a lot of visual effects to give some energy to a very conventional story...
The film has more moving parts than a pricey Rolex, and they are not all in sync.
... it's Douglas who makes Stone's sequel worth a watch ...
People should care as much about Gordon Gekko's family life as they should about Hannibal Lecter's favorite vacation spots.

Stone's surprisingly vital revisit to his hit 1987 movie only really falters right at the end, when it appears to succumb more to old Hollywood conventions than to Wall Street's. But like the key characters in the film it still leaves us wanting more.
Often, the film feels more like a lecture than a narrative-- the one thing that makes a lecture useful: actual information.
Money Never Sleeps never fails to entertain, yet there's an undercurrent of desperation inherent in the idea of even making this film.
Stone assembles a competent, affectionate homage to the 1987 incarnation.
A swift and engaging financial thriller (is that a thing?) that addresses matters of morality without too much moralizing.
After his attempts to branch out slightly with World Trade Center and W., Money Never Sleeps finds Stone at ease in a way he hasn't been in years.

The kind of pointed critique of the American financial system this film might have made ends up without teeth, while the troubled personal relationships at its core are steered, without reason, towards an inexplicably treacly Hollywood ending.
It gleams and glistens but it has no substance. It is, in the end, a missed opportunity.
Gekko has lost a step or two in the 23-year span between the original and now. He's still an untrustworthy slime ball, but one that is too predictable.
Good thing for Stone that Michael Douglas slips so easily into his hair gel and Armani suit as Gordon Gekko and manages to make this warmed-over soap opera bearably entertaining.
There's lots of talk and very little true wisdom which, come to think of it, is also a defining characteristic of the overinflated bubble world the movie is so desperately trying to puncture.
This being Oliver Stone's long-gestating, self-important sequel to Wall Street, Jake will be learning some harsh life lessons.
There is nostalgia value in revisiting the character but, unfortunately, the picture plays like a faint echo of the original, inferior in every way. Greed just ain't good anymore.
Neither knowledgeable nor intelligent about the financial mess it tries to describe, it's still entertaining because of the individual performances of Douglas, Brolin, and Culligan.
Money Never Sleeps is never boring, even as its plot descends into cheap melodrama and the script runs out of banter about the "the NINJA generation -- no income, no job, no assets."
Together, Wayne and Douglas are adept at keeping the dialog light and the action fast.
Lame, late-in-the-day Wayne actioner.
The War Wagon is that comparative rarity, a Western filmed with quiet good humor. It is also a point of departure for John Wayne, who plays a bad guy for just about the first time in his career.
It's not a bad picture, just obvious.
No masterpiece, but very engaging.

John Wayne (in his 162nd film) joins forces with Kirk Douglas in this revenge Western that propagates rather dangerously vigilante justice, a theme Clint Eastwood will carry to an extreme in the Dirty Harry pictures.
The War Wagon is an entertaining, exciting western drama of revenge, laced with action and humor.

Handled with care, allowing plenty of room to explore western traditions and allow the leading men an opportunity to trade barbs and suspicions as they attempt to out barrel-chest each other (spoiler: Douglas wins).
Surprisingly appetizing and funny...for a movie that harangues us for throwing out edible food.
Anthony Bourdain stars as narrator of this wake-up call: some forty percent of food that Americans buy is sent to landfills, contributing to a toxic environment.
Inverts the usual eco-doc formula, spending only enough time on problems to establish their importance, then traveling around the world to prove how satisfying the solutions can be.
Taking a lively approach to an increasingly serious 21st century issue, the skillfully assembled documentary "Wasted! The Story of Food Waste" proves as eye-opening as it is mouth-watering.
It's a sermonizing work as entertaining as it is informative.

Wasted! is sure to be mind-expanding for anyone who's never contemplated what happens when excess food is scraped off one's plate. But the film's real novelty lies in the demonstration of actual solutions that have already been put into practice.
As with many recent environmental documentaries, the filmmakers' call to action is simple and upbeat: This isn't so hard, people, we can do it if we try!
"Wasted! The Story of Food Waste" is ... darned entertaining and hopeful, as well as informative.
As this movie clearly illustrates, people need to pay attention.

This "fictional" look at Philippines President Rodrigo Duterte's "War on Drugs" is a searing indictment of how the innocent get swept up in unbelievable tragedies, copious deaths, and no end in sight to the real problem.
Not your typical drug film as it is filled with unique moments and some heartbreak.
A bleak, riveting thriller
A horror that deserves worldwide attention - even though the world has got a lot to attend to at present.
Overall a brave and gripping drama addressing how Duterte's war on drugs is an ineffective and inhumane conflict that targets small-time players in poor communities.
It has a sturdy, vivid construction, and is a convincing demonstration of the venality that's central to the thinking of hardly squeaky-clean antidrug zealots.
A difficult film to experience, powered by a rising tide of injustice.
[Ben] Rehki's tightly economical direction has something of the efficiency and immediacy of a Warner Brothers cautionary gangster picture from the '30s.
Watch List is at times a little too faithful to the conventions of Filipino screen melodrama. Nevertheless, it's well-directed [and] has a commanding performance from de Rossi...
A powerful drama which brings the claustrophobic suffocation of the slums to life.
Watch List shows the cost of this government's "war" ... with chilling authenticity.
Paired with a fittingly measured pace and a trepidatious atmosphere, Watch List is an immensely somber and modestly urgent thriller that won't make for a pleasant experience.
A strikingly realistic film about the hell that President Duterte is visiting on his people with a best actress of the year performance by Alessandra De Rossi.
We Are the Best! is the rare film about childhood friendship that seems to take place inside the world of children, not filtered through an adult scrim of nostalgia.

It's the details of the journey that matter in this good-natured film. Bobo, Klara, and Hedwig's story of Sweden's finest teenage girl punk band will feel universal to everyone who has ever set out to prove that punk won't die on their watch.
Lukas Moodysson scores a crowd-pleaser after a few years in the wilderness with this return to the tender, bittersweet nostalgia of the rep-making Together.
What we have here is an exhilarating blast of a movie, full of heart but still punk rock... We Are the Best! is loud, crude, socially irresponsible and totally irresistible.
A coming of age frolic with lessons for all ages.
Extracting naturalistic performances from all his young stars, Moodysson seems to revel in these spirited characters. And you should too. It's a delight from start to finish.

Swedish filmmaker Lukas Moodysson returns to the improv-style charms of his earlier films (like Together and Show Me Love), a welcome break from his more recent grim experimental dramas (see Mammoth or Lilya 4-ever).
The three girls are full of life. They have a lot of fun just being kids. They are excited about their potential and their possibilities. This movie is a tribute to the spirit and optimism of youth.
But this is not a movie about kids learning the value of intense practice and dedication. Instead, it's a movie about the major and minor tumults of growing up.
A classic coming-of-age story that embraces the messiness and stubbornness of adolescence, delivering a drama that is alive with attitude, humor and heart.
An unexpected charmer about friendship, identity and the liberating power of making a racket.
Despite the unruly music at its center, the filmmaker has crafted a uniformly gentle ode to growing up.
Moodysson's film is hard to dislike, and while it puts more emphasis on the light in light-hearted, We Are The Best! is time well spent.
Audiences can be pleased to find a story in which its young female characters aren't victims, or even pretty little liars, but just friends. And good ones, at that.
Lukas Moodysson's film allows its trio of girls to express themselves through gender, certainly, but not undermine their desire to be heard as artists first.
Impeccably, nay astonishingly, performed by Mira Barkhammar, Mira Grosin and Liv LeMoyne, the film sweeps us into their world
The performances of all three young actors are superb, soulful, honest and full of joy. Their dialogue is often ridiculously funny and there's no sense of manufactured drama.
The great charm of Lukas Moodysson's We Are the Best! lies in its total lack of pretension and adult editorializing.

Expertly combining a youthful desire for agency and rebellion with the death throes of the Swedish punk movement, it's a heart-warming tale with three captivating performances from its young female leads.
Warm, joyous, and excellent, Lukas Moodysson's We Are the Best! is an honest and refreshing celebration of young girls' friendship, with a few playful punk punches thrown in.
Though skeptical, the film isn't at all mean-spirited.
The usually great Piccoli-saddled with a ridiculously contrived failed-actor backstory-comes off like an unholy mix of Grard Depardieu and Robin Williams at their sad-puppiest.

Moretti here mostly meanders agreeably but toothlessly, parting the veils of ecclesiastical pomp and bureaucracy and finding nothing more subversive than a rejected thespian suffering from an extreme case of stage fright.
What appears to be an amusing tale of a leader who has lost his way is also an unapologetic challenge to faith itself.
There are only so many yuks Moretti can milk from the sight of old men in clerical robes.
A premise in search of a thesis, a handful of scenes in search of a story.
Vatican-based comedy could have been sharper
There is hardly a single credible character other than the Pope, and... not a single situation that isn't cheerfully forced for maximum sweetness.
A meditation on the guilt, regret and shame that come with age and acquired wisdom as a pillorying of orthodox hypocrisy.
Whenever it stays with Piccoli ... it's mysterious and moving, struck by the humility of a man who's not up to playing God.
Uncertainty is the essence of this unusual tale that is a curious melee of serious drama tinged with some unexpected comical elements
It's an amusing feature but also emotionally resonant and expertly performed.
[Nanni] Moretti pushes on to tell his story thoughtfully, with humor and deep humanity.
It's a half-sweet, half-rueful existential drama in which the satire comes secondary.
It's an uneven film, almost pleasingly vague in its conclusions yet also unsatisfying.

(Michel) Piccoli gives a wonderful performance and is truly the film's heart and soul. I was also most impressed by how much of the Church's rituals, traditions and clerical garb (writer-director Nanni) Moretti gets right.
There's a sweetness to Italian director Nanni Moretti's "We Have a Pope" that belies its seemingly unholy premise...
A mildly amusing political satire from Moretti, which is relevant but not witty or ferocious enough.
Such slapstick actually works, reminding us that the clergy are people, too, and the Vatican runs on electricity instead of a higher power.

The film has a suitably dramatic ending but that comes rather too late in the proceedings after Moretti, ever an actor who likes the limelight, has turned his film into something too lightweight to get to grips with its central dilemma.
Donald Petrie's movie is so over-laundered that it has completely sacrificed shape for comfort.
If ever a film was in need of an order of Levitra, it was Welcome To Mooseport, ranking amongst the limpest political satires I've ever seen
About as middle of the road as comedies get.
Mooseport is one of those dreaded middle-of-the-road comedies. It's a friendly, nicety-nice, mock-funny, play-it-safe and use-all-the-cliche's-we-got style deal. Yech.
"Could have used three or four more passes through the funny machine."
The outcome of the election is never in doubt in this fluff, and neither is the dramatic face-off.
This lackluster production fails to generate much in the way of tension and less in the way of merriment.
Clunkily earthbound as its characters and the situations plod forward while never getting anywhere.
Hackman wins in a landslide in the otherwise mediocre Mooseport
Unless you're a real Romano fan, take the bypass.
If the script never rises above the sitcom level, at least the lines are delivered by people who are so good they almost seem like wit.
It plays like six subplots in search of a sitcom.
"White House meets outhouse" comedy isn't fit to serve, and Marcia Gay Harden and Maura Tierney outshine stars Gene Hackman and Ray Romano.
Gets old faster than uncovered cheese.
A movie marred by a flaccid script, listless pacing, a plethora of cutesy-poo gags and Ray Romano.
A comfortable movie.
Delivers on a fundamental and familiar level, so that those of a certain age and inclination will be charmed.
Offers a charming distraction from the current campaign season by sidestepping real issues and making light of the process.

Welcome to Mooseport is the movie equivalent of a bowl of unadorned oatmeal: It's bland, a bit lumpy and, though it'll tide you over until something better comes along, you won't look back fondly on the experience.
An ocean of blown opportunities.
Confident and very funny, We'll Never Have Paris paints a perfect example of why relationships are never black and white.
Uninspired romcom has some racy scenes, drinking, language.
A film that neglects the basic requirement that an audience not thoroughly hate its protagonist.
This derivative comedy, in addition to not being particularly funny, gives off a sense of telling us more than we needed to know.
The nebbishness is spot on, but it lacks vintage Woody Allen's charm and humour.
Although Quinn may strike some viewers as more annoying narcissist than self-deprecating charmer, he's a vivid creation.
Simon Helberg's cringe-inducing (non)romantic comedy crudely force-feeds its characters on time-honoured flaws, only to watch on hopefully as the audience eventually gives in to its absurdity.
a sporadically amusing minor league comedy retread.
I highly recommend it for its superb cast, brilliantly told story and charming lead.
This film requires so many leaps of faith and suspensions of disbelief that you might develop acrophobia.
Too often the flat-lining jokes and botched attempts at emotional sincerity merely enhance the character's pathological nature instead of offsetting it.
This lacklustre romantic comedy seems a little like a lost episode in the life of Helberg's Big Bang Theory character, Howard Wolowitz.
"We'll Never Have Paris" won't be setting any box office records, but it's an enjoyable effort, with an impressive cast.
A charmless venture from husband and wife Simon Helberg and Jocelyn Towne.
[A] Woody Allen-lite comedy ...
A fantastically clever script with fun performances from the entire cast, especially leads Simon Helberg, Melanie Lynskey and Maggie Grace.
We'll Never Have Paris, a nimble and tangy comedy, sails through most of its fleet runtime without a hitch, only to lose its nerve, slightly, in its final moments.
Lynskey's performance is sympathetic, but the movie doesn't fully convince us in its dramatization of her responses to Quinn's large and small blunders.
The danger in writing, directing, producing and casting yourself in the same movie is that there's no one to pull you back from the cliff.
Throughout, Helberg's awkward-anxious routine proves insufferable ...
The bottom of the barrel of disaster movies
A fun, sometimes cheesy descent into apocalyptic nonsense.
When Worlds Collide is sincere, but doesn't take itself too seriously.
Dated but enjoyable end of the world flick
Totally outdated by now . . .
Mr. Pal barely gets us out there, but this time he doesn't bring us back.

Never mind plot logic, don't think too hard about the 'sci' component of the sci-fi, and certainly keep the unsubtle sociology and Pal's typical Bible-based gloss in perspective. When Worlds Collide remains entertaining and satisfying....
This probably looks about as stodgy now as it did back then.
Top honors for this inter-planetary fantasy rest with the cameramen and special effects technicians rather than with performances of the non-name cast.
Cinema's most neurasthenic version of the apocalypse
Best appreciated for its apocalyptic special effects.
Too bad the finale plays like a greeting card you wish someone had just given you the money for instead.
When Worlds Collide continues the current rage for science fiction movies and it is one of our better ones.
You have to admire any film that casts Clint Eastwood opposite Richard Burton; the real violence is in the clash of acting styles.
Non-stop action of the highest quality.
Old-fashioned thrills, spills and escapes, making this something of a classic.
Clint Eastwood and Richard Burton team up for a fairly high-flying adventure.

It is so long (almost three hours) that it may finally bore the very action trade for which it was intended; yet it's just at that point of surface boredom that the movie aficionado will probably become entranced.

Alistair MacLean wrote an original screenplay that was treated with respect for the writer's unusual abilities as a master of actionful suspense. The resulting film is highly entertaining, thrilling and rarely lets down for a moment.
If it's a mindless roller-coaster thrill ride that you fancy, this is the vehicle that knows how to make it a fun ride.
A straight-ahead, old-school action movie for war-espionage junkies. [Blu-ray]
...it provides full-on thrills, maybe exaggerated thrills, to be sure, but making for an exciting ride, nonetheless.
That I was able to enjoy this movie as much as I did, despite the plethora of plot holes, says something for it.
Hilarious and exciting, often at the same time.
As with Kelly's Heroes, Where Eagles Dare pulls itself together best in its third act

This is not a picture for sensible souls and rational minds, or for those who relish their peace and quiet. It is for children of all ages who enjoy oohing and aahing and baiting their breath and screaming and closing their eyes (but peeking through).
A classic of its time, this riveting WWII drama is rife with great action sequences (the cable car!) and shock twists pulled out of thin air. Three escapist hours very well spent.
For grown-ups, Jonze's exploration of Max's imaginary world is a wonder.

The real beauty of Where The Wild Things Are comes with its simplicity. With only minimal plot to work with, Jonze instead makes this a weird, funky mood piece, finding an odd but highly effective rhythm on which the film joyously floats.
Imagination is the real star of Sendak's classic and Jonze and his co-writer, Dave Eggers, have expanded on its brief text to spin a story in which the tough and the tender smoothly coalesce.
Some very good books were just never meant to be turned into movies. Sadly, you can now add Maurice Sendak's 1963 classic Where the Wild Things Are to that list.
Gene Siskel Once Said Non-Human Character Work or Don't Work Based on Their Eyes and There's a Lot Going On Behind Them Here.
The - I give this children's story pains me...If I had seen this film when I was eight, I would have been terrified.
This blend of the real and unreal is successful because Jonze's feeling for childhood binds everything together.
It has its problems to be sure, but then again so does Max... and like Max, it learns to makes peace with them before time runs out.
The effects are spot-on, little Max Records is ace as the story's boisterous nine-year-old hero while the film mostly avoids the treacle that mars so many kids' pics.
A haunting, innovative, and poignant film about childhood that may have you howling with the Wild Things inside and around you.
What I love about the film is that director Spike Jonze and co-writer Dave Eggers, as well as producer Sendak, have made a film for themselves.
On a purely surface level, even the expanded story feels like the book.
See it, but only once.
I truly hope I never turn into the kind of person who isn't able to enjoy a movie like this.

The advantage of adapting Maurice Sendak's slim tome is that there is plenty of scope for interpretation; however, for the first time in his career, Jonze comes up short in the imagination department.
What would have been perfection at one hour is still a bravely different Christmas movie, one destined to be a cult classic for generations to come.
You never completely lose their feeling for the little guy, but by the end you feel a bit like Max's mom. Once you know he's safe, you're more than ready to drift into deep sleep.
It's as honest a tale of being a child as you'll find on screen...

Unnecessarily gloomy and emotionally convoluted, Spike Jonze and Dave Eggers' script for Where the Wild Things Are is a melancholy adaptation of the one-two punch that is the heavily illustrated, scantly written book by Maurice Sendak.

This is not a coming-of-age film. It's an end-of-innocence film. And that makes every moment, be it funny or sad, so beautiful and so heartbreaking at the same time. You'll want to hug it and hold onto it, as if it were your childhood sailing away.
Writer-director Damien Chazelle has created a masterpiece, aided by superb acting by J.K. Simmons and Miles Teller.
The movie is bursting with grand jazz sets, some classic, some not. All of them pure pleasure, especially if you love jazz.
Think of Simmons' verbal tirades as extended riffs, virtuoso variations on the theme of trial by ordeal.

Whiplash rises on the strengths of a brilliant, Oscar-winning performance from J.K. Simmons and a great soundtrack to complement it, turning what could have been a rather bland story of a determined drummer into something a little more memorable.
Fletcher's contention - and, by extension, that of the film - isn't the most defensible, but the fact that Chazelle is willing to make it at all certainly requires chutzpah.

You have to take Whiplash's tunnel vision for what it's worth, the idea that there's only one sort of perfection, only one school worth attending...This kind of acting is to acting what a drum solo is to music.
Dead Poets Society for sociopaths.
The movie is a sleek machine. It's viscerally thrilling, and distressingly hollow.
Exhilarating and awful, Whiplash raises tough questions about ambition, sacrifice and what it takes to turn raw talent into legend.
Compelling drama about relentless pursuit of perfection.
This is about how we push ourselves, how others push us, and if any of that ends up mattering at all.
It may get a few things wrong, but it aims at, and finally achieves, an authenticity at once more exalted and more primal than mere verisimilitude.

For all its overripe contrivance, you'll leave the cinema with a spring in your step and a thump in your chest, eager to bang the drum for what deserves to be one of the year's real word-of-mouth hits.
A gorgeous ode to drumming, as art, as mastery and invention, as utterly thrilling experience.
Simmons is daunting and extraordinary from the moment Chazelle introduces the black-clad monster, but it is Teller, a former drummer, who carries the film.
... intoxicating movie. [Full review in Spanish]
A spellbinding make-or-break movie aimed at those who have ever wanted to be good at something. At anything. It's one of the year's best films.

Frankly, I would urge viewers to see this film, if for no other reason, than for the final scene. It's the kind of scene that involuntarily quickens your heart, makes your jaw fall open, and catches your breath.

An extremely confident, stylish, brash and superbly crafted melodrama that manages, in its contained story, to examine ambition, elitism, bullying, musicianship, scholarship and many other underlying themes. It is taut, rigorous and menacing.
This is as much psychological thriller as musical drama and it turns on the increasingly toxic chemistry between two clearly damaged people, to the exclusion of pretty much anyone else in the film.
It's a fine example of the way Preminger, on occasion, managed to deflect routine melodrama into something more personal and profound.

There is no doubt that people will do strange things under hypnotic spell and that the techniques of hypnotism may be villainously employed. But you don't catch this fairly rational corner believing for one minute the hocuspocus that goes on.
Preminger's ambiguous relation to his characters and his sense of moral relativity have seldom been put to such haunting use.
Directed with a healthy feel for his twisted characters by Otto Preminger.
Very wry, very Viennese satire of psychoanalysis as bourgeois fad
...a sporadically trashy, thoroughly absurd murder mystery.
Ferrer is wonderfully sleazy as Korvo and makes the perfect foil for Tierney.
Whirlpool's stand-out scene, in which a somnambulant Gene Tierney incriminates herself ... uses the conventions of horror cinema as much as that of noir.
Jose Ferrer's insolent finesse turns a conventional melodrama into a fascinating; one-man show.
A film that keeps me hooked for an hour and a half by combining police film noir and psychological thriller with a twisted plot about hypnotism, blackmail and murder. [Full review in Spanish]
Makes Lassie Come Home look like a stroll through Pet Smart.
Imagine an "R" rated Lassie by way of Spartacus. That's Korn√©l Mundrucz√≥'s White God, a brutal but stirring fantasy about street dogs rising up against cruel and indifferent humans.
...cheekily comments on how we often hide behind civilized culture to mask our basest natures.
White God isn't for everyone. But it is an unflinching, extraordinary piece of film-making.
A poignant Hungarian parable about the terrible things that can happen when there is no reverence for dogs as fellow companions.

Mundrucz√≥ skillfully weaves adventure, coming-of-age, prison-escape and revenge-thriller tropes into a mythic, emotional and visceral experience that poses moral questions about how people treat animals and how people treat people.
White God is something bold and experimental. Beautiful and brutal, and even with its shortcomings and derivative leanings, it's a unique experience.
Milo and Otis by way of The Birds by way of I Spit On Your Grave.
Korn√©l Mundrucz√≥ knows not of subtlety. The Hungarian director's brash new feature White God is over the top in all kinds of ways, for better and worse.
A broad but often poignant allegory of oppression, it's like the beautiful puppy of Au Hasard Balthazar and The Plague Dogs.
The obviousness of the message -- follow the right leader -- would be more tolerable in a less badly acted, less shoddy-looking film.
The screen teems with vitality and energy whenever the dogs return to center stage.
The climax is lovely, Psotta is a beautifully persuasive, serious young heroine and the dogs are magnificent.
As a dark, Eastern European take on "Benji the Hunted," "White God" holds some fascination. But as an indictment of the evil that men do, it's all bark and no bite.
By turns Dickensian, Marxist and dystopian, it's a movie as deliriously unclassifiable as it is expertly focused in its desire to provoke and entertain.
A startling, strange, and disturbing tale of dogs and men
Mundrucz√≥'s focus is clearly going to the admittedly impressive execution, but White God lacks the narrative weight to leave an impact.

White God's attempts to merge arthouse sensibilities with B-movie fun tends to be hit or miss, but while Mundruczo may falter on the arthouse side, he certainly knows how to make an entertaining genre film.
This gripping suspense story considers how any canine can become the unfortunate repository for its master's darkest impulses.
Even those who don't buy in completely to Mundruczo's parable will be impressed by his canine crowd scenes, staged with ambition, skill and genuinely original vision.
With minimal conspiratorial bluster, Berlinger unmasks the compliant faces of evil.
It's a complex case and Berlinger isn't always successful in keeping the story clear.
It's a compelling story. Trouble is, it isn't a terribly visual story, and this documentary doesn't serve it nearly as well as a book or lengthy article would.
The journalism is comprehensive, the scope admirably large. Those who can keep up will learn plenty about how a major, high-profile case proceeds.
Soberly shifts emphasis to collateral damage and police corruption even as colorful characters with rich Boston accents and their crimes almost overwhelm the larger story.
By the end of the film, it can't help but read as another of Bulger's self-mythologizing claims that once made him a false Robin Hood for Southie.
Joe Berlinger covers all the angles quite well in Whitey: United States of America v. James J. Bulger, a straight-forward court case documentary.

A thematic companion to Berlinger's 'Paradise Lost' trilogy, 'Whitey' is less a portrait of the 'hands-on killer who ran amok in the city of Boston for almost 30 years' than an expose of the misdeeds of law enforcement...
Berlinger needs to give his heavy-metal backdrop music a rest, but this is still one of his most ambitious films, vibrating with the same municipal unease as Chinatown.
An informative yet unfocused study of murder and corruption...'Whitey' never quite coheres or fully expresses what exactly it wants to illuminate about any of these subjects.
Joe Berlinger's densely detailed new documentary about the legendary Boston mobster is disturbing on so many levels it's hard not to wonder why Bulger was the only one on trial.
Bulger himself doesn't appear, of course; at age 84, he's currently serving two consecutive life terms, + five years. Somehow, it just doesn't seem long enough.
"Whitey: United States of America v. James J. Bulger" takes all of our accumulated experience of places like "Southie" and makes it real. Terrifyingly, frustratingly real.

...what makes Joe Berlinger's riveting new true crime doc Whitey such an eye-opener is that it isn't just about a bad guy who did bad things, but the layers of corruption and moral ambiguity that stacked up on both side of the law.
[A] fascinating, expertly crafted film ...
Berlinger may be our premier true-crime documentarian (though he has many other arrows in his quiver)...a crisp (if dense) examination of a shameful and tragic story.
Taking one of the most notorious criminals in US history, Berlinger makes a truly compelling argument against the status quo when it comes to Bulger's sordid past.
It's a fascinating, and troubling, two hours.
Within the confines of an under-two-hours running time ... Berlinger does an impressive job of keeping the film coherent and often fascinating.
Even for those familiar with Bulger's story, Berlinger offers some new angles amid his thorough yet straightforward approach.
Devastatingly tragic.
Faraldo's most engrossing and inventive script, alternately serious and comic, is beautifully realized by Binoche, Auteuil and Kusturica.

Protagonizando uma histria emocionalmente complexa, Binoche, Auteuil e Kusturica conferem peso dramtico aos seus personagens, apesar da direo distante de Leconte impedir que o espectador se envolva intensamente com a trama.
Patrice Leconte offers a profound study of sincerity and hypocrisy.
Sad and beautiful.
Binoche gets a chance to demonstrate her on-screen radiance with subtlety and amplitude.
Hypnotic and haunting -- that rare period piece that resonates with provocative life.
Like all the French heritage pictures, this one looks terrific.
The Widow of Saint Pierre is a visually attractive, well-acted tale.
Rendered with impeccable beauty and dramatic precision.
A great cinema original, brilliantly directed and written ... and acted to perfection.
When it comes right down to it, Leconte understands that Binoche's face tells all the story we need.
Saved from failure by its stars' strong performances.
Leconte again manages to be one of the filmmakers of any nationality who can create convincing romantic attachments.
Leconte lets The Widow of St. Pierre resonate in ways that transcend its black-and-white scenario.
A dignified and subtle drama.
The story takes emotionally-hooking twists.
Rides a romantic spirit that would have fit splendidly in a classic Hollywood production.
Leconte creates a seductive other world, a screen rarity indeed.
A compelling French Canadian drama.
Writer/director Daniel MacIvor does a wonderful job of establishing this small town...
Mediocre.
Wilby Wonderful is pleasant enough storytelling with a handful of truly brilliant scenes.
Wilby Wonderful tries to be audience-friendly without pandering.
About as Canadian as Canadian movies get. And no, that's not a good thing.
Despite its hipster-coffeehouse soundtrack, foul mouth, randy characters, and violent patches, Wilby is wholesome and ultimately remarkable for its optimism.
A fine ensemble cast and a low-key approach that's both charming and a little dull.
Bergman's dual journey of remembrances and reveries
It's a personal and profound work.
Don't let pretentious film snobs scare you off from Wild Strawberries
One of Ingmar Bergman's many masterpieces, this universal meditation on the meaning of life is extremely well-acted by Victor Sjostrom (also known as director) as ther aging professor.

With unyielding moral precision no less austere for the lack of any religious conviction behind it, Bergman subjects his protagonist to judgment for the crimes of indifference and selfishness, and pronounces a verdict of "the usual" sentence: loneliness.
...a touching look at old age and how memories from the past can affect us as mature beings.
Quite simply a must-see for the serious filmgoer, offering a perfect introduction to the work of one of the world's greatest directors.
An archetypal Ingmar Bergman film, and one of his best.
Several actors who were to form the director's virtual stock company are here, but it is Sjstrm who is heart and soul of the film.
Mr. Bergman, being a poet with the camera, gets some grand, open, sensitive images, but he has not conveyed full clarity in this film.

Poetic and richly elegant -- and sometimes playful (but don't tell anyone, because lots of people think of Bergman as stupefyingly serious).

[VIDEO ESSAY] "Wild Strawberries" is a thematically abundant film that fluidly condenses a lifetime's worth of experience into succinct cinematic fragments under Ingmar Bergman's complex construction of abstract corollaries.
A celebration of the power of actors to create rich personalities for us to spend time with.
A deeply moving film that extends beyond Bergman's experiences and speaks to the importance of emotional connections among human beings.
Brilliant.
My favorite Ingmar Bergman film, without question.

desperately unfunny
Wild Target gets its gears gunked up by a detour into the shallow, polluted waters of pseudo-psychological melodrama.
"Wild Target" has fast, quippy dialogue and exactly the right actors to drive it home.
A few tart, amusing lines echo the fabled Kind Hearts and Coronets, yet this British movie based on a French farce falls into morbid silliness.
Wild Target takes aim at various styles and genres and misses the mark every time.

...mindless entertainment in a refined style.

Director Jonathan Lynn already made one assassin comedy ... Consider this the lazy encore no one asked for.
With an interesting premise and a capable cast, it's a shame the result is such a dead horse.
Since irony is so often director Jonathan Lynn's weapon of choice, Wild Target should have been a good fit. It's not quite.

A mostly admirable attempt at a Crichton-like escapade that runs out of steam a bit before half-way.

an uneven, often aggressively unlikable tale of awkward folks making rotten decisions.

Wilson, the motormouthed misanthrope Woody Harrelson plays in this workmanlike adaptation of Daniel Clowes' graphic novel, is an acquired taste.
As far as I can see there is no reason to go to see this, just as there was no reason to make it or release it. It is violent, profane, and without any redeeming social or entertainment value.
One of those unheralded, unpretentious films that offers unpolished truths about human nature and the awkwardness that comes with honesty. Please don't let this small gem of a film slip by you.
Funny, touching and insightful. Woody Harrelson is in top comedic form in this tonally unique comedy with a lot on its mind.
Whatever magic might have existed on the printed page evaporates in a meandering, tone-deaf tale that trades in blunt eccentricity until it succumbs to sloppy sentiment.
I didn't want to hug it. But I can give it a nice pat on the back.
Wilson himself is meant to be likably unlikable, but spending 90 minutes with him proves to be mostly exhausting.
While it might please fans of Clowes' prose or for those on the festival circuit looking for a breather from something heavier, Wilson isn't a film that's likely to appeal to many.
The plot opts for cop-out sentimentality and begins to melt into goo.
Harrelson, who elevated sarcasm to a humanistic art form as the put-upon high school teacher in last year's The Edge of Seventeen, buries his heart under layers of antagonistic attitudes.
Wilson, the man, may serve up great work from Harrelson, but Wilson, the movie, soon proves that 94 minutes in the character's company are far too many.
It struggles to fill the big screen, either emotionally or visually, and after a while Harrelson's say-it-as-it-is persona becomes irritating.
Boosted by terrific leading performances from Harrelson and Dern, "Wilson" is fatigued quickly, working very hard to sell an atmosphere of illness that, while insistent, isn't all that compelling.
It is exactly the movie it wants to be, yet what it wants to be is so fundamentally wrong.
You'll want to spend time with "Wilson." Even if nobody else does.
If Wilson wasn't so appallingly annoying, he might be a sympathetic character. But he is, so he's not.

Conventional though the arc may be, Joe Swanberg's amiably rambling comedy finds itself away from the poker table, developing into a neat little dramedy along the way.
Win It All is another reminder that Jake Johnson and Joe Swanberg are a potent and dynamic filmmaking team that are willing to explore seldom seen complex characters in a refreshingly honest fashion.

"Win It All" might be Swanberg's most accessible film yet. The awkwardness and improvised feel often associated with mumblecore is passed over for a tone and dialogue style that's more polished, but no less impactful.
Win It All is a slow-burn dramedy set on undercutting the romanticized, disheveled losers of noir while still developing a charm of its own.
Joe Swanberg's Win It All understands addicts in a fashion that's unusual for American cinema.
The most convincing of the three features Joe Swanberg has made with star and co-writer Jake Johnson (each of which has represented a highlight in his filmography) ...
...a low-key character study that consistently benefits from Johnson's often spellbindingly accomplished performance...
Watch it for [Jake] Johnson's winning performance, and let his poker face distract you from the flaws.
Win It All is a largely enjoyable exercise in the concept of acting as reacting, as most of the film's plot (and humor) is driven by the ways people respond to Eddie and his predicament.

It's a dense character study that rests on the shoulders of Jake Johnson, who delivers his strongest performance to date, casually handling every scene with a magnetism that recalls the likes of '70s era De Niro and Caan.
Win It All is a chance to see a handful of great comic actors, Johnson chief among them, milk Swanberg's low-key narrative designs for all the comedy they're worth.
A smooth-edged comedy and an addiction drama fluent in the language of recovery.

Jake Johnson brings a type of charisma and serious humor that's no different than his past roles in New Girl and Drinking Buddies. His way of acting really helps to tell a very real story of a man on a downward spiral.
One film that defeats the mumblecore flaw of open-ended aimlessness.
Though Win It All plays like a series of vignettes, Swanberg has become both grounded and creatively expanded as a result of Johnson's repeated collaboration.
For the high stakes involved, Win It All feels strictly low stakes.
Swanberg has delivered his most traditional movie to date -- and for this prolific filmmaker, who spent ages defying conventions, that's nothing short of a radical step forward.
The balance between those two impulses - great human tragedy boiled into an almost Shakespearean comedy - is played with throughout and the result is nothing shy of delightful.
"Win It All" is an agreeable little gambling film in the vein of "Mississippi Grind" or "Rounders," but with an emphasis on characters rather than plot.
It achieves the same kind of thrills that the Final Destination films did, but it also feels just as, if not even more, thin and dumb as those movies. Just go see something else at the cinema.

A tedious dramady about an unappealing group of women in Los Angeles.

A sprightly, sexy, campy and outrageously funny ensemble comedy that's best watched with an open mind and a large audience for maximum enjoyment.

This exuberantly uninhibited indie has the anything-goes spirit of something tossed off in a single burst of collaborative energy.
In the "whatever were they thinking of" genre, a new entry: Women in Trouble.
This forced, charmless multi-character movie pretends to show women in all their glorious variety, but it really just traffics in the same old cliches.
Gutierrez's script can't supply female characters as believable as Almodovar's, but in the director's chair he gives his cast room to compensate with funny, self-aware performances.
The film has already reduced itself to an empty exercise in campy, color-bathed titillation, as a gaggle of women are defined by their sexual drives and abilities without comment from the filmmaker.
It's not pornography, but it evokes that same uneasy feeling that you're watching something that's so wrong but so right at the same time.
Unfortunately, while it is a great idea for a sketch, or a web series, it's not a movie length idea.

At a particularly rundown corner of Almodvar Boulevard and Tarantino Lane, you'll find Women in Trouble, a limp, forgettable collection of interlocking tales all centering on the eponymous narrative setup.
Penthouse Forum meets Pedro Almodvar in this frantic slice of trash-masquerading-as-class.

Too much of Women In Trouble settles for banal instances of infidelity, female bonding, or psychoanalysis when it needs to keep the action going. It's fine to be inconsequential, as long as the charged-up frivolity never stops.
Unlikely accidents, shared secrets and zany twists combine to whip up a pleasing froth.
A wonderful, magical movie.
Breezy and likable, and vigorously committed to being the best version it can be of the very offbeat and random thing it is.

Apocalypse certainly has its issues, but it is undeniably a fun and engaging comic book movie that is only second to X-Men: First Class in how well it actually brings the comic book X-Men world to the big screen.

Singer once brought an intimacy to the social political dimensions that often made the X-Men franchise the thinking man's superhero movie. Yet it is clear that the weight in the themes that come with ...Apocalypse has left Singer and his movie floundering.
For every lively moment, there's a reminder that the franchise is tiring. The genre's emphasis on potential mass death is obsessive and unimaginative.
Apocalypse is so desperate to get your attention it forgets to earn it.

Its ham-fisted, overemotional script, completely bereft of charm or ingenuity, its unremarkable villain and second-rate special effects make X-Men: Apocalypse the least successful of the recent Marvel entries.
Those who have seen the previous "X-Men" movies will likely feel motivated to keep their run complete, and over 2 hours and 23 minutes, they mostly get their money's worth.
Singer continues to bring things back to where he left them in "X2: X-Men United" while still fiddling around with the particulars, hungry to make the mutant world colossal once again.
Fiery, intense moments are undermined by a predictable plot.

Bryan Singer has made enough of these superhero things to know how to put them together, and for long periods balances competing story lines and the contradictory needs of action and drama reasonably well.

Despite appearing emotionally and thematically hollow compared to the overwrought subtexts of previous entries, Apocalypse has managed to incorporate weighty themes of outsiderdom in an uncharacteristically subtle manner.

Luca Puenzo's XXY is as finely crafted as a great work of literature.

There's a secret at the heart of XXY, but the real mystery is why writer-director Luca Puenzo insists on unnecessary symbolic gestures for a story otherwise told with delicacy, restraint, and maturity.
Traz um final em aberto que, ao invs de enriquecer a narrativa ao honrar sua complexidade, soa mais como uma incapacidade do prprio filme em encontrar algo relevante a dizer.
