A tale that could have been handled with condescending simplicity becomes a testament to the flawed but noble humanity of both parents and children.
The Argentine writer-director downplays the clinical angle and avoids easy melodramatic pitfalls.
Pic has more in common with standard child/parent conflict dramas than it would probably care to admit, but its sensitive treatment of an equally sensitive theme elevates it into something memorable.

What might be the greatest thing about XXY, however, is that it absolutely refuses to judge. More, Puenzo never feels obliged to bow to the clichs of the genre, instead allowing her picture to ebb and flow like all of this was happening for real.
Ricardo Darin... again proves that he can break your heart with a look, conveying unspoken emotion with a glance that taps you into his pain.
What ensues between them, both psychologically and sexually, is one of the strangest, most fascinating dysfunctional relationships I've seen in a movie. The acting is outstanding.
Fluid camera work filled with shots of window frames, mirrors, and reflections emphasizes the story's doubling, narrowness of view, and constant thinking about fixed ideas and viewpoints.
Despite its sometimes creepy tentativeness, XXY succeeds as a meditation on gender and sexuality, one that refuses an easy answer to the question, 'Is it a boy or a girl?'
A beautifully made, superbly acted drama that packs a powerfully emotional punch and delivers a passionate message about acceptance.
It takes a controlling hand to chisel something more contoured than monotony out of this dense angst, and director Luca Puenzo doesn't have it.

Yonkers Joe confirms that writer-director Robert Celestin knows his way around a local cash-stakes game of craps. It also proves, unfortunately, that his scripting skills need substantial honing.
Palminteri helps the film earn very slight passing marks, if only mostly because it's interesting to see these old operators have to adapt their schemes for new times.
It's far from a natural, but somehow, some way, it makes its point.
Mostly strong, that is, with the major exception of Tom Guiry's portrayal of Joe Jr. Painfully broad, Guiry practically sinks the film with garishly slack-jawed and over-the-top manchildishness.

Celestino's bid to wrap everything up in tidy fashion feels at odds with the grittiness of the film's first two-thirds, but in the end, the movie's glimpse into a seldom-seen slice of life sticks with you.
If you can watch Yonkers Joe without thinking it's a mild Rain Man rip-off, you'll enjoy a film that could have been plagued with plot issues, but rises above it
While Celestino doesn't roll snake eyes exactly, Yonkers Joe could have prospered if the filmmaker had worried more about keeping the dice hot and had let viewers' hearts warm naturally.
Yonkers Joe is incoherent, succeeding neither as an exciting gambling ride nor a touching family story.
As Janice, Christine Lahti is the pivot between father and son. The scenes between Janice and Joe Jr. are sweet, harrowing, movie-altering.

For all its attention to detail, Yonkers Joe isn't half as tough as it pretends to be. The real story of these bottom-feeders and the sad young man they exploit is a lot uglier than the movie even begins to let on.
A sweet and tidy neo-noir underworld thriller with a heart, thanks to excellent performances by the lead trio and a great setting in the seedy underworld of gambling con-artists.
Yonkers Joe is like a so-so trip to Vegas, one where you lose as much as you gain gambling. In other words, it's not the trip you're most likely to tell your friends about.
A nicely photographed, mostly satisfying look at a gang of East Coast sharps and how they part marks from their money.
Lahti burns through a thinly written role with a surprising level of warmth and humanity, and Guiry is at times repellently convincing as a kid genetically incapable of either nuance or fakery.

[Director] Celestino steers clear of the can't-miss pulp thriller that Yonkers Joe could've been, and goes for broke by giving it big dollop of schmaltz. His horse doesn't come in, but it runs a respectable race.
Heartfelt, well-acted but overly sincere drama of a smalltime hustler and the 20-year-old Down's syndrome son he's barely known.
The parts of Yonkers Joe that have to do with gambling are fun; unfortunately, they make up only half the movie.
An extremely awkward cross between Ocean's Eleven and Rain Man.
A very well-made and well-acted film, with a very touching story about fathers, sons, and the difficulties of raising special needs kids.

Leisurely paced at the outset, director Gilles Legrand builds a considerable head of emotional steam.
Great talent and a monstrous ego often come as a package deal, as illustrated by this insightful, taut 2011 drama set in Bordeaux.
Evoking a contemporary fable but unfolding like a thriller, You Will Be My Son is most of all a devastatingly realistic depiction of the festering resentments shared between a father and son.
Perfect for Christmas in the sense that you'll look on your own family a little more warmly after this one.
A classy, full-bodied family drama from Gallic scribe-helmer Gilles Legrand.
A kind of parable that is as much an effective portrait of intergenerational struggle as it is a slick psychological thriller with Shakespearian shadings.
For all of the director's willingness to explore his characters' unexpected depths, he's still hamstrung by his perpetually tasteful cinema-of-quality aesthetic.
As metaphors for life go, wine has a very high yield, and Gilles Legrand's sensitive screenplay tramples out every last drop of juice.
Gilles Legrand's draggy melodrama about miserable characters who persist in their folly and never wise up is strictly vin ordinaire.
This is a potent story about fathers and sons and filmmaker Gilles Legrand builds beautifully and devastatingly on this theme
Lustrous photography and a fine cast make this dark drama a compelling one.

A strongly acted, character-driven melodrama, concerned with the dynamics of family in general and father-son issues in particular, it presents situations so emotionally supercharged that the whole story could have come straight out of Balzac.
As elegantly made as the fine wines that fuel the narrative.
The parallel dramas underline the universal theme of primal jealousy, as fathers confront the prospect of their sons superseding them.
Father v son or father & son? A theme frequented by filmmakers, the father/son relationship is powerful terrain for drama and Gilles Legrand explores it with a fearless sensibility
It all ends in tears, bouquet'd with irony, wisdom and bleak comedy.
A compelling story of family dysfunction on a French vineyard is buoyed by an Oscar-worthy performance from Niels Arestrup.
Everything is explicit; no one makes an unexpected move.

How big the laughs are depends solely on your tastes, but there's little argument about whether they're dumb. But so were the 80s movies being referenced. That didn't make them any less guiltily enjoyable, and neither does it hurt Your Highness.
A textbook example of ye olde two-joke movie -- and beneath those two jokes, there's precious little else to fall back on.
If for you a combination of a medieval setting, plenty of sex jokes, dirty language & topless women makes for a funny movie, then Your Highness is for you (that's not necessarily a criticism).
[Green] has an easy touch when it comes to comedy, which means you can almost sense those moments when the actors give themselves over to the silliness.
Basically, the script, from the title on down, feels like something sketched out on rolling papers.
I feel a kind of head-swiveling awe in Your Highness's concentration of aimless inanity, in the purity of its devotion to its own louche principles.
Plays like second-rate Judd Apatow, and that's not exactly a high barrier to overcome.
This movie is so sophomoric, it makes Pineapple Express, and even Harold and Kumar, look like sophisticated wit.
Your Highness is a well-made but lowbrow period comedy with limited appeal.
Your Highness is actually a pretty good looking film. It just isn't very funny.
The movie's improvisatory recklessness often relies on stock, fallback comedy: scenes lazily punchlined on four-letter words, pot slang, and gay jokes only offensive in their unoriginality.
Monsters, sword-fights, boobs AND laughter? Giveth this a ruddy Bafta.
It sounds idiotic, and it is, but in a good way, if you get my drift.
...this weird, wacky, weedy medieval adventure ends up mostly putting the "R" back in romp.
When somebody says, "The quest sucks," I was inclined to agree.
The screenplay by Danny McBride is so hopeless, he didn't even write himself a good role, and he plays the lead.
As far as stoner comedies go, Your Highness might as well be smoking schwag with the Hooters bus boy you just bought it from.

Unwatchable -- and, thanks to its high-decibel action sequences, barely listenable -- this misbegotten medieval fantasy/stoner comedy marks a new low for David Gordon Green, once ranked among the most promising young filmmakers in America.
Fails to please as a comedy, but was fine as a low-budget adventure movie.
A cunning weave of low and high, regal and smutty, splendiferous and splattery.
Even at its most outrageously bizarre, Your Name is bound together by a passionately romantic core.
Even at its most baffling, Your Name maintains a visual style that approaches the grandeur of anime masters like Hayao Miyazaki.
Stunning but mature animated body-swapping love story.
An unmissable treat for animation fans.

Teen audiences in search of a "relatable" love story will find this every bit as accessible as Baz Luhrmann's Romeo + Juliet, while older viewers will delight in the way that archaic arts have become an integral part of 21st-century cinema.
For animation fanciers new to Shinkai, it could be the beginning of a beautiful relationship.
A brilliant science fiction story for devotees of traditional anime. [Full review in Spanish]
Shinkai creates a gorgeous, richly detailed look at two sides of Japan... Shinkai's gift for melding these two Japans into a single, luminous story is what gives Your Name its exquisite tension.

The movie's spirit is by turns energetic and serene, impetuous and wise, its wild shifts from comedy to tragedy to romance revealing themselves not as tonal swings so much as variations in a larger cosmic pattern.
One of the most poignant responses to a natural catastrophe that Japanese cinema has offered in the wake of the 2011 earthquake and tsunami.
Unforgettable; to miss 'Your Name' is inexcusable.
What starts with a brightly coloured pop leaves behind a powder trail of loveliness.
Two lovers transcending time and space to connect is an inspiring story no matter what country you hail from.

You may have to fortify your illogicality tolerance when viewing the anime adventure "Your Name." But this body-swap romance by the exciting and talented filmmaker Makoto Shinkai is nonetheless exquisite, beautiful and entertaining.
Your Name is a stirring tale of rescue with a boisterous edge of YA mischief. It's also a love story with a swoony romantic affinity for the age-old tussle between chance and fate.
With its balance of grounded emotion and wondrous escapism, Your Name should firmly establish Shinkai as an auteur to follow for many years to come.
The vital second half feels ponderous and over-blown, and the eventual explanation too complex for its own good.
While Your Name's story is dubious, it doesn't disappoint. One of the standout features from London Film Festival, and one of the best animated features this year.
At least it's ambitious, even if it doesn't quite nail it on the cogent entertainment front.
A film that will make you laugh, cry and will make your day happier. [Full review in Spanish]
Even if you already live on the Upper West Side, you might feel the urge to move there before the film is over.
If you thought Hanks and Ryan were endearing in their previous teamings in 'Sleepless In Seattle' and 'Joe Versus the Volcano,' you ain't seen nothing yet.
There's no serious problem that would keep me from recommending the movie, but if you want a more organized, more serious, more humorous and more organic film, watch the similar Sleepless In Seattle.
Ryan and Hanks have more winning smiles than most people have expressions!
You've Got Mail is a relentlessly practical movie, big business versus little business, strangers touching over the internet versus real life volatility.
Seasonal to the max, You've Got Mail is a paradigm of product placement, packaged good cheer and innocuous irony.
You've Got Mail is a timely romance for this impersonal, computer-driven decade.
What a sparkling, sweet treat! It's the most romantic movie of the holiday season.
Crisp plot and smart and funny dialogue.
Charmless and hokey!
As warm and cozy as a cuddle under a favorite old quilt.
Impeccably inane!
Warm, smart, and funny!
Another problem is chemistry; remarkably, Hanks and Ryan haven't any until the last few scenes.
It's a feel-good movie that offers enough comedy and romance to warm the heart without risking a sentimental overdose.
That Joe is smug, oily and a ruthless destroyer of small businesses, while Kathleen intolerably twee, makes for some rough sledding that the combined star power of Ryan and Hanks doesn't ameliorate.
Structural elegance is not the hallmark of Mail; neither is depth of insight into the nature of role playing, love, and identity.
It is chock full of Nora Ephron's perfect writing.
Delightful and uplifting, You've Got Mail is light as a souffle fresh from the oven.
It's handsome, professional moviemaking all around, just a little flat when it ought to soar.
It goes through all the usual celebratory motions but, without giving away too many secrets, suggests that nothing satisfied him enough - in fact, quite a lot made him suicidal.

[F]ans of fashion will delight over the subject, especially those who love the gay-outsider-who-makes-it theme. In The Devil Wears Prada, it took Stanley Tucci one scene to nail it, while this film's still searching at 103 minutes.
Satisfying in its insight into the relationship between creativity, temperament, and (no small consideration) wealth.

Not the first documentarian to examine Saint Laurent's life, this affectionate and frustrating film is essentially a deconstruction of the aesthetic life of this true visionary as defined by the art he collected.
Berg's memories of Saint Laurent are distant and sanitized, which is reasonable given that he is recalling a deceased friend and lover, but they don't make for the most exciting cinema.

Saint Laurent, in archival footage, comes across as an engaging fellow, deeply shy and sensitive, often smiling but without much of a gift for happiness - someone who started out beautiful but whose pain eventually showed up on his face.
...a study in mortality, sadness, and the transience of beauty.
It's a fairly circumspect affair, though Berg talks frankly of his partner's alcoholism, drug-taking and terrible bouts of depression.
A flat and uninvolving documentary about Yves Saint Laurent.

L'Amour Fou is somehow intimate without being terribly revealing. It suffers from an overdose of elegance, and a desire to preserve a bit of the great man's dignity, ...but, like his work, it's only a beautiful drapery.
"L'Amour Fou" sometimes trudges along with little insight into the genius of Saint Laurent.
A biographical documentary tribute to Yves Saint-Laurent and his accomplishments. But, told primarily from the perspective of Saint-Laurent's grieving partner, it's sadder than it is celebratory.
"L'Amour Fou" is an elegant fabric without the rough texture of real life and love.
A true must-see if you adore fashion, interior design, the Sixties and Seventies, travel, and an exploration of depressed genius with guest appearances by Andy Warhol and Mick Jagger.
To suggest, as this oblique film does, that you are what you collect is like looking at Picasso's art collection without correlating it to his own works.
Perched somewhere between a sanded-edged official portrait and a keen examination of affluence run amok.
Appearances by Andy Warhol and Mick Jagger punctuate this lovingly-told life story, but it's really the love and admiration of Berg√© that says the most about this fascinating man.
Those looking for YSL drama and passion are more likely to find it in a department store rather than in a movie theater.
Having opened with the promise of something raw and intimate, "L'Amour Fou" ends with a feeling that everything was orchestrated to prevent revealing anything.
"I don't have a soul," Berg laments as a Brancusi sculpture is packed away. "These objects don't have a soul." Neither does this movie.
Has the potential to become a minor hit on the midnight film circuit with the help of a mid-level indie distributor.
Certainly not on the scale of a Romero, but at least these filmmakers paid some attention in zombie class.
Zombies of Mass Destruction attempts to use its familiar genre elements in the service of a post-9/11 political satire...unfortunately, the jokes fall flat, and the horror never hits a nerve.
Kevin Hamedani's muddy, heavy-handed parody of War on Terror paranoia doesn't vary much from genre formula, but it does serve up political correctness with refreshingly bad taste.
Once the extreme gore hits, the buckets of corn syrupy splatter and one liners don't stop (fans of Evil Dead and Dead Alive will be very, very happy).
There is so much stupid fun in Zoolander 2, the movie practically dares you not to laugh. Don't take that bet. But don't miss the movie.
A thorough disappointment.
The story is beside the point in this pointless movie; it's less tasteless and offensive than the original, but just as god-awful.

Zoolander 2 seems like the result of a 15-year game of "exquisite corpse," the surrealist exercise where different writers add to a story independent of each other, strand by strand, without full knowledge of previous contributions.
Directed by [Ben] Stiller, the work is serviceable but not outstanding, save for the film serving as a compact travelogue for Rome.
Yes, it's ridiculous. It's supposed to be.
Derek Zoolander and company have definitely fallen out of fashion.
It's unbelievable that Ben Stiller decided to end his good directing streak with this poor excuse of a joke. [Full review in Spanish]
A goofy gag machine that will raise smiles for some and make others just plain gag.
Disappoints in all the ways you expect it to, coasting by on catchphrases and cameos and not much else.

The stakes are higher, the action is bigger, the ambitions are grander, the jokes are appreciably less funny. Like many comedy sequels, "Zoolander 2" supersizes everything so that it's that much more apparent how few of the jokes are connecting.
In its sequel, the jokes, if you can call them that, are trying way too hard.
...instead of capturing the heart and charm of the original, this absolutely unnecessary sequel just comes off as a giant mess that should have never made it off the writer's table.
To even attempt an explanation of the over-arching narrative would be rather pointless -- mainly because, there isn't one.
It's a hit and miss hour-and-a-half that lacks the charm of the first movie, but Zoolander 2 raises just enough chuckles to justify Derek's return to the big screen.
Some people find Derek Zoolander funny and likable and endearingly dumb. I don't. I find him grating.
Silly and stupid, but reasonably entertaining if you just sit back and accept it for what it is.
The warmed over humor is a tired one-trick pony that spit the bit barely 15 minutes into the original.
Painful to watch in how many jokes and gags land with a thud (like a bad "SNL" skit that goes on and on). (Full Content Review for Parents - Sex, Violence, Profanity, etc. - Also Available)
Funnier than any terrible movie has any right to be.
